Cheap and delicious. Fat home made corn tortillas topped with a generous serving of shrimp ceviche made from marinated raw shrimp vs pre-cooked. The shrimp are still a bit grey but fully cooked from the acidity of the lime. 

Accompanied with delicious pickled red onions and carrots. 

Fish taco. Battered, fried, crispy light and delicious upon the plump hand made corn tortilla. 

Hole in the wall spot. Dingy but Delicious. Customers include dirtbag smelling kids in dreads and polished white folks in reading glasses.  Cheap, excellently prepared food appeals to all.", "I have been here many a time, and share this place with out of town company. The location is a (now) orange house configured into small dining areas with tables on 6th. I last went with a party of six and it took some doing to collect together two tables and 6 chairs; the space doesn't lend itself to large groups.   I love their horchata and fish tacos. Usually the food is served on styrofoam trays, plastic utensils and come with a side a pickled onions and carrots/veg.  My 8 year old nephew got a chicken quesadilla and everyone one else got different types of tacos per our recommendation. Every visit I get their pico de gallo cup which this visit had mango, pineapple, watermelon and coconut; which they will top with lime juice and chile salt unless you don't want it. I lOVE it.

My aunt and uncle, sister and nephew came from out of state; we all agreed it was a fine meal despite a wait for our order.  On this visit when entering I saw on the outside of the building a list of fresh drinks prepared including limonada; I was excited thinking this was new and ordered it, only to be told NOT TODAY. They often have large white buckets of prepared drink on the counter and you have to look on the counter to know what the offerings will be, despite my excitement to see posted flavors painted on the outside of the building...you get what you get and you don't throw a fit. That day it was jamaica drink and horchata. The restroom situation at Taqueria Pico de Gallo is OK;  one small room with a sink, toilet and urinal for the mens (per my husband)and one room with a sink, mirror and toilet for the women's. I have always found them to be clean, stocked and met my needs. 

Overall this is place to enjoy good food in a casual setting. My only other comment is generally the staff doesn't speak fluent english and so during this visit my sister was wanting to change her completed order and the cashier didn't understand or ignored her and proceeded to take the next customers order. This upset my sister, but at the same time it is what it is. Living in Tucson I'm used to it.", "I hate to give such a low star rating to one of Tucson's classic taquerias, but I have no choice. PICO how can I give you more stars when you serve up a taco with chicken that looked and tasted old; it had the crumbly texture of chicken you would find in a chicken fried rice from a dumpy Chinese restaurant. The Carne Asada was all fat.  Your Salsa squeeze bottles were basically empty, and when I asked for another one at the counter I was handed another almost empty! And the bottles were marked with salsa handprints, most likely from several days of being reused and not washed. 

For several years you had my heart and it breaks my Corazon to say this, but Adios PICO, I don't think i'll be back for a while."]

name: Gigi and Big R
categories_raw: Restaurants, Food, Caribbean, Food Trucks
top_reviews:
["I've said it before and I'll say it again: One of the most pathetic feelings in life is running for a bus with your big dumb bag and seeing that bus pull away. So close, so close... Oh I've been there and I've vowed never to be that particular feeb again.

I was reminding myself of this very promise to myself the other day when I saw Gigi and Big R's food truck parked outside of 30th Street Station. I was already on the verge of being late for that accursed megabus to NYC, but I still found myself tempted to stop for some of this truck's Caribbean stylins. 

NO. I had to put my foot down with me. You know why? Cause if runnin late for a bus with your big dumb bag is pitiful, nearly missing a bus, running with luggage and a styrofoam container heavy with fried flaky white fish, rice & beans, cabbage, and plenty of hot sauce shakings is even more risky business. But I WAS tempted, cause that was some good cookin there. I mean, I thought about it.

We had split that hefty platter when we encountered Gigi and Big R at the Mann Center in September. The deal was kinda pricey at about $15, but I will say that they did give you plenty. We shared it in the rain, under an umbrella on the lawn: Crispy fish fried in long strips, tender sauteed down cabbage, rice and beans, and hot sauce. 

See, that would be a nice lunch for you on the bus, if you indeed made it, except that everyone would want to murder you dead for fillin the bus with the delectable smells, and for enjoying your life or whatever. Yeah, you can't be eating on the bus. I reminded myself of that fact too. That's another thing.  What everyone on the bus has in common with each other is that they inherently loathe everyone else on the bus. Why? I can't tell you, but damn don't it seem to be so. On my way back from NYC one time some cat brought on the bus with him some dirty water dogs from a cart. You could feel the hate for him grow every time he pulled another one outta the brown bag. Like, the nerve...who does he think he is?

So yeah, I wanted that fried fish platter, alright. I wanted it. I'll get it the next time that I'm not running late for the bus. Plan ahead, sister.", "I had GiGi and Big R at the Made in America Festival.

Whilst traveling from stage to stage you encounter your food trucks, your beer stands and promo booths.

GiGi's truck stood out almost immediately.

Aside from the crazy long line, there's the menu.

Amongst a plethora of what I'll call carnival or boardwalk food.. The thought of big food platters of jerk chicken, oxtail and fried chicken was like a blessing!

The prices were damn reasonable considering what other places charged.

Servings are grandma sized, like how you'd expect your nana to throw down a plate for you, so it's a ton of food.

The line was crazy, we sat on this line for near an hour and we fought and pushed out way to the front to get to this group of tired but smiling group of 4 women serving food.

I had the oxtail, rice and beans, Mac and cheese.

Hot damn. So good. I got transported back to the West Indies for a quick second.

The sounds of the concert drowned out. The clouds stopped moving. Time stopped.

All I was tasting was the delicious strewed meat, perfect rice and devilish mac and cheese.

Right then and there it hit me. Only in America can we have these experiences.

A Vietnamese dude with his British-Indian wife, sitting on the grass amongst a sea of people, listening to Meek Mill (R.I.P. btw #backtoback) and eating oxtail. 

Made in America.", 'My friends ... can I call you friends?  It was hot ... the steam was rushing off the blades of grass along the campus of the University of Pennsylvania enveloping those walking Philadelphia's streets with another layer of unneeded moisture.  It was high noon, the curbsides littered with aluminum shelters and colorful delivery trucks providing pedestrians with a global array of aromas.

My chosen mission, after bidding a friend with a temporary residency at U of Penn's hospital adieu, was the discovery of a quality lunch of distinction from amidst the array of options.

No, I did not desire a lengthy searching process but after smelling, staring and snooping along the streets I discovered the right choice on a very hot day!

An extensive menu with small and large plate options greeted me as did a clear path to the truck's open window.  Ahh tropical heat ... I needed the islands JERK was the answer and as my head inched its way into the window I could smell mouth watering delights.

My "man" in the truck was losing pounds by the moment in the heat but his greeting was warm.  The conversation between strangers friendly and he smiled at my choices ... JERK chicken, which he affirmed by saying "you are going to really like it," some sweet yams and greens.

I watched him scoop my very large lunch (I ordered small) into the styro box and it looked oh so good!  The money exchange didn't hurt my wallet either.

It was ungodly hot outside so to enjoy my meal I returned to the confines of the hospital's air conditioned lobby to indulge!

He was right ... I really loved the bite of the jerk seasonings that had me licking my fingers in public!  The greens and yam combo was awesome! I wanted more even though this delicious lunch filled me (And, there was no way I was walking back on those hot sweaty streets!).

So where is Star #5?  Well, as others have noted the chicken was a bit tough and warm not hot.  A curse related to food truck cooking where the food awaits the diner versus being freshly prepared in the kitchen.  Minor complaint because next time I am on Philly's hot streets at lunch time in close proximity to food truck heaven I will be looking for another visit at this kitchen on four wheels!']

name: O Sole Mio
categories_raw: Food, Seafood, Sardinian, Gelato, Restaurants, Pizza, Italian
top_reviews:
["This is the kind of pizza I would drive all over town for, trying to find the best slice...whether: capofitto (RIP), Stella, Vetri, pizza brain, etc. I No longer have to do this since this place opened up in my neighborhood!! Yay!! So long other pizza places. I don't need you. 
And the service is hands down AMAZING! The owner is so sweet and accommodating. 
I really enjoyed this pizza. It was exactly what I wanted and the service was beyond outstanding. 
It was New Year's day and pretty much everything was closed. By the time we had some time to ourselves after my sister's kids were asleep we realized we all still needed to eat dinner for adults and too tired to cook. 
3 minutes to closing, we hoped beyond all hope that they would take our silly little pizza order. He was SO happy to stay and make one more pizza and said to come by in 5 minutes. I apparently didn't know how to order my sister's favorite pizza and so as we got there my sister was in full blown panic that there wasn't tomato sauce on it. Well the owner again said no problem as he was just preparing our pizza dough and so we got exactly what both my sister and I wanted. 
The wood fired brick oven was exactly the blazing temperature to get the pie perfectly flash fired for the perfect crust. The sauce was amazing and the cherry tomatoes on the margarita pizza popped and exploded. Delicious fresh mozza and basil. 
Man that was the perfect pizza.
I've never been so happy to meet someone who loves to stay open on a holiday to feed the neighborhood and has amazing pizza.", 'Was looking for some Italian takeout Saturday night and had seen this place months prior when dining outdoors at Mari BYO, now closed (sad face emoji). 

They've got literally everything, which can be a tad overwhelming: wood-fired pizzas and wings, hoagies, strombolis and calzones, pasta, chicken, seafood, sides, apps, etc. 

BF got the wood-fired BBQ wings and the Mimosa Pizza (ham, corn, basil) and I got the Linguine Pescatore in white butter sauce, which comes with mussels, clams and shrimp, and a side Caesar salad.

Overall, everything was tasty (the mussels were my favorite!) but nothing stood out as fantastic, especially since the similar pescatore dish at Mari is still one of my favorite bang-for-your-buck meals in the city and is so light and delicate. The seafood was plentiful and fresh, but the broth was way salty.

The pizza had interesting toppings/flavor combinations, but was VERY thin/floppy (even for Napoli style) and also only 14" as the largest size, and at approx. $18 I'm not sure it was worth it. BF did say his wings were excellent. If portions were a bit larger perhaps I would order again, but there's a million other Italian joints to try.

Staff was very friendly, though.', "My boyfriend and I were visiting from out of state, my brother and his wife who live here. They both have heard good things about the restaurant but had not stopped in yet until tonight. They're sold and we'll be coming back next time we visit! It's BYOB.. (I have never seen that before so I was caught off thinking it was a funny but it really is bring your own beer!) We were sat downstairs in quaint little area, the lighting was a little dark but overall not bad. Our server was BRAND new I believe it was her first night and she did so amazing! She had not tried anything on the menu yet, we appreciated her honesty, but she knew all the ingredients and information about the food either everything we asked her. She was very tentative to our table and we got an extra order of their bread with oil/vinegar...it's hard to have one serving it's way too good. We ordered three pizzas; cheese, a sweet type (it had honey on it), then one with kalomata olives and pepperoni I believe. (I'm sorry I don't remember the names of the pizzas!) but the one with honey was the best and I highly recommend it. The chef then came out with a 4th pizza, he said that he had overcooked our cheese pizza so he remade us one. We didn't even say anything or expect them to do that, we were still eating it anyway. The service was so nice, it was very nice of them and everything was delicious. Please go check them out!! Plus when you check in on yelp there's a discount ;) enjoy!"]

name: Zeko's Mediterranean Grill
categories_raw: Restaurants, Falafel, Fast Food, Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, Halal, Greek
top_reviews:
["Visited on a Sunday afternoon for meat free bite. I wanted to order a lot of items from the menu but since it was my first time at Zeko's I decided to take it easy & only ordered a Falafal wrap, fries & hummus. The falafal was moist & tasty & I enjoyed the warm pita & crispy fries. The hummus was the highlight - smooth & rich. The drive through was fairly fast with friendly staff.", 'I have been to this Zeko before but have not try their chicken wing. Zeko is a Mediterranean restaurant. They have variety menu. From vegetarian to meat kabab. Their extensive menu includes Greek salad, falafel, fried seafood including shrimp and fish, different kind of shake, beef and lamb kabab, gyro, shawarma, chicken sandwich and wings. 

The restaurant operate like fast food fashion. Order at counter and ready to pick up. After 8:30 pm, most order are take out. I got the honey BBQ wings. The wings is fried and toss over the BBQ sauce. The wing value is $1 a piece is at the average in the Bay Area. Toss sauce with fried wing is not my most favorite. They are just average. 

Overall experience is good. It is definitely better than the fast food in Busch garden.', "Zeko's was a delightful find located right across Busch Boulevard from Busch Gardens. The restaurant serves Greek, Mediterranean, and Middle Eastern cuisine in a large white building with a very active drive-through business. Zeko's is part of a small chain with locations in St. Pete, Bradenton, Temple Terrace, New Tampa, Brandon, Riverview, as well as this location on Busch Boulevard.

From the outside the neighborhood isn't the nicest, and I don't think that I'd make a point of driving to Zeko's in the middle of the night, although the drive-through window is open till 4 in the morning. Nonetheless, the food is extremely good and very affordable.

The menu has gyros, hummus, falafel, shawerma, and kabobs, along with wings, fried shrimp and fish, burgers, and also salads including fattoush and tabbouleh, as well as  Greek salads.

The folks behind the counter were super friendly and happy to answer questions about the menu.

I ordered a traditional lamb gyro with a Greek salad, and was amazed at the size and the quality of the food which only cost about $10. The pita bread was stuffed with so much sliced gyro meat that I couldn't close the sandwich, so I used a fork and knife to cut everything up and mix it into the salad. The Greek salad was huge, and included big slices of feta cheese along with a stuffed grape leave and Greek Kalamata olives.

Very delicious, and well worth additional visits!"]

name: Persian Room Fine Dining
categories_raw: Restaurants, Persian/Iranian, Mediterranean
top_reviews:
["My husband and I have been to the Persian Room in Scottsdale many times. We were so happy to learn that they were opening a restaurant here! 

The interior is absolutely stunning so as soon as you step through the doors, you are immediately surrounded by beauty.

We came here with 2 other couples and everyone absolutely LOVED their meals.  One couple had never had Persian cuisine and they said they can't wait to come again. Everyone ordered something different and each entree was superb. 

There is something for everyone - vegan, vegetarian and meat dishes. The portions are huge so you will be taking food home and having another meal later.  The food is fresh and superb quality.

They offer a full bar and a great wine selection too.

This is the nicest restaurant in Tucson and I am so happy that they are close to my home (although I would drive across town to dine here as it is that good)!!!

Try it, you will not be disappointed!", "I've eaten at the original Scottsdale location several years ago and enjoyed it very much. I finally  made it to the Tucson location, although this time for takeout, due to COVID. The dining room is open, but I have stuck with takeout during the pandemic. We place our order over the phone, although it looks like you can order from Yelp as well! For our group of four people we ordered the Yogurt & Cucumber Dip (Mast O khiar)-
Homemade yogurt with chopped cucumber and mint. Shirazi Salad-
Diced tomatoes, onions, cucumbers, and chopped parsley with fresh lime, lemon juice and olive oil dressing. And the Tour of Persia platter which is a 
combination of barg, cornish, koobideh and gheymeh bademjan served with Zereshk polo and Basmati rice. The menu states is serves three people but it more than enough food  for four people. We had leftovers for the following day. The food was packaged and sealed very well. Everything traveled well in the car and was still warm when we got home. The house-made flat bread is one of those items that is best enjoyed dining at Persian Room. The combination of the fresh herbs (cilantro, basil, mint), raw onion and butter is so unique and really good! I look forward to enjoying that in the near future. 

If you're comfortable with dining inside, it appeared that they had a lot of spacing between tables. For takeout, we only had to wait a few minutes for our food. Everyone we encountered was very pleasant and friendly.  5-stars for great customer service and food!", 'I am soo excited that Tucson has a high quality Persian restaurant. It's in an odd location, almost like a strip mall, but when you walk in, there are chandeliers and a beautiful ceiling that is painted to look like the sky. The decor is very traditional with Persian style art and images reminiscent of the ancient city Persepolis. The high-backed, floral dining chairs look like all my cousin's dining rooms in Iran. They also make their own flatbread there in front of you, which is AMAZING, so it comes out warm. In short, it's comfortingly authentic but in a way that is a bit fancy. 

The menu and food here is top-notch Persian cuisine that rivals most of the places in LA. I want to take all my friends here and show them all my favorite Persian dishes. If you were my friends, here is a list of my favorite dishes that I would suggest for anyone who has not tried Persian (or just anyone who likes good food):

Mast O Mousir, a creamy, tangy, savory yoghurt dip made with shallots and garlic with berries on top that add just a little sweetness. This is a delicious appetizer to dip your bread in but also tastes great mixed with rice or put on any of the meats. 

Kash o Bademjan, this is my very favorite appetizer, I even served it at my wedding. It is mostly roasted eggplant that is mixed with whey, garlic, & onions. When done wrong, it can be overly mushy. At the Persian Room, they do it better than anyone. Better than my Iranian grandma, shh don't tell her. The  ratio of eggplant to whey is spot on. Then they drizzle whey on top with crispy onions and shallots. Oh it's so good! I also put this on my bread, meat and rice. 

Kebab. Every single one of the kebab's are delicious from the Cornish hen (lemony!), the extensive options of lamb, the juicy chicken to the tender steak. However the classic is the ground beef kebab koobideh. It is juicy, tender, full of spices and flavor and always cooked to the right temperature, cooked on long flat skewers so it slides off in one piece. My husband and I like to order one entree plate of koobideh, which comes with two skewers and then add one extra skewer so we have just enough for leftovers but not more rice than we can handle. Now, it may not be the best etiquette, but we like to take the bread, put a piece of meat in it, some of the herbs or a little onion from the sabzy plate (sabzy means greens), dip it in the yoghurt and/or eggplant and then wrap it and eat it like a taco. You'll thank me later. 

I also recommend everyone has hot, black tea on the side, with just a few sugar cubes. You wouldn't believe how well it pairs with everything and it's not an authentic experience without it. If you're feeling adventurous, try the "homemade yoghurt drink" called doogh, a salty, savory, cold, minty, sometimes carbonated yoghurt drink. It's so nice to find somewhere that makes it homemade, instead of in a bottle. It's like a savory lassi. It's incredibly refreshing but can be an acquired taste. 

And for dessert, you must try Persian ice cream. It tastes like saffron, rose water and pistachio. It often has little bits of frozen cream in it, which sounds weird, but it's a heavenly surprise. 

That's it, now you can have a near-transcendental Persian cuisine experience too, thanks to the Persian Room finally bringing this food of the Gods to Tucson.']

name: The 81 Hong Kong Cafe
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Asian Fusion, Food, Bubble Tea, Hong Kong Style Cafe, Taiwanese, Restaurants, Chinese
categories: ['coffee & tea', 'asian fusion', 'food', 'bubble tea', 'hong kong style cafe', 'taiwanese', 'restaurants', 'chinese']
top_reviews:
["What what? I can get Taiwanese food in Tucson and bubble tea all in the same place? YES!! As soon as I saw the menu I knew I had to try this place out. If you are ordering to go it's easy to place your order online but be aware there's a $1.50 extra convenience fee vs. ordering by phone. 

We got the oyster omelette, mixed vegetables and three cup chicken. I also got a Hong Kong milk tea and mint mojito latte. It was ready at the expected time and packaged very well.

The oyster omelette was gigantic! I think it's the largest portion of this dish I've had yet. It tasted pretty much like how I remember other incarnations of this dish have been with the exception of the sauce. This sauce was more savory than sweet which I think worked better with the other flavors in the omelette. There were a good number of oysters in it. 

The mixed vegetables were good, but consisted mainly of cheaper priced broccoli and cabbage with just a few chunks of baby bok choy. It was well cooked and seasoned but I'd probably skip this dish next time at $10.

The three cup chicken was probably my favorite dish that we ordered. It had just the right balance of sweet and savory, served in a large plastic container filled with bone in chicken and fried basil. 

The Hong Kong milk tea was alright. It had a light sweetness and I liked the flavor of the tea but was a bit watery rather than milk infused compared to other HK milk teas I've had. The mint mojito latte was OK as well. I liked that they had fresh mint leaves in the drink but the mint flavor clashed with the coffee flavor to me.", "We will absolutely be coming back here! The chicken bites are out of this world; perfectly peppery and crispy til the last bite. The scallion cake was everything I wanted it to be; crispy on the outside, chewy on the inside, and perfectly filled. But my absolute favorite dish that I will order every time I come here is the hot & sour soup. Just enough spice to feel it, tangy enough to offset the heat, great balance of ingredients and perfect texture. If you're even remotely debating this place, I highly suggest you make the stop. Plus they do to go orders, so you can call ahead or order online for a very easy pickup option.", 'Hong Kong cafe reminded my partner of growing up, his family is from Hong Kong and Hawaii and he loved this restaurant.  The staff were friendly and helpful and the place was very clean with a modern design. They followed all COVID protocols, we are both fully vaccinated so we were not worried but it was greatt to see.

We started with the Green tea and mango boba matcha latte and found them delicious.  The green tea was bright and tasted a bit of lemon and possibly jasmine or other floral notes. The boba drink was a perfect blend of the sweet mango and more floral and bitter matcha cut with milk. The staff kept the water and tea refilled and would regularly checkin to see how we were doing.

Our main dishes were bento, the steak and fish.  Both were huge dishes and delicious.  The steak was tender with a slightly sweet sauce that reminded him of the steak he grew up on from his grandma from Hong Kong.  It had a perfectly fried egg and a large amount of rice.

The second dish was the fish bento which had a crispy, again not greasy, fry and was topped with a sweet corn sauce.  It also had some bok choy and the friend egg.  The sweet corn was a great foil to the fried fish and brought out the natural sweetness in the fish. Both dishes were beautifully presented with the rice holding a great bowl shape.

The layered pudding desert was wonderful! We had tarp and mango and loved the blend of the two flavors. Like the drinks and meal, the desert was not too sweet so we loved it. We will definitely be back and bring friends!!!!']

name: Saguaro National Park
categories_raw: Active Life, Parks
top_reviews:
['Along the mountain ridges,
\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 Across the desert floor;
\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 Arms like verdant armor,
\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 Stalwarts guard our door.
Shading for the lizard,
\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 Haven for the wren,
\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 Source of inspiration,
\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 For past and present men.
⁠--Earl Bloss, "Saguaros," in\xa0Arizona Highways, March 1973



This should be your first stop when visiting Suguaro National Park WEST. It's a typical NPS Visitors Center with all the usual amenities and a nice bonus feature:

-Rangers to help guide you to the hikes you want and pick-up maps of the park. 

-Gift shop

-NPS Passport Stamp location

-Pay your entrance fees here (see below)

-Amazing orientation video on how the Native people see the saguaro⁠--this is a must-see! Seriously. Well worth the 15min if your time. 

-Water refill station that pumps out cool water

-Clean restrooms


Entrance Fees:

Saguaro National Park Vehicle Weekly Pass\xa0-\xa0$20.00
Admits one single, private, non-commercial vehicle or RV and all its passengers. Organized groups are not eligible for the vehicle permit.

Saguaro National Park Individual Weekly Pass\xa0-\xa0$10.00
Admits one individual when entering by foot or bicycle. Individuals 15 years or younger are admitted free of charge.

Saguaro National Park Motorcycle Weekly Pass\xa0-\xa0$15.00
Admits one motorcycle and its riders.', "I have been wanting to visit this park for quite a while. Prior to COVID19 hitting the country, my hubby and I were able to take a trip for my birthday. 

The park is located in Tucson, Arizona and exists on two sides of town. There is Saguaro East and Saguaro West. We looked at both sides on a map and decided to head to the west side. The park ranges in elevation from 2,180 feet in the low lying Tucson Mountains to 8,666 foot Mica Mountains in the Rincon Mountains.  Lots of interesting animals like javelinas, white nose coati's, and evening black bears way up high.

Be sure to take Gates Pass Road as your route to this side of the park. This drive is epic and absolutely magical, filled with luscious green Saguaro's. In case you didn't know, the Saguaro cactus is one of my favorite cactus so I was over the moon excited.

We arrived at the visitor center so we could pay our entrance fee and grab a map, then off we went to drive to our trailhead. 

For those people who aren't hikers, both sides of the park provide roads designed for sightseeing. Remember to share the road with cyclists.

After some off-road driving we arrived at our trailhead. We decided to hike Wasson Peak via the Sendero Esperanza trail which hooked up with the Hugh Norris trail to the top. This was a beautiful trail, very well maintained. So many Saguaros everywhere, one could just get lost amongst these giants! The Saguaro's grow very slowly, only an inch or so during the first 6 to 8 years. They reach full height 40-50 feet at about age 150 years!! They can also grow up to 15 arms and generally die if old age. 

Once we made it to the top, the views were 360 degrees. We could see the Catalina Mountains, Picacho Peak in the distance and the Rincon Mountains. The park is located in the Tucson Mountains.  It was a little chilly up there at the top but so worth it. We took our time coming down and stopped often to take in the pleasing scenery. The park is so vast and open. 

There are several other trails which take you deeper into the park with less people. No pets allowed on the trails which I was very happy about so no dog poop to avoid! 

The west side of the park also features petroglyphs located at Signal Hill picnic area. 

With time not on our side, we only were able to hike a small portion of the park, but we plan to return to hike more of the west and also a peak or two on the east side. 

Total mileage: 7.5 miles RT
Elevation gain: 1643 feet

I highly recommend a trip to and through this park if you enjoy the exquisite beauty of the state of AZ!", 'Tucson, AZ:  Sonoran Desert immersion, YESS!

First time visiting. Despite the forecast in 90sF, and a late start, we loved our drive along the eight mile, paved Cactus Forest Drive. Limited pullouts and parking along this road. Too hot for hiking but the scenery is outstanding for the rich variety of local cacti and wildflowers, set against the Rincon Mountains. The unique Saguaro Cactus is only found in the Sonoran Desert.

The Visitors Center is located outside the park gate with free parking. Wonderful short video, and informative displays provide an overview of the park. Rangers available to answer any questions. A must stop for visitors visiting Tucson.']

name: Olly
categories_raw: Pizza, Food, Bagels, Sandwiches, Comfort Food, Breakfast & Brunch, Burgers, American (New), Nightlife, Bars, Wine Bars, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["I was pleasantly surprised by my dinner at Olly on Tuesday night! I'd heard some good things, and was expecting a nice meal, but dinner absolutely exceeded my expectations. The space is really cozy and inviting; there aren't too many tables so be sure to make a reservation if you want to eat in the dining room!

My friend and I shared a bottle of sparking water which was fine, but I would love to see some inventive non-alcoholic options on the menu (currently they have iced tea and soda). 

The food was awesome, and our server was fantastic. We started with buffalo cauliflower which was much lighter than what I was expecting. Here, you could actually taste the cauliflower, and the sprinkling of blue cheese was a nice addition. Next, we had the mushroom carpaccio, which was delicious! It was spread over the plate with some mixed greens and had a hearty sprinkling of parmesan. 

My friend chose the gnudi for her main (really nice!) while I went with the special of the day, a cod and clam chowder. This dish was hearty and loaded with delicious veggies and tons of flavor. Such a perfect cold weather meal! 

We couldn't resist dessert and had the chocolate tart and apple crisp. The tart was definitely my favorite; it was super rich and came with the most fantastic whipped cream and a caramel sauce that was phenoms. Loved it! 

Scrolling through my insta last night, I saw a photo of some really bomb-looking margherita pizza. Turns out, also from the folks behind Olly! They just opened a concept called Gigi Pizza, which you can access through Olly or a separate door on Bainbridge. Planning my visit!", "Olly was not 'A-OK.' It was alright. 

I was here to sample a tasting menu. The group (it was mostly twosomes and foursomes) was informed that everything on the menu were things in regular rotation at Olly and also things that the chef felt best showcased the restaurant's style. 

Chris D'Ambro, the chef, came out between courses to talk about what was just served as well as general chit chat. He seems like a very enthusiastic, down to earth, 'every guy' type man who really enjoys what he does. And so he must with 2 other restaurants-Southwark and Ambra- to his name. 

The tasting event hostess, not associated with the restaurant and whose name I did not get (and if I had, I'd want to have forgotten it) treated the room like she was Sister Strict Nun and we were all unruly charges. When she wanted to talk, she would ring a loud chime and then comment on how 'good' or 'not good' everyone was in quickly ceasing conversation in order to hear her blab. By the end of the evening, I wanted to throw a pitcher of ice water on her and suggest she go back to the imaginary convent to do penance for her lack of social grace. Again-please note-she is not an employee of Olly.

The venue is a corner location, small, bright (lots of windows) and full of plants and knick knacks. The colors are restfully neutral but the acoustics are horrible. Kalaya, also a new kid on a block not too far from Olly, is the same as far as having a space that holds unmitigated, high level noise. I shared a table with 7 other diners and by the second course, even those of us sitting right next to each other were shouting and straining to hear the person on either side. Maybe that is the new trend in small South Philly restaurants. It does not make for a relaxing dining experience. 

The tasting started with hush puppies filled with corn and shrimp. I found them dry with one corn kernel and nothing else (not a speck of crustacean) in the several I ate. They were served with a side of quartered lemons. The juice from the citrus was all that made them moist. They were served with aioli but not enough of it. Not at all greasy or heavy but not worth the calories, either. My fellow diner took one bite of hers and left the rest. Enough said. 

Following those bites came charred pole beans in a black pepper vinaigrette with pecorino cheese and basil. I just don't like beans. These needed a lot more char and a lot less pepper. The starch of the beans and the heat of the black pepper was all I could taste. The occasional bite of basil was refreshing but not enough to save the dish.

The shining course of the evening was charred broccoli ceasar salad. It was supposed to have chicken in it, though there was none found in all the polite, discreet fork hunting I did as I served myself. This had a fish sauce or anchovy funk that danced well with the skillfully charred broccoli. Had I not been in company, I would have just pulled the serving platter over to my own personal space, eaten every morsel of every component, then licked the platter clean. This is something I have been mentally reconstructing so I can enjoy it again at home. 

The next course was Blue Bay mussels in a buttermilk broth. These missed the mark for me, too. The mussels were plump and well cooked but the broth did not taste like much more than salty water. I love buttermilk but this had none of the tang or the creaminess that makes it a special ingredient. The dish was garnished with Olly's house baguette toasts and even soaking the toasts with the broth did not satisfy my search for the lovely acidity buttermilk brings to food. I was glad I'd managed to keep the lemons from the hush puppy course as they at least added the acid I was missing but unfortunately did not save this dish.

Another gripe I had was with Olly's servers. No one was given fresh plates with new courses. The tables were set with small, round plates that had a lip. Basically tasting plates. Fine for one tasting course but we were expected to try new things with the same soiled plates. A big no. My neighbor, who was a light eater, had so much barely touched food on her plate that she was having a tough time piling a new serving on top of the prior courses. She asked, then I asked for her, that a clean plate be brought out. Never happened. 

Lamb meatballs with cucumber and tomato baba ganoush was the last savoury course. They were so salty I left them all and concentrated solely on the excellent mix of greens and herbs they were nested in. Another miss.

The meal ended with carrot cake which made me groan inwardly with disappointment when I saw it on the menu. Happily I was wrong. This proved to be light, creamy and delightful with a raisin puree on the side.  A heavy, hackneyed dessert blissfully reinvented. Yes!

Would I go back? No. I wish Olly and Mr. D'Ambra well but with only 2 good-ish dishes out of the 6 that I had, as well as the awful acoustics, this was not a dinner outing I'd want to repeat.", 'Excellent excellent excellent service.  The presentation of the food was great.  We ordered the fried chicken and the lasagna.  The fried chicken was tasty but was a little bit over cooked to be honest.  The lasagna was delicious albeit the portion size could have been a tad bigger for the price.  Overall a good experience but nothing really to write home about.  Would definitely come back!']

name: Han Dynasty
categories_raw: Restaurants, Chinese, Szechuan
top_reviews:
["I hadn't been to Han's Dynasty in quite some time! I remember it being way to spicy for my taste at the time, but since then my spice tolerance has grown so much thanks to all the cool foodies I know who forced me to embrace the spice lol

I took the family here for Mother's Day because I knew everyone in that area of University city would be out of town, so the restaurant wouldn't be overly crowded or marking up the price that day.

We were told all the food is served family style so 3-4 dishes should feed 7-8 ppl which was pretty accurate. The host said rice comes out unlimited, but the only tedious thing was having to constantly ask for it instead of them bringing it out as we finished or just bring out one super huge bowl. We are professional rice eaters in my family, and I don't think Han Dynasty was prepared for that. 

We ordered the Scallion pancakes,Dan Dan Noodle,  Pepper Chicken , on Black Bean Style Fish, and one Garlic Tofu dish. All were solid, but the  Black Bean style fish was by far the best. The flavor was so sweet and spicy all at once and the fish was super moist. The cold Dan Dan noodles packed ALOT of spice and flavor as well. I wish I could take that sauce on the noodles home and pour it on everything...except cereal of course.

Anyway, the food was a home run here and the price point was way lower than we all expected. I can't wait to eat here again!", 'I go to Han Dynasty so often that it might as well be an addiction. I have tried every single item on that menu at least once. If you don't like Han Dynasty, it is because some ridiculous childhood trauma has rendered you soulless and dead inside.

You can be assured that every dish I mention in this review is a favorite. Here's how to do Han Dynasty right, based on countless experiences with varying numbers of people at this restaurant-

"The Lonely Man"(for one lonely, sad person)
Dan Dan Noodles, dumplings in chili oil. You will have leftovers.

"The Basic"(for two people, probably a date early in the relationship)
Dan Dan Noodles, Spicy Cucumber, Three Cup Chicken - You will have leftovers.

"Company"(for three people, because your significant other has someone visiting from out of town and you want them to like you)
Dan Dan Noodles, Spicy Cucumber, Double cooked pork belly, Fried Taiwanese sausage.

"The Party"(for four people, because three folks from your work are tired of hearing about you rave about the restaurant and have demanded that you take them.)
Dan Dan Noodles, Spicy Cucumber, Dry Pepper Shrimp, Fish hot pot

Any party greater than 4 usually means that someone with Han Dynasty experience will be in the party and should know what the hell they are doing.

The U.City location is larger and serves the food more quickly than any other location. Seriously, they are really fast here. I've eaten here and received my Dan Dan noodles and cucumbers before the drinks arrive. It is ridiculous.

I've given so many stars to Han's restaurants on Yelp that this chain might as well be its own group of constellations. Google "han dynasty rap" for more of my shameless plugging of this restaurant.', "THREE CUP CHICKEN! Let me say it one more time for the people in the back... THE THREE CUP CHICKEN!!!! This dish was a highlight from my recent takeout order and I can't wait to order it again. The perfect amount of sweet and savory flavors, tenderness, and garlic.

I was in the mood for soup so I ordered a beef noodle soup from Han Dynasty for pickup. While looking through the other menu options online, I noticed the Three Cup Chicken in the specials section. I decided to try it. Based on the way the menu describes the items, I could not tell if this was going to come with rice or not. I assumed (and hoped) it would, and it did. You just never know with takeout these days!

I scheduled it for a later pickup time, ran my errands, and stopped by a few minutes earlier than expected for my food. While it wasn't ready when I got there (100% my fault) they did get it wrapped up quickly and I did not have to wait long. By the time I got home everything was still hot and VERY delicious."]

name: District Donuts Sliders Brew
categories_raw: Food, Donuts, Burgers, American (Traditional), Coffee & Tea, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['When walking down the French Quarter, this was about 1.9 miles, and we actually considered walking. Now before you consider wal - wait, don't. 

Your best bet to get to this heavenly, and yes, I mean HEAVENLY place (these donuts have officially provided me with an out of body experience) would be to drive your car and park on the sidewalk. Now with that being said, there's plenty of seats inside and outside of the place! Upon approaching the register, the woman working the counter gave us recommendations as I was looking into the gates of heaven. About eight donuts that are laid out inside of a small counter, with the workers constantly firing out more. 

Exciting to say the least, I could feel the donuts calling me, "Jimmy, we're HERE! What you've been waiting so long for!" They were right, this place was always on the corner of my mind while walking through New Orleans. My first time coming here, I absolutely had to get four of them. Now enough of me talking, let's get into the donuts themselves:

Banana Cream Donut (5/5):

I thought that the donut itself would be dry with regards to the numerous other donuts I've eaten. Boy was I wrong! After the first bite, I could taste the glaze along with a hint of banana cream. Who knew there was a filling? I was expecting just a plain white cream filling, however, that wasn't the case! The guys hear at District Donuts put time into their donuts, and you can taste it! The added touch of the two banana pieces on top which actually were caramelized, made this treat twenty times better. Definitely the best one of the four so far! 

Boston Cream Pie (4.5/5):

Identical was how I would describe this one. Perfect yet identical. This donut wasn't a disappointment in any aspect. If you've ever had a real Boston cream pie, this would be an exact replica. The cream inside is delicious but fluffy. Delicate, and not overpoweringly sweet. The chocolate glaze on top was moist and appealing on the pallet, almost like New Year's Eve fireworks (except you know, in your mouth).

Now, the other two donuts I chose were toasted coconut and lemon raspberry. Both of those for my parents, because sharing is caring! Overall, just being able to see the staff at District Donuts working hard with regards to making their fresh donuts combined with the delicious quality of the donuts were enough for me to say that I will be back, but hungrier, for more donuts! Make this a mandatory place to visit on your way to New Orleans!', "These D-O-N-U-T-S...OMG... All I can say is good thing I don't live by this place or I'd be in big trouble! This place was voted one of the TOP 10 donuts shops in America and I definitely know why! 

Recently I made a trip to New Orleans for Mardi Gras and District Donuts was on my radar all the way from Los Angeles! Um yeah... I can sniff out good donuts from hundreds of miles away! 

 When I first walked in there was a line, but that didn't deter me. I was only worried they might run out of donuts and I was anxious to get my order in. The line looked pretty long but it only took me about 10 minutes to get through it. I was a overwhelmed because I wanted to try...um..all of them but I can only eat so much. When I finally got to the front of the line I found out my biggest nightmare had came true, they were sold out of the King cake donut, and that was the one I was really looking forward to trying! I asked them if I could pre-order it and wait to the side because they were cooking them, but they said they couldn't do that. I understood because there were so many people that wanted them that people pre-ordering could get confusing. 

If you're not familiar what king cake is, it is a cake during Mardi Gras in New Orleans that is covered with different colors like pink, purple, and yellow. Inside they hide a baby. The tradition is, whoever finds the baby in the king cake has to buy the next king cake. These cakes are very popular during Mardi Gras. 

I ended up buying a box of donut. It included the Wedding cake donut, the NOLA, Red velvet, and the Spicy Maple Praline donuts. I also got a buttermilk drop (it's like a buttermilk biscuit that taste like a donut), a buttermilk biscuit and chocolate chip cookies. Don't judge, I shared all my goodies with a group of friends, that way I could taste everything. For full enjoyment I advise you buy all the above or you will be cheating yourself! 

While I was sitting in the store eating my donuts the owner came up and asked me if I wanted a king cake donut. He had heard the commotion I made at the counter about wanting a King Cake donut and my disappointment. I thought that was really awesome, and I didn't have to wait in line. Thank you Aaron! 

Unfortunately I was so focused on their donuts I missed out on getting some of their breakfast sandwiches and the Croquenuts (griddled donut sandwiches). They look so good that I could kick myself for not trying at least 3 of them each! 

Most importantly donut lovers, District Donuts  changes their donuts daily, which is a good and a bad thing. The good thing is there is a bunch of different kind of donuts that seem endless. The bad news is I don't live in New Orleans so I won't be able to try them all. If you live out here take advantage of how lucky you are. Here's a list of just a few of the donuts they have....

Peanut butter and Jelly
Chunky monkey 
Strawberry basil 
Pad Thai 
Peanut butter bacon
Samoa
Black and gold
Chocolate milk
Strawberry cheesecake 
Margarita 
Cookie dough
Banana foster 
Coffee cake 
Fluffernutter
Hibiscus 
Caramel apple 
Passionate fruit 
Sangria
Chocolate blackout donut
Strawberry basil
Carrot cake peeps 
Chocolate glaze
Cinnamon glaze 
Spicy maple praline 
Nola
Morpheus 
Strawberry banana smoothie 
Boston cream
Mango pink peppercorn
Mint chocolate chip
Nutella mousse
Lemon ginger
Rum raisin 
Pina colada
Cookies and milk
Brownie batter 
Chocolate chip
Carrot cake
Banana split 
Salted caramel 
Vietnamese iced coffee

I can't wait to come back and try them all!", "Exposed brick

Beer on tap

Doughnuts 

Cold Brew Coffee

T-shirts stuffed inside mason jars, Jelly, Pickles & Jalapeños for retail

Oysters

Shrimp Rangoon 

BLT

Booth & bar seating 

Awesomely hip & helpful employees

...are just a handful of the extraordinary things District has to offer.

I couldn't help but try the Special Donut-la-mode which was a concoction consisting of a raised (unglazed) District donut sliced in half layered with lavender honey ice cream, graham cookie crumbled inside, the donut top replaced and drizzled with a mint sugar to form a donut ice sandwich supreme thingie! Taste so good I felt bad about it. I washed it down with their cold brew coffee and was ready for a nap. 

If you're in the Garden District or not; it's imperative that you make it by this spot before leaving NOLA. You'll thank me later.

~Christy"]

name: Kimpton Hotel Monaco Philadelphia
categories_raw: Hotels & Travel, Event Planning & Services, Venues & Event Spaces, Hotels, Wedding Planning
categories: ['hotels & travel', 'event planning & services', 'venues & event spaces', 'hotels', 'wedding planning']
top_reviews:
["Such a late review but came here on a business trip and omg! This hotel is absolutely adorable with its Alice in Wonderland theme! Every detail from the bathroom, to the closet, to the curtains, and to the walls were all beautiful, unique, chic, and modern.

Additional Info: 
* complimentary happy hour from 5pm to 6pm
* complimentary coffee & tea in the morning 
* no bible in the room like traditional hotel... they have a copy of Alice's Adventure in Wonderland as a substitute 
* great location! Walking distant to many attractions (museums, historical sites, restaurants, etc.)
* great service
* super comfortable bed", "This review is of the private spaces at Hotel Monaco. I have not actually stayed there or seen any of their guest rooms, but I did swing by recently for a site visit and I was completely blown away by the gorgeous decor and fabulous layout. The lobby area is filled with unique chairs, tables and decorative pieces, all of which are bright, colorful and patterned, all of which still manage to exist in harmony despite the craziness. 

The large event space fits up to 350 with the adjoining area across the hall, and the space manages a personality that is both classy and modern. It's a refreshing change from your standard hotel ballrooms. For smaller meetings, there are several board rooms on the lower level, plus a gorgeous private dining room that would be perfect for a swanky bachelor or bachelorette party. Or a fancy business lunch, I suppose. 

The rooftop lounge, Stratus, is also incredible. There is great indoor and outdoor space, separated by funky glass garage doors. Plus, there are two private rooms on each side of the outdoor area that are just really cool. I am really looking forward to checking out this space when the weather gets warmer. 

In summary, I'd like to plan every private party at the Hotel Monaco.", "I think this eclectically upscale hotel should probably win some Art Deco-stylized loving cup for Best Repurpose of a Historical Building Into a High-End Hotel. It was formerly the Lafayette Building, an 11-story office building built in 1906 and left vacant for several years due to the recession until the ever-resourceful Kimpton Hotel chain gave it a complete makeover inside. On the corner of 5th and Chestnut, It's right across the street from both Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell, so you may want to pimp out your powdered wig and practice your minuet moves. Alas, I wasn't there for any patriotic pleasures.

I was there for work and could merely enjoy the holiday card scene of Independence Hall outside my window (photo: http://bit.ly/U8kGYg). As it turned out, that was just fine because the room was a Deluxe One Bedroom Suite that was priced at an astonishingly low $171 on a wintry weeknight in January. Although the interior styling points to a historic restoration, the colors and patterns applied are bold and contemporary (photo: http://bit.ly/1o1OvUV). Look at the gigantic floral designs on the carpet, the Revolutionary War-era wall treatments (photo: http://bit.ly/T8ZEbh), the hard geometry of the shelving units and occasional tables, and the words of wisdom stenciled in the closet (photo: http://bit.ly/1kDxzhQ)

Your eye then gets drawn to the bright yellow doors (photo: http://bit.ly/1l1ZpsJ), the shiny mauve armoire housing the TV set (photo: http://bit.ly/1wYu3bL), the uniform iron-gate pattern of the wallpaper, and the lamp with the greyhound sitting dutifully at the base (photo: http://bit.ly/1nJxZeM). The standalone spa tub and deluxe shower are enough to lull you into a transcendental state (photo: http://bit.ly/1hu4MSF). There's also the Red Owl Tavern downstairs and a rooftop lounge. In fact, there's even a free hosted wine bar between 5 and 6 PM every day. Because of its unique location, the only downside to the Monaco is that any other dining or libation destination will require you take a cab. Otherwise this hotel is a genuine knockout."]

name: ABC Pizza House
categories_raw: Restaurants, Pizza
top_reviews:
["Was introduced to ABC Pizza House by a colleague and decided to try them for takeout. The garlic bread was delicious and heavily buttered. As for the pizza, it had a thicker crust than I anticipated and the dough was heavy and dense. I'll probably try ABC again and if I do, I'll be sure to order the thin crust.", "I've driven by this place a bunch of times, but only recently decided to check it out since I had zero desire to cook the other night (I feel like it's all I do lately!).

Thankfully, it was super easy to order on their website, and the pizza was ready just 15 minutes later. My boyfriend warned me this wasn't going to be NY style (my preferred pizza type), but more of a pan style... I was still surprised at how thick the crust was. The good news is, it may be thicker, but that doesn't mean it's doughy. The crust (and bottom) of the pizza still had a nice crunch to it. I did wish I had a garlic sauce to dip the crust in though.

We ordered half cheese, half pepperoni. I had briefly contemplated ordering extra cheese, but I'm glad I didn't -- it was pretty loaded with cheese as it was. The ingredients were fresh... I liked the sauce, and the cheese was great too. Oh, and the slices reheated very well in my air fryer (if you haven't tried that method yet for reheating pizza, you absolutely should).

Now, I still prefer NY style, but I'd definitely keep this on the pizza rotation! I saw they have a pretty sizable Italian menu as well, so I will be back to try more of their food.", 'Finally checked out ABC after driving by quite a bit. The parking lot was packed on a Friday night. I was surprised by how much seating they have, and liked that most of the options are booths. Many families were inside chowing down on the inexpensive food. 

We started with a pepperoni pizza as an appetizer (yeah, we're fat) just so everyone could get a slice and experience the restaurant's namesake offering. The pizza is good, although have others have commented it's not your typical New York style but rather "Greek style" which from what I can tell means a puffy crust and tons of cheese. 

For dinner, everyone in my group went with an entree. I was tickled when reading the menu because it says all entrees come with MELTED CHEESE, salad (which never arrived), and garlic bread. We anxiously waited to see if we'd each be presented with a side dish of melted cheese. When our food came out, we quickly realized what they meant -- each dish was cloaked in a thick blanket of cheese, making one dish indistinguishable from the next. I'm not complaining since cheese is like oxygen to me, but if you're lactose intolerant you best not be ordering one of these dishes. 

My chicken parm was served over spaghetti. It was satisfying and I ended up taking about 3/4 of it home. I tried my friend's eggplant rollatini which was also quite tasty. The garlic bread was not worth eating (but I did anyway, because... carbs.)

The decor in this place is incredibly random and unintentionally kitschy. Table placemats are covered in ads, which included ads for a bail bondsman, pawn shop and critter removal (which really gets your appetite working). There are framed posters throughout the restaurant which range from a knock off of the Last Supper (seriously, it wasn't even a print of the real thing just a completely different rendition with JC sitting on his own side of the table -- most likely eating Greek pizza but I didn't look close enough), a 300 movie poster, a map of the world, St Pete sunset, and many more. My motivation for coming back will most likely be to better inspect the entire poster collection. It was totally bizarre and wonderful. 

Also weird is that you're given a "check" which is really just a take out menu with everything you ordered circled on it, and you're not given the total. I guess since it's so cheap no one minds this oversight. 

But, alas, ABC gets 3 stars since I left full and with leftovers, I had a good laugh, and I didn't spend much money.']

name: Lan Zhou Lamen
categories_raw: Chinese, Noodles, Seafood, Chicken Wings, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['We ordered the skewers of barbecue beef and lamb and chicken. Spicy delicious lamb was our favorite. Try the soup dumplings as well small but very tasty full of a pork and soup mixture very good. Also pork dumplings and spring roll both very tasty. We also ordered the shrimp Ma La pot spicy full of all kinds of fish balls and shrimps and vegetables in a huge bowl enough for three people to share. A very enjoyable meal a restaurant was not full if you desire to sit inside and eat we opted for the fun of eating in the parking lot', 'This restaurant is 3.5 stars. There some good and some average items. I am glad we have the hand pull noodle restaurant. If the can have glass window to the kitchen to show the hand pull noodle, it will be more attractive to the customers. 

We started with the lamb BBQ skew. I like the northern China spice seasoning. The skew probably the best thing we have. The second appetizer was the beef burger. It is beef in pita like item. The pita can be improved and the beef can be more juicier. 

Our entree is the their Lanzhou Beef Noodle. There is 8 pieces slice beef. The soup base is good. Food is good not wow. My wife braise beef is average. She feel the beef is less in quantity. At least this restaurant is a bit above average compared to some other noodle place.', "I had a very enjoyable dinner to go. My noodle dish was filling and lasted me three days. My wife didn't enjoy the soup dumplings but perhaps it was because we got them to go. 

We ordered online via their website but when we arrived, they hadn't started making it so I had to wait. Something was wrong with their website notifications apparently."]

name: Thai 5 Fast Food
categories_raw: Laotian, American (Traditional), Asian Fusion, Salad, Pan Asian, Sushi Bars, Food Trucks, Food, Noodles, Restaurants, Thai
top_reviews:
["My Thai side always gravitates toward Pad Thai, Drunken Noodles, Tom Yum, Mango Sticky Rice, etc. - I can eat it for breakfast, lunch and dinner!

I went with a To Go order of Beef Pad Thai ($9.95+tax) - medium spicy because it is better that way and they didn't disappoint and delivered on that (I received a small container full of chili flakes, so I could customize on the amount of heat. Of course, I added all of it!). They have one size for their pad thai - it can definitely be split between two people! As you can tell in the pic., my friend sneaked a couple delish bites & I still had plenty left. As a personal preference, I didn't like the raw bean sprouts; I'm glad they put the peanuts on the side because I only like it in small quantities and as strange as it sounds, this foodie is neither a big fan of bean sprouts or peanuts. 

They are located next to Pinch A Penny, so that's a tell tale to turn into their parking lot because it's not easy to see from the road.", "So happy to see a Thai food truck back in the same spot where Kombo Kitchen once existed.

When I asked if there was still a connection, I was told it was the same chef as KK. That was very encouraging.

The woman who greeted me and took my order was sweet and accomodating as I could not decide between two dishes. So she offered to combine the two and put them together for me at one price.

My order was prepared quickly, shown to me before being packaged up to take home for dinner and I was offered water while I eagerly waited near my car.

There was plenty of food for the price, so they clearly are generous with the portions.

Unfortunately, I was disappointed in the overall dish and would not have that same combination again. 

Maybe I put two items together that just did not work, but one of the items was simply not prepared as I expected and was actually not worth ordering at all.

Thai 5 is still worth trying again. I'll just be a little less creative next time and ask more questions.", "If you read my reviews, you'll know I was a super, huge fan of the Thai restaurant that was formerly at this location.  So when I realized that a new restaurant had opened at the same location, with some of the same former staff members - I was nervously apprehensive that the food and service wouldn't be nearly as good as it's former predecessor.  It's also the reason why I was slow to write this review.  I wanted to try the new Thai 5 location a couple of times before I came to any revelations on the quality of their Thai food because to be honest, they had big shoes to fill.

I wasn't let down.  Food quality is fresh, flavorful with large portions.  Service is still wonderful and they go out of their way to know who their customers are and make them feel like family.  You'll find some familiar dishes on the menu and also some new options.  Chanel the new manager is gracious and friendly and a beautiful-smiling addition to the Thai food truck establishment."]

name: México Lindo
categories_raw: Mexican, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["What does a one $ sign, fabulous food in a pleasant setting  and great service warrant?     A 5 Star review!!!

That's cute, authentic and amazing Mexican BYOB did the trick for us in filling our bellies on this beautiful summer evening. All 3 of us Ordered the Carnitas which were shredded pork with a side of cactus, beans and rice and guac and chips. Everything was fresh and homemade and you could taste the love. I felt like my mama had made me a great big wonderful dinner. 
And we got to try cactus! The only other time the three of us that had cactus was when we had cactus martinis in the Grand Canyon. The free chips and salsa were refilled  each time our server saw them go low. 
3 ate heartily for $46 including 2 sodas. 
Great experience in this wonderful South Philly Mexican restaurant. We are going back soon", "Most authentic tacos I've had in Philadelphia! Steps away from Bok Bar so it's great for some post beer eats. Other than that, it is quite far away. Owner and waitresses mostly spoke Spanish so ordering was a bit difficult, though their menu is very self explanatory. My friend had the vegetarian burrito ($9) and I got chicken and pork tacos ($6). Meat was tender, well seasoned, and the portion size was perfect. 

They are CASH ONLY. There is an ATM but at the moment, neither me nor my friend had cash/debit card and we found this out after we had devoured the food (oops). The owner was way more understanding than expected and I promised to pay him with cash the next morning. We somewhat shoke on that contract and left. Without paying. Yup. They were super chill and trusting like that. Can't get any more mom and pop shop feel than that 

Anyways, irrelevant to the review but FYI I did bike back a good 30 mins the next day from West Philly and delivered my dues in cash. The owner was surprised I had actually kept up my promise since he looked shocked and thanked me profusely for paying.

Thanks for a great home cooked meal, Maribel! (Now Mexico Lindo)", "Maribel has changed their name, but the delicious flavor and friendly service have stayed the same. I find myself returning here often for their Mexico City style quesadillas. If you have never had this, or even if you have, it's a must order! It's a homemade crispy masa dough that is fried and stuffed with Oaxaca cheese, a protein of your choice or mushrooms, lettuce, cream, and a little queso fresco on top. Then I add some of their homemade green and red salsa for a little heat. The ingredients come together in perfect harmony, but the crispy texture of the shell is what really makes it. 

When I first started ordering them, I got mushrooms because I would share a chicken dish with my husband too, so I wanted to change things up. Recently, I've been going because of my quesadilla craving and ordering them on my own. The first time I did this, I ordered chicken. It was pretty tasty grilled chicken, but I preferred the mushrooms. The second time I ordered it as tinga de pollo and ended up with the delicious well seasoned shredded chicken that is in their tostadas that I love so much. So please make sure you specify which one you're after when you order! 

I also found out that they can make this dish grilled as well. I am always tempted to try it, but the super crispy fried corn dough is always calling my name. If someone gets around to trying it, please let me know. I am just too addicted to the original at the moment!"]

name: Deluxe Hair Salon
categories_raw: Beauty & Spas, Hair Salons
top_reviews: ["I have been going to see Adrienne for several months now. She has done an awesome job. I had been seeing the same stylist for several years before her and he was just too far away for me to continue traveling just to get my hair done. I was extremely hesitant to get my hair done, because several other times I've had my hair colored and cut in the city it was either over bleached or extremely expense. I have been extremely happy since day one with Adrienne. She has helped me with how to style my hair and personally showed me how to create wavy hair with a curling iron. She is very patient and articulate with how she highlights, cuts and even drys my hair each time, styling it before I leave. The prices are the very reasonable as well. I will continue to be a loyal Deluxe client.", "It's a cool salon without pretension. Their prices are very reasonable and everyone  is friendly and professional.  Adrienne is amazing! She really listens to what you want and doesn't rush you. She makes great suggestions and works with you to give you the color and cut you're going for. And she knows how to cut curly hair! You can tell she loves what she does and she's fun to chat with. I highly recommend Deluxe to everyone!", "I went to get my roots touched up. I was so disappointed in the way my hair turned out. I have a black line of hair separating my roots from the rest of my hair as my roots were not completely covered with hair color. I'm currently out of town and will be returning hoping to have my hair colored fixed again."]

name: University Pet Clinic
categories_raw: Pets, Veterinarians, Pet Services
top_reviews:
['The clinic still uses anal thermometers. WTAF. My cat was pissed, and he doesn't even know that auricular thermometers are available. The clinic knows very well that animals dislike anal probing (duh), and, as a scientist, I recognize that while the anal method is vanishingly more accurate (see, e.g., https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23090330 (2012) (cats) and https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3058653 (2011) (dogs)), it is unnecessary for routine checkups. Stop being cheap and buy some auricular thermometers. Would you like it if someone stuck a thermometer up your ass like it's 1957? (I'm not posting any photos of my cat with a thermometer up his ass, but I was like, WTF.)

[This addendum comes in response to your concern-trolling response. 

Response of Karnin R. posted Oct. 30, 2019:
10/30/2019 We always appreciate feedback from clients, Jeremy. 
While we understand rectal temperature taking is not always so comfortable for patients (and pet-parents to watch), rectal temperature measurement is still widely considered the gold standard for accuracy in cats and dogs within the veterinary industry and is backed up with recent research studies and reported in recent veterinary journal articles and petcare publications. It is not uncommon for a health concern to be discovered during even a "routine checkup" when the owner had not even been aware there was a problem, so it is essential we obtain the most accurate vitals during every patient visit. University Pet Clinic's team does our very best to keep both patients and pet-parents as comfortable during your visit as possible, while still providing the highest level of patient care.
We use digital rectal thermometers, which give results in just a few seconds and we use a lubricant on the thermometer to help minimize discomfort. Ear thermometers need to be \xa0inserted deeply into the ear canal to be close to the ear drum to get an accurate reading. Due to the many sizes and shapes of the cat and dog ear canal, digital ear temperatures aren't always precise. Plus, the presence of hair, wax, and debris in the ear canal (not to mention pet's trying to squirm away from or shake their head as the tip of the thermometer is deep in their ear)- all of these common things can affect accuracy. We have tried different types of ear thermometers over the years (we currently have one or two in our clinic for very specific situations), however, in our opinion many pets find ear thermometers to be more invasive and uncomfortable (sensitive ears, health problems in or around the ear, etc.) than rectal thermometers, plus we have found aural results to be inaccurate much of the time.
Jeremy, we hope this clarifies our choice in using a rectal thermometer during your cat's visit and improves your opinion of University Pet Clinic. Please feel free to reach out to me with any further questions or comments (Karin Schorr, Hospital Administrator, 520-795-7016).
Here are just a few of the articles I found related to rectal vs ear and axillary thermometer results (some may show more evidence for dogs vs cats, however, the overall conclusions and recommendations are for both cats and dogs):
https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1098 (2015)
https://www.americanveterinarian.com/news/accuracy-of-auricular-axillary-and-rectal-thermometry (2018)
https://jaaha.org/doi/10.5326/JAAHA-MS-6500 (2017)
https://vcahospitals.com/know-your-pet/taking-your-pets-temperature (2016) 

My reply: Your response, while lengthy, merely propounds lame excuses and reinforces my point while ignoring the consent of pet owners. While I see your public profile @ https://universitypetclinic.com/about-us/our-pack, you seem to just be a homer--the founder's daughter--and lack even licensure as a veterinary technician, let alone as a veterinarian. What qualifies you to cite and discuss scientific articles? What are your credentials? Moreover, you have not earned the right to address me as Jeremy, nor are you smart enough to lie to me about science. The first article you cite merely makes my point that "the anal method is vanishingly more accurate" (see supra), on the order of 1°C. The second link leads to a magazine article making the same point ("the average discrepancy between readings was still 0.6°C"). The third link appears to lead to the source article discussed at the second link. The final link leads to an article containing no experimental data. The idea that a routine check-up needs temperature measured within 1°C, or that such a minor temperature fluctuation commonly alerts practitioners to health issues, is just nonsense. You claim, without evidence, that the clinic has tried auricular thermometers. At the end of the day, your response presumes, wrongly, that it is your choice. Under the law, pets are personal property, and I know you do not obtain consent prior to using anal thermometers because you know owners would object.]', "I just received an email from University Pet Clinic asking for reviews on Yelp. I actually never thought to write them one. But, since they asked for it...

I took a kitten here about two (maybe three now) years ago. The vet came up with a plan of treatment, which involved basically giving my kitten an enema. They then released him to us and told us he should be better in the morning. He died overnight. It was very heartbreaking, and the next day when the staff called to check on Purr-seus's status, I told them he had passed away. They seemed confused about how this had happened, as were we. I understand things happen though, even though I wish the vet would have done something more to help save our kitten. But they get three stars because about a week later they called to make Purr-seus a follow up appointment. Seems like someone forgot to write down that he had passed--which made it really hard to receive a call asking about a follow up. 

The service was ok. It was pricey, but I didn't mind that because I was trying to save my sister's kitten. I wish more could have been done, but maybe not. Hard to say. But someone should have definitely written down not to call and make a follow up appointment for our passed kitten.", "We had a major puppy trauma and thank goodness yelp steered me to University Pet Clinic. They were wonderful from beginning to end of our poor pups dental catastrophe.

I dropped off our pup for what I thought was going to be a routine tooth pulling, one or two teeth. Dr. Adams got in there and discovered she actually had teeth resorption. She was not only going to need 10 teeth removed, but two of them had to be done surgically which involved flaps and sutures. Dr. Adams kindly called and explained the situation mid surgery and graciously gave me time to call and consult my family on what to do before proceeding.

Before, during, and after surgery they made me feel comfortable to call with any questions. Which I did! Called after, almost daily, with a new question and they were gracious and patient with me. 

Our pup ended up not holding down food on her second day post surgery and we called, they had us come in free of charge, and helped us solve the issue with an easy diet change. We met with Dr. White on this visit and he was just as wonderful as Dr. Adams. 

Normally this type of dental procedure would've been referred out due to the complexity, but because they offer dental cleaning discounts in February, Dr. Adams has gained a lot of experience with teeth. They also consulted specialists about our pup before proceeding. This work would've been between 5 and 6k at a specialist, but we paid less than a third of that. Because our bill was higher they worked a deal for us to pay half upfront and half to be billed a month out.  They only do this in special circumstances. 

All of the vet techs and administrative staff were friendly and clearly loved animals! Always reassuring when leaving your fur baby in a scary place. We will be returning here for all future veterinary care."]

name: Suis Generis
categories_raw: American (New), Restaurants
top_reviews:
['One of the cool things about Suis Generis is that because the menu changes on the regular, I get to update my reviews on the regular!

I had dinner here on Friday night and there were two vegetarian options: a house-made gorgonzola ricotta baked pumpkin seed ravioli with asiago-parmesean cream sauce & asparagus AND a Burmese noodle bowl with organic baby bok choi, bamboo shoots & miso-ginger broth. I went for the latter because although the former piqued my interest (and my love for all things pumpkin seed), I figured it would be overkill with the "Fabulous Mezze Plate" (doesn't that sound like something I'd write on my own? But it's their words, not mine) that I also ordered. So much cheese, y'know? While one might think you can't have too much of a good thing, well that one wouldn't be me because you sure as hell can have too much of a good thing when it comes to foods that are rich and decadent.

A note on the mezze plate: It is, indeed, fabulous. It, too, changes so while I can go on about how that double-aged Beemster X-O North Holland Gouda got my taste buds in the throes of passion, you may not get that on your Fabulous Mezze Plate next week. You can trust the fine folks at Suis Generis to pick out other excellent cheeses, however. I'm sure of it.

A note on the Burmese Noodle Bowl: It's damn delicious. So, if they have noodle bowls on future menus, go for it. There was a ton of ginger in there. Seriously, at least a 3 inch fat root chopped up. I ate it all. I love ginger.

A note on Suis Generis' plates and glasses: they make me feel like I'm at a party happening in the late 60s or early 70s. I expect fondue to be served at any minute. 

I love Suis Generis for the food, but I also just love the atmosphere. I love how at night they dim the lights and throw on the fake fire places and disco balls so that you feel like you're in the super cool rec room of some hip teenager circa 1970. It's intimate enough to be perfect for a date and friendly enough so that you can easily come in and eat alone. 5 stars! And read my earlier review about their Bellinis...', 'the food is decent and it's great that they are open late - but the person who writes the menu is a fool:

"velvety avocado"

"ambrosial mushrooms"

"sultry cream sauce"

"a hint of fairy mushrooms"

"feel the rain forest" (in reference to a guacamole)



PUT THE THESAURUS DOWN AND LET THE FOOD SPEAK FOR ITSELF!', 'Well, clearly several of the owners' friends have decided to take to Yelp to lead unsuspecting restaurant goers astray. Be sure to note, fellow Yelpers, anytime a positive review is that person's ONLY review.

This is by far the most contrived restaurant I have ever been to. I don't care how "wacky" or "artistic" your neighborhood is, you can't just slap cheap decorations together and call yourself "hip" or "eclectic" or whatever you fancy yourself as being. 

Worse than the decor, the food itself is contrived. Listen carefully: You do not put vanilla anywhere near scallops, let alone as a "sauce." If you want to experiment, do it at home. Do not charge unsuspecting customers for that abomination. Also, how do you screw up broccoli? My broccoli was completely overseasoned to the point of being inedible. 

Even the restaurant's name is contrived. "Sui generis" is Latin for being unique to itself. "Suis generis" means absolutely nothing. I read somewhere that an "s" was added as a nod to the city's French heritage. That leaves us with a conjugated French verb for "being" that is out of place, and a Latin word that is out of place. It doesn't make any sense, and it's not creative. It's like when a comedian has to explain his jokes after no one laughs. 

You cannot throw together a restaurant like this, be pretentious, and then get your friends to write sham reviews. No, no, no. That violates this city's proud culinary heritage in every way imaginable.

By the way the lone bright spot was the service, but because of everything mentioned above this needlessly pretentious, slapped-together restaurant gets 1 star.']
