Then she said she'd have to take an x-ray and go get the dentist who was Dr Parikh. He wanted to do an extraction of the tooth right then and of course I refused and said that it should be put back the way it was which was bonded together and he said he could not do that until today. So I had to commute from Exton which is where I'm staying with my friend as we're traveling through the area. I would have to say at this point that I agree with a reviewer further on in the Yelp reviews saying that this man is a bit like a used car salesman. We exchanged niceties and we did agree on politics but that doesn't mean anything as far as how he treated me as a patient. In  Dentistry IQ which I recently read it says a red flag of a dentist is a dentist who consistently puts down the dentists that a patient has gone to prior to him or her and that is what he did in this case and it's disrespectful of me and he sets himself up for a lawsuit. My lawyer actually told me that I shouldn't have to pay any more than what I was supposed to pay originally which was the $100 for the cleaning and nothing else but I feel like I perhaps should pay for the X-ray but nothing else past that. Apparently there is another dental office in the same building and I ran into a woman in the elevator who said she'd been going there for 12 years. 
Philadelphia Dentistry has pretty good reviews. Perhaps consider going there instead. But if you do need cosmetic work make sure you follow the advice of Dentistry IQ which is to look at the before and after pictures of any cosmetic dentist that you consider or ultimately go to for your own safety. Dr. Pateh actually had the audacity to ask me if the prior dentists I was going to were legitimate and if they had their credentials on the walls of their lobby. I said I noticed his credentials were not in the lobby.  He said they were behind the reception area. He disrespected and discounted the work I had done in Mexico as well as all the other work I've had done which is more than one red flag. the hygienist yesterday use the term after she made her mistake that I was under supervised negligence. She was negligent in following my request and when I saw her today she looked away."]

name: HORN'S EATERY
categories_raw: Caterers, Venues & Event Spaces, Breakfast & Brunch, Gastropubs, American (New), Restaurants, Food, Event Planning & Services, Bars, Cocktail Bars, Seafood, Nightlife
categories: ['caterers', 'venues & event spaces', 'breakfast & brunch', 'gastropubs', 'american (new)', 'restaurants', 'food', 'event planning & services', 'bars', 'cocktail bars', 'seafood', 'nightlife']
top_reviews:
["Horn's is everything that makes New Orleans such a special place to dine.  Is this quintessential Marigny neighborhood eatery perfect? No, but do they offer a brunch worthy of 5 stars? Absolutely!  

The food is amazing!  Very unique brunch menu with plenty of options to tempt you, but I couldn't resist the waffle Cochon.  An awesome cornbread waffle, loaded with pulled pork, chimichurri & pickled onions.  (If Guy Fieri hasn't featured this dish, it's just a matter of time).   Washed it down with a very good mimosa from their full bar.  

Yes, it gets busy, so expect a wait, especially on a gorgeous Saturday morning the day after NOLA removed the mask mandate.  (I'd never attempt to bring a party of more than four).  The service was super friendly, and efficient.  Decent amount of pet-friendly sidewalk seating as well as several tables in the funky dining room.  So happy it's around the corner from home, but even if you've got to walk a mile, you'll be glad you did!", "Yesterday was my second visit to this cool, funky little corner restaurant.  I had the Jewish Coonass Breakfast.  2 eggs (made mine poached), over spinach, crawfish etoufee and latkes.  Comes with toast or a biscuit.  I got one of their awesome biscuits.  

This was so amazingly good.  It was perfect.  Came out in a little skillet and was just the right amount of food.  I didn't finish but could have.  I just didn't want to punish myself.  

I like the menu a lot.  It's creative and interesting.  The service was great yesterday and I would definitely recommend you try breakfast here.", "I always love when I find myself in the Marigny/Bywater area because there are so many good food places that I have never tried. Enter Horn's. I had heard about how good this place is, thanks to a food group I'm in, but they're only open until 2 so I would have to conveniently have to make sure I was in the area for lunch.

The cafe is small but mighty, with plenty of seating packed into a small space without feeling crowded. I ordered a big cup of coffee (and it was HUGE). I had already peeked at the menu online and decided that the grits and etouffee had my name all over it. I got a side of bacon, just for good measure, and I counted it towards my protein for the day. The whole thing came with a homemade biscuit on the side. Yes, please.

This dish was amazing. Creamy grits and down home crawfish etouffee is the perfect combination, especially when the richness of the etouffee starts mixing in with the grits. The bacon was cooked to crispy perfection and I indulged in some of my biscuit and saved the rest for later, because it was so good.

Everything on the menu sounded so delicious and I am definitely going to have to go back and sample some more goodies sometime soon. My one issue with the place is that it was pretty warm because it was the middle of a summer day and the place was packed. They had the ac on, but it's an old building and it was struggling to keep up. It wasn't a big issue, but if I had been there for a long time, it would have gotten to me. Service was great and the staff was friendly."]

name: Kuchi Sushi & Hibachi
categories_raw: Restaurants, Japanese, Asian Fusion, Sushi Bars, Teppanyaki
top_reviews:
["Good sushi and one of the better hibachi places we have been to.

My husband requested we go to a hibachi place for his birthday. A friend reminded me that Kobe always sends a free meal coupon and I brought that up to him. In the end we decided we rather support local and the Kobe nearest to us has a less than four star rating - wow am I getting elitist on where I eat. I'm actually glad we chose here, because it was pretty empty so we didn't have to worry about my son's crazy antics and the food was good!

FOOD - I always worry that hibachi will be too greasy. Not here! My husband got noodles, fried rice, vegetables, shrimp and steak. All of it was delicious. I really enjoyed the noodles. 

I ended up going with the Salmon Sushi Entree. I really enjoy that they have these combinations of sushi to order - theres a whole page of it. It was about $20 for a salmon roll, spicy salmon roll, and three pieces of salmon sushi. I feel like that combination a la carte would be less than $20, but I didn't get a chance to price it out. It is a little on the pricier side, but every piece of sushi was delicious.  The salmon tasted fresh and not fishy. 

We started with shrimp shumai steamed. Honestly, it seemed to me like the type you could get frozen at the Asian market. I didn't dislike it, but I wouldn't get it again. 

ATMOSPHERE - from the outside this place looks pretty run down. It's in a random location as kind of close to the movie theater, but not walking distance. I guess it is a testament to the food that it has survived so far. Inside it is much nicer. It is split between the sushi side and the hibachi side. Both sides are pretty large. On a Monday night there were only a couple tables occupied.

SERVICE - It is slow. This is not a get in get out restaurant. It takes a while for them to start the hibachi - maybe they are hoping that more people will come to share the table. Our server was nice though so I don't knock them for this. Just don't come here if you are in a rush. 

Overall I liked this place. It is hard to find someplace that both my husband and I will eat, but this is one of them. We will definitely return.", "This was the very first sushi place I ate at here in Florida/Tampa area. I found it on yelp. Reviews were great so I decided to try it. I didn't realize that they closed for a bit between lunch and dinner. Fortunately I arrived only a couple of minutes prior to them opening for dinner (5pm). They also have Hibachi but I specifically went for sushi. Despite it getting crowded quickly, service was prompt and the servers were very kind. I ordered the sashimi dinner which had an assortment of sashimi and also included a salad and soup. Prices are very reasonable as well. Everything was delicious and the presentation was great! I was later notified on yelp that they used my photo for their profile which made me smile. I'm glad this place is very close to where I live and I can and will be coming to eat here often. I will definitely be trying their hibachi as well. 

The parking is ample btw! Definitely recommend Kuchi Sushi if you're in the area! :)", "My daughter and I come here sometimes because she likes it. Every time I come I hope it will be better, but It's just okay. Maybe it's the lack of business, but something about this place is sub par. They even brought me a lipstick stained cup for my green tea the last time I was there. 

The servers are very nice. The decor is really nice. The sushi could be better. It could be fresher. It's not that it's bad, but I'd rather just grab a roll at publix. I did get bento lunch here once, but it wasn't memorable and I don't believe my teriyaki tasted like teriyaki. 

This restaurant seems like it's trying, but something is missing. Maybe fresher fish and new sushi chefs? 

The sauce designs on the plates are a nice touch. This isn't too far away and it's always quiet and easy to get seated....which is probably a sign.

I haven't tried the hibachi, but I'm not easily impressed by hibachi, so I don't think I'll be trying it."]

name: Vientiane Café
categories_raw: Vietnamese, Restaurants, Food, Thai, Coffee & Tea, Laotian
top_reviews:
["This eatery isn't much larger than a walk-in closet, but bright walls, flowers and candles - and the fact that they're a BYOB - make this an affordable date spot. Due to its size, you'll never be ignored by the friendly staff, even when there's a crowd.

The kitchen works fast, turning out piping hot Laotian and Thai dishes in record time. There's the usual assortment of curries, seafood, and rice plates. Fresh spring rolls ($3.95; vegetarian; cash only, last I checked) come with a side of sweet plum sauce and a pleasantly tart fish sauce. Try the pad kee mao ($10.95; with beef): While it could be spicier and the beef is almost dangerously dry, the sauteed rice noodles are moist, and the mix of onions, carrots, broccoli, chili peppers, bean sprouts, and basil give it flavor and color.", "I can't say enough about this place. Everything I have ever had was delicious - panang curry, egglplant/dill/sticky rice, Pad Kee Mow (so tasty that it took me a year to stop ordering it), red curry, yelloy curry, green curry- try it all, rice noodles, curries.  It's not Thai, as some people claim, but Laotian, which is why many people don't recognize dishes on the menu, or certain flavor combination. 

I don't give 5 stars based on food, though. I love this place because it is a neighborhood joint, because you can eat outside in the summer, because it is a BYOB, because it is CHEAP for the amount of food you get, because when you're there you feel happy just knowing that everyone else is having as good a time as you are. It's not fancy, it's just fantastic. 

Also, there are so many vegetarian options, it's always a hard choice to decide between something new and something that I've had beofre and loved. Really, I could go here every day.", "A worthwhile destination, even if you are not from the neighborhood.

I lived at 48th & Hazel back in my art school days which was before the area was cutely named 'Cedar Park' and when Baltimore Ave. did not have very much to offer in the way of ethnic food, other than Lucky's Chinese Take Out, which is still in business after 37 years-possibly under new management. 

After a too long stint on the West coast, I moved back to Philly in 2015. I had been longing to see my old West Philly neighborhood again. In the back of my mind I was also on the look out for some decent, non trendy, authentic Thai food but I never expected to find it here.

Laotian food is damn good food, somewhat along the lines of Thai cuisine but subtler. My dining companion and I found parking on a side street and as we crossed Baltimore and headed towards Vientiane, I was giddy with memories and pleased to see this old street looking better than the last time I waited on the corner for the trolley to take me to art school in Center City.

This place is cash only and byob. 

First impressions-one was how utterly delicious the place smelled when we walked in. I wanted to go from table to table, asking the diners what they thought the best thing on the menu was. Second was the unfeigned courtesy. We got seated right away and were watered and menued up with no waiting. Everything looked so good. Wonderful to see that sticky rice could be had with entrees.

We started with fried spring rolls and Yum Salad with shrimp. Excellent! Smart, crisp flavors and fresh, well handled food. Someone in the kitchen absolutely cared about what they are sending out to diners. The crowd was mixed; Caucasian students, married, straight 20 somethings, elegant looking mixed race couples, beautiful Rasta boys, professors, seniors-all the casual, natural and unstudied diversity that made me ache for Phillly when I lived elsewhere. This is not a big place and it can be loud, bit it's an easy, happy, comfortable kind of raucousness that washes over you and pulls you in, making you feel like part of an all embracing, wonderful party.

Service was polite and pleasant. Entrees were more than ample. My companion had green curry with tofu that she raved about while I had the Lao pork sausages-three fat, juicy ones with a side of sticky rice, lick your fingers dipping sauce and a mound of vegetables which were forgettable but fresh. I didn't care because I wanted to reserve my appetite so I could do the sausages justice. Time slowed as it does when one is having a really exceptional meal. Between the audaciously fine food and the people watching, I was in heaven. We were not rushed or pushed to order more than we already had. 

We finally finished with Thai iced tea and the tempura fried banana (cliched but delicious). As we wound up our repast, we were making future plans to come back for lunch, and for dinner again and then for lunch and...who knows, maybe I'd even head down the block to get something to go from Lucky's for old times sake...

Remember-cash only and bring your appetite."]

name: Frost Gelato
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Desserts, Gelato, Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt
top_reviews:
["Love this place! The flavors here are always delicious and rarely out of stock. Unless it's a flavor of the month that's near the end of the month. The display are very eye catching, they use real fruits and chocolates for decoration respective to their flavors, which I think is great marketing!

The staff here are super friendly and always lined up and ready to help you. Even if you sample the whole line of choices, they are still there through it all. 

What I really enjoy here is the Affogato coffee which you can mix any gelato scoop with. My favorite is the Hazelnut Gelato with Affogato. They even include some chocolate covered espresso beans too. 

Definitely love coming here! Highly recommend!

[ Taste it, Love it, Yelp it! ]", "Ummm, excuse me...but when can we get one of these in Charlotte, NC?! I love my trips to Tucson for the mere reason I get to go to Frost (well, that and family, of course)! 

Frost offers delicious varieties of gelato. I got a combination of egg nog and chocolate. Mmmmm! Besides it's smooth and creamy texture, the presentation is beautiful! 

Depending on when you go, parking can be kind of tricky because there are a lot of popular restaurants and shops in the same area (but there is more parking in the back). The shoppe is clean, bright, and modern. I leave satisfied and wanting more...how many places can say the same thing?", "This Frost is our Gelato spot.  When we go to Sauce next door for Pizza night, this becomes desert night too. 

Many choices , pretty swift line. Free samples if you want to try. 

I usually go for the Italian chocolate chip which I don't know how to spell. 
Yum ."]

name: Creole Creamery
categories_raw: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt
top_reviews:
['So, on a hot, eighty six degree day like this in New Orleans, I couldn't go wrong with some good ole' fashioned ice cream from the Creole Creamery. On my drive there, I went through various neighborhoods, road constructions, and even smaller food stores nearby. On my arrival, the place was hidden amongst a long narrow street with cars parked left and right. If you're looking for some excellent parking, park at the CVS Pharmacy right next to the place, and you'll be able to enjoy a short walk there!

Anyways, let's move on to the actual review! Well, I wanted the best bang for my buck, so I went for the six scoop (mini-sampler) for only $7.00 FLAT! Cash only! Not really too big of a deal for me, and I even left a tip seeing as the woman at the counter provided me with excellent customer service in regards to explaining the various items on the menu to me and offering samplers along the way! 

After shuffling through all the flavors, I narrowed it down to these six:

Honey Lavender: 
Rating: 4.2/5
The honey lavender wasn't too bad, as with a majority of their ice cream, this one was really smooth. Best enjoyed eaten inside, because if you're going for a six scoop, the heat's going to melt your ice cream pretty quickly and soon enough you'll have ice cream soup! The flavor was definitely on point, it wasn't heavy, but rather faint. Additionally, it wasn't too sweet, but in between, you'd be able to taste the lavender more than anything else!

Creole Cream Cheese:
Rating: 4/5
Whenever you get the ice cream, there will be small pieces of cream cheese inside, not an overload of it! That's just the way I like it! The name for me was somewhat off putting in that I'm not a big fan of cream cheese, but at least the ice cream was delicious. The bits and pieces of cream cheese along the way definitely made the experience worthwhile, so why not give this one a try?!

Salted Caramel: 
Rating: 3.5/5
One thing that I NEED, and I mean, absolutely NEED in my salted caramel ice cream, is the flavor and color! The salted caramel at the Creole Creamery was whitish, not the usual lightish brown I'm used to in terms of most ice cream shops. The caramel taste was light, but I didn't receive any of the "salted" flavor in the ice cream which I've previously received at other ice cream locations on the West coast. Overall, it could use more color, texture, and flavor.

Banana's Foster:
Rating: 4.75/5
What I loved about this particular flavor is the bits and pieces of small caramel and banana present in each bite I took. A hearty banana's foster on a hot day like this one is all I'd ever need to cheer me up! Not much to say about this flavor besides the fact that it tasted EXACTLY like the actual dessert, which made me smile a bit on the inside. 

Cafe Au Lait:
Rating: 4.5/5
I'm a HUGE coffee enthusiast, so trying this flavor was mandatory! The ice cream was pretty amazing, it tasted just like a freshly brewed cup of Cafe Au Lait which actually made my tastebuds fall in love with this particular scoop of ice cream. The sweetness of the ice cream wasn't overpowering, but just right! 

Pistachio: 
Rating: 3.5/5
Pistachio? Sort of difficult to pull off, but they got it sort of right. The ice cream's sort of light green, but the taste is smooth and creamy, more light then anything. 

In conclusion, my only regret is that I was on a timed schedule and didn't have enough time to sit outside the entire time to enjoy the ice cream to the full extent! If you ever have extra time, this is the perfect place to take your close friends, family, girlfriend, etc. The customer service is extremely nice, and the employees are always attentive to your needs! Don't be afraid to stop by!', "**EAT ICE CREAM. BE HAPPY.**

I didn't come to New Orleans to lose weight,
so I ordered a sundae here.

ABOUT
======
Old-school ice cream parlor offers an ever-changing variety of flavors, 
including regional specialties and fountain classics.

Creole Creamery is on Prytania in the Uptown neighborhood of New Orleans, 
near the Prytania Theater.

AMBIANCE
=========
Cute, ultra- family-friendly vibes.
Felt like 1960's vintage ice cream parlor
with neon signs and black and white
checkered tiled floors.

ICE CREAM
=========
PEANUT BUTTER FUDGE SUNDAE - $6.25
Two scoops of I Scream Fudge! ice cream served in a peanut butter-coated glass with hot fudge, chopped peanuts, whipped cream, a cherry, and a wafer.
The ice cream isn't as creamy as I would like and a bit too sweet, but the flavors were nostalgically wonderful. 
Love the sticky fudge and the cherry.
RATING: 4/5 

SERVICE
========
Friendly, not over the top.
People left us alone and was
helpful with flavors.
RATING: 4/5

OVERALL
========
Good stop after the movies at the Prytania Theater.
Great for dates and family days.

RECOMMEND.", 'Try the Skyscraper!

This is a very good place to stop by for some Southern style love and sweets. I had some of the best ice cream here. I would come back in a heart beat.

What did I have? I jad the "Skysxraper of Course!"

The Skyscraper..Creole Cream, Honey Lavender, Cookie Monster with Caramel and Hot Fudge. You get q fancy glass and extra long cold spoon for penetrating the bottom and scraping it alongside the layers of ice cream on its way up..a true spoonful makes this a fuve star treat!

They also have smaller treats that are perfect for those with less appetitie, dieting or for the little ones. Dieting sucks so try out the Red Velvet Cake Shake as the side kick for the little one.

One of the best ice cream treats I have had..the skyscraper is as good as it gets.']

name: Gyro Shack
categories_raw: Sandwiches, Restaurants, Fast Food, Greek, Mediterranean
top_reviews:
['"Where do you get your Baklava?", I asked the very nice young woman who was assisting her co-worker with my order at the window.

I was hoping for a response like "Zorba's grandmother".  Or at least a good local bakery.

When the reply was "Food Service of America, maybe.  Someplace like that." I knew this was was chain focus food not family focus food.  As I waited on my order, I set my expectations for outcome accordingly.  That said, expectations were exceeded. 

The two folks working in the kiosk / shack were very friendly and efficient and the gyro my husband and I ordered was pretty darned good.  I'm no expert on the specialty (on the subject of Italian food I could have a far more informed opinion) and I'm not really even sure I know how to eat a gyro properly.  But the Super Veggie Patty gyro, made with all the fixins' of fresh tomato, lettuce, spicy sauce (which is sricacha, I'm pretty sure), pepperoncini, feta, kalamata, hummus, avocado slices and tzatziki was nicely wrapped and boxed up to go (there is no seating here, it is a drive through) and made a nice 'splitsie' dinner at home.

When I asked about the gyro meat offered on all the options but those which are veggie, I was told it is made of a lamb and beef blend.  We were hoping for an all lamb option, (a meat we eat), instead of beef (a meat we don't eat) being included in all.  But we choose vegetarian options most of the time anyway and we were happy to see a single one, "Veggie Patty Pita", on the menu.

"Is the veggie patty like a felafal?", we asked.

"I don't know what that is", said the nice young man behind the window, "but I think this one has chickpeas in it."

Seriously.

For the record, it was like a flat falafel.

When we asked if we could get the "Veggie Pita" that came with all the fixin's like a deluxe gyro it was the nice young woman who said while no longer on the menu as it once had been, we could order and they could make a Super Veggie Patty Gyro that came with everything.

And that is the story of how we came to enjoy our tasty take out dinner.  Big enough to feed two lighter eaters for under nine bucks.  

Would we go back for take out here?  You bet.  And order the same thing again?  Happily.

Be aware "their chain shows" in some items and this is a drive through.  But if you're a gyro afficiando (we're not there yet), we imagine this is a very good place to be.

THIS N THAT:
1) Parking:  If you want to eat at the little picnic table or two at outside the shack, there is parking at the lot across the way.', "The Gyro Shack rocks it.

I enjoy both their Deluxe Chicken Gyro and their Greek Salad Pita.  

Always fresh.

Always ample.

Always delicious.

I've also ordered and enjoyed their hummus with pita bread.  A word to the wise, though--the serving size is huge.  They give you a good 12 or so ounces of hummus.  We enjoyed it for days (definitely not complaining!).  The prices are amazing.  Three of us each got a gyro, and shared the hummus side for less than $20!

Also?  The service is Michael Phelps in the pool fast.  Which is to say, they deserve several Olympic medals for the speed of service (especially considering how fresh and wonderful everything they're serving is).  You drive up, order, and a couple short minutes later you're driving away, food in hand.  I'll take The Gyro Shack over many other forms of fast food any day of the week.

Get to it!", "What's super sad about this place is the new owners don't seem to understand what made it great. For what it WAS I'd give it 5 stars, happy fast service, great food! They have the best gyros, certainly the best in Boise. The Z is delicious and the super is huge and excellent every time! Lamb, bacon, pita bread and veggies are always fresh and on point. What made it popular was that it was talked about by everyone, and I mean everyone, how it was such a great deal. A place with low overhead that built its loyal clients by actually passing savings along to them. I like the new menu concept simplified with pictures and all. The new owners raised the prices of all the gyros and specials etc. I think the sides are all the same but .50 for a couple tomato slices or peppers is overpriced anyway.

Overall it's still delicious and I'll come back for sure, just not as often. You used to be able to feed two people for about $10-12, now it's over $14-17. I get it, just a few bucks but that's a 30-40 percent increase. I guess I just think it's too bad the prices are the same as a if they had a restaurant overhead. Mazzah down the street is $2 less for nearly the same gyro, and way more overhead, no kidding.

Bottom line: still great flavor and quality, but it seems the new ownership has put price ahead of its loyal customer base. (Maybe they had to, I don't know, but I hope they stay in business and I hope things work out!)"]

name: Shangri-La Bath & Sauna
categories_raw: Health & Medical, Saunas, Sports Clubs, Hotels & Travel, Active Life, Beauty & Spas, Resorts, Day Spas, Food
categories: ['health & medical', 'saunas', 'sports clubs', 'hotels & travel', 'active life', 'beauty & spas', 'resorts', 'day spas', 'food']
top_reviews:
["Sketchy factor rating scale of 1-10

Upon arrival into parking lot=15

Not gonna lie----the sketchy radar did pop up as I parked my car and looked around.  Then again I went around 9pm on a Friday---so I'm thinking that might be expected.  At first glance you might be inclined to think that this is one of those creepy rub and tugs with the strangely blacked out windows and sticky floors.

Boy was I wrong.  I'm not a Korean bath house virgin but will admit that I have been to some larger venues so wasn't completely sure what to expect here.

Let me start off by saying that the hospitality here was amaze-a-balls!   Generally when I visit Korean bath houses/restaurants/grocery stores---hospitality is definitely not the first word that comes to mind----but that mind set was very different here.  Took a visit here with my brother.  We were greeted upon entry.  The woman checking us in was very pleasant and asked if it was our first time.  We let her know it was our first visit to this location and she gave us all the details.

Shoes go in the first set of locker cubbies.  Then your clothing belongings go in the second set of lockers.  Wet area was on the small side, there is one hot whirlpool and one cold whirlpool.  The shower area was ample and there was a steam room.  I pretty much had the place to myself so that was pretty cool.  

There are two heated treatment rooms, salt room and clay room--each having different properties that would help me work on my health.  The rooms were on the warmer side but I'm thinking that's to help the elements penetrate your body---or something to that affect.  Whatever it was----it definitely helped clear up my sinuses!  

They have a few relaxation rooms (basically a nice place to just lay down and chill/sleep)  They offer a variety of treatments---body scrubs, facials, massages (I didn't partake in any but will try next time around).

Of course as we're roaming back and forth between the sauna rooms, watching some tv----we start to get hungry------tada! There is a food area----it was about 10pm and the lights were off----my stomach was telling me otherwise-----as we walked around, found a gentlemen carrying some items to the kitchen, so of course we decided to follow him while trying not to look like we were stalking the Korean food goodies----when I asked him what time the food area normally closed he said it was still open and was more than happy to cook up some dishes.

Score!

We had the mandu dumplings, seafood pancake, and kim chae jagae---wowza!!!  The portions were pretty big and the food was very good.  Late night dining that definitely hit the spot!  As a bonus we got a plate of pineapple and sliced apples to close off our meal.   

We had an awesomely non-sketchy experience!!!! Hooray for the little things in life.", 'Well like to start off by saying this place is amazing! When we first arrived just like everyone else I was thinking it looked a little sketchy, but as soon as we walked in the door my wife and I were greeted by the Korean woman who was so friendly it scared me. She went through the "menu" and informed us of everything that was going to happen.

We opted for the gold package since it was her first time and was instructed to go to separate locker rooms so that we can strip down and put on our spa clothes. After that we immediately met up for late dinner in the full restaurant at the back of the spa.

The food was OK I guess I would say so so unless you're into Korean food. What we ordered was pretty decent especially the teriyaki chicken. The red wine was served cold but as soon as I informed him he switched it out for some room temperature red. 

After dinner we each went our separate ways for our body scrub And boy did they scrub! The lady who was working on me pointed out several times a pile of dead skin that I did not know I had. She worked on me for at least one hour including bathing me in some type of milky oil and when I came out I felt like a newborn baby.

I did my time in the hot tub and the cold tub as well as the steam sauna but was eager to meet up with my wife again in the community room.

I think it is important to point out that while the lady was doing my body scrub I was provided with a pair of swimming shorts which I actually was able to wear the entire time I was in the wet area. There were a few other people there for other guys that I counted on a late Saturday night and a lot of Asian women in the community area.

I have been fighting sinus congestion and nasal congestion for a couple weeks but after five minutes in the salt Sama I noticed I could breathe easier and my sinuses are clear. I should have stayed in the soul so the longer but I needed to go. We actually signed up for couples massage but change my mind after I see my hot wife in the sauna LOL. 

We hailed an Uber and made it home just in time to relieve the babysitter before we had our adult time. 

She has already made arrangements to take her neighbor friend back to the spa in a couple of days LOL

This is truly a gem hidden in Tampa Bay! I will definitely be back. I highly recommend this location to anyone looking for something out of the ordinary and extremely relaxing, refreshing, and rejuvenating!

Also this place was as "anti-sexual oriented" as Walmart. Families are welcome and no one should fear being approached or propositioned or made to feel uncomfortable here. 100% safe in my opinion', "If you're a fan of Korean spas and have visited more than one, then there's a good chance that you'll be disappointed here. I feel bad leaving a less than amazing review, because the people truly were lovely, and spa-wise it was okay for the area, but if you've been to any other Korean spa, this might seem like a let down.

First, the size. The check-in area is like any other, not big, not small, and there process is much the same you'll find anywhere else. Now, when you get into the actual spa, that's where things get a little...interesting.

It's very small in the spa. Extremely small, actually. There is ONE hot tub. One. And it didn't have jets. There is also one cold tub. There is a small steam room (which was nice and hot, I must say) where you have to turn on the steam, it doesn't just stay on. And there are two small banks of shower areas (which honestly need to be cleaned), and a small massage area. That's it. There is no sauna, there is no place to sit and relax in the spa, and there are no other hot tubs.

Again, if you're used to other Korean spas, where there is usually a selection of hot tubs and a sauna and some chairs for lounging, be aware that you won't get those things here.

However, the rest of the spa was a nice size. The common areas are as spacious as you'll find in all but the biggest spas, as is the eating area. Okay, I have to take a minute to talk about the food. There seems to be one older gentleman working there who makes the food. He shops locally and brings in fresh food twice a day. That food? Was LIT. It was amazing, and I've eaten in every Korean spa I've ever been in, from L.A. to Washington state. This man's food was fantastic. Treat yo'self.

The salt room in the common area was really quite nice, and just like any other. It was nice and hot, and just what I needed. The clay room was noticeably less hot, but it's nice to have a choice. There was also an ice room.

So, if you're used to Korean spas, don't go expecting what you've experienced elsewhere. It seems that they're the only one in the area, so hopefully they build a big clientele that allows them to expand!

But seriously, try that food."]

name: 1 Tippling Place
categories_raw: Bars, Nightlife, Lounges, Cocktail Bars
top_reviews:
['Strangest thing about Philly - there's no standing room around bars. If there's no seats available, they don't let you sit.  Or maybe that's just 1 Tippling.  I came here to wait after putting my name down at Ranstead for 2 seats at the bar, walked up to the bar, and was rudely told by the bartender that were no seats available and to go somewhere else.  Two patrons at the bar told me they were leaving and I could have their seats and he said "actually there's people in front of you".  They told me not to listen to him and I could have their seats, because he had sent everyone else away in the same manner, and there was no one else. So, I stood and chatted with them for 10-15 minutes, and when they left, I took their seats and he seemed to have no problem with it.  

From there, everything was fine.  The cocktails were okay (not one of the best old fashioned's I've had) and there was no more rudeness, so I still left a 20% tip on 3 drinks. The place itself is very charming and cute - I loved the vibe - cozy yet hip.  Were it not for that initial encounter I'd definitely give it 4 stars, but given the rudeness level I just can't.', "Beautiful speakeasy in Rittenhouse right by the shopping strip. Despite the lack of a hidden entrance, this place is unpretentious and has the comfy couches, oil paintings, and ambience of one! Menu was in thick bound leather and priced more reasonably than the other speakeasies in the area. I got the tequila honeysuckle (with lime and honey) as in my picture and it was super strong and sour, with a tinge of sweet, in the best way possible! Service was great without being overbearing. Definitely come here if you're in Rittenhouse or looking for a speakeasy you can actually find!", 'Generally when I'm sitting at my desk working my soul sucking corporate job and I start jonesing for something 9 out of 10 times its wings, and then the 1 out of 10 is sushi to complete the craving equation. Last Wednesday was different, things were a bit stressful and I needed something stronger than buffalo and more fulfilling than spicy tuna, I needed a Bluecoat martini.   

Luckily I was meeting a buddy that night for drinks and instead of going to some of my normal haunts I wanted to go to a cocktail place. Hop Sing isn't relaxing enough for me and 1TP was just a few blocks up from my office so it was the chosen one. I arrived before my pal and upon entering it was like I walked through the back of closet and into Narnia if Narnia was a den inside of Downton Abbey. This was a far cry from the mess of a setup Jollys used to have. Comfy couches with coffee tables along the walls, WASPy accents, it was set up to encourage group interaction. 

I made my way to the back and sat at a table by the bar. A very friendly bartender / waiter gave me the menu and as I paged through it my desire for Bluecoat was overtaken by the incredible array of cocktails they had. As a disclaimer I shouldn't have been out, I had laryngitis which was turning into bronchitis but I wasn't letting that hold me down. I ordered a gin cocktail with lemon and ginger. I took one sip and it was like a dude in the Alps blew a horn and shouted "RICCOLAAAA". It was a true elixir, my sore throat went away and I was able to speak! For my next cocktail I was having trouble deciding because all of the options sounded great so I explained to the nonjudgmental bartender my throat situation and he said he's got just the thing. He brought me another gin drink with herbs, cayenne extract, with a piece of cystalized ginger in it. The first drink loaded the bases, the second was a Matt Stairs moon shot into right field. 

The people are uber friendly, the environment is relaxed and comfortable, the drinks are amazing, and they have a cream chipped beef and corn chip casserole, what else could you ask for?']

name: Passero's Coffee Roasters
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Restaurants, Food, Coffee Roasteries, Sandwiches
top_reviews:
["Still some of the best coffee in the city - and still a line (that moved pretty quickly) every morning in Suburban Station.

Pricey but so much better than Dunkin or Charbucks.

The Café au Lait and Lattes (the will used your favorite type of cows or nut milk) are so delicious.  Like dessert in a cup for breakfast (and I don't even get any flavored syrups - just a plain latte or au lait is so creamy and sweet.)

Yum!!!!", "I'm hooked. 

This is my go-to before work morning coffee place.  Despite its unfortunate Suburban concourse location, it's accessible and almost a straight shot from subway to work, so it's a no-brainer for me.

Beans are solid, coffee is dark, deep and strong, like my soul. (ha!)

Why ever, ever, go to Dunkin' Donuts when you've got Passero nearby?

The people here are seriously the tops.  Always, super, ridiculously friendly, quick with a smile - and because, you know I frequent the joint on a daily basis, they always remember my order (now that's service!).

Nary a wait, don't be discouraged by any queue that forms here, the team works like a well-oiled machine.

As for grub: lots of baked goods, plenty of vegan/gluten-free options, some serious soups for lunch time - they offer a little bit of everything for everyone.

So, yeah, the coffee is a bit more expensive, but it's worth it to shell out extra coinage for good brew and attentive, lovely service.  The only way to start your Monday morning.", "I'm excited Passero's is back!  The caramel mocha ($3 for 12 oz) is very, very strong.  I could barely open my eyes when I ordered it and 1 hour later I feel like the energizer bunny.  Good thing I ordered a small!

I also picked up a locally baked, vegan, gluten free pumpkin pistachio muffin ($3).  It sounded good at the time, granted I was half asleep.  I excitedly brought it to the office to share with a coworker, but it turned out to be possibly the worst baked good I've ever tasted.  I'm embarrassed I shared it and think I may have lost a friend!  It was bland, salty and slightly bitter.  Play dough comes to mind.  

Friendly service and terrific coffee.  Right now it's cash only, but I think they're working on that."]

name: Barrio Brewing
categories_raw: Nightlife, Sports Bars, Bars, Breweries, Pubs, Restaurants, American (Traditional), Food
top_reviews:
["Always a good choice for food, happy hour or just drinks (not just beer).. hidden off Toole only minutes from downtown.. this place is truly a hidden gem. 

I usually have a burger or sandwich with fries when I visit, but they have great salads and happy hour deals also.. wings, potato skins, chicken strips.. etc

On my recent visit I had the black & blue burger .. Cajun spice with Gorgonzola.. first of all it's huge! The menu says it's spicy.. I didn't think so.

I paired it with a salad .. even though I wanted the fries.. because they are delicious .. as are the onion rings or beer battered fries.. I also enjoy their barrio margarita with Tajín rim. 

They do also sell beer to-go. The hostess is waiting for you outside, she gets you seated right away.. inside, outside & bar seating available. Wait staff is friendly, I've never had a long wait for food or drinks.", "The food was alright. I got the baja fish tacos. We also got a carne quesadilla and a kid's grilled cheese. 

Our server wasn't around much, but I don't blame her because the patrons at the table next to us were kinda creepy. Luckily, we didn't need much this time around.

The beer was great. I love the Barrio Rojo.", "My guide to visiting a new city: Step 1:  Go the top rated brewery.  Step 2: Ask them if they do flights or tastings.  The rest of the steps will take care of themselves.

Barrio Brewery is full of character and flavor.  Situated in a rather run down warehouse just south of town, Barrio seems to be doing good things for an area that is mostly industrial.  If you're a fan of breweries, you have to see this one, exterior to interior they have done a great job at making many understated improvements to the old gal.  Gorgeous copper and wood adorn the interior, with a great view of the mountains and passing trains from the bar.  A long porch, adorned with re-bar sculpted like branches curbs the front.

Beer here is served in a wide variety of brews, in total they had 10 on tap.  For $10 we did a tasting of all them.  Blond, Amber, IPA, Hef, Citrus Pilsner, Raspberry Lager, Porter, Oatmeal Stout and NCAAsomething which was 10% and awesome.

Food was brief, but we did have some fries and I had the Sonoran Dog.  Now, a lot of people trash Tucson for this tradition, but that dog was the business.  When I die I want the treatment this dog got: wrap me in bacon, mayo me up and cover me with pinto beans, yes please.  The dog comes with a grilled hot pepper that is no joke, seriously tasty, serious burn.

Barrio is an excellent intro to Tucson.  Great service, nice mix of crowd and enough T.V.s to watch the end of the game while your night starts."]

name: Gachi Sushi and Noodle
categories_raw: Noodles, Japanese, Restaurants, Sushi Bars
top_reviews: ["Nice service, they offer cleaner and fresher food. I wouldn't eat D graded sushi at the airport but the Tonkastu ramen wasn't bad at all.", "It was pretty early in the morning but I had already been up for 4 hours so I wasn't in the mood for breakfast. I appreciated that Gachi had some lunch options on the menu that early because most places didn't. The chicken and rice bowl was pretty basic but hit the spot... white sticky rice and some grilled chicken with a little sauce. They were already prepared in a heated cabinet so there was no wait. I did get some gyoza as well which had to be cooked. It wasn't great but the chicken bowl was plenty on its own.", "I've actually been to Gachi at the BWI airport before and had great sushi and customer service there, so I was really excited to find one at PHL in the International terminal (A West). When I came here, I got the volcano roll and the miso soup with crab stix. I absolutely love spicy mayo and it was drizzled all over this volcano roll just the right amount. The taste reminded me of my favorite sushi back home! I was also pleasantly surprised by the portion size for how much it was. I've been to other sushi places at airports that charge around the same for very small rolls of 6 pieces. The most unique item was definitely the miso soup with crab stix added (Make sure you ask for it). Most restaurants serving miso soup always give you that generic miso paste mixed with water and only three to four pieces of tofu and nori thrown in. If you go to Japanese restaurants often, I'm sure you know what I'm talking about. The miso soup at Gachi, however, cannot even be compared to any other miso soup. The serving size was great and I literally could not get enough of the flavor and all the ingredients inside (I ordered this twice because it was just that good!!). Overall, the food experience was amazing - and the staff were super friendly too! 10/10 would recommend."]

name: Century Gateway 12
categories_raw: Arts & Entertainment, Cinema, Event Planning & Services, Venues & Event Spaces
top_reviews:
['I love cheap theaters. As my family is about to grow to 6 in November every dollar counts. The Gateway specializes in movies that have been out for a little while already giving you a discounted chance to see  blockbusters on the big screen before  they go to video. The  prices are really reasonable at $3.25. The best deal is to go on Tuesdays when all tickets are $1!', "The movies here are so cheap! Plus they just redid the seats! My husband and I always come here before it gets packed, we were two of 6 people in the theatre. The snack bar is your normal, out of this world expensive, movie snack stand. I love that this location isn't as popular, it makes for a nice date night! The only thing I could comment on about being out of whack is the ladies bathroom. I opened up three stalls with either toilets that weren't flushed, or they looked like a biohazard. No paper towels. I turned around and walked out, I was not about to catch anything! The service you receive is alright, mostly teenagers and college kids. It's a hit and miss, depending in the person. Overall I would come back!", 'Price: $3.50 is cheap to go see a movie.

Concessions: No cheaper than any other theater.

Sound: The sound quality is not a good as regular theaters, which you would expect.

Movie screen: See comments on sound.

Seats: They have obviously upgraded since the last time I was here. They are at least comfortable enough to fall asleep in, which I did.

Overall experience: You get what you pay for.']

name: Riverside Day Spa & Nails
categories_raw: Nail Salons, Beauty & Spas, Massage, Day Spas
top_reviews:
["Big thank you to Ashley, who did an amazing mani/pedi while I was in NOLA on vacation! Had a few hours to kill, it was raining outside, what else is a girl to do on an early Friday afternoon?

Yes, I could've started happy hour early. But I'm of the mind set that partying in New Orleans is a marathon, not a sprint! 

There are plenty of nail salon options in the French Quarter near the big hotels. Lots of the spas require a reservation and are pretty pricey. Riverside seemed A-OK and a mani/pedi costs less than $50. With tip. 

Opi, Essie and shellac polishes are available. I tend to stick with the basics, nothing too fancy. The manicure lasted over a week and pedi still going strong, no chips or flaws as of yet. 

A nice, relaxing experience in the middle of a Party Rockin' neighborhood. Who would've thunk it?", "My review is for the massage I received at this spa. My boyfriend decided to get me a massage for my birthday. We were in Nola visiting his brother and therefore unfamiliar with the spas. He also wanted one and after calling around the day of, this is where we ended up. He said his was good but not great, he received his from a nice young girl. I on the other had had the most awkward and unprofessional, downright creepy experience of my life. The appt. was for 5 and like another reviewer they tried to get us to come in at 4:30 with a phone call. We declined. We arrived at five and were led upstairs by a man and a woman. The woman was in scrubs and clearly a masseuse. The man was a average build Asian man in dress type clothes, dress shoes, and a pager on his belt who I assessed to be the owner. We were led to the rooms and to my surprise the owner told me to disrobe and he'd be back. Taken aback I stammered that I'd like him to focus on my neck and shoulders as they were sore. I have had massages before by a male masseuse, but I was always asked before I booked the appointment if I was comfortable with a male, and they were always very obviously massage therapists. The situation I found myself in was totally unprofessional. I was not asked if I minded a male and I am positive he was not a massage therapists. In fact it was totally messed up that the legit female masseuse worked on my boyfriend while I was stuck with the skeevy owner. There I was lying naked under the thinnest sheet, not even a nice thick one that is used in nice spas but a cheap thin sheet. I had questions about the legitimacy of the whole production before he began the massage but the minute he started I knew there was no way he was a licensed massage therapist. He was awkward and totally unskilled, he just kept running his hands up and down my back. Mind you putting no pressure on me, it could have been a caress. His belt buckle (at least that's what I kept telling myself) kept pressing into my head. His crotch grazed my hands on multiple occasions. I was as rigid as could be thinking about how disgusting and uncomfortable the scenario I was in actually was. If you recall I specifically asked for work on my neck and shoulders, they were totally neglected. After a few minutes in I thought I would just tell him I only want a half an hour massage. I don't know why I was so afraid to speak up, I should have ended it. The worst parts where when he would lift the sheet to put my arm back under, he lifted it very high, far higher than was necessary I feel to get a flash of my rear. Also, when he was massaging my legs his hands kept grazing my rear. The only part I actually could almost relax for was at the end when he was doing my feet. But by then he was making conversation the first question was about my hair color!?! Then he went on about football actually engaging me in a conversation about a sport I have zero interest in, making the only possible enjoyable part of the massage an utter let down. To add total insult to injury, the massage cost 90 dollars (and I'll be darned we tipped him 10!! The curse of being a polite mid-westerner by birth) I speculate when my boyfriend called to make the appt. the accepted both of us, with only one masseuse on staff, so the owner decided to fill in. The guy is an utter pervert and the spa is unethical and creepy. Unless you want to feel like he should have paid you for the privilege of groping your body, DO NOT GO HERE. In fact, the more I think about it the more I am so mad I didn't make a complaint.", 'My fiance wanted to get a massage and never has the time. He works long hours and often on the weekends. So he called me from work on a Friday afternoon and said "Babe I'm off tomorrow, schedule us a massage." Needless to say, at the last minute no one had anything open. I called around to a lot of places. 

So I stumbled across Riverside online and most of the reviews were good. Lucky for us they had a 5pm opening for 2 people. Now I had asked for a couples massage but the pleasant lady on the phone said that it really wouldn't be a couples massage cuz we'd be in separate room. I thought okay fine. 

So the day of our appointment, a man called to confirm and asked me if I can come in early at 4 instead of 5...I was pretty busy so I said I would try but dont really count on it. So around 4:30 the man called again and asked if we were on our way....my fiance answered the phone and told him yea we're coming. then the man said we were "supposed" to be there at 4pm. NOT. So of course I'm starting to get a little antsy cuz I'm thinking they're trying to rush us or they're going to try to shorten our massage. 

Well we finally make it. And it looks like a nail shop. The place isn't fancy at all. But it is neat and clean. I noticed that they didn't have us fill out any paperwork (usually with spas they have just a small questionnaire about your health). So they escort us upstairs via elevator and we go in our separate rooms. 

Now I'm used to calm, quite and relaxing when getting a massage but the lady I had was a chatty Kathy. She gave a good massage,,but she wouldn't shut up. Her name was Leila, and while miss girl worked wonders with those hands and stones, I still really didn't enjoy it fully because she talked to damn much. And then she talked about the owners. Umm, how classy and professional is that? 

My fiance said his was ok but that he didn't see himself going back. He said his room had a window in it so he heard all the noise from the French Quarter. 

So while the ladies were talented....it was still just an ok experience.']

name: SOHO Cycling
categories_raw: Active Life, Fitness & Instruction, Gyms, Cycling Classes
top_reviews:
["Michelle has an amazing studio and I highly recommend each and every one of her spinning instructors.  Not only do they offer the best in sound and video quality I've experienced in a cycling facility, but the instructors bring something amazing to each one of their classes.  Each instructor is different and has their own personality, music and style that they bring to the bike.  

A superb online reservation system allows members and non members to select and reserve their exact seat for their upcoming spinning classes.  Michelle is notorious for being active in the community with fundraisers and charity events.  There are often charity rides at the studio that are a lot of fun and offer several hours of sweating for those that enjoy that kind of torture (I kid).  

I highly recommend this studio.  I just wish I lived closer.", "Soho Cycling is hands down the best spin studio. The staff is welcoming, inviting and professional. The classes are upbeat and instructors motivating. I literally get lost in the music and the ride. Before I know it the class is over. I truly love it here and can't imagine ever leaving.  You may sign up for your classes in advance online and choose your bike. This is so nice.  What is even nicer is they provide towels at no cost, have water available for purchase, have two bathrooms which are kept immaculate, offer free ear-plugs and hair ties. They allow you to cancel a class up to an hour before start time. Other studios require 24 hours or more. My schedule can change in a blink of an eye so I like the fact that Soho Cycling realizes this about people and gives you the option to cancel at the last minute without being charged. It is a very upscale studio. They are active in the community. It is great to see a successful business give back to its city.  They also  give back to their customers by hosting social gatherings on a regular basis, after class, at near by establishments.  Once you experience what they have to offer you'll be hooked. Michelle has a first class spinning  studio.", "This studio is amazing! I love that you reserve a bike in advance or if there is a seat open, you can come & sign in. I hate getting to the gym and having to fight to get in the cycle room years in advance to ensure I have a seat!

SoHo has a fabulous website for scheduling, info, etc. It's great that I can plan my week and schedule classes with favorite instructors/times.

The facility itself is immaculate. Super clean, awesome vibe, encouraging instructors, blowy fans and a booming sound system....winner! And classy. Oh yes.

You know you have taken a great class when leftover makeup is running down your face & 600 plus calories are gone and the hour flew by.... (Thx Eric! I heart your music choices!). Gentlemen, I hope your makeup stays intact :)

Go at least once! Your first ride is free!"]

name: Chubbie's Fried Chicken
categories_raw: Fast Food, Sandwiches, Restaurants, Chicken Wings, Seafood
top_reviews:
["This was a really tough call, but I think I'm going to go with three stars on this one.

All this talk about the best fried chicken in New Orleans got my inner fat kid hungry, and since one of the candidates is located right in Algiers, I decided to head over and try it for myself. Now, when you go to Chubbie's don't expect bells and whistles. It's just a small store with a few tables where you walk up to order and wait a few minutes for your food to be ready. Yes, it's an old Popeyes that has been converted into another chicken place.

I went in for lunch and placed an order for a two piece white with potato salad, a drink and a biscuit. There wasn't much of a crowd, so there wasn't much of a wait. When my food came out, I was delighted at how crispy the chicken looked. There was seriously a thick layer of crust on the breast, the likes of which I rarely see. As I dug into the chicken, I noticed that it was perfectly cooked to tender perfection. The meat fell off of the bone and there was plenty of it.  The skin was light and crispy and practically melted in my mouth.  My only real complaint with the chicken was that there was no spice added to it. I like my fried chicken to have a bit of a kick (I am a Southern girl, after all) and this chicken had no kick at all. It was without a kick.

Also, the potato salad tasted store bought. I apologize right now if it wasn't. Maybe I am super picky when it comes to potato salad, because I've had the homemade stuff. While it was good, I think I will opt for the mashed potatoes next time.  

All in all, for a little over $6, my meal was good and I enjoyed it, I left Chubbie's satisfied and promising myself that I would eat healthy for the rest of the week. I wouldn't hesitate to return to Chubbie's with a bottle of hot sauce in tow.

If chicken isn't your thing, Chubbie's has daily hot plate specials as well as poboys, burgers, salads and other sandwiches. They even have a drive thru!", '5 for the chicken, 2 for the sides 3.5 overall.

Dear Chubbies, 
You have some of the best fried chicken and livers I've ever had the pleasure of eating. And as the eating superhero Fatman, I do love some good fried chicken. Your chicken reminds me of what KFC was in the 70s before every ingredient turned into a chemical. It's crispy, juicy, and the flavor isn't just in the skin, it's "Deep Down Delicious(tm)". 

Your sides, sadly, usually leave a lot to be desired. It's like you know how amazing your chicken is so everything else is an after-thought.  The onion rings have no spice, the potato salad is kind of a sad joke and the fries are soggier than Aquaman's jock strap. 

You can do much better.

Except for those biscuits, of course. You should probably register them as sex offenders because every time I eat one, it touches me in my naughty parts.

But please do yourself, and all of us who love you, a major favor,  Work on your side dishes.


Oh, and please get with your drive through employees and tell them to calm the crap down. They rush you so fast you can't even get time to come up with your order. And if you ask for a second, they will leave you waiting for 10 minutes without coming back to you. Seriously, we were getting honked at for not pulling up but the entire time, we were waiting for the girl to come back and take our order.
After all that waiting, we still ended up waiting in the drive through an additional 15 minutes before getting our food.', 'My first time here. I felt like I went back in time when I first entered the place. But anyway I received my food and took it back to my truck. It smelled so good I started eating right there in the parking lot. The chicken was fresh and seasoned well. The white beans were delicious and the biscuit soft and fluffy. Will most def visit again.']

name: Harkins Theatres  Tucson Spectrum 18
categories_raw: Cinema, Arts & Entertainment
top_reviews:
["A-ha! I was right! As it turns out, the screen has about a million little holes so that it won't move around with the air. There are some bolts or something that this screen is attached to. The part of these bolts that faces the audience is painted black so that it won't reflect light. All except ONE. The one I saw. The one that bothered me to no end. They looked into it because of me, thankyouverymuch. The manager called me and said he couldn't believe no one had said anything before, thanked me for pointing it out and sent us some free tickets. You're welcome. My critical eye is always available.
-Groan- . . . .  if only someone would open a Harkins in Vail.", 'This theater is very nice and good surround system in this place ! Very luxury on the southern of Tucson az.  If you never know this place please need to try it .', 'Checking the listings for still-available Harry Potter tickets went something like this . . . . sold out, sold out, sold out, sold out, sold out, oh wait . . . Harkins Theater? Oh what street? Oh yeah, are these the new theaters around Irvington? Why isn't it sold out there?!?! I concluded that the reason was that the theaters are too far (because I assume that everyone starts off driving from my house). Buying tickets was a breeze. There was NO ONE in line. NO ONE. (since I didn't want to pay the "inconvenience fee" online) 
We situated ourselves and I promptly sent my husband to get the concession goodies. Had I known about the loyalty cup, I would have told him. I am just now finding out about this. Thanks, Jennifer! I don't know how long the lines were, but he wasn't gone very long. The theater is spacious, new, great sound and there are screens hanging down in the corridors showing previews. "A theater of the future" was what I was calling it. 
I have one major gripe, though. During the previews, I noticed a small white dot on the top/middle of the giant screen. I figured this would disappear once the feature began, but that wasn't so. It looked like a tiny rip in the screen. I can't imagine what else it could have been. Something from the projector? I saw it in theater 1, by the way, in case you want to see for yourself. Anyway, this dot pestered me throughout the movie. You know once you see something that bothers you and you can't ignore it try as you might? Yeah, that's how it was. What was worse is that sometimes it looked as though it might have been part of the movie . . . . a sparkling in Luna's glasses (sneakoscopes, for fellow geeks, er, um, fans), a star in a dark sky, an adornment in someone's hair. You get the gist. I hope they fix this because it is very, very distracting. Otherwise, this place it great. Far for me, but great. 
I can only hope that with the opening of yet another theater, some other films - not just blockbusters- will be available to us somewhere other than in The Loft. It would be a great change to be able to view a nice indy flick in a state-of-the art theater. Well . . .  one can dream.

***** I didn't use it, but this place has a "playcenter" daycare. Yes. It. Does. It's for kids 3-8 and is $6 per child. They have a little video on their website. I would have loved something like this before I actually had kids because I hated to hear someone else's crying/screaming kids while I was trying to watch a movie and now that I have kids because I still hate to hear someone else's crying/screaming kids while trying to watch a movie. (as we've only taken ours to age appropriate movies and they haven't cried/screamed). Because of that, we've missed out at loads of movies we've wanted to see and have to wait until my parents are in town or it comes out in DVD. This playcenter deal sounds very convenient.']

name: The Naked Peach Waxing Boutique
categories_raw: Spray Tanning, Skin Care, Makeup Artists, Beauty & Spas, Hair Removal, Waxing, Tanning, Teeth Whitening
categories: ['spray tanning', 'skin care', 'makeup artists', 'beauty & spas', 'hair removal', 'waxing', 'tanning', 'teeth whitening']
top_reviews:
["I'm not sure if the franchise owner reads these comments, but I feel the Naked Peach is a few changes short of its potential. 

There are currently three ways to make an appointment; you can email, call or text. I'm surprised in today's world of technology they haven't decided to offer online booking, it would improve the customer experience. I find their text system hit or miss, there have been times I never receive a response and end up calling to book, which defeats the purpose.

When arriving for an appointment, the lobby is well decorated with snacks and retail items for purchase. They now have a sign at the desk asking you to sign in, but it's a bit odd seeing 1 - 2 receptionists who are  sitting there, not really welcoming you or adding to your visit. For example, the sheet asks for your technician's name, but I rarely know when I book. I leave it blank, and there's no acknowledgment of whether I'm actually signed in. You then take a seat and sit there until your Waxer calls your name (which you wouldn't know as a first time guest.)

This is where the experience goes from 3.5/4 stars to 3, your technician tells you which room to step in...and that's it. There's no instructions on whether to disrobe, how much, where to put your clothing/purse, when the tech will be in, how to lie or even a modesty cover. So you're left awkwardly taking your bottoms off and holding them over your private parts until someone knocks and comes in.

The waxing experience widely varies based on the tech. I've had completely silent appointments, devoid of direction or conversation, and people who distracted me from pain with their pleasant personalities. Some seem like amateurs, leaving tons of hair, agitation and bleeding; others get everything they can. The varying personalities could be solved by adding a white noise machine or sound system with music (preference for spa sounds) to each room to create a better ambience.

It's clear they work under time constraints, but it's even more uncomfortable at the end. You're asked if almond oil is okay, a tiny bit is slathered on your aching hoo-ha, then they ask if you want a beverage and leave the room. Prior to leaving the room, they could really benefit from discussing aftercare options since they sell a bunch in the lobby. I'm not sure about other people, but I don't want to talk about the merits of vaginal exfoliation at the public checkout desk. There's usually a pile of discarded hairy strips and an open trash can full of other people's hair strips. I'd strongly encourage management to implement a discard policy (throw strips away while working,) and invest in a closed top can with a foot pedal. If would facilitate a feeling of cleanliness. 

When leaving, the checkout could also be streamlined. Currently they wait for you to approach the counter and ask if you want to buy anything. Ideally, they would greet you, ask how everything went, then offer to schedule your next appointment. A simple suggestion box or customer feedback card next to the desk would offer the opportunity for customers to discretely provide input on their experience that day or technician without resorting to public forums like Yelp.

All in all, I come here because it's affordable with the monthly membership and the wax service is quick. With that said, I may consider their other services if they made some improvements.", "I think I've entered a new realm of Yelping with this one folks: Shauna gets her first Brazilian wax. 
Let's start by saying that things in the body hair department for me were a hot mess (or maybe just a mess) before Friday evening (what a wild Friday, right?). Being an incredibly anxious person, I researched the hell out of waxing before selecting The Naked Peach for my wax. If you've ever googled 'Brazilian wax' you already know you will be greeted with a montage of stories which make this sound like it's next on the pain scale to being hit by a truck and bleeding out slowly. I read about tons of people who did some combination of the following: puked, fainted, screamed, cried, left mid wax, were left without flesh, etc. Not exactly reassuring. 
I walked in The Peach after scheduling via Yelp earlier in the week (very timely with responding). I purchased a Groupon for a discount for new clients (only good for 1st time visitors). I checked in at the front desk and was offered drinks/snacks. My tech, Kay, was running approx 15 minutes late (wasn't a big deal to me) so I sat in the waiting area for a bit. I observed a few other folks checking in and the process is very streamline. This location is very busy and they set appointments every 15 minutes so they only have a 5 minute grace period for late arrivals. I love this, because I despise late folks (sorry). The shop itself is cute and clean.
When my tech greeted me, she introduced herself and I informed her my anxiety. She made me feel comfortable and explained how the wax would go. I will spare you the details but I was very surprised at how not awful the whole thing was. I kept expecting it to get more painful and then, just like that we were done. Kay was very kind and chatted casually with me throughout the whole thing. 
Afterwards, I was given aftercare instructions and some samples of products offered. I booked a follow up appointment and was given information about Peach Club a monthly program were $35 is removed from an account of your choice and credited to your waxing account (Regular Brazilian would be $55 without club pricing). I didn't sign up but was told if I do at next visit I can still access that price at the time of the visit. 
Overall, I was really pleased with the experience and feel comfortable and confident.", "For a Brazilian wax, I highly highly recommend. They are often crowded and its a tiny shop but they keep customers moving in and out. Everyone is masked but most importantly my buns are soft and silky!!!
I have been getting Brazilians for years and sometimes they can leave me feeling ewww. But here, they have truly mastered their craft. They even give great products for post-care. I now swear by the walnut scrub and post-wax gel. I'll be going back regularly!"]

name: Sucre Table
categories_raw: Bakeries, Custom Cakes, Food, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Due to pricing, 4.5 stars (rounded up). If cost is not a factor for you, easily a 5-star review. I had placed this bakery in my "Must Try" Collection months ago due to its excellent reviews & my love for anything sweet. Today I was in the area on business & decided to stop in. I'm happy I did. 

This sweet shoppe is open Tues thru Friday 9 AM to 5 PM, & Saturdays from 10 AM to 6 PM. Owner & award-winning pastry Chef Brenda is professionally trained in French pastries, which is apparent w/ each bite of her beautiful creations. She is a two-time Food Network Challenge Winner. She is also a graduate of the esteemed Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, New York. Due to her desire for others to "indulge in the true meaning of the art of pastries," she masters in "modern, minimalist & flavorful" decedent creations. 

The menu includes 8 pastries & 3 cake slices. The $10 Chocolate Praline was WONDERFUL w/ its salted caramel; chocolate; creme brulee; & hazelnut. (It didn't make it all the way home:). The Devils Blackberry Cake slice @ $12 w/ its blackberry marmalade mousse & fresh blackberries was just as DELICIOUS. It was so RICH that I stopped after two bites. The menu includes 11 baked goods. The $8.50 Triple Chocolate Bread Pudding was VERY GOOD. (A sweet sauce on top would have made it even better.) After reading other reviews, I obviously need to return to try the Kouign-Amann @ $5, which is a Breton Cake. It's often described as "the fattiest cake in all of Europe." (It's essentially a sweet & salty buttery cake w/ a caramelized crust.)

There are 4 "Savory" menu items, which include a quiche, souffle, & two croissant sandwiches, , there are Macaroons & Canele de Borxeaux-- a rum & vanilla pastry w/ a custard center & caramelized crust. 

If it's a beverage you seek, there are three Teas (w/ add ons that include Sugar Free); Cold Drinks (juice, soda, & waters); & Coffees & Specialty Drinks such as Lattees; Cappachino; Cortado (Expresso w/ warm milk); & Mocha.

The eatery appeared very clean. There are a handful of inside tables as well as outside tables near the entrance. 

24 hours advanced notice is required on PRE ORDERS, 48 hours for cakes, & 2 weeks for custom cakes. Check out the website to see all the choices patrons have regarding custom orders-- six different cakes w/ ten available fillings! (Currently, Chef Brenda is fully booked w/ custom cake orders thru October 2021.)

$25 Gift Cards are available for purchase. 

Definitely a worthy bakery & coffee shoppe, especially if the higher prices are within your budget. I will definitely return the next time I'm in the area-- such a quality (& tasty) establishment!', 'All the 5 star reviews are totally on point. I've never actually said this before, but I would give Sucre Table more stars if I could. I never say that about any bakery. I am kicking myself for not visiting sooner. I've honestly had this place bookmarked for a while, and I'm so glad I finally got to try it.

So, it's in that old strip mall where the Little Donut Shop used to be on Kennedy Blvd. It's in the same plaza as Chicken Salad Chick, Poke Burri, and Revolution Ice Cream. It's also across the street from La Segunda Bakery. If you haven't been to Sucre Table yet then you're in for a big treat. Seriously, these are high end, quality pastries with a beautiful presentation. The kind of pastries you can give as gifts because they are so beautifully decorated, and that's only if you think they will make it to their destination. I'm not gifting any of it. It would all be for me.

Let me first start with the kouign-amann (KA) pastry. WOW!! I loved it so much that I bought another to take with me. I did not share it with anyone. I had it for breakfast this morning after heating it up in the oven and it was just as good as the day before. I've heard about this pastry before but never actually had one until this visit. All I know is that it originally comes from Brittany which is a part of France that I haven't visited yet. I'm putting it on my bucket list because now I'm obsessed with learning more about pastries from that region. I think I may even watch episode 7 of collection 1 of the Netflix series "The Great British Baking Show" to see how the KA pastry is made. Anyway, this buttery and sugary layered pastry is a denser version of the Dominique Ansel cronut. My description doesn't even give it justice. Just read about it. Chef Brenda is extremely talented and has worked in the best NYC bakeries. What can I say? 

I also had to try the sour sop passion fruit tart. Another WOW!! The natural flavor of the tart passion fruit along with the sweet cream layer of guanabana made this the perfect ending for me. I enjoyed savoring every last crumb off that plate. A perfect 10.

The ube spiced latte was also a winner. It was made with coconut milk which really brought out the flavors. It's limited and it's not even on the menu at the moment, but they were able to make it for me. I appreciated that because it was one of the chai drinks that I wanted to try. Oh, and everyone was so helpful and friendly from the counter associate, to the barista, and to the owner/chef who was also there tending to her business. The tables are spaced apart and they even had a few tables outside. The décor and ambiance makes it a very relaxing and classy place to have a pastry with your coffee or tea preparation. They also have savory croissants, quiche, and soufflé. There's an online preorder menu and they take custom cake orders with some really unique cake fillings. 

I can't wait to go back to try a slice of cake and many other treats that I saw in the case. I don't have a single negative thing to say. It's worth a million more visits.', "One of the best bakeries in Tampa Bay.

I sent my sister to pick us up some baked goods, so I can't speak to the actual physical location, but I can comment on the food. Unfortunately, they didn't have kouign-amann when she went, which just means I'll have to go back.

Croissant - Best croissant I've had in Tampa Bay and definitely one of the top ones I've had in my life. It's flaky and buttery, exactly how I like my carbs. I'm not a huge carb eater because it's usually not worth the calories for me, but this one absolutely is. 

Egg Croissant sandwich - Usually this comes with bacon, but since I don't eat pork I took it off. It was very good, but I rather savor the croissant instead of add to it, so I think I'll stick to just a croissant next time. 

Pistachio Tiramisu - My absolute favorite. It's almost like a mousse on the inside and the dome of chocolate gives it a great (and I'm throwing up in my mouth a little for using this term, but I don't know how else to put it) mouth feel. I kept trying to send my sister back to get this again, but unfortunately they were closed on Sunday when she was free. 

Goat Cheese Carrot Cake - I really like the use of goat cheese in this pastry. It has a LOT of icing, so you need to be an icing person to like this. That being said, I LOVE icing. The goat cheese made it not too sweet and the actual cake was very moist. I love the uniqueness of this cake and would recommend it to anyone looking for something a little different. 

I will be going back soon. I just wish it was closer."]

name: Sushi Nara
categories_raw: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants
top_reviews: ["I'd been waiting for their grand opening because I'm a sushi fan. I was greeted by friendly people who immediately pointed me to the serve yourself miso soup table. I could even add my own green onions! They brought edamame along with the menus. The selection was good, obviously mostly sushi but a few other great options as well. I had three rolls (and took half home). They were delicious! Sushi Nara is a great addition to the neighborhood.", 'Delicious from apps to sushi to dinner. The owner/staff are so nice and welcoming. Self serve miso soup is delicious. Sushi is fresh. Orange chicken was to die for. Finally an amazing sushi place on the Eastside!', "My friend brought me here to try it out.
