At first I thought it was a low pricey, however after eating the food I was very happy.\n\nYes it might be a little bit more money than other places, but it's very very much worth it."]

name: The Sultans of Schlep
categories_raw: Movers, Home Services
top_reviews:
['I move every year, and normally it's not a very positive experience. In the past, movers have scratched my furniture, broken my favorite lamp, sexted with my sister, written lewd messages in BLACK MARKER all over my comic book collection and even put my stuffed animals into sexual positions - not funny.

I could tell right away that Tom would provide me a good experience. I had heard from Craig's List about the "works" package, so I asked Tom about it. He wouldn't discuss it on the phone, but in person we negotiated and let me just say this - he delivered! Both me and my girlfriend at the time were FULLY satisfied (she's hard to please). Tom and one of the other guys (I forget his name) even hung around for a while afterwards and had a couple drinks after the move and our "business" was completed. I left a $100 tip, which I thought was standard considering what they did for us.

I'd recommend the Sultans of Schlep to anyone. Here's a tip - order "the works," and make sure you set aside about 30 minutes of private time during the move (wear loose clothes). Although the back of the moving truck was kind of cold and the floor was hard and hurt my back.', "I used to live in Philadelphia. And now I don't. Part of that was made possible by the Sultans of Schlep. This was my first time hiring proper movers and I don't think I'll ever go back(1). Tom was easy to work with on the phone (and a very frequent leaver of voicemails while I was busy) and the flat fee rate he set plus the hourly rate was more than fair. 

The guys picked up all my stuff from a storage unit in Philly (plus the extra furniture my Dad drove up from VA to PA) then drove it up to NYC on the Sunday of Labor Day weekend. They unloaded my entire life and even set up my bedframe (no easy feat).  In return, I gave them a nice tip and some real New York bagels. Then I unpacked all the boxes of wine and properly started my new life.

They even invoiced me via PayPal which was better than any cash-only deal I would have been stuck with otherwise.

Footnote 1: Schuyler L helped me actually get all my stuff into the storage unit in the first place. So if the sultans are busy, you know who to call.", 'Do you like man buns? Beards? Tattoos? Seemingly inappropriate, but apparently highly functional footwear? Then these are the movers for you. No? Well,  if you are only looking for great service during a stressful move then you might want to consider the Sultans as well. 

[transition with a riff from Dire Straits here ...]

Great service begins at the very beginning when you talk to Tom to schedule your move. Super helpful and friendly. He was very clear about pricing and our options (I was really impressed how they only charge to the quarter hour when you settle up at the end of the day). Tom sent me email and text confirmations right before the move. He also was really cool about shifting dates at the last minute and scheduling a second move (reasons listed below) quickly.

Our move was quite possibly the suckiest move in the annals of moves. We bought a house with no plans to do so and had to get our old house on the market immediately. As a result, we had to throw a lot of stuff into 2 gigantic storage units really quickly. Sure, you are saying, like everybody else. Does your husband have a wood shop full of tools and slabs of trees? Trees, I say! Does your husband have the largest antique tool collection in the contiguous USA? Anvils, people; these guys had to move anvils. And post vices. And boxes of axes. Did I mention the blacksmithing forge? Anyway, everything we own is heavy. Not just "heavy" but "Holy s***, what the f***?" heavy. And quantity. If my husband didn't actually use most of this crap he could probably be on a new series called Hoarders in Training. 

While this situation may have caused a few looks of confusion and shock  (or did they get a "shiver in the dark"? -- sorry, last Dire Straits reference, I promise) when we opened up the storage area, the guys were otherwise not perturbed in the slightest, or at least were really good actors. On two separate weekends, they carried all of this stuff out of storage, into truck, and then into our barn, workshop, basement. And it was HOT! They didn't complain and were in a good mood or joking the whole time. Granted, this may have been exhaustion-induced delirium, but I think they are just really laid-back guys.

And no one was scary. Trust me, we had another company move us into our house and movers can be scary people. Both crews were made up of super nice guys, who took time to answer my 2-year-olds questions each time they passed by, stepped over my nosy dog, and didn't bludgeon my husband with one of his many, many, MANY tools. That  may have been warranted in this situation.

Long story short, I would hire them again in a second, but really hope we don't have to ever again.']

name: Vineyards Cafe
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Cafes, Food, Creperies, Internet Cafes, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
top_reviews:
["Sunday brunch in the city... I find it almost impossible to find a place without a wait. Thank god for Vineyard!! 
When you enter it looks like a small coffee joint, but they have seating downstairs. I love the vibe that this place has. 
Chai latte: being Indian, I'm picky about my chai. And this beats EVERYONES chai latte (even Starbucks). 
Eggs, bacon, gouda on a baguette. Light savory dish , just enough to fill you up without that heavy brunch feeling. And the baguette is soft, so you're not tearing it apart like most places! 
Nutella, strawberry crepe: one of the best crepes I've had in this city. 
The owner even came down to check if everything was okay. The food is delicious, The place is clean And the staff is friendly. What a wonderful place in Philly to grab a bite!", "Cute cafe in the Francisville/Fairmount area that provided an awesome place for me to hole up for several hours and have lunch, take a couple meetings, and get some work done. Seating is outside or downstairs, and on a Monday afternoon, I had my choice of tables as there was only one gentleman in the entire place (nice to meet you, Andre!). 

My café au lait was perfect, and I love the help-yourself water station with large glasses. I was excited to see crêpes on the menu and went for the goat bacon with goat cheese, bacon, mushrooms, and tomatoes. The crêpe was good but I would have enjoyed it a lot more if the bacon inside was crunchy. My dining companion's pesto sandwich looked incredible and I had a bit of lunch envy. I'm definitely going to try a sandwich or omelet next time. 

The staff was really friendly and the wifi was complimentary. Definitely adding Vineyards to my rotation of spots to get some work done, and looking forward to trying more from the menu.", "DAYUM that's a good crepe. I've had some good crepes in my day, but DAYUM. Got the Goat Bacon, amazing decision. Menu has savory crepes, sweet crepes, sandwiches and omlettes. The folks running the joint had a french accent which inspired great confidence in their crepe making ability and it lived up to the billing.

The crepe was huge and the goat cheese/mushroom/bacon filling was plentiful. Mark this on your GPS as a go-to spot in Philly."]

name: Mother Nature's Cupboard
categories_raw: Food, Farmers Market
top_reviews:
["They're not fully reopened, but they're doing snowballs and their roasted corn. I was sweating after a walk in the Quarter in a mask, so I was all about the snowball. Hear this- the ice is as good as any you will have, including Plum Street and Hansens, so if you need cooling off this is a delicious way to do it. And.... when they're fully up and running with food again, if you see a shrimp salad roll on the menu, BUY THAT! I got to sample a trial run and it was as good as a lobster roll. Lots of fresh dill and sweet shrimp, perfect for hot weather eating. Put it on the menu, Patricia!", 'This is my special review for a single vender in the French Market. The reason that they need special attention is due to the unique food that they are prepared. If you visit the French Market, do not miss up the opportunity to try their food. Their vender stand is located at the last vender stand of the food venders at first open air structure. It is very much at the middle of two open air structures. 

They occupied three vender stands and a front open air stand. You will not miss it. The front vender stand offers the roast cone and broil peanut. They roasted their corn in the enclose smoker. Once they receive the order, they will peel off the skin and show the ear. Then they will dip the corn to the hot butter, and season with salt, parmesan cheese (yum), Cajun spice (wow). My wife loves this corn. The inner vender stand serves the deep fried corn, crab cake, gator bites, and frog leg. They also serve different type of fruit drink and icy. We were curious the deep fry corn did not turn to pop corn. The vender owner assures us it will not happen. Evidently, it does not and coated with thin cajun coating. I have concluded the deep fried corn is a boy food and the roast corn is girl food base on the preference.

We also order the home made crab cake. The surprise is not the crab cake; it is the side dish that comes with it. The deep fried kale. I have the deep fried kale at the Cool Bean restaurant in Tallahasse FL. I did not expect they are as good as the restaurant grade. The Kale is deep fried for 30 second then season. The best thing is when you put on the tongue and the kale melt like cotton candy. The vender did a very good job.', 'Amazing roasted corn!!! Definitely a must have. Do yourself a favor and just get it with everything! We ended up going back like 3 times. Yes they were that good!']

name: Ron's Caribbean Cuisine
categories_raw: Restaurants, Food, Ethnic Food, Cafes, Caribbean, Specialty Food
top_reviews:
["Ron's has good Jamaican food. I have been here many times but I never thought about doing a review because The spot is always crowded and I thought everyone knew about it.  When you enter the restaurant the food is situated at the back of the restaurant is warming trays. However you don't get to see the food right away because there is always a long line. The line moves rather quickly and before you know it you are in the food area.
 You get a look at all that colorful Jamaican food laid out before you. There's a jerk chicken, red snapper, curry goat curry chicken and curry shrimp, brown stew, peas and rice cabbage and all types of vegetables, everything so fresh and so colorful as so fragrant. 
 You want to buy everything, but as usual I go directly to my favorite Jamaican dish-Oxtails with peas & rice,  sauteed.cabbage and a piece of festival bread. So ono!  I wanted to give them a 5 stars but the staff has no patience and no humor.", 'Tasty, authentic Jamaican food. They are definitely making a killing during the pandemic. Apparently demand has always been high, but the wait right now is insane. You can only call in your order, but it seems they only have one line. It's nearly impossible to get through. After trying for an hour, I decided to just head over. Sure enough there was a line outside so I thought "Great!! I can order at the window!!" Nope! You still have to call it in. Luckily the guy behind me eventually got through and offered me the opportunity to put in my order as well. A lot of people standing on line were also having issues with getting their calls answered. The guy at the window advised them to "keep trying". Certainly frustrating to see patrons roll up after you but manage to get their call in ahead of you. From the moment I got there to the time I left was just under an hour. Not in a rush to do that again any time soon. Ron's needs a smoother system of taking orders.', "I am a person of Jamaican descent and sometimes you can get good Jamaican food OUTSIDE of your own home. Not in this review. Ron's is cafeteria Jamaican food at best. Everything was super SALTY! I per chased ox tails, curried goat, and jerk chicken. PROS-OX TAILS were tender. CONS-they were very small. The very end of the tail. salty and the gravy tasted like a doctored version of the real thing. The best gravy however of the three. PROS- GOAT was tender. CONS- goat was SALTY. No other veggies in the pot. If they added a carrot or some potatoes it would have helped with the saltiness. Would have been the best gravy if it was not so salty and inedible. I threw it away. PROS- JERK CHICKEN was a good serving size. CONS-Not enough jerk flavor. They need to marinate the chicken in the jerk sauce. It was just plain bland. The worse part is they added some cheap barbeque sauce on the chicken and called it jerk sauce. HORRIBLE! Ruined the entire meal! If you get the jerk chicken DO NOT get the sauce! Cabbage was BLAND! Beans and rice a big disappointment. A poorly made version with poor ingredients. Tasted like minute rice. The give you a lot of rice and beans especially in the extra large serving of ox tails. The meat to rice ratio was just unfair. I felt cheated. I will not recommend!

 There was a short wait considering the place was crowded. It looked like organized chaos. The servers were clean, in uniform and their heads were netted. GOOD. They were pleasant also because the masses were kind of difficult. The cooks were dressed in chef whites. Nice touch. Well stocked variety of drinks and desserts. Very clean.  I left thinking I have found my new Jamaican cuisine home. NOT!  THE FOOD WAS JUST BAD. REALLY BAD! BAD!"]

name: The Ritz-Carlton Spa, New Orleans
categories_raw: Beauty & Spas, Restaurants, Hotels, Event Planning & Services, Day Spas, Hotels & Travel, Skin Care, Hair Salons
categories: ['beauty & spas', 'restaurants', 'hotels', 'event planning & services', 'day spas', 'hotels & travel', 'skin care', 'hair salons']
top_reviews:
['After leaving a rather disappointing Spa experience, I was reminded of the last really special pampering appointment I had. Last month, I visited for a little R & R before a special occasion and was treated like absolute royalty. The spa was immaculate, spacious, aromatic and just what I needed. 

My massage therapist and pedicurist were both sweethearts. At the start of my pedi, I was offered a mimosa which I happily accepted.', 'I've been to the Ritz NOLA Spa 3 times now. Twice for balls to the wall, full couple's days & once for a spur of the moment couple's massage. So, obviously I like it & it's the best spa I've seen in NOLA (Gotta have a steam room). But it's not perfect, hence the 2 star deduction.

Facilities: Unfortunately, each lounge is gender segregated. Given my boobs & vagina, I'm relegated to the loquacious hell that is the Women's Lounge:  

Relaxation Area: This area is beautifully appointed & would be a nice place to chill or nap between services, only it's not. Why? Because women won't shut the hell up! While there is a sign indicating the prohibition of cell use in this area, there is apparently no policy to curtail other noise. How cell phone chatting is different from racket in person is a mystery apparently known only to the Ritz Carlton.

The 1st time I was here there was an excruciatingly loud bachelorette party that made any attempts to relax completely futile. And when I was there recently, 2 hens squawked for over 2 hours. No one is that interesting. Each time I spoke to staff about the racket. The responses, "It gets busy on the weekends." Apparently I have to take a day off during the week if I actually want to relax in the Ritz's "relaxation" lounge.

Vanity Area: Vanities, toilets, showers, sauna & steam room. I'm not a fan of dry saunas, so I can't speak intelligently on the Ritz's. However, their steam room, replete with icy, cucumber washrags, is sublime. The temperature is always just hot enough, but not suffocating.  

It's also worth noting that there is something of a "secret" shower, between the sauna and the steam room. While there is a line of perfectly great regular showers, this separate shower has all the multi-jet bells and whistles.

There's also an extensive selection of products and beauty tools, such as shampoo, conditioner, shower gel, deodorant, shaving cream, hair gel, moisturizer, hair dryers, curling irons, flat irons, combs, brushes & even sugar to give yourself a good scrub. Note however that for those of you with curly hair, they do not have volumizing diffusers, so bring your own. Don't be like the woman who asked to borrow mine because the answer is no. I'd rather chew broken glass than let a stranger mash my diffuser into her hair.

Locker room: Pretty standard with lockers and benches. Plenty of room & a changing room with a door for the self conscious.

The Men's Lounge: Sadly, I've never been in the men's lounge. But my man tells me it's a magical place where no one talks. They also have a TV. So unfair.

Hot Tub/Pool: This indoor area is accessible through the fitness room. It's coed, so you need a swimsuit if you want to go into the water.  But my man and I did just fine dipping our legs into the pool in our robes and it was a nice respite from the women's "relaxation" area.

Staff: Aside from either an unwillingness or an inability to do anything about the noise, the staff is efficient, friendly, attentive and skilled. You'll never go very long before you see someone in the Women's Lounge if you need anything.

Services:

Apothecary Scrub Bar: You pick out a scrub, oil, & an herb. Then you lie down on a table where you're either being cascaded with water from a multi-nozzle shower arm overhead or scrubbed thoroughly, all before an application of moisturizer. This is my favorite service & Beth was awesome.  She also recommended the cafe au lait body polish ($10 cheaper than the Apothecary) in the future & even gave me a sample of the cafe au lait scrub.

80 Min. Couple's Massage: Just what it sounds like. We get Swedish, and the pressure is always just right. My only complaint here is that the massage room is apparently right under a guest room & the sound of high heels clicking & clacking back and forth from above during my recent visit was more than a little annoying.

Signature Facial: My face felt wonderful after & again, Beth was the bomb!  Includes an extraction & a hand, arm & scalp massage.

Couple's Bath: A private bath in a nice, lighted hot tub with candles, roses & champagne. Nice, but overpriced at only 20 mins. Skip it unless you have a crummy little bathroom like mine.

Deluxe Mani/Pedi: The included massage & paraffin felt great & the couple's, side by side pedi is fun. But if you're more interested in the results, spend less money elsewhere.  I've seen better polish application & their nail technicians just don't understand that "rounded" means NO square edges, not even where the nail meets the digit.  Also, their pedi chair felt more like being beaten with a sack of potatoes than a massage.  I couldn't adjust my chair, so perhaps this potato beat down was just because the chair was broken & stalled at the strongest setting.', 'I'm baaaaaaack!!!!!

Not my 1st time at this rodeo. Won't say I'm a frequent flyer, buuuuut I've been here a couple times before. And I'm sorry to say, this experience was no better... Lol. I said I wouldn't be returning, but I keep getting "treated" to this particular facility. And honestly, deeeeeeeep really deep down inside, I think that maybe, just maybe, it'll get better  but yeah; that's my thought, soooo until then, I'll finish my review. 

Sooooooo yeah where was I???? Oh yeah, so my masseuse, Gabby, was sub par. At the culmination of my services, I asked the folks at the front desk how long has she been here... 5 years they said... Ummmmm I was like "wait, what"?  My companion's masseuse was Mary, whom I hear was excellent. So I guess it's hit or miss. 

There was lots of noise made (inclusive of her stomach growling) during my session & as a result, I could NOT relax. And after she left the room, I had to wipe my own hands, as she left the oil on my hands. Ummmmmmm this was a no-no. How am I to redress with oil on my hands????? Ughhhhh.

I did however love the complimentary mimosa & champagne that I was presented with post massage. "Can I get a refill??? " (In my Elle Varner voice)

Due to renovations, the ladies lounge area was not available. So we were housed in the male's side, which was nice; but not nearly as nice as the ladies. 

Often times I almost get lost in this facility, I suggest you drop some breadcrumbs to find your way back to the front desk. 

I didn't use the hot tub, sauna, resistance pool or exercise equipment this time. But those are also available if you so desire. 

The ladies restroom is finished with sanitary needs, bobby pins, rubbers (scuncis) for your hair, q-tips, mouthwash, puffballs etc. Nice. Nice. Nice. 

All in all: 
The decor & the facility itself is wonderful; just some of the masseuses are hit or miss... Fyi!!!']

name: Zimmer's Seafood
categories_raw: Food, Seafood, Sandwiches, Restaurants, Specialty Food, Seafood Markets
top_reviews:
["They still get it done in Gentilly.

3 years after the storm, Zimmers is still surrounded by nearby half houses, house stumps, and freshly rebuilt places with kids playing outside, it is always a reminder of the rebuilding that is still going on out here, and worthy of a drive or leisurely bike ride out just to see parts of New Orleans that shouldn't be forgotten...Brad Pitt ain't out here, just ordinary folks still trying to get their neighborhood together...and luckily doing it right by one of the top 3 Po Boy places in town.

Conveniently located right next door to the Gendusa Bakery (Po' Boy historians know it was that families bakery that made the very first oversized po' boy loaves 80 odd years ago) so there is no doubt the bread is going to be fresh. Because of the bread, the po boys never get the dry taste that some other places otherwise decent can suffer from.

The menu is small.  They don't do much, but they do it well.  Fresh shrimp, oyster, catfish, half and halfs and the never to be forgotten french fry po boy.  Mmmm, fried potatoes stuffed in  french bread with lots of mayonnaise and goops of gravy...and as good as it sounds.

The place is a seafood store also, so pick up something to go, like marinated crab salad...in fact going out there just for a pint of that would be worthwhile.

Owned by the same family for decades, it's worth a trip out,,,supporting Gentilly while eating a Shrimp Po Boy that will go head to head with any in the city can't be all that bad of a thing to do.", "I wasn't in love with Zimmer's. It could have been an off day? I really don't know.

I dropped by last week to pick up some boiled seafood. We were hoping to get crab, shrimp, and crawfish. I don't know a whole lot about what seafood is in season when, so maybe it was stupid of me to want crab, but they had crab written on the board so I thought we could have some. When it was my time to order though, I was told that they had no crabs. I would have appreciated it if they had written that, but it is what it is.

The shrimp was probably my favorite, but it was really hard to peel. The crawfish was slightly overcooked. Both had good flavor. We also got potatoes, corn, sausage, and a turkey neck. The turkey neck was way too salty. Well, everything was pretty heavily seasoned, actually. I'm normally one to ask for more seasoning, but I thought it was a bit too much.

As I said, it may have been an off day. It's close to the house, so I may check them out again.", 'I discovered this neighborhood gem from a story in the online edition of the Times Picayune newspaper. Todd Price wrote how Charleen and Craig Zimmer have run the shop since 1980 and how it is hugely popular among locals. 

The shop is known for its fried crab poboys and for its boiled crafwish, so we ordered a couple of the poboys, outfitted with bread from the John Gendusa around the corner, the company that provided the bread for the original New Orleans poboys.

Both the sandwiches and the crawfish were excellent. The staff was friendly despite the crowd of customers that came into the takeout shop.']

name: Love Nail & Spa
categories_raw: Nail Salons, Beauty & Spas, Waxing, Skin Care, Hair Removal, Eyelash Service
top_reviews:
["'Crazy Tony' is the best & does designs!  They accept walk-ins, have many stations & pedicure massage chairs to accommodate.  Very clean, organized, comfortable atmosphere, tons of polish to choose from & they offer you a drink, even wine & mimosas.  Referred by a regular & they had many regulars.  Everyone was super friendly & work together like family. 

Tony did a beautiful design exactly as I envisioned my nails & better.  I highly recommend Love Nails as a person who has been going to the same manicurist in Vegas for a decade.  I will be back when I'm back in Tampa.", 'Pretty sure my gel manicure was the most painful I've ever experienced (and I've been getting them every 2-3 weeks for over 2 years now). In fact, typing this review hurts because the cuticle on my thumb stings every time it touches the space key. While the salon was very pretty and clean and I appreciated that their instruments came out of sterile packaging and they offered a drink upon arrival, the butchering of my cuticles is entirely inexcusable. My nail tech was unbelievably rough from the moment she took my fingers into her hand. She scraped that nail file, buffing off the existing gel polish from my nails, without any regard to the skin she was ripping off along with the polish. I told her she was hurting me, but she still scraped just as hard. If you can imagine, the acetone soak off was the most unpleasant and painful I have ever experienced. It only got worse as the "service" continued...her cuticle trimming actually drew blood. She commented that she was so happy my fingers stopped bleeding because some people they just bleed and bleed and bleed (WHAT???). She kept telling me to relax my fingers and finally I snapped that I couldn't relax them because they HURT. Then she blamed me and said it was my fault she couldn't see my nails so she was hurting me. Sorry lady, but you sloughed off my skin (in a bad way) from the moment you touched that first finger.

Needless to say, I left with stinging fingers and a mediocre gel manicure. Cooking, cleaning, and even showering was unpleasant and painful for the remainder of the day (yesterday) and even today, the majority of my fingers burn when I touch them, type, wash my hands, etc. Of note, for those of you considering this spot, gel polish change is $20 and gel manicure is $25 (reasonably prices), but they charge an extra $5 for soak off (which is ridiculous...of the dozens of places I have been, none have charged extra for a soak off if you're getting another gel manicure or polish change to replace it). 2 stars for cleanliness and kidness, but I still would not return.', 'So located in a strip mall, so nothing exciting there...  The interior is better than the normal nail place, they have a decent decor with a lot of nail techs and they also do massages and waxing.  I was recommended to try Lee and she was friendly and offered me a beverage as soon as I arrive.  She did a nice job on my manicure which was $12.  Everything is very reasonably priced and I would return.']

name: Cafe Du Monde City Park
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Food
top_reviews:
["Wife was bugging me about how we had to try the Café Du Monde.  

Visiting City Park, and there right in front of us was a Café Du Monde, with nobody waiting.  As we approach, a tour bus stops, unloading 48 passengers.  Wife was taking her sweet time, but I wasn't about to wait in line behind 48 people, so put on the afterburners to get to the front of the line before them.     

$3.75, cash only for a $3.40 bag of 3 beignets, before tax.  Comes in a paper bag with napkins.  

Many outside empty tables, but most of them not cleared off, with white powder all over the table tops, and also on the seats.  Minus one star.  Don't want to sit down there wearing dark pants.

I give one beignet to the wife, while I take the other two.  Square piece of just cooked hot sweeet dough, crunchy to the taste, and warm to the touch.  All covered with a mountain of white powdered sugar.  

Was wearing white pants and white shirt just for the occasion, as you will inevitably get white powder all over your hands and then wipe them on your pants and shirt.  Would not want wear dark shirt , with a sprinkling of white powder, looking like you had bad case of the dandruff!  

So much white powder on the beignet, that I even inhaled some of it, with white powder on the tip of my nose, and on my nose hairs.  Another reason to trim your nose hairs before visiting Louisiana!  

Imagine sneezing right now, beignet in hand, blowing all that white powder over my wife's black blouse!

Avoided Café Du Monde in the French Quarter on the river, a place more crowded than an immigration detention center!", 'Historic coffee shop focusing primarily on two menu items: coffee and beignets!

I read some of the negative reviews for this location and wondered why this place would have a less than perfect stars since everyone raves about their beignets. I get it that it's a new location and maybe have to work out some kinks to get that perfect 5 star ratings? was it the beignets themselves? the service? 

For me, I was just happy that I was able to try their beignets since the more popular historic open-air coffee shop (located on Decatur Street in the heart of the French Quarter) was always crowded with a long wait. Their menu included beignets, coffee and a variety of other drinks. I was second in line from their take-out window (which was nice since we didn't have a lot of time)... ordered a couple of frozen mochas and one order of beignets (came with 3 pieces) that hubby and I shared and it was delicious, not overly sweet! I have nothing to compare it to as far as other beignet shops but I've heard that you have to eat these delicious fluffy desserts fast while it's still hot otherwise they become really hard as a rock so I slowly scarfed it down -LoL- and I enjoyed it very much! Yummy deep-fried pastries that are very similar to doughnuts but not really.

Eating beignets at Cafe Du Monde was one of the top suggestions from my friends for things to do in NOLA (thank you, Yelp friends!) and I'm glad I was able to fit it in our two days in New Orleans. Hope to return next year and hit up the one at the French Quarter. Oh yah, I bought a box of beignet mix to take home and I'm going to try to recreate their famous treats! [with emphasis on "try"]

Review #1488', "I love me a good beignet, and what better way to enjoy a weekend than munching on some delicious, warm beignets at a park, with jazz music on a beautiful day. 

I'm so glad I was also introduced to this location as this had less of a line than the one at the French Market. It was also an added bonus that it was inside a beautiful park. 

The line on a Saturday morning wasn't awful. We waited about 10 minutes to place our order and was served almost immediately. It's a little bit challenging to find tables here, but you can definitely choose to enjoy the beignet on a park bench or on the grass if you'd like. 

The beignets are best when served warm and are worth it! They're the perfect treat for your weekend!"]

name: Baguette Deli
categories_raw: Vietnamese, Sandwiches, Specialty Food, Food, Delis, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Ethnic Food, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Very small, minimal ambiance, storefront place right next door to the Franklin Fred Meyer in the same becoming seedy strip mall.  Serving Vietnamese and or regular sandwiches all made on just right texture for banh mi baquette (made daily for them by Orient Market in Boise), pho, bun (one of our favorite SE Asian noodle dishes) and fresh (spring) rolls at bargain prices.

THE DRILL
Big menu boards are posted over the counter.  Order there, they'll give you a number and then call it when your order is ready to pick up.  Which is in short order.

THE VIBE
Then you can carry it back to your seat at maybe eight or so lino topped tables (seating for 18ish people), if you're lucky enough to get a seat at all, to polish off your meal in equally short order.  This is not a place you'll choose to dine and linger, but eat and go.  Or take out.  Seating being as limited as it is in the tight space.   

THE FOOD
In addition to 10 or 12 different Vietnamese style sandwiches there are an equal number of standard sandwiches, pho (beef) and bun (four kinds).  Since the latter is a favorite dish for us, we might have ordered it except we didn't see it on the menu board and only learned they had it as we read a paper menu at the table as we inhaled, ummm...ate...the banh mi.  Which will lead to a comment about service...to follow.

They also make 4 kinds of fresh (spring) rolls daily and have them shrink wrapped in packages of 3 (only $4) at the counter to pick up and take with you.  We had barely made a dent in our shrimp fresh rolls with peanut sauce when they called our number for the bbq (in the SE Asian style not American style) pork bahn mi.

The bahn mi we wisely decided to share because it is plenty big enough even though it carries a modest price tag of just under $5.  The baguette was perfect pillowy-meets-chewy essential for this kind of sandwich and the flavorful grilled meat filling was ample.  But for us it wasn't quite the 'all that' we expected based on some reviews.

That is because for us the point of banh mi is the abundance of pickled fresh vegetables, SE Asian herbs and hot fresh peppers.  While there were fresh vegetables they were not abundant and the pickling was barely there.  The fresh cilantro was good but the jalapeno,sliced lengthwise, was quite thick.  YOWZA!  I like heat but if you're more faint of heart for that bite, you might search and remove beforehand.

They also have bahn mi made with the pate style pork roll that is likely the most traditional filling of all and it appeared in a couple of their sandwiches.  Vegetarian options also available.

THE SERVICE
The lady at the counter was all business as she took our order.  This is not the place to ask to have described what this item or that one is.  We felt a little like being in a Senifeld episode (you know that Soup Nazi skit) when we asked what was the difference between a 'sandwich only' and 'combo order'.  (Answer, fyi, is chips and soda with the latter...nope...not our thing.)  So the point is, if you don't know something about SE Asian sandwiches and food, it is best to learn that before you go in.  We were glad we didn't need the person behind the counter to walk us through.  Nice lady.  But the routine is specific.

ALL IN ALL...
...good enough that we'd go back if in the area at the right time of day when for a quick lunch.  In particular since we didn't notice the bun options until too late to order one of them.   But this wouldn't be a destination for us.

THIS N THAT:

1) PARKING:  Ample amount in the big Fred Meyer's lot but somehow it always seems as this lot if full no matter how big it is.

2) ACCESSIBILITY:  Level in and throughout the small space.  Tables are standard height and a few have ample floor space for wheelchair users.  But likely best to plan to leave strollers outside here.  The parking lot is woefully out of compliance with Federal Law and State Structural Code for accurate number and placement of accessible parking spots.", "Baguette Deli is located in the same plaza as Fred Meyer, specifically next door to Great Clips, with plenty of parking.

My husband found this place on Yelp and so we came here on a Sunday around 6:30 pm. After looking over the menu board, we ended up getting:

Vermicelli, $7.95 prior to tax- This noodle entrée is good for two and was tasty. The meat was also good and tender.

#1 House Special, $4.95 prior to tax- My husband opted for this sandwich. The lunch meat is good but on the skimpy side. The baguette bread used was good and had a nice chew.
-----------------
(Total= $13.14 after tax)

When we came in, I wanted to order spring rolls but they were already sold out. Same with a milk tea that I had asked to purchase. I was surprised that a handful of items I had asked for were already sold out ~ 90 minutes before closing time. But I guess at least they still had the ingredients to make banh mi sandwiches.

Well I've had better, but maybe that's because I'm from Los Angeles where there are a lot of places that make really good Vietnamese food. Overall, this place is okay, thus my 3 star rating.", "Went here after a receiving recommendation for their sandwiches and pho.  I'm usually not a pho fan but the wife is so we decided to check it out.  Great Pho!  I ordered mine without the meatballs which ended up being a good choice.  The beef strips were thin and full of flavor.  The broth and veggies were fresh and delicious!  Prices were more than fair.  At some point I'd like to try their sandwiches but for now the Pho will bring me back!"]

name: AJ's Fine Foods
categories_raw: Delis, Bakeries, Food, Grocery, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["A very posh supermarket in the armpit of the resurrection process of Skyline and Campbell's intersection, but just a supermarket none the less.  I live in the Foothills and still would drive to a Fry's over this place.

The better side:  A large selection of everything, like pumpernickel, caviar, Fois Gras pate, fresh (for the desert) seafood, nice roast beef, a sweet tooth fixer right when you walk in, and for all the boozers, a very wide array of beers/wines/spirits to keep you jolly.

The ugly side:  The sushi bar is staffed by nobody - when they are there, they are rude, so they are still nobodies (which is a shame, really because I tip so well).  The prices are just silly for everyday needs.  Avoid this place for every day needs.  They are not lit very well.

The weird:  They have a middle section dedicated to Lamb Chop puppets, gaudy glassware, and other tasteless kitsch, which makes me wonder why they put a swap meet in between the cornichons and the arugula.

I wish they would play loud Mariachi music through out AJ's, so I might be inclined to buy some of those knick knacks and ignore the prices, like I do at the swap meet...and I wish the swap meet would have a sushi bar and sell duck turds so I didn't have to go to AJ's anymore.", 'I'm one lucky cat that AJs is literally a 5 minute walk from my house. AJs is so fabulous that I'm pretty sure people just cruise in there for an "escape" into all that is gourmet, specialty, delicious and downright picture perfect. It's hard to go to AJs with out making some unnecessary purchases. The flower displays alone bring out the "Martha Stewart" in me. If you make it passed the flower shop make sure to check out the fresh fish and phenomenal beef counters. Here you can definitely buy high quality  choice and prime beef that will never disappoint. They even have grass-fed beef! 
Don't be discouraged by the high prices, because AJs has crazy good sales on the reg. For example, you can buy PRIME New York Steak for like $12.00/lb on sale versus the normal $28.00. 
TIP: Sales usually fall on holiday weekends.

Beyond the beef counter is their delectable cheese section (my personal heaven), which has more than just your average triple cream bries and Manchego Cheeses. I've been lucky enough to score a truffled Pecorino! 

Hungry while shopping? No Prob! You can munch on all kinds of house-made goodies like grilled veggies, grilled fish, rotisserie chicken,  potato salad, pasta salad, Orzo salad and more.

or

Stop in an eat some fresh Sushi at the Sushi Bar. You know you're getting #1 sushi grade fish, with out a doubt!

Like Pizza? check out the Pizza and Deli counter where you can order a custom sandwich or grab a slice. Then cruise over for some Illy coffee and sweets. 

AJs even has an outdoor grill, open daily until 3pm. They make a GOOD hot dog (with Brats) YUM!

It's best to go to AJs when you are not starving or without a game plan, because it can do a number on your wallet!

Love you AJs!', 'Ok, the oblivious, smarmy, and outright weird staff at the pastry and deli counters have finally scared me away.

I'm done. I've reached the breaking point. Finito. Throwing in the towel. 

I've been glared at, ignored, and skipped over too many times. The middle aged lady with the glasses - well, she's in my top 3 "most annoying" category and for the life of me can't figure out why she actually has a job here... Oh...And what's with the overly friendly side conversations when I'm in a hurry? Blah blah blah.

By the way, Hey deli staff - could you please not have your backs turned constantly and be attentive to the flow of customers? I really don't like having to say "excuse me."

Good grief.. Is it that difficult?']

name: The Men's Room Barbershop
categories_raw: Beauty & Spas, Barbers
top_reviews:
['I am a student at U of A and was looking to find a good place to get a haircut.  I've been to two different places in Tucson with just ok results.  I decided to try Yelp to find something better and the Mens Room Barbershop came up. The place looked amazing with 5 stars and great reviews. What could possibly go wrong? Everything, absolutely everything went wrong.  I first had to wait 1 hour in line to get a haircut, but what the heck I thought this would be worth it, right? Secondly, I met my barber(can't remember his name) and he was very cold and didn't say much.  Third, I asked for the most basic, simple haircut. I just wanted in shortened a little bit.  Simple, right? Guess not. Fourth, he goes about cutting my hair with the seat positioned so I can't see what's going on. This position is such that I can't see myself in the mirror and have no idea what he's doing to my hair!  About 10 minutes in, I notice that he starts cutting the front of my scalp a lot. I, like a moron, figure there is no need to worry since this place got such rave reviews! When he's done, he hands me a mirror and I take a quick glance at the cut and I didn't realize how bad it was till later. I don't like to complain and just said "looks good, thanks". When I got home I looked in the mirror and to my horror realized that he basically cut off most of my scalp!! I know I will survive but this haircut really did a number on me! I will be wearing a hat for about a month now. It's pretty tough to do but the Mens Room Barbershop managed to give me the worst haircut of my life! Congrats!', "The keyword at this place is service. Was offered a drink while I wait was stunned by the selection. Arnold Palmer, coke AND Pepsi, bottled water etc. drinks are unlimited and free btw had two before the cut and was offered another on the way out.

The straight razor shave was a true spa like experience and after two passes I had baby butt smooth skin through the weekend. Didn't get a haircut but I do know cuts come with a massage. I saw the old school device asked about it and was given a brief shoulder massage with it myself whatever it is it turns your hard muscle into soft dough. 

Can't remember my barbers name he is in the pictures name starts with J i believe I'm guessing Jose or Jonathan but I don't want to sound racist with the guessing. Not too chatty but I like that. Very informed though talked me through step by step of the shave process. 

The gripes are few and I don't want to sound like I'm splitting hairs (no pun intended). But they do take their time so there is a wait when only two people work I recommend come during the day. Also hardly any magazine selection but there is free wifi to compensate. You pay for quality 14 for a shave or cut but Wednesdays cuts are 11 for students.", "I generally like going to a barber as opposed to the large chain haircut places, so I was please to see this place pop up in my search results.

I may bump to five stars on a return visit, but I came in on a Wednesday, which is apparently student discount day, so I had to wait over an hour to get in the chair.

Parking is a little tight, but I was able to find a spot.  Seating while you wait is along one wall across from the barber setup.  I was offered a water or a soft drink, which you can grab from the fridge free of charge.  You sign up on a spiral notebook and may request a specific baber on the sheet.

As I waited, I noticed the amount of time and care that went into each cut.  I asked to have my beard shaped up around the edges, and I wasn't charged for the service.  A nice touch.  The price of cuts is set to go up to $15 in March if I remember the sign on the fridge correctly, a bargain even if it were more expensive.  You can opt to have your hair shampooed and they also offer straight razor shaves.  My haircut looks good and I will most likely return in the future."]

name: Le Monde Creole
categories_raw: Tours, Hotels & Travel
top_reviews:
['Like Zoolander, I'm not an ambi-turner. I can barely tell my left from right ("Your other left is a phrase that is often repeated to me), I honestly have no idea what people talking about when they say NE, NW, SW, SE, and the compass app on my phone is completely useless. Basically I'm telling you, I could not walk my way out of a paper bag.

So when the boy surprised me with an impromptu trip to New Orleans for my birthday we spent our first day wandering the streets with no real places to go. Sure it's a wonderful city but we had a limited amount of time, places to go, and most importantly things to eat. It was time to call in the professionals. I emailed Le Monde Creole at 2 am in the morning to book a two and half hour tour of the city.

Yeah it's touristy, but I highly suggest taking a walking tour. This trip helped us take in the culture better and also plan the rest of our trip there!

I could not be happier with our host Bill, a local with a knack for storytelling. His musical, lilting voice took us into the story of the a Creole French family in the 19th century. Let me tell you, this is no American Girl story. The Lacoul Family had everything you could ever want: sex, intrigue, violence and scandal! I held on to every single word. For a girl who was diagnosed with ADD by a psychic at her high school graduation (another story, another day) this is quite the feat.

I highly, highly recommend this tour. Besides the story you will also get to check out some private New Orleans courtyards (including one where an American Horror Story scene was filmed!), cemeteries (and see the NIcholas Cage future burial place), pharmacies, houses, etc!', 'I was very frustrated and upset by this tour. 

The quick and dirty:

* The tour ran almost TWICE as long as advertised. 
* There were only four courtyards visited, and they were all, as far as I could tell, publicly accessible. Not one was, as the website claims, private. 
* We spent more time locked in confined spaces listening to lectures than we spent looking at beautiful architecture or museums.
* For running two hours late (almost four hours total!), no time was provided to look around or take photos and we were rushed through everything interesting. 

The long version:

The website said the tour would take "about" two hours.Since the tour starts around 10:30, that would mean we ended around lunch, which is what I planned for. We actually ended well after 2 PM. The tour took almost twice as long as anticipated. Not only that, but it ended well after lunch. As I'm a person who needs to eat on time, I was miserable and exhausted by the time the tour wound up. Furthermore, I only had one day in New Orleans and had planned my schedule carefully. An almost two (?!) hour delay meant I had to cancel other items on my to-do list and miss out on a lot of fun, like visiting the cemetery in the Garden District (which was closed by the time I got there).

I would probably have forgiven this IF it meant we had taken more time in special spots, or saw a lot of neat, fun, interesting architecture that I could not have seen otherwise.  However, that was not the case.

First stop: A courtyard behind an ice cream shop (publicly accessible). It was here we spent the most time, sitting for what felt like more than an hour  hearing a very meandering explanation of New Orleans history that basically felt like a Wikipedia article read aloud. This was all information that could have easily been conveyed en route between destinations, and, since I was already familiar with this history of the region, it was torturous to be forced sit and feel the minutes drag by while our tour guide drank her coffee. We weren't even allowed to get up and look around the courtyard.  

Second stop: A courtyard in a local history museum (which was free, btw, and publicly accessible). After being rushed through the museum and told that we should consider "coming back later to really look around" we were led out to the courtyard and given an interesting talk on Creole courtyards, which I did enjoy. I did not enjoy that the second the talk was over, we were rushed out of the space without being given time to look around or take photos. We were there less than ten minutes, fifteen tops if you include time spent walking through the museum.

Third stop: Pharmacy museum and courtyard. A lovely courtyard, also publicly accessible. A shame we were only there less than five minutes. We were then rushed up through an interesting stairwell into the pharmacy museum where, instead of being allowed to look around, we got a brief but salacious recounting of Laura Locoul with lots of obvious questions and Innuendo. I think the pharmacy museum would be a great place to visit, but I wouldn't know because I didn't really get to visit it.

Next was the cemetery, where we did get about two minutes of  interesting history, and over five minutes on why we should not desecrate tombs before being rushed out without time for photos or to look around. 

Finally we reached our last destination--Laura Lecoul's town house. Oh, lovely, her actual home! This is the only (apparently, not 100% sure) non-freely accessible location, since you'd normally have to pay for a tour of the home from what I gathered as we rushed past the reception desk. We didn't pay, but we didn't get a tour of the home, either. We were whisked through the courtyard (less than one minute this time, in and out and through as quickly as the tour guide could manage), past a tantalizing staircase that promised a lovely home that we would never see as we were herded  into a dark, windowless living room where the tour guide SHUT THE DOORS to give us another painfully long family story that seemed barely relevant. Meanwhile, we are sitting in a dark, tiny room of a gorgeous New Orleans town house with a gorgeous New Orleans courtyard, looking at antique reproduction furniture and an anachronistic mirrored fireplace and thinking of all the amazing house we are not seeing that we could be seeing at that exact moment. 

To someone who loves architecture and homes it was like that science experiment where they tell the children that they have to wait for the marshmallow and if they wait, they will get two marshmallows. But then imagine at the end of a three and a half hour exercise in frustration and boredom, the child is told to please buy the tour guide's eBook and get the hell out and don't you dare try to linger or look around because the TOUR IS OVER.', "We found Le Monde Creole via Yelp and it didn't disappoint.  What I really liked was that much of the tour took place in quiet, out of the way spots.  Our tour organizer did an excellent job presenting an overview of New Orleans, cultural fun facts and the story about the Creole family.  It was fun ducking into beautiful courtyards and hearing stories that took me back to another time."]

name: New Orleans Social House
categories_raw: Tapas/Small Plates, Bars, Restaurants, Nightlife
top_reviews:
["Stellar review coming.....brace yourselves!!

I wanted to try somewhere different. I have been wanted to check this new hip spot out for a while. I heard the chef uses to work at a renowned restaurant and had to try. 

Social House is what it's called!  The social/happy hour is 4-7. We got there in the nick of time. It was after work and close to 6p. We were hungry but not too hungry. 

Decided on the oysters from Louisiana, Asia and West Coast. Faves were the asian oysters. Suckers were almost $3 per oyster. La oysters were .75 ech. I didn't like the way the waitress skipped the social menu tho! I give her the benefit of the doubt, the spot is only 3 weeks into existence. 

The wines were on time and like half off during social hour. Everyone was extremely nice and it was very empty on that rainy Monday evening. The lobster tacos were GREAT. They send out 3. It's a light bite. For dessert try the chocolate thingy ...sooooo goooooood!!! We really enjoyed.", "I was here for a birthday party on a Friday evening WITH the bubbles happy hour drinks! I had the Wycliff (too sweet for me) and the Charles Roux (weirdly heavy) but you can't go wrong with the Ruffino Prosecco. At some point I switched to the HH Mule's which were tasty and not too tart. 

The birthday girl had reserved space for her gathering and I was able to sample some of the cheese from the cheese & charcuterie bar. Tasty. And I ordered a bianca flatbread which was good but a bit bland. I didn't get much roasted garlic at all.

The space is large with plenty of bar seats. They were jumping on a random Friday night in November. Definitely will be back for HH pricing and bites.", "NOSH is in the space that used to be Tommy's Wine Bar and they offer a daily happy hour.  Most of the food items on offer for their happy hour menu are pathetically small and a waste of time and money to even order while the main decent special they offer would be the 50 cent raw oysters.  The service is really slow and mediocre at best.  The drinks are ok but their happy hour prices are not all that happy and still seem overpriced.  The crowd usually seems that it isn't a very friendly or happy gathering type so this place just lacks the usual happy friendly vibe most NOLA establishments generally offer.  The bar itself has a nice ambiance and very comfortable seating which is unchanged since before Katrina and still works quite well.  Overall without the 50 cent oysters there would really be no need to even visit here and even with the oyster special Superior Seafood offers a more enjoyable friendly crowd along with their 50 cent oyster special which also offers much better drink specials."]

name: Sweet Soulfood
categories_raw: Restaurants, Vegan, Soul Food
top_reviews:
['I am FULL AS A TICK... All I need is to pitch a hammock in City Park on this breezy, beautiful April the 13th... Hello!!!!!!

Oh my God!!!!! What a god-send in mylife. I think this place was personally created for me. 

When I got wind of the opening, I knew with haste I must make my way & today was the day; and there was NOOOOOOOOOO disappointment. 

Broad & St Phillip is where you'll find this treasure; located beneath a babershop the "pièce de résistance" lives!!!! 

Walking in, to the right are 3-4 tables & chairs for dining; to the left is a table for two that sits flush with the wall... then straight to the back is all the veganie-goodiness... The FOOD!!!!!

Two sides, one is for hot food & the other is a salad bar of sorts.  All the food is served by the staff, this is GREAT; I don't care for buffets, things happen at buffets, ewwwww.  

The food is served a la carte or you can get a combo-of sorts, 2 entrees and 2 sides.  I choose the Pasta, Okra Gumbo, Sweet Potatoes & Mac-n-Cheese (I'm a cheese lover, despite being lactose intolerant).  Then to top it off, I got some VEGAN ICE CREAM & a drink of Green-Goddess; all for under $20 bucks; winning with a CAPITAL W!!!!!!

ALL THE FOOD AMAZINGLY great & flavorful.  Lots of times, removing ingredients from foods you've been eating all your life, you anticipate am unfamiliar, 'gotta get used to it' taste; but that wasn't the case this time go round.  

The okra was robust & tasted of all things creole, thankfully it lacked that acidic tomato taste; this was fantastic, made my tummy happy.  

The sweet potatoes tasted like my granny's; enough said!!! 

The pasta was a new taste for me, just because it lacked seafood, but the replacements were right on time & made me glad I had made the selection.  

And the MAC N CHEESE; since this is an ALL TIME FAVORITE of mine... This was the seller for me.  It PASSED THE TGB-MAC-N-CHEESE test!!!!! I love it!!!!!!!!   

With some many other choices to select, I'll definitely be back to get more of this VEGAN SOULFOOD.  

Oh and the Ice Cream, you can taste the flavors should that be your desire; but it's VEGAN too... I'm over-joyed this little piece of heaven is open & in the direction of my house... HELLO, dinner as I head to the house.  

Ooooooh and the Green Goddess, to rinse it all down... I'm a happy, happy, dairy free, vegan food eating camper.', "I never thought I would be writing a review on a vegan restaurant in New Orleans but here I am and my goodness the food was absolutely fantastic. I was indecisive so staff offered samples of my choosing. 
O-M-G everything I sampled was so darn good. Staff was helpful, friendly, and offered supreme customer service. 

I love the buffet tables that you can see all of hot food and salad on display. I ordered a pick 4: orange cauliflower, cashew mac and cheese, greens, and stuffed bell pepper with corn bread, bread pudding rum, and praline candy. Everything was seasoned and cooked perfectly. 

My carnivore loving parents were curious, so I gave them a little bit of everything to try and they too loved it so much that they went for lunch the following day. 

The overall experience is five stars: food, service, presentation, and store cleanliness. 

Highly recommend whether you are Vegan or Meat and dairy lover. 
You won't be disappointed. 

Please check their Website/Facebook/ Instagram page for daily menu, updates, catering, and changes in store hours. 
https://www.sweetvegansoulfood.com", "The one thing the other reviews left out was the bread pudding!

I'm not one for soggy bread things so I usually pass when it comes to bread pudding. Besides people asking for the menu of the day and commenting on their Mac n Cheese, their bread pudding is the next most popular discussion on their Facebook page. I decided I should at least give it a shot. 

Once I finally got to the front of the line there wasn't much left so I was thinking it wasn't going to happen this visit. It did. Mind blown. I'm not going to try to figure it out because I know I won't ever get it right but I would love to see how they do it. It wasn't too sweet and it wasn't too soggy. 

Also! That stuffed bell pepper .....man. Another food mystery that I'm perfectly ok with not knowing how the magic happens. 

Forgot to mention they already sold out of ALL their food earlier in the day and closed up shop for two hours to cook more."]

name: Please-U-Restaurant
categories_raw: Cajun/Creole, Breakfast & Brunch, Diners, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['As far as diners go, you will not find one in the city that does as good a job as The Please-U. I've been coming here for years and I can honestly say that it is my favorite breakfast spot in town. Although some might find its menu items unrefined, I find it quite comforting to have a simple American breakfast without all the bells and whistles. Besides, if you're looking for something along the lines of a duck confit corn muffin with yucca pancakes, try just about every other breakfast place in the city, not here. Along with having an unpretentious menu, affordable prices and extremely prompt service it seems that Pleas-u does "diner" better than any other diner in the area. So don't say that I didn't warn you when they say that they are all out of unpasteurized artisanal cheeses for your free-range eggs benedict w/ baby bok choi.', "Greeks own diners.  NOLA loves a big breakfast.  This old school joint was the perfect marriage of both! 

I went basic - 2 eggs over easy, sausage, hash browns and a biscuit.  

Eggs were perfectly cooked 
Sausage excellent mix of meat, spice and fat! 
Hash brown crispy goodness 
Biscuit - dense, flakey, butter as a biscuit should be! 

Things I had to pass on but looked amazing 
Grits - buttery cheesy and creamy 
Gyro - omelette 

They're only open for breakfast and lunch.   Coffee not espresso. 

Service is very fast and friendly.", 'This is an old diner style restaurant with a NOLA spin and a dash of Greek.  You can get breakfast and lunch here most of the day.  They have one side of the menu dedicated to their lunch offerings and the other side is their breakfast.  You have a lot of choices here and there should be something on the menu to satisfy almost anybody.  They also are very fast here and typically get your food out to you within a matter of minutes.  It's got the old dive ambiance that we love in NOLA and I like sitting at the counter.  The menu and food probably haven't changed in years which has its good points and bad points to various folks tastes.  This is a solid choice if you're in the mood for a quick meal at a fair price in a diner type setting.  Before Katrina this was a 24 hour establishment but unfortunately, like so many other businesses, they haven't returned to that schedule.  The only real disappointment I get here is waitresses don't call me "love, darling, sweetheart, or honey" like they do at other NOLA joints like this.

I would skip the burger and the turkey plates.']

name: Stigma Ink
categories_raw: Boat Repair, Piercing, Professional Services, Tattoo, Arts & Entertainment, Eyelash Service, Beauty & Spas
top_reviews:
["Came here to work on one or two of the artists as a massage therapist and then got some ink for myself. My artist was Matt.

Matt was extremely professional. We consulted over what I wanted, and he drew it up, presented it and got to work.   It'd been a decade since I've had any ink done so I was a little apprehensive, but I didn't have to be. He was gentle and made sure I knew exactly what he was doing, what needle he was using and everything else. 

He made sure to check in with me, to see how I was handling things and when it was done, I was incredibly pleased. I now have the Lotus I wanted! It's delicate and the ink work is incredibly fine. I can't wait to get more ink soon!", "What a great experience! I've been itchin for another tat and it was time. Based on the reviews I had to check this place out. 

The shop is located in a small plaza shared with restaurants and other businesses. Very easy to find but pay attention or you may drive right past it. When you pull into the lot, look up...it's on the second level. 

The shop was clean and the artist's sections were neat and organized. Tony was my artist for the night and he was so funny which made the entire experience. They were playing old school music...Dr. Dre, Scarface to some new school jams which made you want to move. 

All that...and I have a new tat I love. Check em out!", "I got a Forward Triple Helix piercing done and I must say this was an interesting experience.  I've been pierced and tattooed before, but, Chino was different from the rest.  As many others have stated, he makes you feel at ease throughout the entire process.  He was extremely informative and knowledgeable about everything, prior to starting he advised me of exactly what was going to happen and did not sugar coat the pain (it wasn't as bad as I thought), the fact that you are talking through the process kind of takes your mind off of the discomfort.  The shop was clean and everything was sterile.  I will definitely be back if I decide to get another piercing and will be sure to recommend Stigma Ink to my friends."]

name: City Putt
categories_raw: Mini Golf, Active Life
top_reviews:
["Great course. Good pricing. Lax standards.
But if you allow smokers to f-up the enjoyment of the majority then you deserve 1 star (for the guy who decided to up-vote due to the fact that someone who also wanted to be free to breath didn't like the loose rules on smoking).
Thanks for helping me figure out my star number.

P.S. Don't be a dick. What you want to put into your lungs is fine. It can even be a giant dildo...but for non-smokers, it is painful when an inconsiderate a$$munch cares more about their wish to smoke than anyone around them.We deserve to breath what we want to without being subjected to other people's self poison.", 'It was one of those rare "not so humid, not so hot" New Orleans summer days when David and I decided to finally check out City Putt. Yeah, I know that we are totally late to the party, but I like to think of it as being fashionably late.

We were here in the late afternoon, so lucky for us there was no line or wait, We paid, picked our golf balls and headed out. There are two courses you can choose to play or you can play both. I hadn't played mini golf since my "Putt Putt" days as a kid, and I thought I would be rusty, but I caught on pretty quickly. I like how the course is set up with different "water hazards" and there are misters going at every hole to cool you down if you get really hot. The landscaping of the whole space is lovely and I like how each hole has a different theme inspired by a different city in Louisiana.

My only complaint is those greens. I don't know what happened, but SO MANY of them are torn to shreds and falling apart to the point where it interferes with the game. I don't understand why they haven't made some effort to replace them. I understand that normal wear and tear happens over time, but on some of the holes it looks as if someone (kids?) have tried to actively pull up the green. That was the only thing that prevented this from being a 5 star experience for me.

I had a great time and, while the game was really close, I ended up winning by 3 strokes! I want to go back and play the other course. This is a fun way to spend an afternoon, if you are looking to do something for an hour or so.', "Fresh off my jaunt at City Putt, I have to say, it's quite nice having a putt putt course a hop, skip and a jump from my house. There were 8 of us, and we did the cultural Louisiana course of 18 holes for $8 (if you want do to both, it's $12). 

We completed the course in about an hour and a half, and had a nice little time doing it with our cheap $3 tall boys of Miller High Life (they also have an Abita, Miller Lite, Blue Moon and another one I can't remember). They also have the obscure Tab soda if that's your jam!

The Louisiana course is pleasant, with little diddy's that our friend read in a very Morgan Freeman narrative sort of way about different places around Louisiana, though they could've been a little bit more entertaining. 

We probably hit our balls in the water five or so times, but there is a great little net to fish it out at some holes. Most holes are a par 2, nothing tooo crazy. A few of us got hole-in-ones, which we definitely did celebratory happy dances for around the hole!

It was a slow night, so we were able to take our sweet time. I can't wait to try the New Orleans side, 'cause I hear it's a little bit more entertaining. Only qualms are that we had wished for more trash cans, since I found myself carrying my empty beer can for about 4 or so holes, a place to write on your score card and put down your drinks by the front of the hole.

Just a heads-up, no food is allowed on the course and you might want to spray yourself with bug spray before hitting the course."]

name: Gaslight Theatre
categories_raw: Arts & Entertainment, Performing Arts
top_reviews:
["STOP BEING SUCH A SNOB AND ENJOY YOURSELF DAMMIT!!!!  This is my mantra before going to a show at the Gaslight.  You see IIIIIIII was a theatre major (see how I even spell it the snobby way).  I first saw a Gaslight show in college and I was oh so offended.  Servers delivering food while the actooooooooors were performing.  How offensive!

THEN I GOT OVER MYSELF!!!

Gaslight is EVERYTHING a night out with family and/or friends should be, side splitting laughter great food, great fun, great performances, just great great great great great.  so unless you're a super annoying pretentious snoooty snotty snot head like I used to be, get your tushie and the tushies of your loved ones over to the Gaslight for a rip roaring good time!!!", 'My parents live in the Tucson area and took me to the Gaslight when I visited in December. To be honest, it has taken me this long to post a review because I'm not quite sure what to say about the experience. When people say it's cheesy and hokey, believe them. I will add that this is entertainment for third graders of all ages. If that's your thing, great - the five-star reviews will tell you everything you want to know.

For those who are unsure - or who are fans of REAL theatre, Gaslight does not fall into that category. This is a cross between vaudeville and show choir, dressed up as theatre. I laughed a few times during the show we saw (The Secret Santa), but mostly I put on a happy face for my host and hostess. Thank goodness the place has a liquor license.

This is not to take anything away from the performers. Gaslight has found a genre that works for the audience it seeks to attract - and the performers ("actors" and musicians) deliver. And there were actually some effects in the show I saw (the bobsled race, in particular) that were charming and executed very well.

So I give Gaslight three stars for seniors, children, and anyone else who delights in light, corny entertainment and gigantic hot fudge sundaes - and pen this cautionary tale for everyone else.', 'It has been way too many years since I've visited Gaslight! My husband has never been (and we've been together 14 years), so when we had the opportunity for a date night surprise us a few weeks ago I thought I'd take a shot at seeing if there were any seats left for the holiday show.

We got lucky! Called that day for the (early) show that night--two seats in a pretty good location (though I can't imagine many bad seats in that theater). 

While the first act was a little slow, I just loved the kitsch of the whole thing. The actors were funny, the stage had clever little bits of interest (the house on the left, the stars in the ceiling). I loved that the actors were "in on it" and would regularly interact with the audience's boos and cheers--even mentioning by name some folks who I would assume are the regulars. 

The best part was after the traditional musical show, they did a sing-a-long songs show at the very end. The performance of "Santa Baby" had me laughing till I was in tears, and the "It's Christmas Don't Be A Jerk" by Spongebob Squarepants was hilarious. 

The actors were a blast, the music was great--I can't imagine a more fun date night! We even ordered dinner to the table from over at Grandma Tony's. Can't wait to come back again.']

name: The Brunchery
categories_raw: Restaurants, American (Traditional), Breakfast & Brunch
top_reviews:
['3.5 stars. A satisfactory brunch establishment. Nothing was bad, yet nothing stood out as exceptional. Our 6 mouths did not explode w/ bursts of amazing flavor combinations. Not one of us is dying to return, yet we won't hesitate to stop in if we're in the area & hungry for breakfast or lunch. 

In 1989, a year after the original location opened in South Tampa, my then husband & I stopped in repeatedly; we couldn't get enough of the cream cheese & crab omelet w/ side of home fries! I was excited to check out this new location. (Unfortunately, you won't find the omelet on the menu.)

Sitting on Bruce B. Downs (& just west of I-75 & Glory Days), The Brunchery does not have a large dining room. There are no booths, but many tables that can be combined for larger groups. There are four outside tables (w/ umbrellas), as well as metal benches for those holding onto pagers. 

Locally owned & operated, it is open seven days a week from 8 till 2 PM. Inside, you'll see a large "Specials" chalkboard; however, the board is deceiving. ALL the items listed were the same regularly-priced items found on the menu. 

When you eat here, you'll have a choice of 8 Omelets; 7 Benedicts; 5 'Heart Healthy' options; 4 Country Skillets; 6 'Sweet Temptations;' 4 Breakfast Sandwiches & Wraps; 2 egg breakfasts (Feature & Triple 222); 4 Salads; 12 Sandwiches & Wraps; 5 Kids Corner entrees (no age requirement); 15 Sides (no hash); & 6 Beverages: Coffee; Sodas; Tea; Milk/Chocolate Milk; Hot Chocolate; & Juices. 

My Breakfast Burrito (SEE PIC) was good. It should have been great. It was large, & due to its size & thickness it required something stronger than Cheddar, such as Pepper Jack. The sausage pieces were small & rather limited-- which contributed to the Burrito's lackluster flavor. Definitely a fresh-tasting entree, but nevertheless a tad disappointing. The BLT Avocado was the Best of Show-- SEE PIC. It was loaded w/ flavor. We each loved our side of Seasoned Potatoes-- as delicious as they were in 1989! Our four other entrees were good. Our server (Ian) was very good. The young woman at checkout was as well; she kindly offered a bag for leftovers. 

A restaurant PLUS-- there's no age limit on the children's menu. None! All five offerings are available to the young at heart. SEE PIC of the hearty $5.95 egg option-- large egg; 2 slices of bacon; & one French toast. Additionally, there are MANY sides offered here-- all can be combined to create an entree. 

Three menu areas where I'd love to see IMPROVEMENT: add a side of Corned Beef Hash; currently, if you want hash, you'll have to order a Lazy Frog Omelet or the Brunchery Sandwich. Offer more varities of cheese to improve entree flavor; & even though not federally required for chains under 20 locations, add CALORIE COUNTS to the menu.

Will I return? Yes. Someday. There are a few menu items that called to me: the Loaded Pancakes (w/ bananas, blueberries, & strawberries); BLT Avocado; the Brunchery Burger; & the Southern Country Skillet.', "Delicious breakfast and lunch place in New Tampa. They have a nice large dining room which was full on a Saturday mid morning. I had the special- strawberry cream cheese stuffed French toast topped with strawberries, raspberry sauce and whipped cream ( no diet for me today). The food came out very fast, within 5 minutes from the time we ordered and it was delicious. The only thing I would say is because they stuff the French toast with strawberry cream cheese , the dish is a little sweeter than I would prefer. I think plain cream cheese would cut the sweetness a little better, but that's personal preference. It also came with 2 eggs, breakfast potatoes and choice of sausage or bacon. I was completely full after this meal and had all the breakfast potatoes to take home. The coffee was fresh and often refilled. Service was excellent. Overall great experience for breakfast, will be back. It's located in a shopping center on Bruce B Downs so there's plenty of parking around. They are open Monday to Sunday from 8am to 2 pm.", "My husband and I had an errand date this past Saturday to Tampa and arrived during breakfast. Hungry and not knowing where to go - Yelp to the rescue! We found The Brunchery just a few minutes from where we needed to be, right off of I-75 and Bruce B. Downs Blvd. They are open for dining in (and take out/delivery) and we were sat immediately. All of the staff were very pleasant and polite people, efficient and helpful - never neglected but they didn't hover.

We chose not to have coffee, but stuck with water, but the coffee smelled very good here. I think we were the only ones not drinking it. (Water comes with lemon, so if you don't want that, you need to tell them immediately.)

Giant chalkboard on one wall with specials had us drooling, but I had already spotted the BLT Avocado Omelette on the menu and any other tempting item couldn't lure me away from that. It took my husband a lot longer to choose. Our food arrived promptly, hot and very fresh.

My omelette came with seasoned potatoes, but I asked if they could substitute anything else, and they had choices of grits, tomatoes, and. fruit cup (up-charge for fruit) so I chose tomato. The tomatoes were lovely and super fresh. Oh, there was a biscuit on the side that was light and very fluffy.

The BLT Avocado Omelette itself was a treat. It was a spinach omelette with Swiss cheese, topped with another tomato, bacon, more cheese, and avocado. The omelette on the bottom actually stayed hot longer that way, with the cooler items on top instead of being stuffed inside.

My husband ordered The Brunchery Benedict, which was poached eggs, ham, mushrooms & Swiss. I had a bite and it was delicious. The hollandaise sauce was perfect. He had the seasoned potatoes with his. I tasted those as well, delicious and he agreed, but there was a lot of them (and that Benedict was very large) and he said he wished he had substituted tomatoes for his as well. 

The prices were great for the amount of food we received. We talked about how we wished there was one of these close to home in Lakeland because there were SO many things on the menu we would love to try - and we didn't even look at the lunch menu!

I highly recommend this place if you are in the neighborhood."]

name: Philadelphia Auto Body
categories_raw: Body Shops, Auto Detailing, Automotive, Auto Repair
top_reviews:
["Shout out to Ed and crew! 

After scratching up my car pretty solidly in a tight driveway earlier this year, plus more love taps than any car should endure, my vehicle was looking pretty beat up. 

I pass Philadelphia Auto Body regularly and noticed their signs to check them out on Yelp. I was impressed by the reviews and before/after photos, so brought my car in for an estimate. Admittedly, it was a little more than I wanted to spend, but Ed walked through every step and I realized I had underestimated the amount of work needed. At the end of the day, I feel like the price was well worth the result. 

My car looks beautiful! There is zero evidence of the driveway incident, and my bumper was also touched up quite a bit (anything more would have required a new bumper so I am thrilled with the results of the touch up). Additionally, Ed recommended a bumper license plate protector for the front of my car - a genius suggestion that looks great and will hopefully help keep the front from getting too banged up in the future. Last but not least, the team identified some shoddy repair work from a previous incident that was handled by another shop in the city. They fixed these mistakes as part of my service, which I greatly appreciate. 

But wait, there's more! My car was returned with a full detail. Goodbye, Jersey shore sand and grime. 

I feel like my car is new again. I'm so happy! Highly recommend these guys and wouldn't hesitate to bring my car there again.", 'I want to preface this by saying that they have a lot of great reviews, so my experience may be atypical. I trusted them largely based on these reviews, however, so I feel that I should share my experience.

First off, they do beautiful body work, which is the reason they got two stars at all. Even the dealership has trouble matching my paint color, but Philadelphia Auto Body had no trouble making my car look like new.
