The only thing I would change about the whole experience would be to live here a bit longer so that we could hire them more regularly!", "I found this housekeeping service on yelp when my regular housekeeper cancelled at the last minute. I called a few companies listed needing a cleaning ASAP. Angie Nola's responsiveness sealed the deal. I called them on a Sunday, they were at the house on Monday morning. 
She kept communication open with needing to come an extra hour later which I appreciated. Their price was comparable to other companies out there. The ladies who came to clean did the base boards, floors, rugs, washed, dusted, cleaned out the fridge in addition to the regular housekeeping. I was thoroughly impressed and will call them for cleanings regularly."]

name: Glazer Children's Museum
categories_raw: Toy Stores, Shopping, Arts & Entertainment, Museums, Local Flavor, Children's Museums
top_reviews:
['Huge museum downtown for curious kiddos. 

Visited on 5-30-19 at 9:30am. Children 1 and under are free, kids are $10, adults are $15. Parking in the garage was about a dollar an hour and it was PACKED. 5 levels of parking and I had a hard time finding a spot.  

This is a high dollar museum and it shows. It's super clean, modern, and has lots for kids to do. A lot of times kids use and abuse the exhibits but they do a fantastic job of cleaning, doing repairs, and replenishing exhibits as needed. 

Downstairs is a huge water table which mimics the port of Tampa, a toddler area for the little ones, a "sand pit"(the "sand" is made from recycled rubber bands), and a Subway restaurant. The next level has climbing areas and loads of play pretend environments. Every area is very interactive and hands-on. 

I was here as part of my child's field trip. I don't think I'd pay full price to go back but he and I really enjoyed our visit today.', 'I have to update my review now that the downstairs part is also open.

Even though it's like a third of a floor, opening the downstairs part really makes a huge difference. Now, on the first floor, there is an area for the 3 and under crowd, a huge water table play station, and a "sandy" area. 

Can we all just agree that 3 and under should stay 3 and under? This isn't the museum's fault and it probably isn't worth the money to staff someone to watch this, but there is a young baby/toddler section so they don't get run over. My son almost got jumped on by children who looked over 5 years old in the mini ball pit. All the young children were just hanging out there barely moving and some older children came jumping. Maybe they were kids with younger siblings so the parents wanted them all in the same place, but it was in no way ideal. I'm still happy that they have this little section, I just wish it was policed more. 

The "sandy" area is pretty neat. It's not really sand, but more like super tiny rubber pieces. You don't have to worry about your kids being covered in the stuff. The only reason we stayed out of that area is I'm sure my son would try to eat it. 

The giant water table is pretty cool too. They have outfit covers for kids to wear to try to stop them from getting soaking wet, but there are few and disappear quickly. If you have a splasher it might be worth bringing your own poncho. I can say that because I have a million Yelp ponchos. 

On the weekend, upstairs can be quite chaotic. The Publix is a free for all where the kids are grabbing all the goods and one museum staffer is halfheartedly trying to reshelve them. However, the other areas, although somewhat crowded, never felt overly so. 

It may be that now that my son is walking I enjoyed it more because he could explore, but I definitely think for the price this place is worth five stars.', "Definitely a museum for kids. Lots of kids activities and even some that I wanted to try like the paper airplane shooter. 

Half a day is enough. 

Downstairs was great to get some wildness out of our little one. Definitely made upstairs more manageable with him a little winded so we put him in the carrier and just walked with him. 

Such a great small children's museum in the middle of downtown. 

We spent a bunch of time playing on the drums. And watching the gear in our boys brain just a going."]

name: The N Crowd
categories_raw: Performing Arts, Arts & Entertainment, Nightlife, Comedy Clubs
top_reviews:
['This was a really great time. EVERY Friday night at 8PM, they do their short-form improv comedy show. I was laughing the whole time. Tickets are only $10 and the show is nearly two hours long! The time flies because you will be having fun.

The theater space they currently use is on the second floor of the Actors Studio on Third Street. It is a small space with about 38 chairs. The AC was running constantly so the space was kept nice and chilled while the performance was going on.

Jokes and wit come at you at 100 miles per hour. The energy and ingenuity of this group is absolutely outstanding. If you're a newcomer to improv, the short-form style (or improv games) are what make up this performance on Fridays. So, if you've seen "Who's Line is it Anyway" on TV, you'll kind of know what's going on. But that's not really important, because improv is about being spontaneous! They also do long-form, but at different times.

Afterwards, you're most likely to find the cast getting drinks and some food at Charlie's Pub just down the street around 10:30 PM.

Check their website for show times, other events, and to order tickets in advance. However, you can always buy them at the door.', "If you're tired of spending your Friday nights getting drunk in your local Philly watering hole and are looking to expand your cultural horizons (well maybe not that cultural but whatever) than look no further than the N crowd. 

Its a improv comedy club that performs every Friday in old city. Not every moment was falling out of your seat hilarious, but there were plenty of good moments, and I had a whole new appreciation for how difficult improv comedy must be. The show does let out fairly early so you'll still have plenty of time to get drunk, if spending a Friday night watching a comedy show is too sober for you. I definitely recommend it...", "Recently came here on a first date and while the date was overall fantastic, the N Crowd provided a fantastic way to spend some time breaking the ice and laughing together. 

The venue is small and intimate, which only encourages the required audience participation. The performers themselves were funny, some more than others, but certainly all were more quick witted than I could ever hope to be!  The series of skits made time fly and it was well with the cost of the ticket. 

I'm really looking forward to coming back someday!"]

name: Pho An Hoa Restaurant
categories_raw: Vietnamese, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["I finally branched out and tried another Vietnamese restaurant in the Tampa Bay Area. The restaurant was clean and the staff was very friendly. 

We started with the fresh rolls and those were very good. I ordered the large bowl of beef pho, which wasn't too bad. The broth was ok too, still not as tasty as my favorite, Saigon Deli, just down the road. I was disappointed with the portion of beef and noodles in pho. Usually, I end up taking home leftovers from most Vietnamese restaurants but there seemed to be more broth than anything in this pho. 

My friend's Bún looked good, but once again, the portions of pork and eggrolls were very small. 

I would probably go back and maybe try other dishes but I prefer bigger portions from the other Vietnamese restaurants.", "This restaurant has the seven beef courses for $35 for two and $45 for three. We did not go for it since I want to eat light tonight. Their seven beef course is probably cheaper in Bay Area. 

Tonight we have order a grilled quail for appetizer, combination beef pho and the Hu Tieu Nam Vang noodle soup. I have try many restaurant grilled quail, each one have their differences. This restaurant added a sweet sauce on top make it very nice and juicy. I like it when the hot sweet sauce eventually cooks the lettuce below and it is great to eat it.

The pho is average in the Bay Area. I like the rare slice beef when they cook it. In Canada, they have the rare beef on the side for you to add. This is better since you don't want it to overcook. Unfortunately none of the Bay Area Vietnamese restaurants have prepared this way. The Hu Tieu Nam Vang is noddle soup with clear both with fried garlic base. I like they add the liver, quail egg, shrimp, squid and ground pork into the soup. This is a good soup when you are sick. 

Overall the restaurant is busy. The service is average; the waitresses are able to speak English. Food quality is great. I like the grilled quail here. The rainbow drink is with ice cube instead of shave ice. I prefer shave ice.", 'Our favorite place for pho in Tampa.  Be prepared, it looks like a dump.  In a very unassuming strip mall off Waters it is worth braving the wonky parking lot and awkward intersection to get in and feast on the most delicious pho Tampa's got.  They were notched down one star because they don't carry ANY vegetarian options.  I asked once why and the owner said they used to but never sold any and it kept going bad.  I get it.  But that sucks.  

I order the large bowl of Pho Ga EVERY SINGLE TIME.  I order it without chicken and extra veggies.  I've never strayed and I've never been tempted to.  It's delicious.  I crave it when I'm sick, I crave it when I'm well.  It's so damn good.  The large bowl (they aren't kidding around with "large") comes with perfectly cooked rice noodles and fresh veggies simmering in the rich chicken broth.  It's pretty good on it's own but you should never have it on it's own.  With each bowl of pho comes a plate of fresh sprouts, limes, jalapenos, and basil.  You need to add all of it.  Then scoop some condiments in.  I usually just add some garlic chili sauce and call it perfection.  Also available though is Siracha, teriyaki sauce, soy, fish sauce (blech), and chili oil.  

The service is great and the bowls come out really fast.  We've ordered the spring rolls before and they are good but I've always asked for them without shrimp and they always come with shrimp.  They are very fresh so I don't think they are pre-made but something gets lost in translation.  Even after removing the shrimp it still tasted shrimp-y.  

Bottom line, go here.  For around $6 you can leave with a full belly, no MSG headache (we asked), and a serious craving to come again.']

name: The Saint
categories_raw: Nightlife, Dive Bars, Bars
top_reviews:
['After a serious review of my review I find no reason to not add a star since, by some miracle, I survive every visit to The Saint, which is saying a lot.  

Please preface my update with my previous review. It all still stands. What have I gleaned from my serendipitous visits over the last 4 years, and my most recent experience this NYE?...I will tell you. 

Leave any 'tude at home. This space is NOT, dare I repeat, NOT big enough for it. No 'tude. Just good or weird vibes can pass the librarian-meets-orc defender bouncer, with proper ID, through the dark foyer (I'm not sure what else to call it but you'll understand if you ever go) into the Saint. 

Most recently, I had some dudes looming over me that were like, "dude, I was here first...no I was here first." You're not in line to get a cookie during little recess, bros. Your neediness scares away the 'tenders. Act like you totally don't want that drink, and you will be served promptly. 

Recent Discovery #1: Go With A Daq! There is no need to act like a badass and order Jameson shots just to realize you also want a vodka soda so you have to act like you don't need a drink again for another 15 minutes...'cause, hello, the rotation has started over again. 

Back to the daqs...they have delicious options! I asked for a chocolate-y one, and they had TWO, not one, but TWO options. Real talk, I can't chug uber-cold drinks, so one of their daqs can last me hours so no need to patron the always busy bar as often. And if you were to ask the 2:00am version of myself, they ain't too shabby. And no one gets 'tude when drinking daqs, and if you do, you probably need to go see someone about that. 

Recent Discovery #2: The Photo Booth! I WISH I could tell you whether or not it just took cash or credit as well, but my recollection is that it's just cash per my hazy-but-somewhat vivid recollection of yelling for more dollars at anyone passing by. You call it a hot mess, I call it makin' memories. Also a great space if you would like to have an earnest conversation with a person you just met that doesn't remember you the next time you're there 6 months later (spoken through a friend). 

Recent Discovery #3: Sex Toy Claw Machine. I haven't so much discovered it as just kind of looked at it. I have been known to extricate a fluffy bunny or two from such machines, but alas, I probably need to carry some coinage with me next time I visit The Saint. 

Last Discovery...I must keep to myself. It is the sole reason I was not swept away by the wave upon wave of overly-eager patrons that crashed into The Saint at the ungodly hours when it thrives on New Year's Eve. 

...and no I have no bathroom aka Hobbit Hole updates. 

Last note, and this isn't a recent discovery. This is like the ultimate rule. Never. ever. ever. ever. ever. ever. ever ever. ever. Don't ever check the time and/or say it out loud while you are in the four...er. maybe like six or eight walls of The Saint. Quite possibly the biggest sin you can commit in there and you will immediately be transformed into the biggest of fun sponges that ever did live. Personal experience? Wouldn't you like to know...', "There comes a point in life when something clicks and you suddenly realize you are in public....Holding 9 shots of Jameson, 4 cans of PBR and a minty coffee beverage that tastes like the soul of an innocent girl scout.

Surrounded by graffiti.
Its dark.
Its dirty.
And its sticky. 

You look around.

What day is it?
What was I doing here? 
Where did I come from?

Was I just roaming around in a frenzy of some kind? 
Who are these people, these faces? 
Where do they come from? 

You're right in the middle of a fucking reptile zoo, and somebody is giving booze to these goddamn things. 

It won't be long now before they tear you to shreds.

Panicked, you make it through the double doors at the front entrance and realize you are 1 block off Magazine street.

The sun is out.

It's only Tuesday.

And you're at the Saint.", 'No two nights at The Saint are ever the same. I've had epic nights, and mellow night, dead nights, and nights were I couldn't even get past the bouncer. Most these nights are weekend nights, and I've yet to find myself Sainting it up on a weekday. 

Heads up: We all know there are New Orleans bars that your 17 year old cousin that looks like she's maybe 19 1/2 can get into by batting her eyes at the bouncer and passing back IDs. Not this one. Don't even try. This bouncer is stone cold. Walk away. 

I've been to The Saint during epic techno parties during the witching hour where it had to have been 30 degrees outside, 98 inside, and a gentlemen in a purple mohair jacket owned the dance floor. Make sure you're good and drunk for the late night scene or else your sense of smell with slap you silly and your hearing with give out. 

I've been there, and discovered the amazingness that is their patio with an outdoor bar, quite possibly just as large as the bar, though I actually can't tell how large the bar truly is due to lighting and poor eye sight. I really enjoy the patio for an Uptown afterwork scene. Next time, I'll snap a pic! 

I've also been there during weird middle lulls between when everyone who came after work has moved on to their second bar around 9:30/10ish and the after midnight crazy hasn't started yet. The Saint isn't a place you can do a drive-by and figure if it's "poppin'" or not, you've got to go into the belly of the beast. 

Another Yelper was spot on about the bathroom; one of my lesser favorite Hobbit hole sized ladies rooms in town so bring your hand sani and hover. 

I would definitely suggest you spend some time on their patio to see how much more this place has to offer. I need to catch a weekday or a karaoke night with the boyfriend sometime to expand my Saintly experiences.']

name: SET NoLibs
categories_raw: Mexican, Bars, Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Lounges, Nightlife, Salad, Tacos
top_reviews:
["So what I was NOT expecting on a lovely Mother's day of taking our moms and wives out was to experience one of the best burgers I've ever had. First of all, Set NoLibs is an interesting name, but at least the outside seating was swanky with a table fire pit encased in glass. Only hard part was passing food and hoping the person grabbe the plate fast enough so you don't burn yourself lol Be careful! 

The oakwood benches looked cool, but most of our butts were hurting after a short while and our feet were getting numb. Random, I know. The no touch menu made things easy to order and I took the safe route with a burger which was a 30-day dry-aged beef burger with a fried egg and garlic aioli sauce. The burger was perfectly cooked and seasoned well. Not too salty, or greasy at all. The egg was perfectly cooked.

My fave part of the burger was that brioche bun and garlic aioli. The garlic was stronger than I expected which was a great thing to me. The waffles fries that came with the burger were amazing as well! It was enough food to fill me up half the day. MY sister didn't like her tater tots and tried to steal some of my waffles fries. She's lucky I love her, so I gave her 2 fries lol", "Let me start off by saying I loved it here and cannot wait to return! With that out of the way, went to brunch -- there was mimosas! The end! LOL!

Of course, I wanted the mimosa tower for $69 (it's better for maybe 3 or more people). It was just my friend and I. She met me here (drove over an hour to Philly). We opted for the bottle of champagne w/ OJ $35. I got a shot of peach flavor to go with my mimosa. I enjoyed every drop and loved mixing in the OJ, champagne and peach! On point...delicious. 
Buzzzzzed! I ordered the hangover tots!!! I did not know I wanted this in my life! I loved this yummy,  hot mess, of a concoction! Friend is vegan and she enjoyed her meal too!

Made reservations several days in advance for Sunday brunch on OpenTable. Outdoor seating was the only spots available (at the time)-- I snagged it! The reservations are a hot commodity I see. We were both running a bit late. There's a little bit of a grace period and the employees here were very accommodating to our delay. Customer service was good too!

Love...this...spot...for...BRUNCH!", 'i wanted to like this place, i really did. but it's so overpriced and the quality doesn't match!!! it's a 2.5 / 5 for me dawg. not worth it. way better drinks and food in the area


my first time here i just got take out and got some sliders and waffle fries and it was delicious! so it convinced me to come back for brunch with my friends

we got some bloody mary pitchers, margaritas and mojitos

bloody mary - bland bland bland. even though it says "thai chili" i tasted nothing thai or chili about it. it was so bland that we asked for hot sauce and mustard and added in our own flavor to not waste the pitcher

margaritas - this was nasty. it was just lime juice and maybe a sparkle of tequila. we asked for new ones and tried to send them back but the server said too bad and wouldn't take them off our bill... which was $300 by the way.... RIDIULCOUS!

mojitos - it was OK. super sweet and didn't taste very natural. for $16 i could have found a better one in the neighborhood

now on to the food... it was better than our drink experience but not good enough to make us come back

the vietnamese steak and eggs were OK. steak was cooked well but these potatoes underneath the eggs were so mushy. it was almost like boiled potatoes even though it said "home fries" it was inedible for me

my husband said his burger was decent but all his waffle fries were these little pieces of potato, he only had 3 full fries. 

the avocado toast meal is literally one piece of bread. NOT EVEN 2 for the price.


all in all, save your money, there's better brunch picks in the city']

name: Revival
categories_raw: Fashion, Men's Clothing, Beauty & Spas, Shopping, Barbers, Men's Hair Salons, Hair Salons
top_reviews:
["Long story short I found Revival at their old location in the LGD, but they've since moved a couple blocks from me ( huge blessing). 

The new location is nice and Chris is just a awesome guy. Every time I go in we always have great conversation and he's an extremely gifted barber as well. Not to mention the prices are really reasonable given the quality of services. 

There's no longer a shortage of barbers in Mid-City thanks to the gentlemen at Revival!! Give them a shot you won't regret it.", "When it comes to men's style haircuts, Revival Grooming is as good as it gets. I've been getting my hair cut here for about 9 months and I have no regrets. Chris is one of the coolest dudes you'll ever meet and he's a rockstar of his trade. He always checks in with you at the start of your appointment to see what you want done with your hair (even if you're a regular) and then delivers time after time, a super solid cut. I always enjoy my convos with Chris and I appreciate that he doesn't just rush through my haircut. 

Being a queer woman, I find it incredibly intimidating to find a barber most of the time. Chris, puts me at ease. In fact, anytime I ask a queer friend of mine who cuts their hair, they usually respond that it's Chris over at Revival! 

If you are searching for a barber and live in NOLA (or even if you're visiting), you've got to check this place out. You won't be sorry! The location is A++++ because it's right next door to Courtyard Brewery and on the same block as French Truck Coffee. It's also a couple blocks away from Bakery Bar. So basically, you can do your own coffee, haircut, booze, dessert crawl if that's your kind of thing and treat-yo-self, because hey, you probably deserve it.", "The last guy who did my hair up in Brooklyn NY kind of screwed me up, and I had to grow it out to let a competent barber fix his mistakes.  Got my hair cut and styled by Justin Kane February 19, and it was absolutely perfect.  Got me right through Mardi Gras and into Corona Gras.  Now I'm starting to look a little shaggy,  but after 6 weeks I still look better than I did after the Brooklyn cut. Nice job Justin, hoping to see you in May.  By the way, order a Tee shirt at revivalgrooming.bigcartel.com and endorse these guys!"]

name: Wilensky Locks & Hardware
categories_raw: Contractors, Home Services, Home & Garden, Hardware Stores, Keys & Locksmiths, Door Sales/Installation, Shopping, Building Supplies
categories: ['contractors', 'home services', 'home & garden', 'hardware stores', 'keys & locksmiths', 'door sales/installation', 'shopping', 'building supplies']
top_reviews:
["I had a very positive experience with Wilensky's. Our front door lock had been getting tougher and tougher to open\xa0over the course of a few weeks -\xa0to the point where we realized we couldn't leave the house without getting it fixed because we feared we wouldn't be able to get back in! 

I found Wilensky's on Yelp, gave them a ring in the morning and spoke with a friendly guy who said he would have their locksmith give me a call as soon as he was in. I received a call maybe an hour later and the locksmith said he could be over around noon, and he was. 

Turned out, something in our lock had broken and needed to be replaced. This was remedied in about fifteen or twenty minutes and now our lock works perfectly. The total charge was $140 -\xa0eighty or ninety of that was the visit alone and the rest was for the fix. Yowza. Hopefully my locks will be good to go for a long time!", 'i dont know how long wilenskys has been here but it looks like forever, its like the country hardware store your "pa" would go to and i love it. the floors here are older than most of our houses and sometimes while looking through the shelves you'll find a tool dating back to the 70's.
 until recently the owner or father of the owner worked here very regularly and despite my offers and his age (90 i heard today) he would climb to get the spray paints i wanted. there are old wooden bins filled with nails and a whole case of knives for only $4.99, wow! 
 i wont lie, they dont have everything you can get at home depot, but they have alot of what you never get at home depot. the two guys who work here now ( barry and jack i beleive) are friendly and honest, and have really good advice most of the time. they make keys and do it cheap. if you live in south philly, anywhere in south philly, you deserve wilenskys and they deserve you.

p.s. rad old cash register.', "OK - I'll be honest: When I saw this Polish name, I, as a Pole, KNEW that it would be my favorite hardware store. But when I MET Mr. Wilensky, I just fell in love. He is so patient, learned, diligent, and accomodating....and fair. Not only fair in practice, but in price. I have read the other reviews touting his rescue endeavors with all manner of lock and key screwups, and I know who I'M going to call when I'm in a bind at 2 a.m. His store is stocked full with all the necessities and then some. Leave it to a fellow countryman to honor fine craftmanship, good business practice, and a neighborhood faithful following. Sto Lat!"]

name: George's Sandwich Shop
categories_raw: Italian, Cheesesteaks, Restaurants, Sandwiches
top_reviews:
['We visited Little Italy and stopped at the Visitor Center and asked the lady there where the locals go to eat their Philly Cheesesteaks and she mentioned this place as the place to go to. This is not a sit down restaurant, they have a window where you order your food and then you either take it to go or you find a sidewalk table or bench to have you meal. We chose to go around the corner and just sat at a church stairs and have our lunch. My girlfriend ordered the tripe sandwich and I went with the Philly Cheesesteak. Both sandwiches were unbelievably good. My cheesesteak was so flavorful and cheesy with onions, and my girlfriend essentially said the tripe was similar to the way she makes tripe at home. Bottom line, the next time I go back I will hit this spot again!!', 'Looking for something tasteless, greasy, and overpriced?! Head on over to George's Sandwich Shop! What a disaster. The roast pork sandwich is listed as $7.00, fine, but any sandwich-eater worth their salt (or pepper) knows that a sandwich isn't complete without some toppings, and George's sticks it to you ever-so-casually: "Anything on that?" Unsuspecting customers will be charged on top of the $7 for what should be basic, included toppings. This would be acceptable if the sandwich had any semblance of decency, yet it is completely revolting from first glance to last choked bite.The bread was completely soggy and drenched in oil that was hot enough to burn my hand. The pork was entirely flavorless, the provolone and broccoli rabe couldn't even save it. I regret wasting my appetite on this disgrace of a sandwich. Do yourself a favor and go down the street to Paesano's instead.', "Whether you're looking for delicious traditional options, or for a taste of the bizarre, George's has plenty of sandwich varieties to tantalize your taste buds.

For the long haul I knew that George's was a prized South Philly sandwich institution; even if it is a little more off the radar than the likes of John's Roast Park, Sarcone's, the Pat's/Geno's monstrosities, et all. But like most Yelpers, it wasn't until I saw the incredible Philly edition of Bizarre Foods where our (and Federal Donuts!) own Felicia D. took Andrew Zimmerman here that had me intrigued. And while I wasn't exactly sold on chowing down on the tripe and tongue combo right away, I knew that it was a destination that I had to hit!

My first bite of pure sandwich bliss was the hot Italian sausage (the normal hot, not the BURN MY ASS variety!) fully loaded with broccoli rabe. If you're looking for a perfect sandwich combo this is hands down it! As I gradually worked up the stomach to go bizarre I found that tripe and tongue (which isn't even on the menu officially) surprisingly make for another perfect combo. juicy and tender would be two adjectives you wouldn't think of in the situation that actually hit the mark.

From cheesesteaks and cheeseburgers, to meatballs and roast pork George's definitely has plenty of the usual offerings done right. But when you're looking to take a bite out of adventure on your lunchbreak, it's a sandwich shop that's somewhat unrivaled."]

name: Fox In a Box Tucson
categories_raw: Arts & Entertainment, Active Life, Escape Games
top_reviews:
['I am back in Tucson and decided to do another 1 of their escape rooms.
The staff are friendly and helpful. They make sure to explain everything before you start.

We did the Zombie room last time, but this time we decided to try the wild wild west room where you try to save the town from destruction.

This room was very fun, plenty of hard puzzles to figure out, but with some helpful hints, it was nice to escape with a few minutes to go.

The room was kind of dark, wish there had been better lighting to help with reading some of the clues. 

There were a few puzzles that did not make sense intuitively, but that did not hinder the game.

Definitely looking forward to trying the 3rd room next time we are here.', "I have done escape rooms in Oceanside and San Diego and they are all slightly different. I really enjoyed my time at FIABT.

It started with playing some puzzle games in the lobby waiting area to get your mind ready, and then Neil,1 of the owners, thoroughly explaining all of the rules, tips, hints, answering all questions, and finally playing a fun video that gave back story to the Zombie Lab experience. We were advised it had no clues to help in the room but it was still a nice touch and well put together.

The room itself is large size compared to other escape room companies.

The locks are easy to spot, while getting them open is not so easy. 

I don't know how someone did this in 28+ minutes unless it was their 2nd time. We got close to finishing and the owner showed us what was left and how to solve it, we probably could have finished in 5-10 more minutes. We definitely should have used all of our hints, and asked for them a little sooner and we might have been able to finish on time. 

The puzzles were pretty fun, well thought out, there was a good flow to the room, and the various stages to progress thru the experience.

I found out that the 2 existing rooms have been there for 2.5 years, the bank room is the harder room and only has about 33% escape rate, the zombie lab room was easier and about 45-50% escape rate, and they have a brand new wild west room starting tomorrow.

You can have as few as 2 people or up to 6 people in your party.

It is located near campus and plenty of shopping and paid parking.
It is up stairs and there are restrooms nearby and water available for purchase.", "This was such a different experience. I've never done an escape room before but I can't wait to go back and try their other rooms. 

This place is located on the second level in main gate square. They validated parking for the Tyndall garage. The owners and game masters were incredibly nice and welcoming.

Our group of 6 tried the bank room. They gave us our back story to help us get in to character and it was helpful to be in the mindset of a bank robber. I loved that there was a ticking clock to remind me to move quickly. The clues required mathematical thinking, abstract thinking, divergent thinking, seeking skills and teamwork. It really helped that we had a well rounded group of people, different ages and occupations. Some had done escape rooms before and some had not. Every one of us had fun! 

I can't say more or it could spoil YOUR fun but you should absolutely give this place a try. The people in our group who tried other escape rooms told me that since I started with this one, the other escape rooms in town pale in comparison and I'll be disappointed if I try those. So if you're new to this type of activity, or you've done a bunch before, I'm sure you'll have fun here and won't be disappointed."]

name: BK Tacos
categories_raw: Restaurants, Tacos, Mexican, Hot Dogs, Breakfast & Brunch, Steakhouses
top_reviews:
["Looking for a greasy Mexican spot? Or like me and my homegirl, are you looking some big ass tacos at about 10pm on a Friday night? Look no further. I definitely dug the divey atmosphere with a menu full of your tex mex favorites along with hot dogs. Say what?

Their salsa bar was large and had some odd toppings. It took me a hot second to comprehend why the hell a salsa bar had mustard and shredded cheese, but then it dawned on me... the Sonoran hot dog. This isn't your average salsa bar, because it also happens to be a hot dog bar.

I went for the al pastor and the chicken tacos and I've had better. They were large, but super greasy. The guac was extremely creamy, but definitely didn't taste the freshest and it was that dark green hue that comes from maybe some of the avocados a little past their prime. It was also topped with like a parmesan style cheese which didn't help. 

The sonoran hot dog? A few bites, but it was more bread than dog. Womp womp.
The margarita? Sugary, but strong!

Service was great, it was pretty cheap and definitely has a divey, locals scene. I think there's probably better out there, but for some late night eats, not so shabby!", "Man, I've waited too long in my life to finally eat at BK Tacos. I finally made the plunge and got two Sonora Dogs with the works. I went drive-thru and a sign lets you know to be patient, as they prepare and craft your meal. It did take a while, and boy was it worth it. Not sure what I can add to the other flowing reviews other than, yum. Soft buns, delicious dog, excellent toppings. Now that I have popped my BK cherry, I will be sure to return more often and sample the other yummy looking items on the menu. And at $2.99 a dog, it's a steal!", 'My local Tucsonan friend talked up this restaurant so much that I had to go try it out.

Food was not bad at all - ordered four tacos: two carne asada tacos, a chicken taco, and a fish taco. They came out pretty quick, fresh, and they came with plenty of toppings in individual containers. My friend told me that pre-Covid, they used to have a salsa bar, which is not temporarily closed.
I also tried my first Sonoran Hot Dog which was pretty good, but I'd had better hot dogs before.

The only downside about this location? Service.
After we were seated, despite the many servers who walked by our table and looking in our direction, NOBODY bothered to stop by. We waited a while, and then waited some more, until I eventually had to ask my friend, "is this restaurant full service or do you have to order at the bar?" to which she replied, "It was full service before Covid, but maybe it changed?". So, I got up and walked to the bar and asked to the guy behind the bar, "Are y'all a full service restaurant? Or do we have to order here because nobody seems to want to help us at the table?" And only after then did someone finally came by to take our orders. She was apologetic about it, but the fact remains that even she had seen us at the table and decided not to help us just like the rest of the servers there.']

name: Good Karma Cafe
categories_raw: Food, Cafes, Coffee & Tea, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["after a crazybusyfuuunnn thanksgiving weekend, i finally caught up on my zzzzz's sunday morning as i woke up around noon and didn't motivate off of my friend's couch until well past 2pm. by that time, nausea had turned to hunger, and my belly needed food...my head needed coffee.

seeing as it was a chilly day, the belly was fed a piping hot bowl of tomato basil soup with rice. it came served in a giant bowl along with a sizable slice of sourdough bread, which i used to sop up every last drop of the soup. if you see this on the menu - get it!

along with my hot soup, i enjoyed a hot coffee. (i repeat: chilly day.) no fancy latte or cappuccino for my hurtin head....just a straight up cup o' joe. i had the medium roast (nice that they offer this along with light & dark roasts) with vanilla soy milk (just ask, they keep it behind the counter) and it was simply lovely. bonus points for being fair trade.

for some reason i was expecting a dark nook of a cafe and was pleasantly surprised to walk into such an airy, well-lit and spacious....space. tho nearly every table was full, it didn't feel crowded. no barking dogs or unruly children (or parents). if my vagabond lifestyle leads me to waking up in this 'hood again, i'll surely be back.", 'Big fan of their drink selection and sandwiches! The best mango smoothie I have ever had!', "I guess you could say Good Karma left me feeling a little cold. Literally. The cafe is all adorable-like up front near the windows, but as you near the back, the charm pulls a fade faster than that one hot piece of man candy from freshman year.

This back area was drafty and chilly on a winter's day. Fortunately, my delicious latte helped keep me warm.

I could see possibly returning in order to get some serious work done; there wasn't much in the way of distractions, and the wood tables and chairs kept me from relaxing too much. If I want to grab a cuppa with friends, however, I'll head elsewhere."]

name: 21st Amendment at La Louisiane
categories_raw: Nightlife, Bars
top_reviews:
['Bar far my favorite bar in New Orleans. 
Beautiful 1920's decor. Fantastic Jazz bands played all four nights we came by. Great space for dancing. Wonderful taste in movies playing behind the bar. They were playing American Gangster the first night, and other equally good choices the following nights. 
The bartenders here have so much talent, and wonderful variety of booze, herbs, spirits, fruit & veggies to work with.
The bartenders were champions of my favorite drinking game "here's some things I like, and surprise me". Not only did they surprise me, but they were dangerous drinks. Ones that sneak up on you, because they taste so lovely and innocent, but they certainly are not. 
We love you Amendment 21! 
2016 #28', 'Some of my buddies that live out here in Louisiana recommended to meet here at 21st Ammendment and came out with a group of friends to check it out. 

Once we got here it was shocking how nice the bar was based on the Bourbon St experience.  Went up to the bar and asked for a drink menu that had a very nice selection of your higher end drinks to sip and enjoy. Bar tenders take pride and time on making each drink that is rare to find. 

Anyways experience was great if you want to lounge and enjoy a drink with good service and ambiance. 

Highly recommend.', 'Live jazz and cocktails here!

I am loving the name and what this place has to be offer entirely. 

I adore the vibes because of its speakeasy surrounding.']

name: The Palace of Indian
categories_raw: Restaurants, Indian
top_reviews:
["I was so excited to try this place. I've spent a lot of time in India and live just around the corner...

Sadly - the waiter (who I think might also be the owner) was very rude. He spoke on the telephone extremely loudly through much of our meal. I understand he needed to respond to delivery orders but there is no need to yell! He never checked to see how our food was and seemed annoyed when we hailed him down to ask him for things. He rushed us in our meal. And at the end, he asked us to get up and leave because he had people waiting for the table. We had just signed the check (which took forever to get processed) and were calling an Uber on a rainy night. I've never experienced anything like it in any restaurant!

The food was bland and unremarkable. Frozen palak paneer from Trader Joe's is better. I wish I could recommend - but I don't think I will ever go back.

* note: see the owner's response. Every time someone has a bad review of this place, it is usually because he was rude. And then he responds to the criticism rudely - and with a different version of the experience - and with basic ignorance of restaurant practice. (i.e you never ask a customer to leave, especially when they have only just paid the check. And he certainly did not do so politely.)", "Just gave this place a shot as my husband and I live in the neighborhood. We won't be going back. Server was rude and flippant, food (malai kofta and lamb korma) both bland, the naan was fine, but oily, but besides the totally underwhelming food and rude waiter, it was SO HOT inside the restaurant that I literally wanted to get out of there after sitting at our table for 5 minutes. Complaining to the wait staff about the heat  at this establishment (even when you are 8.5 months pregnant) just gets you a to go box and smirked at. Don't waste your time and money here and if you're in the mood for good, authentic Indian, just go straight to Ekta.

- update** - I'm not on Yelp to argue with business owners, but the fact that he felt the need to respond so defensively to my review AND accuse me off lying on top of that should really tell you something. AND.... what Indian restart charges for extra rice??? Ridiculous.", 'I'd actually give it a 2.5 but that's not an option...

This location has been the home of numerous restaurants since we've been living in this neighborhood. We were excited when we saw it would be an Indian restaurant, and when we spotted the "open" sign a few days ago, we decided to have dinner here Saturday night. 

The service was perfunctory. Not much effort shown here. We called ahead to find out if we could bring beer or wine in and we were told yes. When we arrived, I asked for an ice bucket so we could keep our beer cool. The server said they did not have any ice buckets and the best he could do was to put ice in our glass of beer. Whaaat?! No, thank you. (Whaaaaaat?!?!)

When we received our appetizer, the vegetable samosas, we were given three sauces but the server didn't tell us what they were. The samosas were great, though, and seemed freshly made. 

I had the palak paneer and it was somewhat disappointing. I've had this dish all over the US and in the UK and I've never known it to be sweet. This version had a sweet taste that was off-putting. Maybe the chef had a bad night?

My husband had the chicken tikka which was serviceable but no better than Tiffin. 

The best part of the meal was the naan -- fresh, hot and buttered. 

I think I'd be open to giving this place another try once it has the kinks worked out. After all, it did just open. 

I noticed there were some shallow, positive reviews here already and I'm thinking you should take these with a grain of salt. I'd love to hear the opinions of other people who have actually paid to eat here!']

name: St. Louis Cemetery No. 1
categories_raw: Funeral Services & Cemeteries, Historical Tours, Public Services & Government, Local Services, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Tours, Hotels & Travel
categories: ['funeral services & cemeteries', 'historical tours', 'public services & government', 'local services', 'landmarks & historical buildings', 'tours', 'hotels & travel']
top_reviews:
['Best New Orleans Cemetery!

When we visited NOLA for the first time (Sept 2019) we didn't get a chance to take a guided tour at any historic cemeteries although we were able to stop at the St. Louis Cemetery No. 3 for 15-mins from a New Orleans bus tour we took.

I was happy to see this cemetery walking tour included in our City Pass because the public can't just walk inside and sightsee on our own. Visitors actually need to be escorted in by a licensed tour guide. Whaaa? Really?? That's because the cemetery has been subject to much vandalism over the years and the church just got tired of cleaning after it. Once again our "tour group" ended up just being the three in my party so we kinda had a personal tour which was nice. Odile, our tour guide was very informative and entertaining...

Highlights:

1) St. Louis Cemetery No. 1 is the burial site of voodoo queen Marie Laveau. People aren't supposed to but they come and leave offerings for the voodoo mistress (see photo). Why the hair ties? Visitors dropped hair accessories near her grave... Marie Laveau was also a hairdresser.

2) For the love of NOLA. I asked if there were any celebrities buried here. She said "not yet" as she proceeded to lead us to the plot for Nicolas Cage, who is still alive and well today. The Oscar-winning actor loves New Orleans and Louisiana. His tomb is shaped like a pyramid, perhaps from his movie "National Treasure." There's no name on it yet but it has the Latin words "Omnia Ab Uno" on it, which translates to "Everything From One." Also, while the actor's 2 properties in New Orleans were foreclosed the government didn't take away his tomb. 

3) First ever I've heard of "Social Tombs." We saw social tombs for Portuguese, Italian and even a musician's social tomb. You could choose to be buried with other strangers if you're on a budget or if you're family couldn't afford your own tomb.

4) The cemetery is tiny and crowded, not much bigger than a square block and tombs are above ground which New Orleans cemeteries are famous for. The vaults are laid out like little houses in mazelike aisles that feel like tiny streets. Many are surrounded by black iron fences, like they have private front yards or something.

5) ... but why are the burial vaults built above ground?? It was explained to us because of the high water table and flooding, and because it was a European cultural custom.

6) Pictures were allowed in the cemetery but we can't film or take videos. But why??? Blame it on actors Dennis Hopper and Peter Fonda from the film "Easy Rider." There was a scene where they dropped acid while cavorting with women. The scene was shot without permission and led the church to ban filming in the cemetery! Gee thanks, Dennis and Peter. Btw, they used the Italian Benevolent Society tomb as a back drop. I have a photo of that social tomb. Yikes! 

7) So they have a weird system for the dead. After being buried the deceased would reside there for a year and a day, before being deposited in the basement, after being effectively cremated naturally in the hot climate.

The tour was about an hour long but it was one of my favorite thing we did. We love the mystery of a cemetery! Thanks to our fantastic tour guide! 

Review #1718', "A historic cemetery with lots to see and learn. A few years back this one was open to the public. Now it's only open for tours at about twenty per person. This because of vandalism in the cemetery and the tix costs go to repairs and upkeep. 

Inside you'll see mostly above ground tombs. There is a small area in the back for Presbyterian graves and those are below. A couple of noteworthy graves are Marie Louveau, aka the voodoo priestess. Also Nicolas Cage had a pyramid shaped grave here for when he passes away. 

Tours are 45 min and fill you in on the history of the burial styles and different types of graves you'll see. Be sure to bring water with you as there is no shade here so you'll wanna keep hydrated. Sunblock isn't a bad idea either! 

Overall: A
Great way to learn a unique piece of the cities history.", "It is the oldest and most famous cemetery in New Orleans, established in the late 1700's, now a top tourist attraction, the Voodoo priestess Marie Laveau is believed to be interred in the Glapion family cryp, and actor Nicolas Cage purchased a pyramid shaped tomb as future final resting place. This cemetery used to be open to public years ago, now all visitors must be accompanied by licensed tour guide."]

name: House of Blues Restaurant & Bar
categories_raw: Restaurants, American (New), Burgers, Southern
top_reviews:
["Stopped in on a Thursday right around the time that Happy Hour was about to end.  The bartender was kind enough to extend it for us.  Which we truly appreciated, it's the little things that show that you value your customers.

I partook in some beer while here and at the prices they had, I was pleasantly surprised.  My friends had decided to get an appetizer while we were here.  I had already eaten or I would have selected something.

They went with gator bites, at least that's what they told me.  I would have tried one, but the corn dusting coating isn't the best for me.  They said it was good and the dipping sauces were great.  They said the hotter one doesn't hit you right away but sticks around for a bit afterwards.

The live music was great to listen to in here, made for a lighter experience.  I also loved the decor.  I'm a sucker for that type of thing.  I know to some it may look cheesy, but I love when a place taps into the area to pull inspiration for the way they look and act within the community.

Store inside was kind of cool too, great place to pick up a souvenir.", 'I have never been to the House of Blues and what a cool restaurant/bar! We missed happy hour which is from 3-6pm but luckily there was live music starting at 630pm. We ordered the brisket nachos and Cajun fries to share. 10/10- the food was delicious!! So happy with our order. The hostess and our waitress, Rebecca, were very nice and attentive. Highly recommend this place as eating/drinking with live music is always great!!', "My friend and I came early for happy hours before our concert. We both order two items each and share. I love jalapeno so I got the jalapeno cornbread and also the chicken tenders. Ria got the brisket nachos and mac & cheese. We didn't realize how huge the nachos were when it came out. We barely made a dent on the nachos because we ate almost all the jalapeno cornbread. The jalapeno cornbread was the best of all four snacks/appetizer we ordered. It was so moist and flavorful with a side of sweet honey butter. The chicken tenders were thin cut and battered and dry. The fries that came with it didn't taste that great either. It taste like it been fry and was left in the warmer too long before being served. The mac & cheese skillet was ok, we both agreed the pasta would taste better if it was soft. I would definitely  come back for more jalapeno cornbread and the nachos. Our server Mike was so helpful and friendly, asking if everything was ok everytime he passes by. So the three stars are for the food and the one star to make four is for staffs and the live entertainment. Two guys were killing it with their guitar and singing. We were well entertained will eating."]

name: Philadelphia Training Academy
categories_raw: Gun/Rifle Ranges, Specialty Schools, Education, Active Life
top_reviews:
["Today was a milestone for me because I did something I've had on the checklist for many years. 

I shot a gun (safely and legally here, of course).

And yes, I realize that shooting is not for everyone, and if that someone is you, then you don't have to read my review. But thanks for stopping by Yelp anyway  :)

But if you're even a little bit curious about going to a shooting range, or you're a seasoned pro, I highly recommend you check out the Philadelphia Archery & Gun Club. I went with a friend of mine who is a gun owner and has been there before and another friend who, like me, was a first timer. From the moment we walked in the door the staff was friendly and professional. Admittedly, I was a little weirded out by all the gun stuff, but hey, I WAS in a shooting range, so I knew I'd be seeing firearms. My friend and I signed a waver, we all three showed our licences, and then went upstairs to the range. It is a very safe facility and you have to go through multiple doors to end up in the shooting range itself.

Once upstairs, we were given earphones, safety glasses, a target and oh, yeah, bullets. Gulp. This was the real deal. I was actually going to shoot a gun. I think I got a little sweaty and my industrial goggles actually fogged up.

We went through another 2 sets of doors and then there we were, gun, bullets and all. After a lesson on loading it and proper etiquette (bottom line - don't point it at people and don't be a spazz) I stepped up to give it a try. 

First things first - if you've never shot a gun or heard one before (like me) it's extremely surprising how damn loud it is (ohh, THAT'S why you wear earphones). And the kickback on the gun (I was shooting a Glock) was unexpected, too. Oh yeah, be prepared for shells to fly, which takes a little getting used to.

The first shot was really, really scary. The second, a little less so. And by the third, well, I was totally into it. I emptied one clip and my friend took her turn (hopefully she will Yelp about it, too). And then I had one last try before I had to get back to my regularly scheduled life. My grand finale involved emptying a round into the target of a 70's dude who looked a little like Ron Jeramy. It was crazily satisfying and I left feeling very empowered. And, believe it or not, I was actually pretty good at it.

There was an instructor (Bobby) who was on hand to answer our questions and show us proper positioning so we didn't slice our thumbs off. And the fee that we paid when we left was incredibly reasonable for 20 minutes of feeling like a badass.

I'm never going to own a gun and I'm not interested in ever shooting anything outside the walls of a shooting range. But I am almost certain that I'll be back, because this was an experience unlike anything else I've ever done before.", 'I really enjoy squeezing off a few rounds from a pistol, or even better, an AK-47, on an otherwise quiet Sunday afternoon, and what better place to indulge this hobby than at the Philadelphia Archery & Gun Club located right by the Italian Market in Bella Vista? 

For anyone who has been to other gun clubs in the Philadelphia area, it's not uncommon to overhear conversations rife with overt hatred for "bleeding heart liberals" or, prior to his presidency, see targets with Obama's face, head wrapped in a turban. Places like that are disconcerting and just not fun. You won't find this attitude at SPAG. 

The staff and clientele at this club come from a diverse background and share only one thing, a love of firearms and target shooting. No political agendas here. I've found the staff extremely helpful in asking questions about different firearms or potential purchases, and they're always willing to suggest a new rental option for you to try. 

Best of all, they let you shoot some pretty high-powered stuff here. No automatics, and no 50 caliber sniper rifles, but otherwise, it's pretty free reign. The only downside is that there are only a handful of lanes, and at peak times, you might have to wait a bit to shoot, but I've never waited more than 30 minutes, and there's no time limit on how long you occupy a lane. For members, lanes and targets are free, so the only thing you'll ever really need to buy are the bullets. 

If you've never fired a gun before, this is the place to visit. They'll get you set up with what you need and you'll feel right at home. After you work up an appetite blasting paper men and rescuing hostages from the 1980s, grab a bite at the Italian Market. I always go for the great tacos at La Veracruzana at 9th & Washington.', "I had an incredibly frustrating experience here. I've waited a couple weeks to make sure I'm writing it with some objectivity. Long story short, the owner refused to sell me a gun because I have bad handwriting. I'm not sure if I should ever go back.

I'd been there a few times in the past with a friend. They have a good location, and a pretty good setup. The staff had always been friendly and attentive.I went again this weekend for their annual Springfield day. An XDM has been on my wishlist for a while now, so I was looking forward to trying and buying one. Initially, it was a pretty positive experience. I signed up for a membership at a special price, less than the cost of 6 sessions at the non-member cost. I tried out a few different pistols. Upstairs in the range, the RSOs moved people through quickly, but still took the time to give me tips loading the magazine, which was a bit trickier than the revolvers and .22s I'm used to. Ammo prices were reasonable, though due to the crowd they were only selling a half box at a time. Then I went to the sales counter and asked about buying an XDM40.

This is when the trouble started. As I began filling out the transfer form, the owner said I wasn't writing clearly enough. I'll be the first to admit that I have atrocious handwriting, but this is a form that gets filled out leaning on waist level counters in shops like this, or on any available surface at gun shows. He told me to start over and to write carefully.  I was now running late to meet friends for lunch and a concert, but started the form anew and tried to take my time. I finished the forms, the salesman looked them over, and called in my background check. Everything seemed fine until I got to the owner at the register and he started reading it over. He got really agitated and very critical of my handwriting. I did my best to stay calm and ask what my options were. He just kept complaining about my forms. I told him I was running late, and asked if I should put down a deposit to come back and try the form again, or if I should just go. After asking that 3 times while he continued to berate me about the form, he conceded and told me to come back the next day.

When I showed up the next afternoon, the salesman remembered me, and said the owner told him not to sell to me if I came back. I was pretty incredulous, but he and another employee just deflected that it was the owners discretion. I asked for a refund on my membership, since I had no reason to use it, and they did. I understand that selling guns is a regulated business, but the situation just felt absurd. It's a handwritten form filled out on the fly, surely they make some effort to deal with handwriting issues when the forms are processed. They even took a photocopy of my Drivers license and credit cards, and I had offered a passport card for further verification.

It's a shame, because until I dealt with the owner, the staff had been great, and it's a very convenient range for me. Even dealing with the other staff after being denied the purchase was cordial and professional. Every other time I'd been there it was positive, but now I'm not sure if I'm ever going back."]

name: Aqui Con El Nene
categories_raw: Fast Food, Restaurants, Mexican, Food Stands, Hot Dogs
top_reviews:
["This was my introduction to the Sonoran Hot Dog, and I don't know if I'll ever wanna go anywhere else now. It's so good. And hey so was everything else we tried from the menu, especially the Taco Yaqui, a chile relleno stuffed with meat, cheese, bacon, and mushroom. All the flavors! 

Check this place out if you're in the Tucson area. I know we'll be making a trip back for another Sonoran Hot Dog and more stuff from the menu. 

An easy five stars.", 'I have been DYING to try this place. Let me set the scene... We passed this place on the way to a friend's house and I told my wife, maybe after their party we can stop here on our way home." She says, "OK, we'll see if they are still open"... and to my utter happiness THEY WERE!

We got our food to go and the whole trip home I had to resist the urge to just pull over and start tearing into the food. My jowls ached from holding back the waterfall inside my jaw.

After AN ETERNITY, we get home and open the food. I am not disappointed. I ordered us each a carne asada quesadilla, which the guy corrected me to call them caramelos. Call them what you want. For $3.75, they are little meat filled blankets of love. I made it a point to take as many offerings as I could from the plentiful salsa bar. I am sure they watched in amazement as I left with my bulging bag-o-salsa-bar. Don't judge - I wanted to try it all.

I also had a Sonoran dog. Although I just don't think I am a fan of Sonoran dogs in general, this was probably the best I have had. The caramelos were, altogether, another story. My wife actually said they were too cheesy. WAT? No, they had the perfect amount of cheese and LOTS of tasty carne asada, I adorned each bite with a different kind of salsa, liquid cheese, pickled onions and cucumbers from my bag-o-salsa-bar, Each bite was better than the last.

Long story short - OK you already got the long version - the best $10 I have spent on this amount of food in a very long time.', "Alright Tucson, there is some major magic going on on the corner of Wetmore and Flowing Wells. It's kind of a drive for most of us, but who wouldn't make the effort for a taste of some of the most succulent Sonoran food offerings in the OP? PLUS, the magicians cooking up all this deliciousness are doing it out of a food truck! These guys hail from Ciudad Obregon (which is where my mother is from) and not only are they serving all kinds of tasty treats in a timely fashion, at reasonable prices, but they also include one of the BEST complimentary condiment bars in T-Town. You can load up on fresh cucumber, shredded lettuce, pickled red onions, pico de gallo, cilantro, onion, guacamole, salsas....and the list goes on!

I've had the luxury of enjoying the Sonoran hot-dog, served on a fluffy toasted bun and loaded with beans, bacon, tomatoes and onion..YUM

If you haven't tried their Lorenzas do it! A Lorenza is a corn tortilla that is baked/fried so its kind of like a tostada, but its served with melted cheese and any meat of your choice. Then you can garnish it any which way you want!

Their carne asada torta was pretty darned tasty too.

There is plenty of seating if you want to show this place to a group of friends. 

I am definitely not surprised that Rachel Ray listed Aqui con el Nene on her Tasty Travels show.

Don't miss out on this place Yelper friends!"]

name: Aart Accent Tattoo & Piercing
categories_raw: Piercing, Tattoo, Beauty & Spas
top_reviews:
['A couple of years ago, a friend from out of town was visiting and we wanted to get matching tattoos before she flew back home. This shop was located right down the street, so we came here after we could not get into where I initially wanted to go. Parking is limited in the area, so be aware of that. Snake did mine while another guy was doing hers. At least I think his name was Snake. It was an unusual name. Hers got infected within days and she had to take antibiotics. She has both of her arms and most of her legs covered in tattoos, so she knows how to take care of them. Mine also got infected and still looks like it has bubbles from the ink, not a good thing. I look at it and am still kind of ashamed at how bad it turned out. I will be getting it fixed soon.', "If this shop were an animal, it'd be an Aartvark.

Absolutely wonderful tattoo shop which offers a lot of sexy designs right down to their extremely sexy sign. I would probably give them five stars for the sign alone, but some of the designs they offer and the artwork they have is very erotic and definitely fits in well in a city like New Orleans.

So I have nothing but good things to say about this place, and when we start getting tattoos, this is one of the places on our list.", 'I came here one night a few months ago to get my nose pierced. I normally like to bring my business to Electric Ladyland on Frenchmen Street, but they only pierce noses with rings and I wanted a stud. This place was close to my house so I thought I'd check them out.

I parked right out front. It was later in the evening, although I can't remember the exact time (sometime between 11 PM and 1 AM). The two guys working the store were outside smoking. As I walked up they asked when I was there to have done. I said I wanted to get my nose pierced and they said they were going to finish their cigarettes and to go wait inside. *Sigh*....so that isn't the biggest deal in the world, I get it..you're on a smoke break, however--they were just so blah and unfriendly when they said it that I was a little put-off. 

So I wait inside for about 10 minutes while they shoot the breeze outside. There are a handful of customers inside looking at tattoo books. Most of the customers look younger than me and I am in my early-20s. Finally the guys come back in and gesture for me to come up to the counter. I give them my debit card to pay and without saying anything they just point over my shoulder. I'm confused and then finally turn around and see an ATM. Uhh, okay, couldn't you have just said you didn't take cash rather than being obscure and using hand gestures?? I'm close to just saying "f*%$ it" at this point, but I get my cash out and pay.

The guy that took me to the back and pierced me didn't have a very good bedside manner. When I go to Electric Ladyland, all of their staff (especially their piercer) are so friendly and keen to explain exactly what they're doing with your piercing and/or tattoo. They are also good about keeping up small talk to help with nerves. The guy here at Aart barely said anything (except to correct me when I misidentified a part of the city I was talking about). He quickly pierced me and then sent me on my way without giving me cleaning instructions. 

Despite all of this, I still tipped him. When I tipped him, he seemed genuinely surprised and immediately became much more friendly. Maybe what  happens is that, since this place is on the outskirts of the Quarter and open late, they get in a bunch of drunk tourist customers who don't tip and, because of this, are a bit disenchanted with their job. However, that still isn't an excuse to act like working on your customers (who are your livelihood) is a chore. 

I won't be returning and wouldn't suggest this business to family or friends.']

name: Sips Specialty Coffee House
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Food, Internet Cafes, Cafes, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["For better or worse the coffee shop barometer is the institutionalized Starbucks.  Fortunately, sips stacks up.  They have the quality of drinks to survive.

Beware if you are allergic to hipster because yes.  They have different assorted furniture and knick-knacks.  Not everything is tasteful like christmas lights or fake vines(very floridian).  A young couple seemed to be having some awkward date talking about their feelings and love of music.  I've built a resistance over the years.

I had the turtle frap?? It has caramel pecan and chocolate etc.  Not overpoweringly sweet-- just right.  A pleasant surprise.

I wasnt going to review from one drink, but the customer service is fantastic.   On staff was a grandma and grandson duo.  Really?? The grandson Connor did my order and also followed up to see if I liked it.  He was very friendly and kinda adorable.  This place is straight up kittens and marshmallows.", '*drum roll please*

I will be the very first to confess that I am not a coffee drinker. I never got used to the taste of coffee, although I do like the smell of freshly-brewed coffee. What I do enjoy is a place to visit with friends, sip a beverage of my choosing, and relax in a comfortable "homey" environment.

Sips Specialty Coffee House is just such a place, located along Gunn Highway near Citrus Park. You'll find Sips in a little strip mall out in front of Super WalMart and down the block from an Amscot financial center. It's right at the intersection of Gunn and Henderson Road.

Walking in the front door I had to do a double-take because I thought that I'd stepped back into my mother's kitchen. You could smell all of the wonderful scents of baked goods, along with the flavors of coffee and toppings. There were people sitting at tables, sipping their drinks, playing cards, board games, laughing, and chattering away. The decorations were definitely right in line with what my Mom would have placed around her kitchen.

I had the opportunity to meet the owners, Caryn and Ken Reed, and learn a bit about their journey from Michigan to Florida, and the idea for their coffee house which opened six months ago. Very nice, down-to-earth people who are looking to provide that comfy neighborhood gathering place for people to meet up, play a game of Jenga or chess, and do a bit of networking. 

Oh yes, and enjoy that coffee - hot, iced, blended, frozen - you name it. The house special is Sips Mocha which is made with white chocolate, swirls of caramel, steamed milk & espresso. They have lattes and mochas and cappuccinos and espressos, fruit smoothies, hot teas, iced teas, and your regular ol' cup o' Joe. There's also a refrigerated case with fruit juices, soda, and bottled water.

They have a baked goods counter with bagels, muffins and pastries, and these AMAZING homemade dark chocolate cupcakes with Reese's cups inside.  YUMMMMM!!!!

For those who are on the go and don't want to climb out of your car, then Sips has a drive-up, full-service window. You can get a single-serving cup, or pick up one of their containers of coffee for the office.

Now one final treat -- especially for us Yelpers. Sips happens to employ the very lovely and sweet Ms. Cece C. as a barrista, and I highly encourage you to stop in and say Hi to her.

Yes, I understand, there are a lot of places where you can stop for coffee, but not many places offer this type of cozy atmosphere. It is worth the time to stop and make some new friends while enjoying a great cup of......well, I was gonna say tea, but y'all would probably like the coffee a whole lot too.', "Sips has a great vibe and is everything you want in a local coffeehouse.  Very friendly staff and patrons and the best barista in town!  Cece truly cares about perfection and my latte with almond milk was prepared with precision and care! 

Only regret is that it took me so long to discover this gem which is walking distance to mi casa. That and a broken keurig brought me here for my much needed caffeine fix. 

They have live music and free wifi and serve up bagels and pastries. Haven't yet tried the food but will soon. They have all kinds of coffee drinks as well as teas and the frozen matcha is on my radar!  

Ps, you can fix your keurig with a paper clip!  Thanks google!"]

name: All About Hair
categories_raw: Waxing, Hair Salons, Barbers, Hair Removal, Beauty & Spas
top_reviews:
["***Note: The Ranstead Barber Shop has moved to a new location.  Lou can now be found at 42 South 19th Street  (between Market and Chesnut) in a shop that is much more easily found***

The crew at the Ranstead Barber Shop gives a great no-nonsense haircut for a totally reasonable price; Lou is my go-to guy.

I've gotten to be friends with Lou since moving to Philadelphia in August, and the more I know about him, the more I enjoy getting my hair cut.  It feels like I'm catching up with one of my dad's friends when I'm sitting in the chair.

Bonus points for the fact that Lou is childhood buddies with Philadelphia hero Bobby Rydell and recently brought Bobby back to Philly to play a benefit with his band (http://www.philly.com/inquirer/opinion/20080217_A_South_Philly_night_to_remember.html).

Additional bonus points for the fact that Lou cuts Cardinal Rigali's hair.

The shop is a bit hidden on Ranstead Street, but just follow the red, blue and white painted poles down the street to the shop's front door-- it's well worth the hunt.", 'My fellow traveling co-workers thought I was crazy to consider getting a haircut while out of town. But my hair was getting crazy shaggy, and this NorCal boy was withering in the heat and humidity of July in Philadelphia. So I put my faith in Yelp, and took a walk on the wild side.

The place is a hard to find but, in my confusion, I stumbled upon a drug store selling water ice, so it was all good.

Neither Gaetano or Lou were there, just a nice Asian lady. She was finishing up when I walked in, right before closing on Saturday. I think I waited 15 minutes, my hair was "did" about 30 minutes later. A scalp and neck massage were included in the price. I forget exactly -- it was around $20. There was a sign on the wall apologizing for the recent increase.

I gotta give props to the shops keeping it old school. And all the more so for friendly, quality service.', 'I moved to Philly 6 months ago and have been going to the Ranstead Barber shop since then. I usually go on the weekends. They are one of the few barbershops in center city Philly open on Saturdays.

Both Gaitano and Lou are very friendly and know their job well. There is nothing fancy about this place, just an old fashioned barber shop.

Lou was nice enough to recommend some restaurants in the area and in South Philly as well while I was there.

I would recommend them without hesitation']

name: Holmesburg Bakery
categories_raw: Restaurants, Food, Bakeries
top_reviews:
['I saw it as an omen to come here, when I arrived 30 minutes early to an appointment, and checked out all the raving about this place on Yelp. I was surprised that you do have to get buzzed into this tiny place, or maybe there is a butter cake thief out there. And this place is tiny! If 4 customers came in, 1 would have to wait outside. 

Thankfully the girls behind the counter, although teenagers, are extremely sweet and helpful. I kept asking about the cream donuts, and then Boston cream, and then something else they were also out of (it was 3 PM on a Friday) and she patiently waited as I tried to make up my mind for something else and apologized for not having what I wanted.

Finally I picked up a mix of donuts, some cinnabuns and this butter cake that Joe D. was raving about. I was happy with all the pastries, especially the cinnabun, but I was so NOT happy with that butter cake! You see, I am a person that eats with my eyes, and this cake looks like the most boring, ugly pasty cake you will ever see. For a small baking plate (like where you would make 6 brownies) you pay $7 for a butter cake that is essentially a dry thin cake with a thick layer of butter and cream on top. The top part is a strange texture and wayyyy too sweet even for someone like me that loves sugar. I was extremely disappointed and threw out the entire thing after one bite (my beau did not care to even try it).

Needless to say, I am willing to try this place one more time to attempt one of these highly sought after cream donuts, but I'm"m not exactly racing back. Also, bring cash, there is a $10 min for plastic.', "Butter. Cake. Butter. Cake. Butter. Cake.

If I was on death row a Holmesburg butter cake would be my final meal.  I remember growing up as a kid after moving to South Jersey from the Northeast and heading back over with my father and brother on a weekend to pick one of these gifts from the heavens up.  We would take it home and then fight over who would get the center (and most gooey part) of the cake.  Thankfully even if you lost the battle for the center your consolation prize of either edge was still damn good.  I've heard many ravings about their cream donuts but for some reason I'm too dumb to ever get one because I see the butter cake and I just can't think straight.

Last time I got a butter cake a few years back I was caught in a terrible traffic jam on 95 and I kept calling to tell them I was coming for that butter cake!  Don't sell it!  

This place is Northeast Philly baking.", "I have never encountered a staff so rude in my life...I walked in with my mom the women took me first as I placed my order the other women says whose next, so my mom says that's me. The lady begins to argue with my mother saying ummm no that's not true you were not next. I turn to the other lady that is arguing with my mom and say she was next we walked in together. So the lady that was helping me rolls her eyes and says oooo so your saying you're paying separate..(ummm yeah since were two separate people yes we are I thought to myself), I just say yes cause I didn't want any more hassle. So the lady says to my mom ok than what do you want I guess I have to take you than, so my mom begins to ask how the dunking sticks are purchased per stick or pound, so the lady gets frustrated and says everyone knows it's per half or whole pound.  So my mom continues with her order, I continue with mine. I ask my lady if she could possibly split the dozen of donuts 6 and 6 so I could take 6 to a party I was going to and leave 6 at home. She rolls her eyes and says you know what now I got to charge you per pound for the donuts, like how much of a hassle could splitting the dozen up be???  I say never mind sorry to be a bother. My mom is now paying for her order and the lady helping her gets nasty again and says since your order was under $25 we have no choice but to run it as debit saying it in a way that it felt like that lady didn't even want my mom's business, my mom says that's perfectly fine. I get done my order and give the lady my credit card and she rolls her eyes YET AGAIN and says we now need to wait cause this lady (meaning my mother) is running her card first and is taking too much time...I hate to even put out a review like this as I do like this bakeries pastries...but the staff needs to GOOOOO!!!! I asked a friend of mine that was there a week prior and she said they were ignorant to her as well...It's a bakery how can you be so rude, usually bakery staff are so helpful...I WILL NEVER GO BACK HERE...NO WAY!!! THERE ARE PLENTY OF BAKERIES IN THE AREA THAT DO NOT HAVE RUDE PEOPLE WORKING FOR THEM!!!"]

name: Louis Pappas Fresh Greek
categories_raw: Greek, Restaurants, Sandwiches, Cafes, Salad
top_reviews:
["Several visits since the reopening.  I've dined in twice and did a take out order...

My typical go to is the chopped salad.  I always order the small because it's huge!

My to go order was of 4 small chopped salads for a home dinner gathering and Monique was super sweet and accommodating....  Put the potato salad on the side (like to serve it on the side, some people don't like it).

It's a tasty salad even without the dressing.  I wish they would put more feta, however, I love cheese!

Decent pricing, but only because you get so much salad for the price - you can have 2 meals out of it but for $9, it's a fairly expensive salad.  BUT, a lot of the ingredients are from Greece (olives, peppers, feta and oil), so I'm going to be lenient on the pricing issue here.

I do enjoy the food here and will definitely be back.", "Louis Pappas is a gem in the fast food realm of Tampa and in my opinion has the best Greek food in Tampa. The restaurant is set up with a order counter but you are able to dine in if you wish. The restaurant is clean and the décor is really nice. There have a huge artistic metal tree that I'm in love with on one of the wall. The prices are reasonable for the amount of food you get ( I promise you will leave full). 

The trio spread is a great starter and includes hummus, tazziki and a garlic feta spread and is served with warm pita bread (thinking about it makes me drool a little). If you want to try something different the Chicken Avgolemono soup is really yummy, it's a ticker creamy lemon/chicken soup with orzo. You can never go wrong with the traditional or chopped salad... I would suggest ordering the small (the portion is massive).  I always order the gyro sandwich, which is packed full with lamb, onions and tomatoes slathered in tazziki.  

I think a good indicator that you have landed on a good restaurant is the quality of their soda available on draft.
