['I feel honored to have stumbled upon the Mueller family-owned 1958 ice cream parlor that was recently rated one of the "Top 12 Best Ice Cream Shops in Tampa Bay" (Stuff To Do in Tampa Bay-- UNATION City Guides, March 2021). On a 10 PM weeknight in pouring rain, I crossed paths w/ this pastel-laden TRUE TAMPA GEM! And I am thrilled that my 10,000-th Yelp photo is of Dairy Joy! 

Not only is Dairy Joy priceless for being a South Tampa family-owned establishment for 63 years, the newest owners (2018) have already helped the community by sponsoring an event to raise money for the family of deceased TPD Officer Jesse Madsen. 10% of all sales from 11 AM to 11 PM on a very busy Saturday in April went to the Madsen family. The owners have also  brought some added fun to their shoppe w/ Doo Wop Nights, where staff dresses in traditional 1950's parlor-style attire & offer up fun vocals-- SEE PIC.  

Open 6 days weekly from 11 AM to 11 PM & Sunday from 11 AM till 10 PM, this iconic shoppe sells soft serve, hard-packed ice cream, dips, shakes, smoothies, snowcones, sundaes; floats, & more. If you're one of the lucky ones as you walk up to one of the two windows, you just may breathe in the smell of freshly made Waffle cones-- such a beautiful aroma. Three sides of the shoppe are glass from ceiling to floor; w/ one look inside, you'll see that this is a clean & organized ice cream parlor. 

While I stopped by, the menu options included: 3 Smoothies @ $5.99; 14 Snow Cones (in a cup) flavors @ $2.75 to $3.75; 11 Sundaes (in a cup) @ $3.69 to $6.99; 5 Speciality Sundaes @ $6.99; 27 Premium ice cream flavors available in 5 sizes ($3.25 to a quart @ $9.99); 4 Extras (Dip; Sugar Cone; Sprinkles; & Waffle Cone); & two sizes of Rootbeer Floats @ $3.99 & $5.99.

There are also 29 Milkshake flavors w/ prices ranging from $3.25 to $6.99. My medium Peanut Butter Shake was INCREDIBLE! Allow me to stress that-- IN*CRED*I*BLE! It was reminiscent of the peanut butter shakes I consumed & loved as a child in Maine. The creamy soft serve w/ the PERFECT amount of peanut butter made for an EXCELLENT shake. (3/4 of it remains & graces my freezer; I'm able to enjoy it for many days.)

Beverages sold here include Coke; Diet Coke; Rootbeer; Sprite; Orange Crush; & Bottled Water-- each $1.75. If it's food you want, you have the option of a Boar's Head hotdog @ $3.99-- 7 toppings are available. 

Dairy Joy offers its patrons outside picnic table seating-- on both sides of the parlor. This makes it Canine-friendly. Once side is covered & it has a black & white tile floor (SEE PIC) while the other is uncovered w/ asphalt & astroturf-- SEE PIC. While you enjoy your icecream, you'll have no choice but to partake of the whimsical nature of this ice cream parlor-- from the decorated-for-every-occasion statue of Elvis to the three classic car drive-in where young & old alike can enjoy ice cream & pose for a photo op. To schedule a Dairy Joy BIRTHDAY PARTY, email "dairyjoytampa@gmail.com" for information on available packages.

There is customer parking on the private lot as well as on the overflow adjacent lot. CASH, CREDIT/DEBIT are accepted forms of payment. 

I am actually excited about stopping in the next time I'm in the area. I'll be able to get a Blueberry Coconut shake & once again stroll down Nostalgia Lane. DEFINITELY a must see & try ice cream shoppe! But before YOU take a stroll, check out Dairy Joy's Facebook page; the uploaded customer pics are PRICELESS!', "Unbelievably adorable mid century ice cream joint with a walk up window. Cash only!

Visited on 7/1/18 at 7pm. I just love the aesthetic of this place! It feels like a trip back to the 50s for a malt. And the prices will have you saying gee whiz.

I had a scoop of peach ice cream in a sugar cone. The ice cream was smooth and creamy and full of chunks of real peaches. The portion size was generous! 

Service was fast and friendly. I saw a lot of things I'd like to try on my next visit!", "It neighborhood support ice cream joint. Just across the library. This ice cream place established since 1958. Very old store. You can tell they are very successful with many come to visit. It is a dairy joy to people here like it's name. 

I got the vanilla dip cone with butterscotch. Only few ice cream place has dip cone. This is one of them. The banana split here look very good. One day I will try it. The small cone we have is good quantity of the soft serve. They have good technique to swirl it up higher. Keep up the good work which attracts people here."]

name: John's Water Ice
categories_raw: Local Flavor, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food
top_reviews:
['John's is so classic South Philly! This corner, grab and go counter only spot is serving up delicious, pure "wooder ice" in that unmistakable South Philly no nonsense manor. For those reading this not from Philly and aren't familiar, that's how it's said here here in the heart of South Philly..."wooder". It's super classy :) 

The offerings are simple...4 classic flavors with the occasional special of the week. That's it. Nothing fancy. Nothing crazy. Chocolate, cherry, pineapple or lemon are their staples. Their cherry is THE best cherry I've ever had and I've been eating water ice my entire life. Their pineapple is my second favorite, tangy lemon is quite good and definitely refreshing! 

Prices are inexpensive. For just $1.75 you can get yourself a small 90's retro cup filled with two flavors. They are generous with the scoop and a small is really enough. Gelati (1/2 ice, 1/2 ice cream) is also available and is made with hard homemade ice cream here, not custard. If you're used to other gelati, maybe try it here since it's so different. 

The girls slinging the ice are super efficient and you can tell they're ready for a crowd which you will see gather on sweltering days. They're so sweet and notably cute. On our last visit when the girl handed me back my change (they are cash only of course) I automatically motioned to put it in the the tip jar except I didn't see one. I asked about it and she told me they have to keep it behind the counter because people steal it. Oh, welcome to Philly. So if you so feel inclined to tip, just hand it to the girls and they'll safely put it away. 

Please, I beg of you, if you're in the city DO NOT go to one of the water-ice chains! It's almost sacrilegious, especially while in South Philly. Places like this are the real deal and what you want. John's has been a family run business since 1945. It's currently run by a 3rd generation owner who uses ​only fresh fruit he personally selects and squeezes by hand, filtered water and sugar.​ That's it! No preservatives, no additives and no junk like the big names chains use. Trust me, this is where it's at. THIS is Italian Philly "wooder ice". 

*Knocking a star off because I feel they could set up a table or two. Maybe at least a bench. Moms who don't want their sticky, wiggly kids in the car feel me..', 'My gf doesn't think much of her Johns, but I think a lot of John's. It's one of those amazing water ice places that can only be found in South Philly. It's my 3rd fave of the 4 that I frequent, just ahead of Jimmy's, just behind Italiano's and Pop's. Not sure how to compare Dati's to these ones.

Water Ice is like the Roast Pork Sandwich and the infamous Cheesesteak. Only unlike the Cheesesteak (and much like the Pork), it's absolutely delicious. I have no idea why, of these 3 claims to food fame, it's the bland, boring one (Cheesesteak) that became internationally famous. Forget it. Come here and get yourself a water ice or a Gelati, and you'll see what I mean.

Water Ice has been exported around the country now by Rita's, which is from Philly, but it's still not as famous as it should be. In South Philly you have an assortment of tiny little family-owned water ice shops, which over time will go out of business if we are unlucky. I believe Italiano's already has, or will be soon.

Gelati mixes layers of frozen custard with water ice. It sounds like it might not work but it absolutely does. It's wonderful. Rita's does a version using soft serve and it works really well, but since you can get that at Rita's, skip that option, and do the Pop's original, the unique specialty for South Philly Water Ice shops... the Gelati using hand-dipped hard ice cream. Vanilla, specifically.

There are some ridiculously attractive servers here at this location, especially the owner (I think) who is the really extremely tanned one (swoon). The boys are really hot here too, so my girl says. She flirted a little too much with them and I liked that she did that a little too much.

As for the products. Nice lemon, has a good taste. Not too crazy about the cherry but it wasn't bad. I love the texture of John's, it has an excellent mush consistency. The birthday cake flavour ice cream is just awful. It'll set you back around 1 75. 

I was going to say this is the most "Jersey Shore" of the Philly water ice stores, and then I found out that *omg* they have one in Jersey too. Figures.', "Summer has only just begun, but I've already made several trips to John's for their delicious water ice. My favorite is a pineapple and cherry combo. Both flavors are perfection and just the right amount of sweet. The prices are great; it's two bucks for a small which is perfect for an every day sort of treat. I look forward to many visits as the weather heats up!"]

name: District Tavern
categories_raw: Local Flavor, Event Planning & Services, American (Traditional), Bars, Nightlife, Restaurants, Gastropubs, Venues & Event Spaces
top_reviews:
["I really enjoyed District Tavern.  It has the look and feel of what a gastropub should be.  Open and spacious with lots of TVs and seating and good food.

Melissa and I came before the Billy Joel concert, whom we hadn't seen For the Longest Time (see what I did there).  Now, you might think that before such a concert, we should have a bottle of red, or ooooooooo, a bottle of white, but that wasn't the kind of mood we were in that night. No, on another night, You May be Right, but not tonight.  Tonight, me and my Uptown Girl just needed a quick bite, maybe a drink, and we had to run to the arena, where you'd think I would be a Big Shot, but no.  They treat me like I'm The Stranger.

I ordered a simple whiskey and water and a southwest chicken bowl - I don't recall the name and can't really be bothered to look it up right now.  However, it came with quinoa (or rice, but I went healthy) and blackened chicken and it was very good.  Don't recall what Melissa got, but I am fairly certain she enjoyed it too.

This is a great place for a pre-show meal for a couple of reasons.  First, it is within walking distance.  Second, because it is off the beaten path a bit, it was not nearly as busy as the places in Channelside or Fergs Live, or even some of the other pubs and restaurants in the business area of downtown Tampa.  We were surprised how easy it was to get a table.

That said, a number of reviews complained about the service, and while our server was friendly and everything was fine, service was slow.  Normally, I would consider deducting a star for it, but it wasn't so bad that it screwed up our evening.  Still, you should plan on needing some extra time all the same.

And so it goes, and so it goes, and you're the only one who knows.", "This place is spacious but seem tucked in the heart of Tampa. It would be great for game night with the boys/girls and has good looking food. I haven't tried any yet but next go round definitely will be stuffing my face. 

My sweet bartenders recommended cinnamon on the rim of my cup when drinking seasonal beers. One of the best advice I've ever gotten from a bartender ( trust me I've had a lot ). It gives a rich experience that I would past on to the ones reading this so please try if you're a beer expert.", 'A friend of mine who lives in Tampa recommended this spot when I was in Tampa on a surprise trip for my birthday.  It's located at the bottom of a highrise, near the water (but not with a view of it).

We were here on a Sunday, so brunch was going on.  You can have unlimited mimosas for $20.00, which I did not partake in.  However, my friend did and her mimosa was more of a glass of champagne with a splash of OJ.  The cost of the unlimited mimosas was a bit more than I'm used to, being an Orlandoan (usually $10.00 to $15.00 at most).  I opted for one of their local craft beers that was on tap.  They had a good selection to choose from, which is always a plus in my book.

The brunch menu was a little lacking to me.  Nothing stood out and made me say "oohhh, that sounds awesome!"  Same goes for the lunch menu.  However, I did enjoy my meal and thought it was very tasty.  I ended up ordering a flatbread off of the lunch menu that had alfredo, bacon, and spinach on it.  I also added grilled chicken to it, which I thought made the flatbread much better and more filling. 

We sat at the bar and I thought the service was great.  Our bartender was attentive, offered suggestions when we asked for them, and always made sure our drinks were full.  My only suggestion would be for the bartenders to be more up-to-date on the beers offered on tap.  I asked what a few of them were and he was unable to provide me with any answers.']

name: Galatoire's 33 Bar & Steak
categories_raw: Bars, Nightlife, Steakhouses, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["When you're on a mission to treat yourself this is the place to go! I called ahead to make sure  I would be welcomed even without a reservation, and luckily the restaurant was not busy that particular night. I'd recommend calling ahead and making a reservation if you know you will be dining at Galatoire's.
My waiter was very kind and attentive. He explained the specials, and showed me the cocktail list. I knew from the pictures on Yelp that I definitely wanted to try the crab cake. Believe me when I tell you it's all crab, and no cake! It's a wonderful mass of crab meat and its warm when served. It's perfect, and I'd highly recommend you order it.  As for the main meal I ordered a filet which was cooked perfectly, and had a good flavor. I also ordered the creamed spinach. This was also good, but I think it might have needed a little salt and pepper to make it even better. Then there was the lobster au gratin. This dish was awesome, and with the steak it was perfect.  I was not kidding when I said I was treating myself.
Overall I had a great experience at Galatoire's 33 Bar & Steak. I'd most definitely return, and would encourage others to give it a try if you haven't already.", "I really wanted to love Galatoire's 33 but our lunch experience wasn't up to par with similar establishments. Ambiance was reminiscent of old world New Orleans with Southern elegance. Food and service were average.

A warm complimentary loaf of bread and soft, rich butter were happily devoured as we waited for our drinks and food. The crab cake appetizer was ultimate goodness- filled with tons of crab meat and very lightly breaded on the outside. I welcome more meat over breading! The crab cake was fresh and not overly salty. This one almost rivals the one at Vic & Anthony's! The Caesar salad was one of the best I've had in a long time because it had the right amount of dressing, topped with an anchovy.

The 16 oz ribeye came with edges burnt to a crisp. I had to cut off the edges because they were literally black and inedible! However, that did not stop me from devouring the rest of the medium-cooked steak, which was nicely seasoned. The brown butter mushrooms were deliciously buttery and juicy. The steamed asparagus were overcooked (I don't like mushy asparagus!). 

Service was impeccable but more on the slow side. We didn't mind waiting but would have appreciated more promptness after dining to get the check and to-go boxes. I would recommend Galatoire's 33 just for cocktails and appetizers at their lovely bar. With the higher prices and established reputation, I expected more of the wow factor. Overall, I wasn't blown away with a stellar experience and might have to rethink coming back in the future.", "So I have to start this review by telling you about Tacy, the bartender.... Not just a bartender, but THE BARTENDER (You must use all caps). She is very knowledgeable, friendly, and talented and has a great smile. She really makes you feel comfortable and want to stay awhile with her great attitude. She is great a creating drinks that she may think you like based on your taste buds, which is never wrong.  She makes great classics to different creations, espec ially get her to make you up one of her tasty shots when you getting your night started.  My favorite cocktails at this location consist of whiskey (they have a great selection) and a simple Champagne and St Germain.   What also makes this place great as the bartender; you never know what shall happen. Once visiting, Tacy THE BARTENDER, she sung some Etta James with a piano player. She can sing her heart out! She makes me smile and just want to have a nice classy sip!

 I have tried a few of their appetizers, my favorite include their deviled egg (so divine), Jumbo Lump Crab Cake, and the baked oysters. I honestly have nothing bad to say about any of these appetizers. They were all tasty and just right.

Atmosphere is pretty upscale yet relaxed at the same time. In the bar area seems like a nice place to even enjoy some sports watching. The only downfall is the location is directly on Bourbon, but you can find street/lot parking close by so you wouldn't have to walk around the area much unless it's something you are into."]

name: Rubyz Threading Studio
categories_raw: Hair Removal, Threading Services, Eyelash Service, Waxing, Eyebrow Services, Beauty & Spas
top_reviews:
['I've been going to Ruby for over 5 years as she's was my favorite threader at the shop she used to work. I was sad to see that she was gone and was in despair until a week ago when I ride down Sheldon and saw the "Rubyz Threading Studio" sign! I had to be sure it was her so I came in this past Saturday. I'm so glad my favorite eyebrow threader has opened her own threading studio!

Rubyz is a brand new shop taking the place of the old Jem's natural food store located in the greater Westchase/Citrus Park area. I can pop over after a trip to Costco. The shop is much larger than most threading studios, very clean, has modern furnishings and plenty of comfortable seating in the waiting area. 

Ruby is one of the best threaders I've been to. She listens to what you are looking for and is very precise. Every time someone else jacks up my eyebrows she does what she can to fix them and consults on how we can get them back to where I want I want them. She's also very caring and remembers her customers. She always asks how my job and kids are doing as well as any of health issues that we've discussed! She's a genuinely caring person and I trust her with my brows.

Eyebrows are so important as they frame the face. I don't even want to go anywhere if my eyebrows are jacked. I'd rather have good eyebrows than makeup. 

Ruby always gets the job done perfectly and I highly recommend her.', 'I have been going to the same woman for eyebrow threading for three years now (my longest relationship). To my dismay, about four months ago, she up and left. She quit, changed her number and headed to the west coast - a tale as old as time. Since then, I have been grieving the loss of this relationship while looking for a rebound. I've made it to International Mall on four separate occasions, with the intentions of Heely-ing in to one of the eyebrow threading salons. I never made it out of my car, not even once. 

Present day: my eyebrows have been untouched for fourth months. While I was getting by, earlier this week I overheard someone say "is that big foot?" and knew it was time. I had to make a decision. I had to move on. That's when I found Ruby's Yelp reviews.

I figured that if anything, I can trust the squad of Yelpers to lead me in the right direction. What's the worst that could happen? She would remove my one and only redeeming quality from my face? I had to take a risk.

Ruby's studio is clean and serene, you know what I mean? I walked in and sat in the comfortable waiting area until it was my turn. When I met Ruby, I knew I made the right choice. She had a very calming presence and was very soft spoken. She gently asked me what I wanted, and told me to have a seat. This was it. I couldn't turn back now. I've had my eyebrows threaded for three years, and the process was painful each time. Ruby must have the hands of an angel, because I felt no pain. Nothing. She was very thorough and took more time on me and my eyebrows than my other lady ever had! When it was done, I gently grabbed the mirror and glanced at myself. I went from a solid 4 to a negotiable 6, just like that. Ruby is AMAZING. My eyebrows look better than ever before. Trust the reviews. I am now loyal to Ruby. I will never go anywhere else. Ruby, please don't leave me.', "It was my first time here (I just moved) and to my surprise nooshin was there! She used to do my eyebrows in carrollwood and now works here. She's a licensed esthetician and has been so for over 10 years I believe. Very detailed, I love her work."]

name: Joe's Steaks + Soda Shop
categories_raw: Sandwiches, Restaurants, Cheesesteaks
top_reviews:
["Hello Yelp Friends,

Went to Philly to go to charity football game   against Philly Police and Fire football team and promised to take the lady for an authentic Philly cheese steak.
We were both not disappointed. 

Covid pick up orders only but the staff was very nice through a small opening in the lower door. I'm sure this place is jamming at peak hours.

The Philly cheese steaks were freshly made and made to perfection and the shakes were thick and delicious and our side was French fries dipped in cheese. I usually order food for her and always get the leftovers but not today. I got that's mine and don't touch it for the very first time. That should say it all. We got home and this morning for breakfast she was eating her leftovers.

Thank you Yelpers for helping me find this neighborhood non tourist place.

I strongly recommend this place.", "One lovely Saturday morning a large group of friends and I decided to start the day out with a round at Juniata, a la beer-a-hole. Things went smoothly but slowly, however, after 18, I still had plenty of time to make the reception of the wedding ceremony I had missed around hole 15 (don't frown at me, I was a friend's fourth string plus one). All was still well as the twelve of us began loading up the car caravan, when suddenly we heard a low rumbling. Much like a yawn, that belly talk spread through our crew like wildfire, and within seconds every one of us was jockeying to name drop the most slammin' local eateries we knew. 

After many strong guarantees from a day walker I know, Chinks won out (who listens to those stricken with gingervitis, you ask? apparently this guy). 

Cruised into the old school looking shop and started dropping orders: whiz with, provolone and extra hots, American with saltpepperketchupandhotsauce.... the combos went on like that for a minute. Started chowing down on mine as soon as it came and immediately loved it, so much so that the girl constantly calling to check my ETA didn't take a drop of the enjoyment away for me. Steaks aren't chopped (not my usual style), they come on a fairly good roll, and with a healthy slathering-o-cheese. That meaty meal was so satisfying that 75% of us decided to go in for round two... so good that I had to cover the receiver as I again fibbed about being minutes from home just so I could re-up. Yeah, I know, how rude of me, but you don't know all the facts; there was a strip club directly across the street for the other four fellows to go wait out our extended meal, so everyone was happy. 

Never did make the wedding, but at least I learned about another solid NE cheesesteak (she forgave me eventually).", 'In my food explorations I tend to keep an open mind, thinking that there could be better somewhere out there. Rare is the occasion in which all the pieces fall into place, the heavens open up, a mighty beam of light shines down, and a choir accompanied voice says, "This is the one". 

Today, I ate "The One".  (wipes solo man-tear from eye) 

The girls are great.
The food is great.
The vibe is great.

You want ok, go elsewhere. You want great, go to Chink's. I do.']

name: Loa Bar
categories_raw: Lounges, Cocktail Bars, Nightlife, Event Planning & Services, Bars, Venues & Event Spaces
top_reviews:
["I just adore hotel bars and even if Loa Bar isn't as grand as one of my favorites, the King Cole Room at the St. Regis (their bar snacks are macademia nuts), their cocktails are in fact, possibly better. 

I've spent many an hour in a hotel bar that gets away with expensive, but mediocre cocktails. Loa's bartenders are at the top of their craft and you'll get a drink that's on par with any that you'd get at, say Cure or Tonique. Check out all the curious garnishes, herbs, bitters, shrubs and spirits (sitting at the bar is where it's at, btw. I recently sat in the terribly chic lounge area and it just wasn't the same). It's like a lush drink laboratory. 

The cocktail menu is impressive. I've tried a bunch of different drinks and they were all top notch, yet I'm afraid I can't give you specifics. Note to self: next time pay closer attention.", "Mercy! Mercy! Me! In My best Marvin Gaye voice. Such a fun spot to have some drinks and muster up energy to SPILL IT, BLAME IT, CONCEAL IT..then have a REFILL.  I love the ambiance in this bar. Watching bartenders stir and shake makes my night MAG. I wish there was a happy hour here. The location is perfect a perfect start to the night.. Say hi to Victory, Indulge, Windsor Cort, W, maybe the Hyatt if you are prepared. I much prefer this part of the Downtown area because it doesn't have the city congestion.", "An upscale hotel bar located in the heart of the CBD.

Great atmosphere and crowd.  A great place to stop in after work for a drink.  I dated a guy who worked in this area a while ago, and we would get together to enjoy a happy hour together after work on Fridays.  The have nice sofas by the windows, where you can sit with a group.

The bar is completely smoke free and the crowd is a little older, so it's a good place to go if you want to get away from the youngsters and their hangouts."]

name: Cru Cellars - Palma Ceia
categories_raw: Restaurants, Bars, Tapas/Small Plates, Nightlife, American (New), Venues & Event Spaces, Event Planning & Services, Wine Bars
categories: ['restaurants', 'bars', 'tapas/small plates', 'nightlife', 'american (new)', 'venues & event spaces', 'event planning & services', 'wine bars']
top_reviews:
["Popped in here with a friend to discover a very cozy wine bar in the back of a wine store.  They offer a dimly lit room with a bar and a handful of small tables. Space is tight. We were the first to arrive. Even though service should have been spot on it was spotty, as our server seemed distracted while she continued to prep for the night behind the bar.

We went with a mushroom flatbread, which was tasty. A reorder for me. We also got the house salad which was fresh and enjoyable. Lastly, we tried one of the Farmer's Platters. Ours had an assortment of cheeses, nuts, olives, jams and bread. My friend loved this and this is the reason we went here. I'm not a fan of cheeses and cured meats. Plus this is easily prepared at home, so it is not a menu item I would ever choose. I didn't have the heart to tell her this would not get my taste buds excited. I went with the flow. Plus our bill for these three items and 4 glasses of reasonably priced wine was $100.00.  I personally think this is high. They do offer a happy hour with special pricing on wine and bites.

I'll come back to try Cru Cellars again. There are other items on the menu I am interested in trying. For now it's a 3.5 in my book. Oh they have an outside area which would be nice when the weather cooperates.", 'Loved this place! Perfect for wine and charcuterie boards, great selection of both. They also have small plates. The cheese curds with jalapeño ranch were soo good! Very elegant inside. Nice staff. No complaints. Will be returning.', 'After a long week, I wanted to try something new and saw what great reviews this place had so we went on a Friday night. 

When you first walk in, you think it's just a wine store, however, as you look further towards the back, you see there are quite a few tables. 

I was with a group of people, and one of them was "hangry" and after hearing that the wait would be about 20 minutes, the "hangry" person didn't want to wait. Luckily, I was able to use my awesome skill of persuasion to convince this individual to wait it out. 
The wait was pretty quick and we sat down at a long table which we shared with other patrons. 
After looking at the menu, I decided to do the wine tasting. The rosé was very good and had a crisp taste. 
We ordered a number of appetizers. We got the blackened octopus that was cooked to perfection. We were able to choose the type of cheese we wanted as well as the meat selection. The pate had a creamy taste. I ordered the duck confit that I have to say was one of the best I have ever had. The duck was perfectly cooked medium rare, and the cole slaw on top had a slight acidity that went well with the duck. To end it, we had several desserts, but the banana foster one was amazing. 
At the end of the meal, I asked the "hangry" individual if he was happy we stayed and he responded with a big fat yes!!']

name: Benjamin Franklin Bridge
categories_raw: Automotive, Local Flavor, Active Life, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Public Services & Government
categories: ['automotive', 'local flavor', 'active life', 'landmarks & historical buildings', 'public services & government']
top_reviews:
["I, to be Frank, lean to the left, heavily, and this bridge, to be Frank, leans both ways during wind storms and what not. And it will Ben, but it won't break.

Of course I've now crossed the Benjamin Franklin Bridge more times than I can remember, as anyone who lives in or regularly visits Philly probably has, and it always kind of annoys me. It's absolutely spectacular, and as you're coming down with the amazing view of Philadelphia on the way down, it's just spectacularly laid out and impressive. What a city - huge and underrated.

It's a long and high bridge and goes over the Delaware River, and is especially lovely being viewed from beneath on the Philadelphia side, where I used to park and sleep sometimes, even though you're not really allowed to do that, nor is it safe.

It's amazing. Despite it being a little pricey, I still give it five stars for the amazing views.", "Many a day I've sped across this bridge...hold on, do the cops read these reviews? Oh well...

It's a lovely bridge boasting even lovelier views of the waterfront & Phila skyline. Of all the bridges in/out of Phila, I like this one the most. I always seem to get thru to NY via NJ quicker by taking this bridge route; probably a psychological thing but I like it.

Rush hour traffic & traffic in general is an issue on any bridge or roadway so stop with the moaning folks. This is an old favourite!", "After today's Eagles game, I accidentally got a lost and ended up going on the Benjamin Franklin Bridge. While I wasn't expecting the situation, I did get to go on the bridge. 

First, the bridge is nicely paved with electric signs easily directing you in every lane. They also clearly say that the toll costs $5 so you don't have to rush once you get to the toll. 

The toll itself is $5, but it's only one way so it is really $2.50, but it keeps traffic from building up. 

Also, the bridge sometimes has events where you can walk across the bridge. Friends of mine have walked it before and I want to try it some time! Also, they have a pedestrian walk on the sides of the bridge. 

Architecturally, the bridge is pretty cool and it gives you a great view of Philadelphia! 

Altogether, this is a nice bridge that connects Pennsylvania and New Jersey!"]

name: Suraya
categories_raw: Active Life, Beer Gardens, Grocery, Middle Eastern, Specialty Food, American (New), Parks, Cafes, Food, Nightlife, Restaurants, Coffee & Tea, Lebanese
top_reviews:
['The best food-related thing that happened to me in 2019 was that when I tried to book dinner at Philadelphia's award-winning Zahav Restaurant, the place was unable to accommodate my request.

My dining companion, a local Philadelphian, suggested that we try Suraya, a Lebanese restaurant well-regarded by Philly's food press. Though I was skeptical of Suraya's newness and trendy popularity, I am a sucker for good Lebanese cooking, so I booked a reservation.

As a result, I enjoyed the best meal I've eaten in years. Thanks, Zahav.

[n.b. I'm about to sound ensorceled by Suraya's charms, so to maintain some credibility, here's my single complaint: Suraya's cardamom-scented kouign-amann was good, but not as good as one I had earlier that day at ICI Macarons & Cafe. That's it. That's all I've got.]

**********
Our meal began at Suraya's tidy bar, where, on the recommendation of our barman, Jesse, we ordered Old-Fashioneds made with Sazerac Rye. Mine was the smoothest and most elegant Old-Fashioned I've ever tasted. Jesse is a boss.

My buddy and I had arrived with a plan in mind. The flexibility of Suraya's tasting menu and the range of choices it offered appealed to us, and we'd already made our selections.

But then we were shown to our table, a perch set slightly above the main floor that provided a view of the open kitchen, where a wood-burning oven was cooking the dinner I didn't know I wanted.

As she took our order, our server, Nena, asked if I'd like the special: slow-roasted young goat with stewed chick peas, Swiss chard, garlic and cilantro, finished with crispy shallots, lemon yogurt and goat jus.

Are you kidding me?

Does a stranded man long for his lover's embrace? Do birds enjoy a light thermal lift as they cross the sea? And, speaking of birds, do Eagles fans revel as Tom Brady slips into aged decrepitude?

The answers, of course, are "yes," "yes,"  and "Hell, yes!" 

I thanked Nena and asked, "May I please have the goat as a part of the tasting menu?" She said, "Sure," then left for the kitchen.

Soon, Nena brought our mezza, then these things happened:

- Substantial but light and slightly lemony hummus that reminded me of the hummus my Teta made by hand, fifty years ago

- Baba ganoush, whose charred eggplant was seasoned with tehina, lemon, garlic and a special treat: sweet and smokey urfa biber chili

- Muhammara, a smooth spread of roasted red pepper and pulverized walnuts blended with chili and cumin 'til it was dense and rich, like pesto, but spicier and more appetizing 

- Labneh, an Arab dairy respite from smoke and spice, a purpose served in other cuisines by lassi, tzatziki and kefir
 
- Tabouli, a usual hearty and cooling salad of parsley, cucumber, tomato, scallion and mint, made unusual by a tart drop of pomegranate molasses

Nena, a skilled and personable server, was unstoppable, as was the mezza, which also included: fried kibbeh (beef and bulgur "dumplings" stuffed with raisins & pine nuts); fattoush (another salad, dressed with lemon-pomegranate vinaigrette); and baskets of fresh-baked Arab bread or "khubz" that was just-chewy, tender and good enough to eat on its own, all night long.

**********
Here's how to eat at Suraya: bite, savor, look around, order more, take a different bite, chat, sip, then do it all again.

Dining at a Lebanese table is a creative endeavor that requires one to engage; "What should I taste next? How would this taste if combined with that?" We're also asked to appreciate the art on the plate; not gratuitous "look-what-I-can-do" decoration, but actual food, placed in such a way that the eater is enticed not to gush and take photos, but to eat.

By now, seven stellar dishes into the evening, I'd abandoned my usual pessimistic expectations. I was persuaded to trust Suraya's chef and his cooks to respectfully interpret recipes handed down by the owners' grandmother - the eponymous Suraya - and developed in consultation with her daughter, Maude.

It was clear that they weren't trying to improve (or, despicably, to "reimagine") Suraya's food in some Millennial way, but were instead doing as they'd been taught, then ever-so-slightly tweaking, using best-quality and authentic ingredients that took their food from what one might find at home to dishes one might find in the best hotels along Beirut's Corniche.

**********
For his main course, or "mashawi" - a rough equivalent to the Italian "secondo" - my friend ordered kawarma - Suraya's grilled and slow-roasted lamb, which was rubbed with "baharat," a mixture of black pepper, allspice, cardamom and other savory spices.

I tasted his meal, which was delectable. Then I savored my own fork-tender, succulent, almost buttery portion of goat ribs and loin. I'm embarrassed to say that I gloated as I announced that my plate won the evening.

Finally, as a bonus, Suraya only offers roasted goat every few weeks - ten orders per night - and by coming across it when I did, I lucked out. 

So really; thanks again, Zahav.', "The one thing I will say about Suraya is the layout is absolutely beautiful and well thought out. The front is more like a chill cafe for casuals which blends into the main dining area for both casuals and some fine dining without seeming like their trying to hard. 
The decor of Suraya reminds me of the one friend with the one Aunt /Uncle with old money that no one in the family actually knows what they do for a living, but damn can they throw a chill gathering with good food and good vibes. 
The food itself is pretty solid and more portions than I expected. 
The only thing I did expect was a lot more flavor, but it just wasn't all the way there. Not that the food wasn't amazing, but I didn't day dream about it as much as I daydreamed about the decor.
We ordered the mushroom hummus which was the best item of the bunch. Full of flavor and nice big portion of it. The falafel wrap was what you would expect. A wrap. 
I will surely be back to Suraya to try the cafe side next time out of pure curiosity, especially since they have a kid menu.", "Obsessed!! Not only with the insanely gorgeous space that showcases impeccable attention to detail and so many stunning ways to honor and highlight the culture... in the decor, market goods and dish-ware, but with the food too. And I haven't even tried half of the traditional Lebanese offerings! 

 I'm going to go bold here and say Suraya dishes up the best falafel I've ever had...and I've eaten falafel in the Middle East! It's pretty darn fantastic!! Unbelievable, actually. Crispy fried golden exterior, perfect warm interior. Perfect crunch to soft ratio. So incredibly delish! If you want to save the carbs or just eat a smidge lighter, go for the balls themselves, and not the platter. Not listed, just ask! 

To date, I've tried two of their hummus flavors... the mushroom and the crispy chickpea. They're both uber creamy, totally flavorful, loaded with toppings, and just excellent. Up there as my second favorite hummus in ALL of Philly! 

I've also tried their baba ganoush complete with pomegranate seeds! What a lovely, crunchy, colorful addition to the dish. This smoked eggplant dip has just the right amount of smokiness and garlic! Great texture too! 

Their rosewater lemonade is just beautiful and refreshing. I absolutely love it! Tart and sweet. A must! 

The clementine ginger beer with cardamom served in a copper mule mug is also fantastic! 

The beet salad, and Man'oushe (Lebanse flatbread) are up for me next! Oh, and the tehina hot chocolate! Yessss!! 

Make sure to leave some time to walk around the entire space. It's just gorgeous! The cafe is super sweet with fresh deep jewel tone blooms on each table and bright light shining through the big windows. The bar is gorgeous and inviting. The dining room is spacious and candle-lit, and the back porch will transport you to another country!! I can't wait until it's officially open back there! I'm in love with the patterned pillows, wrap around bench, wood-burning fireplace and tiled floor!! Oh, and definitely take a peek at the goods for sale. Most of them, if not all, are straight from Lebanon. Spices, oils, body goods, and textiles too! It's like perusing a shuk! 

The only things that bum me out are the fact that they're closed on Mondays. There have been several, several Mondays I've wanted to go. Also, the fact that they don't take ressies for brunch. I really wanted to bring my mom and our fam here for Mother's Day. Perhaps a dinner soon will be better? Those cocktails and even the Lebanese beer are calling my name. I hear Open Table is starting to accept reservations for that time frame!

I cannot say enough good things about Suraya!! It's such a pleasure for all the senses to dine here. I'm so in love! I heard 'Suraya' is the name of the owner's grandmother. They are certainly making her proud. 

I honestly can't see me ever tiring of this gem! It's really worthy of all of the hype it's receiving!

*There's street parking which is easy to find during the day, but also an entire lot across the street!"]

name: Taqueria Guerrero
categories_raw: Mexican, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['A friend of mine religiously goes here, so I thought I'd take her up on the offer of us both popping in here. We sat down in the window to the left, and were IMMEDIATELY served complimentary chips and two kinds of salsa, red and verde. We ordered their guacamole to give us time to look at the menu. I apologized to our waitress at least 3 times because she kept coming back and I still wasn't sure, so know that the staff is very attentive. 

The place has an authentic look about it, in terms of a Mexican restaurant where actual Mexicans and/or Central Americans living or visiting New Orleans would eat, if that makes sense. The menu has the names of the dishes in Spanish with half the explanations in English and half in Spanish and some explanations in both... It was only us and two other tables; one with a very unhappy baby, but it was nice to not be on top of other people eating dinner.  

The guacamole arrived, and we ordered the large Cocktail de Camarones and the pork Tostadas Mexicanas to split. Their guacamole is more of a soupier guacamole, not really chunky at all, but so so good. You can pick up flavors of cilantro and lime, and I really like this spin on a guacamole that's almost more of a guacamole salsa. 

The Cocktail de Camarones and Tostadas arrived not long after. They were both picture perfect as you can see; the tostadas matching their picture on the menu to a T. I should've seen that their were refried beans on the tostadas, aka frijoles, but I guess I thought I could pick around them. If you like beans, you'll like these since they make up the majority of the Tostadas with not a copious amount of pork on them. I didn't think the flavor was really there (again, I'm not a huge bean person, so take note). The Cocktail de Camarones reminded me more so of an Ecuadorian shrimp ceviche rather than your typical shrimp cocktail, and it's the closest I've come to tasting that flavor here in New Orleans. In Ecuador they use ketchup in their ceviche to tone down the acidity of the lime. The best way to describe it was, "tangy." Again if I hadn't been sharing, I probably would've added some heat, but it was a goblet of shrimp, and a ton of avocado, so I would definitely order this dish again. 

The split bill was equivalent to us both getting a footlong Subway, and we had an app and two dishes, so I'll probably stop in here again to try some other things, right after I knock out a few chapters of my Rosetta Stone.', 'In this modest vehicular path adjacent Earthling structure devoted to inserting various manifestations of flattened grain plants into one's digestive tract, you will find a heightened pleasure to your molecular sample receptors previously unknown to the typical long-term neural storage networks clustered within an average American bipedal primate's hardened calcium-enclosed neck weight.

* Would you like the ion channels in your own muscular hydrostat to absorb the altogether similar ions in the sliced up muscular hydrostat of a previously homeostatically metabolizing bovine pasture mammal, within the confines of what is called a "chimichanga"?

* Would you like to experience the unborn embryos of a grain-fattened generally flightless bird in a "ranch" sauce, aside repeatedly lipid-heated legumes and gaseous-water thermodynamically-accelerated paddy-cultivated cereal grains with even some coagulated infant-feeding protein fluid to complete the meal?

* Would you like to rehydrate with a disaccharide-enhanced carbohydrate solution derived from the rectangular cell-walled pulp of numerous species of ripened flowering non-human ovaries?

The answer to all of these is the creation of the sound: "Sí". Other acceptable pressure wave transmissions are: hai, ja, oui, da, yebo, and YES.

For those reading this long after it has no longer become acceptable to exchange dried flattened soups of plant flesh, or magnetically-encoded series of 0s and 1s denoting stored "value", please take note: a visit here requires very little, as of this date established by the 2013th orbit (relative to the planet's only man born without the contribution of spermatozoa) of the third planet from the fairly nominal ball of fusing hydrogen in this particular galactic spiral arm.

P.S. Earth is hilarious.', 'Beware gringos, this is not Americanized Mexican or TexMex. And the staff speaks Spanish much better than they do English, which I kinda like--a badge of their authenticity? But if you want authentic, delicious, and cheap Mexican food in NOLA, TG is your place. 

But you don't need Spanish, do you? Because I just posted their menu for you, and it has pictures on it.  I mean, did you come for the conversation or for the food? The menu even has numbers on it, so just tell'm "numero tres," or point. Then have a seat, sit down, eat, and smile. 

I can vouch for the awesomeness of their chiles rellenos, pupusas and tacos pastores, so far, but I plan to continue working my way through the menu. Can't beat the central, Mid-city location on Carrollton, can you? And I think that the comments here by other yelpers about the decor are a little unfair. It isn't fancy by any standard, but it is very clean and nicer than I expected after reading other reviews here. 

The only bummer is that they don't serve alcohol, but that means you can bring your own. Hard to bring a Margarita though, like the one you can get at "Juan's Flying Burrito" down the street, but in my opinion, the food here is much better and cheaper, so nine times out of ten, I go here and BMOB, or get take out and make the margaritas at home. 

Besides, the juices and horchata here are as tasty as they are refreshing, so who needs alcohol? They have really killer seafood and savory soups as well, which will improve your mood on rainy days. This review is starting to sound like an advertisement, but after not trying this place due to its outward appearance for some time, it was the food that made me a believer, and I think you'll agree. A book by its cover, right? 

Anyway, it's the kind of place I am likely to return to often for the flavor and for the deal, a much appreciated piece of Mexico right here in Mid-city. 

Vivan los guerreros!']

name: Nothing Bundt Cakes
categories_raw: Desserts, Cupcakes, Bakeries, Food
top_reviews:
['Some good, some not so.

Positives:
Rich, moist cakes with equally rich frosting.
A wide variety of cake foundations - from chocolate and vanilla to red velvet and carrot.
Free/easy parking in front of store.
Terrific, clean displays and easy to follow menus.
Delightful, albeit pricey, individual/gift-sized and gift-wrapped bundtlet cakes.

Negatives:
The cakes are accomplished the old fashioned way - high cholesterol butter and eggs with high-glycemic sugars, per their about-us-story. Yes, your fingers, napkins, paper plates will immediately soak through with grease. In this respect NBC has not evolved anywhere near the 21st century in terms of nutritional mindfulness or creativity.
Speaking of which, no employee could point me to the actual nutritional contents, not even the bare bones carb, fat, fiber, cholesterol and protein. They swiftly directed me to the website as if they'd "answered" that query a hundred times. Unfortunately, unlike every other restaurant chain, NBC does not post any nutritional information anywhere on their website. None. And in hindsight this explained the darting eyes of the employees when they told me to check the website. Not cool.
Lastly, the cakes are bland, flat. Even the carrot cake has almost no texture (most critically, no walnuts, never mind raisins).

Sugar and butter will always have a following, but not for me.  Give me coconut or olive oils. Load in the flavor textures like pecans, seeds, and cut back on the simple sugars by including natural alternatives, from honey to monk fruit and do the same with chocolate by elevating cocoa content above 51%. And just be upfront about your contents. Now we're talking!

After writing to corporate I received the nutritional breakdown of each Bundtlet (the grapefruit-sized cakes).  A Bundtini (their smallest cakes) are roughly 1/3 the calories of a Bundtlet, per the email that I received.', "These cakes are amazing! Yes, they are rich, sugary and just plain delicious, but I do not think they are intended to be eaten weekly. But they are perfect for a little something to share, or also for someone's birthday. I like how they come in not only different flavors, but also the different sizes from buntletts, to buntini's to entire cakes serving 5+ people depending on the size. I stopped by this new location on Thursday of last week since I had a free coupon. The employee there was so sweet (no pun intended) and friendly! She gave me all of the information I needed and even offered to have me try the white chocolate raspberry they had on the sample station. Great location, even better employees, I highly recommend NBC!", "From birthdays to anniversaries and graduations these cakes are good for almost every occasion. Each and every cake I've had here was made to perfection. They have a variety of sizes that can fit every occasion. The prices are a bit steep, for good measure. Sometimes cakes can be overwhelming with the frosting, but these always have the perfect amount. There are also soooooo many different flavors I haven't had the opportunity of trying each of them and my go-to flavor here is the red velvet. I would definitely recommend sticking to Bundt cakes for special occasions that call for cake!"]

name: Crescent Park
categories_raw: Active Life, Dog Parks, Parks

name: PAWS Veterinary Center
categories_raw: Pets, Veterinarians, Mass Media, Radio Stations
top_reviews:
["Overpriced, after months of working with these people these are my findings.

Don't ask for your $1,200 bill to be itemized because you will get a cold stare. Even then when it comes back it won't be completely itemized, they don't seem to know how much they charge for what.

They play on the heartstrings of shocked, concerned and grieving pet owners, maybe a better word is prey.

They will offer you every kind of treatment known to mankind for a pet that may not be able to recover. They are not forthcoming in terminal cases either.

No matter how much you have spent in the past, don't expect to get a nod of the doctor's head unless you are paying for his time. He may or may not send a message out to you via a tech.

Front office is slow, to action, slow to greet, and doesn't seem to mind that you are taking time out of your day, your money earning day, to wait for them to get it together. They often seem to be having technical challenges with their computers.

I spent over $3,000 here and still lost my pet. A second opinion told me that she was terminal, and that they never recover from this kind of illness.", "I took my Chloe here after I found a mass on her stomach. Dr. Aronson did surgery on her and removed the mass. Dr. Thurston broke the news to me that the mass was cancerous but they were willing to do whatever I felt was needed to keep my Chloe as happy and well as possible. Unfortunately my Chloe girl died shortly after because the cancer came back so quick. I brought in Chloe's body (she passed at home) and was given a genuine bear hug from one of the girls at the front desk.  I was shown such amazing compassion and sympathy. When I picked up Chloe's ashes I was met with sincerest apologies for her passing. Everyone who works there took time out of their day to write a condolences card which made me cry. And they also made a little clay imprint of Chloe's paw, which made me sob. 

I will not be going anywhere else but PAWS. The care and concern for my cat and for myself is absolutely amazing and I couldn't appreciate it more. It's the little things like signing a card or making a paw print that make this place so wonderful. Thank you PAWS for making me feel cared about!", "There is no question that PAWS is a beautiful facility with competent and caring staff.  I went there because my dog has been coping with a chronic gastrointestinal problem and as it is advertised as integrative medicine, I thought they would offer holistic alternatives. I scheduled a consultation with Dr. Randy Aaronson because I was hoping to help my dog and avoid the expensive endoscopy which I told him at our visit.  He was very encouraging that there were several things and an endoscopy was much further down the line.  Unfortunately, the blood test, x-rays, and fecal test were negative.  When the medication he gave my dog did not resolve the problem within two weeks, Dr. Aaronson suggested doing the endoscopy (close to $3000) rather than spending a lot of money on trying other things. He's correct that this procedure is the ideal way to guide the treatment of GI problems.  It is worth noting that even with a diagnosis, not all dogs will respond to treatment or they will relapse.  

I was surprised that Dr. Aaronson could only offer prescription dog food and worming as alternatives to the endoscopy. Recommending the endoscopy was, he said, to avoid spending a lot of money trying different things.  I'm confused-- what are some of these things that would cost a lot of money?

My other concern with PAWS is that at the time of my initial visit when we didn't know for sure what the tests she was given that day would reveal and her GI tract was upset, I was sold over a month's supply of Tylan.  Then after two weeks when it hadn't resolved the problem, he recommended the endoscopy.  I wondered why so many pills in the first place (at $140) when we didn't know they would work.  I also was sold that day three supplements that I could only begin using after she got better. Looking back I wish I had had the presence of mind to question this since as it turns out I'm still not sure when I can give them to my dog. 

If you can afford to spend over a $1000 in diagnosing your pet's GI disease, I'd recommend PAWS.  My impression of Dr. Aaronson is that he is knowledgeable, upbeat, and experienced and the staff is caring and professional.  Unfortunately, I ended up feeling like since I couldn't spend the money they were done with me.  I got the impression that I was too much trouble since I wasn't going to accrue credit card debt.  It left me with a somewhat disappointed feeling-- quite different than when I left the initial consultation."]

name: Westside Pizza
categories_raw: Food Delivery Services, Restaurants, Food, Pizza
top_reviews:
["Our first visit to the pizza joint I heard is the best pizza in town and we weren't disappointed.  I would rate it right up there with Pixel Chick, which is now no more.  We had the gluten-free crust and they gave us the thick gluten Crest and thinner gluten free crust to try, which i wouldn't have even thought about without their offering.  I have a friend who is gluten free and I enjoyed this pizza as much as a regular crust.  The pizza had generous toppings and really enjoyed the staff.", 'Westside Pizza is a nice little place shoved into a strip mall not too far down from the Overland Walmart and the city's largest Edwards movie theater complex. You might miss it if you're not looking, and you might miss the turn if you're passing by it on the west-bound side of the road.

The question today is, should you make sure to make that turn?

Here's the thing. Do you enjoy eating in spaces with a chrome-polished medical center cleanliness? If you answered yes, then Westside is ideal for you. Contrary to last week's Flying Pie, you won't find any cutesy plastered papers on the walls or hilarious soda fountain puns. Instead, you'll be greeted with a clean, shiny, orderly grouping of tables and chairs and the convenient drone of whatever sports game is likely to bring people in that week.

Perhaps they haven't found the thing that "makes them cool" yet, but you could probably walk out of Westside and into any brand new sports bar and not know any different. The atmosphere was effectively nonexistent.

The staff were friendly in the sense that they seemed thankful they didn't work in a Little Caesar's. Nothing to complain about, but nothing to praise.

But of course, sometimes the quality of the pizza can be so good, it makes you forget about all your little disappointments in life. So, how was it?

Well we ordered up a "Grand" sized pizza, half of it pepperoni and the other half was a specialty called "Veggie Gourmet," which boasted artichoke hearts, pesto base, and sun-dried tomatoes. The size chart in Westside claims "Grand, Large, Medium, and Small," but what we got out of a Grand felt like the same as what you'd get at Little Caesar's. No inches to help you confirm, either, but lemme tell you, the "Grand" is not so big as it might sound.

The price, for the pizza and one drink (everyone else in our party got water), came out to around $30.

-Pepperoni-
Westside could probably boast their Pepperoni as their signature. To be honest, the visit was not my first in my tasting of their pizza. But in all my experiences with their pizza, no specialty has yet beat their pepperoni. But this isn't necessarily a compliment. It's good, nothing great. The sauce has a solid mixture of spices, the peps are toasted well (but not quite crunchy, unfortunately), and the cheese plays its part right. You eat it and go, "This is pizza, yep." And then you remember the price tag and you start to wonder if you shouldn't have just hit up the ol' LC.

-Veggie Gourmet-
The artichoke hearts were cut very large, which I like. The tomatoes, however, seemed almost absent. I'm pretty sure they were on there, but they were hidden under the layer of cheese. I know I tasted them at times, but it was hard to identify any thoughts towards the tomatoes because my buds were being severely overwhelmed by the thick pouring of pesto. Pesto base is generally a favorite of mine, but I have to say that it felt like a little much here. It wasn't awful, but it was even more mediocre than the pep.

-Verdict-
Westside is the kind of place you go when your dad wants to watch The Big Game and you want to eat pizza and browse Tumblr while pretending you get along with your dad's interests. Hopefully your dad is footing the bill, too. Stick to the pepperoni and you'll be fine.

3 slices out of 5', "My review is going to be tough but when it comes to pizza I know my stuff. I've had pizzas in every single state, 42 countries, and locally, I believe this is at least the 20th pizza spot I've tried. 

Pizza in Boise, ID isn't life changing anywhere but when there's amazing spots like the Wildler and Red Bench Pizza, there's no excuse for choosing a place like this. 

We've tried supporting them multiple times, but after continuously poor experiences I need to share my 2 star review. First: the ingredients. Everything tastes cheap. Honestly it tastes like enriched white flour with generic store bought cheap ingredients. If you're used to picking the cheapest flour, cheese and marinara sauce from Walmart this might taste similar, but if you have a palate that's used to high-quality ingredients, this just tastes cheap. 

The pizza crust is always extremely dry, flavorless, and there's no oil or crunch at the bottom. It's just bland. There's nothing worse than unmemorable calories but that's exactly what this is. 

Next: customer service. We've ordered pre-covid-19 and during. Pre-covid we were never greeted, never thanked for grabbing our order and if we asked for anything like extra marinara it was never given. Now that we're in the middle of it, we've waited in our car when they said they'd bring it out, but instead it was left in under artificial heat until we walked inside. Fool me once ok. But say it twice and I'm actually upset, especially if I'm waiting in my car a half hour longer than I need to and I have a type one diabetic sitting next to me who needs food when it's ready.

I really want to support all local establishments, this one included, but until they attempt to offer a superior product to the competition, they don't deserve to be anyone's first, second or even third choice."]

name: Lloyd Whiskey Bar
categories_raw: Nightlife, Restaurants, Wine Bars, Cocktail Bars, Gastropubs, Bars, American (New), Lounges
top_reviews:
["I was very pleasantly surprised by my experience at Lloyd a couple weeks ago. I expected the bar to be dark and divey, but the atmosphere was definitely more in the style of an upscale gastropub. The happy hour runs from 5-8 (amazing) and I really enjoyed the cocktail of the day, the Americano, which our server described as a lighter twist on a negroni. 

The food menu is pretty short and sweet but probably has something for everyone. I went with the burger, cooked medium. It came out prepared as requested and the beef was super juicy, but I thought it was lacking in seasoning. It was an okay burger but I'd probably try something else next time. 

Service was great -\xa0attentive and friendly. Looking forward to more visits!", 'Lloyd is my new favorite bar in Fishtown... and all of Philadelphia for the matter. With its cozy atmosphere, cool background music, and great friendly service, I've already become a regular in just the first couple weeks this bar has been open. From the food to the cocktails, Lloyd knows what they're doing and they are doing it right! This bar is just what the neighborhood needed and it will be a hotspot for locals and visitors alike for a long time!

Here's what I've tried so far:

The Food:
Texas Tommy- This delicious and decadent hot dog is served smothered in cheese sauce, wrapped in bacon, and topped off with bourbon soaked bacon. Maybe the best hot dog I've ever had. I could eat these things all night!

Lloyd Burger- I order my burgers medium rare and this one came out perfectly. As the menu states, they use a special house blend of beef, muenster cheese, pickled onion, lettuce, tomato, on a brioche bun. Delicious! It also comes with awesome fries.

Goldfish-Crusted Mac & Cheese- Creamy cheesy goodness. Can't go wrong with this dish!

Green Tomato Grilled Cheese- Provolone, gruyere, and muenster cheese on sourdough. Grilled just right and served with a field green salad.

Crispy Fried Deviled Eggs- The caper aioli is the perfect accompaniment for this tasty appetizer.

Desserts: I've tried both the rice pudding and the bread pudding. Each are a perfect way to end you meal (unless you'd prefer another whiskey!).

The Cocktails:
I can honestly say Lloyd served up the best Manhattan and Old Fashioned I've ever had! The happy hour is from 5-7pm and some of their cocktails and beers are on special. I recommend the Jack & Wendy and The Overlook (simply because I'm a huge fan of The Shining). I hope one day I'll find a "Delbert Grady" on the cocktail menu.  Looking for something quick and easy? Go with "The Lloyd", only $5 for a can of Miller High Life and a shot of Old Grand Dad.

With dozens of bourbons, ryes, Irish Whiskey, and Scotch Whisky on the menu, you can't go wrong. Whiskey isn't your thing? No problem! Lloyd has plenty of beers, wines and other spirits to loosen up your inhibitions. 

As you can tell, I've been sampling a lot of the menu and haven't been disappointed yet. I'm looking forward to trying the chicken po' boy, the beef stew, and BBQ turkey meatloaf in the near future. 

"I like ya Lloyd, I've always liked ya. The best damn bar from Timbuktu to Portland, Maine...or Portland, Oregon for that matter." -Jack Torrence, The Shining', "Lloyd is quickly becoming one of my favorite places to hang out in Fishtown. I have had a few of their appetizers and have also been one night for a whiskey and pork pairing event featuring Brooklyn Brewery, but mainly I come to drink and enjoy the atmosphere. Their customer service is top-notch. Whenever I walk in, no matter how busy the place is, someone seemingly appears from nowhere to seat me, whether at a table or at the bar. Once seated, I never have to wait long for another drink or even a refill on my water.

I'm more of a beer drinker myself and would love it if they had a more expansive draft list to choose from, but I always find something I like in what they do have. My partner is a whiskey drinker so he's never lacking in choices here. They also know their stuff when it comes to cocktails and you can tell they take pains to make sure a drink is made correctly.

We usually show up on the later side of things and Lloyd can get somewhat crowded on weekend nights, but I've always been comfortable no matter the size of the crowd. The atmosphere is what puts Lloyd over the top for me; I love the music and the classy, understated decor. Some of the other whiskey bars in the city can be a little over the top for my taste. Lloyd gets it right in my opinion."]

name: Danny's Baboquivari Restaurant & Lounge
categories_raw: Nightlife, Restaurants, Bars
top_reviews:
["Ahhh dive bars. 
Oh how I love thee. 
Danny's is just one of many, but most definitely a favorite. 
Cannot lie, we are there frequently enough to be known not only by name but by drink of choice that is nicely poured (and priced) as well. 
Juke box has a great selection and clientele is almost as varied as the juke box. Back patio makes for great conversation and friend making. No seriously, I have made 2 life-long friends cause of this place. 
Bathrooms are...well, dive bar bathrooms so don't expect much. Just don't touch more than you need to, do your thing and get outta there.", 'I usually have a good time at Danny's but after a recent experience I will never be going back. The bartender was being a complete trash bag the entire night.

After a couple beers my friend ordered a water and the bartender grabbed a random dirty glass off the bar, dumped the contents, and without rinsing, filled it with water and ice. He then placed a straw in the water that had disgusting black nodules on the drinking end and served it. My friend pointed out the grotesque straw and the bartender gave a halfhearted apology and got a fresh glass. We wrote it off as an accident and went on with the night.

Later in the evening, we noticed that the jukebox seemed to be malfunctioning whenever our songs were playing. The first several seconds of the song would play before it skipped to the next track. Other songs seemed to be playing fine but our songs were getting skipped for some reason. This happened several times. We wrote it off as a problem with the Jukebox but after our last song was skipped, the bartender got on the PA system and announced to the whole bar, "That song sucked." I should mention that this isn't one of those Internet jukeboxes where you can pick whatever song you want. This is a good old CD jukebox with a selection of music curated by the bar's managers. We put money into the jukebox, waited our turn, and the shit heel bartender publicly insulted us.

At this point I demanded the bartender refund the money from the jukebox and close my tab. He refunded me $1 out of the $4 I put into the machine. He returned my debit card with no receipt and told me to leave. The next day I found that he had charged my card $125. We are talking about a total of 8 drinks split between two people at a dive bar. Even if we were drinking top-shelf liquor, the total shouldn't have been more than $64.

I would like to make it clear that this bartender is a total stranger to me. It is not as though we have some history that might explain his behavior. I was just hanging out with a few friends at the bar, playing shuffleboard and pool, and listening to the jukebox.

As long as Danny's employs people who engage in this larcenous and unsanitary behavior, I cannot recommend anyone spend their money there. Please, for your own sake, stay away.', 'Super fun dive bar!!

Cheap drinks, air hockey, shuffleboard table, pool tables, friendly crowd, fast service. Pretty much everything you can ask for from a dive bar.

I would definitely come back here the next time I visit Tucson.']

name: Smiley's Cafe
categories_raw: Juice Bars & Smoothies, Food, Mediterranean, Greek, Restaurants, Sandwiches
top_reviews:
["Cynthia, my ex-wife, used to say that I never took chances with my life. She was right -- I always wanted to play things safe. I mean, working as an actuary is a good career and everything. But I got so invested in my work that I compartmentalized everything. 14 years worth of our marriage, all gone, and it was my fault. Our twin sons are going to live with their mom in Glenside. It's not too far away and they'll be coming to stay with me at my new apartment in Manayunk one weekend a month. I know it's for the better but it doesn't feel like it is yet.

Anyways, I walked past Smiley's the other day. Like I said earlier -- I've never been much into taking chances, and that includes food. I'm more of a hamburger kind of guy. Cynthia (my ex-wife) always wanted to try Mediterranean but I always found a way to not try it. What a mistake! Smiley's food is SO great. I had a delicious platter -- pitas, hummus, roasted veggies, etc. 

It was so great! The family that runs this place are THE NICEST people. It's so great seeing a husband and wife that still know how to connect with each other. If all it took was Mediterranean food, I would have taken Cynthia (and the twins) out a long time ago.

I would recommend Smiley's Cafe to anyone in the Manayunk area who ants to eat Mediterranean food while replaying in their mind all of time times they took the road taken, instead of trying new directions. Life is a highway, as that awesome song says.", "Absolutely love this place! When I lived on Main St, I probably ate here once every two weeks. I always get the Greek Gyro wrap, and sometimes falafels. Everything is great. 

The place is owned by a delightful family who go above and beyond to make sure you're served your meal with a smile! 

The pita is thinner than usual pita at greek restaurants. I would consider this pita to be more-so lebanese. Delicious!", "My fiancé and I have called in for takeout several times. Each time ordering was super fast and we were able to pick up as fast as we could walk there. Both sandwiches and platter are delicious! Sometimes we'll get an extra side of hummus to share which is also superb. Affordable and portion sizes are generous!"]

name: Mike the Bike Guy
categories_raw: Active Life, Sporting Goods, Bikes, Shopping, Local Services, Bike Rentals
top_reviews:
['TOTAL DICK!!!!!
I am a neighbor and walked in to ask if he could give me some advice or help in any way with a bike rack I was trying to put on my car - he is the bike guy right ?
This is the response, " UH, NO".  
I was even going to give him cash for the help, but I did not get the chance to offer or ask.
Next time I see him stumbling out of the bar across the street I will not slow down.', "Well looks like the owner has been brazen enough to leave me a really rude owners comment. Honestly mike, when you resort to calling someone a liar and getting nasty you only make things worse for yourself. Lashing out and getting hateful with reviewers is not a very good way to get your point across. Talking to people like dirt only proves me and other reviewers right. By the way I don't work for a bike shop, I actually have a REAL job!!!!

I have read some of these other reviews and they pretty much stress the same message that was in my review, His attitude stinks! Hmm.... maybe someone needs to take a hint already!

I know that the owner will read this update and I am glad. Here are the things that I want to stress to him.
1:There is a thing called the first amendment that allows freedom of speech. 
2:Be careful what you post on here because everyone can see it.
3:A little politeness and common courtesy go a long way.

In his response he told me not to bother him. It's been 3 years since I last went there. If I didn't go back during that time why would I ever consider it now?", 'I notice that I am not the only one on here who has a problem with this guy. I already posted a negative review about this man on google, so I will post my review on here as well.I am a real person and this is a real review.
 I went to see Mike the bike guy I arrived at his shop at 5:00pm. His mechanic and this one lady at his shop greeted me with a warm friendly demeanor. The same could not be said of Mike the owner. He gave me a menacing glare and in a really hateful tone he told me,"I am only fixing flat tires right now". Despite this the lady behind the counter took a look at my bike. I knew what the problems were, the back rim needed to be replaced and the brakes needed to be fixed.I told her this she agreed with me and said that they could work on it tomorrow. Also she said it would only be about $95. Mike walked over there and gave me a different story.He proceeded to tell me that it would cost about $200(before tax and labor fees) to fix what was wrong with it. I asked him if I could leave my bike in his shop overnight and come back tomorrow when he fixed it. He instantly got defensive and told me"NO!!!!". After that tirade he said was not willing to work on it because the brakes were shot. Then he scoffed at me and told me that I should throw my bike in the garbage and by a new one at Wal-Mart(easy for him to say, he didn't pay $500 for this bike). Needless to say I left from there in total disgust.When I was on the corner of Soniat and Magazine I found another bike shop. I went in there I was greeted with a friendly attitude. The same problems that Mike wanted to charge me $200 dollars for they only charged me $55 dollars for. And yes they kept my bike overnight in their shop. When I came in the next day it was fixed. Despite all these positive reviews for this business. I can't say that I feel the same way as the rest of these folks. 
      This incident happened like 2 years ago But it still haunts me as one of the worst customer service fiasco's I have ever experienced.']

name: BOIL Seafood House
categories_raw: Seafood, Cajun/Creole, Restaurants, Comfort Food
top_reviews:
['Fresh and very flavorful seafood boil! My family and I came here for lunch and were very satisfied after finishing our order of The House and Kind Crab Legs. Perfect for a group of 5 while also wanting to save room for the next meal on our list. 

The shrimp were my favorite part while my sister loved the crab legs, and my dad the crawfish. No complaints!', "I tend to find myself coming here when I have friends and family wanting to try a boil but still play tourist and explore main sites around the city such as Magazine Street. Food is solid and I've never had any issues. The menu has a wide array of other food options. A solid location that hits a few checkmarks.", "I visited the Boil Seafood House on my visit to New Orleans because I had a taste for crab legs, and the Seafood House did not disappoint. 

My Uber driver told me to make sure I stop by so I did just that. They have both indoor and outdoor seating, but it was too hot to sit outside. My waitress was so nice, friendly, and checked on me consistently. The indoor dining area is a bit small, but I believe they also have an upstairs seating area, but don't quote me on that. There was no wait, and I was seated right away, but It was also quite early. I got there around 5:00pm.

Their charbroiled oysters were scrumptious as well as the Gumbo. I ordered a seafood boil that consisted of crab legs, sausage, shrimp, & corn. I've eaten seafood boils all over NYC, and they all pretty much taste the same. The Seafood House was no different. It was good, but nothing spectacular. It's a nice friendly atmosphere with good food, and good music. 

I would definitely stop by if you're in the area. If you do the hop on hop off bus, the tour stops right down the block from the restaurant.

Enjoy!"]

name: Street- Taco and Beer Co.
categories_raw: Mexican, Bars, Restaurants, Nightlife
top_reviews:
["Was craving a Sonoran hot dog and saw this place had some tasty looking ones around the corner from my hotel.

Once you get inside, there's a bunch of tables, a bar and a menu hanging over a line of meats, cheeses, breads and other things to create your meal. You start at one of the line, tell the person behind the counter what you want, and since they're creating in front of your eyes, everything is completely customizable.

I went with their Street Dog and two tacos (pollo pastor and al pastor) on corn tortillas. The hot dog was everything I was craving and more. There was a hearty amount of beans, condiments and it was housed in a fluffy bun. The tacos are street taco size and the pork was my favorite of the two.

The staff was super friendly and they did a great job of keeping things moving while still clearing/cleaning tables so people had a place to sit. When the weather is nice, they have quite a few tables outside to enjoy as well.

Will definitely be back.", 'Fun taco shop with friends.  Come and get your classic favorite dishes.  Good seating for a quick bite in downtown Tucson.', "It's a local version of Chipotle,
Much like Mexico in Season was- except Mexico in season used fresh ingredients, sourced locally and was vegan/vegetarian friendly. This spot? Well, it's good, it's relatively cheap and fast, but nothing really stood out. It's definitely a good choice for folks on the go or for a quick lunch, but generally I'm not rushing to get through a meal, so this isn't really a place I'll be a regular at. Local brews on tap are a nice touch. We sat at the Bar and the service was pretty indifferent, perhaps we'll sit at a table next time and take advantage of the drink order button I've read about in other reviews."]

name: Kabob House
categories_raw: Mediterranean, Restaurants, Afghan, Indian, Middle Eastern
top_reviews:
["If one was smart enough to understand brain surgery and was fluent in Dari, a language spoken in Afghanistan, one could have a detailed discussion on that topic with Shams, the owner of Kabob House.  He is a physician and that was his area of specialty when he practiced medicine in Afghanistan before coming to the United States with his wife and children a few years ago.
