My understanding is the family's relocation was with assistance of an American General after Shams helped with military patients at Bagram AFB.

It is lucky for us that while Dari is not a language my husband and I speak at all, English is a language Shams speaks well enough for us to be grateful to him for the hospitality he extends to his customers at Kabab House, which he purchased in mid 2018 I think.  (Reviews and photos prior to that will be for the previous owner's time.)

And before I share more about our dining experiences, I feel compelled to speak about a recent reviewer who was so critical of language obstacles as to leave a 1 star for that reason when she was twice advised by her host of the 20 minute time it took to grill kabobs she ordered for take out.  Acknowledging language challenges exist and with respect for her right to hold an opinion, I wonder if she would have been so ungracious in review had she known the backstory. 

From our experience, thanks to Shams' effort to speak English and our wanting to listen to and speak with this charming man, we have enjoyed the food served in his restaurant and the hospitality of customers treated like family.  For this physician in Afghanistan turned restaurant owner in the US and for this family business and for the food we say five stars in the context of the whole.

A TRUE FAMILY BUSINESS:  My husband and I are 'food explorers' (or in my case even food obsessed) and familiar with some cuisines of the Middle East like Lebanese, Israeli, Persian (Iranian) and Iraqi dishes.  We are also familiar with the food of Pakistan which, like Iran, borders Afghanistan in Central Asia.  But Kabob House has provided our introduction to Afghanistan food.  All of the food here is cooked by Sham's wife and served to tables by him.  In true family business style, his sons assist in the kitchen and with table service when they are out of school.  Open seven days a week for lunch and dinner, imagine the hard work to make that happen.

SPARKLING AND WELCOMING:  Remembering that Shams' original profession was physician, it likely explains how sparkling clean is the restaurant.  And it is welcoming for all people for seating at a combination of standard height tables and chairs, some traditional low upholstered seating booths, and a couple of standard height booths as well.  There is no music sound system and we love that for being able to enjoy conversation with other diners and with Shams.

WEEKDAY LUNCH BUFFET & MAIN MENU & FOOD:  The previous owners of Kabob House had a lunch buffet and a couple of months ago Shams started offering one too.  We enjoyed trying it once to acquaint us with something we had not seen on the main menu -  a wonderful Afghanistan styled baked bean dish that I'll be sure to look for on the menu now - and delicious chicken tikka masala since chicken is not a protein we typically order. 

But our favorite way to eat here is to order from the menu which ranges from appetizers through salad and soup to kabobs and sides like basmati rice and naan and main dishes and desserts.  Family platters are offered too.

Kabob dishes may be the draw, given the restaurant name, but it is worth noting quobali polow (spelling?) which is recognized as a national dish of Afghanistan.  There may be as many variations of this dish as there are cooks in Afghanistan, but in general it is lamb under a bed of basmati rice topped with carrots and raisins.  At Kabob House the lamb is a large roasted shank and this is a dish that can easily feed two. (All animal proteins used at Kabob House are Halal.)

Most cuisines have a  'savory turnover' in the repertoire (like samosas in Indian food or empanadas in Latin America) and the sambosas on this menu of savory pastry filled with potatoes and split peas are delicous.  They came with a cilantro sauce alongside to use if you want to which is so good that my husband and I were tempted to drink it!

Naan is excellent and it comes with the cilantro sauce alongside.

The Persian tea served here is lovely in fragrance and flavor, made with whole green tea leaves and cardamom.

One lunch time visit when we shared our sambosas with the couple at the next table, they ordered dessert for us of tiny little tender fried dumplings served in a small pool of perfect-barely sweet brothy syrup.  Delightful.  The rice pudding here, it has mango in it I think, is really good too.  

ACCESSIBILITY:  ADA parking in private mall lot.  Level in the door and all on one floor inside.  Ample floor space.  Standard height seating.", "Kabob House 

Exotic yet familiar food in a hospitable and inviting atmosphere. 

Name dropping  
After reading yelp legend Michele's review, Indy and I decided to have dinner here. Thank you Michele! You have excellent taste. 

Ambiance
There is the flag of Afghanistan hanging on one wall, beautiful ethnic art on another, and low tables with pretty cushions. There are also standard height tables and booths. The owner greeted us when we walked in and let us choose where to sit. He was very kind and accommodating. Indigo was treated like a princess. 

Comfort food, middle eastern style
Indy and I chose to sit at a booth. We  ordered sabzi chalow (basmati rice and sautéed spinach), naan (flat bread), sambosas (delightful turnovers filled with potatoes and split peas) and green Persian chai. The Persian green chai was served in a charming floral teapot. We enjoyed everything. Those sambosas were perfection, as was the basmati rice.  

A lesson in communication
Indigo made friends with a sweet little girl. Neither spoke very much. Fortunately, language barriers are never an issue for toddlers. They mostly giggled and smiled as they played which was a beautiful thing to see. 

Kabob House. A place where everyone is welcomed to enjoy a lovely meal that is cooked with love. 

Indigo recommends the fries, high fives and smiling. 

All the stars.", '"You can't have your pudding if you don't eat your meat." Scolds the schoolmaster in Pink Floyd's The Wall. English boarding school cooks must not have been influenced by Afghan cuisine, post British occupation. Because you will have no problem eating your meat that Kabob House lays out before you on wide rectangular plates. The lamb, beef combo comes with a few veggies and a green chutney type dipping sauce that must have cilantro. Lamb is the perfect red meat because sheep are raised in smaller operations than other animals. These lamb kabobs honor the special status of this sacred animal. The spices and grilling deliver a spectacular flavor. No wonder we sacrifice lambs to the gods. The beef is good too but,... Did I mention the lamb? Thanks, Allah for providing!

The side salad is large and lightly dressed. Every leaf was verdant, showing attention to freshness seldom seen even from the nearby Saladman (who should change his name to BagofPreservedSaladMan, by the way.)

Green Persian Tea has cardamom spice which blends nicely with the other fare. Order a second pot for your final course. I'm speaking of the pudding, of course. 

Roger Waters probably would not have been such a sourpuss if he had some Shir Brenge (Brenj?) for dessert. The name literally means rice milk, but it is really Persian rice pudding. No wonder the Iranian Guardians of the Revolution are so zealous. This rice pudding is worthy of fanatic fundamentalism. 

Kabob House reminds me that South Central Asian food is top of the world. Thanks for opening in Boise to  jog my memory of travels long ago. 

Spend an afternoon here (buffet ends at 2:30) and chillax with the afternoon crowd, drink a third pot of tea, and write something about Anglo-Afghan encounters.']

name: Cuenelli's Peruvian Restaurant
categories_raw: Peruvian, Restaurants, Latin American
top_reviews:
['This was not only a great dining experience, but a learning experience also.  The Peruvian cuisine is derived from a multi culture influence from all over the world, using local ingredients (from Peru) while creating a unique taste. The result is a delicious blend of spices flavoring different excellently prepared meats, vegetables, and rice.  

My favorites of the evening were the Pollo, tostones, and the cilantro rice; Mmmm, good!  Everything else was delicious also, but those three dishes stand out in my mind. 

This restaurant is nice inside and out, and conveniently located with plenty of parking. The food came out really fast, and like I mentioned before, all great!  We were served two sauces, and both were outstanding.  The thing that pushed this place over the 4 star mark was the stellar service.  Okay, the food would still get this place a 5 star rating, but great service is the "cherry on top".

The only complaint I can think of is, I wish the menu was bigger.  Not bigger physically, or bigger lettering...  bigger as in more delicious foods to try.', "This place was good, but it wasn't as good as I thought it would be. The Sides were salty. Chicken was very moist , fall off the bone, but the sauces that are very important for dipping, were a disappointing. The yellow one that I'm use to being creamier, was watery, didn't have much flavor, it just tasted salty. The cilantro rice was decent , but like I said, just a tad salty , and even the French Fries were a bit overly salted. Hey! I like salt don't get me wrong, it's a very important ingredient used to bring out the spice in food, but in this case I felt salted to death. 
Another thing that bugged me is that they are very stingy with choice of sides. I didn't want fries so why couldn't I have fried yucca instead? I did order some on the side which raised my bill another 4 bucks. Thumbs down for that. Another thing I would not have chosen is rice , but they don't offer other options with the combo meals like my favorite place Pico Rojo. If you want the good sides, you have to order them separate. Blah. 
I should have never cheated on my Pico Rojo. Oh, I loved my Passion Fruit juice, almost forgot about that. Wrapping it up, I would try this place again if I was in the area and a friend wanted to eat here, but I will not come out of my way because I wasn't very impressed. My lunch was too expensive for sides i didn't want", 'We like to try new eateries.  Last night, I was trying to think of someplace unique to grub down at, and I saw the review for Cuenelli's. We have driven past this spot 5 or 6 times, but never when we  are actually hungry, so I made sure we were hungry tonight. 

We can throw my knowledge of authentic Peruvian recipes out the window. Other than knowing that the potato originated in the geographical region of Inca Empire, I don't know Jack crap about the food, and have never had it. That being said, what I can tell you is that the food was magical. We throw down at a lot of Latin spots, but this was completely different. The flavors were not what you'd get from a Caribbean Latin restaurant at all, and that was a pleasant change.

I had the LOMO SALTADO, which I believe roughly translates to "this dish will make you wanna slap ur momma." (I've added a pic for visual assistance.) This was a sirloin or flank-type steak cut into thin strips and stir fried in a soy-vinegar sauce with tomatoes and onions. It was served on a bed of french fries and with what seemed like an endless supply of white rice. (I thought only Puerto Ricans served dishes on top of fries.)

La Chica had the BISTEC A LO POBRE, which roughly translates to "poor people's steak." This was a palomilla steak served with fries, white rice, black beans, amarillos and topped with a fried egg. This dish is actually pretty common in Latin America. Hell, you can get the American version at IHOP. The whole world probably eats some variation of this dish. Either way, it was really good.

We did order some chicken since that's their staple item, and it was really good. It came with CILANTRO RICE (a-freaking-mazing) and SPICY BEANS. The chicken was moist, tender and cooked to perfection. It came with 2 dipping sauces that accented the flavor of the chicken beautifully.

We will definitely go back.']

name: MD Oriental Market
categories_raw: Ethnic Food, Food, Specialty Food, Grocery
top_reviews:
["Except for making Filipino Lumpia (& requiring the frozen Spring Roll wrappers to make it), I am a novice w/ regard to Oriental Markets, so keep that in mind as you read this review. 

I found this to be a nice market for anyone seeking foods & beverages from approximately 14 countries: Australia; China; Cambodia; Canada; Hong Kong; India; Indonesia; Japan; Korea; Malaysia; Nepal; Philippines; Singapore; & Sri Lanka. There is a very good variety, & it's a relatively large store.  The are four MD markets in the Tampa Bay area.

If it's saute pans, flying pans; pots, woks, steamers; kitchen tools; bowls; cups; chopsticks; an insulated thermos; coffee cups & pots; tea pots & accessories; & rice cookers (etc.) you seek, the aisles are long & well-stocked-- just an extensive variety @ decent prices. SEE PIC.

In the far back of this market is a seafood counter w/ tanks. Some of the tanks could use a good cleaning, but the fishes; lobster; crab; eel; frogs; & other interesting live sea creatures appeared healthy. Two somber-looking staffers were working behind the counter-- see pic. 

There is one long refrigerated case of packaged meat along the back wall; & at least two displays of fresh produce. The produce was BEAUTIFUL-- ALL very fresh. The meat was very good in color & texture. I had fun checking out the pork kidney, pork spleen, & pork liver, as well as the duck tongue. There are also refrigerator cases of packaged fish & other such water creatures. 

Vertical & horizontal floor freezer cases hold MANY food items: a variety of eggs; Tofu; buns; dumplings; spring rolls; desserts; ice-creams; appetizers; veggies; meats; & a gazillion more food items that I found fascinating. (This is a market that makes browsing fun.) There were also many refrigerator cases; I was especially surprised to find many varieties of hotdogs-- SEE PIC. 

Within the walls of this store is an elongated aisle of rice & one of noodles (and a refrigerator case of them to the far left as you enter). There's also an aisle of teas-- SO many teas. Many other food items sat in plastic bags & cartons on selves, including kelp & dried fungi. Almost all the aisles were well-stocked except one. 

The store was not spotless, but it was satisfactory. All food products were price-marked-- shelves were labeled & prices were visible. Not one of the items I handled had an expiration date that had passed. 

I had difficulty locating a staff member to assist me in my trek for frozen Bao Buns (Korean). Once I finally located an older gentleman, he didn't seem to understand me. In fact, he kept pointing to the non-frozen rack of dessert rolls. I was on my own.

Employees spoke Chinese; however, the manager spoke English at the register while discussing payment. I love hearing foreign languages (and expect to hear them in an Oriental Market), but it would have been nice to have at least one employee on the clock who was fluent in English for those of us who unfortunately took five years of French. Additionally, not one of the five employees I encountered was friendly-- not even the female cashier who was at the register as I checked out. Basic eye contact & a smile would have been appreciated. Perhaps there was a language barrier & she was afraid I'd initiate conversation and/or it's a cultural aspect-- who knows. Perhaps I'm too picky-- could be. 

As Oriental markets go, prices here appear lower to me than that of the other markets I've frequented. The checkouts have plexiglass & accept cash, credit & debit cards. Masks are mandatory for customers & employees. 

There is generous parking. Currently, no business shares the lot. Standard metal grocery carts are located in front of the store, & there are plastic carry ones stacked just inside the door. 

I'll definitely return for additional Spring Roll wrappers to make Lumpia, & to grab more Bao Buns (which are located in a floor freezer case near checkout). The colorful, fresh produce will draw me back in as well. Yup, this three-market chain that serves North & South Tampa, Brandon, as well as Pinellas Park, is definitely worth your time.", "So far this is one of the only places in Tampa Bay where I can do some real shopping for Asian items. They don't have everything...at least not all the time. Other Asian groceries focus on a particular culture, so I buy 1 or 2 items and move on to the next store. MD caters to most of Asia including some Indian foods. 

I cook some Pinoy food, but since I grew up in Hawaii I was exposed to a variety/fusion of Asian and Polynesian food. The Filipino store in my neighborhood isn't always enough for me because they don't carry certain Japanese or Korean items for example.

Finding your items is hit or miss. I have a difficult time finding the brand of yaki soba noodles I like to cook with that's usually refrigerated or frozen. On the west coast I can find it everywhere. The first few times I went to MD there was no trace of the noodle, but just yesterday I found a whole freezer door row of them. I love green tea ice cream and the first few times I went to MD there was tons of it in different brands, but yesterday there were only a few containers left. I think MD's inventory control is off.

I do have to say I'm almost positive I can find more Filipino dry and frozen items at MD than my local Filipino grocery....but you can't find fresh bakery items at MD. What they do have is an impressive isle of tea and Asian drink mixes, fresh seafood, a butcher and all the Asian sauces you can think of. They even carry Hawaiian Aloha Maid drinks, but yesterday they were out of my favorite passion orange flavor.

The produce is just okay, but as with most Asian groceries you'll find items at MD that you won't find in Publix. I was so delighted to buy green mangoes that I can eat with bagoong!

So far I've only dealt with pleasant cashiers at MD. 

I do want to visit a few more popular Asian groceries to see what I'll find. I really do like coming to this side of town to shop because there's so much flavor!", "Everything you ever wanted for your cooking experience in Asian foods! We often buy frozen dumplings here and make lasso soup spicy delicious excellent flavor. Be sure to photograph the bags of dumplings that you purchased I've learned that in the past because they were so many different kinds recently tried the chicken and black mushroom very good as well as the seafood dumplings. When I make chicken soup I need chicken feet and this butcher always has The feet. Also have used many different cuts of their fresh beef needed flunking for a soup yes they had that kind of meat.Vegetables spices lots of snacks chips and frozen items as well. Be sure to buy things that have no English writing on them and try them you will be delighted and surprised. Been shopping here for over 15 years ever since I've lived in Tampa I've never been disappointed with the quality of any of the foods I've bought here."]

name: Duckweed Urban Grocery
categories_raw: Grocery, Food, Specialty Food, Bakeries, Beer, Wine & Spirits
top_reviews:
['Why 5 stars? Because I'd be a regular if I lived nearby.

   ---   ---   ---

If you live Downtown, Duckweed is probably your favorite place in the world, by default. Going to the grocery store is probably not very convenient for downtown dwellers, so I'd imagine people that live in places like the Edge, find Duckweed to be an essential part of their life. But the great thing about Duckweed is that not only can you find some of your grocery essentials here, but they are also a specialty food store. It's quite impressive when you consider the size of the place, how many amazing things are packed in here.

The beer selection is superb -\xa0not only bottles, but also taps for growler refills. Other taps include Mother Kombucha and Commune Co coffee. Speaking of alcohol, you can pick up a bottle of wine (or 3) here. There's a sweets counter with fudge, cupcakes, chocolates, etc. There's a deli with hot and cold subs, and a bunch of side dishes that you can pack up and heat up later. I'd imagine quite a few people living downtown aren't exactly the "dinner-cooking" types, and probably survive at this counter.

I feel like the above was a script for an infomercial. That's not what I intended, but I'd definitely be their spokesperson if they asked. Long live Duckweed!', "I love this market! 

We needed some snacks to our accompany our rainy night in, and thankfully, Duckweed Urban Market was only one block away. There is a great selection of items and a wide variety of craft beers. There are several beers on tap, if you would like to drink your beer in the market. They also occasionally do wine tastings! 

There are several meats and cheese, and they will be happy to make you a sandwich. You can eat your meal there or take it with you.

Many of the items they sell here are organic and healthy, so you don't need to feel too too bad for binge eating those chips. 

I look forward to returning to this market and checking out their sandwiches and wine tastings.", 'For me the best thing about Duckweed is all the local food products and brands they offer. 

* Sassy Cucina hummus, feta, and olive tapenade dips
* Cultured non-dairy probiotic cashew cheese dips, hard "cheese" and yogurts
* Toma-Tola tomato veggie juices
* Base Culture granola
* Happy Baker baked goodies
* Urban Canning Company jams and pickle jars
* Chocolatica dessert bombs
* Sunset Salsa
* Fat Cat sauces (Orlando)
* Chill Dill pickle products

They also have a great selection of specialty beverages, ice creams and unusual gourmet foods. There are also local jams.

And the employees are friendly and helpful. The store is a cultural center for downtown with various events and tastings taking place here. There's a deli, juice bar, and even a beer tap. Lots of tasty products to try and specialty in house made beverages and sandwiches etc. 

It's been great to see the biz blossom along with downtown. I was happy when I first got around to checking out the newer Duckweed Market location,l after the store relocated from a small space on a side street. 

It's definitely got a counterculture vibe growing (haha I meant to say going) with lettuces and herbs that used to be literally growing out of the walls, but the owner said people felt bed harvesting the pretty plants. :) They still carry lots of alternative food product offerings (paleo, gluten-free and all that jazz) as well as foods from independent small businesses trying to make special gourmet goods. A local spaghetti sauce company and an Oldsmar based  The Chill Dill pickle line of products.

I enjoyed exploring the unusual brands and they have a nice wine and beer selection. The boutique food brands they offer aren't cheap, but I got to come back and try some of them at a Sustainy event they hosted and I was SUPER impressed.

First of all, who knew there were all these local food companies starting out in Tampa? There's one that makes fresh salsa, there's one that makes terrific hummus and other dips, there's another that makes a terrific tomato juice, and there's one that makes granola and bread (gluten free and with not much suger (hypoglycemic). 

They ahve a nice little cafe and they make delicious fresh juices! They kind of won me over and I'm a fan now. I think it's worth the splurge to know you are buying the good stuff and helping people who are chasing their dreams to make better food that not only a lot tastier but a lot better for you. I hope all of them are successful! It's great to be able to buy local products and be part of a vibrant community. Downtown Tampa has come such a long way and this cool, funky little market is another piece in the puzzle. So go in and ask about all the products that are made locally!!! Tell 'em Nick sent you. They'll reply, "who?"  :)

Parking is free in this area of downtown after 6 p.m. and on weekend FYI!!! And the photo museum in the Cube next to the beer can museum is "suggested donation" and worth checking out too!!!']

name: The Sweet Life Bakeshop
categories_raw: Food, Cupcakes, Desserts, Bakeries
top_reviews:
["Five stars from order to consumption! I must say with so many bakeries I was very indecisive about a bakery for my daughter's birthday party. 

I finally made it down there to place my order. I had a short time frame but they made it happen. The theme was Moana/Hawaiian but I had no requirements; I honestly just wanted them to just be creative. I emailed a couple pictures of ideas and they went from there. Funfetti cupcakes with vanilla butter cream and the most beautiful decorations.

I also brought a mixed dozen for adults which were a hit! So far.. my favorites are the Salted Carmel, sweet and savory and Strawberry, OMG! I would say it's a strawberry pound with strawberry pieces and strawberry icing of course with strawberry pieces! Goodness!!

The customer service from the owner and staff was exceptional! Even made sure we had candles. I absolutely love the Sweet Life Bakery!", "The salted caramel banana pudding is absolutely positively divine! It's really authentic to what I'm used to eating at home or at family gatherings.

I love that all the ingredients in their products are real and not imitation. My banana pudding was filled with lots of love! It was filled with bananas, cookies, whipped cream and overall salted caramel goodness. I also purchased the peach cobbler which was okay, nothing to rave about but their banana pudding is definitely the star of the show.

The sweet life bakeshop offers different varieties of their banana pudding such as strawberry banana, peach cobbler and snickers. The owner Maggie was really nice and personable, she thoroughly explained all her products and kindly answered all the questions that I had as well as provided background info on how she started her business.

Overall I look forward to returning especially since I was sad to see my banana pudding come to and end - sad face emoji!", 'Good cupcakes are true day brighteners. I'm throwing this obvious factoid at you in the middle of the night when hours later I'm thinking about the busy kinda stressful day, and then recalling, "Ooh there was that cupcake though."

I'm kind of insane about the coconut cupcake from Sweet Life; that's all I know. 

It's a light, fluffy, sweet and creamy little cloud of coconut with this little little touch of lemony brightness. I had a real moment. 

I instantly felt like some kinda cuddly creature who lives in the clouds- a Care Bear maybe, just not the surly Grumpy Bear, for once.  

There's a stupid analogy for a super tasty cupcake, for ya.']

name: Soho Wellness & Med Spa
categories_raw: Massage, Skin Care, Beauty & Spas, Hair Removal, Hypnosis/Hypnotherapy, Medical Spas, Laser Hair Removal, Massage Therapy, Day Spas, Health & Medical
categories: ['massage', 'skin care', 'beauty & spas', 'hair removal', 'hypnosis/hypnotherapy', 'medical spas', 'laser hair removal', 'massage therapy', 'day spas', 'health & medical']
top_reviews:
["This is my favorite spot in Tampa!! Wehb looking for a little self-care and me time, this is the place!! 
In a renovated Victorian close to downtown, it's beautifully refurbished, calm and quiet. 
I've been here several times since they've opened and tried out several different services. I love that they have specials weekly for facials and massages! 
When you join their email list they send out monthly specials in addition to Massage Monday and Facial Friday! Everyone is so nice and they have recently implemented a monthly subscription service. It's worth checking out. 
Each service includes time in the infrared sauna. Which in addition to the health benefits is a fantastic way to start or end your session!", 'Beware the $9 Botox 

TL;DR: cheap Botox means they're gonna recommend more than you need to drive up the overall cost. Experienced Botox-ers who can advocate for themselves may be fine. Newbies should seek out somewhere else for their first time. I've had great experiences with Dr. Anne Hermann. 

I went for my 6-month Botox treatment the other day at SOHO Wellness Spa. I opted to try it because it's walking distance to my house and it advertises $9/unit Botox, which is pretty cheap. It is my opinion that they do this to get you in the door and then oversell the amount of units you need. 

My experience with Cathy was more reminiscent of a used car salesman than a spa employee. She was asking me questions but wasn't listening to my answers as she was tending to other tasks simultaneously. She started to tell me the difference between a muscle relaxer like Botox and fillers on three separate occasions despite me telling her I've had both before so I had an idea. When she asked what I was there for I said I wanted to touch up my forehead. She asked if I was interested in treating my crows feet. I didn't say yes or no - instead I mentioned my usual Botox doctor said she wouldn't treat my crows feet because of where they are located (idk the specifics but if a doctor turns down money and says she wouldn't do it I'll listen to her). Cathy marked up my face and forehead and recommended 54 units to "get me my desired results". For perspective I usually get 12-15 units in my forehead. I also was unsure what she meant when she mentioned my desired results as that wasn't something we ever discussed. I told her I was only interested in my 12-15 units in my forehead and not any of her other recommendations. It's my opinion at this point she become annoyed. She said that that few units wouldn't get me my (again) "desired results". I think she interpreted it as questioning her expertise? It's at this point she started doing some math out loud and saying "we can take this off and do this and that and it would cost this" but she was still including treatments of areas I had by now explicitly stated I didn't want treatment on. I said I was no longer interested and would just go back to my usual doctor because I wasn't comfortable with her sticking poison into my face if she couldn't listen to what I was saying. 

Perhaps I lucked into finding a great doctor for my first few Botox treatments. Maybe this is the usual level of service at other spas who offer Botox and fillers by a nurse. Maybe Cathy was having an off Monday. I'm not sure. I can state matter of factly that I didn't feel like Cathy was 100% focused on me as a client and luckily I had several opportunities to recognize that she wasn't listening to what I was saying prior to letting her inject my face.', "This spa is such a little retreat, it takes you out of the hustle and bustle of your everyday life and lets you get away and relax. Very clean and lovely decor inside, it is welcoming and so is the staff!

My 5* is both for the hypnosis with Debbie and the facial equally!
The hypnosis I have done before back a while ago for stress and it helped, I was looking for someone in whom I connected with and knew how to help digestive issues with hypnosis. DEBBIE IS YOUR WOMAN with anything but especially crohns/digestion. She is very intuitive and just starts talking to you. She tries to understand where you're coming from and how to help you. I have very severe crohns and within just 2 sessions I'm already starting to feel the crohns under control a little due to my subconscious. Do not hesitate to come to Debbie she a phenomenal and can help anyone!

The facial I got was the European facial with microdermabrasion. It was so fabulous and relaxing I just melting into the bed and relaxed. I can not say anything negative about it because it was phenomenal. My face looks so clean and glory afterwards that I am in total shock!"]

name: Tiny Tap Tavern
categories_raw: Dive Bars, Nightlife, Bars
top_reviews:
["I know a number of super fans dig the dollar, room temp Bud Lights and the ne'er-change atmosphere of an archaic (if not absolutely true to form) dive bar like Tiny Tap.

But you are playing lung roulette if you happen in on a night where everybody and their mother is ripping Marlboro unfiltereds while commenting on Olympic curling. See, smoking is still fine here, and when the space is Tiny, you're in the cloud.

That was this night. Cheap pool, cheap drinks, and if you're accustomed to smoke-free bars, a cheap SHS headache.", "The dive bar of dive bars in Tampa. This has been a bar for almost 70 years and is one of the oldest continuously operated bars still running in Tampa. This is a Tampa hallmark and must-see if you are into dive bars. You might want to avoid the men's bathroom, but that's part of what gives it character. The pool tables haven't moved in decades as evidenced by the worn linoleum. 

And... they finally take credit cards!!!! So come get a PBR tall boy and feel like a local!", "How does a dive bar get 4 stars?  It reeks of cigarettes, is dirty, only accepts cash, and is usually dead. Not sure why people are scoring this so high but there are other bars in Soho that offer 2.50 beers and even for less that aren't complete dumps like this and accept credit card. Macdintons has $1 beers on Thursday's and isn't a complete dump. A dive bar at best should not smell should still be clean and could still be cheaper than this"]

name: Wasabi Sushi
categories_raw: Japanese, Nightlife, Bars, Sushi Bars, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["First time - i orders stuffed mushrooms with spicy tuna and crab meat, salmon skin hand roll, and salmon hand roll for my lunch. They only had one lunch combo for $13. So ordered a few thins off the menu. 

Just to note - I'm pretty picky about seaweed when it comes down to rolls as I grew up with many different types of seaweed. So here are my thoughts on what I had:

- Stuffed mushroom - four pieces of deep fried mushrooms. The first bite was divine. Just enough spicy tuna and the crab meat with the perfect crispness of fried light Japanese breading. By the fourth one though, I felt like it had a bit too much sauce. Just one piece will be plenty so I would order it again only if I am with others to share the dish with. 

- Salmon Skin - not too much rice and right amount of salmon skin and cucumbers. One thing though, salmon skin strips were a bit too skinny for me - I like to taste more meat for this dish. And the seaweed...please refer to the next item. :)

- Salmon Hand Roll - Perfect amount of tasty salmon and not too much rice. But the seaweed was NOT perfectly crispy!! It was a bit on the stale side. If it wasn't for the seaweed, this hand roll could've been one of the best ones I've had in town.", "Been here on weekend and weekday.

FOOD:
Honestly, I go here for their katsu curry. I've never tried the other menu before but this is where I get my katsu curry fix! The menu looks pretty varied and I would like to try the other food on my next visit. 

PLACE/AMBIANCE:
Saturday lunch for 2 people-quiet (3-4 other tables). Tuesday lunch for myself-dead quiet (1 other table). 'm not sure whether it's because of the location or people just don't know this place exists. I actually like the fact that it's such a quiet place to enjoy my food. But I want this place to stay in business so check them out! The ambiance/decor is nice and unique. Love the lanterns! And they have big parking lot too.

SERVICE:
Since on a few occasions I've been here it was always quiet, the service was always great. The server was very attentive. But I can't attest to service on busy days/nights!", "We recently relocated from that state that everyone in Idaho hates (insert a sorry emoji with a peace sign) and have tried a few different sushi places. This place has become one of our favorites. They have fantastic food, great location, and although they are sometimes a little understaffed, they still manage to get those orders out. I know staffing is difficult right now and we appreciate the people who work extra hard to make up for it. Try this place, you won't be disappointed."]

name: The Screamery HandCrafted Ice Cream
categories_raw: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food
top_reviews:
['Yummyyyyy! 

For the first time ever I had to wait in line and had a chance to actually look at the menu. I've been fortunate that I usually get to order immediately and, because my eyes are bigger than my stomach, I get the first thing that looks amazing, which is everything here! 

I found out that I don't have to get a massive scoop, I can order a kids scoop which is probably a more appropriate serving for an adult. I also learned they serve "nachos" which are waffle cone pieces surrounding a massive scoop of ice cream topped with hot fudge. One of these days I'm going to order the farmhouse - 8 scoops and unlimited toppings!

I recommend the honeycomb, cookies and cream, and I recently tried rough seas (candied nuts with honey swirl and pretzel). I think some flavors are only available for a limited time because I didn't see my beloved cowboy cookie. 

The only thing I can (barely) complain about is that their handmade waffle cones are thin and fragile. They're delicious and sugary but the tips are not tightened so ice cream always inevitably drips out. I recommend the cone by all means, but ask for a bowl to hold it!', 'The Screamery Handcrafted Ice Cream has me ready to shout from the rooftops in adoration. I'm John Cusack in "Say Anything" for this ice cream. ::Cue the Peter Gabriel:: Using natural ingredients and milk from grass-fed cows, this homemade ice cream is hands-down some of the best I have E-V-E-R had! I can't help but compare any honey flavor to the Sweet Cream Honeycomb. A sweet cream base with swirls honeycomb pieces. I will eat a whole pint in one sitting and I don't care. Sorry, thighs! Easily in my top 5 favorites ice creams EVER from ANYWHERE! Grab yourself a pint but be prepared for the overwhelming desire to serenade a dessert by holding a radio over your head by the time you get down to your last spoonful.', 'I AM IN LOOOOOOOOOOOVVVVE!

Was finally at this end of town and stopped in. First tested Marshmallow Mash-Up - "marshmallow infused base mixed with homemade M&M rice crispy treats." WHOAAA! Then I tried Sweet Cream Honey Comb - "sweet cream ice cream with handmade honeycomb pieces." ARE YOU KIDDING ME???!!!!! Then for baseline, I just had to try their "regular" (nothing's "regular" here) Chocolate - "two blends of Ghirardelli chocolate for the perfect chocolate flavor." *GASP* EYES ROLLING IN THE BACK OF MY HEAD

I get two scoops. (Wish I could have gotten four or five.) Sweet Cream Honey Comb and Chocolate.

As I take a spoonful heading out the door, I exclaim in a semi-loud voice, "This is INCREDIBLE!"

Yeah, that good.']

name: Lima Rotisserie Chicken And Peruvian Cuisine
categories_raw: Soup, Seafood, Peruvian, Chicken Shop, Latin American, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['It is about 3.5 stars. Not 4 stars yet. This place open before the pandemic business close. Now it open back up for customers is a sign of the returning to business. It is considered a new restaurant near Cross Creek. The previous restaurant close down due to lack of customers traffic. I hope they do well. 

I got the full chicken with tax is about above average price grilled chicken around here. If they they can adjust a little bit for their price, may be can be more compete with neighborhood rotisserie chicken. I would said they have good marinated sauce into the meat and bone of the chicken. This I give them an A. 

If you order takeout, you may want to call ahead. Because they may not be ready for you on time. The reception need to improve in speed for dealing with customers order. Seem like need improvement.', "Great service with a smile at Lima in New Tampa. I was excited to have a Peruvian place in this area.

My husband ordered the half chicken along with two sides which he chose tostones and yuca. He said everything was tasty. He didn't even let me taste it so I guess he liked it.

I ordered an order of ceviche and a Lomo saltado sandwich with yuca. I was impressed by both.

Our server was exceptional. Super sweet and helpful. So glad we have a Peruvian option in the area. Will be back sometime to try their parihuela(seafood soup), and have my husband try their Lomo Saltado. It was so good and even as a sandwich version.", 'It has been quite a while since I've had Peruvian food. It's nice to see there's an option for it in New Tampa now. When "Rotisserie Chicken" is listed right under the name on the website you'd certainly hope it was quite good. That definitely was the case with Lima. The chicken was very moist and I especially liked the herbs that were added to the chicken. For ten bucks you can get a quarter chicken with two side dishes (with a nice portion size). I'm looking forward to trying some of their other dishes over time.']

name: El Merendero
categories_raw: Mexican, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Wow. The things you notice when you are having a poor dining experience.  

So, I have been here a couple of times now. However, I hadn't been back for a while because I found during my previous visits that the service and the food were both inconsistent. 

On this visit, I noticed much of the same that concerned me before: an absentee server, stale chips and watered down salsa. I imagine that the restaurant caters to many of those people who are merely looking for a cultural experience. That's cool. Sometimes you need a starter restaurant when you're trying to break in to a particular type of cuisine.

Still, there are couple of things that I like about the restaurant. In particular, they have great specials -- especially their daily lunch specials, which include seafood specials as well. I also love the natural light. I find that this place is great for lunch, and maybe dinner.

Now, back to this current visit and the reason why I'm giving this restaurant an abysmal number of stars.

There was old salsa caked to the side of the bowl, "sandy" seats and drive by waiter service. My server even asked me from a table over if I was ready to order. 

I went with a half-dozen oysters. I told her that I would keep the menu because I wanted to order something later. The oysters were meaty but served improperly -- stacked. I have never experienced this before and it ruined the oysters. Not only did the leftover residue on the bottom of each stacked shell muddle the oyster beneath, the liquor from most of them drained out because the were haphazardly placed. What a bummer.

Finally, I just decided to call it a day. But I couldn't find my server anywhere. So I just decided to leave my cash on the table and leave. 

On the way out, I told the busser that my cash was on the table and thanked him. As I was backing out of the parking lot I heard someone yelling at me, "you didn't pay me!" Ahhh! There's my server, yelling at me (read: microaggressions). I let her know that the money was on the table, at which point she gave me the most embarrassed look in human history and apologized. 

Well, that experience does it for me. I will be taking my hard-earned money to other wonderful Tucson establishments.', "Wow - I've spent years trying to find Chile Rellenos like I grew up with so I could take my Mom there...sadly, she passed over four years before I found El Merendero.

This will be my Mother's Day tribute review:

Mom - you would've loved the Chile Rellenos here - light, fluffy, tender, tasted fantastic.  Just like we used to get 30+ years ago.  Wish I could've taken you here.  I miss you (probably why I'm still always on the hunt for the best Chile Rellenos - I think I found them, but I'll keep trying, just in case).

The beans were fantastic, and the tortilla - wow!

This is some good chow!!!", "Omg omg omg... I do NOT know where to begin with words. This place is more than greatness lol everything felt very authentic and VERY delicious!!.. we were literally tripping bc how delicious everything was. My man started with his chicken quesadillas and was speechless lol! Like literally, and I had a michelada drink which was sooo yummy!! And huge!! (FYI not everyone can make a Michelada correctly esp mainstream places back at home). He also ordered the carne tacos and tortilla soup and he said it's a 100/100 lol.. I had the veggie chimichanga w/rice and beans .. everything was SO DELICIOUS!! Most definitely a place we will be returning to and I'm sure they'll start remembering us by name hahaha"]

name: So Korean Grill
categories_raw: Korean, Barbeque, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Sooo much fooood! 

Cool and clean interior; spacious and spaced out booths; service was fine.

The food:
They offer different rice and noodle dishes, soup, à la carte bbq items as well as different "sets" with a variety of bbq items and veg, that serve different numbers of people. If you go there really hungry, perhaps your party can finish the set designated for the number of persons in your party.

Our set included different cuts of pork, including pork belly, sausage, different cuts of beef, chicken, shrimp, squid; a variety of kimchi; vegetables; salad and miso soup. It was a LOT of food.

For the most part, all of the proteins were tender and quite tasty. The kimchis were all excellent. The miso soup was unexpectedly good. The side salad was just filler. 

Staff set the grill temperature and assisted with cooking, as needed. When we turned up the grill to hasten cooking, a staff member came by and flipped it back to her setting. Lol. 

The beauty of this place is that there is plenty of time for good conversation and noshing on the side dishes, while the food is grilling.

There is a return in my future, hopefully with a lot of greens in the interim to prepare for all of that protein.

4.5 stars', "Randomly stopped in once Yelp told me this place was new in my area.   I was solo so I decided on the pork rib and beef sirloin.  Being keto I skipped all of the beginning accoutrements aside from the salad and soup.

The beef was solid but my god the pork ribs were AMAZING.  Those two items alone were enough to fill my belly despite my avoiding rice and every other carb on their menu. Servers were super nice and since it's 5 minutes from my house I'll definitely be back. 

My meal came up to $24 before tip (I had two diet Pepsi's.", "My boyfriend and I are from Boston and we came to Philly to visit family. We were craving Korean and decided to try this place out since it was new and had great reviews. 

The cold noodles here are phenomenal; very authentic and the best we've had in the east coast of U.S. The bbq meats are really good cuts and portions are actually a lot, which is never a bad thing! The ban chan (side dishes) are freshly made and should be eaten. Their dipping sauce goes so well with the meats.

The ambiance is good for a couple or a group of friends or family. It's very clean and nicely decorated inside. They play kpop music but its not too loud and actually is great background music.

Lastly, the service is really stellar. Their staff is attentive and came to help grill the meat, as well as checked in to make sure we were happy with everything. They also gave complimentary warm dipping sauce, baked egg, and  watermelon as dessert. 

Overall, we had such a great food experience here that we are eager to come back again when we are in Philly. We highly recommend foodies and Korean food lovers to check this place out!"]

name: The Quarter Stitch
categories_raw: Arts & Crafts, Knitting Supplies, Shopping
top_reviews:
['The way I feel about art stores is the same way I feel about stores overflowing with whimsical needlepoint canvases, colorful threads, and the sort of people who gravitate to this stuff.  That is:  they put me in my happy place.  

I'm not the fastest needleworker out there and going into a shop like The Quarter Stitch forces me to exercise restraint.  I can look around my home and find two needlepoint canvasses in progress and one completed but not yet blocked.  So, as the enablers encouraged me to get a canvas here "as a souvenir of our vacation" the realist in me asked about their web site and took a bunch of photos.  

The Quarter Stitch has some really great, vibrant canvasses, ones I've not seen elsewhere.  Staff explained that their web site isn't all that but that they're very good at picking out something you'll like, just call them and talk about what you like or share photos and they'll enable you quite successfully.  

The store also features, equally, the stuff that knitters and crochet-people need.  

Whether or not you do needlepoint, if you walk into The Quarter Stitch during your time in NOLA you might just find yourself picking up a new hobby.  If that's already a hobby?  Don't miss this fun and inspiring shop.', "The Quarter Stitch is an urban yarn store. That means it is in a city, where rent is expensive and space is at a premium. So yes, sometimes things are stacked everywhere for hapless patrons to knock over. And sometimes, the store can't stock everything we want, children. 

As an urban yarn store veteran (shout-out to Rosie's Yarn Cellar and Loop in Philly!), I would give the Quarter Stitch two thumbs up for managing their space. They have really deep stock for such a small store, and I'm always impressed with the cross-section of yarns they bring in. 

The prices, for your standard urban yarn store, are about average. 
(Dear yarnies from out-of-town: Everything in New Orleans is expensive. Even the yarn.) 
I don't feel like I'm paying through the teeth, and I typically get what I want for the project I came in to enhance. 

I know jack-if-all about the needlepoint stuff, but apparently it's quite good. 

The wife falls over drooling with dinner-plate eyes every time we come here because it is a visual treat. There are tin things hanging from the ceiling, ribbons and bows all around, needlepoints and yarn and fiber and colors just exploding. Basically, New Orleans in yarn store form. Hot damn. 

Accessibility notes: Store is up one step, and the doorway is narrow. Very little space for mobility devices to maneuver. No braille signage. The store is small so it can get loud if it's crowded. Staff are very helpful for patrons needing assistance.", "Today I realized I'm a yarn snob. The usual place I go to for yarn was closed. I schlepped over to Michael's and looking over what passes for yarn there made me depressed.. I really needed a yarn fix that didn't involve 100% acrylic (ha!) Then I remembered:

The Quarter Stitch!

I hadn't been there in about two years (parking in the Quarter is the worst, etc) but I walked in and was greeted with fabulous yarn and smiles all around. I explained to the ladies there what I was trying to achieve and the type of yarn I was looking for and they were soooo helpful! They didn't even seem to mind when I, obviously not a seasoned knitter, asked a lot of questions. 

I've noticed other reviews saying how expensive the yarn is here and it is pretty pricey but 1) It *is* in the French Quarter so expect higher prices and 2) Its worth it, especially if you are making a gift or smaller piece. Lets face it, do we really want to give someone a knit piece made of Red Heart super savor??

I may have to give up the other place I've been frequenting and stick to the Quarter Stitch from now on."]

name: Hieux Boil Seafood House
categories_raw: Caribbean, Restaurants, Seafood, Cajun/Creole
top_reviews:
["So after passing this restaurant for several months we decided to try this place for dinner. 
The waitstaff checked for our vaccine cards/72hrs negative test. We still chose to be seated outside because it was a nice day. The inside was relatively empty. 
We ordered the Cajun Shack with garlic butter. The garlic wasn't over baring and the seafood was cooked great. The potato's were tasty but the corn was a bit gummy. I would've gotten more potatoes if I'd known the corn wouldn't have been good. The shrimp were my favorite. 
We also ordered a shrimp platter and a catfish platter. The shrimp were fried good along with the catfish. The corn nuggets tasted really good. The fries were good, we also got a crab cake which was more cake instead of crab. The portion size of the meals were decent. 
All in all it was a experience, I probably wouldn't come back nor recommend this place. Nothing really stood out or made me feel like I'd like to come back to eat.", 'Tried this place yesterday with an order to go consisting of 5lbs of plain crawfish (plain at Hieux is tradition boil) medium spice, 2lbs of shrimp with the Cajun sauce (it is a butter based sauce with traditional seasonings) and bang bang shrimp.

The bang bang shrimp appetizer was good.  Pro tip: toss it in the sauce they give you on the side (because it is to go) and it is so excellent!

We loved the crawfish - they were clean, flavorful and the medium heat was just right for our crowd.  We were underwhelmed by the side order of potatoes, mushrooms and corn.  We received two potatoes.  For $3.75 that's not right.  In fact, it's straight up b.s. to get two creamer potatoes for $3.75.  If we got a 1/4 of mushrooms I would be surprised.  So the message there is skip the sides.

The real star of the table was the two pounds of shrimp in the Cajun sauce.  We bought head on shrimp and they were a little overcooked but we think that was due to transport and sitting in the container, as opposed to being served at the restaurant.  The shrimp were beautiful, the sauce was succulent and had a nice heat that sneaks up on you.  We ordered medium and I have to tell you - we had four left over shrimp (we had other take out too) and we peeled them and left them in the sauce to eat the next day.  Holy Batman the heat was off the hook the next day but definitely delicious.

So, Hieux puts everything in a butter based sauce unless you ask for plain.  They were excellent about explaining it after I placed my order online - but the website would truly benefit from an explanation of the sauces, their flavor profiles, and how to order if you want it "traditional" as opposed to their way.

We will definitely go back and look forward to trying other things on their menu', 'So, I've been wanting to try this spot for the last few weeks. I finally got to try it tonight with a friend of mine. We arrived around 7pm and it was PACKED. We ended up sitting at the bar because the hostess told us it was full service. After looking at the menu for a quite some time I decided I wanted to try the crawfish. The bartender tells me "oh, we are out of crawfish. Unless you get a bucket." That makes zero sense to me because either you have crawfish or you don't. I feel like she was trying to force me to get a more expensive option. So, I decided to just get a "bucket" because that was the only reason I came here was to try the seafood. According to the menu, the bucket contained 1 lb of crawfish, 1 lb of shrimp, 2 potatoes, corn, and andouille sausage. When the bucket was brought to me there was no corn. I asked the bartender if the corn was on the way and she said "oh, we are out corn. So they gave you extra potatoes." WHAT?!?! Why wasn't I told before I ordered the bucket that they were out of corn and why was a substitution picked for me without giving me any options? This irked me because I didn't even want the bucket to begin with. (Also, it comes on a platter and not even a bucket.) As we are sitting at the bar another server comes out and starts screaming that they were out of crawfish, corn, mushrooms, and only had a few orders of crabs left. Granted there is a restaurant FULL of people and several people on the waitlist on a Saturday night. Ok.......

I ordered the Cajun flavor, extra hot. It didn't even make my nose run. Disappointing. They weren't bad but I just don't see the hype especially for $9/lb. I also ordered a dozen chargrilled oysters. They had potential but there was literally no butter so each oyster was stuck to the shell. I had to scrape them out with the fork. 

Ordered 2 frozen cocktails and didn't even feel a buzz. Sigh. I can check this place off my list of places to try now but I highly doubt I'll ever go back! We finished our food and got a to go box packed up and waited for the check. 20 minutes passed and the bartender just kept walking past us without asking if we were ready for the check. I truly don't recommend.']

name: Prohibition Taproom
categories_raw: American (Traditional), Bars, Nightlife, Restaurants, Beer Bar, Gastropubs, Breakfast & Brunch, Tapas/Small Plates
top_reviews:
['Prohibition Taproom has got personality. Their huge "BAR" sign calls to you, even visible from Spring Garden. This faux-speakeasy's interior fits their name, with a large wooden bar dominating the space, lit by beautiful hanging Victorian bulbs. There's room for a crowd, even in the bathrooms[1]. My only gripe is that the exterior is brighter than it ought to be.

Prohibition opened earlier this month, and as young as they are, the staff was anything but. Brendan, our bartender and a trained chef, kept us happy, making us shots and taking food orders (they have a full menu). We took down gin ($7/shot), Jameson, and pineapple rum shooters[2]. Would have drank more, but conceded, with great lugubriousness, that it was a Monday night.

Stop into Prohibition[3], and tell 'em I sent you[4]!

[1] Their non-unisex bathrooms can fit two comfortably, though most will prefer to go solo. Don't ask how I know.
[2] I asked for a light, random shot, and was pleasantly surprised with the shooters.
[3] Do this!
[4] Don't do that!', 'Establishments like Prohibition Taproom are one of the many reasons why I love Philly. I've been here a few times , and with every visit it has been nothing short of awesome. What is even better is that the owner of Prohibition is also the owner of Bufad and Cafe Lift. This is what I like to call the "Trifecta", with damn good pizza, a great bar, and another great brunch location all on the same block.
 
My most recent visit at PTR  was after a Yelp Event at Punchline Comedy Club, where we turned this into a UYE. That is an "Unofficial Yelp Event" for those who may not know what "UYE" stands for.  You know after any event, that kind of party just can't end there, you have to keep that vibe going. PT had a good crowd in there when we came in there, and what made it better was we scored some great seats at the bar.  

The last time I was here this place was blowing up, as it should be with the great crafts they have on tap. As for mixed drinks, those well blended cocktails are also something that should not be ignored. In all which ever route you take , you'd definitely be satisfied in wetting your whistle. 

Their menu is also something that needs your attention if you feel you need to get some grub action. The menu does change every once in a while so if you had something here before it might not be back in their rotation.  The options are endless, plus they even do brunch here,  and not to mention their donuts they make.  

Little food for thought about their menu. (pun intended)

Deviled Eggs~ Yes its an egg, yes a lot of places serve them,  but these little morsels had chunks of pork belly on them. Enough said. 
 
Braised Lamb Grilled Cheese~ Shh you read that right, and yes that picture does do it justice. If you could only imagine how that bad boy tasted, it literally melted in my mouth with every bite. The way they had the goat cheese, with pickled eggplant intertwined with the lamb had me moaning with delight. Ask Tara G. as she was cursing at me as she also enjoyed several bites. 

Manhattan Bourbon Glazed Donuts~ Hot and fresh, that was glazed which was drizzled in bourbon with a chocolate sauce that will separate the fools from the diabetics!  

What better way to enjoy your time from the service that was on point ,down the choice of cocktail. In all Prohibition Taproom is a great spot to visit from their happy hour, or to just go in and chill with that good vibe atmosphere.', "Nice find just north of City Hall. It had a decent selection of beers and wine. The atmosphere was fun but subdued. Nothing too hyped up but if you're looking for a good selection of drinks in a spot to hole away into and get away from the more crowded areas of the city - it's a great option! 

Being away from the main action of the city has its advantages. There was ample street parking just steps away which was handy given how windy it was outside! 

The proximity to City Hall is also nice since the Winter Garden was in place at Dilworth Park. If the weather was nicer we would've walked there to check out the different shops. Great location since there is always something seasonal set up at Dilworth Park. 

Would recommend for a night cap or happy hour for sure!"]

name: Tucson Massage Company
categories_raw: Massage Therapy, Health & Medical, Day Spas, Massage, Beauty & Spas
top_reviews:
["I went for a 90 minute deep tissue with Torin today because I have herniated disks and have been in a lot of pain. I drew on the chart the areas of my body that have been bothering me, and Torin worked on those areas with careful attention which was wonderful for me because I feel relief. Torin was professional, compassionate, and gave me some great info when I left. I'm really glad I followed the reviews I found on the internet, and if someone is reading this who is especially sore, see Torin to get some healing. (Sidenote: Torin rubbed my foot in such a way that made my brain go into a fourth dimension. I did not know a foot was capable of feeling that good. Torin you understand bodies. LoL)", "Had a great massage here the day after New Years which was what was needed. I was a bit skeptical at first, but what the heck, I've been to some really shady massage places in the past and this one, despite its location, looked fairly legit.

The experience was awesome! We had a 90 min couple massage booked and the staff listened to everything we had to say and executed flawlessly. I felt like i was on cloud 9 the entire day and didn't want to do anything else but relax and be quite.

Awesome place, highly recommend.", 'Charity is amazing!  Excellent massages.   I love that you can easily book and pay, if you want to, on their website.  Their new location is very convenient.   Super serene.  Good parking.  I highly recommend.']

name: Cafe Square One
categories_raw: Food, Coffee & Tea, Cafes, Salad, Sandwiches, Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
top_reviews:
["I haven't been hitting too many new businesses lately so I'm making sure to give extra love to the ones that have been getting me through this year. Every single time I'm in Old City, I figure out a way to swing by Cafe Square One. Their salads are still just as awesome as they were when I first tried them a couple years ago, and the employees are always friendly and welcoming. 

One day I'll deviate from my beloved southwest salad to try one of the wraps or sandwiches... one day.", "I discovered Cafe Square One when I was in the neighborhood for a meeting and ran a Yelp search for salads. I was surprised that I had never heard of the place since it has great reviews and a lot of them! The cafe is small and has a few tables, but I've taken my orders to go. 

I've stopped by on two different occasions and have been very satisfied with my experiences. The menu is pretty comprehensive -\xa0lots of sandwich, wrap and salad options. I've had their chicken caesar and southwest salads and both were great. Fresh ingredients, delicious dressings and super tender chicken (and lots of it!). 

The employees are so friendly! And I haven't had to wait more than a few minutes on each visit. I will definitely return whenever I'm in the area and need a quick, healthy lunch!", "It's high time I updated my review of Cafe Square One! They've been open since late 2014, I'd say. They went through a couple phases for restaurant layout and menu items, but it seems they've landed on the perfect combination. I love their wraps, paninis, and smoothies. My favs are the Chicken Pesto Panini, Turkey Hummus Wrap, and Oriental Chicken Wrap. They serve breakfast and lunch and are one of the few Old City restaurants actually open on Mondays. 

Service is super friendly. Take out orders take between 10-20 minutes during lunch, so it's best to order ahead. The seating is cute but kinda tight when the line forms. Everyone loves this lil gem!"]

name: Bai Wei
categories_raw: Chinese, Food, Bubble Tea, Restaurants, Dim Sum, Szechuan
top_reviews:
["Bai Wei is the successor to Sakura Mandarin at the corner of 11th & Race in Chinatown, Philadelphia. Same ownership. Renovated and expanded dining room. Where the focus was formerly on excellent xiao long bao and other Shanghai delights, it has now expanded to include a strong taste of Szechuan and Hunan pepper and black bean hot dishes. I quite liked the old house, and returned late last week to see what the newly imagined kitchen held in store.

From our exploration of the two dishes we ordered, it would appear Bai Wei (many tastes) has it going on.  Their takes on crispy spicy chicken and cumin lamb dry pot were excellent. The chicken was loaded with red Szechuan peppers and small morsels of deep fried chicken. Enough to give our tongues a sincere capcesin workout and loosen our sinuses; stopping just short of bringing on tears. Completely addictive. The lamb, tender in a mix of chopped onion and more peppers and overwhelmed with a dusting of coarse cumin seed. Delicious. About as good as the best Szechuanese bowls I've found in the USA.

The only downside was the continuing attempt by the staff at up selling our order. We were repeatedly asked about appetizers, drinks and rice - even after we declined multiple times. Sure, they want more money per customer, but it became excessive and annoying. 

But for that weird dynamic, we thoroughly enjoyed the meal. Just train your servers to accept the customer's wishes and you have a winner.", "We've passed Bai Wei/Sakura hundreds of times and never wanted to check it out. This last weekend though, we decided to give it a shot.

Sadly, our preconceived notions of the restaurant was confirmed. Subpar food at high prices. We ordered the marinated duck, the House Special Spicy bowl and the mushroom dry pot.

The food was bland and the portions were on the smaller side for the prices they were charging. I was also annoyed that there were no variety in the mushroom dry pot. There was only one type of mushrooms stir fried, and not the quality kind.

On top of that, you have to pay for rice?!?!? Never have I eaten in a restaurant in Chinatown where I have to pay for rice. Rice is  FREE when you buy dinner from a restaurant!

Do yourself a favor and skip this place. There are plenty of better options not far from Bai Wei.", 'We were in Chinatown on a cold December Friday night. There must have been a convention going on as everywhere was packed. We tried Bonchon but that was over an hour wait for a table. When we walked by Bai Wei, the line was not too long and we were told a 10 minute wait for a table. No brainer.

Bai Wei was true to its word and we were seated in less then 10 minutes. The new interior is sophisticated and hip and seems to be the way Chinatown is moving these days. We started with soup dumplings and we all agreed these were very good and up there with DSG and Shanghai#1. We had the Dan Dan noodles and a fish stew dish also. Both were tasty and brought the heat. The fish was was very tender and deboned. The wait staff was both friendly and attentive.

I liked Bai Wei, it is another option for us in Chinatown. The problem is there are so many new and cool restaurants popping up down here, it may be difficult to get back soon.

3.75 Yelp stars']

name: Biscardi Vision
categories_raw: Health & Medical, Optometrists
top_reviews:
['I needed cybernetic enhancements and searched Yelp for an eye doctor.  

While sitting in Dr. Biscardi's office, I wondered how awesome life would be if my eye upgrades would give me the powers desired - seeing into the future, and a terminator eye that gives me random data and scrolls 2D images of whatever I'm looking at (plus the sound effects upgrade directly wired to my ear)

First, she had me read these spaced-out capital letters.  Thought this was a little unusual since A) I should soon not have to read because my right future-seeing eye will soon know what was written and B) a terminator eye would not care for such things.  My left eye really struggled to read the tiny print.  At this point I reminded her that once my left eye is a terminator eye, I want the zoom feature to be automatic, none of this squinting crap.  

Dr. Biscardi placed numbing drops in each eye as well as a dilating solution. I figured this was routine before undergoing these sort of changes.  We chatted for a few minutes... I suppose to let the solutions take affect.  

"Which eye will be first?" I asked.
"I'll be looking at both at the same time," she answered.

Wow!  Thank you, future technology!

The lights were dimmed; my vision was squirrley at best, but who cares... these eyes are going soon anyway.  A bright light was flashed in each eye - not sure if she was taking genetic code to program my new cybernetic implants or she just wanted to see how green my eyes really are.  I didn't ask.

"So, what's the verdict?  How soon can I be enjoying my enhancements," I asked.
"You have a slight astigmatism and dry eye.  You don't need glasses."
"So, that's it?" I asked.  I was so pissed at this point.
"Yep, you're eyes look good.  I can check you again in a year," she offered with a smile. 

WHAT!  I felt like I was duped.  I hear of these people getting synthetic limbs that learn movement and I can't get a damn terminator eye!  

"You're all set, have a great day!" her secretary said.

The hell I am!  I get to wander my way through the city with blurry dilated eyes and no enhancements!  Better luck next year I suppose.', "I called in to schedule an appointment as a new patient which was initially very helpful. I realized that I had a couple of additional questions about the office location so I called back. The second person I spoke to was very rude and when I asked questions she told me she was not a front desk person and does not normally answer the phones. At this point I decided to cancel my appointment and when I requested to do so, the person on the phone hung up in my face. I called back to make sure the appointment had been cancelled and it was thankfully. I can't imagine supporting businesses who treat you this way before you are even a patient. methinks not.", "When it comes to healthcare, I am super picky and exponentially more stringent in my reviews than I am with a restaurant.  If you have a bad meal no big deal; if you have a bad doctor it is your health at stake.  

I found Dr Biscardi via yelp, which made me slightly nervous as this is not a place I usually come to for healthcare recommendations.  But I am so glad I found her. Dr Biscardi is extremely thorough.  She really takes her time.  I have been to see her twice for regular check ups and both times she spent at least a half hour with me.  She ran lots of tests, explained what they were, why she was running them, and what the results were.  I feel that she wants to help me see well but she is also looking out for my long term eye care and health.  She is smart and able to answer my questions - and I ask a ton of questions.  

I really like her personality.  I never felt pressured to buy anything.  She truly wants to collaborate with me in making sure I have the best contacts and eye glasses possible.  I feel comfortable telling her my concerns.

They have a wide variety of frame styles with something to suit everyone, though not a lot of depth to the selection within a certain style.   They are affordable compared to fancy pants boutiques.  The woman who works in the frames department knows her stuff.  She doesn't try to push something on you.  Instead she takes her time to make sure the frame actually fits your face and the spacing of your eyes.  I have been to every boutique frame store in center city and nobody has done that with me at any of those store.  This woman (sorry I forget her name) will tell you if the glasses are not a good fit for you.  They also don't try to rip you off by up selling features or lens processing that you don't actually need."]

name: Rusty Pelican - Tampa
categories_raw: African, Venues & Event Spaces, Steakhouses, Restaurants, Seafood, American (New), Event Planning & Services
top_reviews:
["I was in Tampa for about 24 hrs for work. I wanted to have a nice dinner at a nice waterfront restaurant. I had some recommendations from Yelp friends and my plan was to eat at one of them.

Wouldn't be fair to name the restaurant for we'll leave it at that.

I was heading for my hotel before dinner but my GPS took me to a wrong location. You guessed it, that's right, I ended up in the parking lot of the Rusty Pelican.

I familiar with the Rusty Pelican in Miami, or I should say Key Biscayne. Anytime we're anywhere near Miami we eat there. Love it.

It was a Little early so I left and came back a little later hoping to see the sun set over Tampa bay while having dinner.

Surprisingly it was not very busy when I got there so I got a good seat looking out over the bay. I ordered the stuffed Grouper for dinner. Stuffed with crab meat and they don't fool around when they say stuffed. More like bulging with crab meat. 

But then the main event arrived. A beautiful sunset over the bay. It was mesmerizing. I couldn't stop watching it while taking bites of my Grouper. 

The Grouper was excellent, nothing bad to say, but that sunset was superior, hands down.  I ended with a cappuccino which made the evening perfect. 

Only one problem. I was alone with no one to share it with. 

Next time I must bring Mrs. E along for a day at work with me, followed by dinner at the Rusty Pelican.  Join us please", 'What a view to have while eating dinner. The restaurant is above the water, right by the edge. Siting by the glass wall will get you the perfect view of the sunset. A very classy and romantic ambience, this place was pretty close by to our hotel so quite convenient for us. Restaurant has valet parking. The inside had low lightings, very chill vibes.

The service was great, very polite and friendly as expected from an upscale restaurant. I went with something light, the lobster mango salad. Good portion and simple presentation. Beautiful presentation of the dish. Overall, a perf place for any special occasion or for a dressy night.', 'Nice views. Sad food. 

Visited on 6-23-19 at 12:30 for Sunday brunch. The price is $49.95 per person for adults, 5 and under is free, and children get a discounted (but still exorbitant) rate. Our server Sandra was fast and friendly. 

The bathrooms look like they haven't been updated since 1994. It smelled like a nursing home in there and it was dirty. They had a scented candle burning on the counter so they obviously know it's funky in there. 

We got seated in a lovely dining room with a nice view of the bay. Sandra explained that we can order speciality items off the menu and visit the buffet for the same price. Husband ordered eggs benny and kiddo requested waffles and I headed for the buffet. 

At first the buffet room looks like foodie heaven...until you get a closer look. The food is about what you'd find at a mid-level catered wedding. Nothing exciting or really high quality. 

The crab legs are served cold (is there any bigger sin?) and they were extremely salty. The shrimp tasted like they were cooked yesterday in the same salty water. I had "prime rib" which looked and tasted like pot roast. Powdered scrambled eggs. Croissants from Sam's Club. 

The desserts were so sad and cheap. I went around and around the table just trying to find something that looked like it was worth the calories. One of the desserts was a half of a cupcake with whipped cream on top and a slice of strawberry. The rest looked like they were dumped out of a freezer box and sliced into small pieces. 

The best thing in there was the waffles. They are light and fluffy and crispy and sweet and heavenly. I wiped a bit of syrup off my lip and the cloth napkin smelled like mildew. I tried the other two at the table and they all smelled like somebody left them in the washer for two days.

Think about this...for the same price, you could go to Bern's, Texas de Brazil, Charley's, Fogo de Chao....somewhere super clean with amazing food. I feel ripped off. I won't be back.']

name: Termini Bros Bakery
categories_raw: Food, Restaurants, Bakeries
top_reviews:
['There are two items that will keep me coming back to Termini Bros Bakery at Reading Terminal Market in Philadelphia, PA.  

Their Cannolis are DELICIOUS!!!!  Perfect balance of yummy Ricotta filling in a fresh crispy shell!!  Best I've had outside of Boston!
 
Their Pecan Diamond is so Sinfully Fantastic!!  This bar shaped treat is packed with yummyness, and it is worth every single calorie!!

Termini Bros is absolutely one of my "Must Visit" destinations at Reading Terminal Market.  They should be yours as well!', "BEST CANNOLI EVER!

*Clouds in the sky parted, sun beams rays directly down on Termini, heavenly angels sing, and this cannoli appeared to bring joy and delight to all those on earth.*

Choice of fillings: Chocolate, Vanilla, Cheese & Chocolate Chips.  The later of which is what I had.  

$3.00 for one and worth every penny!  Perfectly crunchy pastry shell, smooth, sweet, cream with chocolate chips, powdered sugar sprinkled on top. Thank God for the local Philadelphian who send me here for one.  WOW!  I nearly fainted with delight.

(They have other items too... candy, sfogliatelle - baked ricotta cheese, orange peel. and cinnamon, fig bars, cookies, coconut macaroons, cakes of all kinds,)

This stuff is so good that you can order it and have it shipped anywhere in the US.  6 cannoli for $40, 12 for $60.  Order them for a party and you won't be sorry!  You can also call their 800 number - 800-882-7650.", "When you find yourself standing in front of Termini Bros Bakery, you can't help but stare.  Well lit displays slammed full of pastries and treats make your mouth ready to be stuffed.

Staff know the drill and many posed for the camera when you're taking pics of their displays...needless to say, it's a friendly bunch.  

They make their cannolis right in front of you, filling the empty shell with cream that looked great.  Sadly I didn't buy one of these.  We instead shared their Lemon cream cake.  

Geez this thing was popping with citrus flavors and sweetness that made me sad that we didn't buy more!  Located near the rear of Reading Terminal, Termini Bros Bakery seems to have a crowd always, and while there's no seating at the bakery, there's plenty of places to sit in the Terminal.

Really enjoyed my Time at Termini Bros Bakery, and my only gripe is that we didn't buy more.  Do me a favor and buy some of their treats and enjoy!"]

name: Green Basil Thai Kitchen
categories_raw: Thai, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Tucked away on the eastern part of South Street is a little Thai Bistro called Green Basil. While this restaurant has received mixed reviews on Yelp, I have a few friends who really like it and are pretty experienced with Thai food.  Well after eating there this week, I join them in their opinion.  I really liked Green Basil.  Mind you, after a week of eating and enjoying holiday cooking from Austria and Philadelphia, I was ready for a little Thai food.  Your meal begins with a nice pot of Thai hot tea.
