On this cold day, I followed that up with a spicy lemon grass soup while my friend opted for spring rolls.  An appetizer of Thai sausages was excellent .... especially with the ginger soy sauce to dip them in. My main course was a delicious version of Thai Jungle Pork.  The homemade chili sauce the waitress brought out was a perfect accompaniment.  I tasted my friend's Pad Thai which was def decent enough although not as spicy as I like.  The service was both friendly and excellent throughout the meal.  Yeah, you can def count me in among the fans of this little Thai bistro!", "For some seriously good thai food, Green Basil Thai Kitchen hits the spot. I'm glad I discovered this place because they really bring the flavor impact. They just added online ordering, so you actually get 20% off your first order through their website greenbasilthaikitchen.com.

Starting out with the soup, I love how savory the broth is and how it really warms the soul. The noodles are coated in this spicy sauce that coats the palette. You can tell that it's well seasoned with the heat of the wok and the crisp vegetables. There are plenty of vegetarian options too so the rest of family was incredibly happy about that.

I will definitely be back for some more of this comfort food. They even cater too, so maybe I'll share some for the next potluck.", 'Visited on a Wednesday afternoon. Was a weekday after lunch rush hour so we were the only ones in the restaurant. We were given prompt service. 
We started off with the steamed pork dumplings which were delicious. 
Then I had pad Thai with shrimp. The food tasted amazing. Loved everything about it. Will be back to try more.']

name: Mei's World Pizza
categories_raw: Salad, Pizza, Barbeque, Soup, Restaurants, Taiwanese, Chinese
top_reviews:
["Pizza and Chinese food - weird combination, but it works.

My husband was furious at me for not taking him here earlier. To be honest, I had no idea this place existed until a coworker, Jonathan T., visited and myself and Brett N., my boss/last Tampa Bay CM, came up with places to take him. The email exchange went like this:

J: I'm planning to eat healthy while in Tampa.
B: We need to go get Chinese pizza.
J: Hell yeah we do.

When I brought up the ridiculousness of this exchange, I was basically met with, but it's Chinese pizza! Who was I to argue, I wasn't planning to eat healthy, so we put it on our list to check out. 

Saturday afternoon, about 12:30 p.m., and we are the only table in the restaurant. If you have little kids, they only have one high chair. I was victorious in getting it and I heard families after me ask and be told there were no more high chairs. It's a small place, so the one high chair thing isn't the most ridiculous thing ever, just a little surprising. 

It's in a strip mall and the restaurant itself is a little jank, but the food is legit. They make fresh dumplings on the weekend so we had to try that. We also got a scallion pancake and this stuffed with chive dish that I could never understand what the waitress was calling it. Then we finished this order with a Mapo Tofu pizza, Chicken Terriyaki pizza, and General Tso pizza. 

I couldn't try the dumplings because they had pork, but everything else was amazing. Admittedly, the Mapo Tofu pizza was everyone's least favorite, but it was still good. I wasn't a fan because I don't like spicy food. The Chicken Terriyaki and the General Tso pizza were amazing. It has a sweetness to it, even in the crust. The combination just works. They also do not skimp on the cheese. The best part, these pizzas are only $10! For 7 people we walked away paying $70 not including tip and we were stuffed. We basically took home over half of the Mapo Tofu pizza. 

For the price, quality, and novelty, this place cannot be beat. I'm lucky it is about half an hour from my house or else my husband would easily be 10 lbs heavier.", "Totally hit the spot. I am now completely recovered from the calamatous noodle soup experience Anna Montana caused when she pranked me by sending me to some horrible faux ramen place on Kennedy..

Mei's is homestyle Taiwanese soups, fried pork chop, dumplings, buns, congee, tofu dishes, stir fry string beans, and general tsos.. And or pizza and wings. And when I say and or I mean they do a general tsos pizza! Word. 

I had the pig feet soup. It was by far the best pig feet soup I've ever had. I'm not even a huge fan of pigs feet, they are pretty fleshy and fatty, but this was yummo. 

So come in and relax. There is no ambience, just you Taiwanese Mom and good food.

Several vegetarian dishes as well. Good for you veggie peepsters.", "My Yelp friends Coty and Paul asked me to join them one evening at Mei's World Pizza and Salads along Bearss Avenue, near Bruce B Downs, in the USF area. I wasn't quite sure what to expect, as the name of this place seems to imply a pizza shop, and yet Coty told me that they serve very good Taiwanese food. Hmmmm, well, she has never failed me with her selection of restaurants, and so I was game to give this place a try.

Sure enough, this little restaurant on the north side of Bearss Avenue looks like a pizza / sandwich shop from the outside, but inside, the place was packed with college students in the know, as well as folks looking for good Thai food. 

The first thing you should know is that nothing on the regular Thai menu is priced over $10. That includes rice bowls, noodle bowls and platters, traditional Thai appetizers, and a great mix of entrées. Secondly, they DO serve pizza......and apparently you can have them put Thai or Chinese / American food on top of your pizza. Finally, if you are so inclined, they do serve pig's feet, chicken feet, chicken lips, chicken butt, and a whole lot of things that will never go into my mouth. Sorry, but I just can't picture a chicken walking around on a pair of crutches because someone wanted to eat chicken feet! Nope, it's not gonna happen.

Coty ordered a number of very tasty dishes for the three of us to share, and so we enjoyed Mei's pan-fried pork buns, pepper-seasoned fried chicken (no feet, please!), hand-cut Zha Jiang noodles in a black bean sauce, and a sliced, boneless pork chop served with a tea egg. The egg was awesome, so we ordered some more of them. Mei, is of course the owner, and she & Coty got in to a very fun discussion about Coty's upcoming trip to Taiwan as well as her experiences with enjoying Taiwanese food in New York City.

I really enjoyed my meal, but was glad that I went there with people who were more experienced in ordering this cuisine. The wait staff at Mei's was super-friendly, and very helpful about making recommendations about the menu.

I liked this place a lot, and will gladly go back when I'm in the neighborhood."]

name: Toni & Guy - Tucson
categories_raw: Beauty & Spas, Hair Salons, Hair Stylists, Barbers
top_reviews:
["Ryan should be the only person in this salon allowed to wash clients hair. It was the best most relaxing hair wash I've ever had. I can't even describe it. Kind of like a head massage and he would slightly pull on the hair too which would make scalp tight. It was fantastic!!! They offered us water right when we arrived. They do have different levels of hair stylists. Some are more advanced and have more training and years of experience. They don't really explain what the different levels are. I'm sure I could google it to find out. They did install dividers between the hair wash stations due to Covid-19. That was nice and everyone wears masks. 

I would say they could have a few more chairs for waiting area but they might have removed them for social distancing rules. 

I didn't get my hair styled. Just a deep conditioning and Ryan did the diffuser at the end. Leaving it nice and curly.", "The Toni & Guy locations in Tucson really bring hair maintenance into the category of art.  I've never had a cut that's been less than great and I go here about once a year.  All the locations (I believe there are three in the city) are top notch.

I've been dealing with a not-to-pleasant haircut for the past month and all of the sudden something dawned on me.  I could spend $30 at a cheap place in town to get a cut that's mediocre or makes me feel awkward and unattractive OR I could spend $70 (or less, depending on how much you tip) to get a cut I KNOW will be great and not have to worry about it for a long while.  Once again, they did not disappoint.  In fact, they delighted with a low-maintenance that will grow out well.", 'Not a fan of the "specialized" stylist thing 

I don't like the fact that 2 people have to work on my hair. In the past my hairstylists have become my favorite people and dearest friends. Personally, I find it difficult to find ONE new person to trust with with my hair, two seems impossible. 
 
I picked Toni and Guy based on their hours of operation and Yelp reviews. My experience was less than pleasant. First the person who toned my hair gave me anxiety with her uncertainty. Maybe she's new to the hair game but I've never felt so afraid to let someone tone my hair. The lady who cut my hair wasn't my favorite. She didn't listen to what I wanted, so I have to give a mediocre review. 

I did find a great stylist though! Look out for my next review ;)']

name: Cucina Zapata
categories_raw: Thai, Food Stands, Restaurants, Mexican
top_reviews:
["Quite simply, this food truck is amazeballs.

Yes, this is a Thai Mexican fusion truck. An undeniable awesome marriage between two of my most favorite cuisines. I swung by to try their famous Cap'n Crunch crusted tilapia burrito but I ended up ordering their entire menu. And I wasn't even hungry!

THAI SHORT RIBS TACOS (1 for $3)- Tender yet perfectly chewy. The flavors literally burst in your mouth letting you know these meats were given a good marinade bath before it was cooked. Generous slices of avocado canopying the filling of veggies like shredded cabbage and cubed tomatoes. And oh my, that green sauce.....creamy, yet light and refreshing.

CHICKEN KATSU W/ AN EGG ($5.50) 
Extremely crispy, thin flat cutlet of well-cooked chicken served with a bed of slaw, a fried egg, rice, and spicy mayo drizzle. Ask for extra sauces! 

CAP'N CRUNCH CRUSTED TILAPIA TACOS (2 for $6)- The disadvantage of coming here late to avoid the long lines was that they ran out of burritos' ingredients. However, they accommodated us by making us a taco instead! Made with the same love as the ribs tacos, except with the crunchy, slightly sweet breading, and delicious flaky fish inside! 

I don't generally expect good service from a food truck. But the people who work here go above and beyond with their genuine helpfulness and friendliness. I was super impressed with my entire experience. 

I only spent $15 for all of that deliciousness and I was 100% satisfied.", "Hands down the best lunch truck food I've ever had. 

Thai Tacos? WTF is that? They're amazing that's what. This place has such unique food that will blow you away. Plus it's cheap because its a lunch truck ($6 range), and plus there's great consistency. 

You do often have to wait in line during lunch hours, so it's not ultimate 2 minute for a hoagie truck type, but the quality is much higher. 

If you're on Drexel's campus, you should try this place! Better than any of the restaurants on campus too. 

I'm vegetarian and usually get the veggie burger (and they make it for me without the buns to save some carbs!)", "Like David B, my first introduction to Cucina Zapata was also at the Vendy Awards. Curried chicken over rice hooked me in while mini tacos with chicken and short rib sealed the deal. It was one of the few trucks that day that kept the line moving quickly and was also prepared for the crowds. Even when an L&I inspector jumped aboard in the beginning of the event, causing everything to grind to a halt, the food truck peeps kept their cool and business was back up and running in no time. 

I'll definitely make a point to seek out Cucina Zapata for lunch in the near future!"]

name: In the Valley
categories_raw: Nightlife, Restaurants, Wine Bars, Bars, Tapas/Small Plates, Cocktail Bars, American (New)
top_reviews:
["I love this bar. Last night was my second visit and I enjoyed it just as much as round one. The cocktails are well-balanced and delicious; the bartenders really know what they are doing. 

Happy hour is a total steal, featuring a really nice red and wine selection and a handful of cocktails, plus some of the regular bar snacks at way reduced prices. I won't tell you how many orders of the puffed pork chips with wild onion sour cream dip I ordered, but it was more than one.", 'One of my family's oldest and dearest friends happens to be quite the foodie. Before I ventured home to Philly for Thanksgiving, this friend urged us to make a reservation at ITV, Nick Elmi's newest business venture. She happens to be best friends with Jonathan Cohen, Elmi's business partner, so she's committed to getting the word out about this place. Luckily, we managed to book far enough in advance to score one of the few tables in this small but mighty eatery. Though I haven't been to Laurel (Mr. Elmi's four-bell, fine dining spot, adjacent to ITV), the food at ITV is apparently quite different--here, a more casual but equally innovative a la carte menu. Our night at ITV was divine, punctuated by standout service (food comes out FAST!). 

ITV is a small space. In the front half of the restaurant, seating options are limited to the bar/a high top against the window. In the back, four or five small tables in dim, intimate lighting. ITV is as much of a bar as it is a restaurant, so alcohol is very much on display here. The bar area is gorgeous and stocked with plenty of fancy bottles. Most bar-restaurant hybrids tend to excel in one area alcohol-wise, oftentimes at the expense of others. Not the case here. ITV boasts a well-curated drink list with equal care given to beer, wine and liquor. 

Though the cocktail menu doesn't immediately strike a person as exciting, these drinks have that "fancy" quality to them. It can't really be described by way of flavor, but you know it when you experience it. These are like that. Well-balanced, high-quality ingredients and super tasty. I tried the Drunken Farmer (Bourbon, Fig Leaf, Egg White) and the Kirby (Gin, Genepy, Aperol, Lime) which were both fantastic. Given the egg white, the Drunken Farmer was a bit lighter but still in line with fall flavors. The Kirby, though shaken (I believe), was on the stronger side but fruitier/more sour than the first. Can't go wrong. The food was still the star, though. Eats, below:

Hamachi Crudo, Grapefruit, Black Olive, Sesame: A-
Perfect starter. Light and gently wakes the palate up. Delicate flavors, nice and citrusy. Didn't wow us, but a great first dish. 

Puffed Pork Chips, Sour Cream and Wild Onion: A
Fun artistic touch that you need to look out for if you're seated in dim lighting: the dip, spread in a crescent shape along the side of your plate. We almost missed this sophisticated sour cream and onion dip on the side! In any case, this is the most elevated pork rinds/dip combo I'll probably ever come into contact with. Another fabulous starter. Light and airy but still quite flavorful. 

Beef Fat Biscuit, Scallion Honey Butter: A
This one was just for my bf, but I gave it a try. Not surprisingly, it was magical. Flaky and decadent. 

Chicken Liver Stroopwaffle, Plum Agrodolce: N/A
Both of us tend to dislike chicken liver. Which is a shame, because I can tell that I would have loved this preparation had my taste buds developed differently. The waffles and plum were a yummy sweet/savor combo, but we sadly had to set this one aside. 

Smoked Trout Rillette, Pumpernickel Soldiers, Trout Roe, Radish: A+++
The star of the night. I can't even describe why these were so good, but they were perfection. The rillette was heavenly. The bread was spongy but crispy. The roe was plain luxurious. A masterpiece. 

Bacon and Wild Burgundy Snail Ragout, Mushroom, Jimmy Red Polenta, Soft Poached Egg: A+
What a special, creative dish this was. Everything worked together in perfect harmony, here. I have a quirk where I like to eat dishes one component at a time, but this one's best just mixing everything together--poached egg and all. Rich, warm, hearty and bursting with flavor. My bf had never tried snails prior to this night, so it was a fantastic introduction to him. I tend to avoid polenta, but this preparation managed to touch my heart. Well done. 

Little Neck Clams, Pancetta, Scallion Broth: A
A thoughtful, yummy seafood dish. The clams were some of the best I've ever had, and I typically don't love clams (depends on the preparation for me). The pancetta was a lovely touch, though made the overall flavor profile a bit salty. Minor complaint, though. The scallion broth, as well as being gorgeous in color, was yummy and perfect for bread-soaking. 

Rabbit Schnitzel, Celery Root, Green Apple: A
Simple but incredibly tasty. The light salad served atop the schnitzel balanced the dish nicely. If the idea of eating rabbit doesn't give you the willies, give this one a try. The meat was cooked perfectly and is fantastic with a quick squeeze of the seared lemon served on the side here.

To top off what had already been a beautiful night, we were lucky enough to meet Chef Elmi. I had asked the waitress if Jonathan was in that night (our family friend's friend--and he wasn't), but it was Mr. Elmi who came out instead! Gracious and sweet. Getting to meet the chef is always a special treat for me, but a famous Philly/Top Chef guy was just too great.', "ITV is Chef Nicholas Elmi's newest offering on Passyunk, located adjacent to Laurel. ITV features the same great service and its dishes are similarly well-crafted, innovative, and beautifully plated, but with a much more relaxed atmosphere and a more casual if somewhat limited menu.

First off, ITV is more of a bar that offers (excellent) food than a restaurant. Drinks occupy five-sixths of the menu, with an extensive offering of wines by the bottle and by the glass, beers, ciders, and sophisticated mixed drinks. The food menu has a limited selection (~12 to 15 items) of affordable, tapas-style mix of small plates (~$8) and slightly larger offerings (~$15).

Our party of four stopped by for dinner and ordered just about everything on the menu. Small plates highlights included the beautifully plated hamachi crudo with ribbons of refreshing radish in a tangy buttermilk sauce, the intensely smokey trout rillette tartines, chicken liver and jam sandwiched between crunchy stroopwafels - a pleasing combination of sweet and savory, the delicately fried and seasonally sweet tempura pole beans, and the crackling pork rinds with a buttermilk-dill sauce, which arrived at our table still crackling and are, in my opinion, the pinnacle of bar food.

From the larger plate selection, we especially enjoyed the shrimp in a mild cajun sauce with avocado and the sesame-crusted lamb ribs, which were tender and intensely flavorful. We also ordered the fried chicken, which was very good, but a bit on the bland side. The chicken also came with a side of cornbread, which was amazing - especially the scallion butter.

The service was friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable about the drinks and food menus. Our waitress checked in with us throughout the meal and was attentive to our drinks - excellent service for a bar. The food comes out as it is made and is served in easily shareable portions, ensuring a steadily paced meal and good conversation as we marveled over how delicious each dish was.

Overall, ITV was certainly not what I was expecting - and also exceeded expectations. Rather than a restaurant, I would classify it as a bar with a smaller but clearly well thought-out food menu and three sit-down tables in the back room. There are enough dishes that one can eat a filling and varied dinner - and the menu seems seasonal, so I imagine dish offerings may change every few months. ITV offers a more affordable and relaxed way to experience the mastery of Elmi's cooking, perfect for lighter meals and late-night bites with lively conversation."]

name: Eat-well Food Mart
categories_raw: Vietnamese, Restaurants, Food, Convenience Stores, Sandwiches, Specialty Food, Ethnic Food
top_reviews:
["MUST GET THE PHORITTO! It's not on the menu so make sure you ask for it. I was skeptical at first when I heard about it but I'm glad I tried it. I barely even used the broth that comes with it because it was already infused with great pho flavor. It also comes with a side of hosin sauce & sriracha. The phoritto has everything that would normally comes in a bowl of pho. Brisket, noodles, veggies such has bean sprouts, basil, and jalapenos. It was easy to eat and wasn't soggy like I had expected. Will be back for more!

I also order a foot long banh mi (vietnamese poboy) and it was made with lots of flavor. A friend of mine recommended me to try it with their special aioli sauce and I did. It had the right amount of spiciness to it. My boyfriend tried it and he loved it! Probably the best we've had. 

This place is a convenient store with a few small tables if you decided to dine in. There is also parking behind the building which is a plus considering it is located on canal street. I'm ready to come back to try out their other items on the menu.", "This place is definitely a hidden gem within Mid City. Hidden in a corner store, I used to pass by the place all the time. Until one day I was perusing Yelp for some good pho in Mid-City.  

And I've never looked back. They're never busy (maybe because it can be seen as a seedy convenience store, you don't really want to linger) and you have to go to the back of the store to order. But I don't mind the sketch when you taste the quality of their food. 

Now, I have been slightly obsessed lately with their pho. Chockful of ingredients, I was wonderfully surprised by how similar it was to my mom's delicious concoction the first time I tasted it. Rich and brothy, it was obvious it had been simmering overnight so the ingredients and flavors had plenty of time to marinate. They also gave me traditional Vietnamese herbs and plenty of bean sprouts. I also like the fact that they use the same hoisin sauce as we do at home. Best of all, you feel satisfied afterward and don't feel the need to drink lots of water since it's not laced with MSG.

Their fried shrimp po-boy done Vietnamese style is also really really good. You don't get tons of shrimp, but the shrimp is perfectly fried. Plus it's a different flavor from the traditional po-boys so I'll get this when I want something different. Wasn't a fan of their bun bo hue. The meat was a little grisly and there wasn't enough noodles. Broth was deep and flavorful though. 

One star off because sometimes they're brisk and seem to be sick more often than not. And sometimes they will overcharge you for things. So check the register to see what they're ringing up.", 'Eat-well Food Mart is a convenience store that also happens to serve Vietnamese food in the back. Located on the heart of Canal, it embodies the all cliche keywords: a hidden gem, a hole in the wall, a local favorite ... all in one package. There is no doubt if I lived nearby that I'd be going here all the time.

Had it not been for the large window decals of "Vietnamese Pho" or "Banh Mi" I would have missed this place completely. There is little parking (beyond the street) to speak of and the area could be considered a bit sketch. All sorts of characters are coming in and out of here at all times. Inside the place looks like a convenience store found at any gas station but the real action is in the very back. Look for the food photos and the kitchen counters and one will find all sorts of goodness here. Order something and grab a seat out front where there are TVs playing.

I had the pleasure of ordering for a group where we ordered several "regular" (aka dac biet) banh mi, summer rolls (goi cuon), fried dumplings, the infamous phoritto (pho cuon), finished with some a few Vietnamese iced coffees and sodas. It was around $70 for everything and because it was a convenience store, that meant other snacks were available and they accept credit card.

We loved everything. The bread for the banh mi was airy and fluffy, which meant there were no cuts to the roof of the mouth. The dumplings were crispy and tasty and the summer roll was very average. The real surprise was the phoritto, which despite the gimmicky feel was actually exactly like pho in a wrap. The dipping broth was particularly excellent and the wrap was packed full of tasty ingredients (pho noodles, cilantro, onions, beef slices, and an *extra* egg). It was far and away the most expensive item at $9 but I don't know of too many Viet places (let alone convenience stores) that sell something like this.

Lastly the husband and wife duo who own the joint deserve all the kudos. They were polite, extremely friendly to all who came in, and took the time to ensure my order was as close to perfect as can be. I hope that all of my future visits to NOLA will include a trip to this fantastic biz.']

name: CRUDA Mariscos & Oyster Bar
categories_raw: Restaurants, Seafood, Breakfast & Brunch, Mexican
top_reviews:
["I've really been enjoying this spot anytime we've gone to Downtown Tucson lately. Their mole is outrageously good and just about every time we go to La Chingada, I order the chiki-changa with mole sauce. The guacamole also has an amazingly delicious garlic flavor, so honestly, it's hard to go wrong with just about anything on their menu. One of the other draws of La Chingada is the drink menu and they've got some interesting takes on classic Mexican cocktails. I really love the margaritas and even the non-alcoholic aguas frescas are amazing. It's hard to say if it is a good or bad thing, but the service can be slow, but I know they are actually making everything fresh. So, if you've got plenty of time to relax for a meal and don't mind ambient noise/music that's a little loud, this is the place for you!

But, honestly, one of my favorite things about this place is that it is immediately across the street from thr parking garage in downtown, so you don't have to walk far for an amazing meal.", "Sunday Funday is our thing when we miss Friday Date Night  We decided to cruise through Congress and use Yelp to find some lunch! La Chingada popped up as soon as we searched for Mexican food. We drove by and the patio caught our attention (plus the music because it totally gave me throwback vibes). I dropped my sweetheart off to add ourselves to the list which ended up being a 30 minute wait. We expected that as it was very busy and of course, Sunday funday is serious here in Tucson! 

 We got seated at the bar and was greeted right away  For drinks, we ordered the cucumber lime and pineapple margaritas  which we highly recommend! The cucumber gives you the refreshing feeling with a bit of a buzz  As for the appetizers, we ordered the Birria Nachos which came with birria juice  the most delicious thing I've had in a while! But be careful, it can get a bit messy  As for the main entrees, we both ordered the tacos de camarones. This entree comes with 3 tacos but we were a bit bummed that it didn't come with rice and beans. That didn't stop us from having a great time.

The atmosphere was perfect. They had pictures hung of Maria Felix, El Chavo, Cantinflas and more  Total throwback vibes when I was little! The best thing overall was the music. From Julieta Venegas to Reik, it was perfect and felt so great. 

We highly recommend this place to those who love the Hispanic vibes and comida (food)  We are definitely coming back soon!

THANK YOU FOR GIVING ME ONE OF THE BEST SUNDAYS", 'I love the modern updated look of the restaurant and all the decor. We were luckily able to avoid a wait by choosing to have a seat at the bar. The bartender was quick to help us and friendly. The prices are moderate and we were satisfied with our plates. The flavor was a bit different than what I expected but it was still good, and the beans were delicious and had chorizo flavors mixed in which was so good. I wish the drink menu had more of a selection away from tequila cocktails but I got some watermelon agua Fresca with vodka which was okay. It was a cool little brunch spot and I was happy to finally check it out.']

name: Shing Kee
categories_raw: Noodles, Chinese, Restaurants, Soup
top_reviews:
['This is a solid place to grab Chinese food in South Philly.  I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of the food.   Service was quick and food came out extremely fast too.

We ordered:
- beef chow fun - great flavors and beef was tender
- pepper steak - boneless ribs with pepper and onions (they used orange peppers as opposed to green).  Sauce was spot on and beef was cooked perfectly.  Served on a hot sizzling dish
- shrimp curry - lots of spice to the curry.  Great flavors.  
- Chinese broccoli:  wok- fried quickly in oyster sauce.  This was a little too oily/salty - would get something else next time as a veggie.  

Pretty authentic dishes and my new go to place in South Philly for Chinese food!', "Shing Kee is one of the few Chinese houses on Washington Avenue.  It serves of Hong Kong/ Cantonese style dishes that are fairly authentic, very tasty, and at good prices.  It came highly recommended by my friends who work in the area, and rightly so.

Service was above average in that promptness and smiles were part of the interaction with the servers.  My only nit was that there were two large HDTVs on the walls that were both tuned to the same channel that no one was watching, although the Eagles preseason game was available.  They just couldn't manage to change over to the game despite saying they would.  I just decided to finish quickly, and catch the game on the car radio.  

The dinner was good aside from that annoyance. Scallion Pancakes were two deep and as wide as a large dinner plate.  Not too greasy, and enough green onion flavor.  The Pork Cutlets were large, well fried and very tasty is a good Garlic Sauce.  There was some bone left, but it was easy to pick them up and work the meat off.  I appreciated that they were a large size and non-oily.  The ubiquitous Broccoli Florets were ho-hum. 

Shing Kee is a definite keeper, especially in light of the absence of many legit alternatives in the area.  It also is a good driving destination as they are in a shopping center with a decent parking lot.  While there, there are a couple of markets for grabbing your Asian ingredients for your adventures in Asian cooking.", "I am very disappointed . It is because they treated me unfairly. A couple weeks ago,  I went there for the first time. I liked the food, so I told my friend to try this restaurant. Tonight, I went there again and I saw that my friends were there (They were located in two different tables). When I came into the restaurant, they were almost done. While I was enjoying my food with my family, they had finished. Before they left, the waitress gave them one big box full of clementines for free (It was given as a New Year's gift.) Also, my other friends (at the other table) received a free big box of clementines. My table and one of the other tables had paid the bill, the only table that got the free stuff was the other table and I did not receive anything. I saw that they still had many boxes of clementines. 
I won't go back there to spend my money."]

name: Lilly's Cafe
categories_raw: Cafes, American (Traditional), Vietnamese, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Lilly's about saved my life last week! With temps dropping to the point of actual *icicles* forming, I still had to be out and about (not such a bad thing as pretty much anywhere is going to be warmer than my old drafty house) and although our intention was to get one of the amazing salads at nearby HiVolt, all I had to do was walk by Lilly's and change my mind because... well, vegan phó. 

Some of you are going to stop reading right here and that's OK, I don't blame you. I'm pretty certain that meaty phó is a whole other ballgame, what with the meat drippings seeping into the soup and adding that bit of unctuousness you're never going to get with a vegan version. But there I was freezing cold and do you know how hard it is to get a big bowl of vegetarian soup in this city?

Started with the spring rolls, because I can't ever pass those up. Vietnamese spring rolls are in my top 20 things to eat, seriously. And then came the enormous bowls of soup that warmed our souls that chilly afternoon. Flavor is light and I have to add tons of spice (wish they had sambal chili paste rather than sugary Sri Racha, just a note), but dang if that soup didn't make the rest of the day and frigid night bearable. 

And it was crazy cheap, too. Lunch for 2 (both of us had spring rolls and phó) was less than $30. True story.

Add in the sweetest, most attentive service (our waitress told us we "did good" as she took the bowls away) and Lilly's is definitely one of my favorite lower magazine eateries.', 'I've met the banh mí that I want to marry and live happily ever after with!

I shamefully admit that for a while now, I've been kinda meh about banh mí in general. I'd listen to people go on and on about them and was skeptical. I've found that in my experience, there's too much bread and flavorless filler stuff and not enough "meat" (OK, tofu). But now that I've met Lilly's, I've seen the light... These are some serious sandwiches! They aren't shy with the protein and what makes this sandwich more flavorful is that they slice the tofu up really thin before marinating and frying up in what I believe is lemongrass and various spices. Add on some soy sauce and super-tangy but flavorful slaw and you've got the best damn banh mí this vegetarian has ever had. It's also large (think: 6" po boy) and at a very fair price. 

Need something a little heartier and/or hotter? Veg heads take note: there are loads of vegan options (including pho). Fantastic spring rolls that have both tofu *and* avocado. Bun. They love us, they really love us!

My days of bemoaning the fact that I can't fulfill a cheap Chinese craving here in NOLA are over. I really do not care AT ALL when there's far healthier and more delicious Vietnamese to be had.', 'Legitimately have no idea how I haven't reviewed Lilly's before!

Of pho broths in this city, I do think that Lilly's has my favorite. It has a cinnamon-y fragrance that is rich enough but not overpowering. I also like the accoutrements you get with your to-go order. Whenever I am sick or it's cold outside, Lilly's is my go-to!

It can get pretty packed on the "pho weather" days as I like to call them so I tend to order pick-up then which is pretty fast and efficient. 

Their Vietnamese coffee is no joke. It's delicious and is a great option to power through a sleepy afternoon.

Of the phos, I usually get the Combo but have tried the Spicy Shrimp (does have a kick but not overpowering) as well. I also enjoy the Spring Rolls with strawberries and the nutty sauce that it comes with complements it well!

They are closed right now for a hot second ( maybe renovations?) 'til March so call before heading in to make sure they're open!']

name: The Pet Mechanic
categories_raw: Veterinarians, Pets
top_reviews:
['When we got our pandemic puppy, we had trouble finding a vet that could see him within the first few weeks of his arrival home. The Pet Mechanic on South Street was able to get us in within a week, so we eagerly made the appointment.

This was August 2020, so there were strict rules in place regarding the number of people allowed in the waiting area. We were not allowed to go back into the room with our pup. We waited in the lobby and filled out some paperwork. A vet tech came out to ask us a few questions and let us know about their "Puppy Plan". For a little over $700, the plan covered essentially everything needed in our dog's first year of life such as the neuter/spay surgery, vaccinations and boosters, and check up visits. We took advantage of this plan and found it to be VERY worth it because the first year can really add up.

Our pup went back for his first check up and after, our vet Dr. Ellen M. came out and let us know that everything looked normal and that he was healthy. She asked how things were going with him at home and answered all of our questions. She is very kind and intelligent! We are glad that she is our vet.

We have since referred many friends to the Pet Mechanic because they have a great staff and fair prices compared to other vets in the city.', 'After a horrible experience at the groomer, I took my dog in to be checked for a small cut (that turned into a scab) on her face. I was quickly told nothing could be done because it was on the face and near her eyes. The vet recommended Benadryl and a cone. On Monday, a month later, I had to take my dog to an emergency room for the same problem. When I arrived I was told that the dog had an intense infection and the skin would need to be soaked & scraped off. The emergency vet told me that had this been treated correctly an infection wouldn't have occurred. Not only did I pay a silly fee at Pet Mechanic but I also then spent nearly $300 at the emergency room for the SAME issue. 

To make matters worse when I called the office to express my disappointment, the receptionist sounded so rude and without an ounce of empathy told me a "practice manager" would call me. Still waiting for this call.', "I took my dog here to have his nails clipped.
I must have blinked a half a dozen times before he was brought back out to me. I was surprised at how fast they did it, until I looked down while holding him and realized there was blood coming out of multiple nails. 
It would have taken about 5 minutes to do this correctly, without hurting my animal and rushing us out the door to close. If they didn't have the time, even though I made an appointment, they should have let me know instead of assuming it was ok to take their chances at cutting my dog. 
AND they missed some nails. 
If you are going to charge for a service, actually provide it.
I don't need you to give me an anatomical explanation of nails, I know how they work. I need you to take the time to do your job responsibly."]

name: Orangetheory Fitness New Orleans - Mid City
categories_raw: Trainers, Gyms, Boot Camps, Fitness & Instruction, Interval Training Gyms, Active Life
top_reviews:
["Just tried my first Orange Theory class yesterday morning and guess what? I'm a member now. How did that happen? Lol. It happened because I ended up loving the class and my results that much! It's nowhere near my house, so I have to go fifteen minutes out of my way to get there, but it's worth it in my opinion.  

Let me begin by saying that I'm already a moderately active person. I work an office job during the day but I exercise at a regular gym at least 5-6 times a week. I normally do a mixture of weight training and cardio when I go. I've also recently started adding yoga and Pilates once a week to my routine to develop a stronger core. So do I NEED Orange Theory to lose weight? I don't (because I've lost several pounds on my own already), BUT I love their concept of targeting your maximum heart rate zone and believe it will give me the extra push I need to lose these last few pesky pounds. I do have a Fitbit already and use it to monitor my heart rate, but it's a lot more fun when you're in a class setting with a personal trainer and can see your results from the Orange Theory heart monitor on the screen. It made me feel really motivated to stay in the orange zone, which is the recommended zone (based on your stats) to really burn fat.

The class is a mixture of interval training with cardio and circuit training with weights. It's not for everyone because my fiance tried it with me and hated it lol. However, he has never been a fan of instruction while I've done guided classes for years. It passes by quickly! I recommend trying out one class because it's complimentary and they will loan you a heart monitor. I really like that your results are emailed to you at the end of each class. Some people do complain that it's pricey but you truly get what you pay for and health and fitness are definitely something that are worth the splurge! It amazes me how people are willing to spend hundreds of dollars per month on eating out, cable TV, shopping, etc (you get the idea) but cut corners on health/fitness and only be willing to spend a few bucks on a typical gym membership. At the end of the day, you really can't put a price on the sense of accomplishment you get after you finish a grueling workout that challenges you, or the feeling you get when you look in the mirror and are happy with your physique and progress. You only have one body, so why not take care of it?", "Where was I before Orange Theory? Oh that's right, on my couch drinking wine every night complaining about not being in shape. I had a friend that praised this place and after awhile when one popped up in mid city, I decided to give it a try. Initially I said no because of the price, but once you calculate the cost it's really not so bad. Health is wealth baby. Immediately from my first class, I knew I had made a good decision. Not only was the staff extremely welcoming and personable, but I loved everything about the concept. It literally pushes you to work harder and get in shape. I don't have the drive to do it on my own, so fortunately this was exactly what I needed. I've been coming for 3 months now and no workout has ever been the same. I love the energy when u walk inside. For people like me who have extremely hectic and inconsistent work schedules, this is perfect. All you do is download the app and you schedule according to what works best for you. They have classes all day at all different times. If your wondering about bringing headphones or making a playlist, don't bother. The instructors have the music bumping when u walk in. I haven't taken everyone's class, but Brandon, Jeff, and Josh's music selection definitely will have you in the zone. Everyone needs a little trap music in their life lol. If I haven't convinced you by now, then go in and see for yourself. They willingly will give u a walk through and let u do a trial class. Thank me later!", "OTF and I had a rough start. When they initially opened it was impossible to get into a class, and I also didn't understand the whole wait list concept, so it was a frustrating initial few months. That being said, they have a come long way! It's now pretty easy to get in, provided you sign up relatively ahead of time, and you can also schedule classes way in advance courtesy of the app. 

The classes are fun and always a little bit different which is nice. I've enjoyed all of the instructors and they have great attitudes and work hard to keep the class high energy;while also keeping you safe with the weight movements. The music is fun, and I like that it's dark in there relatively speaking, since I look disgusting when I work out and don't want to seen by anyone.

The cons? During the summer the room feels super stuffy and stinky. It doesn't feel like there's very good circulation in there, and while it wasn't really noticeable during the winter & spring...now you can tell. It is stanky. Also, they have this 12 hour cancellation policy which is both a pro and a con. You can't cancel after 12 hours or you lose a class/pay a fee; but it does motivate me to actually go because I am cheap. Depending on your outlook it be either a positive or negative experience for you."]

name: The Venus Experience
categories_raw: Beauty & Spas, Hair Removal, Day Spas
top_reviews:
["I had a very relaxing and thorough wax job here. The price is great too!

BUT Yelp  users should know that Venus Experience double dips in their wax. This means they use the same wax for each client and each client is waxed with one popsicle stick applicator that is re-dipped into the wax multiple times until the service is finished. Then it is thrown away. This is VERY UNHYGIENIC. A spa should use a new popsicle stick wax applicator each time the wax is applied so only clean, unused sticks go into the wax. 

I asked this spa why they didn't do this and they said that the hot wax kills all of the germs. This is untrue. See the article below for details.

http://www.womenshealthmag.com/health/bikini-waxing-dangers", "These ladies get the job done at the lowest price that I've found. I wish they used the wax that Esthetique Facial Spa uses because it hurts less and works better. I also wish that they'd see customers at the scheduled time. I usually have to wait 15 minutes, but they do work swiftly. I am always able to get waxed and head back to work within my lunch break. Often, I am able to make appointments the same day as my service.", "I've been getting brazilians for awhile and I will not be returning here. Yes, the $40 price is great, and it's also very close to where I live, but they do NOT use hard wax and they double dip in their wax! 

Double dipping is unacceptable. It's very unhygienic and can cause infections. Every other place I've been for waxing does not double dip - common practice is to throw out the popsicle stick after using it once. I will not be returning."]

name: Hyde Perk Coffee House
categories_raw: Food, Coffee & Tea
top_reviews: ["My hairstylist recommended this place's cookies and cream big train iced coffee and it is darn good. It's dessert and coffee at the same time. It is also nice to see that they support another local business, FitWrapz, by selling their healthy burritos.", 'Did you know you can get a protein shake there in the morning, and add your coffee to it? Really good idea!', "Beautiful coffee shop own & run by local family! It's feel good to support local businesses! We went there this afternoon for their soft opening. We order a White Cho. Mocha, kid hot chocolate, a snickerdoodles cookie & a cranberry scones! Everything was yummy! We'll be back! I wish the best for them!"]

name: La Mesa Tortillas
categories_raw: Specialty Food, Food, Local Flavor, Restaurants, Mexican, Ethnic Food
top_reviews:
["Decided need to eat tamales.  Put ? to YelpApp and went to the nearest one. Glad I did,  we had the red beef and they were really to our liking: LOTS of tender beef,  flavorful red sauce but not  salty. We ordered a dozen and ate them for 2 consecutive meals.  Here today, gone tamale. Ha! We loved em. Also brought some jalapeno tortillas home.  Really unusual,  spicy! and perfect for sopping up some frijoles I had at home. We will be back to get some dinner 2 take home and lunch done there.  Nice owner lady. I asked her if the tamales were any good, not knowing she owned/made them & she sweetly replied,  'I'd like to think so.' Awwww! She's so right.", 'What can I say? Can you get much better than your neighborhood tortilla place? Spotless and simple environment? Check! Surprisingly expansive menu? Also check! 

I had no idea La Mesa existed; I stumbled across it today when I was intending to go to Ferguson to get a replacement part for the tub faucet, only to find it closed. Surely, there had to be another reason to drive all the way out from Oro Valley. This was, apparently, the reason to do so. I took a glance at the menu, and all looked good, but I was in a tamale mood; I had not had one since Winter. I took home half a dozen green corn, and half a dozen red chile beef. This place really goes with what works as far as tamale-making is concerned. Occasionally, you will run across a place that will try to re-invent the wheel, causing something to get lost in translation. Not the case here. These tamales are every bit as good as tamales that I know and love. They are not dried out, they are flavorful, and filling. They were a hit at home; all have been eaten.

I cannot wait to try other items on their menu!', 'This place had good reviews on Yelp, unfortunately it was average for me. I had the chili burrito with red sauce, it was dry and nothing special, also the tortilla was nothing special.']

name: Adolf Biecker Spa/Salon
categories_raw: Beauty & Spas, Day Spas, Cosmetics & Beauty Supply, Hair Salons, Hair Removal, Shopping, Massage, Nail Salons, Skin Care
categories: ['beauty & spas', 'day spas', 'cosmetics & beauty supply', 'hair salons', 'hair removal', 'shopping', 'massage', 'nail salons', 'skin care']
top_reviews:
['The front desk/reception staff here is so nice, I feel guilty writing this, but hey, it's the truth.  So my husband and I booked a very lovely night at the Rittenhouse, and I thought I might try to get a massage in before our dinner reservations (hey, we have a toddler and one on the way, so we don't get out much).  I had to call about 5 times before I got anybody on the phone.  MMMkay.  They are able to fit me in at 6 as long as the restaurant can change our reservations to 7:30.  Great.  Done.

I show up, it's nice, I seem to be the only person there, which makes it even weirder that there is a wet bikini tossed in the corner of the shower...

anyway...

I go and wait in the waiting room at about 5:50, enjoying some trail mix and some aveda tea (which I come to find out I shouldn't be drinking pregnant).  My appointment is at 6.  6 comes and goes, 6:05, 6:10, and finally at 6:18 I go to tell the receptionist that I won't make my dinner reservations anymore, and I have to leave.  WTF?

On my way down the hall, a woman stops me.  This woman looks like a Bon Jovi roadie circa 1980.  I'm sorry, but it was true.  So anyway, she points at my pregnant belly and says "I think I have you next."  I say, "I was going to tell them I had to leave.  It's almost 6:20."  She, with a healthy dose of Philly attitude, says, "Well, I had somebody else."  

Um, that's cool.  But I had an appointment 20 minutes ago.

She then opens the door to a room and trying to radically shift gears and act all nice, says "Go ahead and get undressed and I'll be in."

I look at the table which is at a near 45 degree angle (clearly set up for a non-pregnant woman), remember this woman's strangely black teeth (I'm sorry - it's true!), and open the door.  "I'm sorry, I have dinner reservations in an hour from now, so I need to cancel this."

So I walked out, and nobody said a word to me.  It was kind of insane!  I suspect the massage wasn't cheap either.  Go figure.', 'Steer clear of Roberta.  I had the worst massage ever at Adolf Biecker today from Roberta.  It had been a rough week, and I thought I would cut out of work early on Friday afternoon and get a massage.  After striking out trying to get an appointment at Rescue (my usual massage spot), I tried Adolf Biecker, figuring that it was nearby and in a nice hotel, so it should be good.  Um, not so fast.  The facilities were ok, but the real problem was Roberta.

Oh, Roberta.  I am hesitant to trash someone's ability to practice her chosen profession, but I would hate for someone to waste $100 and an hour on this massage.    The word that comes to mind in describing the massage is unskilled.  It honestly felt like my husband (who is an attorney, not a massage therapist) rubbing cold sunscreen on me.  It was weird when she started with my feet, and it just got worse.  I was laying there thinking, "What is she doing?  Is she a professional massage therapist?  Was she trained?  Can I stand this for a full hour?"  At one point she had my hand pinned back to the middle of my back.  It wasn't painful, just annoying.  When I felt her pressing into my kidneys, a big massage no-no, I knew it was time to go.  

I decided that I would tell Roberta that I had to go to the bathroom.  I came back and explained that it just wasn't working for me.  Frankly, she did not seem surprised.  I would guess this was not the first time it happened to Roberta.  When I checked my watch back in the locker room, I realized that I had only been in the massage for about 20 minutes.

I asked to speak with the manager.  I told her that I have been to a lot of massage therapists at different spas in Philly, and I had never ever even considered walking out in the middle.  I told her that Roberta's touch felt unskilled and amateurish.  I asked whether they had confirmed that Roberta had formal training.

The manager responded that Roberta had several years of experience, which is not the same as training.  The manager swore that Roberta had regular repeat customers.  Maybe it was just a bad match between me and Roberta, but, like I said, I have had a lot of massages and this is the first time I ever considered leaving.  The only bright spot was that they did not even suggest that I should pay for the service.', 'While the service is friendly and the salon itself is nice.  I do not recommend going there for bayalge. This is the third time back to try and "fix".  The color at the bottom is ok now but clearly fixing didnt work as there is no blending and there is a defined line of where the highlight starts. Not worth the $135 for and hours at the time at the salon to do this. Can't wear my hair down till this grows out or I can get it done again - somewhere else.  I will say that becky the manager did handle this very well and was able to refund my money and was pleasant about it.  Good customer service from that perspective.']

name: 30th Street Station
categories_raw: Public Transportation, Transportation, Train Stations, Public Services & Government, Hotels & Travel
top_reviews:
['I used to be a daily commuter through 30th Street Station when I lived in Center City and worked in Trenton, NJ. That was nearly 25 years ago when the station, though still beautiful in its faded glory, struggled to maintain its class and dignity in a city that had fallen on hard times. Walking through the grand center hall was like a stroll in an ancient temple paying homage to the greatness of a bygone age. (Please read my earlier review for a flavor of its history.)

These days the station has been refurbished and renewed beautifully. It has returned to its former grandeur and it could be said it is even better now than ever. The expanded food court is an example of this improvement across the board. The entire south side of the station houses a multitude of fast and fast casual eateries, cafes and bakeries that are as attractive to sit in as their products are tasty to eat and drink. It reminds of the amazing food court that was rebirthed at Union Station in Washington, DC, a few decades ago. 

30th Street is now both a high functioning contemporary transportation center and a "Please Touch" museum in the heart of America's first capital city. It has become a destination for rail travellers, city dwellers and visitors far and wide. 

Even parking has been streamlined and made safe and affordable. Picking up my son coming in from Latrobe on The Pennsylvanian, I was able to park across the street, take the walking bridge to the station using the smooth escalators, and be waiting for him at Track 7 as he emerged from the beneath the station platform, in just minutes.', "I miss going to 30th Street Station where they've ramped up on their procedures to prevent Covid19 while continuing their never ending quest to keep the grand ol lady of the rails regal and sublime. It's so pretty and smart! Going back there  again will symbolize a return to normal as well as freedom to those of us in self-quarantine.", 'I loved everything about this lovely train station.  The staff was friendly and helpful.  The station was beautiful.  Every aspect of passing through was wonderful.  It is a great place.  Thank you Philadelphia for making our vacation special and providing such a great place.']

name: Chez Bow Wow Pet Grooming
categories_raw: Pets, Pet Services, Pet Groomers, Pet Training
top_reviews:
['I want to begin by saying that I was a regular customer here and always left with a groom that I was quite pleased with.
On my final visit, I dropped off my dog at around 8am, expecting to pick him up around noon (I had an afternoon picnic to go to and told them I was hoping to pick him up before 1).  
At around 1, when I had not heard back, I called to see if he was almost ready to be picked up and I was told he was up next for grooming.  I decided to make the drive to Northern Liberties (I live on the other side of the city) and have lunch at a local restaurant and wait for the phone call to pick up my dog.
At 3:30, when I still had not received a phone call, I called the salon again, and was told he was being groomed and they would call me shortly.
At 4:45 (knowing the salon closed at 5) I called back to tell them I was coming to get my dog, finished or not. 

The salon charged me full price for my dog ($70) but did not offer any reasoning why it took 9 hours OR apologized about my inconvenience or the fact that me entire afternoon plans were lost. I cannot imagine a salon keeping a dog for 9 hours let alone an anxious dog who does not do well at the groomer.

I will cut my dogs hair myself before putting him through a grooming session at chez bow wow.', 'We call this place Chez Ow Ow Ow. 

I was in the neighborhood and my dog needed her nails trimmed so I took her in. 

Horrible, horrible, horrible. 

From the "I couldn't care less" customer service to the way they manhandled by dog, to the annoying "I'm going to let your dog sit here uncomfortably while I talk with my douchebag friends" to the absolute butcher job they did on my dog's nails. 

Seriously, there was blood everywhere. And she continued to bleed for an hour after.

Just horrible. If this is how they handle dogs when owners are standing by, I'd hate to see what they do when owners drop them off and pick them up later.', "IF I COULD GET THEM NEGATIVE STARS I WOULD. 

I was reluctant to make this post because I take pride in supporting local businesses in NoLibs, but the kind of dishonesty that Gwendolyn (the owner) pulled a little while ago can't go untold to dog parents looking for a place to bring their dog for a grooming. I would not trust them to care for a toy dog, let alone a real one after this experience. 

First, the bait and switch. These guys are pro's at it. They'll lure you in a $50-$60 cut (all in) and then afterwards try to charge you all extras based on fabricated reasons - ranging from extra brushing to the funniest/most ridiculous one I got from them was a supposed extra charge based on the breed of my dog. 

Second, it's a mess in there. It doesn't look like they vacuum after each grooming because there's extra dog hair all over the ground and in the air. 

Third, they don't follow through on their appointments and treat customers in an obnoxious and aloof fashion. I was bringing my dog there before a big family event. I told the staff months in advance (and confirmed a few days prior) the importance of timing and getting the full groom done that day. When my girlfriend brought my dog 5 minutes before the scheduled appointment, they said they didn't have my dog scheduled for that time and didn't have any availability for grooming. My girlfriend left and called me. After patiently walking through the owner about their scheduling mistake, she had the guts to act like she was doing me a favor and tell me that because it was 15 minutes after my scheduled appointment at that point (the lateness of course which was due to their own efforts), they could only do a brush out. But would need to charge full price of groom because of X, Y, and Z. Needless to say, that was the last time I entertained this place. What a joke. 

Go to another reputable place - Spots spot is night and day compared to here."]

name: Chickie Wah Wah
categories_raw: Jazz & Blues, Italian, Arts & Entertainment, Restaurants, Nightlife, Cajun/Creole, Music Venues
top_reviews:
["PLEASE DO NOT SUPPORT THIS VENUE!!!  They treat musicians like absolute crap.  Dale the soundman/part owner obviously has anger management issues.  
My band was supposed to play their last week, but because of Dale we actually walked out of the gig!  I have never in all my years as a musician been treated with the utmost disrespect, and flat out rudeness by anyone, ever!  And I've played some pretty seedy places with some pretty mean soundguys, but nothing compares to this!  All because I asked for a microphone in front of my amp and not a Direct Input! I swear!!! Then came a barrage of profanity directed at me.  When I first arrived to the gig I introduced myself to him and he flat out said nothing back.  Not even a look! Unbelievable.  This was the first time in my life I ever walked out of a gig, and probably the last I hope.
If you care about the treatment of musicians, or just the everyday ethical treatment of humanity, PLEASE BOYCOTT THIS PLACE!  
In the parking lot I met another musician who said that 6 months ago the same thing happened to him, and he walked out too!  How is this place still in business?
I must say though, Dixie, the other owner, was very friendly and polite to us when we arrived.  Its too bad the ship is going down because of this Dale guy.
So please, while you're enjoying all that the wonderful city of New Orleans has to offer, please scratch this off your list of things to do.  Nobody in this world deserves disrespect like that!", "My girlfriend and I went for our first time tonight and our experience was shocking seeing as we didn't make it more than 5 feet from the door before we were confronted by who I'm assuming was the owner/manager who wanted to know if we were there for the show. We told him we came for beer and BBQ and was informed, in a very rude manner, that this was NOT a restaurant, but a music venue with a cover charge, and we would have to take ourselves outside to eat..... WOW. This guy must have failed How to Treat A Customer 101. 

Still somewhat taken back by how unwelcoming this guy was, we decided to not spend any money on drinks here and instead just ordered BBQ and ate outside.

The kicker... when we went to bring our empty BBQ plates back in, we didn't make it inside because he opened the door, took the plates, and shut it before we could step in to see about washing out hands. 

It's a shame to see places that look like they have great potential literally turn away customers in their tracks because of unfriendly and outright rude management. Won't be back.", 'I have to wonder...Why do so many food places come and go through Chickie Wah Wah? 

I sometimes wonder if the way the owners run the business is with too much of an air of arrogance.  I know when my Girly and I had a bad experience there, the owners/business never said anything but the business in the kitchen stepped up quickly to make things right.

Why can no one seem to stay in your tiny little kitchen area? You NEED good food to keep going. It seems like new, and often good, businesses keep popping in and out like they were TV shows on FOX. 

You are no longer that huge minority of places where people can drink and watch live music without smokers f-ing it up with their stank...So it might be time to get your stuff together and find a great place to partner with. Balance is everything.

You seem to always be off balance.']

name: Gio's
categories_raw: Nightlife, Bars, Italian, Wine Bars, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Solid 4 stars restaurant. We were early on the dinner. We're were the first customers. Most of the customers come around 7pm. If you looking for a romantic dinner, this may be your place. They have live music at night during weekend. Price is medium range at dinner, weekday lunch have better deal. Time change a bit for pandemic so call ahead. 

I got the Pesca Alla Griglia - grilled grouper with Italian herb and drizzle with balsamic vinegar. This dish come with two sides. It is sautéed veggies and potatoes. The sides are excellent. The grouper is fresh with good seasoning with grilled mark. 

Our second dish is the Pollo Scarparella. This is chicken breast sautéed with Italian sausage. It sauce with mushroom, roasted red pepper, onion in white wine with balsamic vinegar and Demi glazed sauce. The sauce is wonderful. This is a good dish to have. 

Service is good. Very attentive. Food has good taste and flavor. It is good for romantic night.", "Food still good. However, the ventilation need improvement. I like to sit in the dining hall and smell the fried garlic. But the food smell stick to the clothing. So don't wear or bring any leather cloth or purses. The food smell will difficult to get rid off. 

We got the pollo ala romana and spaghetti grouper Mediterraneo. We did change the grouper dish from spaghetti to angel hair pasta. The skill for the pasta is very good. It has some form noodle bouncing but not too soft. My wife say the grouper is a bit fishy smell. The chicken dish come with vegetable medley and top with prosciutto. It is delicious. 

Overall the service is good. The food come out a bit slow. It take 30 minutes wait. In addition they need to improve the dining room ventilation. I would still give them 4 stars until next visit. If this not changed, I will lower the stars on next visit.", 'I love pasta. I am not ashamed to admit that I like to satisfy my craving at Olive Garden. I know the OG gets criticized for its "Italian" food, but I still like it, so get over it already. Anywho, I have been trying to expand my restaurant repertoire, so I decided to research some authentic Italian food restaurants.

I looked here on Yelp for the highest rated Italian restaurants, and came up with a few options. After looking at reviews, menus, and location, I was most interested in Gio's. I read that the location was tucked away in a strip mall and a little hard to find, so the tip to look for Gold's Gym was helpful. I just took I-275 to Busch Gardens, turned right on Florida, then right on Waters, and it is on the right before Dale Mabry.

The outside of Gio's has an awning and a little bit of outside seating. Once entering, we were greeted, and promptly led to a table. It was lunchtime, and there was only one other table occupied. The dining room is fairly small, but makes good use of the space. There are wine bottles lining the wall, and a piano at the front, which is played on the weekends. The atmosphere felt a little classy actually, with dimmer lighting, a flower on each table, and nice tablecloths.

As I always do before going to a restaurant, I checked out the menu online to see what I would order. I had narrowed my choices to two pasta dishes, the Linguini Di Mare (Seafood linguini. Linguini with shrimp, calamari, clams, mussels and scallops in white or red tomato marinara sauce) and the Linguini Alla Vongole (Linguini with clams. Linguini with fresh clams in a red or white wine sauce). However, when I heard one of their specials was lobster ravioli, I promptly changed my mind. 

While waiting for our entrees we were brought bread and house salads, which come with lunch entrees. The bread was soft thankfully, because I hate getting bread where the crust might break my tooth. The house salad was very good, containing mixed greens, carrots, and their homemade dressing. Additonally, we ordered the Bruschetta Al Pomodoro appetizer (Thinly sliced fresh baguette brushed with olive oils and garlic and topped with fresh chopped tomato and basil). I really liked my lobster ravioli, which was done in their princess sauce, and contained a nice amount of filling. There were five ravioli, which was a good portion for me. My boyfriend ordered the Vitello Millanese (Veal dish. Pounded veal lightly breaded and topped with homemade bruschetta), and came with a side of bowtie pasta. 

The lunch prices are pretty reasonable, I think our entrees were about $13-$15. We took a peak at the dinner menu, and those items are quite pricey for us (in the $20s). The service was very good, and we had several different people remove finished plates and refill drinks. We will definitely go back for lunch.']

name: Earth Odyssey
categories_raw: Shopping, Hobby Shops, Gemstones & Minerals, Jewelry, Local Services, Psychics, Arts & Crafts, Watch Repair, Art Supplies, Flowers & Gifts, Gift Shops, Spiritual Shop, Arts & Entertainment, Astrologers, Supernatural Readings
categories: ['shopping', 'hobby shops', 'gemstones & minerals', 'jewelry', 'local services', 'psychics', 'arts & crafts', 'watch repair', 'art supplies', 'flowers & gifts', 'gift shops', 'spiritual shop', 'arts & entertainment', 'astrologers', 'supernatural readings']
top_reviews:
['Had a reading with Nancy in Dec of 2016, wanted to wait before I commented. She predicted a lot of things about my career....most of which never came to be.

She did hit on one thing when she said "news that benefits me give or take week from Jan 20th". It was around this time when my work was singled out by my old job I no longer worked for as exceptional.

She said in Feb of 2017 I'd see path in front of me clearly, nope.

Jan likely to make a commitment of some sort, nothing.

Said Flowers in feb in your something, again nope

Said March it's back to someone I've worked with before, didn't work with anyone in March, unemployed.

Say May looks good financially, May was beyond terrible financially.

If you want to hear good things told to you by all means call, I you want an accurate prediction then go to someone else for she was way with me.', "In the streets of the French Quarter away from the crowds and loudness you will find Earth Odyssey. A place to get in touch with your spiritual being, whether you are a devout believer or just a curious passerby, this is a great place to check out. My psychic for my visit was Jessica. Although nothing she foresaw really has happened (been over a year), I still found the experience very pleasant and intriguing. Aside from my reading, there is plenty of spiritual items and jewelry to pick up. I found customer service helpful in this area. Not pushy on sales but very knowledgeable and enlightening for any questions I had. My only knock is that I would like to see some truthfulness in my psychic readings but that is not really something I expect can be controlled! Overall, Earth Odyssey is a great place to check out if you're visiting or are just a spiritual person looking for a place to go. Definitely worth trying out!", "My first every fortune reading of any kind! Can't say I wasn't some what skeptical, still excited and curious regardless.

There are so many psychic reading being offered in New Orleans. I've always wanted to try it. So what's better place to have my first experience than here right? I had to depend on Yelp (again) to help me decide. Didn't have the time, or really wanted to pay hundreds of dollars for several different ones. 

We happened to walk by Earth Odyssey and I recognized the name from Yelp. Came in to make an appointment. They were fully booked for that day (we were leaving the next day), but said they'll take me in for the last appointment. Awesome!

The ladies here are all so nice and friendly. While waiting for my turn, I had some time to look around the store. They have so manyyyyyyy things that you can get here as far as jewelry, energy rocks, souvenirs, etc...

Overall, my reading went fairly well. She was able to tell me a few things about myself and my current situation that a complete strangers wouldn't know otherwise. At the same time, there wasn't much detail of anything about the future, but that wasn't surprising. The only down side is, because I was the last customer of the day, she did my reading a little too quick. It lasted maybe 15-20mins, compares to the one that went in before me, hers lasted close to 30-40mins. Lesson learned, I would definitely do another one, but would not schedule anything close to their closing time."]

name: Blanc Beauty Bar
categories_raw: Nail Salons, Hair Removal, Beauty & Spas, Hair Stylists, Waxing, Hair Salons
top_reviews:
["Walking into this modern beauty bar everything seems so relaxing and quiet. Not your typical salon that's noisy and technicians screaming across the salon. I walked in and was greeted by their friendly host. She sat me down in my pedicure chair and assisted on me right away. As I was sitting there she brought me over many pallets of colors to choose from.  I found the perfect dip color for my nails and my toes I always stick to French.  My technician came and he started on my pedicure right away. He was very friendly and he made sure every step of the way that I was happy with his service. A+++++. Even when he was painting my French pedicure Ryan made sure that it was up to my expectation. Once my pedicure was done, he assisted me over to the bar top manicure station. He started on my dip manicure, usually during this time I get very nervous because I never know what's the outcome of my nails.  He was very detailed on my nails and made sure every finger looked perfect.  I was in shock that Ryan did such a perfect job on my pedicure and my dip manicure. Usually I always have to tell the technician wherever I go to do a certain way up to my liking. But with Ryan I didn't have to say a thing besides that I wanted my nails square shape... 

I highly recommend this Salon to anyone that is visiting Nola because I'm a visitor as well and found this Gem. Now everytime I visit Nola I know exactly where to go to get my pedicure & manicure done! 

Btw... when I was sitting there I notice that after every client the staffs at the salon they really do disinfect their area down... That's a big plus in my books...", 'So yesterday I started looking for an eyebrow threading place in the area since my normal place doesn't do threading till Thursday (esthetique facial spa- amazing) and I'm leaving for Santa Barbara on Wednesday. I call three places, no threading. I call Blanc- they have threading (yay!). I am told to make an appointment so I get one at 5:45 (when the man on the phone reads it back to me he says 4:45 and I correct him- no big deal) 
I drive over and walk in at 4:45 to see the place with one customer and 6 or 7 people all standing together in the middle of the place talking (staff meeting I guess?) everyone looks over at me and I feel like I'm interrupting. There is also an adorable dog in a costume and that is worth a star at least. The man at the counter has me sign in and tells me to go back and points to the back of the place where a girl is standing in a doorway. I walk to her, go to the room and lay down on the chair. At this point I notice she is warming up wax and specify that I had asked for threading "oh we don't do threading" oh. The girl said she felt bad and said I could leave if I wanted to. I walk out and the 6 or 7 staff members and dog in costume all turn to look at me- intimidating, uncomfortable, cute (dat dog tho) The man at the desk asks what went wrong, I tell him that I wanted my eyebrows threaded not waxed and specially called earlier to make sure that they threaded. I tell him that the man I made the appointment with confirmed they do threading, at which he looks over at a man in the group and the man says "I heard waxing". Everyone kind of stands there for a beat just uncomfortable silencing (dog included) and then I say alright bye and walk out. 

1 star for the place being so beautiful, 1 star for the dog in costume 

Now I will go to Santa Barbara with a unibrow. Oh well.', 'Chris Rock once said, " Women only need three things to exist: food, water and compliments. Oh, and shoes." I'd venture to substitute one of these things for a great pedicure. I found such at Blinc.

I'd driven past for months, meaning to stop by. Finally had the chance this weekend and was so happy I did! Airy, spacious, devoid of that formaldehyde smell. Took me perhaps five minutes to select a color - the array was vast. My nail tech was wonderful and the beverage service was superb. Some may squawk at the cost, but the level of cleanliness and service options were definitely worth it.']

name: Sprouts Farmers Market
categories_raw: Food, Grocery, Specialty Food, Health Markets, Farmers Market, Organic Stores
top_reviews:
['Mixed feelings here.
I'd give a 5 for their cupcakes!
Next time you go to sprouts get the Chocolate Peanut Butter cupcakes if that's your thing. Good Lord, I was making love to those things lol so good! Cookies were okay, but I'll skip those next time, and focus on more cupcakes. LOVE the Albanese Gummi Bears! Just Love.

Produce- Yes, it's cheap, but I have not been happy with what I've bought there so far. 
Cherries had no flavor.
Parsley seemed great, but started turning yellow after a day & a half.
Cantaloupe- not very sweet at all. 
Bananas- didn't seem over ripe from the outside, but when peeled were brownish. 

Sigh... I'll come back here for the sweets, but more than likely not buy anymore produce. 

Prices are really high on some items. Like REALLY high for breads to be more specific .. etc
Even on things that are "all natural" not even organic. 

C'mon, be serious Sprouts. Your shit is going to rot or get freezer burn when nobody buys it because the price is ridiculous. 

It's literally a very mixed bag here so they get a 3.', "Why 5 stars? Because I already know I'll be a regular.

   ---   ---   ---

I didn't know much about Sprouts, but I read a few articles about it as they prepared to open, and I knew I'd be visiting as soon as I could. If a place near my house opens that has groceries, especially specialty and/or healthy groceries -\xa0I'm going to be there really often.

My first visit was the third day of Sprouts being open. If I was claustrophobic, I may not have made it out of there alive. I don't think I've ever seen this many people in a grocery store. But I pushed through the crowd and definitely saw plenty of great stuff! Whether you're looking for specialty groceries, organic produce, or fresh meals you can simply heat up - you'll find it worth your time to fight through the new store crowds.

I ordered the italian trio sandwich and was a bit off put when I got home to see that it was on very basic wheat bread, and that it included mustard, which was not noted on the menu board. My wife ordered a panini, and I was so jealous, that I returned the next night to order one of my own.

This time, I went with the caprese panini, but I added the meat from the Italian trio. I can't recommend this combination enough - it was amazing.

I do want to point out that the sandwich ordering process seems a bit convoluted. There are little ordering sheets for when you order something custom, which is confusing and definitely seems like what you have to use for any sandwich. There are different types of these sheets, which adds to the confusion.

When the sandwich maker is putting your order together, they don't do it in front of you. They take your order, and head to the back, and out pops your sandwich a few minutes later. They did not ask me for any clarification on my order during either visit, hence the unwanted mustard and bread on my first round. Also, it took an inordinate amount of time to make my sandwich on the second night, but I'll chalk that up to it being their first week open. It was just frustrating to see 10-15 employees on the other side of the counter, but only one making sandwiches. Again, we'll chalk these issues up to the first week blues.

In the long run, the only bad thing about Sprouts opening is that I feel like there's going to be a casualty in the neighborhood. Between Publix, Whole Foods and even Abby's... can all of these survive in such a small area? I don't know, but I'm going to enjoy them all as long as I can.", "If you are going to dream about something here at Sprouts, it's those prices on the produce.
