Wow I can definitely tell the difference.  Please oh please come to Wesley Chapel. It would be wonderful.

Another dream come true are the raspberry lemonade cupcakes with lemon curd inside. Wow, yes so happy I picked them up.

I came here at 9pm on a Saturday. All I could think of was who comes here on a Saturday night? I got over it and was happy to see the selection of produce and the items I picked up. 

I also picked up the biggest scallops ever and it was an awesome price for sure. My pomegranate seeds were more than half off than the price at Publix too.

This store is a winner in my eyes. Too bad I'm Not ALWAYS in the area, but when I am, I am for sure stopping here."]

name: Sockeye Brewing
categories_raw: Sandwiches, American (Traditional), Restaurants, Nightlife, Salad, American (New), Breweries, Bars, Food, Gastropubs, Pubs
top_reviews:
['This place is absolutely gorgeous! I love how the incorporated the river birch inside since they are surrounded by it.  So neat! 
The food being run to the tables looked so freaking good! I hate rye bread but I was so close ordering the Reuben sandwich... it just looked that incredible. I ended up ordering a poblano chicken sandwich... it had all of my favorite stuff on it... but it was really bland.. kind of a bummer.
My wife ordered the salmon fish n chips.. she loved it.
My son ordered the Mac n cheese and said it was gross... which is weird because that's his go to.
My mom and her friend both ordered the spinach steak salad and said it was "sooooo good!!", so I definitely know what I'm ordering next time. 
I know it's a brewery and they have to push their beer but I really wish they had a full bar. 
All in all dinner was good. I wouldn't really recommend it to someone who is looking for a great meal but would totally recommend for someone looking for a great patio.', "We had an auditor in town from Michigan and we wanted to take him somewhere unique to Idaho for lunch.  He's a microbrew type of guy so one of our employees suggested Sockeye Grill & Brewery.  This was our first time eating here as well and we were pleasantly surprised.  It is very nice and clean inside with a warm atmosphere.  There was variety in tastes around the table... salmon pita, cheeseburger, crispy chicken, finger steaks and of course various beers.  The winners of the day are Hell-Diver Finger Steaks and the Hell-Diver Pale Ale.  Once I tried a bite of the finger steaks with the smoked tri-tip I couldn't go back to the bland crispy chicken.  They recently updated the menu and offer the full menu all day (no lunch specials).  It was a great place to go and carry a conversation for business.  We will be back to check it out on a weekend as well :)", 'There is a LOT to review here, so I'm going to split into their brewery side and the restaurant side. 

Brewery: Sockeye is a central hub for Boise. They've been around for a long time and they make some damn good beers. I love their Lonesome Larry Lager (mostly because I can give my table mates a fun Idaho history lesson that none of them asked for, lol) and the Woolybugger Wheat. 

Sockeye beverages are everywhere. You can find them in all the major grocery stores and on tap at a lot of restaurants. Their brews are tried and true and they really reflect Idaho. You can do a brewery tour here too, which is super fun. You'll just need to set it up in advance. I absolutely love the smell of beer brewing. It smells homey to me. Yup, I know that's weird. 

Restaurant: I was very bummed when their Cole location closed. It was a favorite haunt for my old co-workers and one of our favorite places to have "choir practice". But the Fairview location is HUGE and beautiful. They can accommodate very large groups. My father in law loves to take us all out to dinner when he comes to town (and this ends up being 15-ish people) so we frequently come to Sockeye. They can always get us in and don't seem to mind our large horde of loud Italians and squalling babies. They have a large, nice patio with plenty of shade for the summer months. 

The food is pretty good. Probably my least favorite thing about the whole experience. Nothing has ever been bad or even mediocre, but I never leave feeling wowed. I would recommend the trout though. Trout screams Idaho to me and Sockeye does it well.']

name: Lather Hair Studio
categories_raw: Skin Care, Hair Salons, Beauty & Spas, Makeup Artists
top_reviews:
["I had a friend convince me to try this place.  I usually keep my hair really short, can't get rid of the military in me I guess, but I let my hair grow much longer than usual so I could warrant a salon hair cut.  Dena cut my hair, she is super nice and put up with all of my craziness with a smile.  I went during the happy hour times where you can get a drink while your in the chair, definitely a different experience than i'm used to.  There is a world of difference here and I can't say enough good things about this place.  They can do wonders even for one, such as myself, stuck in a style that needs an update.

Update:  I was back for my 3rd or 4th time, I can't remember.  Had possibly the best haircut i've ever gotten yesterday.  Like I said earlier, I usually kept my hair military short and have had a hard time letting it grow to warrant a visit to Lather.  Dena is awesome, she put up with all my weirdness and completely understood what I was going for, but made the cut so much better than I had hoped.  This is a place you simply can't pass up.", "I've been to several different places to get my hair did. Barber shops, salons, my step-sister in the kitchen, a hand mirror and a razor, etc. etc. Lucky for me these clown options are a thing of the past, because I've found the best salon in town.

The vibe is perfect. The decor is welcoming. Each room has it's own unique color scheme while maintaining a constant narrative throughout the space. The music is always cool and sexy. The natural light accents the salon like a cherry on top.

The space isn't just eye candy. You're going to get quality cuts and color from the best in the business. Although Lather is a new salon, the staff members are all seasoned professionals who finally broke out on their own. Clients get everything they would expect from a high-end, swanky, Old City / Center City Salon. The difference: clients don't pay high-end swanky prices, and support a local neighborhood business. It's win-win.

I now look forward to my hair growing out, because I get to visit my new friends at lather. I always leave with a smile on my face and a new clean look that makes me feel great!", 'I decided to try and find a place in the area to get a cut and a style today. Lather was the only spot open in the Art Museum area today (of the 5 or so places I looked at)...lucky me! Dena was able to fit me in first thing today. Her salon is cute and bright with natural sunlight coming in the front. Dena was very sweet and friendly throughout and did a fantastic job with my conditioning treatment, cut, and style. Next time, I want to come back and try a color treatment. This place rocked!']

name: Bury The Hatchet
categories_raw: Local Flavor, Recreation Centers, Amateur Sports Teams, Active Life
top_reviews:
["First of all, can we talk about how amazing our Axe Master, LEX was?!? So engaging, humorous, and full of so many good vibes!!!
I didn't know what to expect during my first axe throwing adventure, but the other group my group partnered with were some cool people. The mini games were super fun and creative with the addition of connect four and 21. We played 21 for an official axe throwing trophy on the line that I kinda won...cough cough...Anyway lol
Of course it was BYOB and there was a local beer spot a block away. The best part was learning the technical aspects of throwing from LEX who made us comfortable with our terrible throwing lol 
Overall I can't wait to Axe throw again. Next time I'm bringing cheese steaks", "I definitely had my reservations about axe throwing, like how fun could it possibly be? I'm happy to report however, that it's a lot of fun! 
The space is super laid back which adds to the jovial atmosphere. It's a byob which is awesome! And everyone there brought food to enjoy in between throws. We ended up getting pizza delivered. 
Bury the Hatchet doesn't just give you an axe and tell you to have fun. There are different games to enjoy and an axe master assigned to each group to keep score, offer pointers, and occasionally taunt you. The different games keep it interesting. The two hours flew by!
For $40 I can't think of a better way to enjoy two hours of your life. Whether you want to unleash some simmering rage, learn a helpful post-apocalyptic skill, or just partake in something a little different, definitely check this out if you haven't already!", 'I'm obsessed!!!!!! I've been to Bury the Hatchet twice now. Once for a special event, and again with my friends and family. My most recent visit included 4 of us, so we were paired up in the same lane as another larger group of people (because I think they want 10-12 people per lane). At first, we were apprehensive about this, because we saw 8 other people getting paired up with my group of 4, so my group thought we would get overtaken by the other group ,and our axe throwing time would get minimized, and we wouldn't get as many chances to throw. After 15 minutes, we realized that was not the case. The Axe Master made sure that everyone was participating, and quickly, so that we all had multiple chances to through, often, over and over again. 

We started with a game called "get off my court" which basically means 2 people go head-to-head, 1 shot, and the winner stays in the lane to throw again, against a new opponent, as the loser exits the lane. This was a good quick way to get us throwing the axes to get used to the technique and feel, but also to give everyone plenty of turns. After maybe 30-45 mins of this, we played a new game of boys vs. girls teams, and the team with the most points wins. This was really fun also, and even though it split up our groups, it was OK since we all bonded fine and had a great time. It was a great team building experience. I would have rathered we played a "bracket style" tournament where I can compete against everyone else to have 1 winner. We did this at Urban Axes and I liked it better.

But overall, I love this activity, and this facility. I think Bury the Hatchet is better than its competitor Urban Axes in north philly because Bury the Hatchet has a more social trendy atmosphere.There are TVs to watch the game, cozy couches/chairs to socialize and hang out while others are throwing axes, and BYOB refrigerators near every lane. Also, the layout of the place has all the axe lanes around the edge of the room, leaving the middle of the room wide open for socializing, instead of the competitor whos layout is more like parking lot style lanes where you walk down each row of lanes. 

I love axe throwing, its my new favorite activity over bowling, ping pong, darts, etc. Go on the website, reserve your spot early, because it fills up and sells out fast. Usually $35-$40pp for 2 hrs. Totally worth it, I love this place! Tip: BOYB and BYO Food. There are pizza menus there, which you can order pizza delivery near by. Also, I forgot to comment on how amazing the staff is here... soo friendly, helpful, and they all just rock, and really love their jobs. Makes the experience so much more fun!']

name: Buffalo Bell
categories_raw: Chicken Wings, Burgers, Restaurants, American (Traditional)
top_reviews: ['okay, im not just writing here because my daddy owns this place, but the hot wings are really REALLY good! they have different levels of spices, and the sauce is yummmmmmmmmy! its a secret family recipe! i always go for the medium sauce cause its sour and spicy enough for me to enjoy. & i love celery sticks dipped in ranch sauce. the ranch sauce is home made also, and its delicious! they offer alot of other stuff too like burgers, fries, zucchini, fried shrimps and other fried stuff, ribs, toast, shakes and alot of other variety of drinks. (but no beer, haha.) everything is made when you order so its super fresh and hot.  its a good size small fast food place, but you can dine in too, it has A/C cause u know how hot arizona gets, a tv to watch while you eat, clean restrooms, and my family are very friendly! or u can takeout. there is a drive through window too. =) since i live in cali, i only see my daddy once or twice a year. everytime i do go, i cant wait to eat his chicken! i crave for it all the time! i always joke with him to overnight it to me, lol. \n\nyou should def. go in and try their buffalo wings, and you will be addicted... just like me!', 'So everyone is right, you gotta come here for the wings. We ordered about a dozen wings, the bbq flavor, some seasoned fries and the potato skins. Lets start with the wings, they were very saucy, fried hard and they were good. I sort of wished I had ordered them with light Sauce cause they were really saucy. The seasoned fries were really good. I was surprised! The potato skins were also good with cheese and crispy bacon! The customer service could use some help but overall a good visit!', 'Family owned business that makes great wings!  I come here once a week and they treat me like family.  Just replaced tables so its much nicer']

name: Ironwood Dermatology
categories_raw: Health & Medical, Medical Spas, Dermatologists, Doctors, Beauty & Spas, Skin Care, Hair Removal
top_reviews:
['I had two nevi (moles) removed several years ago at Ironwood Dermatology.  Obviously I had a bad experience, and I am sure some of you had great experiences here.  But mostly importantly, I want to share my experience to help those who got misinformed or recently had a disservice at Ironwood so you know your options when things go south.


WHAT HAPPENED?

Long story short (still pretty long so keep reading if you think it will help, otherwise skip to the next section), both of my moles removal wounds did not heal right and got staph infection, which was determined by another medical facility through a culture test.  Ironwood Dermatology refused to acknowledge that my wounds were inflected.  Instead, they said the wounds were not inflected, and all wounds have staph bacteria, so it's normal.  While I tried to seek for second option from another physician outside of Ironwood, they stopped me from doing so by telling me that they knew the situation the best and would not want me to get a check-up by another clinic or hospital.  So they wouldn't give me a referral.

After a couple weeks later with the wounds not being healed, I contacted the other hospitals and clinics and hoping to schedule an outside opinion, and unfortunately all of my requests got rejected because no one wanted to touch my wounds due to legal reasons.

I revisited Ironwood many times while I was struggling, and usually an assistant would do the check-up, but never the Doctor himself (Trout).  At one point I finally demanded to have Trout to take a look at the wounds, he actually said "I didn't know this turned out like this", but still decided to wrapped the wound back with new patches and not do anything else about it.  Note that it costed me extra $30 just to see him, and he did the same exact thing that the assistant had done; by doing nothing.

Fortunately I have connections in medical field so I got a Surgeon involved, who then determined that my wounds were indeed bacteria infected wounds and also considered as "defected wounds".  

Now, a doctor typically won't tell you this is a malpractice, otherwise they will have to attest against the other doctors, and most of them don't want to go that route.  So "defect wound" is the safest way for them to tell you "this is not done right" and still staying out of trouble.  Anyway, the Surgeon performed the surgery by cutting out the rotten meat.  One of the wounds healed within a week, while the other one still have a bit "leaking".  This "leaking" is caused by "undissolved stiches", according to Behr, who took care of Trout's mess several months later.  Sound familiar from other reviews so far?

After the wounds were healed, I got a hold of a medical malpractice attorney, who determined that this would be a $60,000 to $70,000 lawsuit, but since no doctors would attest against another doctor in the same state, we would need to get two doctors out of state to do this job.  To do that, it would cost me $4,000 out of pocket in advance.  Trout is lucky that I was only a student at that time and I didn't have $4k.


WHAT I WOULD TELL MY LOVE ONES TO DO:

So here are a few things I would tell my kids or my parents if they have similar experience (I cannot advise or recommend anything to readers):

1.  It's okay to have a small procedure done at Ironwood for biopsy purposes.  If any physician here decides to "go-large" on your biopsy wound due to a skin cancer concern, MAKE SURE YOU REQUEST A REFERRAL TO SEE A PLASTIC SURGEON.  This was the biggest mistake I made; assuming all doctors are equal.  I am sure some dermatologists are great, but many of them don't receive enough surgical training.  DO NOT TAKE THE CHANCE, GO SEE A REAL SURGEON FOR YOUR OWN SAKE.

2.  If the damages are already done, make sure you record everything.  Date and time, etc.  Keep all your records.

3.  You have every right to seek for outside opinion.  If they refuse to refer you, ask them to put that in writing or just record the conversation with your cell phone.  You need to have this documented in case you want to pursue legal action.

4.  If you are really in pain, just go to an emergency care.  Yes, you will have to pay for it, but better then dying with infection.  I hesitated and delayed the treatment for more than a week.  I hope you don't make the same mistake.

5.  Many people actually don't know this but if you can't afford a lawyer, you can still report a doctor at Arizona Medical Board.  Sometimes a clinic might decide to settle your concern even without getting a lawyer involved.  AZ Med. Board actually takes those issues seriously.  With enough issues reported, the doctor will be under heavy reviews and they do NOT like that.  I didn't know this back then, and it's too late for me to report Trout since my case already passed the mark.

NOTE: I am not in medical or legal field, just sharing my experience here.  Please consult with a medical or a legal advisor first before implementing any of the methods above.', 'I went to see Dr. Behr because I was concerned about a red blotch on my face. She came in and spent literally 1 minute looking at me then said it was normal and that I should use sunscreen. She never even attempted to look at the rest of my skin which any good dermatologist always should do and she never asked if I had any questions before she suddenly left. Even more disappointing is that she charged my insurance over $200 for the appointment.', 'I had an appt with Dr. Glassier scheduled to check a purple/black irregular mole that developed very rapidly on my chest.  I checked in and waited.  And waited.  A man and woman who came in after me and sat next to me began talking.  He was apparently a friend of the doc, assuring his girlfriend that despite not having an appointment, he would get her in to inspect the pinhead-sized white dot on her forearm.  Although I had an appointment and had been waiting a good 45 minutes, they were called in ahead of me.  I was then shuttled back to a room, where after waiting another 20 minutes, a tech came in, looked at my mole, told me it was likely genetic and cosmetic, and sent me on my way.  The doc never saw me, but I saw her chewing the fat with her "friend" in another room.  Real professional...']

name: Parada Maimon
categories_raw: Latin American, Caribbean, Dominican, Mexican, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Right on the edge of Center City Philadelphia is a bright and cheery Dominican restaurant called Parada Maimon.  This is def a good place to know about as it serves down-home Dominican food in addition to breakfasts and items like Philly cheesesteaks at incredibly low prices. Everyone is friendly here and the food is tasty.  Their lunch specials served all day are amazing.  I recently enjoyed the oxtail platter which came with yellow rice, salad, black beans, and sweet plantains for less than $7.  Wow!  But you def have to add one or more of their pastelitos.  The chicken one was yummy.  There Is a cool atmosphere with lots of rustic wood here and even an outdoor eating area. And did I mention free Wifi? There are a few free parking spots to the side of the building or if you come by foot you are two minutes walk from Chinatown or the Reading Terminal Market. Parada Maimon is a great and affordable addition to the Center City dining scene!', "We stumbled in here headed back to our car after the Eagles Victory Parade!  It's a bit away from the city center and casual. We needed a place to warm up, fill up on lunch, and use the facilities.  And Parada Maimon looked to fit the ticket (and I didn't even consult the Yelp reviews prior).

The lunch portions were huge, the food flavorful and delicious, prices inexpensive, and service pleasant.  And, they even had a large flat screen TV for us to continue to view the Philadelphia festivities still going on at the Art Museum.  

We ordered the Ropa Vieja and the Coconut Fish.  Both were accompanied with choice of Spanish or white rice as well as the choice of red or black beans.  The one issue I had with the food was that it was too salty for my taste.", 'This is my second time ordering food from the restaurant. The food here is top-notch quality and VERY authentic!!  Everything I have ordered reminds me of home. My mother is Puerto Rican and she is not local, therefore any time I can get some "homestyle" cooking I am brought to my happy place. While the restaurant promotes itself as being Dominican, there are many Cuban and Puerto Rican style dishes on the menu. I have ordered the Pollo guisado (Stewed chicken), arroz con gandules (yellow rice with pigeon peas), arroz blanco con habichuelas (white rice and red beans), pastelitos (fried patties) pargo (snapper), and maduros (sweet plantains).  All very well seasoned!!!  I cannot comment on the dining services because I have ordered takeout each time. The interior of the restaurant is quaint and I look forward to being able to enjoy a dining experience there one day. Keep in mind that they are BYOB. The portions are grand so be prepared and have a heavy appetite. The prices are more than fair. I honestly think they could probably get away with charging a bit more for the size portions that they provide. and I'm definitely not complaining because I appreciate being able to get great quality food at a more than fair price and enjoy several meals from one purchase.  

And BONUS! This is a minority-owned small business. I'm all for supporting local small businesses! Wepa!']

name: Piezanos Rustic Pizza and Wine
categories_raw: Restaurants, Pizza, Food, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Italian
top_reviews:
["I used to come to this location when it was Vito's (one of the few pizzerias that had salami had a topping).  Such a great location for those of us who live in the area and want to frequent local businesses.

Three of us tried Piezano's two weeks ago and we were impressed.  My girlfriend and I split the Caesar and then we ordered two pies.  Great sauce and fresh toppings.  Having had such a great experience, my girlfriend and I returned a few days ago.  We decided that the Caesar is probably one of the best in Tucson and we wanted to try the wings (5$ on Wednesday).  And order another pizza. 

Once again, we weren't disappointed.  The wings were lean and not fatty like you find in other places.  The pizza was great again.  We've ordered the meat pie both times and the sausage is a little on the spicy side (so dont douse the slice with dried peppers until you try it).

I agree with the other reviewer: I hope this place lasts too!

Can I suggest adding salami as a topping?", "We didn't expect to find such cozy ambiance in this pizza place, which from the outside looks like any other strip mall in Tucson. The pizza is quite good! We tried the Greek and the Sonoran - I wasn't too excited about ordering the Sonoran (green chiles with pizza sauce didn't sound so good), and though it wasn't my favorite, it wasn't bad either (everyone else at the table really liked it).  The Greek was excellent, with spinach, black olives, chicken, and a heavy dose of feta - yum! They make a pretty decent Caesar salad, and the house chicken wings were tangy and juicy. There is a limited but nice selection of wine and beer, including a couple gluten-free offerings. And for the gluten-intolerant, gluten-free crust is also available. 

This place clearly has a loyal following. Both times we've been here, the owner was there, chatting with the regulars. Friendly staff. This isn't Blackjack, so expect your pizza to take a bit longer to cook - however, it's well worth the wait.", "The husband and I picked up a pie to go on our way out of town (because nothing is better than eating pizza while you're driving.. right?!?). The pizza was ready to go when we got there, hot and tasty. It's fairly standard pizza, but I would pick it up again. It's worth a shot."]

name: Sully Mansion Bed & Breakfast
categories_raw: Hotels & Travel, Hotels, Event Planning & Services, Venues & Event Spaces, Bed & Breakfast
categories: ['hotels & travel', 'hotels', 'event planning & services', 'venues & event spaces', 'bed & breakfast']
top_reviews:
['I am seriously perplexed why these owners have a B&B - they don't like people!

We stayed here because it had good reviews.  We take reviews, especially yelp, very seriously. 

Unfortunately, we have never been so disappointed with something that had some great reviews.

To sum it up, just in case you don't have time to read all the details, here is the breakdown of why you should not stay here.

Owners are dishonest.
Owner, Nancy, took part in inappropriate conversation at breakfast.
Downright rude.
Play favorites with their guests.  If your not "in" they certainly make you feel unwelcome. I have never been treated so badly.

Dishonest:  We booked a room with a Queen bed and a couch pull out for our friends who would be joining us.  We had much to do so weren't worried about spending too much time in the room and being cramped.  After the website has you pay for the room it says that you will be charged and extra $25/per person/per night, if you have more than two people.  We were going to have 4 adults.  So, the difference between the REAL cost of that room, that was very underhanded, and just upgrading to the next size was very close.  
  So, I take it upon myself to call and clarify over the phone.  I asked very specific questions and got a solid quote over the phone from the owner Nancy.  Bottom line was, they weren't going to charge us the extra $50/night.  How nice.  But, not really. They did charge us at the end and said they have no reason to believe that I was telling the truth about the conversation we had.  Wow, i have never been called a liar.  I was floored.  Nancy went on to try and "prove" her case against me....(guess the customer is never right in their business).  Nancy said she had no record in her notes that we had the conversation. How convenient for their end of the deal. Yet, I have it on my email notes with date & time & exact amount she quoted.  I remembered precisely because I called my husband to tell him the "good news" after I got off the phone with her.
More dishonest tactics but I'll move on.

Inappropriate: I came in late the night we arrived so hadn't met the owners.  I show up at breakfast and get the "evil eye" from Nancy.  I assumed she was a guest who was in a terrible mood. No problem...I move on and look around to get an idea of how this B&B worked.  I asked, very politely, "so how does this work?" since I didn't see anyone who was running the show or welcoming me as a guest.  Nancy huffs at me under her breath and starts to explain how "the guest is to ask the owner.....".  She refers to herself as "the owner" several times yet never introduces herself or welcomes me.  I then realize that she IS the owner and I actually feel a little bad for asking how it works, so as not to embarrass her I say I haven't been to too many B&B's. That was me being too gracious, again.  I have been to enough B&B's, I'm from the Napa area for goodness sake.  Enough B&B's to know that I am supposed to feel welcome, not as if I've intruded in someone's home.  She never smiles at me.  Yet, makes it very obvious that she is quite happy to have all the other guests.  It was like a joke.  I truly looked up at the ceiling to see if I was on some kind of hidden camera show.  You know, like Boiling Point, or something.  One of those shows where you are so badly treated and they test you so much to see when you will break.  She is like this the entire weekend.  It was unreal.

Then she starts taking part in a conversation about politics over breakfast.  I'm no stick in the mud and want folks to have their breakfast conversations but that is just inappropriate.  And, I wasn't the only guest that felt that way.  But, since Nancy so aligned with the political viewpoint of her 4 other guests she carried on.  I got past it but another couple was seriously disturbed.

I can go on for so long but no more time.  Kids calling my attention away.  I imagine you get the jest.

Don't go here!!  And, spare your friends and family and remind them not to go here either.  You might be one of the few lucky folks that the owners decide to like....but if you are not, you are going to be in a world terrible treatment.  So bad you think it's a joke.  

I'll say it again, I'm still perplexed as to why they are running a B&B.  

I sure hope this saves you from having the terrible weekend we all had.', 'The owners are horrible.

And, you're paying way too much for what you get.  Location is pretty good. The 'mansion' is what you would expect in the district, but nothing special. You will pay top dollar for a "large" room that  is actually tiny and cannot accommodate the number of people that they claim.

I am no local, but lived in New Orleans for 2 years.  The owners of this place are from NY and know nothing about the area.  They're also rude and incompetent.  INCOMPETENT.  DISHONEST.  Don't trust their website. 

If you have a chance to go to New Orleans, good stuff. Worst time is Mardi Gras, best time is Jazz Fest.  And -- without children, stay in the Quarter close to Royal if you're young.  With children, stay Uptown by Loyola and Tulane - close to St. Charles (where the trolley runs to downtown) and find another b and b - there are plenty -- unfortunately, not many in NOLA or outside the SF bay treat yelp as the authority, so it's hard to judge.  I'm telling you though, this place sucks big time, sparing you the details.

Just don't stay at this place.', 'I meant to write this when we stayed at Sully Mansion in May, but put it out of my mind until someone asked me about where we had stayed on our NOLA trip and if I would recommend it. Short answer, absolutely not.  

When I stay at a B&B, I am used to a welcoming, homey experience. That is why one would choose a B&B over a hotel. That being said, it is incomprehensible that Nancy runs a B&B. She is so cold, unwelcoming, and downright rude, that we seemed to be a burden to her, not paying guests at her venue. Blaring music woke us up at the crack of dawn, drawing us to a mediocre spread for breakfast (average baked goods, cold, bland eggs and cereal). We attempted small talk as we were being stared down at the table, to which Nancy responded that she's "so tired of having the same conversations." Perhaps it was our age, as she was equally as nasty to our friends staying there (we're all in our thirties) but "delightful" according to my parents who came by to meet her. When I needed an extra towel, I received a condescending lecture on properly closing the shower curtain (also, why did I need to explain my request for an extra towel?). 

The accommodations were spacious but not luxurious, overpriced, and not worth the hassle of having to deal with Nancy. Despite the ideal location uptown, we will never stay here again, nor recommend this to our friends (many of whom make multiple and/or annual trips to New Orleans).']

name: Trattoria Carina
categories_raw: Restaurants, American (Traditional), Italian
top_reviews:
["Trattoria Carina blew me away.

From the attentive service to the incredible pasta to the BYOB option-- this dining experience was really top-notch. I'm not in Philly often enough to try the same restaurant twice, but I have a feeling I might have to make an exception for Trattoria Carina.

We started out with a variety of small plates -- meatballs, ricotta mushroom bruschetta, burrata topped with pistachio and prosciutto / sopersatta. Everything was standout but the meatballs definitely stole the show. If you are just going to order one app that would be my suggestion. 

Most of the main entrees are pasta, and with so many delicious options it's really hard to want anything else. My friend who has tried many items off the menu suggested going with the bolognese for my first time. She was absolutely spot on. The pasta was cooked perfectly al dente, came topped with the most flavorful meat sauce and had so much fresh parm. I tried some of my husband's chicken parm and that was also delicious. It was literally the size of an entire plate.

Did we over order? Yes. 
Was it worth it? Yes. 
Would I come here again? Heck yes.

A nod to getting old - I'd rather stuff my face in a plate of pasta over going into a bar on St. Patties day. But you know what? If I can do it at Trattoria Carina I don't mind.", '(to the tune of "Gorgeous" by Taylor Swift)

You should take it as a compliment
That I'm known for not loving Italian rest'rants
But I couldn't leave the neighborhood without
Visiting it's newest, adorable haunt

You could bring your mother, or even your bae
Whoever you bring, this place will brighten your day
The joint's so cool, it's sure to blow you away (blow you away)

cocktails on ice, few wines, they're nice
Will improve your night, just wait in that line

You're delicious
You make me want to stuff my face
I just love this place
And I'm so furious
That I'm just now moving further away
But what can I say
Delicious...

On a crisp Monday night, I went to celebrate some good news with my partner. We abstained from the adult beverages, opting to fill our stomachs with all the goodies they offered (minus the pasta, this time.) They bring you some DIVINE bread & olive oil (butter on request) after you order. After what felt like no time, the dishes were upon us.

Lobster soup - HOLY MOLY this meaty, warm bowl of heaven... There was SO much lobster meat in there, it could've been a meal. But we had just begun. Pumpkin & farro salad - came recommended, and with good reason. Grilled pumpkin, surprising and delicious, with a dressing that was refreshing without being too heavy. Three meatballs COVERED in a dusting of shaved ricotta. These meatballs were nice a big, a little tightly packed, but still tasty with the abundance of sauce. We also ordered a side of brussels sprouts, a special of the night, with capers, salsa verde, and MORE shaved ricotta - a real delight.

Finally, our entree - a special of the night, the braised beef shoulder over creamy polenta and broccoli rabe. Confession - the broccoli rabe was the only thing the servers brought that didn't rock my world. It tasted almost chemical-ish, like it was cooked under butane or something. HOWEVER I just pushed it aside, and focused on the velvet beef shoulder, which fell apart when you looked at it, and the polenta, which soaked up all the juices like the tastiest sponge. 

The servers were incredibly attentive and worked together seamlessly, without hovering. The pace was timed perfectly, and the whole experience was simply executed expertly. 

This is worth the trip, no matter what neighborhood you live.', "I can't tell you how happy I am to finally have a great Italian restaurant in the neighborhood! While I loved Fitler Dining Room, it was more of a once in a while restaurant for us. I can see Trattoria Carina popping up on the rotation far more often. 

The restaurant was buzzing on Saturday night -\xa0we lucked into one of the last open tables outside and it wasn't long before people were placed on a wait. At this time, reservations are not accepted. I kind of like it -\xa0there aren't many places that offer first come first served, so Carina is perfect for a night when you didn't plan ahead but still want a nice dinner.

There is a short list of cocktails and also red, white, rosé and sparkling wine, which you can get by the glass or bottle. The menu is broken into starters, salads, pastas, mains and sides. We wanted to try a little of everything so we ordered the meatballs, pumpkin salad, tagliatelle with bolognese, shells with crab, branzino and broccoli. 

I thought all of the food was nicely prepared and presented and tasted great. I love a good plate of pasta and neither of our pasta dishes let me down. The shells may have won out by a small margin -\xa0the tomato sauce was just spicy enough and I loved the toasted breadcrumbs for some texture. The branzino was perfectly cooked and I really enjoyed the citrusy tomato salad underneath. Also, those meatballs! If Carina ever opens for lunch, I really hope they put a meatball sandwich on the menu. 

I'm looking forward to many more meals at this neighborhood gem!"]

name: The Independent
categories_raw: Restaurants, Nightlife, Pubs, Food, Bars, American (New), German, Coffee & Tea, American (Traditional), Beer Bar
top_reviews:
['I came here for the first time a few weeks ago and was very into the concept of this place. The vibe was so relaxed, the beer selection was great, and everyone seemed to be having a good time. They also have a great food selection, so it seems like a really good place to spend an afternoon or evening underneath the hanging lights, enjoying time with your friends. 

The Independent has a long list of sandwiches, so there's basically something for everyone here. On top of a lengthy sandwich list, the Independent also has salads and German specials like sausage! I thought that was pretty unique. 

On the weekends, this place is a very relaxed "chill" place to grab a drink and hang out. It gets very busy in the evenings, so the line for the bar can get pretty long.

There's also a great little coffee part of this bar which I thought was a nice touch. They have a selection of pastries available for purchase.

There is live music that plays here pretty frequently. All in all, a great local spot with a laidback vibe!', "This little golden find is hidden down n Florida ave. They have quite the array of beers and wines! I love that this is German based. They mostly house craft beers and unique twists on dishes. 

I tried the Reuben. It was pretty good but it wasn't over the top. The salad side however was amazing. They make a grape blue cheese salad with the most delicious dressing! I highly recommend getting that side instead of the chips. They offer brats, leberkase, sandwiches and other bar type food. 

The beers are pretty cheap and huge for what you pay so that's worth the stop alone! They have a nice outdoor seating area as well. 

Parking can be tough if it's crowded but I usually have no problem parking in the back. There's also parking on the side streets but non really out front. 

Overall, I enjoy this place! It's a cool, hipster type hangout spot. You will not be disappointed if you're here for a tasty beer on a hot Sunday afternoon!", "The Independent is one of my 
Favorite spots in Seminole Heights
I look forward to chillin' on their patio
On some cooler Tampa nights!

They've got an amazing selection
Of craft beers on tap. 
Enjoy a few too many,
And it's time for a nap!

What's even more impressive 
Are the bottles kept in the cooler. 
So many rare, hard to find beers...
Pardon me, I'm a bit of a drooler. 

They also offer some food,
Tho I have yet to eat here. 
There's usually one thing on my mind
And that one thing is beer!"]

name: Weavers Way Co-Op
categories_raw: Pets, Cheese Shops, Health Markets, Grocery, Food, Specialty Food
top_reviews:
["Love the Portlandia reference and passive aggressive label  from a previous reviewer. Pretty accurate. Couldn't have said it any better but I'll  try.

Let's seperate the pros from the cons.

  Con# 1 : 

Prices.
 
 A joke. Really gouging. The mark up is tremendous.
$6.99 for Organic Strawberries?
$1.50 for a cottony apple?
$6.99 a head of organic califlower? 
WTF? Pleeezeee...

Con # 2

Employees
 
Let's give a hand to the angry, uninspired, condescending, eye avoiding, I'd rather be elsewhere group of smoldering, unsmiling staff.
 Is there a more unhappy group of people on this earth? 
Nope.
 Customers! If you have a question for these folks get ready to shield yourself from being on the receiving end of a condescending reply.
 Employees have total disdain for the customers especially the Mount Airy location where they seem skilled at the art of resting bitch face.
Word of advice: the prepared food section in Chestnut Hill is a game of eye contact. The first employee who makes eye contact while they see you waiting for help loses.

Con # 3

You. The Customer.

 The above tirade applies to all of us who shop there.
 Forever in a hurry to get to a prime spot at Mommies Yoga. 
And yes, no eye contact here either. 
The space is tight in the Mt. Airy location so if you, unfortunately don't know the rules, be prepared to get an elitist  tongue lashing from one of many carbon copy, middle aged, resident women sporting practical Teva sandals. 

Con # 4
The Parking. Getting worse.
Watch out! Almost duked it out with a fellow, card carrying, liberal. 
Another middle aged woman in linen cargo pants and practical footwear. 

Pros

The food. Good variety of prepared food.  Really good local produce. Very clean interior and exterior. Everything that Wholefoods has except WF employees try hard to please their customers. 
If you are looking for a warm fuzzy experience you wont find it here but if you want to get in and out with minnimal damage, except your wallet then this is your place.", "I give this place- and all of those who work there a lot of credit.
For Weavers Way exists purely on the hard work and dedication of a neighborhood of Tree Huggers and Earth Children. 

I first found out about WW a few years ago when a friend of mine brought me along while she went shopping. I was impressed by the movement and joined shortly thereafter.

I do all of the shopping for my family, and I was the only one who went there. That didn't matter, being a part of the co-op meant that my husband also had to work there a certain amount of hours per year (that went over well).

So, after we both worked all day- we drug our asses to the basement of this place and stuffed bags with twigs and berries until our eyes were bleeding. Painting the space above the freezer, stocking shelves, pricing cat food are just some of the jobs that I worked there because I could never get my husband to go back! 

That was the main reason why I let my membership expire. That and the fact that I was sick of paying $30 a year when I never really got to go as often as I should have. When I did go, I have to admit that I really felt like an outsider; especially when I would come straight from work wearing makeup and a suit. 

Forgive me for sounding like an asshole- I really do get the concept.
I guess when it comes right down to it, I am just more comfortable shopping at my local Acme where I can get all the things I need without having to stock the shelves and mop the floors.", 'My lover and I were on a long lover's walk in West Mt Airy.  As we were in desperate need of groceries after a power outage at the esteemed Welshly Arms Hotel had spoiled our food, we happened upon the Weavers Way Co-op.  Taking a moment to caress my lover as she rode upon a magnificent coal-black hobby horse across the avenue, we entered the quaint building, lustful passions upon the evening air, rising like a devil's miasma.
As I perused the organic produce, the local meats and cheeses, I could almost hear the faint music of a jug band, enthusiastically playing while farmers hawked their wares to the townsfolk.  I grabbed my lover, as if possessed by Zeus himself, thunderbolts crashing, screaming "Is this our love!??!"  My lover embraced me fiercely, standing by the convenient refrigerator filled with artistan sandwiches, delicately-smoked fishes and lusty chickens.  As it turned out, I was merely feeling the effects of a minor electrocution I had sustained from an old  racket zapper I had purchased at the thrift shop.  
We continued throughout the store, and as I viewed the organic products, the fresh baked goods that seemed to be delivered by great Odin himself, the dairy from farms most near...I could hardly contain myself.  I'd have taken my lover right then and there, in the biggest bulk section this city has ever seen, if not for the paid cooperator giving me queer looks and asking me if I knew my nose was bleeding.  
I cursed the heavens for not being a member, as the extra 5% discount would have kept my checking account from going into overdraft mode, but such is a lover's life.  My lover and I exited, continuing on our lover's walk.']

name: Keith's Auto Repair & Services
categories_raw: Auto Repair, Automotive
top_reviews:
["When I lived in Old Jefferson, this was my go to independent repair shop and its where my parents still go.  I always found them to be honest and above board as well as getting me my car back when promised.

It's an old neighborhood gas station (the elderly man who owned it in my childhood fixed my bike on occasion for free) and you can't miss because they decorate with inflatables on the roof for every holiday.

I don't use them any longer because I tend to use a repair shop in my neighborhood.", 'They tried to screw me on brake job. I got a second opinion and they were exposed! I will never ever set foot there again!', "Overall a great business - quick, friendly and affordable. I was wary of the Yelp reviews because they are all so glowing, but I was not disappointed. It's rare to find a repair place that gives it to you straight and doesn't try to screw you over with pricing and unnecessary repairs. I am even more sensitive to this as I don't have the first clue about cars so I put 100% of my trust in to people like this. 

I came to Keith's with one major problem and 7-8 minor issues with my Nissan Murano. They went above and beyond in terms of getting everything taken care of in an efficient and cost-effective manor. From the moment I walked in the door, they were trying to save me money. For example, they did not charge me for a tire rotation because I needed my brakes replaced. They rushed the parts they needed over to the shop and stayed an hour after closing time to get my major issue fixed. Unfortunately, the problem was bigger than what they had anticipated, so I was back in the shop when they opened the next morning. Now whether this bigger problem was missed the day before or would have been missed regardless, I don't know. But they took the time the next day (4 hours) to comb through the entire car and make sure everything was in place and working properly. 

I would say that by going to Keith's rather than the dealership (my usual go-to for everything car-related), I saved at least $1000, if not more. My side mirror got knocked off - the dealership was going to charge me $400 to replace it, Keith's is doing it for $150. My key fobs stopped working - the dealership was going to charge me $120 PER FOB, Keith's is doing it for $100 for both. I originally took my car in for a horrible noise it was making - the dealership was going to charge me $150 just to put it on the rack and take a look, Keith's charge is $18. These are just examples of some of the cost-savings I got at Keith's.

I will definitely be going back. And I'll be disappointed when I move away from New Orleans as I'll never find another place like Keith's."]

name: Wei Asian Cafe
categories_raw: Chinese, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Delivery! The food has always arrived hot and as ordered. The portions are large and we can feed four with two entrees, rice, and crab puffs. The flavors were good without being overly sweet or salty. We love the Moo Shu (chicken or pork), cashew chicken, fried rice, pork egg rolls, and crab puffs.
We have only just found this place but I'm sure everything is delicious.", 'Wei Asian Cafe does delivery! One of the "gems" of the Eastside, this spot serves up major varieties of Asian cuisine. Granted, the majority of the dishes in the menu is mostly Chinese food but they have some Vietnamese, Thai, Korean, and more. So far, I had a craving for pad thai and their take has beef, shrimp, and chicken all in one dish! It was different but good. If you're wanting Vietnamese, they do have pho or bun thit nuong (grilled porkchop over vermicelli) or the spring rolls. The other dish that I really enjoyed from this place is the Eggplant with garlic sauce, which isn't always great in most delivery places but really packed well from them. I've never tried to dine in pre-covid times but from the quality of the delivery I'm sure the food is worth the try especially with the minimal options for Asian food this side of town.', "Lacking in stylish decor, the food and the service here more than make up for the restaurant's faded, '80s look. The menu is enormous with Thai, Chinese, Japanese, Korean and Vietnamese options. We got 3 different things and they were all delicious. The chefs were even willing to create an off-menu dish for us. 

Delicious, accommodating and not very expensive. If I were local, I would definitely be coming back."]

name: Massage Studio
categories_raw: Sports Medicine, Health & Medical, Reflexology, Doctors, Day Spas, Physical Therapy, Beauty & Spas, Massage Therapy, Massage
categories: ['sports medicine', 'health & medical', 'reflexology', 'doctors', 'day spas', 'physical therapy', 'beauty & spas', 'massage therapy', 'massage']
top_reviews:
['I can't say enough about Massage Studio. I have been a member for over a year and it has been worth every penny. Every visit I have had here has been five stars from start to finish. It is also conveniently located close to where I live, so that makes it perfect in my eyes.

Lauren and the front desk staff are always so friendly and welcoming. They take every precaution to make sure all their guests are COVID safe, from taking your temperature right as you walk in to assuring that everyone has a mask on in all common areas.

Kristen is a godsend and I swear she has "magic hands." I look forward to my monthly visits to see her. She has helped with my problem areas tremendously. In addition, she has also recommended stretches and other ideas to further assist me.

The prices are great here and you can also book your appointment online. Don't pay attention to negative reviews that seem to be written by someone who "conveniently" recommends another place to go at the end. 

Thanks Massage Studio for always making my day when I come to see you guys!', "Had a great experience at Massage Studio recently. I opted for the 90 minute deep tissue massage. Will was great and very professional. He really worked the kinks out in my back and shoulders. I can't wait to go back!", "Tried their relaxation introductory offer for $49 and then checkin via Yelp for another 30min additional upgrade.  So you will have a total of 1 1/2 hrs for $49 only.   The place is very clean, high ceilings, individual rooms are well kept and simple.  Very calming feeling at the waiting area and or check in area and it's overlooking a patio outside.  Ample parking and very quiet too. Catherine who was assigned to me is very good but this place don't do abdominal area so that the  only reason it's a 4 star.  I am so used to having a deep pressure and the introductory relaxation massage is light pressure only.  When I asked for more pressure, Catherine told me that it will need upgrading to deep pressure and that means diff price which is up.  I am just used to having a massage that if I say more pressure that they do without hesitation in other places and since I am trying this place for the first time, I understand that they have rules and details on what type their massage offerings.  Overall, you will have to choose from what type of massage pressure you want and how many min or hours and they have diff pricing.  The best part is that they have a membership offerings that you will save money if you do massage as a body maintenance for yourself."]

name: Tandoori Of India
categories_raw: Indian, Venues & Event Spaces, Desserts, Food, Salad, Halal, Event Planning & Services, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['tried out the new spot - great flavor, attentive service. Menu is pretty extensive. Will definitely be going back, and ordering takeout.', "Had the Veggie Samosa, Garlic Naan and Chicken Tikka Masala. It was all delicious. Loved it!! Will definitely go again when I'm in the area.
Service was great as well.", 'I've always said that Philly needs more made-to-order Indian places, and it looks like my prayers have been answered in the past few months! Tandoori of India is located extremely close to my boyfriend's house, which made for an easy weeknight date night. The staff (really just the front of the house guy and the chef) were super nice and helpful, even going as far as having an "Indian" spice level gauge and an "American" one.

I'm usually the type to get the tikka masala or butter chicken, but I ventured into tandoori territory and got tandoori chicken, which, while it took forever to cook and come out, was completely worth it and I ate pretty much everything. It was flavorful, and obviously well taken care of. It's nice to eat in, but take-out is pretty accessible and easy too. For the price, the portions are great, and I really hope this place does well enough to stick around for a while!']

name: Frost Gelato
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Desserts, Gelato, Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt
top_reviews:
["Once again, the reliable Yelp community led me to another great business while on my last trip to Arizona. I was craving something cool and dismissed the fact that it was about 60 degrees out (yes, 60 degrees is considered cold for Hawaii locals)!  Frost Gelato has a nice large corner location in Tucson on the long and semi-rundown strip of Tanque Verde Road and is in a newer building than ones of their neighbors. 

Frost Gelato is housed in a bright clean and spacious space that offers both indoor and outdoor seating. My timing was perfect as there were only two other customers and I found a prime parking stall right in front of the shop and didn't have to wait in line. I was immediately greeted by two friendly employees and they were patient with me while I tried to decide on what flavor gelato I wanted. Of course I wanted all 38 flavors that they offer but I had to be reasonable! What helped was that they offered free samples and I finally decided on cheesecake and salted caramel. I got it in a cup and although their gelato is a bit pricey, it was well worth it because the flavors were on point and the serving was pretty generous. They stuck a wafer roll in the gelato which gave it a nice touch. 

They also have waffle cones and sugar cones including their Spizzico cones which are their miniature sugar cones. The next time I'm in the Tucson area, I will find a way to make it back to Frost Gelato. Why wouldn't I? They have the whole package-great customer service, a nice clean and spacious location with ample parking, and the gelato's top notch! 2 down, 36 flavors to go...", "So many different flavors of gelato, all sprawled out to see...and sample! I feel like I sample the whole world when I come in here; yet I always walk out with a cup of the same thing...Almond! Okay, every once in a while a Tiramasu, or Hazelnut....but mostly Almond. This place never disappoints, the flavors are absolutely delicious. The fruit-based gelatos are great to combat the Tucson heat, and are not as sweet as the others. (Mmmmm....mango!) The only bummer is that they don't do flavor combinations in the smaller order size. Sometimes I can't decide, and that would help! :)", "This place has the best gelato I have ever had. I've tried gelato before and have never found anything too special about it and could rarely ever distinguish it from ice cream or froyo. The gelato at this place is so much more different.

I ordered the cherry gelato which was pretty good, but my fiance ordered the rum raisin - which I thought was going to be bland, but it was so amazingly tasty. The gelato here seriously takes like exactly what you're ordering. The place is definitely a bit pricey, but it's definitely worth it. Treat yo self."]

name: Besito Mexican Restaurant
categories_raw: Mexican, Restaurants, Salad, Food, Bars, Nightlife
top_reviews:
['Popped in here recently to grab a bite and a drink. Have been here several times. I like the atmosphere. It is very warm and comfortable. I especially like sitting outside on the patio which has a beautiful fountain. At night it is really nice. Our server was spot on. Quick to greet us and very attentive. Drinks were served up in a timely manner. He was able to juggle quite a few tables. Service here has always been good. 5/5 stars.

Ordered the guacamole for the table which they prepare table side. Quite good. The ceviche was tasty. Also ordered the Camarones Ajillo which is jumbo shrimp cooked with mushrooms, bonita and salsa. All the food was a ok.  A 3.5/5 stars. It was a solid experience. The whole package is nice.', "Still one of my favorite places to eat in the Westshore area.

It's a little embarrassing that I haven't updated my review since 2015, especially when I love this place so much. Here are the main reasons this continues to be a staple in my restaurant rotation.

GUACAMOLE - The table side made guacamole is superb. The chunks of avocado give me life and it is perfectly seasoned. It's a good amount for 2-3 people, if you order it and think uh I think that feeds more than 3 people, Christina, I'm a fatty, what can I say. 

Pair it with the superbly thin and well-salted chips and it is a recipe for addiction. They do not hold back with the salt, and I am here for it. 

FREE CHIPS AND SALSA - It hurts my heart when I go someplace and they don't give free chips and salsa. Please always do this.

CAMARONES SALAD - Yes, I continuously get the same salad. When I have so much other turmoil in my life, I'm looking at you my one-year-old son, I don't like to branch out with food anymore. This salad is delicious and nutritious. I'm so happy to have a light option when eating at a Mexican restaurant, because I know I'm eating all my calories with those chips and guac. 

SERVICE - You can get in and out in less than an hour. They know how to get food out during lunch hours. You would think this would be standard at any business during the week, but you'd be surprised. 

ICE TEA - They bring out the ice tea and give you a little carafe (well, it actually looks like a Patron tequila bottle, but carafe sounds classier), so you can replenish your own tea. They even bring sweetener to the table. I love this.

DESSERT - Free churros to round out the meal. It's the perfect amount of sweet to finish lunch.

The one negative is the parking situation. It continues to be impossible to find parking in the lot in front! This is a mall so of course you will find parking close by, but you might have to walk a bit. I ended up sucking it up and valeting (which was $5 not including gratuity), because I circled the parking lot once and then said screw it. There's nothing you can do about this, but add in five minutes to your drive time!", "Why 5 stars? Because good Mexican food is a rare find around here.

   ---   ---   ---

My fiance and I both hail from Houston where 14 great Mexican restaurants can be found in any given square mile radius of the city limits. In Tampa Bay, this is sadly not the case. Instead, we're blessed with tons of Cuban, Latin, and South American fare that Houston does not possess. So you take the good with the bad, but when you find a place like Besito, hope is restored.

Besito is far from your traditional Mexican restaurant. The menu consists of a large amount of dishes that I've never seen before. But different vs. familiar isn't important... the bottom line = deliciousness wins!

After visiting Besito for a Yelp event during my first trip, I knew I had to return and get a full experience. The guacamole is possibly the best I've ever had. And the queso fundido is one of the most addicting substances you can put on a plate. 

But the main dish was incredibly impressive to me - the Costillas al Piquin. I almost never enjoy short rib because it tastes a bit more like stew, than good ole' fashioned ribs. But these were easily the best short ribs I've ever had. I had almost sworn them off forever, until Besito saved the day :)"]

name: Rocks and Ropes
categories_raw: Amateur Sports Teams, Climbing, Amusement Parks, Active Life, Summer Camps, Rock Climbing, Gyms, Fitness & Instruction, Yoga
categories: ['amateur sports teams', 'climbing', 'amusement parks', 'active life', 'summer camps', 'rock climbing', 'gyms', 'fitness & instruction', 'yoga']
top_reviews:
["I have now become a member and climb at least once a week, sometimes when I have time I will climb twice. I normally come Saturday's or sundays and sometimes monday's, and its always crowded, but its not that bad, you just wait your turn. Sometimes its annoying when you are already climbing and someone starts on the route right next you and climbs much faster and kinda gets in your way, so when that happens I just sit back and relax. 
There are 3 autobelays in the gym, and the routes change often. I really really recommend this place its so much fun and totally worth the $", 'Rock climbers are strong and smart. Well, the whole death defiance aspect of the sport borders on the less than sharp. So I'm visiting Tucson when I get the"call of the wall" - that's my way of saying that I want to rock climb. I yelped for more info and found Rocks and Ropes.

The place has close to 50 top ropes at 35 feet high and a several lead areas including a nice tall cave. Their bouldering area proved to be harder than most with taped, but unrated routes. That also goes with the rest of the gym, a lot of the climbs were unrated. Ah, be not discouraged oh, rock hugger because Rocks and Ropes has a member rated system where they take an average opinion of a climb and rate it later. That means that the setter's opinion is not law. I like!

So when I actually climbed I found that the gym offers climbs for beginners and elite athletes. It's challenge level, based on the climbing on nearby Mount Lemon, tends to fall a bit on the harder side for the higher rated routes. Tall climbing and plentiful top roped walls round this off as one of the best indoor places I've climbed - ever.

The rap:
- $12.00 entry fee (average)
- Inexpensive rentals ($6.00 each for harness or shoes - average)
- Military / Student Monty Discount ($45 - nice).
- Daily Specials (Mondays and Fridays are best $9.00 entry fee)
- Nice adder: Guided trips to Mount Lemon

Rounding up, I found this to be a fun place to climb some rather high indoor walls. The gym offers a lot of unusual features that should train even the best climber for the hard climbs out in the Mt. Lemon area. Climb on!', 'This gym really tested my limits.  It also humbled me quite soundly when I started there.  The routes are set "Mt. Lemmon" style, which means HARD...I was brought low to a 5.8 or 5.9 when I started there and had been climbing 5.10s easily at my old gym.  What I eventually found out was that they were rated high...which only eased my pain a little.  
Eventually I grew to like the challenge that the setters presented and along with the steep overhang wall my climbing advanced very quickly as well as my strength.  
The staff are very nice, super friendly and helpful, everyone is willing to help with beta.
I had a very difficult time breaking into the 5.11 and 5.12 range at this gym, the routes are set so that it's impossible to reach some holds if you're shorter than 5'9" tall.  I've even had the employees and setters tell me it's not possible, which makes it hard to advance beyond a certain point there.  
Saturdays they have "Kid's Climb" and it's kids only from 9 to 11, parents should check it out, it'll tire them out pretty good and it's fun for the belay volunteers.']

name: The United States Mint
categories_raw: Public Services & Government, Landmarks & Historical Buildings
top_reviews:
['Call me a geek, but I get a kick out of looking at how money is made..........after all, the company I work for is in the business of handling money!

I was lucky enough to have visited (2) Mints, the first mint I ever went to was in Washington D.C. (back in 1995), as one of my childhood friends hooked me up with a tour, as that time he was living in D.C. and working for the late senator Daniel Akaka. 

In 2011, my old boss (he's retired now) sent me up to the east coast for work, and I found myself working in New Jersey, & Philadelphia during the summer...........a fun & great experience, and that is how I ended up visiting the United States Mint in Philly............
Honestly, I knew there was a mint in Philadelphia, but I wasn't planning on actually visiting this place, but over the weekend while exploring the beautiful city of Philadelphia, I just so happen to run into this place, so I said to myself - "why not? I'm here already!".

Of course since I am in the business of money, you know very well that I had to check out this place! 
No reservations were needed, as I just walked into the joint. 
The entire tour is self guided...........and no, you cannot just walk around freely where they make the actual money folks...........otherwise folks will be trying to stuff their pockets full of money! Lol! 

The tour of the mint itself is in an elevated glass enclosed gallery area, and as you walk, you look down, and you can see the things going on with the process of making money. 
Don't worry folks, there are signs along the tour, and the signs will explain what's going on in the various areas of the building.

While you take the tour, there was a "walkman" like type of thing, where you could wear on your head while taking the tour, as the device gives you a "voice tour" while you walk along the tour............ i'm not sure if there was a charge for the device, but when I took the tour I elected to not to wear this, as the last thing I need is to catch some ookus (head lice) on my head! Lol!

The self guided tours are Monday through Friday, 9:00 AM to 4:30 PM, there is no admission fee (Dealages Yo! Free Baby!!!) 
For Weekends, please call at (215) 408-0114 to see availability. 
Like I said before, I came here on a weekend (Saturday)............so I guess I just lucked out when I just so happen to run into this place while visiting the city.

Also, I just wanted to let you folks know.............once you go inside of the Mint (to take the tour), they DO NOT ALLOW PHOTOS! 
I swear when I went to the Mint in Washington D.C. back in 1995, I thought they allowed photos, but my memory may be fading.......if it was allowed back then, it was before  9/11, and by the time I saw the Mint in Philadelphia,  it was way after 9/11. Posible "no photo" rule due to security???

On the brochure I picked up from the Philadelphia Mint, let me share with you a little about the Mint Story -

George Washington was president and Philadelphia was the nation's capital. It was April 2, 1792, and an act of Congress provided for a national coinage and the establishment of the U.S. Mint.
The first Mint was erected at 7th and Arch Streets. As the young nation grew, larger Mint buildings were needed. The present Mint, which opened on August 14, 1969 is the fourth in Philadelphia. 
The Philadelphia Mint is part of a nationwide Treasury agency. From headquarter in Washington D.C., the Director oversees the Mints in Philadelphia, Denver, San Francisco, West Point, and the Bullion Depository at Fort Knox.

They said that the huge machines at the Mint can work 24 hours of the day, 5 days a week making coins. 

There is a process of making a coin, they are -

1. Blanking
2. Annealing, Washing and Drying
3. Riddling
4. Upsetting
5. Striking
6. Inspecting
And last of all..............
7. Counting and Bagging of the coins.

 A pretty cool place to visit, and I would say a "must see" if you're ever in Philadelphia! 

Check 'em out gang! No can go wrong!', 'Tour is completely self-guided and is fairly informative. 

Tour "begins" at a first landing that is strictly information only. There's a short film that runs continuously that gives you a background of the necessity of a uniform monetary system. You also get to look at some of the first pressed coins among other artifacts.

Upstairs begins the modern day coinage system. We actually spent a LONG time here because the machines were all actively running so it was very interesting to watch the long sheets of metal be fed and cut into planchets, heated, cleaned, annealed, then struck. When workers caught you eye, they even waved back much to the delight of many school children that were also visiting that day.

There were also some fun games along the way if you take the time to participate (identify the coin just by touch, I Spy on US Quarters, etc). The entertainment is definitely in the details which is so easy to overlook on a day to day basis as you spend and collect money. 

The gift shop does sell quite a few knick knacks and for collectors, does offer a decent collection to supplement or replace personal collections. Mom picked up some presidential quarter proofs to replace the ones she's found just randomly in circulation.', "The tour is self-guided and free. Make sure not to bring any cameras including cell phones (those have cameras too). There are no lockers here so you will have to take them back to your hotel or put them in your car or whatever if you plan on taking a tour. 

So unfortunately, they are not producing many coins right now so we didn't get to see it operating. It was still pretty cool checking out the facility and learning about the coin making process."]

name: The Fudgery
categories_raw: Food, Candy Stores, Specialty Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt
top_reviews:
["The chocolate scent wafting in the air around corner brought us in here to explore. What a sweet little shop! When we entered they offered us samples of anything we wanted to try. They were also making a fresh batch of New Orleans pecan praline fudge. We were able to watch and all the while the confectioner was singing and smiling. It was so entertaining and fun! As soon as it cooled he passed around samples. Delicious!

They have beaucoup flavors of fudge, rice krispie treats, candy apples, shakes, ice cream and even giant marshmallows rolled in oreos, peanut butter cups, m&m's-if you can think it, The Fudgery is one step ahead of you!

Next time you're in the French Quarter go let the awesome employees at The Fudgery entertain you and indulge your sweet tooth!", "Yum! Their New Orleans praline fudge is the way to go, although I had to taste a lot of different ones to figure that out LOL their cookies and cream is also really good and a classic flavor. If you're craving a smoothie, get the strawberry and banana one! They use real fruits and it tastes really delicious, and not artificially flavored at all.", "Oh. My. God. Do not skip this place during your trip to Nola or else you will be doing your tastebuds a serious disservice. We had just eaten a delicious Cajun dinner elsewhere in the city and were walking about Decatur Street craving our sugar fix when the scent of the Fudgery just welcomed itself up our nostrils.

We walked in and were immediately enticed by the sound of the 'Fudge Chiller'-- which consisted of ice cream, a slab of fudge, and homemade whipped cream. We got the chocolate peanut butter one and asked for extra peanut butter. Do. Not. Skip. The extra peanut butter.

The staff was so upbeat, relaxed, very warm and approachable. We also got a kick out of the clever singing while being served! We even got a sample of the fudge to try, which had such a fluffy, amazing texture-- unlike any fudge we've ever had anywhere before. It was even better than the New Jersey boardwalk fudge everyone raves about near where we grew up. No way, NJ shore fudge can't even touch this stuff.

This was so good that we went back a second time to get the same exact thing. If you need your sugar fix, or even if you don't, go here without question."]

name: Jack Dempsey's Restaurant & Bar
categories_raw: Seafood, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['First, let me say a few words regarding the negative reviews.  I think, for the most part, those writing these reviews just don't get it, or maybe even don't get New Orleans.  This place is a time-warp, and an endangered species.  I can understand that some people do not like old-school places like Dempsey's- I would suggest that you just don't go if you're built that way.  Now, to the reviewers who felt they didn't get quality food: I really question that sentiment, having been a regular here for at least 20 years.  In those 20 years, I've never had a meal that wasn't at least above-average, and I can be highly critical.  I'll be the first to bitch the second Dempsey's lets me down, but 20 years of consistency is a damned good track record.  The place is like the fried yat version of Galatoire's.   Ok, got that off my chest- now to the review at hand.

I don't think I mentioned it before, but Jack Dempsey's clientele is always an even mixture of white yats and black folks, mostly from the 9th ward, Bywater, and St. Bernard parish, with a sprinkling of occasional yuppies, guppies, and yat yuppies looking for some good cholesterol.  We're all sitting comfortably together, like a good gumbo. Old photos of St. Pat's day celebrations, TV sets, and neon signs adorn the walls.  Tables have red plastic tablecloths with huge squeeze bottles of tartar sauce and remoulade on them.  This is serious blue-collar eating, but very high quality.  

Let me explain how I know this place is 5 stars- growing up in New Orleans, my parents dragged me to virtually every fried seafood joint in town, and I've been to many since. Dempsey's blows them all away, except for one- I'd say they're in a tie with Middendorf's in Manchac (which is really not in town- it's a pilgrimage, but that's for another review) quality-wise.  The fact that Dempsey's is right down the street from our house makes it even better for us.  Tonight's meal was perfection, as usual.  Had the "1/2 catfish, 1/2 erstas plattah" with a side of mac and cheese.  Perfect color, crispness, texture, and flavor.  Also had the obligatory frosty mug of Abita to go with it.  Our usual waitress, Cherine, wasn't there tonight.  A new waitress named Tammy served us, and she was awesome too. They're really all very friendly.  As we were leaving we were pushing on the door, and it wouldn't open. This yatty waitress says "pull the leavah!"  I had forgotten that the door locks after 9, and you have to crank down on this lever lock that came right out of the 1950's.  She jokingly said, "Ya gotta stay if it don't work.  At least we got a lotta food. heh heh heh heh."  Indeed they do- great food, and completely New Orleans.', "Old school New Orleans fare. Everything is fried and delicious, the servers are always sweet as pie. No other can beat their frosty ice cold beer chalices.

I really like love their turtle soup and don't forget the dash or 3 of sherry on top! The Fried shrimp plate with dat Mac'n'cheese that just don't stop is one of my all time favorite 

Last words: Bread pudding with sauce", "Pretty much the greatest. I'd lived around the corner from this place for about a year before I set foot in it. As a vegetarian, seafood places are usually pretty low on my list of fooderies. However, I had an old friend in town and he wanted to try some New Orleans seafood. We'd made plans to hit Deanie's, but after a long day of abusing drugs and cavorting in the summer hell heat that is August in New Orleans, we decided to keep it in the neighborhood.

Christ, this place is a hidden gem. The inside reminds me of the bar my dad got stoned in with his buddies post weird middle-aged dude softball league games when I was a kid, circa 1995. The only real difference is these people can fucking cook. My lady and out-of-town friend set to work on devouring a small mountain of fried seafood while I feasted on fried mushrooms and baked macaroni and cheese all the while guzziling cheap ambers and inhaling second hand smoke. I'd recommending getting a bit blitzed first as it makes the nostalgia stronger, the matronly waitresses seem that much more motherly and helps you forget that each visit moves you 3 years closer to a massive heart attack."]

name: Michael's Grill
categories_raw: American (New), Nightlife, Breakfast & Brunch, Bars, American (Traditional), Seafood, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Why 4 stars? Because Michael's is a chameleon.

   ---   ---   ---

What I really like about Michael's is that it can range from:

-A place I call in a with a to-go order.

-A fairly casual spot to grab a burger.

-A date-night destination.

Maybe it's a product of being in Florida, where almost any restaurant can be considered casual, but Michael's is a great hybrid. It's far from stuffy or pretentious, but the lighting is dim, which means it's automatically good enough for an anniversary dinner, right?

My first appearance was via option #1 - a to-go order. I got the burger, and it was very solid. It was definitely a place I wanted to visit again. So I brought the fiance for dinner shortly after.

I had the strawberry fields salad with salmon, as well as some she-crab soup. It was another solid meal, without much to complain about... except one thing. My fiance had a very similar order, and our bill ended up at $76 after tip. It just did not feel like a meal worth that that price tag. While we did not dislike anything we ate, it wasn't something I'd rave to my friends as a place that everybody must visit. For $76, it just felt a little steep.", "I've been here twice, mostly for brunch and I don't know what the fuss is about lol, food is decent. Unfortunately I didn't see anything out of the ordinary in the menu. 

I've tried their seafood omelette, burgers with fried pickle and side potatoes. Seafood omelette tasted good, potatoes were just roasted (nothing special), aside from the fried pickle, the burger was a burger. 

The food at this place hasn't wowed me.", "My friend and I decided to grab a bite to eat  after a long day of apartment hunting and she told me about this little place she discovered off of North Dale Mabry behind Mimi's Cafe. I always love trying out new places, but always with a little hesitation and skepticism. Sometimes its easier to go  to your favorite place and get the usual, but how will I ever get a favorite place if I never try new ones!?
