So overall I am giving 4 stars for this visit. Next time I will check out the menu first (and they have a very varied menu... from fried shrimp to salads)", "I've never had any meal here other than pizza, and I probably never will.  Their pizza is just *that* good.

I grew up in Maryland, and whenever our family got pizza, it was from Ledo's.  After driving by this location on Dale Mabry multiple times, and laughing at the coincidence of a pizza place using the same name as my favorite place in MD, I looked it up online and realized it IS the same place.  Woo hoo!  I've been here three times now, and the pizza is just like I remembered, and just as good as I hoped it would be.

To start with - the pizza is square, and the pieces are cut into little squares.  It's thin crust, which is my favorite kind of pizza, as I hate filling up on dough.  The red sauce is sweet, and very distinctive.  I've tried all different varieties of pizza here, but I always come back to the classic pepperoni pizza.  Each individual square piece of pizza gets it own thick cut slice of pepperoni on top.  Heaven!  Then, before you know it, you've eaten multiple squares, and you roll out the door, fat and happy.

Service was good, waitress was friendly, and stopped by frequently to make sure we had what we needed.  I do wish they supplied better quality paper napkins, as I went through about 1 per slice, but at least they are on the table to grab as many as you need.  Long and short of it - you know I'll be back!"]

name: Inn At 500 Capitol
categories_raw: Hotels, Hotels & Travel, Event Planning & Services
top_reviews:
["We stayed for 2 nights here over a gorgeous sunny weekend in June (during Pride). Found the property randomly on Booking.com and was impressed by the Yelp reviews. We had a fantastic stay from start to finish and would totally return here in the future. 

We were on the 5th floor, standard King room (no balcony) overlooking downtown. We were able to see the Capitol building during the day, Pride fireworks at night, and the gorgeous morning sun hitting the rolling hills each day. Our room also had a fireplace and a little daybed by the window, which were extremely zen. Bed was luxuriously comfortable and the showers ran hot (which is awesome). The fancy half-door meant I got water all over the place, but it was all good. 

Hannah at the front desk is a rock star - she gave us great service every time we saw her, and we loved the free drinks at check-in (they give you tokens if you're not prepared to chug a beer on the spot). The hotel is right in front of Julia Davis Park + the Greenbelt (a must-do in Boise) and walking distance to everything else. Check out breweries in the area for good times. 

The Inn at 500 was a great base camp to a beautiful weekend in Boise, and made our stay infinitely better than it otherwise would have been. If you're looking for an obvious YES hotel, check them out!", "I know, I know. If you're from Boise you HATE this place with a burning passion. It stands for everything that's wrong with Boise- massive new construction, questionable design, expensive rooms... BUT. If you are visiting Boise or know someone who is, you really can't beat the brand-spankin'-new rooms, cleanliness, and amenities. Free Mercedes bus airport shuttle? Check. Beer or wine and snacks upon check-in? Check. Beekman toiletries, fluffy white bathrobes and slippers? Check. In-room dumbwaiter so you never have to answer the door for room service naked? CHYEEECK. 

Shuttle pick up was smooth and easy. I even received a text message from the van driver to let me know that he was waiting for us upon landing. Check-in was also quick and friendly. They even had an iPhone cord that I could borrow for the night since I forgot mine at home.

We stayed in a King suite with a large, well-equipped bathroom and a two-person jetted tub set off in the corner, right across from a small private balcony. I enjoyed the spaciousness - and the privacy - of the suite, from the separate chaise sitting area to the table/desk and the comfortable king-sized bed. We couldn't resist immediately turning on the water for the bathtub (which comes from the ceiling and splatters everywhere... cool look, weird design), and even using the gas fire place. 

Check out was just as easy. 

Now, I lived in the area for years. If I still lived here, would I be complaining about how everything is changing (no parking lot, no Dunkley Music across the way, about five downtown hotels already up or going up since I left in early 2017!)? Of course I would. But now that I'm back in Washington, this would be my hotel of choice during return visits for being close to everything: BSU, the airport, and all that downtown has to offer. It's a great central location for sightseeing, music festivals, or travel to all points around the beautiful state of Idaho. I, for one, have a thing about brand new, extremely clean properties, thick white towels, fluffy slippers, crisp white duvets, and super duper comfortable beds. Sorry, locals! I'll be back!", "I plan to update this review after Jan. 27th and we've had a chance to stay here. As for now, this review is to comment on the building and staff. 
I was waiting for a friend to grab a cocktail at the newly opened Richards, the hotel restaurant fur Inn 500. However, when I entered, Bailey at the front desk offered me a tour as I waited. In addition to the hotel being stunning, she was the epitome of professional. I felt like I wasn't a stranger off the street, but perhaps a shareholder surveying my investment property. She shared the vision of its proprietor, the history of the local artwork, the inspiration for the various room themed decor, and the future plans for the expansive spaces tucked inside. 
The rooms are stunning. So much so, that without a good reason, I did indeed book a stay. I'm hoping for the wine themed room! But I'm looking forward to checking in and getting the complimentary local beer/wine, relaxing in the people-watching lobby, (not) working out in the stunning gym, and dining in the new-but-old Richards. 
I'll keep you posted!!"]

name: Urban Village Brewing Co
categories_raw: American (New), Bars, Food, Pubs, Breweries, Pizza, Restaurants, Nightlife
top_reviews:
['(to the tune of Jason Derulo's "Swalla")

Pizzas in a thousand different flavors
Should try to taste a few of them tonight
If you don't have dinner plans
you should bring all your friends
The beer flows fresh and the price is right.

All the folks in here, if you're feeling thirsty
C'mon fill your glasses, craft beer's what they're serving!

Cheesy cheesy 'za, sammies too, and more 'za (drink)
Urban - ooh la la! (drink)
Village la la la
All up in the Piazz-za-za!
Cheesy cheesy 'za, sammies too, and more 'za (drink)
Urban - ooh la la! (drink)
Village la la la
All up in the Piazz-za-za!
Hungry, hungry girls....
My hungry, guys and girls.

This is a BIG get for the Piazza, especially replacing the former King's Oak, which always felt a little "off". The space is gorgeous, with fire pits outside for some chilly evenings and a smooth and polished wooden interior. BUT let's get to the goods:

-LOTS of pizza options, with some incredible crust. Our favorites: 
-The Penelope (house made pepperoni, pesto, ricotta)
-Samantha - spicy sausage, golden fennel, & ricotta salata
-Alma - White pie with asparagus, house-made bacon, house-pulled mozz, and black pepper
-Becca - OH baby! Another white pie with brisket, horseradish, mozz, pecorino, an egg, and some chili relish

-The whipped ricotta appetizer was delish
-Their limited (3) sandwich menu features a KILLER pork-belly option you don't wanna skip and all come with fries
-The "shaved"salad (daylily shoots, asparagus, more golden fennel, almonds, ricotta) was refreshing and wonderful.

They have a huge focus on in-house production, so you know the ingredients are fresh. I was ALSO thrilled with their beer options, especially fond of "Beets by Jay" a low ABV tart brew made with over 300 lbs of roasted beets to smooth it all out. Their Rye Bread IPA is a can't-miss if you're a hop fan.

I already am looking forward to my next trip!', "Urban Village first had me with a Berliner Weisse flavored by beets. And since then it has won me over with bold beers, stellar food options, and a great outdoor seating area.

When I first read about the aforementioned beet beer I was scoffing at the idea but also very willing to try. And when I did it Beets by J added up to an unexpected win that also showcased their willingness to go beyond the typical IPA overload that most breweries do. And even though they also do pale ales like their Rye Bread IPA, and juicy milky mosaic hopped Super Villain very well; they continue to make bold new beers like their kettle sour Fruiti Di Bosco made with 3 kinds of fruit puree, and their Night Howler Imperial Stout.

For awhile I knew all this beer stuff about Urban Village without actually visiting the spot thanks to going to fests and grabbing cans at other spots. But upon visiting I instantly enjoyed things like brussel sprouts sauteed with bacon and spiced sweet potatoes, smoked wings with a Moroccan chili sauce, and beer fries with a manchego cheese sauce. I also made note to try things like their pizzas and pork belly sandwich on future visits. The beer was even better in flight form, and the outdoor area was huge and perfect for a good weather day. Toss in even more beer at the Piazza Pod Park now (with a namesake beer to boot), and there's even more reason to stop in.", "Northern Liberities finally has a brewery again (RIP Schmidt's). I've seen the beginnings of this brewery since late last year and have been patiently waiting for it's arrival. This brewery is perfectly themed for the area with a good mix of indoor and outdoor seating (firepits!) serving a classic - beer and pizza.

I have tried almost all the beers (not really an IPA person or a stout person) and I have really enjoyed them all. The smoky vanilla porter was a stand out in their selection but I think my ride or die will be the Wildey Wheat. It's such an easy beer to drink. The pizza on the other hand is TOP NOTCH. I love a chewy crust that has a little umph to it. My favorite so far is the Rita, which is just a classic margarita pizza. Just thinking about it makes me want to stop by for happy hour...which is awesome. $10 Rita's and $3 8oz pours. I like that they do their 8oz's on happy hour so you can try a bunch of brews and find your favorite. I think they have a few other pizza's at the $10 happy hour price but Rita is my homegirl. I was impressed that they even have a vegan (no cheese) pizza and other vegan options.

Staff is a little squeaky but that's what you get going to a brand new place. It's worth the visit (plus free parking in the lot next door!). You have no excuse to not make this your next Philly beer excursion."]

name: SoFresh
categories_raw: Gluten-Free, Food, American (Traditional), Wraps, Vegan, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Salad, American (New), Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Why 5 stars? Because it's healthy and delicious.

   ---   ---   ---

I enjoy the ritual of eating out, but I also try to be healthy more often than not. So when I find a place that combines those two things, I'm, as the kids says, "all about that life."

I went with the poke bowl, and my girlfriend ordered the BBQ chicken bowl. I thought mine was solid but hers was absolutely amazing. It comes with corn, beans, onions, cheese, and you can substitute zucchini noodles for rice, which is what she did. Zoodles are God's gift to the human race, when trying to limit those calories, but not sacrifice on taste!

We will definitely be back when we're looking to break up the monotony of our own healthy cooking!', 'SoFresh is a great little healthy food eatery located along South Howard in between Platt and Swann in the SoHo section of South Tampa. The restaurant is small, and so the place fills up quickly at lunch. They have a couple of larger tables inside, which are stacked up with communal diners, and a few smaller tables to the back. Most folks were taking their orders to go, as this place seems quite popular with nearby residents and business workers.

Parking is atrocious in this section of South Howard, so be prepared to circle the block while looking for a space in their tiny shared parking lot, or else bring a designated driver while you dash inside to pick up your to-go order.

So Fresh has a lot of customizable bowls, salads, and wraps, along with their homemade soups and smoothies. This style of healthy eating has become popular lately, and though it can be pricey, it's certainly a tasty and filling lunch.

The menu is displayed on big flat-screen TVs over the front counter, with constantly-scrolling pictures of the bowls, add-ons, and a list of ingredients. They also have printed menus for those who don't with to stand there and go "uhhhhhhhhhhh" while holding up the line.

The basic bowls and salads start at $10, but you can add-on various protein toppers, or egg and avocado for an upcharge. Wraps start at $8. I ordered the Greek bowl, which was made with brown rice, onions, diced tomatoes, spinach, feta cheese, cucumbers, and house-made tzatziki sauce. I topped that off with seared Ahi tuna for a $3 up-charge. If you want to eat super healthy, they you can top your bowl with tofu or Zoodles (zucchini noodles).

While waiting for them to prepare my Greek bowl, I also ordered their homemade chicken veggie soup ($4), which was a fantastic blend of veggies and slices of chicken breast simmering in a very tasty broth. Unlike a lot of soups, this one was not overcooked, and the vegetables still had a lot of 'bite'.

I thought that my meal was delicious, though it's a bit pricey to eat here every day. Eating healthy is a good thing, and SoFresh gives you a delicious way to enjoy a healthy meal.', 'Highly recommended and just the menu alone was indicative of that.

Once I figured out all my options (and the guys behind the counter certainly did offer to assist), I ordered a pesto club wrap with chicken and was very happy with the finished product.

Yes, the ingredients were fresh and I liked that it was really packed tight with all those good things and then placed on the press before serving it to me.

I benefitted from only a few other customers being in there at 6pm on a Saturday in getting very fast service considering how they do take time in preparing all items. (Most of those crazy FSU fans were already across the street at The Lodge getting ready to root on the former Notre Dame QB to open their football season)

Next visit, I will sample one of their bowls or salads to see if they put even more of those fresh ingredients in one of those than wrapped in a tortilla. 

And maybe I'll find out how a "Zoodle" tastes now that I know what the heck it actually means.']

name: Certified Kitchen + Bakery
categories_raw: Food, Breakfast & Brunch, American (New), Bakeries, Restaurants, Coffee & Tea
top_reviews:
['Certified's location used to house a long time family run upholstery and rug cleaning business by the same name.  I was a "high-five" delighted customer of that Certified and grieved (seriously - my heart hurt) when the owner decided to close his business and sell the building.  So I was intrigued when owners of The Wylder eatery announced plans to open a bakery - cafe keeping Certified in the name.  A nice nod to the history of the building they remodeled here.

With all that as context, I offer up this fan-review for the English Muffins alone.  Having yet to brave the chaos of the North End and what I know to be woeful parking in this neighborhood and at this location (as place holder, the back door entrance to Camel's Crossing is just across the lot from Certified) to visit this new business myself, it was a wonderful surprise when a friend (who shall remain nameless but initials are Joy W) gifted me with sleeve of Certified's fantabulous English Muffins.

I am something of an English Muffin fiend, which means I am no expert but a really big fan and my friend read my mind because although we had not talked about English Muffins,she figured I would love these.  And I do!  Split in half with two forks, like a proper English Muffin should be, and double toasted at home in my wide mouth Breville toaster (which I bought specifically with proper bagels and English Muffins in mind) they crisp up with perfect nooks and crannies to receive whatever it is you want to top them with.  

I hope to get into Certified soon.  In the meantime, just a note that the English Muffins are fantabulous.  

And also a note that Certified is offering pre-made meals in a case in the eatery - they told me when I inquired - which includes lasagna (the Wylder's recipe), mac n cheese, chicken pot pies and vegan enchiladas.  Not on their web site - so far - or a printed menu for these but a heads up for busy weeknight convenience!', 'Update 'heads up' for a new "Thursday Family Meal" that Certified offered for the first time this week (8/20/20) as delivery - including for a nominal fee to my distant from Boise location of Eagle.  Most of the quality ingredient Boise eateries we enjoy don't deliver to our neck of the woods and that Certified is on our quality list and delivered for only $10 gets a "woohoo" from us!  Delivery in Boise proper is only $5. Or you can pick up the meal at the eatery.

We are 'well seasoned' home cooks who source mostly local ingredients (so we have high standards for take away) and enjoy cooking a lot (it keeps us sane in crazy times).  But it is lovely to have good food at home that one neither has to cook themselves nor make the almost one hour round trip to Boise locales to pick up! (We choose not to use Uber or GrubHub knowing how they financially bleed independent eateries already working on slim margins.)  

Certified offers this family meal sized to serve 2 or 4 people.  I hope it is wildly successful so they'll continue to offer it and we can continue to use it.  Check Certified's Facebook page or website for more information.  But the basics follow, keeping in mind this is a new program for them and so subject to change.

HOW IT WORKS:

*They announce the menu on Friday or Saturday with orders needing to be placed (by email) by 5p Sunday for the meal choice for Thursday delivery.  Tip: Get on their email distribution list to receive this directly.

*Confirmation of order email is by email.  Tuesday or Wednesday they call to collect credit card payment information and confirm the Thursday morning delivery time.

* Delivery was spot-on on time in the Thursday morning window, the delivery person - who was owner in our case - wore a mask and stood back after ringing bell to see if we had any questions before leaving.

*The packaging was perfectly done - not all takeaway orders from all places get this right and it is so important.  All items are refrigerated on arrival and with clear, easy to use instructions on how to reheat those that need reheating when you're ready to do that. 

*Dinners can be enjoyed day of delivery or up to two days later per the instructions.

THE EATS: 

*On inaugural week there were 3 options to order:  roast Mary's chicken with chimichurri, brisket with gravy and veg lasagna.  All came with salad of super fresh mixed greens with grilled nectarine, goat cheese, toasted almonds.  The chicken and brisket options also came with an orzo side that had fresh cherry tomatoes and corn in the mix.  (We chose the chicken option and Mary's is a quality brand we use too.)
  
*Prices were $30 for service for 2 or $55 for service for 4.  Pencils in at $15 or less per serving.  For top quality, generous portions and delicious food it is a great value. 

*You can also order add ons to your delivery from a set list of options including a couple of cocktail mixes (remember this is the same family that owns The Wylder for the bar there), desserts (we chose yummy nectarine and blueberry crostata - $6 each - from Certified's bakery), breakfast 'you-bake' scones or their wonderful English muffins (a half dozen of these - $9.50 - were also on our list), housemade pickles and more.', 'A couple of "ho-ho-holiday" tips about take-away meals and good gift ideas all in one because in addition to baked goods - and excellent English Muffins (see first review) - Certified has prepared meals and soups to go in the freezer case in the shop.  Good prepared food makes a welcome gift any time of year: think as for working parents with school age kids, parents with a new baby, neighbors who just had surgery, your host and hostess who probably don't need another bottle of wine but who can always use a frozen meal to heat and eat next week, senior aged friends and family who have trouble cooking for themselves... The opportunities to share these - and to buy them to use at home - are boundless all the time including holidays.  

That's the top line.  Details follow.

ALL THE TIME OPTIONS:  You'll find in the freezer case. (Have tried them all.)

*Certified Lasagna with beef, Italian sausage, pancetta of The Wylder recipe - this is the same family that owns that downtown area eatery (in small and large sizes to feed from 6 to 10 I think - $39 & $78)
 
* Mac n Cheese in super cheesy four-cheese style using penne (in small and large sizes to feed from 4 to 8 I think - $12 & $24) 

*Chicken Pot pies (to feed 1 or 2 with lots of tender chicken, peas, carrots, potatoes in delicious sauce and excellent crust -  $14)

*Vegetarian Enchiladas (small - 3 enchiladas fed 2 at our house- and large sizes - filling may change seasonally but our winter purchase was cubed roasted sweet potato and pintos with just enough chili kick - yummy - $12 & $24)

*Assorted 32 oz soups - we picked up Tomato Bisque (still in our freezer) and Pumpkin Curry (delicious) and also saw Potato Leek and Veg Chili in the case.

(12/27 update - Certified offered wild mushroom VEGETARIAN LASAGNA as an option on order in advance Christmas holiday menu - I ordered a couple.  A bit much cheese for us but glad we tried it.  If you enjoy super-cheesy style lasagna this is a fit for that preference.)

SPECIAL HOLIDAY MENUS 2019:   This year they offered holiday specialty take out menus for Thanksgiving and Christmas, both of which required placing orders several days in advance by email or phone and picking up orders in a specific time window on a certain day.  Convenient if you're hosting or being hosted to be able to pick up good food to go and if they expanded the pick up day and time options that would be even more swell.

FRIDAY SURPRISE I HOPE THEY'LL CONTINUE:  As "What a GREAT idea", for a couple of consecutive Fridays Certified posted on FB that they were offering rotisserie whole chicken, roasted veg and ciabatta one week (biscuits the other) as take out for $35 (+/-...the price varied).  Limited amount, pick up starting at 5:30ish.  The first week was first come, first served and they sold out quickly.  The second week they offered 'call to reserve' option for the 5:30 - 7:00 pick up window.   PS - being the "Portlandia" type I am I did ask where the chickens come from and the answer that they are Mary's organic - a very good brand - makes this all the more excellent. 

SERVICE:  Friendly, friendly, friendly.

PARKING:  A considerable challenge in the North End and in particular for people like me who need accessible parking.  (I have had MS since college days.)  So it goes.  For anyone who doesn't live walkable distance from Certified, this North End neighborhood parking is a bear.  That is what that is.  And it is what keeps me from being a regular here.

ACCESSIBILITY:  Newly opened as remodeled from a building that was once Certified upholstery and rug cleaners, this is one of the few businesses in the North End that has tried to be equally accessible for people with mobility limits. ADA met for entry the door, standard height seating availability and the loos too.  Good for them for those minimums met.  The Civil Rights law of ADA is 30 years old so they should be no surprise to a building designer.  Yet I saw a wheelchair parked outside on snowy day because path of travel when people are inside was too narrow for minimum passage required.

A NOTE ON SEATING IF YOU'RE EATING IN:  Seating at low tables is convenient for eating a bakery item or sandwich.  But it is not particularly comfortable as seats themselves are smallish round stools.  This is probably a "perch and go" even for someone of my size 2 frame and maybe really not comfy for larger folks to be a "linger and nosh" kind of place for that reason.  But it is a pleasant space with lots of light and sparkling clean decor.  For me it will be all about the take away I think.']

name: Fiamme Pizza
categories_raw: Italian, Restaurants, Food Stands, Farmers Market, Food Trucks, Caterers, Pizza, Event Planning & Services, Food
top_reviews:
['Neo Brooklyn style pizza! I love the idea. While on vacation it's a bit of a trip ritual to get some local late night pizza to go and eat it back at our hotel room. We had an 18" Margherita pizza.

The pizza was a hefty portion! It was indeed like a hybrid of Neapolitan and Brooklyn style pizza. The slices were large and the crust thin like a Brooklyn style pizza, but was a bit more pliable with more of a tender chew to it like a Neapolitan pizza. The pizza was so good that the toddler picked up a slice (The largest one of course) and licked it to claim it as hers. She is learning early on in life about pizza property rights!

I appreciated that the fresh basil was in a bunch off to the side of the pizza so you can add it right when you eat it. Some of the basil was a bit tired, brown and wilted looking though but overall it still tasted good. 

If we're in the area we'd definitely stop by again.

P.S. Check on YouTube for owner Scott Volpe's extraordinary acrobatic pizza spinning skills!', "FIVE TIME INTERNATIONAL PIZZA CHAMPION RIGHT HERE IN TUCSON.

In my earlier review, among the favorable aspects of the food I emphasized the quality of the pizza crust.  This may be the distinguishing feature of Fiamme pizza that elevates it above all others in Tucson.  I noted how it achieved that perfect combination of chewy and crunchy at the same time, an element that I found routinely in my decades in New York City but never in the Southwest.  It is achieved when the proteins in the dough are properly stretched, something achieved when the dough, in that classic image, is tossed and twirled.  As I had never seen anyone at Fiamme toss dough, I questioned how they achieved that perfect crust without the tossing.  

Boy was I wrong.  They most certainly do know how to toss dough, I had just missed the performance.  Owner and Chef Scott Volpe turns out to be a five time international champion pizza twirler.  Mystery solved.  Here  is a link to Scott's winning performance in Parma Italy:

https://www.facebook.com/watch/?v=598068604040219", "This gem of a pizza place has the most wonderful chewy and flavorful wood-fired crust. I read they make it from a sourdough starter and it really is something to rave about. My Capricciosa Pizza had the tasty salt and acid flavors from olives and artichokes that balanced nicely with the intense sopressatta salami and umami-laden mushrooms. Their Caesar salad was topped w freshly shaved Parmesan and crispy croutons, with a couple of anchovies on the side along, as was their homemade dressing. So delicious. I can't wait to try their Italian (fennel) sausage, as well as their pizza deal for 2 - only $8!"]

name: Pizzeria Vetri
categories_raw: Italian, Pizza, Restaurants, Salad
top_reviews:
['Loved their pizza and tap water (she said it is filtered tap water).

We got lucky to dine in here without any reservation. They only have three tables inside due to COVID and reservation is recommended for indoor dine in.

Tap water tasted so soft, why am I commenting about their water but it really was tasty. 

They have a happy hour (ended 15 minutes before we arrived) and price on drinks and appetizers looked very reasonable.

We shared 28" braised pork (seasonal) and the pizza was very good. I liked that texture and flavor of the dough.

Sometimes pizza sits in my tummy for a while and I tend to avoid eating pizza but this place is exception. I would eat their pizza often if I live nearby.

I enjoyed watching the chef cooking from the dining area. They all ware mask and face shield. I know why but I wondered if they get really hot near that oven.

Staff was friendly and overall it was very pleasant experience dining in here.', "I met up with a friend for lunch outside on a gorgeous afternoon a few weeks ago. There were plenty of outdoor tables which were covered by a tent that was open along one side. Because it was so sunny, it actually felt quite warm but I bet the tent would be great at blocking some wind on a chillier day. 

I was happy to see some booze free options on the beverage list, and ordered a Don't Call Me Shirley, which was a simple club soda with housemade grenadine - fantastic! 

We shared the arugula salad, margherita and mushroom pizzas. I specifically requested the salad first but everything was brought out at the same time. Nonetheless, every single item was delicious! So delicious, that my husband and I ordered dinner from the Pizzeria Vetri in Rittenhouse that same night.

I feel like Philadelphia has gone from pizza desert to pizza wonderland in a pretty short time. I don't always think of Vetri when I think of pizza, but it's a consistently solid spot that shouldn't be overlooked.", "After hearing a whole lot of hype about this place I can tell you that it's good pizza. Not necessarily great pizza, but good pizza. It is vastly overpriced for what it is, but that's typical amongst artisanal pizza places.

The rotolo is probably their best offering. It's unique and low priced, and a great starter in general. I love their use of pistachio, and it just all comes together to work well as a dish. The pizza is good, but nothing groundbreaking. The crust is fluffy but also floppy when you pick it up. The speck pizza I got was very tasty, but this was mostly due to its toppings. The speck was salty and flavorful, and the onions and pistachios gave it an interesting texture. 

I would have the pizza here again, but it's not something I would go out of my way for. If they dropped their prices just a smidge, I might be more willing to drop in for round two. Pretty good overall."]

name: The Cow and The Curd
categories_raw: Food, Food Trucks
top_reviews:
['My friend who was a fried cheese curd virgin: "Is this line really worth the wait?" Me: "Hell yeah!"

The truck was at the Big Brew Beer Festival in Morristown, NJ. I bought 2 orders of cheese curds and my friend bought 2 as well with hopes of bringing the extra orders home to share with friends who never had it. Well we ended up eating all 4 orders because it was so damn addicting. Each bite had the perfect crunchy outer layer and soft yet somewhat resilient gooey cheesy insides.

Some other reviewer said these were like frozen mozzarella sticks in ball form but I beg to differ. These are legit cheese curds! The curds are fresh with that squeaky texture when you bite into it that is springy / rubbery / airy in your mouth. Also mozzarella sticks don't come with this kind of crunchy batter. They weren't too greasy either.

I docked a star because they are pretty pricy at $8 an order, but heck they must know what they are doing with supply and demand since I bought 2 orders anyway.', "Squeaky goodness! I'm a sucker for cheese. Fried in beer batter? Even better!

My older bro Jose C. brought me curd orders of white cheddar and a sharper cheddar cheese last year from a Beer Fest. I was so impressed with the taste, texture, gooeyness, and batter that I instantly became a stalker. The next time I saw them was at NJ Foodtruck Festival this past summer. Though the event was very disorganized, The Cow and The Curd delivered with flying colors. Anytime I'm in Philly, I look it up.

With or without chipotle sauce, they're a joy to eat! Also- great reheated in a toaster oven! Eating fried curds is a novel experience everyone deserves.", "Fried. Cheese. 

But not just any cheese -\xa0these curds are pressed in Wisconsin and sent straight to the folks at The Cow and The Curd, where they are prepped and served within days of arrival. Bite into one of these little nuggets and expect some of the ooziest cheese around. Definitely try them with the chipotle dipping sauce, which only makes them tastier. 

I highly recommend splitting an order with a friend or two -\xa0much as you'll want that little bucket all to yourself, it's probably in your best interest to share."]

name: The Book Trader
categories_raw: Bookstores, Books, Mags, Music & Video, Shopping, Vinyl Records, Used Bookstore
top_reviews:
["I would block off a good two hours of your schedule to come here. This book store has two floors packed (and by packed I mean be careful where you step this place might trigger your claustrophobia) with books. 

They have everything from popular brand new releases to titles no ones ever heard of. And as messy as the place looks when you walk in, everything is actually very well organized. They also have books in many languages. 

The second floor has plenty of small nooks for you to hide away and preview any books you will be purchasing. And the windows give a great view of the neighborhood. 

The also have a small section of music and record for sale available in a room upstairs. 

I can't wait to back here again on a free Saturday and load up with books to read all winter long.", 'I didnt think it was possible to have such a completely horrible experience with any business that had managed to remain open for so long. While it is not possible to give this place zero stars, book trader has taught me a lesson in the exponential negative inversion of possibility. As bad as something is, it can get worse. 
I left a good sized crate of not-cheap books off to sell with a young man who clearly couldn't care less. He did manage to ask if I wanted what they wouldn't buy returned, and I confirmed that I did but he made no note of it. I had to insist that he at least take my name but he refused to take my phone number- "we don't call out." Calling back to see if I could retrieve $/books, I was told my name was not in the log, my books were nowhere to be found and that the owner would call me.
In a lousy attempt at being diplomatic, he called to basically say he would have to make up some credit amount to give me, insisting that I should basically be thankful for this. I insisted that I'd really like him to please find my books, that it was problematic to "lose" someone's things. He said "well, you saw the place when you came in!" as if it being messy makes it my fault that they just basically stole my things. He threw out a number of other so-whats such as "they were books- not gold, just pick out a book and we'll call it even."
There were books I would have liked to have kept if they were not going to pay something decent for them. Some old nice editions and some newer pretty expensive design books, things ive seen in used book stores for good amounts of money (there were at least 3 books that sold for around 40$ each in there). None of that matters- i'm being offered a meager flat rate trade: come in in the morning to pick out a book....... only to get a call back that they actually wont be there tomorrow, followed by far too-personal details of the owners schedule and health.
I genuinely want to support local businesses and I had fond memories of this place going back to when they were on south street- it's romantic, a place filled with old books, a stereotypical disinterested younger man and a oddball caricature for an owner. I've sold books in the past on amazon and while I knew this would be less money, i thought it would be an easier option and one that felt better. With this degrading, insulting, frustrating, time consuming,... disappointing experience, the robots at amazon are seeming FAR more personable.', "This shop is dangerous. It may steal away my free time.

I mean, it's practically floor-to-ceiling books. It smells heavenly. It's beautiful. It's *the* perfect store. 
(And reasonably priced to boot.)

I'd like to move in and spend week after week just going alpha order down the fiction section reading away. That would be the ideal life. 

I could retire here one day.
Yes. 
That would be nice."]

name: French Toast
categories_raw: Breakfast & Brunch, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["I have one word... Aebleskivers. 

If you are looking for a quaint place to enjoy breakfast, French Toast is the place for you!

We dined at this great little gem a few times for breakfast, and enjoyed it so much. I love the fact that it is not indigenous or typical to the area, but rather a unique and interesting find. In many ways, it reminds me of West Coast yumminess. It absolutely is worth going for breakfast.

Diners Tip- use the Yelp app for call ahead seating. It's a smaller restaurant, and they get busy pretty early in the morning.  We lucked out, and we were seated fairly quickly each time.

Each meal always included Aebleskivers.  If you've not ever tried them, it is like heaven to your taste buds. They are danish pancake balls that are traditionally served as a dessert. Remember, life can be short eat dessert first!
You have your choice of fillings-lemon curd, warm chocolate etc. you can order them in threes, or fives etc.
I highly recommend the lemon curd. It is the perfect taste sensation. They are brought to the table warm, and should be enjoyed immediately. They are pretty much hollow on the inside which allows you to easily open them up and add whatever your choice of filling maybe. Once you fill them, bite into that yummy goodness, and your life will be completely changed. I love the fact that while they are slightly sweet, they are not overly sugary, and it is the perfect treat to have with a good cup of coffee.

I absolutely loved my toast with the smoke salmon. It was rather odd to have it with a scrambled egg on top which is their recommendation, but I will tell you, it works. The smoked salmon is not overly salty, is a fairly generous portion, and the combination of all the flavors together make for a perfect harmony.

The crêpe that we ordered that was filled with the banana and the Nutella, was definitely way too sweet for me, and I preferred the savoriness of my salmon toast.  

This definitely is the perfect place for breakfast when you are burnt out by the heaviness of the local fried treats, and you are looking for something completely unique and wonderful. I highly recommend the salmon on the toast! The entire menu sounds incredible, and I look forward to going back and trying other dishes. They do offer other dishes that are savory, in addition to some of the sweeter sounding counterparts. This is definitely a place worth checking out!! 

Don't forget the aebleskivers !!!", "This brunch was INSANE and I am so incredibly happy we had a chance to eat here! My boyfriend and I woke up on a Sunday ready to eat, but we knew the lines for brunch and lunch would be insane. Luckily, I noticed that French Toast features the Yelp Waitlist feature, so I added our names to the list while we walked the 20-minute journey to the restaurant. It felt really comforting to see our place move up in line in real time. We used those extra minutes beforehand to explore the French Market a bit nearby, and before we knew it, our table was ready.

We were seated at the counter, and were overwhelmed by all of the incredibly unique brunch options. I started off with a pomegranate mimosa (YESSSSSS!) and my boyfriend ordered an Irish coffee. These were the best decisions. If you want something cold to drink, I recommend that mimosa, and for something warm, go with the coffee! I dare you!!!!

Picking something to eat was extremely difficult, because *everything* looked incredible. I wavered back and forth between the fried oysters avocado toast (c'mon, that sounds ridiculously good) and the king cake french toast. I ultimately went with the french toast, which was a very, very good decision, because it was stuffed with cinnamon cream cheese. How dare they, honestly?! How dare they come up with something so fantastic?!?!

Along with our individual meals, we asked for an order of aebelskivers, because we saw pretty much everyone around us eating these powdery treats. If you're even mildly curious as to what these would taste like, ORDER THEM. Just do it, and get the jam to dip them in. The aebelskivers here are warm, doughy, and topped with powdered sugar. Like a lil' beignet. This was the perfect addition to our brunch!

Thank you to the sweet staff at French Toast and those who created the menu. I highly, HIGHLY recommend this spot for brunch. Add yourself to the waitlist... now!", "Another place that disappointed with not only the food but also with service. Yes they were busy on a memorial day weekend but the servers were in rush to get you through the experience quickly. 
You can join the waiting list on Yelp, but you'll have to check in within a given period of time. It also tells you how many parties are ahead of you. 
Food wise, coffee was just okay, chicken was dry in fried chicken sandwich and we couldn't finish it, omelette was plain, very plain and I've had better. The avocado toast was okay, but the bread itself was tough and we didn't finish it."]

name: Le Rendez-vous
categories_raw: Restaurants, French, Tapas/Small Plates
top_reviews:
['I can't believe I found this place and I am really glad I did. This place is amazing. I love French cuisine and this tiny little place is literally an oasis in the desert.
Google Maps is your best friend lol. I googled "French" and this place popped up. I saw that they made souffle's and I was like, " Oh hell yes." So after some convincing, my husband (remember he's cheap), agreed and we went for our wedding anniversary. 
This place is kind of hard to spot from the road: it is a white building that says Le Rendezvous on the side, but if you're driving it can be difficult to see from the road. The inside has a bistro side and a restaurant side--the only difference is you see the specials on the bistro side. We chose the restaurant side because we looked at the menu online beforehand, and had an idea of what we wanted. I remember the bread was freshly baked, straight out of the oven and we couldn't stop eating it. It took a good amount of self-control to not ask for another basket. My husband got the steak frites and I got the scallops. The steak was cooked a perfect medium/medium-rare. The scallops were also cooked perfectly, not rubbery or raw. The garlic aioli the scallops came with was really flavorful and added depth to the overall dish. For dessert, I got the souffle and since my birthday was only 2 days prior, we got a free creme brulee. 
I love this place and again I am really glad I found it. I wish everyone to try it because it is truly a gem.', "We recently spent our one year anniversary trip revisiting where we got married, minus the stress and the guests!  Wanting to go off of our resort for one night and enjoy one of our favorite foods/meals , we were lead to Le Rendezvous. Because we were staying at our wedding venue on Starr Pass, and were likely to have wine, we took an Uber. For a few minutes, I wondered where we were headed, but the lengthy trip was worth it! We were warmly greeted and seated in the dining room upon our arrival. The dining room is small and quaint and the Rat Pack crooned over the sound system adding a nice ambience. It was, our wedding reception music, after all!! Did they know?! There is a Yelp check in offer for a gratis glass of wine , but we opted for a French 75. This classic lemony martini topped with champagne was handshaken at our table.. the extra left in the martini shaker for us. Nice! I would not come close to finishing this drink and I knew pretty quickly that if I tried, I would be done. It was good, but it packed a punch!! The wine list, primarily French wines from all the various regions in France, was impressive! I spent several minutes trying to decide what would be my wine for dinner! Our server, was so gracious and friendly .. he knew the menu backwards and forwards and recommended dishes and wine to me when I was hung up on what to order. The menu is classic French but was missing Foie Gras, which I love ! He excused himself for a second and asked the chef if they could grant my wish: Voila! Wish granted! I ended up not going with the foie gras, after all of that, as my main was a Beef Wellington, which is rich and wrapped in foie gras. Can I ever just make my mind up ?! I started with the Salade de Epinard: a spinach Salad with carmelized sweet onions, chèvre , perfect crisps of lardons amongst the perfect Dijon vinagrette.. THIS could have been my main! I was quickly taken back to Cafe du Trocadero in Paris where I had this salad all the time ! My husband ordered the pate to start. This starter was a tremendous amount of pate! So rich and filling ! He also had the Gratin du Oignon, a steaming rich , bubbling gratin of French onion soup that was bubbling with delightful Guyere cheese on top. Next we both opted for the Beef Wellington. This isn't a dish that is often offered on menus and I've only seen it once , maybe?, in Phoenix .. so it's a treat, when prepared correctly. This Beef Wellington was an ample serving of filet , tucked amidst foie gras and baked rare within a perfect , flaky warm crust that was melt in your mouth heaven! Our dishes were served with crisp yet tender pomme des Annas, potatoes that were just perfectly crisp and seasoned and also vegetables to balance the meal. This Beef Wellington was outstanding and perfectly prepared! There was so much of it, and it's so rich , there was no way either of us could complete our meals. This wasn't your typical upscale meal, where the food is all about looking decorative and not a lot to eat; NO! These portions were a lot for a French , upscale restaurant! Next came out dessert, the waiter brought us a Grand Marnier Soufflé to share for our anniversary celebration ! The concierge at our wedding resort must have set that up! Literally, I've never seen a soufflé so puffy and perfect! It came with Chantilly Creme and again... so very French! This meal was one of my husbands and my favorites likely for the year... and as you can see from my reviews, we travel and we eat a lot!! I can't say enough about Le Rendezvous and how amazing the food was here! The entire experience was almost as perfect as it could be outside of France... even the waiter snapping at his helper was authentic! ( Yes! We could hear that from our table 'number 2' !! :-) ) Finding good , VERY good French food in Arizona is hard.. this is the place! Merci Beaucoup!!", 'I was very impressed with this place. Very classy joint, I felt very under-dressed (but then again I was wearing shorts and a T-shirt, so my bad). My wife and I came in right at the end of their lunch service, so the place wasn't quite empty, but you could tell things were winding down; by our waiter's demeanor, however, you would never have known they were about to close up. Our waiter was great, very patient, and urged us to take our time. We started with the baked brie appetizer, and it was fantastic. Brie covered in a puff pastry, accompanied by what I believe were caramelized pears and a tangy balsamic vinegar. For the main coarse, I ordered the beef wellington, and shortly after it came out, my brain exploded. First time I'd ever had a beef wellington, so I have nothing to compare this to, but it was a revelation for me. The most tender beef, gently engulfed in a pastry crust, smothered in gravy (or au jus, but whatever it's all gravy to me), with hidden nuggets of fois gras nestled within it. The beef just melted in my mouth along with the pastry and I was in heaven. This is one of those rare meals that, when you finish, you are genuinely sad that it is over. I'm pretty sure my wife ordered something too, but I couldn't tell you what it was because I was far too focused on mine. 90% I didn't even say 2 words to her during dinner service because of my mouthgasm. I guess what I'm trying to say is: "Order the damn beef wellington!"

In summation, go here.']

name: Pontilly Coffee
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Food, Bagels, Bakeries
top_reviews:
["Hello!!!! Winning!!!! Only a month old!!!!  

If you build it, THEY WILL COME. 

SORRY St*rbucks, y'all missed out. I'm happy to see more businesses come to the area and this one is no exception. 

The spot of the former ICE HOUSE on Gentilly across from the Baptist Seminary; between 'God is good car wash' &  Church's Chicken is this god-send of a coffee shop. 

Not only that, but this is a FAITH BASED coffeeshop... LOVING IT!!!!

Proceeds from sales go to the program to help other program participants; way cool!!!! 

Annnnnnnnnnnnd to top it off, there's a loyalty program that is super duper awesome. 

Pros:
Close to my house
The loyalty program
Great hours 
Great pricing
Giving back to the community
Coffee, tea, lattes, snacks & lite bites 

Cons:
More parking

I'm so ecstatic!!!!", "I'm very excited about this place. It's a coffee shop in Gentilly! Very close and leading into the East, so it's able to serve both communities which makes me happy. It's located in a central location on Chef Menteur, directly across the street from the New Orleans Baptist Theological Seminary.

Great vibe in this location. You walk into jazz playing in the background and friendly staff. The staff is awesome, smiling and very informative. They give you the rundown of everything they have available and make suggestions. I really enjoyed their enthusiasm. The location is accommodating with indoor and outdoor seating, with seating for 2,4, and 6 individuals. Good place for studying, working, meetups and they don't close until 9 pm; which is a plus, especially for this area.

I went with a specialty latte called Pontilly Latte, which included honey and cinnamon and it was such a delightful treat for my morning weekend start.  This medium latte cost $3.60 and it was wonderful.  There is a large offering of coffee, frappe espresso, tea items on the menu for extremely reasonable prices. They also offer pastries, specialty biscuits and specialty mini sandwiches called Nola Che.  You definitely got to check this place out.

There is some parking in front and back. Shouldn't be much trouble to find parking while visiting. 

What makes this better is this is a social entrepreneurial project, owned by Bethel Colony, in which this coffee shop supports residential treatment programs for men and women.", "Stopped in a few times on my way to work and really love this place, the decor is pretty fun and the coffee is excellent! Give Pontilly a shot if you're in the neighborhood!!"]

name: Filipiniana Philippine Café
categories_raw: Filipino, Restaurants, Bubble Tea, Food
top_reviews:
['So this morning I looked at my Peen
And was shocked to see it had turned green
Drove to the ER
And they said "ha ha ha...
You just need to eat more Philippine!"

When Filip turns Ana's navel from an outie to an innie, that's known as "Filip-innie-ing-Ana." It happens often. But this is not that.

In fact this is an adorable little Filipino bakery, but they need way more help than they're getting tho. Takes literally forever to get any given thing if anyone is in front of you, especially ordering drinks. But man, they have wonderful pineapple cakes. 

If this rating was based on the wait time for what I ate here then I would have to give one star cuz it was just ridiculous and I mean really ridiculous.

But... If I'm going to do it based on the quality of the goods, it would actually get five stars. I still haven't tried a lot of the stuff I want to try, like the drinks, because they didn't have the ones that I was looking to try on the day that I came, and it's another problem to be out of some of their top stuff, especially for an out-of-town who only comes through once every few years like me, who can give them a really great review and implore people to come here, and spread the word, but they didn't have what I wanted on the day I was here.

In any case nothing but good things to say about the baked products in a state which doesn't have a lot of great Asian bakeries, so there's no doubt that I'm giving them five stars.

If your friend says don't come here, I ask you, what does he know?
He probably spends half his life gambling in a Casino
He probably skips Vegas so he can go to Reno
Forget him and come here and eat more Filipino!

WHAT!', "Wow.

I hardly write reviews anymore and five stars is definitely generous.

I missed the Yelp brunch event today because I was already attending another event in Tampa, but was not interested in the restaurant there. Instead, I wanted to finally cross Filipiniana off my list because I had been to Saigon Deli many times.

They are the Filipino version of Jimmy John's! Everyone was so eager to help. I ordered the beef menudo (weekend special) and a pair of cheese cupcakes to go.

I had just finished signing my e-bill and my food was packed and ready to go. Finishing eating just now.

Omg. The beef menudo tastes like the carnes con papas my Cuban friend used to make me. And the cheese cupcake tasted like pound cake.

So glad I finally tried it! I could come back next time I make it over the bridge.", 'Whenever I walk inside I can always count on a cheerful greeting from Jenina & the crew which adds to the friendly & fun atmosphere of this place. From the painted purple & green walls to the pictures of yummy Filipino desserts plastered on the walls, Filipiniana is a place that can be loved and appreciated by anyone craving for dessert & boba drinks!

Their biggest draw is their Halo-Halo (meaning "Mix-Mix"), a popular Filipino dessert containing shaved ice & a various assortment of jellies, ice cream, fruit & sweet beans topped with pinipig (toasted rice flakes) that when "mixed" together forms a wonderful dessert to cool yourself down after those hot Florida days. Hands down Filipiniana serves the best Halo-Halo in town!

They also serve other popular Filipino desserts such as Taho (silken tofu w/brown sugar & syrup), Mais con yello (shaved ice served with condensed milk & sweetened corn), ensaymada (Filipino pastry topped with cheese & sugar) & various other treats shipped in from Christine's Bakery in New Jersey.

I've come here sooo many times that I've even gotten my own boba drink! Next time your in the area, stop on by and order the LARRY. I guarantee you'll love it!']

name: Mac Mart
categories_raw: American (Traditional), Restaurants, American (New)
top_reviews:
['Why can't I go higher than 5 stars for this review?  I quit , I am not going to continue with this soon to be awesome review. Oh I am just kidding my fellow mac and cheese addicts, you know I have to give Mac Mart their props. 

They say if at first you don't succeed, try again until one is successful.  I think that is it, or maybe something of that nature. I came on opening day to only find out they were sold out of this creamy cheesy goodness by 6 pm.  I mean c'mon, this is probably some of the best mac and cheese out there, I wouldn't expect nothing less coming from Mac Mart. 

I could place the blame on Mac Mart for dropping the ball in not having enough, but I won't. I could also place the blame on mother nature for the rainy day. This is where every idiot was out there driving, causing accidents, and jam ups making me late, but I won't though.  I will say this, my second visit made it even more pleasurable where the expectations were met.  

Mac Mart, I am clearly infatuated with your mac and cheese. A cheesy decadent bowl of gratification is what you'll be diving into. Mac Mart has their well known signature bowls, their concocted blends that will seriously have you saying " I want that one, and this one" . They also have a make a bowl where the options are endless, and there goes any kind of self control you think you might have. I am strong and secure enough to say it happened to me, I fell victim to this.  

I went with their Wit Mac, which by the way was not an easy decision to make. A "Wit Mac" bowl is prepared with  cheesesteak, caramelized onions and a potato crunch laying over top. So friggin good, but I added bacon, along with sriracha to this work of art. My masterpiece has now been completed ,and I was in heaven. I seriously wanted to get another one to go, but this time I wanted to get their Crabby Mac, BBQ Bowl ,Cowboy bowl and their well known Marts Mac. That one is a 7 cheese blend by the way, and you can never go wrong with the original.  

The prices are up there, as Stephanie had mentioned with being in the city I can see why. You are also getting a pound of mac and cheese with toppings to fulfill ones appetites, or desires. The crew in here are all in sync , making sure there is a constant fluid pace, feeding the on-goers . These guys have always been jammed packed with those cheese crazed patrons (myself included). If it isn't that well known pink truck feeding the masses through out the city, it's now to their store.   

Mac Mart you guys provide a cheesy, creamy, goodness that needs to be revisited over and over again. Keep up with the great work guys, and I can't wait to see you at Night Market, on the streets, or maybe in your store.', "First off, Mac Mart is my favorite food truck in Philly. So the fact that they were opening a brick and mortar location literally around the corner from my office... oh man you can bet your mac and cheese I was friggin excited! 

The store is just like the truck with an amazing selection of mac and cheese bowls packed into a cute little shop! Of course they couldn't deny that signature bright pink truck and the to-go bags are the same beautiful hue you can proudly carry around Center City that says heck yeah I just got some amazing mac and cheese, BE JEALOUS!

Ok so the mac is amazing, just like the truck! They've got quite a few options and even a build-your-own. I've been here a few times - the last time I got the wit and the time before that was jalapeno of some sort. The wit was awesome... I mean really, how can you deny yourself cheesesteak wit onions, drizzled in ketchup, panko, and crushed potato chips, all on top of the warmest most gooiest most delciously creamiest mac n cheese ever!

Seriously, this stuff is good. Like way more than a little bit. I like it a lot. A lot a lot a lot! As others have noted, it is on the pricey side but then again so is their truck for what you get so it's really not far off base. My ONLY wish is that they offered a smaller portion size! Sometimes I could just go for a mac snac (go ahead, steal that please - Mac Snac TM).

Go eat the mac, right now!", 'Love this new little nook and all the inventive ways they spin macaroni and cheese! I see some complaints that it's "pricey" for mac n cheese, but I don't agree - each item on the menu is less than $10, which is a great deal when you compare it to restaurant prices for the same thing. In addition, their "flavors" are all so creative - my friends and I ordered quite the variety so as to get a good sampling.

My personal favorite (and the group's): In the Buff, AKA the buffalo chicken mac n cheese. The creamy ranch and buffalo buffer the richness of the cheese w/ just enough spicy kick and give it this savory goodness that makes you take bite after bite. I want to go back to Mac Mart and eat In the Buff all day every day.

Runner-up: Roasted Red Pesto - if you like veggies and pesto, this is the one for you! The Jalapeno Popper is great for those of you who like spicy and cheesy. The Rittenhouse is reminiscent of spinach and artichoke dip - creamy and rich. I don't think you can go wrong at Mac Mart, each option on the menu looks great! I'll definitely be coming back to fill in my punch card (buy 10 get 1 free!).

Tip for the owners, if they see this: I love the tupperware and I'll definitely be re-using mine! To be eco friendly, it might be a good idea to offer some small discount for people who bring their tupperware back. Just a thought!']

name: Hotel Monteleone
categories_raw: Hotels & Travel, Hotels, Event Planning & Services
top_reviews:
["New Orleans? The Big Easy! 

I have been to this town a few times and it is not just about the French Quarter.  This city has a rich history and so happens to be my favorite foodie town of all time! Make sure you visit the whole city but if you are checking out the French Quarter, you can't  beat the location, quality and traditional history this hotel has. Yup, the hotel is old..dirt old. The rooms are small. However, this hotel has been renovated and is kept in excellent condition. Views from the upper floors let you gaze over the Mississippi. Other rooms have balconies overlooking the prime streets of the French Quarter. Views from the rooftop pool allow you to gaze over this entire gem of a city!

Yup, it is even haunted by a toddler.

I have stayed here twice. Each time has been great. During busy times, customer service does not exist. During slow times, good luck finding the parking attendant.

Overall, I am a fan.", "Beautiful, historic and supposedly haunted hotel in the middle of the French Quarter. Excellent location for walking to everything you need! 

One of the biggest draws is the stunning, rotating Carousel Bar which is not to be missed!!! They offer nightly classic jazz and super strong cocktails with French inspired names. We loved having a drink while waiting for our room and before a night out on the town. 

There is an on-site restaurant serving brunch, lunch and dinner if need be. It has decent reviews. Personally I feel there are so many other great restaurants in this fine city, why bother with one in your hotel? Get out and taste everything! Emergency hangover food only. 

Some in our party ordered room service which is always great to have as a late night munchies option especially when you know you'll be drinking. They said it was tasty but did take quite awhile to be delivered. 

Walgreens and a Smoothie King are located on the same block for forgotten/emergency needs or for a morning detox smoothie to go. There's also Café Beignet just to the left which is not to be confused with Café Du Monde. Both can be very crowded depending on the time you visit. Don't give up if the line is long. Check back! Coffee and sweets and a nice courtyard area. 

There's a lovely relaxing rooftop pool with amazing views of downtown New Orleans. Whether you're swimming or not, take a peek up there! It's so gorgeous!! Don't forget your suit! 

There's a also a small gym with enough equipment to break a sweat. 

The rooms are very cozy and have a vintage feel. Beds are uber comfortable and pillows are super plush too. 

Shower pressure is great and the toiletries were of a higher quality. 

There are Kuerig machines on each desk, but I would have appreciated a fridge as I always had leftovers. 

The staff is wonderful!!! Big shout out to the friendly, smiling faces at the front door!! We were given many suggestions each day, especially a lot of locals only places which we really appreciated! We were also directed towards the street car which was a fun, easy way to get around! Highly recommend! Picking up our Uber for the airport and our tour van out front was simple too. 

We arrived super early before our 4pm check-in and had no issues leaving our bags in the room designated for storage. (Don't forget to bring cash for tipping!) I should note our room was ready before standard check-in time, but we were already out on the town!

Another great thing about the hotel is it's massive sign you can see from almost anywhere in The Quarter! I'm not going to pretend like it didn't come in handy while stumbling home at night, perhaps a bit dazed and confused :) 

I think it's a great option for a romantic getaway with that sexy lounge and bar and for families because of the pool. With so many hotels in town I'm not sure I would return here right away, but I would consider it again after seeing other options. 

The only reason for the less than 5 star was something that may not bother others and may seem minor, but I think it speaks volume about the management, and that's the fact that there was no complimentary coffee in the lobby. This hotel is not cheap by ANY means and a little hospitality goes a long way. To boot, a small cup was $3.50 in the gift shop. It would cost the hotel very little and would be a very nice gesture. I don't even even drink it, but my friend did each and every morning I was turned off by this greatly. Lame!", 'HOW TO "OWN" THE BEST HOTEL IN THE CITY:
I purposely choose my staycation week to score the Monteleone's best annual rates during that oppressively hot third week of August. It is then that tourists most avoid the city and kids have started back to school. 

It's pure discounted luxury: an empty gym, room service in just 20 minutes, no elevator passenger stops, a fortuitous room upgrade, the sole use of the pool, and my favorite seat in the Carousel Bar always open. Coincidentally it's Coolinary and reciprocating museum month.  Owning a week at the Monteleone, well it doesn't get much better.']

name: Urban South Brewery
categories_raw: Breweries, Food
top_reviews:
["I love Urban South Brewery so damn much!!

They've actually installed AC in their brewery and it's gorgeous. Beer flavors are always changing, colors of the tasting room are so vibrant and welcoming (not to mention they're #OpenToALL )

During the beginning of the pandemic they were one of the first breweries to change production from beer to hand sanitizer and they not only donated a shit load to the community but they sold it to the public at prices that were more than fair and they didn't price gouge when it was literally like hitting a gold mine finding hand sanitizer.

I've grown quite fond of their hard seltzers ( gotta love a low carb, low cal option), but my tried and true, Paradise Park will always have my heart.", 'Yes!!!!! Another awesome brewery in Nola! And, delicious beer! 

I tried: Holy Roller IPA, nice and subtly hoppy, good color and cooooooooold as ice. I love that they serve their beers in mason jars. 

Charming Wit: Nice alternative to all the super hoppy stuff most breweries are doing these days. Almost floral, very fragrant. Easy to drink!

Charming Shandy: Man! This is going to be delicious in the summer. A bit overly citrus-y for my taste, but refreshing and one will be nice when it's HOT outside. 

What I didn't try: Grapefruit IPA, because they were out. 

Organic Lemonade, because it's non-alcoholic and I'll leave that to the kiddos. 

The large and almost barren warehouse space provides seating on picnic tables. There's a "kid area" with a chalk board and games/crafts. In door bathrooms, which is always a nice convenience. 

They take credit cards via square (you can have an open tab). They also sell growlers and merch, like t-shirts. 

There's plenty of parking on the side street. 

The one MAJOR complaint I have is that there's a large fan and it's ridiculously loud. I mean, you cannot have a conversation loud. I bet the cool air will be nice this summer though!!', 'Urban South was founded by Jacob Landry.  They opened their doors in March, 2016. Jacob is a native Louisianian.   The seeds for Urban South were planted during Jacob's college years when he lived in Europe for a stint.  He fell in love with the European brews and wanted to bring that home to NOLA.  The history of beer in Louisiana is interesting.  There used to be a scene, but it died away, and has only saw a rebirth in recent years. It seems a step behind other cities, like the beer scene in Austin, TX for example.  The mission of Urban South is to "bring the heritage of European beer making with the "brashness" of American styles".  The tasting room and production area are located in an old warehouse district.  We had a hard time at first finding the entrance. We walked around the huge warehouse until we found it!  The interior is open and quite large. I have never seen such a family oriented tasting room!  They had a bouncy house and many kid friendly areas.  I am not sure if this was just for a special event, or if they have something similar on weekends often.  There was a football game playing on the TV's and many locals were just hanging out with their kids playing around them.  We saw several pizzas get delivered while we were there.  The staff were friendly and knowledgeable.  My husband and I each tried a flight.  They offer free tours on the weekends.  My husband had been trying local beer throughout our stay at local establishments, and this was the best of the trip!  He even bought some cans to take home with him.  I don't love beer, but I enjoyed all the beers in my flight (that's saying something!). I found them to be well structured and balanced.  The merchandise here is some of the best I have scene.  We don't usually buy stuff, but we bought a jacket, shirt, and glassware.  I would definitely recommend a visit to this brewery if you are in the area. It will be a to do for every visit. We really enjoyed our time at this family fun hang out spot with good brews.  They seemed to have large fans with large warehouse doors that open up. So I am not sure if they have AC.  It may get hot in the summertime.  We went in the fall so the weather was a bit cool. WE just kept our jackets on.']

name: Lobster Haven
categories_raw: Specialty Food, Seafood Markets, Seafood, Food, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['I think this place changed owners because there was a few things I noticed that were different.  Visually, the crab cake sandwich didn't look as appetizing like before. Completely different sandwich. If you look at my old photos the food looks nothing like what I recieved on my first visit . Much smaller portion on a roll they use for the lobster sandwiches (tasty bread) , but made the crabcake smaller? If I can hold a sandwich with one hand and not both, we got problems. 
I can do without the Potato Chips filler in the basket. At least put good potato chips in there if you're going to do that. I know they have to try to make it look like you're actually getting food here, but you're not. 
They can keep those, and should serve a more decent sized scoop of potato salad or coleslaw  instead of the small souffle cup serving that would normally be used for a to-go side salad dressing. That's sad. 
That should not be considered a side that comes along with your meal. Take an ice cream scooper, save your soufflé cup and plop one scoop of potato salad In the basket. 
DITCH the cheap chips! You save way more money getting rid of those chips, saving the cups which are pricey alone, and you have a way more satisfied customer. You're welcome.
It didn't help that they were out of potato salad, and I was stuck with coleslaw . 
I actually love coleslaw, so I didn't mind, until I realized how much I needed the potato salad to help fill my stomach because of the small portions . 
I wanted more food! * pounds fork on table repeatedly *
, but I wasn't about to drop 40 just for myself on lunch. 
I was hoping the Yelp check in offer for free bourbon street pudding(also made differently)would help the void in my stomach. Sadly, we didn't finish it because it was cold in the middle, and not as soft as it should have been. Also, they used to serve it in a bourbon sauce which was way better, and this was a cream cheese like frosting spread on top. 
Check Groupon for the "deal" before coming. It's the only way it's worth coming here for a try. 
I let my guest take the Groupon deal because she ordered a lobster roll that would have been $21.99 without it. It was ridiculously small. . 
Overall, the sandwiches were tasty, but I don't like to leave hungry after I spend  $20+ on lunch. 
not worth the value for me personally.', 'A seafood restaurant with a distinct costal New England feel to it. As you can tell by the name, at least 60% of the menu items have lobster in it. 

Lobster "chowda," lobster rolls, lobster cakes, lobster wraps, lobster tails, lobster guacamole, and entire cooked lobsters that you have to crack open are what you'll find here. 

They have buckets of live lobsters in the back so everything is made fresh on premises. 

That being said, I thought the lobster roll was decent but tasted bland. It was filled with chunks of lobster but I wish they would season it more. It's lobster + mayo on bread. Am I missing something? 

The homemade chips and potato salad weren't anything memorable as well. Not bad, no good, just meh...

Overall, I'm stuck in the middle about Lobster Haven. I wouldn't recommend but I also wouldn't discourage someone from giving it a try.', "One of my new favorite seafood places.

I took my dad all over Tampa Bay to eat while he was in town and his favorite meal was here. That alone should tell you how spectacular this place is. 

ATMOSPHERE: This place doubles as a seafood market. There aren't many tables, but it wasn't that busy at lunch on a Monday so it didn't matter. It is clean and there is a slight fish smell, but it fades away pretty quickly once you get use to it. 

SERVICE: From what I could tell, there was only one person working there. She was super friendly and checked in just the right amount of time. The food also came out pretty quickly. You can definitely get in and out of here in less than an hour.

FOOD: This is the best part. The food is spectacular. We started with a cup of clam chowder. It was thick and hearty. I've never had a clam chowder that was so thick before. It must have been supremely rich, but it didn't taste that way. There was a ton of clams. I could wax poetics for hours about this clam chowder. Just writing about it makes me want to go back and get a bowl of it! The lobster roll was also delicious. My dad was a little surprised that it was $21, but I find that it the going rate for lobster rolls in Tampa Bay. The crab cake sandwich was also fantastic. (I think the theme here is everything is great). If I had to choose, I would probably go with the lobster roll over the crab cake, but by a slim margin. I tried both the potato salad and the coleslaw. I liked the potato salad better, but both are pretty good. They give you a ton of chips, but don't waste your stomach space on that. It comes out of a bag, so it is nothing special. When we checked in on Yelp we got a free bourbon bread pudding! It's homemade and it is sinfully good. I had to tell them we weren't going to take the rest home because I knew that it was slowly killing me. Right now, writing this, I am mourning that decision. It was so moist because it soaked up all the sauce and slathered in icing. Go in prepared to get the bread pudding so you don't eat too much and get full before dessert!

This was all a very long way of saying I love this place and I would return weekly if my waistline and wallet allowed it."]

name: Buffalo Exchange
categories_raw: Fashion, Used, Vintage & Consignment, Men's Clothing, Thrift Stores, Women's Clothing, Shopping
top_reviews:
['Any store with the quality and style of merchandise that this particular Buffalo Exchange has runs the risk of turning into a hipster island, filled with holier-than-thou 80s fashion and lots of noses being looked down. 

Instead--quite refreshingly--this store is stuffed with hip, sexy, cool stuff and staffed by people who just like fashion. Sure, they're hip looking. Yes, they may be hipsters. But damn if they weren't actually nice instead of pulling the "Gosh, I'm just cooler than you" shit. 

The woman at the cash register was bouncy and straight forward, explaining the pricing system and the token thing. When we questioned the price of a pair of shoes (on the wrong rack), she was polite and professional. Not once did she make me feel stupid. It was so nice. 

I was a little disappointed in the selection of fat girl sizes, but I know that depends greatly on the day. I'll check back for more good stuff in the future, and I may even sell some of my own clothes that have long bored me. And how do I know there wasn't a large selection of my size? Because everything was where it should be. Magical. 

Accessibility notes: Step up into the store. Narrow doorway. Changing rooms are large enough for mobility devices or assistance. Shelves extend up the entire wall so some items may be out of reach for seated customers.', "I Find This Store RACIST Against  Blacks,When I Comes Down To Selling CLOTHS TO THEM 
Me And My Friend(Who IS White B.t.w)
Went into the store in hopes of selling our used cloths I went in first with nothing but designer cloths Michael kors,Vintage Coach,Gucci and all and they didn't take Any of it... Which left me quite puzzled,
SO I sent my friend in there just to double Check And BOOMMMMMMMMM 
THEY took everything In the bag GUYSS PLEASE BEAWARE
I WILL NEVER ENTER THIS STORE AGAIN", 'Absolutely my new favorite place on the planet. So far I've been there twice, once in search of Mardi Gras costume options, and more recently because I needed a dress to wear to the NOLA Fashion Week wrap party at Eiffel Society, where I knew everyone would (as usual) look infinitely more fabulous than me, times a million. These were tremendously successful shopping trips, on both counts. And I loathe shopping. Mostly because I suck at it. But I'm starting to get the hang of it here. 

Next time I visit, I'm bringing every article of clothing I don't wear, and then some. Hell, maybe I'll just bring it all. They take clothes whenever they're open for business (as opposed to on certain days of the week like some used book stores I know). While you wait, they'll sort through your unwanted stuff, determine what they can sell and for how much, then give you a store credit for 50% of that total amount and tell you to have fun. Alternatively, if you want cash, I believe the percentage is 30%. Added bonus: they'll go ahead and donate anything they don't want, so with one trip you can offload all your "what-on-earth-was-I-thinking" slash "admit it, you'll never be that size again, or age for that matter" slash "fat clothes" slash otherwise out of style/out of favor articles of clothing.

Fabulous stuff, for cheap. Offload your less than fabulous stuff, to buy more stuff. This is genius. I heart you, Buffalo Exchange.']

name: Li'l Dizzy's Cafe
categories_raw: Restaurants, Cajun/Creole
top_reviews:
["Louisiana fried chicken is some of the best in the country.  Why Popeyes started in Arabi, Louisiana.  Fried chicken is serious in New Orleans.  While super hot Nashville fried chicken is pervasive these days, IMHO, fried chicken in NOLA is my fave.  I have been to 20 highly rated fried chicken joints in NOLA and hands down Li'l Dizzy's is the most delicious and perfect fried chicken I've ever had. It is lightly crunchy, garlicky, juicy chicken;  a couple of  drops of Louisiana hot sauce and I am  in fried chicken nirvana.  

Other dishes that are exceptional here? The seafood gumbo (light roux, with blue crab, two kinds of sausage and shrimp) is unbelievable as I've noted in past reviews.   The burnt ends of the bread pudding here is to die for too. The shrimp and grits is soulful. And, the rolls are everythang. Lol. I can keep going.
