As the previous reviewer mentioned below, they always have room in their class! Very frustrating that they aren't on class pass - I'll just have to find a new studio to love that honors that.  One other negative is that the yoga rooms themselves need updating. The floors need to be redone especially in the hot yoga room. They should use the Zebra flooring that another studio has. It's a lot cleaner and easier on your joints. There's also an obstructing pole in two of the rooms that just breaks the vibe of the class. It's not pleasant to look at if you're in the back. 

All in all, my love for Yoga began at Bella but I think until they make some changes I'll take my practice elsewhere.']

name: Gusto Osteria
categories_raw: Restaurants, Italian
top_reviews:
['I am pretty sure that Gusto Osteria translates to "Party in your Piehole". The food is super tasty, fresh and homemade. So much so that the food deserves five stars. They get minor deductions for the ambiance, which is just a little sterile.

Let's talk about the food: Our server (a VERY talkative young man - I will talk more about him later) pointed out, more than once, that all their sauces are made from scratch. He also suggested that we order something pan-seared and gave us examples of items that were. I took his suggestion and ordered one of their specials - a pork tenderloin, breaded and pan-seared, stuffed with ricotta, covered with sauce and cheese and then baked. I must say that it was one of the best Italian dishes I have had in a very long time. My wife had the Fettuccine Alfredo, with chicken. She gave me a taste: It was super authentic, not the Chef Boyardee stuff you get in practically any restaurant.

Their wine list, while still under development, was super affordable with plenty of choices. A glass of their house wine was $3.50, with prices going up on other wines from there. The house wine went perfectly with the dish I had ordered. My wife had Merlot (I ribbed her about ordering a red wine with a white sauce chicken dish, but the wine police never arrived at our table to haul her away) which she really enjoyed.

We were there pretty late during the week and the place was kind of slow, so our server had time to chat with us. I mentioned before he was really talkative, but pleasant to talk to. He knew a lot about tequila and was able to talk about wines, beer and food, all of my favorite subjects. My wife's comment: "I think you just found your son-in-law."

Now I just have to go back and drag one of my daughters over there. I should probably take them both... law of averages you know.', 'Welcome to the first of 29 reviews I'm writing in February as part of Yelp Tucson's Spread The Love Review Challenge 2012. (read more here http://www.yelp.com/topic/tucson-2012-yelpolutions-challenge-february)

Color me impressed Tanque Verde & Sabino Canyon. Outside of having one of the most craptastic intersections in all of Tucson, your instantly gaining points with me for this little gem of an Italian restaurant! At this point I've only had one dish, but it's incredible... smoked salmon and greens, tossed with olives, parmesan, feta and bow-tie pasta. If I'm being completely honest (which I'm going to be) the pasta doesn't do anything for me except make me feel like I am 5, so I ditch that. I also don't cheese it up because I'm lactarded and don't want to suffer the consequences of devouring dairy. With that said, this salad is topped with some of the best smoked fish I have ever eaten. And I usually make fun of people who say things like "the best thing I ever put in my mouth" and "so good I could die," so trust me when I say it's good. I'm told they smoke it there and I've never come up for air long enough while mauling the thing to ask what that means. I'll find out though and tell you what I come up with. I don't LOVE the seating style (see I just used the word love in case you were looking for it as part of February's review challenge), it just doesn't feel as warm and friendly as I'd expect from an Osteria, not that I know what an Osteria is. Gus... the G-U-S in Gusto tells me that it's sort of like a wine bar with food. He's a pretty cool guy, owner and overseer of operations. OOO[1]. Check them out, they're super tucked in the Safeway shopping center, and worth the drive and that stupid intersection for the smoked salmon. 

[1] Completely made up term, but I think if I owned a company I'd rather be an OOO than a CEO or CFO. How cool would it be to hear people say, that's Corey, he's our OOO as I walked down the hall! AND if I happened to be a magician and an OOO people could say, Corey, OOO he's magic.', 'Good food even better service. The people woking here are delightful! The food is good, not great. We had a Maniccoti App, Pizza, and a spinach salad. I would definitely go back to try other items. I loved the art work.']

name: Cafe Envie & Espresso Bar
categories_raw: Breakfast & Brunch, Tapas Bars, Bagels, Restaurants, Food, Coffee & Tea
top_reviews:
["Definitely stop here for breakfast in the French quarter! We went here one morning after a late night out. I enjoyed the drinks and food. The tables and restaurant were clean. I loved their giant bar like counter. We tried a few things. I recall ordering: 

1) Raspberry schnapps mocha (tastes exactly as you'd imagine, and it's a nice surprise at breakfast time)

2) Turkey and pesto panini (classic Turkey pesto, nothing too fancy)

3) Breakfast in a cup (great if you're on the go, the grits were notably good)

I'd go back! Especially for that raspberry schnapps mocha, because, why not?", "Review by a coffee fiend...

True, when one is fiending, you might think any ol' bean extraction would suffice, but I'm no coffee whore. I'd gladly suffer the headache rather than swallow down some weak swill.

Envie's got the goods. The espresso drinks are buzz-worthy here (don't ask me about their drip. Don't ever ask me about drip). What's more, you can add booze to 'em! Do it! I have... one fierce hurricane afternoon. The occasion called for it. It was during Hurricane Isaac (this was about the only good coffeehouse open in the area). No one had power in their house for days. Most people were skipping work. And most people seemed to be at Envie. They kindly set up power strips and extension cords and it was like a Social Media Palooza going on in there. Because of course Facebook and Twitter is vital at a time like this. As is a giant, sweet, cold boozy coffee drink.", 'I can't say much about this place, other than their coffee is a life saver. Their iced coffee is delicious and full of flavor and the space itself is perfect if you want to get some work done, or just relax during a fun day in the Quarter. The staff is friendly and helpful and, although I didn't have any food on this stop, I will be returning to try some of their delicious offerings. I guess a place like this might be seen as a "tourist trap", but I think locals will enjoy it too.']

name: Crime & Punishment Brewing
categories_raw: Nightlife, Bars, Food, Breweries
top_reviews:
['Most of what I said in my original review holds true still.  Primarily, I think it's great that there's an actual brewery in Brewerytown. Please refer to that for my general thoughts.

I'm giving Crime and Punishment the extra star because the beer deserves it. After a few visits and about a dozen beers under my belt, this brewery has what it takes to standout and succeed.

Most recently I had the "Interrobang" and the "Peaches and Crime."  If you like hoppy double IPAs, Interrobang is fantastic. It can totally play the game with some of those rare DIPAs bad boys that like to float around Philly. On the other hand, the Peaches and Crime was light and refreshing. Not as peachy as the title would allude to, but very complex. Bottom line is that their beers have the complexity needed to differentiate themselves in a growing craft beer world. 

And guess what? Having Crime and Punishment in Brewerytown has gotten myself and many others into that neck of the woods, including other businesses like Spot Burger. Bravo! I'm seeing even more good things to come with this brewery and neighborhood.', "I came here for the grand opening with some friends.  We all had a great time sampling several of the beers, which were fairly reasonably priced (approximately $5-$7 per beer).  We all liked the beers we tried, especially the Eye for an Eye (imperial IPA), which clocked in at 10%+, but did not have the strong alcohol taste of many of its higher ABV relatives.  On the other end of the spectrum, we all also liked the Ghost Station, a raspberry Berlinerweisse, which was a perfect mix of sour, salty and sweet, with this style of beer quickly becoming my go-to summer session.  The space is nice.  It reminded me a bit of the decor in La Colombe's flagship.  All-in-all, the grand opening left me excited to see what Crime and Punishment will churn out.  I have yet to try the food, but I can see this brewpub becoming part of my bar rotation.", "Breweries are in hype nowadays in Philly. But a Russian literature themed brewery?  This is the only one.

I grew up in the 80's China, with heavy influence of Russian literature, culture, history and politics. Dostoevsky, Pushkin, Tolstoy, Turgenev, Chekhov...Russian novels, plays, movies, music, were all parts of my childhood.  To have a brewery named by Dostoevsky's novel? That was on top of my list to visit.

And it did not disappoint. I can't think of anything I don't like about this place.  A solid 5-star!

The place was small but adequate. Charming, with décor of Russian/Slavic posters, bookshelves filled with Russian/Slavic books, music covers and small statues.

The menu was equally short but sufficient.  8 beers on tap, including 2-3 IPA/DIPA, English, RIS, and Belgian. We had all the IPA, DIPA and RIS.  All surprisingly delicious.

For food, we shared the Polish Snack Pack and Charcuterie Board.  Both used with top quality ingredients with creative preparations, resulted fantastic and delicious East European experience.  

On top of everything, prices were reasonably and staff was pleasant. I can't wait to go back to try more brews and other East European inspired food items!"]

name: Hotel Mazarin
categories_raw: Venues & Event Spaces, Food, Event Planning & Services, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Hotels & Travel, Hotels
categories: ['venues & event spaces', 'food', 'event planning & services', 'beer', 'wine & spirits', 'hotels & travel', 'hotels']
top_reviews:
["We booked this hotel because it was the top 3 hotels rated on Tripadvisor. The other two hotels were in other parts of NOLA. We wanted to stay in the French Quarter, which made this hotel expensive for what you get.

-First off, location is important, we got to walk everywhere because this hotel was close to everything. 
-It's a sweet, quaint, boutique hotel
-Free continental breakfast in the mornings till 11
-Cute courtyard that we didn't get to use because it was too cold outside
-Loved the flooring in our room and the  beds were comfy.

Now, for the not-so-great
-the windows were double paned and can't be open
-Our room was by the fountain so it always sounded like it was raining outside, even when it wasn't
-the toilet was clogged and the water pressure is a little low, considering it's a hotel
-continental breakfast wasn't bad, but the coffee outside was lukewarm. 
-When we tried to book something with the concierge, she ignored me and talked to these two guys for a good 20 minutes before I said anything and she helped me. 

All in all, a nice place but when I come back to NOLA, I'm going to check out another place.", 'I'd never been to New Orleans before this week, and now I'm completely in love. Hotel Mazarin gave me a comfortable and aesthetically pleasing environment to rest my weary head at night, and it's set in a prime French Quarter location. A few steps in one direction you'll find Bourbon Street, and a few steps in the other is Royal. You can walk to so many fantastic bars, restaurants, galleries, and shops all within a short distance. I encourage everyone to explore further (duh), but you could seriously be well fed and entertained without going far at all.

I think Hotel Mazarin is lovely. I'm a sucker for decadent historical stories (who'd have thought I'd love New Orleans?!), so I was happy about the portrait of Giulio Mazarini in the lobby and so nerdily excited to read the print out of his life story in my room. Ol' Jules was a cardinal, a lawyer, a gambler, and a diamond collecter/designer. Whaaaat. Befriending kings and popes in order to gain higher positions in society, wooing queens with his jewels and developing battle schemes. Oh, the drama! I love it.

My hotel room was pretty little, but the bed was extremely comfy and I loved the black marble floors. I had a tiny window overlooking a small courtyard, and I was pleased with the well-working thermostat. I like a COLD room. Of course it was in the 40s and 50s outside during my stay, haha. I wonder if the temp could hold at 66 degrees in the sticky summer heat?! 

It rocks that Patrick's Bar Vin and the 21st Amendment bar are both inside the hotel, especially since they're both awesome. I was also impressed by the hotel's complimentary breakfast buffet (a really decent spread of pastries, bagels, bacon, sausage, scrambled eggs, fresh fruit, etc.). However, I had a few not so positive moments with Hotel Mazarin that I cannot overlook: 

1.) My shower didn't give me hot water. At all. I seriously had to take a barely luke-warm shower (meaning it wasn't ICE cold but it was still cool), and it was so unpleasant. Some of my colleagues figured out a trick for unleashing the heat, and if that's the case there needs to be a diagram or something! 

2.) The front desk staff gave off some seriously negative vibes. I found at least 2 of them to be completely aloof and rude when it came to my meager needs (like getting into my room and being directed to one of the bars). I'm not a high maintenance hotel guest in the slightest, but you'd have thought I was making ridiculous requests by the looks on their faces. First of all, check-in was sloppy and weird. It took an unusually long amount of time for the whole "initial this piece of paper and present your ID" scene to go down, and then no one offered to help us with our bags or point us in the right direction when our struggle (overpacking) was clear. No "enjoy your stay" or even a well-wishing smile.

After I was given my room keys I immediately went to my room, but neither key worked. No big deal. When I went downstairs to let them know, I was rudely lectured on how I'd deactivated my cards. "Don't put them in your wallet" with an annoyed sneer, like I was a child who knowingly disobeyed just to get attention. I never put the keys in my wallet, but even if I had it shouldn't matter. I'd expect to be given new room keys that work with a smile.

In the end, I had a positive experience here and I can see myself returning. But the not-so-helpful (or friendly) customer service was lacking, and that's the most important thing for me.', "4.5

I used to live in New Orleans. This was prior to Katrina and the livin' was easy. I had a brilliant 2/2 in a converted Lower Garden District mansion (across from Archie Manning's place, around the corner from the first Real World mansion and close to one of Anne Rice's spots)... and I didn't appreciate it. I was young and inexperienced and I thought that everyone had formal dining rooms, 15' celings and walk-in (as in multiple steps) pantries. Oh, youth. But, one thing I'd always wanted to do was to stay in the French Quarter. I'd eaten there. I'd imbibed there. I'd... well, I'm not going to tell on myself but I was young, single and a lawyer so... life was good. But, again, I never stayed there... and I regretted that.

Life moved on, job opportunities took me away from the city that care forgot, the storm hit, and I didn't think anymore about staying in the quarter in NOLA. After all, I had other cities to visit. Well, after 10+ years, work brought me back to the city and I was determined to stay in the Quarter. Luck shined on me and I found a fantastic deal with the HM. I study of Yelp reviews let me see that I was in good hands. I booked the room and got excited about my trip. As soon as I walked in, I knew I had made the right choice: a huge courtyard, large ceilings, mirrors, be-our-guest service (including two comp drinks at 21st Amendment just because)... I was back in New Orleans. I knew the avoid a room that looked out over the dining courtyard so I was extra pleased when I walked into my back courtyard room. It was gorgeous: marble floors, French Quarter charm, big tv, complimentary water (it's the little things), pedestal sink, writer's desk, plantation shutters, free wifi, ornate (but not gaudy) furniture, a comfortable king bed, large (modernish) shower (a nice surprise given then classic amenities), and a plush robe. Yes. This would do nicely.

The location can't be beat: you're in the middle of the quarter but not directly on Bourbon, so the noise won't make you crazy. In fact, noise was never an issue. Some times, in older properties, the walls are thin and every creak, bang and pop becomes an annoyance. Not so here. Something else I enjoyed: the complimentary breakfast. This was no Holiday-Inn-off-the-interstate breakfast (not that there's anything wrong with that; time and place rules all). This breakfast was full of choice, fresh fruit/juice, meat, eggs, bready goods, and sweets. Add to the bounty, eating the food in an open air courtyard... it's perfect. It's New Orleans. I can't believe I'd waited so many years to come back."]

name: Halcyon Floats
categories_raw: Massage, Medical Spas, Physical Therapy, Float Spa, Health & Medical, Beauty & Spas
top_reviews:
['It's official, I'm a "floater!" 

About six months ago my friend told me about the sensory deprivation tank craze that's everywhere in the Pacific Northwest, and I was immediately interested. I found a float tank in Bristol but it seemed like to much of a hassle to get to, and a lot in New York - but when I had a chance to get to the city I never had the time to squeeze in a soak.  Fast forward to an article I saw on be well Philly - finally a spot was opening up right on girard!  Once the website went live I booked an introductory package and scheduled my session.  

I didn't have any real expectations and knew that basically you get in a tank that's heated to the temperature of your skin, and float in a mixture of Epsom Salt and 10 inches of water.  You wear ear plugs, and lie in the dark all alone with you and your thoughts.  Sounds scary, but it's not.  The experience is yours alone and it is what you make of it. 

When the time came for my appointment I walked into a clean and bright space, and was greeted by a nice woman who immediately put me at ease.  She explained the tank and the process.  Each room is equipped with a private tank, a small shower, bath robe, towel, head pillow, ear plugs, and face towel with a water bottle to spray down your face in the event that you get salt in your eyes.  You even get a water proof light to bring inside the tank to help you until you become more orientated to the dark.  

I am very familiar with the benefits of Epsom Salt:  first off your body can absorb a good amount of magnesium this way, Epsom salt is good for recovery from work outs or muscle aches and pains, It is known to detoxify, help your nervous system function, improve heart health, and just relieve stress in general. A 90 minute session here is a more than sufficient time period to reap the benefits of an Epsom soak. 

I went into the tank with my pillow and light, closed the door, and got situated.  You really do float in the water! The 90 minutes i spent in the tank went by quickly.  I had read that some people can really get into a deep meditative state, but I don't think I was there - yet. It was very relaxing and really very comfortable.  My mind kind of shut off, and it wasn't until she knocked on the door, to tell me my time was up, that I snapped back into reality and thought "oh wow I'm in a weird dark tank." 

I took another shower, and this time I had to scrub all the salt off.  I did bring my own shampoo and conditioner - but they had all that there - I just am picky about products (ie LUSH products).  I use Epsom salt at home so I'm very familiar with the drying aspect of the salt, so I also brought my own lotion.  There wasn't any lotion in the private room but I noticed some in the shared bathroom - along w contact cases and a blow dryer.  So I guess if you forget yours they have it available.  

The place was clean and besides the dark tank, everything in the space is bright and fun!  There is water and tea available when you have finished, and I think I even saw some snacks - but i was in a rush to go to a birthday party so I just popped out as quickly as I came in. I left feeling totally relaxed and very calm. I feel like the next time I go I will try to get a later appointment so I can go home and sleep after wards. I didn't leave tired or ready for bed, but I could see myself getting a tremendous nights sleep after going here later in the evening. 

I can't wait to float again- I could see myself doing this once a month.  It's really nice to go somewhere and totally check out, not worry about your phone or your plans or whatever - and just take 90 minutes to float away.', "I'd been wanting to try a sensory deprivation tank ever since Lisa Simpson did it (http://vimeo.com/42916032). Now I have. I think I liked it, but here's a bit of what went through mind during my float:

I'm scared. 
It's dark in here. 
I need to turn this little light off.
No, it's too scary.
What if I can't get out?
I can do this. 
I love Epsom salts.
Cool, I'm floating. 
It's fun to stretch in here.
I'm probably moving too much.
Chill out.
Relax your big toe, 2nd toe, 3rd toe, 4th toe, baby toe.....
My neck aches.
I have mermaid hair.
inhale-exhale-inhale-exhale-inhale-exhale-inhale......
My skin feels slippery.
I'm a little bored.
I have to pee. 
I'm cold.
I'm hungry.
When can I get out of here?
Has it been 90 minutes yet?

And then the music started & I was so surprised that the 90 minutes had gone by because it felt more like 1/2 hour!

I liked it, I definitely liked it. It was relaxing & I like anything that forces me to be away from my phone. I felt great afterward--super relaxed, no aches or pains, & super strong the next day.

That being said, I probably won't go back. I recommend trying it at least once, because floating is pretty awesome. For the time & money, though, I'd rather get a massage.", "I never did anything like this ever until yesterday. To be honest, I was a little unsure how I was going to react in a sensory deprivation tank. (It sounds so much more intimidating than it actually is though.) First off, I have pretty above-average anxiety- I cry on airplanes that hit turbulence, get cold sweats when the dentist comes at me with a Novocaine shot, and I regularly envision myself in a horrific car crash while driving on 76. All crazy, I know. So the idea of an isolation tank was both intriguing and terrifying. And let me just say that is was AWESOME.

Unless you've done this before or been in a space shuttle, you've never felt this. The sensation of floating is incredible and relaxing. Floating in the water after the initial period where you have to learn how to relax, for me was all about concentrating on the sound of my own breathe and heartbeat. It might sound difficult for many people- being alone with your own thoughts for 90 minutes - but for some reason in that tank it is easy to turn off the outside world.  

The tank itself is bigger than I imagined in my head, and the water is only about 10 inches deep, so immediately my anxiousness kind of left me and I closed the door and turned off the little floating light ball. Truth be told also, you lose time in there. 90 minutes felt like maybe 30. 

When I emerged from the tank I felt this incredible lightness. Like my body finally got a rest and was rejuvenated. I don't get that from sleeping... I wake up and feel the aches and pains of whatever I was doing the day before or for my last 33 years. When I walked out of that room, I felt like a weight had been lifted and I was renewed. I can see why some people want to do this all the time. 

Halcyon Floats is a lovely little shop. It's clean and quiet and the staff is so helpful and wonderful. They all float, so they are enthusiastic about the benefits and the experiences people have. They definitely helped to calm the nervousness I was having about doing it for the first time. Afterward, it was an added plus to be able to chat with them about the experience and hear about theirs.

A few tips: you may not think that little scratch that didn't break your skin will not bother you but I can assure you ANY minor abrasion you have should be covered with Vaseline. I was scratching an itch on my shin and didn't know I had any sign of abrasion until I got in the tank and it started to become irritated VERY FAST. Covering it with Vaseline immediately fixed the problem. Lastly, have an open mind. Like most things in life, this experience will be what you make of it. If you want to go into the tank with skepticism and a closed expectation, you will likely not enjoy yourself. You've got 90 minutes in there with yourself, so relax and stay positive!"]

name: Orange Tint and Graphics
categories_raw: Car Stereo Installation, Automotive, Windows Installation, Auto Repair, Professional Services, Auto Parts & Supplies, Home Window Tinting, Auto Glass Services, Vehicle Wraps, Car Window Tinting, Graphic Design, Home Services
categories: ['car stereo installation', 'automotive', 'windows installation', 'auto repair', 'professional services', 'auto parts & supplies', 'home window tinting', 'auto glass services', 'vehicle wraps', 'car window tinting', 'graphic design', 'home services']
top_reviews:
["I came in to get my car tinted shortly after purchasing it. When I called to schedule my appointment, the options were overwhelming! The woman offered to email me the info so I could look it over with my husband. After receiving the info, I did some research and decided on the Crystalline, the highest quality tint (which they have priced reasonably, from what my research indicated). When I dropped my car off, I was waiting for my husband to pick me up when he called to tell me his car battery was dead. Of course, we don't have jumper cables. The ladies at Orange Tint and Tune kindly sent one of their employees with a jumper box to jump our other car at home, about 5 minutes from the shop. We were so appreciative! 

Now onto the actual tint work...they did a great job. I had some issues with my driver's side window because the window goes down ever so slightly when you open the door, which caused the bottom of the tint to lift before it was dry. Chet, the manager, noticed this before I left and said to stop back in if it caused me any problems. I stopped back in today and long story short, Chet decided to re-tint the window for me. He didn't think it looked 100% perfect and he wanted to make sure they got it right.

This business stands behind their products and workmanship. It is very clear that if something ever goes wrong with my tint, I can stop in and they won't hesitate to make it right. Their customer service is excellent as well.

I would recommend them without hesitation!", "We had an early morning weekend appointment and waited while our car was tinted. Rosemary was really helpful in deciding which tint to go with, and overall was really friendly, professional, and helpful. The customer service at this place is hard to beat, and the adorable dog is an awesome bonus.

It's honestly really hard for me to give this place less than 5 stars because the customer service is so good, so I waited a few weeks before reviewing so I could be more objective. The reality is that the tint job we got was not very good. I've never used another place in Tampa, so I can't compare there, but I've had several cars tinted before elsewhere and never had the same issues. 

So the job was this: remove the tint from a 2010 Civic, add a new tint. I know it's an older car and isn't going to be treated with the same care as a new car in many cases, but I can really only judge on my own experience. When we initially got our the back, there were a lot of issues with the quality of the tint, and there was glue residue and chunks of tint all over the inside of the car. The person who did the tint came out and looked at the car and honestly didn't seem very happy that we had issues, and attributed to the issues to his guy who was newer having messed up. But they were happy to schedule a day to redo the parts that were messed up, which I really appreciate.

That day I took the car home and spent over and hour trying to clean up the car. The residue was all over the doors, and it still remains. I scrubbed and scrubbed, used three different types of cleaners, nothing worked. When we went back to get the bad parts of the tint redone, they tried to remove it too and couldn't. So there are permanent stains on my doors. Since I'm not a car person and my car is older, I'm relatively okay with it, but it sucks to spend hundreds of dollars to end up with permanent stains on your car. They said it happened during the tint removal, which was a separate fee, and there was no offer of refunding that or anything. Had this been a newer car I probably would have wanted at least a partial refund, which they don't do, so I definitely would not get a newer car done here. Weeks/months later I am still finding random little pieces of tint in my car. I really feel that when you're paying hundreds of dollars, even if your car is older, some level of care should be taken.

In addition to that, the radio in our car no longer works when the rear defroster is on. This seems to be a relatively common issue when getting tints done, but worth mentioning as I didn't know this until it happened to my car.

I do see that I'm in the minority in my experience. I believe this is at least partially because most people are going in to do a new tint and not to remove an old one.

Again, their customer service is great. Had the job itself gone more smoothly, this would definitely be a 5 star place. But overall, I sadly couldn't recommend this place to a friend due to all the issues with the tint removal and tinting, the cleanup time I had to put in, and the permanent stains on my car.", "I called Orange Tint and Tunes on a Wednesday to get pricing on window tint for my new car and spoke with Rosemary. She was incredibly sweet and explained all of the product options telling me the pros and cons of each. She told me the pricing for each option and I decided to give them my business. I scheduled an appointment for the following Friday, and she gave me a call on Thursday to confirm my appointment.

When I get there on Friday morning, she once again explained all of the product options and showed me a sample of each. I picked the option that I wanted, and she told me it would take around two hours. Additionally, Rosemary offered me a bottle of water, and gave me the WiFi password so I didn't have to use my phone's data plan.

While I waited, the office dog (Lucy) roamed around and spent some time near me letting me scratch her head (she's really soft, and really friendly, and is a very spoiled pup). Before I knew it (less than 45 minutes later) the techs were done with my tint. While processing my payment, Rosemary told me how to clean the tint, gave me a cleaning cloth to use, and gave me a few warnings about not rolling down my windows for a few days so that the tint has time to cure. 

The shop is incredibly clean and the bay where the actual work is done is enclosed and air conditioned. I was told about the tint warranty options, and given a warranty card that can be used anywhere that authorized 3M tint technicians work. I paid a little more than some of my other quotes, but I feel that the customer service I received, the cleanliness of the shop, the professionalism of the staff, and the quality of the tint job I received make the price well worth it."]

name: The Foodery
categories_raw: Nightlife, Food, Delis, Bars, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Every time I walk into the Foodery, I'm excited by the well stocked beer selection, which I am confident has been handled with care to avoid any possibility of spoiling.    

Every time I walk out of the Foodery, I feel like I've been robbed in broad daylight in front of a police station.

Why did two bottles of Stillwater Ale cost almost TEN DOLLARS more at Foodery than at a competitor (ahem, Food & Friends) across town?  I get the convenience factor of the location, and the fact that Foodery started the trend, but come on.  Maybe the price gouging works on the clueless but I'll mix my six elsewhere.", "Wait, what? A place in Philly that sells beer that I don't need a college dude to carry out to my trunk because I'm drinking when I should be working out, and thus not strong enough to lift a case? And not just beer, but BEER...the best selection I've come across in ages. Maybe I am dreaming, but this little corner store is too good to be true. Can someone please explain to me how they can do this and not be shut down in a hot second?

Who cares that it's pricy? For realz, I'll get a second job or hock some of my estate jewelry (ha ha) to pay for this nugget of goodness. I am totally in love with the Foodery. Throw in a pizza from Rustica and I am good to go.", "Great beer selection, good deli, good selection of upscale corner store grocery items, and friendly staff who don't have problems answering questions. That is what you get at the Northern Liberties location. Yeah, it'll cost you an extra buck or two, but I also know of places that are way more expensive, so I'm not gonna complain about the prices. I'm always happy to stop in here and patronize this place... 

Plus, the last time I was in here, I saw hipsters, yuppies, and hippies all shopping here at the same time. Now if that doesn't prove that this place has magical powers, then I don't know what does..."]

name: Bacchanal Fine Wine & Spirits
categories_raw: Jazz & Blues, Bars, Arts & Entertainment, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Wine Bars, Food, Nightlife
top_reviews:
["A hidden gem... A local told us to come here. And I am glad we did... Located in Bacchanal in front of an abandoned Marine Navel Base that is just falling apart since Katrina filled with graffiti.... Here stands this lovely restaurant that is alive with music, twinkling lights, wine, beer, spirit, and amazing cheese plates that you will create!!!

Came here to drink and check out what this place has to offer. As you open the door inside, your jaw will drop how beautiful this place is!!!! Adorn with twinkling lights with various wines to choose from a fridge filled with various types of cheese. This is the place to be!!!!

Alot of history this place has to offer especially after Hurricane  Katrina hit. This place was a place for hope. From being just a backyard event. Being a place that was closed down because it didn't have a permit. People getting together to make sure this place stays open...  And it did. It got a permit and this place is packed. 

Live music. Plenty of tables that immediately fills up. And a 2nd floor that offers a balcony that looks over the backyard and the party!
The 2nd floor also host a private party. 

It's not cheap. It's on the higher end. A cheese plate with all the trimmings was $45.00. but so worth it especially if your a cheese lover!!!!

Down stairs there are buckets to place clean ice for your beverage or your wine. And there complimentary bug spray to keep those critters off you which is a common thing here in NOLA!

One thing that I do love is how the place continues to support it's community. They had a gal selling shirts, books, and DVD that supports the local shelter.

I hope you visit this place when you are in town!", 'Bacchanal is a wine & cheese shop with a fairly large added "Heurige," which is an Austrian word for outdoor wine garden.  They also have a bar area with specialty cocktails upstairs.  

They have a neat concept.  You pick out the sliced meat and cheese you want from the fridge.  Then they will nicely plate it for you.  Then you pick up a glass of wine and sit down outside to listen to live music.  A jazz quartet played while I was there.  

Bacchanal is located in the Bywater section of New Orleans, which is up and coming and also far from the touristy French Quarter.  

Definitely recommend.', "Bliss.

Absolute bliss.

Thanks to Katie B's gushing recommendation - we joined her, Farrah A, and Tomas R at Bacchanal for the most delightful afternoon - full of chilled rosé, stunning cheese plates, and beautiful music. 

Sitting in the comforts of the shade beneath elegant overhanging trees - while beaming faces - enjoyed the enclosed oasis of fantastic wine and wonderful company - I felt abundantly thankful.

Bacchanal is worth the Uber ride. It's non-pretentious, full of great vibes, and it's always graced by lulling live music.

I recommend coming on the earlier side- since I've heard it does get busier later on in the early evening. But definitely don't sleep on this New Orleans gem. You could easily spend all day here.

Trust."]

name: Poke Burri
categories_raw: Restaurants, Japanese
top_reviews:
['I am addicted to this place. I always get the super poke bowl. 

I tried the sushi pizza, which is served in a pizza box. It's pretty big, I was full for the rest of the day after eating it for lunch. Completely covered with fresh tuna and salmon drizzled with spicy Mayo. Even the "folding crust " has some fillings in it. Highly recommended.

The fries with Tokyo sauce is really good because of the spicy sauce.

The sushi sandwich is another creation with a nice crunch', "New location that just opened up. My friends and I were able to dine in and I have to say I wasn't disappointed. 

We ordered the bagel, corn dog off the secret menu, make your own Ramen and pokebowls, poke burrito, tokyo fries, and Thai iced tea. 

Everything was delicious and came out promptly. I have to give special props to the Thai iced tea, which can be a hit or a miss depending on the place.

A bit small for a dining area, so I do recommend carry out instead. *None of my photos are altered or filtered* enjoy!", "While I have yet to stop by in person, I have heard such great things about these donuts and had to try one myself. I took a look at their Yelp page and realized you could order delivery right there so I took advantage of the opportunity and placed an order for lunch.

Some people know that I am secretly picky... so I opted for the Vegetable Donut and the Miso and Ginger Salad with added Grilled Chicken. My order arrived early (always a plus) and wow was it delicious.

I was worried that the donut would feel like eating a lot of plain rice, but it was sticky and slightly sweet with the avocado, seaweed and what looked like ginger dressing on top. The ingredients tasted very fresh too.

The salad was a small side salad and the dressing was delicious. I'm a huge fan of good ginger dressing and this one was up there among my favorites. The grilled chicken portion was generous and cooked perfectly. 

I would HIGHLY recommend trying Poke Burri for takeout!"]

name: French Quarter Phantoms - Treme Tour
categories_raw: Historical Tours, Local Flavor, Tours, Hotels & Travel, Walking Tours
top_reviews:
["We found them on Groupon but honestly this was one of the best tours we did on this trip. Their office are located near Armstrong Park so you can walk around there if you have some time to kill before or after the tour.

Their office is also shared with a bar, so treat yourself to a Hurricane or two if you want to! Just don't bring it into the cemetery later. 

We did the St. Louis Cemetery #1 tour. I don't recall what our guide's name was, but she was lovely and had a lot of history to share with us. It was well paced so it's good for young and old alike.", "Took this tour this morning  with Leena.  Great tour by a great guide.  Very informative and interesting.  Wear good shoes because the ground is uneven in the cemetery and bring gifts to leave at the Voodoo priestess' crypt.  I hear she likes money and booze! ;)", "This tour was excellent! The history and cultural information shared was so interesting. I doubt I would ever have heard it if not for this tour. Robin was our tour guide and I can't say enough good things about her. Her knowledge of the area and its history was impressive. So glad we did this tour!"]

name: Tsunami Sushi
categories_raw: Cocktail Bars, Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Bars, Nightlife, Soup, Sushi Bars, Salad
top_reviews:
["Hunker down y'all, Tsunami Sushi has arrived in the Big Easy and it's here to stay. Drop what you're doing and head down to the CBD for excellent sushi with a dash of Louisiana flair! 5-star food coupled with 5-star service in an upscale atmosphere makes for a great night out! 

It's incredibly hard to find high quality, fresh sushi here in the land of crawfish and so you can imagine my excitement when I found out that Tsunami was opening it's 3rd Louisiana location here in Nawlins! 
I've dined here for lunch and dinner and have always been 100% satisfied with the food and service. I always enjoy sitting at the sushi bar (which has an open kitchen concept) to admire the captivating work of the creative and talented sushi chefs. Make sure to sip on a deliciously potent cocktail while you dine too! I like to order the chef's special or whatever chef conjures up with those stellar sushi-making magic skills. My most favorite dish is the Sunflower, comprised of thin sashimi slices of seared tuna in spicy ponzu served with tobiko, masago, scallions, and quail egg. Not only is the Sunflower absolutely delicious, but it is also a beautiful piece of art and sushi perfection! 

Come on down to the CBD and ride the Tsunami wave- I promise it will be well worth it! You can even feast to your heart's delight with daily happy hour specials. I highly recommend Tsumani for the BEST SUSHI in New Orleans!!!", "I've been to Tsunami several times but this last trip was my favorite. I've been doing keto so chose low carb options of the truffle salmon sashimi and roasted brussel sprouts. 

The salmon was fresh and good but the star of my lunch was the brussel sprouts. They were not Asian at all but perfect roasted and crispy with spicy sweet slivers of sausage and sprinkled with Parmesan. So good! Crazy good!", 'Happy hour specials are amazing--- half off sashimi! Life changing!!! 
The albacore was so tasty and fresh!!! 

The happy hour drink specials are unreal!!!

Tuesday has a great special from 6-10pm']

name: Ochsner Urgent Care - Warehouse District
categories_raw: Naturopathic/Holistic, Doctors, Health & Medical, Urgent Care, Medical Centers
top_reviews:
['Quick N Easy. From filling out paperwork to seeing the doctor on hand. They accepted my insurance and it was pretty painless (not including the pain my body was enduring).

Everyone was super polite and very cordial.', 'Brought a friend here to receive follow up care for a broken finger. Surprisingly, the waiting room was packed with people with a myriad of symptoms, ailments and complaints. 

The staff behind the desk were deft, patient and empathetic. My friend was seen quickly, as were others. The waiting room was clean and the magazines were current. 

Insurance is accepted,so it could be a good option for those who live and work nearby. 

The drawback? The hours are limited.', "1-17-09

By the time I got to the New Orleans Urgent Care, I was in such pain that I had self medicated (it's New Orleans after all and I work with a bunch of nurses and doctors). I was driven over here by the Event Manager (Leicey) at the JW Marriott who was handling my event that was going on that weekend. 

My BF Mark meets me there and in we go. I fill out all the paperwork and I am taken to the back to get checked out by Greg the medical assistant. He asks why am I here? Well I tripped over a box in my room in the middle of the night almost 3 days ago and hit the granite minibar and heard my knee go POP!  And as you can see it is now the size of a watermellon and I am in so much pain that I can't take it anymore, please give me some drugs and fix me up please I beg. 

After a short discussion about what I did and what I had been doing that morning (self medicating-ask if you want to know) he was impressed I was still able to walk on my own  - then Dr. Nikolic comes into my room to check me out. 

She wants some x-rays as she said I did some damage and needs to know how bad it is.  Into a wheelchair I go off to x-ray with Greg. 
Let's just say when I came out of x-ray - several people were shocked at the language that came out of my mouth (I am a lady after all) while getting my x-rays. I kept saying I was sorry and everyone said it was OK they understood how much pain I was in. 

As Greg wheeled me out of x-ray, Dr. Nikolic tells me I have cracked my patella and shows me my x-rays on the computer screen and hands me a cd with a copy of the x-rays to take with me home and that I need to see an Ortho surgeon when I get back home ASAP. 

In the mean time I am to stay in bed at the hotel until I get back home. Take my meds and keep my leg elevated at all times as well as ice it down 3-5 times a day. 

As I hobble out of the urgent care on my new crutches I just got. Leicey comes driving by and asked if we need a lift. What a Savior is all I can say.  I got back to the hotel with Mark and he hands off all my meds to Isabelle the concierge at the hotel and off she went to make my scripts appear. 

I can't say enough about all the care that I received here, I even had to go back to get a note so that I could get on a plane home as they didn't want me to fly if I could get a blood clot.  Dr. Nikolic took great care of me ASAP and I was headed back to DC with all my instructions on what needs to be done. 

Thank all of you for your kindness and great care! The treatment was 1st class and I could not have asked for anything better. Next time I am in town if anything happens I know where to go or I just might have to stop by and say Thanks for everything."]

name: Envy Nail
categories_raw: Beauty & Spas, Nail Salons
top_reviews:
['The salon is new and beautiful, with gleaming floors and brand new chairs. All the workers were very friendly and welcoming. I was the only customer in there on a Friday afternoon, so most of the employees were just relaxing. This also involved re-watching and providing running commentary on the Olympic figure skating routines on the big screen television.

My technician did a great manicure on my fingernails. She offered useful advice when I was wavering between colors. I do wish she had put a third coat of gel on, though, because my nails turned out to be a bit more translucent than I prefer.

I will definitely be back because I loved that use sanitary equipment and how neat and clean everything seemed.', 'Less than 7 days after a pedi and my polish was chipping. This place is pretty & I've only been here once so I wasn't going to review thinking MAYBE me and the bestie caught them on a bad day...but a bad pedicure combined with polish that doesn't last means I won't be going back. 

I should've thought twice when I walked into a place that had ONE customer being served. Issue number 1: there's only one other customer in the entire place yet you sit me & my best friend directly next to them without any "personal space"...why?? Were you expecting a crowd that never showed up? 

Issue number 2: my tech never said hello, my name is, which pedicure would you like, is the water temperature ok, NOTHING. I had to specifically ask for the pedicure menu which only had 3 pretty boring options anyway. Not sure which she would have defaulted to if I hadn't asked for the list? And the tech working with my friend asked me if I wanted a water, thankfully. Maybe my tech didn't speak English. Issue 3: I had to guess what her hand taps meant because she sure wasn't assisting me. I think I was tap one time, bend your leg, two taps means put your foot back in the water? Every other pedicure I've ever had, the tech would take my foot and do what she needs with it. This was annoying. I know how petty it sounds but it would've been less frustration if she just told me what she needed. 

Issue number 4: the massage, or lack thereof, was awful. Don't advertise your pedicure coming with a massage if it's merely rubbing lotion on my skin. I can do that myself.

Went because of awesome Yelp ratings but there's too many other options to repeat any place that is less than amazing.', "I walk in at 12:30 PM on a Tuesday during lunch they tell me they are busy and can't accommodate me for another hour... I think that's horrible service they should have planned properly for staffing purposes I told him I won't be coming back."]

name: Casa Video
categories_raw: Books, Mags, Music & Video, Shopping, Videos & Video Game Rental
top_reviews:
['"You're boring," Cassie said. "Why don't you get off your ass and find something to do?" I remember it like it was yesterday. Pretty sure she meant, "Why don't you find something for us to do together, like snuggling up to watch a movie!" LOL, she had such a way with words!

Anyway, I went to Casa Video, and I was blown away by their selection--a wide variety of documentaries, indie flicks, and foreign language films, along with all the traditional fare. Netflix doesn't have anything on these guys, mainly because the staff is super helpful. They pointed me in just the right direction, and I found "Y Tu Mama Tambien."

When I got home, Cassie and my pal Rick were anxiously awaiting the movie; as soon as I opened the door, they shuffled in their spots on the couch really quick! I was excited, too! I like Spanish flicks, and plus, I didn't even know Rick was coming over! I thought the movie was pretty good, but Rick and Cassie REALLY liked it! They said they were gonna show it to our friend Ben, and they took off. Pretty sure it speaks for itself! Casa Video has just the movie for you, your loved ones and your friends--you just can't wait to share!

***

2/5/14: Woohoo, review of the day! I bragged about it to Cassie in my daily D-Blast to her (e-mail, text, voicemail, Facebook message and LinkedIn discussion forum), and when I asked if she'd go on a date with me for 5 minutes for every friend I got today, she said, "Whatever!" LOL, I know that means "Yes," so friend me!', "Casa video always takes this old millennial on a trip down memory lane of many a video store trip with family and friends. It has that small town, local feel I grew up with- not a Hastings or Blockbuster vibe. 

Great selection of movies new and old, stuff you won't find on Netflix! You can take your time browsing, no line of people behind you pressure like at a red box. Fun assortment of bottled sodas and snacks at checkout. Plus-- you don't need a membership card- your lD is all you need!

Daily specials listed on their website and FrEe PoPcOrN to go or while browsing! 

(I've never hung out in the bar next door- but it looks really fun!)", "Casa Video continues to up the awesomeness by adding a bar! Seriously, they have a bar with a TON of beer on tap and coffee and tea and they'll even order in food from next door. It's seriously cool. It was weird sitting in the area where the children's movies and VHS tapes used to sit. And get this: the children's movies are now stored where the XXX films used to be. Trippy! Casa is finding new ways to re-invent itself as not just a movie rental store but a place to have some delicious beers and take some home in a growler- eat some free popcorn- and buy movies too. And their website is awesome and you can order movies by mail. Casa is the last of its kind in Tucson and across America: a movie rental store. It should be treasured for what it is, because if we lose it, we're just going to Redbox. And Redbox doesn't have films obscure and old, or the amazing upstairs foreign/documentary section that is outstanding and one-of-a-kind;"]

name: St Mary's Mexican Food
categories_raw: Restaurants, Mexican
top_reviews:
["Our first stop as soon as we got to town this trip was St. Mary's tortilla factory. It has great reviews online, we were there just as lunchtime is starting, it was very convenient and it smelled delicious! 

St. Mary's tortilla factory is definitely a no fuss restaurant. You place your order at one window and pick it up at the next. All of the dishes are served in to go containers. It's your choice whether you take it to go or you pick out one of the tables inside to eat at. There are no waiters and you bus your own table. Nothing fancy just good food. Nice family friendly atmosphere, St Mary's Tortilla Factory is very welcoming and inviting, even to us out of towners! 

With that said unless you are fan of extra spicy salsa (which I am not) you may want to take your order to go and use your own salsa at home. The spicy salsa fans in our little group had no problem with the house salsa that came complementary with lunch. But otherwise without any kind of salsa my food was just kind of dry. 

I ordered the lunch combo chicken taco and green corn tamale. It wasn't bad but it wasn't a meal that I would run back to repeat anytime soon. It was just so dry and kind of bland. The refried beans and rice however were very flavorful and very good! The fresh tortilla (wound around a popsicle stick and put into the plastic bag to preserve freshness,) was very good too. I can see why this place is popular with the locals and after traveling all morning - the food was exactly what we needed and really hit the spot.

While others in our little party loved their lunch and bookmarked the place with plans to return soon - my favorite part of the meal was excellent lemonade! It was so cool and refreshing, tart and sweet but not overly so - I would definitely stop in again for another cup! 

The service was fast and very efficient. The restaurant is kind of small but seems just right for an operation that offers take out as well as dine-in, and during the time we sat eating I saw plenty of people stopping in for both. Lots of open free parking, St Mary's Tortilla Factory is very easy to get to and by noon there was a line out the door for food orders! So get there early!", "Carne Seca! There are very few places that do Carne Seca, which is sun dried beef.  Here, at St. Mary's Tortilla Factory, you can have carne seca with fresh home made tortillas. It's a double win!! 

We came in for the breakfast burritos which had carne seca rolled up in a homemade flour tortilla, along with potatoes and eggs. It was super noms! St Mary's Tortilla Factory offer up hearty, affordable, breakfast options that represents some of the best regional stuff Tucson has to offer.", "I hang my hat in San Francisco now, but when I Iived in Tucson, I went to St. Mary's all the time. The shit is goood. Like two-syllable good.

Tortillas are meant to be fried. I can only think of one place in San Francisco that fries their tortillas, and that's Chavo's at 4th and Bryant. All the other places use steam presses - something better reserved for laundry service. Even with the frying, Chavo's is only so-so. Nothing beats El Farolito in this city. But I digress. Back to Tucson...

St. Mary's takes the art of the tortilla a few steps further by making them all by hand, daily. They melt in your mouth. They're probably full of lard. If that's the secret, then God bless lard.

St. Mary's is exactly the kind of hole-in-the-wall joint I love. Unpretentious as a crosstown bus. Sometimes the service is friendly. Sometimes you get the stink eye. Sometimes it's speedy. Sometimes glacial.

Everything on the menu is delicious, but my favorite is to go early enough for the breakfast burritos. Tucson chorizo is spicy as hell, so I usually take mine without. Unless I'm hungover. Then definitely with. 

Even when I was so full I could barely stand, I never left the place without buying a dozen bag of tortillas. Or sometimes gorditas - smaller and thicker.

Man I miss that place."]

name: Fresco Pizzeria
categories_raw: Food, Food Delivery Services, Salad, Italian, Pizza, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Fresco Mathematics (also known as Pizza Pi):

Long Hard Day + Too Lazy to Cook = Hot Delicious Pizza Delivered from Fresco

Hot Delicious Pizza Delivered from Fresco x  Bottle of Wine = 2 Full Happy People

Hot Delicious Pizza Delivered from Fresco  x  Bottle of Wine + 2 Full Happy People / Long Hard Day = Nap on the Couch', "I have eaten at this pizzeria several times and have used the catering part of the business also several times.  THIS IS MY FAVORITE PIZZERIA & PASTARIA IN ALL OF TUCSON!

When we arrived the other night we were greeted by very friendly employees who took our order.   We had ordered the Spinach & Ricotta Stuffed Shells and the Alfredo Florentine.   Our meal arrived in a very timely fashion.  The dinner was absolutely excellent and generous proportions (in fact I got to eat part of my wife's meal the next day!).

On previous occasions we have ordered the pizza and it is probably the best in Tucson!  My absolute favorite is the Margherita Pizza followed by a Pesto with Mozzarella Cheese (I usually have them throw on some mushrooms as well).  However, my absolute favorite is the Ricotta Cheese and Spinach Calzone!  This is to die for!

Fresco is not a chain and there is only one location.  However, they recently expanded their existing facility to allow a much larger sit down crowd.  So they have take out, delivery, eat-in and catering.", 'Living downtown, I have several places to choose from for pizza delivery, but I had a craving for Frescos crust and was delighted to find out they delivered to my area! I called up and spoke to the nicest employee. He helped me pick a size for one - 10" has six slices and will make for a great dinner and next day lunch. The most distinguishing part of this phone call was I could actually hear the person on the other line! I call plenty of pizza places and strain to hear due to all the background noise... So maybe I am getting old but its nice to hear and be heard. About 40 minutes later, the piping hot and fresh pizza was delivered. I honestly cant get enough of the crust! I could eat it plain, but all the creative pizza options make it hard to just order crust. I have had maybe 3-4 pizzas but my two favorite are the absolutely alfredo's creamy deliciousness and the tangy and sweet blue cheese, bacon and pineapple. With all the new pizza places, Fresco still hold their own, I just wish the prices were a little more affordable. Its a splurge, but a tasty well spent splurge!']

name: Two Chicks Café - CBD
categories_raw: Juice Bars & Smoothies, American (Traditional), Restaurants, Food, Breakfast & Brunch
top_reviews:
['While visiting NOLA we walked here from our hotel. The place is small, eclectic and GOOD! Check out the excellent service and wonderful food!', "Yummy yumm! This was one of my first places to have brunch at when I moved here. I usually go to the one on convention center blvd but it was PACKED. 

This place is so cute! They were very busy but the waitresses were busting butt! We didn't wait long because it was only two of us but it did get busy shortly thereafter. I LOVE their OJ because it is freshly squeezed. I will say I like my OJ cold but this OJ felt a little on the warmer side. That made me not want to finish it.

It did take a little bit for someone to get to us. I think they only had four waitresses for the whole place. We got to order and I had the crab cake benedict and my bf ordered the cafe breakfast. We also split the Papa's french toast. 

Crab cake benedict is a croissant split topped with two crab cakes and poached egg in a cajun hollandaise. Papa's french toast is thick slices of Texas toast dipped in a rum batter rolled with corn flakes. We ordered fruit for our sides because you know #healthy. But I love that the fruit is bananas and strawberries and not some fruit no one ever eats. 

We will be back for sure!", 'Pretty good. Our table had the egg & cheese croissants, grits, fruit, the french toast and a variety of juices and smoothies. 
The croissants were DELICIOUSLY buttery and flaky. Our server, who was extremely nice, was great about letting us make substitutions or replacing a fried egg that was fried a little too soft for one guest. The grits were cheesy and substantial and I love that they have real breakfast potatoes. The french toast wasn't a hit with me but my sister enjoyed it. The juices were refreshing and are truly just "the juice" no sugars, etc added, which I appreciated. We will make it back.']

name: Grey Line Tours
categories_raw: Hotels & Travel, Tours
top_reviews:
['While we were in New Orleans, we happened upon Grey Line tours.  We purchased several of their tours.  We did the Bayou Pontoon Tour, the Cemetary Tour, and the Haunted Walking Tour.  

Each of the tours were great!  The Bayou tour was very relaxing.  It was about a 45-60 minutes drive in the bus and a little wait to get on the pontoon.  However, it was a great tour.  Our tour guide on the boat was fun and informative and he let us all hold a baby alligator.  He got alligators to come near the boat by feeding them marshmallows.  Who knew?!  Alligators like marshmallows!

Our Cemetary Tour was led by Bill, who happened to be a new anchor in town.  He led a very informative tour on the way and in the cemetery.  He had some great recommendations.  We did get to see Marie Laveau's grave and Nicholas Cage's as well.  The history of the cemetery is fascinating also.  "Saved by the Bell" was coined in New Orleans in the cemetery.  They used to tie a bell to the limb of someone who had passed from yellow fever and leave someone on duty after they were buried to be sure they didn't wake up.  Apparently, this happened often with yellow fever victims. 

Our Haunted Walking Tour was led by Billie Jo.  She was such a fun tour guide.  She was excited and had so much energy.  She took us to places that most tour guides don't take us and she had great history and stories that she shared.  We did catch some spirits on camera!  

Grey Lines will definitely have any tour you need.  I know we will use them again!', 'Fantastic tour! Sandi, our tour guide, shared so many stories and so much history with us. She made the walking cocktail tour very enjoyable. 

We stopped at 4 bars to sample some New Orleans favorites:
*Pimm's cup at Napoleon House
*Side car at Antoine's
*Absinthe / Sauzerac at Broussard's
*French 75 at Patrick's

Note-you have to purchase your drinks at each stop. The ticket price gets you the tour guide and history / stories / access to special rooms / drink specials.  It does NOT get you any drinks at the stops. However, you do receive a free Natchez rum punch from the tour company when you depart from the "lighthouse".', "From pick up, to drop off, this tour was fantastic. Sandy Beaches was our guide, and she was so funny, knowledge, and personable! 
The plantation home itself is air conditioned, which was such a fabulous treat! :)
Tom, the boat driver on the swamp was completely entertaining, and I LOVED his accent! Sit closely if you have a hard time with accents....Tom is born and raised in the area....it's thick, but fantastic. :)
You get to hold a baby gator, if you want, and the boat ride itself is slow and steady. 
My only negative would be the girl at the ticket counter when we checked in.... I asked her questions, she flat out didn't answer me. But that's a small detail that was overshadowed by everything else."]

name: El Cucuy
categories_raw: Nightlife, Bars, Cocktail Bars, Mexican, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['As someone who grew up in a bordertown, I think it's kinda hard for locals/tourists alike to understand this concept of food and taste. The cuisine from El Cucuy references the Mexican flavors and cuisine one will find when visiting cities and towns in Mexico alongside the Texas border. 

There is a distinct cuisine of Mexican cuisine one will acknowledge and even understand as Mexican dishes served in Mexican towns alongside the Cali-Mexico Border and New Mexico-Mexico Border are way different than Mexican towns in Tex-Mexico Border. Don't believe me... just ask a Californian, New Mexican, and a Texan what type of bread and beverage should be served with menudo and you'll see a foodie argument escalate so quickly. Now add that Texas spans about 16 hours across and even regions within Texas differ slightly ie El Paso/Ciudad Juárez and The Valley/Mexico and you have a full blown Hunger Games discussion.

////

Bringing it back to El Cucuy now these dishes are not meant to be served in a plated way or feature ingredients one may be accustomed to when eating Mexican food in New Orleans. The flavors are way different and seasonings are a bit more intense, in a good way of course.

Of course, El Cucuy has some items that although are still delicious it's just not the particular style of serving I'm used to. This goes for their queso, but hey I'm not complaining, queso recipes are a family heirloom (I'm dead serious) and I can definitely recognize this recipe had the touch of an Abuela's influence. I just prefer the Abuela's in El Paso, San Antonio, and Ciudad Juarez if that makes sense.

Now for their tacos and elote, DAMNNNNNNN, just take my money every time because I love it. Is it a bit pricier that I've paid for in Mexico, sure, but I also was eating them off a street cart in Ciudad Juarez and not on Tchoup. Street where I'm sure their lease alone is stupid expensive. 

Menu prices account for location due to retail space and monthly leasing, etc. It's a business y'all not your friends house...

I love making their tacos "cruda" which is a fried Chihuahua cheese layer within your taco. It's like a little love letter to home and my childhood. The Elote is delicious and I appreciate the proper toppings they use. 

*Secretly crossing my fingers they one day do an "elote en vaso" for their menu. 

Their tacos when ordered have the protein mixed with a paired in-house salsa. If you're not one for salsa, simply ask for them to make it dry or to include the salsa on the side. Btw their asada and trompo are delish and the al pastor has pineapple in it. (I'm curious if maybe they added the pineapple recently since earlier reviews?)

Chips and salsa are bomb btw! I haven't tried their whole menu so can't speak for everything else.

//

Most likely COVID-19 Related:
It's quite easy to order although the logistics on a busier day isn't as ideal. You go up the stairs, place your order at the door, receive a number, and then you find a table. If all the tables are full though, you kinda just wait in a "queued line" alongside the house until one opens up. Hopefully this changes once you can actually dine inside post-pandemic.

//

As for the 20% automatic gratuity...

Everyone needs to understand that eating out is a form of art and you're paying for the luxury to have a team cook for you, serve you, tend to you, and clean up after you. I personally think all restaurants when dining in should require a minimum of 18-20% gratuity because sadly folks as a whole don't tip properly. If your food was served or delivered wrong you should bring it up immediately to the team or staff, it's not the servers fault if the kitchen does it incorrectly. You can't put 100% of the blame on them. Also just so folks understands tips from servers almost always gets shared with so many other roles in the restaurant as a thank you. 

You're not just tipping your server you're providing a livelihood to the server, host, bartenders, bar keep, dishwashers, kitchen line, cleaning crew, etc...

Eating at a restaurant is an experience and a service and is something that is not a requirement in life. Everyone is more than welcome to pick up ingredients and cook/eat at home. Your meals don't just magically whip up in twenty minutes there's a full production that happens behind the scenes the day of, even a week or two in advance with marinating, food prep, etc.

//

Maybe my one and only recommendation for El Cucuy Team is to just have a sign clearly stated at the stairs "We Charge An Automatic 20% Gratuity To Support Our Staff & Their Livelihood" so if folks aren't in agreeance then they can leave without ever stepping foot.', 'In the words of Omar little "if you come at the king (in this case it's neighbor barracuda) you best not miss." While the margs def didn't miss and neither did the eloté. the tacos did and they weren't even comparable. Barracuda has better tacos by not even a mile, 20 miles at least. Everything was Overpriced as well. The euros were just overpriced and Overhyped Doritos. They added a 20% gratitude fee which for a self sit place is Ludacris to me. to go along with all of this the steak in the tacos were very dry. If you want tacos and a fairly priced meal barracuda still reigns as king. While also in all honestly is on a whole other level.

43 dollars for 2 subpar/ below average tacos, marg, glorified Doritos and eloté is criminal/ borderline robbery. This all is coming from a New Yorker.', "Uhh. What am I missing here? If you can't get the tacos right then you might as well shut down. The tiny dollop of chicken or carne asada on each taco was tough and dry. I ordered all the toppings which amounted to a barely perceptible sprinkling of cheese, onions and a fleck of cilantro. There are two places making loaded, scrumptious tacos nearby: barracuda and liberacion. You'd probably find higher quality at Chipotle and avoid paying $15 for three pitiful excuses for tacos. Also, the owner's snarky, immature responses to legitimate criticisms in other reviews really leaves me with zero guilt here. I'll save you some time: I pay for my own Netflix, and I'm in the service industry. This place just doesn't seem to care - skip it!"]

name: Backspace Bar & Kitchen
categories_raw: Burgers, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Cocktail Bars, Bars, Food, Nightlife, Dive Bars, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["I've been working week long Conferences in New Orleans for five years, and I'm no stranger to bars and restaurants here, and great service in New Orleans. The service industry is such a huge part of New Orleans, I've got nothing but admiration for the patience and hard work of servers. I had such a bad server experience at Backspace- it was bizarre, and seemed purposely directed, so much so that an acquaintance of mine also seated at the bar stepped in to call it out. 

After working 50 hours in 3 days at my Conference, I was super stoked to get a burger and a beer here after reading all the great reviews. Bellied up to the bar, asked for a menu, and ordered an Amber. It came in a plastic cup, which was the first strike when obviously dining in.  Then when I got my food, the bartender talked loudly about his bowel movements in front of me while I was eating, and joked about doing so. And here's when bad service felt like it was being done purposefully, I'm not a naive diner. My friend seated nearby comes to Backspace whenever he's in town, and called the server out (that's how obviously gauche the service was). 

New Orleans is great for its choices when going out, and I'm happy to Yelp about those great experiences, and spend my dollars elsewhere.", 'In addition to the great bar and service, the food is awesome here. I had a roast beef sandwich which was flat out delicious. My partner had a BLT and loved it. We came here because they serve food late, but come in anytime for a great sandwich.', 'On a chilly Sunday October morning I made the mistake of thinking that we may be the only people in New Orleans that would want to have a delicious brunch. Well guess what? We were greeted with "no room in the inn" and left to wander the barren streets in search of food and comfort. That is when our weary soles (of our feet) trekked into the Back Space where we were given food and comfort, in the form of Bloody Mary's. The bartender was friendly despite sharing our mutual hangover.
We ate well, the roast beef sandwich was undeniably delicious and I, as well as the bartender highly recommend it. It was just the right amount of ooyey gooey. If I were to order it again I would skip the tomato and lettuce but the sandwich did not disappoint. 
Thank you Back Space for not denying our weary souls.']

name: Raptor Canyon Cafe
categories_raw: Cafes, American (Traditional), Breakfast & Brunch, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["I work nearby and heard of this restaurant but never went...I usually bring my lunch.  Today my friend and I decided to get breakfast, we both ordered the one egg biscuit sandwich with bacon.  I couldn't believe it was only $3! Homemade biscuit and bacon was perfect...I inhaled it, I loved it so much.  I also bought the oatmeal scotchie cookies two for $1.50 just out of curiosity...they were amazing!  The dining area was nice and roomy and the owner was super friendly, he even opened the door for us on the way out...we were offered cucumber water while we sat and waited for our food...nice touch!  I will definitely be back.

Update: They raised the price on the sandwich it's now $4.", 'Our nice neighbors invited us to "dine," in their backyard. The four of us were all 6-9 ft apart, brought our own drinks, etc. They ordered the steak and pasta on the "special"  Covid 19 menu for take-out. 
OMG, it was GREAT, but if you do order their take-out remember that the meal really, truly feeds at least 6 people.  
After this Virus is over, we're going to make Raptor Canyon Cafe our new favorite for eating out.', "Really nice spot right downtown a great selection of breakfast if you want to go big and have nothing to do later and just food, out of there you can or if you need to get something good cheap and fast with lots to do it's a great option good coffee I saw a couple guests with other items like their breakfast tacos that's looked awesome also really good service hope they can stick around a long time"]

name: Raijin Ramen
categories_raw: Noodles, Japanese, Diners, Restaurants, Ramen
top_reviews:
["We came to Raijin on a Sunday night for dinner to celebrate a good friend's promotion.  Parking was limited and most patrons had to find parallel spots on the street.  

Our party had to wait outside in line but were called in within 15 minutes to wait on the inside benches.  We were seated shortly after that in a comfortable booth that accommodated 4 easily, but anymore would have been a stretch.

We were started with waters and deliciously fruity chu hi drinks (Japanese soju highballs with surprisingly high alcoholic content).  After browsing other Yelp reviews, I knew I wanted to try many of their appetizers so I ordered takoyaki, karaage, fried octopus, and gyoza to share.  Everything came out very quickly and piping hot.  The fried dishes were perfectly crunchy and golden.  The gyozas was bathed in dumpling sauce but was somehow still crispy.

Entrees also arrived quickly and were very hot.  I ordered the black garlic tonkotsu.  Presentation was gorgeous and the serving was generous.  It came with bamboo, half of a soft boiled egg, and a thick slice of pork, all topped with black edamame seeds.  The garlic in the broth was not overpowering and all flavors were excellent complements.

I would dare say the food was Los Angeles-caliber good.  Service was fast and friendly.  The price was very reasonable.  Four appetizers and four ramen entrees came out to about $110.  Overall, this is hands down the best ramen in Tucson and I highly recommend bookmarking Raijin Ramen!", 'Tasty ramen joint in Tucson.  I enjoyed the spicy tonkatsu ramen.  There is good seating and with tasty options to choose from.  This place is good for groups or with just a friend or two.', "This restaurant is on point!!

Having lived in Japan for four years, you certainly build up an expectation from experiences over seas. To be honest, we went in here, post-Covid wise and was expecting to some degree a reference to other reviews. The only thing I can attest to from other reviewers is the atrocious parking conditions. They don't have many options but the parking lot is seriously compressed. Otherwise, it was an absolutely delectable experience.

Seated within seconds of walking in, we were offered indoor or outdoor options. In Tucson, I prefer outdoor, especially in the summertime. The entire outdoor seating area is encompassed in a mesh netting and the tables are sanitized right before you. 

With recommendations, my wife hit the Black Garlic and I hit the White Tonkotsu and that recommendation came with the spice on the side. Verrrry good point. I was warned about the spice level and glad I took this route. 

Ordered the extra fried chicken and the Gyoza. I kid you not, the meal was in front of us in under 3 minutes. Yes....all of it!

The atmosphere, service, food, food taste, environment and entire experience was nothing short of perfect. Maybe the stars aligned for us, but between parking, seating and food, there where ZERO issues on our visit. We complimented the staff on the food tasting very relative if not excellent to our experiences in Japan. 

They simply do it right here, honestly."]

name: Village Bakehouse
categories_raw: Bakeries, Restaurants, Food, Breakfast & Brunch, Sandwiches
top_reviews: ['Everytime I consider purchasing a birthday cake/pie elsewhere, I always come back to Village Bakehouse. Their pastries and baked goods are always a hit. You can pop in anytime during business hours and surely you will find something you will love. From cookies to muffins, danish, croissants, fruit tarts, lemon bars, and more. They bake fresh pies daily. You might even luck out with a whole cake on a whim. But with 24 hours notice, you should be able to secure a cake or pie that is on their menu. The cherry on top: they  serve breakfast all day!', "Amazing bakery and very reasonably priced!!! We first used them for my fiance's brother's rehearsal dinner. I was in charge of the dessert table so we ordered lemon bars, brownies and two 8inch round cakes with designs on them. Village bakehouse was so easy to work with. Everyone at the party raved about how great the cakes were. \n\nFast forward a few months my fiance asked the head baker if they could make a vanilla rose water cake. My family is from Jamaica and we use a lot of rosewater in our desserts. They had never done this before but were willing to try. My fiance took over the rosewater he wanted to be used and left it in their hands. I was so surprised at how delicious it was. I think I must have had close to 10 pieces of cake that weekend. It was sooo delicious and extremely moist. The icing was vanilla buttercream and was to die for. Thank you Village Bakehouse", "Searching for a cake? Add Village Bakehouse to your list. They can do almost anything you could imagine even on short notice. We ordered a Boston cream cake for a birthday the day before and they hooked us up. The cake was perfect and there were no leftovers! Village Bakehouse is TUCSON classic. That I hope more people will continue to support and discover. If you're not in the market for a cake they have all kinds of other pastries, breakfast and lunch."]
