Four pool tables in the non smoking section, separated by four pool tables in the smoking section (glass divider).   Place smells / looks really clean, bathrooms fully stocked and clean.  My only criticism (jokingly) is the door to the outside squeaks by the pool tables - but I picked up a can of WD40 yesterday and will solve that issue next visit.  

Look forward to my next visit, working my way through the French Dip and then the Rueben!  Thanks Red Garter for creating a cool place in the Pala Verde neighborhood!   See you soon."]

name: El Tipico Criollo
categories_raw: Restaurants, Latin American, Dominican, Caribbean, Delis
top_reviews:
["I was told to come here after complaining to a Dominican guy I met that I'm so mad that Mangu in Brandon closed down and that was THE best Dominican food in Tampa Bay although there are several Dominican restaurants nearby. Well, El Tipico Criollo is no Mangu Cafe, but it's very good Dominican fare.

HubbyStanks is Dominican. My mother in law and sis n law cook really well, but they aren't going to teach me anything (we'll just leave it at that), so I just figure it out...and although I haven't mastered every Dominican dish out there, the ones that I can cook, Sancocho, Mangu, Dominican Pastelon, etc. etc. I make very well. So, I'm picky when it comes to Dominican food. For the items I don't cook or if I am too lazy, I hope for a great restaurant with decent prices to fill in where I lack the skills (or the time to figure it out). There was a convenience store on Waters that served Dominican fare, but it got bought out by who we assume is a non-Dominican Hispanic. El Tipico so far is the closest Dominican spot to my home that can fill that void.

I had the chivo guisado (goat), mangu, rice and beans and avocado salad. All of it delicious. Only reason this doesn't get a 5 star is because I now rate every Domincan restaurant against Mangu Cafe and it was like Mangu Cafe was adding a bit of crack to everything because it was out of this world good! El Tipico is a solid choice, however. It's also better than all the Dominican restaurants I've tried in the Town and Country area.

Ordering is easy because all the food is laid out on a line in front of you, so you can see what everything looks like. I haven't eaten in, but I picked up my to-go items during lunch and there was plenty of seating as well as outdoor seating and the seats were filled. The staff is nice, but more of a no nonsense, what the heck do you want and I'll give it to you kind of nice, but you better know what you want...I may just feel that way because I don't speak Spanish. Mangu Cafe spoiled me because they were one of the few Spanish establishments in the same category that had customer service down!

I know I keep talking about Mangu Cafe and I heard that they were trying to make a comeback...until then I can live with El Tipico Criollo.

This place is a bit in the cut off of Memorial. You can see the restaurant from Memorial, but it's easy to miss if you're not actually looking for it. 

I want to go back and try other items, like pollo guisado (chicken), rabo (oxtail) and sancocho (national dish meat stew only served on weekends).", "This shit is nasty AF. I got 2 dry ass empanadas, a dry ass Cuban sandwich and one of they dry ass meat combos that came with some dry ass pork and dry ass rice and beans with some dry ass plantains. This shit is nasty, worse way to give away $14 bucks! I wish I would have just gotten an empanada and not all the rest of the food. If I would have eaten the empanada first, I wouldn't have ordered from here after eating that. 

I'm going to try Mr. Empanada next.", 'I've had two sandwiches from here, and both were really great.  The first, obviously, was a Cuban sandwich and I found it to be up there with some of the best in town.  Pepo's Jr. on Northdale still occupies the throne, but El Tipico is a little closer to home and is a fine substitute when there's a craving.  Their roasted pork here is really good, and if wasn't for that, their Cuban would rank a lot lower for me.  Why?  Because they use boiled ham.  In this day and age, there's just no reason to ever serve boiled lunch meat ham.  It's largely un-flavorful and only acts as a pink-colored filler on the sandwich.  There are other cost-effective hams that actually bring TASTE to a sandwich.  Also, they add lettuce and tomato by default.  While I like to break from tradition sometimes and add tomato, this is a no-no.  Still, not bad in a pinch.

Their "Philly" is a non-traditional version. Served on fresh Cuban bread with provolone cheese and slices of what appears to be skirt steak with caramelized peppers and onions?  Sounds like a real mash up, huh?  Perhaps they should just called it the "Tampa Cheesesteak" so as not to offend "Philly" purists.  Either way, the sandwich is good.  I might have enjoyed it more than the Cuban.

As for the name of the place, El Tipico, I think it's funny.  We do indeed have a ton of these little spots in the 813, so it's not like they're offering anything vastly different from the others, and I think their satirical name suggest that they know it.  But what I can say is that it's probably the best TnC has to offer, and I plan on eating here a bunch.

CUBAN SANDWICH REPORT CARD:

Bread: Fresh, bakery unknown.
Ham: Lunch meat / boiled ham
Pork: Pernil Al Horno
Salami: Yes, but no peppercorns
Swiss: Yes
Mustard: Yes
Pickles: Yes
Pressed: Yes
Lettuce/Tomato/Mayo: By default
Rating: 3.5 / 5.0']

name: Mayfield Florist
categories_raw: Shopping, Florists, Event Planning & Services, Wedding Planning, Flowers & Gifts
top_reviews:
["My friends were re-opening their restaurant, and so i wanted to send them a nice floral arrangement.
I'm in California, so i searched on yelp for a nearby location in Tucson.
I called several places, but ended up choosing MAYFIELD for several reasons:

1. They have a website. And although i understand my arrangement won't look EXACTLY the same, at least i have an idea on prices, style and size.
2. Staff was friendly, and very understanding. They knew immediately what type of flowers and style i was looking for.
3. Delivery charge was a little bit cheaper than other places
4. Although i ordered at 11am, they were still able to make and delivery by 2pm!
Greg Coleman was the BEST! He recommended a tropical arrangement, which turned out beautiful!
He even sent me a picture via text message of the arrangement so i could take a peak before it got delivered.
And with the order number, i was able to track step by step and know exactly when the delivery was made, plus an email confirmation was automatically sent to my email!  
It just couldn't get easier than that!", "It's possible that I owe my marriage to Mayfield florist. 

Time and time again, I seem to do everything in my power to nearly mess up a birthday, Valentine's, or anniversary... and time and time again Mayfield comes through in the clutch with beautiful bouquets and memorable arrangements. 

Do I tell my wife that I picked them out myself? Of course!

Do I let the incredible team at Mayfield tell me what to get? Absolutely! 

All I need to remember is a few of my wife's favorite flowers and a dollar amount I want to spend and the expert designers at Mayfield take care of the rest. They can work on a budget and their turn around time is very quick. Best of all, their fresh flowers seem to last all week.", 'Their response time is beyond the reasonable doubt. Are they even interested in continuing their business, I wonder?.One thing is for sure. I will never order flowers from them. My weekly delivery of flowers went to elsewhere.']

name: Magasin Kitchen
categories_raw: Imported Food, Food, Specialty Food, Ethnic Food, Restaurants, Vietnamese
top_reviews:
['Great little restaurant in the CBD that we frequent when we're stuck in the office and have to do a work lunch. 

The food always is the perfect temperature. Great to the taste. Very cost efficient. And timely. 

This time around, they took the time, at our directivenof course, to separately label all food as we had an order for a group of 8; that was done with "tender loving care". 

We ordered online and it was delivered via UberEats; we were happy campers and chowed down like there was NO TOMORROW. We all entered in the "NO LEFTOVER ZONE"; talk about delicioussssssssssssss. 

My Pho was neatly separated into components; in an effort for the veggies and food to not be wilted upon arrival; GREAT JOB!!!! The shrimp were seasoned PERFECTLY. The broth tasted soooooo good, I could've drank it as provided. The veggies were boiled very well and I actually started eating them prior to inserting them into the Pho . 

Only thing, I wish they served BUBBLE TEA; but even though they don't, it's all good; the deliciousness of the food makes me forget about how in my mind, I think Pho and bubble tea go together.', "Love! Love! Love! The location of where the restaurant sit looks like it's in a high end and new area of Nola. Walking into Magasin Kitchen I didn't realize that I was walking into a Vietnamese restaurant. The place looks very urban with a open kitchen concept, which you rarely see in any Asian restaurant.  The detail in the place I can see that the owner put many thoughts to it even down to the chopsticks.

Looking at the menu I even like the way how simple and well organize the menu was design. So I've decided to order the Crab Rangoon as an appetizer dish, the Miso Salmon Vermicelli and my friend ordered the Vietnamese Bimbop Bowl.  The server bring out the Crab Rangoon, it was hot and crunchy. Once you dip it into the sweet & sour sauce and take a bite, it's filled with my favorite ingredients. The Miso Salmon is next . I love how they serve the salmon with many different type of vegetables and the spicy fish sauce is a great combination to this dish. My friend loved her Bimbop, I wish I could have more room in my tummy to try her dish as well... But of course there's always next time when I travel to this city again, I will bookmark this place to make sure I make my stop.", 'BEWARE: MANY PRICES HERE ARE 10-25% HIGHER
than the original Uptown location. This is a major irritant to me and reflects a missread of the Warehouse District's South Market residential base. Published menu prices below are as of 13 Jan 2016.

Uptown v. Warehouse District menus:
- Filet Udon $12.50; WHD: $15.00 (20% increase)
- Pho Brisket: $8.00; WHD: $9.50 (18.75%)
- Chicken Spring Roll: $4.50; WHD: $5.50 (22.22%)
- Fried Tofu Banh Mi: $4.50; WHD: $5.50 (22.22%).

"THEY ROLL UP THE SIDEWALKS AT NIGHT"
one South Market Manager told me this summer. This area is primarily a lunch spot for budget-conscious office workers. 

So why in the heck raise prices at this location?

Particularly since most/many(?) nearby apartments are owned by non-residents as part-time vacation or Air BnB spaces. This demographic quickly led to the closures of "Ursa Major" and "Cafe 821" this year.  Even "Haro", the neighborhood anchor, is cutting back it's hours to 6PM because of little demand. 

AND THE FOOD IS BLAND!']

name: Riveters Tampa
categories_raw: Bars, Nightlife, American (Traditional), American (New), Cocktail Bars, Restaurants, Sports Bars
top_reviews:
['This restaurant is open space bar near airport. It is also next to strip club. As a result their operated hour to late night or early morning. It is good place for snack or late supper. 

We were here at their happy hours. The appetizers selection is decent. The price also decent. We started with old forester bourbon. I have it straight. The first appetizer is the Hellcat Wing. The wing was fried with choice of dipping sauce. The second app is the chicken and waffle slider. The fried chicken has good coating. The waffle need some work. The third app is the wildcat shrimp. I recommend this dish with good shrimp. The fourth app is munition mussel. I like they way prepared the sauce in the mussels. It is decent. Out last app is the prime rib slider. This dish I also recommend. The prime rib was well prepared. 

Overall our visit is positive. Very close to 4.5 stars. Definitely worth a visit. Service is good.', "Riveters has something for everyone and plenty of parking behind the strop club which is also next door.  The outside patio dining is huge they have a stage fir live music/DJ on select nights.  They offer both indoor and outdoor bar seating and fire pit dining.  This place is awesome either lounge at outdoor fire pit, or play a game of darts or ping pong table there is a lot to entertainment. 

Every day there is a happy hour from 4-7 and on Thursdays it's ladies night $3 drink specials and after 10pm ladies drink free!  They also have a house DJ spinning the beats and the whole outdoor patio becomes a dance party.  Food is good too I got some different things from the shrimp appetizer to the Reuben sandwich and a mix of cocktails during our party.", "I was not expecting Riveters to be anything more than another Hooters or Winghouse, but I was very very wrong! Stopped by on a Saturday afternoon around lunchtime and it was pretty quiet which was nice. Sat at the bar and had some of the BEST $3 mimosas I've ever had in Tampa. The food menu has something for everyone and the prices are ridiculously reasonable for this part of town! I had a burger without a bun and a caesar salad for a side. Everything was really fresh and the burger was cooked to perfection. Our bartender was absolutely awesome and took excellent care of us. The live music was also on point as it was not too loud and the outdoor singer was fantastic. I will totally come back here! And awesome pre-game spot for a Bucs game."]

name: Angry Chair Brewing
categories_raw: Nightlife, Breweries, Food, Bars
top_reviews:
['What brewery can you go to and actually enjoy pretty much the WHOLE menu of what's on Tap? This one . One of the BEST Breweries in Tampa Bay HANDS DOWN! Their beers are awesome. The list of beers I love from them goes on and on. I even loved their flavored Gose , and I hate Gose . Their Cucumber Lime Gose was so refreshing . I also loved the 5 lives Gose . I was daydreaming about them the next day while I was on the beach getting my tan on wishing I had gotten a growler. Looking forward to trying more flavors in the future. 
Their Red Ale is great  , Triggered Rye IPA , ... and their 2 Pumps Chump?  ... O-M-G frickin' A-M-A-Z-I-N-G. Get that. That's definitely a "Trouble" Beer for me . So sad this brewery is not closer to my side of town , but happy at the same time because I'd spend a lot of money in there and have a beer belly.', 'Great selection on tap! I happen to be a dark beer fan and tried I think all of their dark beers. They were so good! Particularly the two-pump chump was a fav. The bartenders are awesome people. Very chill vibe. Would definitely recommend.', "This is one of my favorite breweries in the country. Luckily I have the convenience of being close enough to them that I get their beers often. Either when I'm in town for work/play or when my buddies snag a bottle while in town - and bring them back to me to share.

So many delicious beers to name.... but I have never had anything from them that wasn't delicious. I usually go for their Porters and stouts, known for being dessert inspired, and on the sweet to extremely sweet side. If you have  sweet tooth I can't recommend their beers enough. It's legit dessert after a meal.

The tap room itself isn't too large. A couple of tables and bar stools. That's it. but I'm cool with no frills as the atmosphere is great for kicking back a few cold ones with friends.

Going to crack a couple of their beers tomorrow with some friends...if you are reading this review, you should plan on doing the same with your friends soon!"]

name: Overhead Door
categories_raw: Building Supplies, Garage Door Services, Fences & Gates, Home & Garden, Shopping, Home Services
categories: ['building supplies', 'garage door services', 'fences & gates', 'home & garden', 'shopping', 'home services']
top_reviews:
['This is really BIG.   Yesterday early evening hubby and I were going out to dinner and lo and behold pressed our button to get out of the garage.This was Sat. evening. Worst day of the week to have this problem.  We heard the most horrendous noise which we thought that the springs on the door had broke off.  We had our 2 cars in the garage and could not get out.  So sadly  we were stuck in the house.  We were never happy with any garage door people so found ourselves at a loss as to who to call and would anyone answer the call on a Saturday at 4.30 PM.  Tried a few numbers.  No luck. One machine told us the hours Mon- to Fri. 9 to 4.  One guys said his employee had just quit and couldn't see us until Mon.  Ending the conversation with " Now you have a wonderful weekend".  Called Overhead Door Co. and immediately Art Alcon was on the phone and at his office on Drexel.  We live Swan and Sunrise.  He arrived by 5.00 PM while nursing a bad cold cheerfully took out his tools to replace our rollers, springs, repaired a bent garage door.  He knew exactly what he was doing,had all the correct tools and parts and worked very efficiently.  Oiled all the parts.  This is the only place to use.  Price seemed very fair and even honored the discount coupon we had in the yellow pages.  Great guy.  Before he came he had bought some soup to take to his wife and family who were also suffering from bad colds. By the time he finished the soup was cold.  I told him to microwave it and wished him and his family get better soon. I will always use Art  in the future for any garage door problem.', "This is my second experience with Overhead Door. 
My second home in Tucson, and they were recommended to me by my next door neighbor at the first house. 
This time I bought a Tucson patio home from out of 
State. One of the problems was the old door. 
Overhead door was my first and only call, from the 
Quote to replace to the fininstall they were professional and prompt. 

Thanks JR and Sue.  I always felt like we were a team on this. 
Mahalo from Maui. 

Update:

It's been a few months since the door went in. It was starting to get noisy. 

So a service call solved everything.  Things needed lubricant. A couple bad wheels. 
So the rep came on time, solved everything in a half hour. 
Now it's nice and quiet again.", 'Incidentally, I have a 5 stars and a 2 stars feedback. So overall is 3. You may wondering why..........

==================== Five Stars =========================
I had replaced two garage doors, openers and the whole tracks by them couple years ago. I was impressed by their professionalism on the work, quality products, reasonable price, prompt installation, and accommodating  schedule. They even painted the garage doors on my drive way to match my house color.

The new units, 4040L were so quiet operating, secure (code changes every time), safe (beam to detect and not close) and with an exterior emergency key pad. 

So impressed, I have recommended to all my friends and relatives. And we called Overhead and replaced our California home garage door too.

==================== Two Stars =========================
Nevertheless, it seems they are NOT as good in support and help afterward. I had a problem with the wall control buttons (not as sensitive and sometimes you have to pushed few times or stick inside) within an year and It costed $75. I thought that should be part of their warranty service. 

Then, I had some problems this afternoon on one of my garage door which won't close all the way down. I called them and Arthur answered the phone. I knew this should be something very simple to readjust or reset to make it working again. I tried to explain to him what happened and hoped he could give me few tips to try first before had him sent someone over. But he said it might take few hours to explain over the phone and kept pressuring to send someone over to check it out.  Since I had an appointment came up, I told him that I would call him back when I return. 

Upon I returned home, I brought out the users manual and it took me ~5 min to figure out and adjust the "travel door up" and travel door down" settings on the opener. I called Art back and told him that I fixed the problem and not so happy of his unwillingness to help over the phone. I am sure he knows how to fix this kind of problem if he can just listen to my explanation more closely. He did not apologize. 

I just hope, they can be more sincerely listen to customer and help them with trivial issues or problems over the phone instead of always sending technician and costing them money.']

name: Tucson / Lazydays KOA
categories_raw: Campgrounds, RV Parks, Hotels & Travel
top_reviews:
['Second time using this particular KOA, booked right through the app. Check in was a breeze. Campground is laid out logically. Both times I chose a full size pull-through, just to keep things simple as the first time I knew I'd be arriving late, and as a pro tip for ya, the  town of Tucson has a "light ordinance" so at night, it is DARK DARK. So if you plan on showing up at night, better have a flashlight to guide ya back because I'm telling you it is DARK. 

The price is about $85 a night for the full-hookups, 30/50 amp service, cable tv (didn't use) and wifi (didn't use) 
The thing I appreciated about this particular KOA was the wide roads. Real logical layout. I also LOVED the fact that almost all the sites have fruit trees. Our one trip we had a lemon tree and this trip we had a orange tree. Fun!
I did use the shower facilities, and they were clean every time I used them. Water pressure was great. 
There is the typical sundries and gift shop at check-in. All staff were welcoming and pleasant.
There's a dog walk area. This particular campground clientele both time was "Snow Birds." Quiet, chill, happy older folks. The campground is also very quiet at night. Not much highway noise. Easy in and out. 
I didn't do too much exploring on site,but I know there is lots there, like a heated pool, laundry facility, game room, gym, dog area, fire pit areas. 

Extremely clean. Easy to navigate. Wide paths. Another stellar KOA! 

Would return, would recommend !', "It's a really nice resort campground. The WiFi is okay right now for checking mail, using Yelp. The WiFi seemed better last fall. Fruit trees are nice. Sites are nice and level. Staff was friendly. The BBQ restaurant has great food. I stored my trailer here last year but they are full this year. They told me it was due to an expansion project.", "Spent two evenings at this KOA campground in Tucson, Arizona.  The RV campsites were pretty spacious for the most part.  It seemed that many of the sites also had a fruit tree which was really cool to see.  Our site even had a two story patio.  We did not spend too much time outside because the temperature was soaring above 100 degrees!!  No shade on the second floor.  

The property looks terrific for the most part.  Nice playground for the kids.  Fitness center had a quite bit of cardio equipment that appeared to be in good shape.  The pool areas were well kept.  They have an onsite bbq restaurant which we were unable to try, but still nice to have on the property.  My only complaint would be that the Men's restroom was not well maintained.  Both days, the restrooms were not swept up, stocked, or cleaned.  Quite disappointing especially considering that everything else on the property was looking great.

Would I stay here again?  Yeah, if the price is reasonable."]

name: Charro Steak & Del Rey
categories_raw: Diners, Restaurants, Steakhouses, Mexican
top_reviews:
['I'm a little surprised by this place.... in the best way possible. I know that El Charro is a 
Tucson institution but I will say (blast me if you will) I am not their biggest fan. That said, these guys really seem to know what they're doing and Charro Steak may have begin to change my opinion of the Flores group of restaurants.

The space is, well, let's call it rustic elegance. Lots of metal and stressed wood tables. They have two bars: one where you can wait for a table if you don't have a reservation (which we did) and one inside the restaurant. Maybe that's overkill but having the bar in front made the one inside more accessible to the servers. Although, in hindsight, the timing of the drinks was the only true hiccup in service.

Before I start to talk about the food, I'll mention that their menu is largely gluten free and it's noted next to the dish. I'll also mention that they really focus on local ingredients right down to the corn tortillas they use for chips. Their motto is "ranch to table". Not terribly original but it speaks to their meat focused theme.

I ordered Monica's Martini. A standard vodka martini but was garnished with a bleu cheese olive and pork belly chicharron. It didn't show up to the table until after our albondigas appetizer. But those albondigas... served with charred Chiles, Manchego cheese and Prickly Pear barbecue sauce. The server mentioned the sauce was spicy so we asked for it on the side. I'll offer some totally unsolicited advice - they need to put a rib dish on the menu and serve it with that sweet, spicy and just plain tasty sauce. I'd order it in a heartbeat.

Since we had ordered the meatballs, we decided to split the boneless ribeye. It turned out to be enough, with the sides, but I'd probably get my own steak next time. I'd figured, since we were splitting the dish, the least they could do is bring me a plate and a steak knife. They brought one knife for my wife and me to share and I was left with a small plate meant for sides. That didn't deter me once the steak and sides arrived. The ribeye was probably closer to medium well, but that's fine with me. It came with a little cup of charro beans and their "salsa padre" which tasted eerily similar to A-1 with salsa. The steak hardly needed that sauce anyway.

Sometimes, in a steakhouse, the sides are where they can really shine... and Charro Steak does. We got the Esquites, charred corn with cotija cheese and crema and the Papas de la Casa, with crema and green chiles. They really did classic steakhouse sides justice putting a Charro spin on them. Both of them and the charro beans were really good and made me forget I was eating a steak on a plate meant for appetizers.

When the dessert menu was presented and we saw Tamal de Nutella we looked at each other and knew we had to try it. Really creative and not too sweet, it was a good finish to our meal.

I know I can be long winded in some reviews. I really try to give details because I know that's what I look for in reviews. So, if you're still reading, I'll either apologize or thank your for indulging me... you choose.

Service, for the most part,  was outstanding. A busser noticed our chips were kind of broken so he offered us some new ones. Plates were cleared and water refilled promptly. The only issues with service were the ones I mentioned and the fact that the wine we ordered with our steaks showed up a little late. Those kind of service boo boos are totally fixable and won't stop of from returning... soon.', "Missing Charro steak big time. Our last order during Covid was a little complicated due to the time on their system not matching up with the website to place our online order. But that's nothing a quick phone call didn't fix! The charro burger and half bone in chicken were cooked to perfection. I love a simple burger and charro has all the right ingredients for a classic. Thank you Team Charro! They all work so hard!", "Charro Steak is my go to place, for out of town company. It's got a wonderful southwestern flare. The menu has something for everyone. It's got a rich vibrancy and the tall ceiling makes it feel even more grand. I've enjoyed many a Sunday brunch, lunch and dinner. I love the food and attention to detail the staff pay to the table. We have brought out of town business guests here many times, and every occasion El Charro Steak has exceeded our expectations. My husband loves their carne asada, estilo style( with roasted chiles and cheese). I am a big fan of their Sunday brunch, which is Sundays starting at 11am.
If you are going with a group, get the Tabla del Charro ( Charcuterie Board). I could just live on a cocktail and nibbles of the cheeses and offering that board provides....heaven!  At certain times they offer live music; a great delight which is often a classical guitar player. During brunch the music is just perfect for an al fresco meal experience, with the windows slid open along Broadway.
On holidays, check their website, as often they have special menus, which are cause to go see what tricks they have up their sleeve. Charro Steak frequently is the site of special wine paring dinners and fund raisers. If you need to arrange a special occasion party they can easily accommodate big groups. The restaurant is a very large area with multiple dinning areas, two bar areas and semi private walled area. The only down side is with all this space, the restaurant just has three single stall restrooms for the entire place, even though there are two bar areas. Once I was attending a wine paring dinner, and had to wait 10 minutes for the stall, since someone was doing their makeup or texting in the restroom or who knows....I don't know how I held it. I have since learned there is a single unisex stall in the bar area of the entrance. There is also a outdoor patio area, but I haven't sat outside for a meal yet.
For a great meal, with outstanding atmosphere and service, don't miss the chance to hit up this gem off Broadway!"]

name: The Three Coins Diner
categories_raw: American (Traditional), Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Why 4 stars?  Because the key to my morning heart is a good omelet.

   ---   ---   ---

2+ years living in Seminole Heights

Several hundred occasions driving right past Three Coins Restaurant

Zero trips inside.  

I just wasn't sure what to expect in there.  It recently dawned on my curiosity to check out Three Coins on Yelp, and the reviews guided me to finally stop in.

What I got was a better version of Denny's, that's closer to my house...and most importantly...locally owned!  Mmmm....local....(Homer drool sounds)

The girlfriend needed to catch a 6:55am flight, which meant I was up at 5:30am on a Sunday.  This typically would cause me borderline schizophrenia, but I suffered through waking up when it was still pitch black outside, knowing that a new Seminole Heights gem was on the docket for the morning.

I braved this venture alone, as not only were none of my friends awake at that ungodly hour, but I believe only 11 people in the city of Tampa were conscious during this time.

My omelet hit the spot, big time!  The fact that I was sitting across from a prostitute that was just getting off "work" for the night, was a bonus.  I got to listen to her haggle with the waitress over how much extra jelly cups would cost and why she couldn't do substitutions for free on certain menu items for take-out orders.  I couldn't tell if these silly restrictions were legitimate, or if she was a regular trouble maker that they were trying to eliminate from coming back.  Either way, I got dinner and a show.', 'It was a better world before a lot of things. The baseball cap on backwards, Rap, the Bowl Alliance. Your whole grain police hadn't passed a law against any food that tastes good. Sausage and eggs weren't a felony. A cheeseburger didn't get you shot at. Hell, you can get arrested for food in your own home if you don't register your low-fat mayonnaise. You ever had that? Why can't we get some scientist on a government grant or something to get to the bottom of this? That stuff just don't ruin good tuna fish, that crap will poison a whole city!

Anyway, this is long overdue and I know I'm driving my friends crazy with all the 4:00AM checkins at this place, but it has honestly become my favorite spot in town for great and what might even be described as upscale diner food. 

I have made a full lap around the menu and everything, well almost, has been superb. The only thing that didn't exceed my expectations we're the cheese grits. I chuckle whenever I pull into the parking lot imagining the staff whispering to themselves..."On no, here comes the Cheese Grits Man!" LOL

There is always a good crowd here, no matter what time of day. Its popular with both students and retirees, and that's rare. The first time I came here I took one look at their expansive menu and thought "Well this can't be any good." I was wrong, its better than good, its incredible.... and I don't impress that easy. And BTW, save room for some of their homemade coconut cream pie, and remember me in your Will.', "We wanted breakfast, so we ordered here. 

The restaurant was clean, friendly employees and nice guests. Social distancing is a must and you must wear your face mask. 

I don't eat breakfast meat, so I ordered a mushroom omelette, grits and potatoes. My son ordered French toast, bacon, sausage and scrambled eggs. My Husband, my daughter and her boyfriend had corn beef hash, grits and eggs. They were supposed to get biscuits, but didn't get any. 

The food was delicious and we will be back again."]

name: Tanya & Matt's Ice Cream
categories_raw: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food, Coffee & Tea
top_reviews:
["Visited Tanya & Matt's for some  homemade ice cream. The space is quaint with clippings of newspaper articles & accolades pasted on the walls. There were live musicians - a guitarist & a singer that brought a cheerful vibe to the space. I had the rum raisin ice cream, it was flavorful & didn't have too many raisins which I loved. I enjoy supporting local businesses & I look forward to visiting again.", 'Nothing like a great mom n pop ice cream shop! 
This place has the best shakes in the area. Covid has closed the inside, and they now have a window for you to order from. I have always enjoyed anything i get here. 
After about 5 minutes our order came out and the chocolate peanut butter shake was thick, full of flavor, and delicious. They have old school ice cream machines and something about the old machines make the ice cream amazing. Located in a shopping plaza there is plenty of walking around to do while you eat or drink your ice cream. 
Do yourself a favor at least once, try the milkshakes and change your life.', 'Great rich ice cream and many creative flavors for selection. This sum the store best thing can be found. The ice cream store located in the plaza close to T J Maxx. At night time in winter, they still get a lot customers. This tell me they have good regular customers   

Their flavor includes something you cannot  imagine. I got eggnog and rum raisin. The ice cream as they have advertised. Creamy. Not bad at all. They do have milkshakes and sundae available if you want to that route.']

name: Muriel's Jackson Square
categories_raw: Cajun/Creole, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Although Muriel's has only been around since 2001, the location it has in Jackson Square has a history dating back to the 18th century. 
The building was originally constructed in the mid-1700s as a home for Jean Baptiste Destrehan who was the Royal Treasurer of the French Louisiana Colonies..

The home changed hands a number of times and had portions rebuilt after a fire in 1788, was used as a store, became the home of the Heritage Hall Jazz Band and was then another restaurant before becoming Muriel's.

The current owners did extensive and accurate renovations on this property bringing the interior back to the look it had in the 1800s.  When you walk in you're immediately struck by it's beauty and grandeur but it doesn't feel fussy or too formal.

We'd made reservations ahead of time for the jazz brunch.  We were warmly greeted when we entered and brought to our table.  
We were seated at a corner table affording a little more privacy which was nice. There was a window to the left and then a clear view outward into the rest of the lovely room.  

The window seat turned out to be a mixed blessing.  Although it afforded a view onto Jackson Square, it was in the path of the ubiquitous carriage horses and mules which fill me with sadness when I see them.  Suffice it to say, I'm not a fan of this trade. 

The brunch menu offers lots of options including spinach salad, crawfish and goat cheese crepes, Gulf shrimp remoulade, crawfish omelette, smoked salmon and bagels,and a pasta, mushroom and vegetable plate and a number of others.
The shrimp and grits were served in a really savory and rich Abita Amber beer sauce .  It was a delicious dish.  I've seen the Abita Beer sauce used in dishes elsewhere around town and it seems to be a local favorite.

The brunch cocktails include Bloody Mary's, Brandy Milk Punch, Sazerac, Ramos Gin Fizz and an Absinthe concoction.

It's worth taking a stroll around the restaurant to check out the many rooms and nooks and crannies.  Other areas include an outdoor balcony, an indoor courtyard bar area and The Seance room where the resident ghost of Pierre Antoine Lepardi Jourdan is said to reside.

The jazz trio was fun and added an upbeat element to what was the start of another lovely day in New Orleans.", "It's been almost 8 years since I last visited and reviewed Muriel's.

I think I've resigned myself to the fact that this is just going to be one of those places that I visit for atmosphere and history, rather than for a phenomenal food. They just don't really seem to be inspired to do anything approaching creative nor outstanding for their vegan and vegetarian customers. It's a traditional kind of place and that is agreeable to a lot of people.

The restaurant really is lovely and the service is also excellent. Dare I say I just need more these days? I'd expect something a bit more interesting after 8 years.

So. You'll get a salad with the whatever-makes-it-more-than-just lettuce left off. You'll get a tasty, if unexciting, pasta with vegetable entree. I don't believe there were any dessert options.

I'll be back for wine at the bar and to soak in the beautiful surroundings", 'For my 1100th review, I review the iconic Muriel's Jackson Square, one of the loveliest restaurant/event spaces in New Orleans. I first attended a wedding here on Halloween 2010. My two fabulous friends pulled out all the stops and had an amazing horror movie-themed wedding where Jason and Leatherface got things started with a bang (er, a chainsaw). Sure seems like the folks behind Muriels worked well with my friends and the wedding was an occasion to remember. We were upstairs, where private events are held, and took breaks from the main room in the bordello-like seance room. One of my favorite things about this night included hanging out with cocktails on huge balcony overlooking Jackson Square. 

By the way, if you're dining here and there isn't an event going on, you're free to go upstairs and check all that out. You can even have a drink and bring it up to the Seance Room (and I strongly recommend that you do, if you like rooms dripping in red, chandeliers, velvet and brocade. It makes me want to decorate my entire apartment in a similar fashion). 

Recently I came to realize that besides the gorgeous environs, the restaurant serves up some really great food and drink. My friends and I had lunch here recently. We were seated in the room where they open the huge glass doors to the sidewalk so you can watch passersby and listen to music being played out in Jackson Square. 

At lunchtime, they offer $4 Bloody Marys, wines and martinis. I indulged in a Bloody Mary, as I am often wont to do, and found it to be quite satisfactory (garnished with olives, pickled green beans and citrus and served in a pint glass. No skimping here just cuz it's a mere 4 bucks). 

I ordered the modestly-named Vegetable Plate. I'll be honest and say I wasn't expecting much because I've had many a pedestrian veg plate where they barely even marinate the vegetables before skewering them and grilling. Booooring. 

I'm thrilled to report that Muriel's Vegetable Plate belongs in the Vegetable Plate Hall of Fame. First of all, it contains braised kale. Almost 'nuff said there, but I'll go on to say its flavor is just so so so very good. The other star of the plate is that compact square of polenta flavored with herbs and Parm cheese. Everything is so delicately placed, which I love, and nothing overwhelmed with oils or heavy sauces to "make up for" the fact that you're eating a plate of vegetables. There's a delightful little bit of everything from beets to parsnips to tender shittake mushrooms. A healthy, hearty plate. Thank you, Muriels! I seriously could not stop thinking about it all day.

They also have a gluten-free menu.

I think I'll be dining here on the regular when I have visitors in town. It's just the perfect place to take them when they want the quintessential French Quarter dining experience.']

name: Marjie's Grill
categories_raw: Barbeque, Southern, Pan Asian, Thai, Vietnamese, Asian Fusion, Salad, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['If Southern-style dishes made a baby with Southeast Asian cuisine and they decided to raise their love child in their quirky grandma's house (but it's that grandma that always made great comfort food), that's Marjie's Grill. 

The building is a bright lil' ray of sunshine on a underwhelming stretch of Broad Street. You walk into a quaint dining room where intentional hodge-podgery exists in every nook and cranny, like the hand-embroidered sign of their Instagram handle hanging over their cutlery station. The sweet aroma of "I want that" wraps you up in an invisible blanket of hunger. Grab a chair upholstered in this fabulous retro cosmic vinyl to peruse the menu. 

The menu changes so drool over what they've got online or just be ready to enjoy whatever they've got going on. From my experience, I doubt you'll be disappointed.  Alas, I still felt the need to write a love letter about what I enjoyed!...

Fresh Cracklin' $7 
Dusted with tumeric-chili spice. 
Delicious, the perfect amount of chewy and crisp with a hint of spice. 

They had riblets (short ribs) as a special that day and they were perfect. You know how in other reviews I talk about my problem with sharing? If you like short ribs, do not, I repeat, do not share this dish. Perfectly sauced and easily came off the bones. 

Charred Pork Shoulder Steak $26
served sliced with tons of fresh herbs and a sweet chili sauce.
*Expletive Expletive Expletive* So gosh dang good. This hunk of meat was twice the size of my head and the four of us struggled to finish it. When they suggested we wrap the meat in the bounty of fresh herbs and dip it in the sauce, I hesitated...for maybe two seconds. The fresh herbs complemented the rich flavors of the meat and were only elevated by the light sauce provided. Hot damn, y'all. Hot damn. 

Did I mention we also ordered cornbread? Dios mio. 

With drinks and a copious amount of food, I couldn't believe how affordable it all was. I have an internal struggle telling Yelp about this because it really was one of the best meals I've had in New Orleans as of recent. 

Did we leave smelling like the sweet aroma of "I want that"? We sure did. Did we care? Not in the least bit.', "I LOVE Marjie's Grill. First, I walked in and the place smelled amazing. And when I tasted the food, I was still just as impressed. My friend L and I ordered a bunch of stuff that I can't remember anymore, but everything was very tasty. If they are serving grilled sweet potatoes, get them. I also really loved the pork knuckles. 

Do yourself and favor and eat here!", 'This was the only restaurant I visited during my trip to New Orleans that was worth repeating. Marjie's Grill serves a type of fusion cuisine that I had never seen before, pairing Southeast Asian flavors with Gulf Coast barbecue dishes. The chefs slow grill their meats over coal Santa Maria-BBQ style in the restaurant's backyard. The selection of spices and produce used to prepare the vegetable sides are purchased from local farmer markets.

This type of food gets me excited, because it's inventive, local, and demonstrates culinary sophistication, unlike some trendy (but boring) Asian fusion concept nowadays that may involve permutations of tacos, buns, french french fries, heavy sauces, and meat.

I stopped by Marjie's for two casual lunches. The menu was simple during lunchtime with a few weekly options. Essentially, you build a one dish meal consisting of a meat, vegetable sides, and rice. You can add as many vegetable sides as you want to the plate, I would recommend trying two at a time.

During my first visit, I had the BBQ pork shoulder that was thinly sliced, slightly peppery, with charred edges, glistening of pork fat, topped with a garlicky and sour relish that tasted like a Thai or Vietnamese dipping sauce. On my second visit, I ordered the spice-rubbed Gulf fish that's delicately charred on the grill and topped with a orange peel-like citrus seasoning. The white fish was buttery soft, perfect to pair with rice, which is also locally sourced. Both BBQ meats were exceptional and perfectly grilled.

I thought that the vegetable sides were equally as brilliant as the meats. All of the vegetables seemed to have more pickled, bright, and sour flavors than expected, which makes them more complex and interesting. My favorite was the spicy arugula mixed with fresh mint, studded with sliced kumquat and dressed with sambal vin. What made this side special were the pure sweetness of the kumquats (even the peels) and sourness of the citrus salsa. I loved tasting these "dressings" derived from whole natural ingredients. The braised greens in chili vinegar was what I believe to be a creative take on Southern collard greens, but not prepared the Southern way of being bland. It's glazed and spiced up to be bright and pungent, reminding me of Thai flavors. I also enjoyed the cabbage w/ scallions & carrots, all briefly charred on the grill and topped with sesame. As for the most interesting side, I would pick the spicy green beans, apparently pounded in a mortar and pestle.

If you're in New Orleans, I would recommend checking it out. This place would be my first stop the next time I'm in town.']

name: New York New York Pizza - Carrollwood
categories_raw: Pizza, Italian, Restaurants, Burgers, Sandwiches
top_reviews:
['When my mom-in-law told me that this was where my niece wanted to celebrate her birth DAY with our immediate family, I was excited because I'd never been here. Y'all may be aware of my pizza obsession. After a confusing Yelp search, I realized this location had very recently moved... not far, but across the street. Now in the plaza with Burger Monger, we found it easily via Google Maps, with lots of great parking. 

I was surprised at how sparse the dining area is! We commandeered two large round tables, which was sufficient for our group of 9, but I only remember seeing a couple of small square tables still available for others dining in. However, it looked like most customers order for take out. So while I'd noticed that we'd taken over the bulk of their tables & seating, it didn't seem to impact their Wednesday night business.

On to the pizza... WOW! The crust was what I think of as "Brooklyn style"... hand-tossed but very thin. Delicious! It was perfectly crisp, not burnt, and not soggy nor doughy. We ordered their white pizza with spinach & chicken, and I LOVED it. The next day, I was additionally pleased at how well it tasted warmed up in my toaster oven at work. 

Obviously my niece loves this pizza, and I respect my (adult) in-laws' opinions on pizza as well. New York New York is everything I had hoped it would be... not exactly NYC-style pizza, but outstanding, nonetheless. I'm delighted to have found a new pizza joint!', 'I was sadly disappointed on my first visit to New York New York Pizza in Carrollwood right after the place opened. And so rather than blast a new restaurant that was trying to get established in the community, I waited for several months and then tried the place again. I should have stuck with my original opinion of this restaurant.

New York New York Pizza is a small Tampa-based chain with outlets in Ybor City, Hyde Park, Riverview, Westchase, Wesley Chapel, and now Carrollwood. This location is in the shopping center at the corner of Dale Mabry and Linebaugh. It's the same shopping center as Publix, Tijuana Flats, Golfer's Grail, and Brass Tap

Their website advertises that they serve slices that are large, wide, thin, and foldable. Their menu also advertises that in addition to pizza, they also serve subs, burgers, wraps, salads, and Italian entrées. That may be the case, but this restaurant is clearly catering to the "pizza by the slice" crowd.

On both of my visits I selected slices from the various pies sitting in their display cases. The cashier lifted the slices onto a round, metal pizza pan, moved them to the pizza oven, and then delivered them to the table a minute or two later. That gave you plenty of time to collect your drink, and find an open seat at a nearby table.

The crust was crisp, but I certainly would not call this NY-style thin crust. It was more of a normal thickness, and frankly pretty bland. A little more salt in the pizza dough would have helped immensely. This was not a slice of pizza that you could easily 'fold' lengthwise, but rather a slice that you have to crack the outer rim, and then squeeze it together in order to eat.

The sauce and the cheese seemed to be in the right proportions, but the sauce was also pretty tasteless, and clearly just sauce out of a can. The amount of toppings was great, but that also contributed to my major issue -- the grease. This was a pizza that I wanted to wring out, or at least blot with several napkins before attempting to eat. The grease was overwhelming, and the slice kinda dribbled the whole time that I was trying to eat it. Hardly appetizing.

Several hours after eating a couple of slices, I still had the lingering after-taste of grease in my mouth and belly. A couple of Tums later and I was back to normal. Not a good experience.

I hope that you have a better experience at NY NY Pizzeria than me. I'm very familiar with NY-style thin crust pizza from Little Italy, and this isn't it. Perhaps you'll like it, but I don't plan on ever going back.', "NYNY (NY squared or NY with a  G1 Shrapnel vocal Tic) Pizza is located in a plaza on the southbound side of Dale Mabry next to Broken Yolk cafe and a few feet from BurgerMonger.

They serve NY style pizza by the slice or in whole pie form along with other Italian fare. The interior is yellow and there are a 3-4 circular tables with 3-4 chairs each. It is a bit small and seems intended mostly for the take out.

The specialty slices are $3 each. 2 specialty slices and a soda are $7, which is not much of a deal. The pieces are big and the crust is crunchy. The cheese/sauce are decent, but not a standout.  
Their toppings on the works/supreme pizza are plentiful.

IMO, they are better than average but not as good as Eddie and Sam's in downtown Tampa. Though this is obviously much more convenient than going there. To be honest, I'm not a pizza fanatic these days (I used to like pizza a lot more when I  was little and into TMNT and still had sleepovers lol)

They are a 3.5/5 imo."]

name: Blue Giant
categories_raw: Desserts, Food, Noodles, Chicken Shop, Chinese, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['My visit was long overdue but wowza, I left with the biggest smile on my face and simply floored on not only the food but the service we received.

Our server was an angel and she really was the star of the show. From her witty and friendly banter to her superb service and suggestions. She alone deserves like a million stars. (Once I find out her name I'll make sure to edit my review!)

She really does embody the spirit of New Orleans and the dining experience one dreams of whether you're a local or a tourist. I also have to mention her swag was just so badass, like the cool kid who is just so cool and gets along with everyone and makes friends with anyone. My partner and I were so blown away by her that we didn't hesitate to leave a generous tip and personally thank her for making our date night so memorable. 

Anyways... Dining in the midst of a pandemic can be quite tricky but if you're concerned about the practices here. DON'T BE. Blue Giant has knocked it out of the park with all of their COVID-19 safety practices. Honestly this was one of the safest dining experiences I have ever had. They have a total of five tables open so reservations are an absolute must. Installation of plexiglass, check-in station at the front, masks required, hand sanitizer, constant sanitizing, I felt like a true VIP.

When one is on a date night, you know you have to start off with some cocktails if that's your poison. Their signature cocktails are worth trying and one of them even benefits the Son of a Saint non-profit!

Now for our first bites of the evening, I don't play around nor do I try to look cute in front of my partner anymore. I'm ordering the whole damn menu and I'm going to create a spread that should be for four people not just two.

My boyfriend and I started with an egg drop soup, dan dan noodles, shrimp wontons, and another item that my boyfriend wanted.

Holy crap those dan dan noodles. Have you ever had a bit of food that is so good you contemplate saying it taste horrible so you don't have to share. Well I sure as hell did, because I would've gladly ate this dish all alone or even reheated in the middle of the night while he was asleep. Every bite had the right balance of crunch and texture, my taste buds were really having a trip of their lifetime.

The spicy chili crunch on the shrimp wontons is fire (but not super spicy at all)! You have to order this dish and share amongst the table, it's a great dish and as you start exploring the menu you really do realize that this will be a signature dining experience within the city.

We hadn't even ordered our "main dishes" and I was already crying tears of joy with my third glass of wine. (Oh yea, they also serve beer and wine!)

I was intrigued about the crispy beef being a dine-in only dish, so I wanted to take full advantage of the opportunity. I'm one who stalks a menu for like the whole day and scouring through countless amount of photos so I know ahead of time and make "casual suggestions" whenever I'm dining out. 

*I'm putting my [food] stalking skills for the greater good I keep telling myself.

So when the dish comes out, I made sure to let my boyfriend have the first few bites. Balance, y'all balance. So when his eyes lit up, I was like hot damn this is gonna be a treat. So I use my chopsticks and pick up a bite and put it into my mouth. 

Chefs Kiss.

I was ready to go behind the kitchen and just hug the kitchen. I can't give proper justice to this dish; however, I can see that the reason it's not available for to-go/takeout is because I understand it wouldn't give proper justice to this dish. It has to absolutely be served straight from the kitchen.

Now the surprise winner of the night for me was the char siu pork. So f*ck#ng tender and literally would break apart from the touch of the chopstick. It was so good that I ate a second dish of it alone. My mouth is actually drooling while I'm typing this out haha.

Blue Giant is just such a romantic and hella cute spot. I'm so happy to see them around and thankful I was able to dine-in and support them.', "Yeeesssss! I finally made it to Blue Giant!

So it was my birthday and I was on the hunt for a casual spot where I could kick back with my family and have a good meal.  I generally keep my birthdays on the DL, so a small dinner with my family is my annual birthday jam. Thanks to Tomas' glowing review, I had a feeling that Blue Giant would be perfect. 

This place is the sh$&.  

The staff warmly welcomed us into this hip joint. We had a reservation, and it was a good thing because they are busy.  

Now for the food. We def over ordered and it was a good thing. This was what we chowed on.:

Chili oil cucumbers - fresh and amazing
Potstickers - good but not my favorite part of the meal
Dan Dan noodles - oh yeah
Crispy beef - do not skip this one!
Mandarin chicken - delicious
Pork belly over sticky rice - mind blowing

My favorite dish was the crispy beef, hands down.  I can't even describe it, you just have to trust me and order it.  Second favorite was the Dan Dan noodles. They were spicy and so rich. 

I'm looking forward to a girls' night here when COVID gives us back our lives.", 'Buzz has been surrounding Blue Giant for months and I already had a plan of action going in. I find with these hot-spots it's best to try and go at lunch, so I headed over around 1 p.m. on a Saturday. There was a bit of a wait, but we quickly settled into a booth in the cozy dining room. 

I love the atmosphere of this spot. It's small inside, but not cramped, and the open kitchen provides thrills as you wait for your food. There are a few booths and more seating at the bar space, overlooking the kitchen. Peking ducks hang in the kitchen's window, tempting those dining to try one out for taste.

Onto the food! I started with an order of egg rolls ($3 each) and an order of the shrimp and pork dumplings. I was so excited about this egg roll; it came out so fresh that it was steaming when I cracked it open. There is a nice crust on the outside, and it has that nice "crunch" when you bite into it. It's packed with a generous amount of pork and shrimp and the flavors are exotic and familiar. I love a good egg roll and Blue Giant's immediately jumped to the top of my "must order" list. The dumplings are another star; they are pan fried and come with a nice lacy crust on the outside, almost akin to edible art. The dumplings themselves are soft and flavorful and filled with tender pork and shrimp. They have a very light crunch on the outside, while the inside is soft and melts in your mouth.

For my entrée I got the Salt and Pepper Catfish. This is piece of catfish sliced, battered and fried, almost tempura style, and served with sautéed onions and peppers, which added some spice. The catfish itself was light and it was a dish that would have easily paired well with some of the other offerings on the menu, especially if you're visiting for dinner and you're looking to go "all out."

Don't go into Blue Giant expecting an authentic trip through the Orient or typical greasy American-Chinese take-out. The dishes here err more on the side of Chinese-inspired, but if you like Chinese with an American twist, as I do, then this will be the place for you. 

*Portions of this review was written, by me, for Offbeat Magazine. Read the full write up here: http://www.offbeat.com/news/american-chinese-eatery-blue-giant-is-a-new-star-on-the-dining-scene/']

name: Ba-Dar
categories_raw: Chinese, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["The need for an abundance of caution during this COVID-19 crisis has made ordering food become the norm.  Ba-dar delivers... literally and in the execution of their food.

They have a really large menu so, if you can't find something you like, well... Chinese food is just not your thing.

If you have a tender palate, and don't like spicy food, try the BBQ pork chow fun. The wide, flat rice noodles looked like they would be bland, but they weren't. The dish had a lot of flavor and plenty of thinly sliced pork. I wanted to try it in it's original state, but next time I will ask for it spicy. They can make any dish spicy at your request.

Speaking of spicy... it was hard not to order my go-to dish from Ba-dar, Eight Jewel Blossom. It's one of their signature dishes... and it's easy to see why. Chicken, beef and shrimp swim in harmony with water chestnuts, bamboo shoots, mushrooms, bean curd and peanuts in a very flavorful, spicy sauce. I mean, if you you are a Chinese food fan, like me, what's not to like about this dish?

The more you spend on your order the more free stuff you get, i.e. spend 25 bucks and get free crab rangoons.  How cool is getting free stuff for food you're going to order anyway?

They use fresh ingredients and delivery is fast and dependable. If you live in their delivery area, you really need to give them a try. You won't be disappointed.", 'Decided to order take-out from Ba-Dar during the COVID19 stay at home.  Trying to support our local food industry as they try to survive.  This was the first time we have ever had food from there and I can tell you definitively it will NOT be our last!  Their menu is extensive and they actually have two menus, one with Chinese characters and a WIDE variety of dishes, and another more "standard" Chinese restaurant menu.  We ordered crispy orange beef (has chilis in it to give a touch of heat but very orangy), Singapore rice noodle-House special (my fav), squid with snap peas and ginger and chicken lo mein.  The portions are ENORMOUS.  Add to all that goodness, the fact that if you spend more than $45 you get free fried rice (we got the BBQ pork) which is also huge!  I am glad it was all so delicious because we are going to be eating it for days!!!

In addition to delicious food, the phone service was terrific.  We got disconnected accidentally (not sure if it was them or me) and when I called back she was so apologetic and helpful.  When we went to pick it up it was all ready and steaming hot!  Additionally, all the packages were sturdy enough that we didn't end up with a lapful of soup!  Can't wait to try some of the more "exotic" items on the menu!', "I am not a Chinese food expert. Having grown up in the San Francisco Bay Area, I have eaten at some excellent Chinese restaurants there. I do know real bad Chinese food, and up until the last few years, I had not been willing to try any Asian restaurants in Tucson, because almost all of them show up in the poor ratings section of the health department inspection reports in the Star. 

But about a year and a half ago, a Chinese friend of mine from Singapore recommended Ba-Dar as one the few most authentic Chinese food joints in Tucson. I have not been disappointed with her recommendation. 

I have always enjoyed my meals here. As I've mentioned in couple of my other reviews, I get into a rut eating the same things, so I have tried to broaden my experience here, BUT I LOVE THE ORANGE SPICY BEEF SO MUCH! The rice noodles are excellent, the beef is generous, and the orange flavor is subtle but never missing. I've tried some other dishes, including Kung Pao beef, chicken, and shrimp, as well as a couple of others - they've all been great - but it's the orange spicy beef that keeps me coming back. The plate is about $9, but I get two meals out of it. 

My wife and I have never had a problem with service at Ba-Dar. As for the atmosphere, it's typical Chinese - better than most - it's not tacky like a lot of them can be - and it's clean. I believe I've never seen Ba-Dar get a poor health inspection report. 

They offer delivery and takeout."]

name: Carrollwood Florist
categories_raw: Shopping, Florists, Flowers & Gifts
top_reviews:
["Stopped in for some flowers for my grandma's birthday. I didn't place an order ahead of time so wondered if they had ready made bouquets for purchase. Greeted right when we entered and they did have ready made ones. She walked me over to the cooler where they were located and we browsed. She also offered to show me some online that they could make up in 15 minutes. We wanted a bouquet with sunflowers. She showed us 3 and we found this one. Absolutely beautiful. Cost was $80 with tax. Great service and beautiful work. My grandma was surprised and loved her flowers.", "Another stunning arrangement!  I should have posted this when I picked up the arrangement (May 25) - but check it out...!  This picture was taken today...!  A week later!  

Carrollwood Florist came through again -  this time for my wife's birthday.  They took the time to listen to my request and made the perfect arrangement.

Their flowers are top-notch, and the florists/stylists know their stuff.  

New florist for us, 100%.", 'CHECK IT OUT!   a week later...and these roses are as healthy and beautiful as when I picked them up!!']

name: Fork
categories_raw: American (New), Burgers, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
top_reviews:
["Fork, in 5 words: A stainless steel eating utensil. 
I'll try again: Stylish, excellent service, pedestrianly sophisticated.

I'm just always late ok?
My sis was in town recently I met her, along with her friends, at Fork for dinner. Being very late to the party, I showed up 25 minutes to closing (cringe). Sebastian, our waiter, brought me fresh coffee and then took my dinner order at around 10:40, no problem. I ordered the tomato basil and grilled cheese fondue and it was fantastic. #grilled_cheese_for_adults 
I would have not usually ordered food that close to closing (it's just not right) but on a scale from 1 to hangry, I was about to start flipping tables. 

The Waiter
Fork must have excellent management and high standards for servers or maybe they were just fortunate to hire Sebastian. When I show up anywhere 25 minutes to closing, I expect consequences and a less than amused server. I was pleasantly surprised. Sebastian never once rushed us, and if he was annoyed he didn't show it.

Fun
Despite a bit of mischief, which I had nothing to do with, Sebastian was unfazed. He handled our shenanigans and was a champion at banter. I can confidently give Fork 5 stars for excellent customer service and ordinary food dressed up fancy in a classy atmosphere. 

I don't always have extraordinary servers, but when I do, I leave an extra good tip and then write nice things about them on yelp.", 'T'was a Thursday afternoon & the wifey and I were hankerin' for a lunchtime joint that was new to us. So whatta we do? We Yelp of course! ...and together we came up with Fork.

Our hostess showed us to a table in a nearly empty dining area. It's just before noon, so I'm guessing Boise's work force hasn't let out for lunch just yet. As we perused the menu, Steve, our waiter brought over our rubber corked bottled water & filled our iced water glasses (a nice touch I might add) as he proceeded with his schpeel on Fork's organic dishes in which they use only the freshest local ingredients from vendors, suppliers & farmers in the Idaho & Pacific Northwest regions.

He recommended a few starters & we settled with the Grilled Jumbo Artichoke. By the time I had consumed half of my Outlaw IPA (by Payette Brewing Boise, ID), the Artichoke made it's arrival to our table. Larger than other artichokes we've had at other establishments, this one had a nice slightly grilled char on the inside halves, but didn't taste all charcoal-y like others we've had in the past. Nicely seasoned, it also had a hint of lemon. It was served with a mayo based rémoulade which had hints of roasted peppers & garlic. It was a devine pairing with the lemony 'choke leaves.

The wife ordered the Brisket/Sirloin blend Sliders served with glazed onions for her main lunch course & I, the Urban Burger w/bacon cooked at a juicy medium. I placed the fresh tomato & red onion slices under the top half of the soft pillow-y bun. At first bite it was perfectly cooked w/hints of red meat mingling with clear juices & the melted Tillamook cheddar. Put a dollop of Fork's burger sauce on that bite & it's OH SO effen GOOD! The burger came with a side of these Rosemary/Parmesan fries that the wife & I shared. She really liked them, but for me, though hot & gave off the aroma of rosemary, they were "dry" as if baked rather than fried in oil. The powdered parm cheese that lined the fries left a chalky aftertaste in my mouth that I didn't care for. HINT: It's better when dipped in the Fork burger sauce, yo! So ask for more. I washed it all down with my 2nd beer, the Sockeye Dagger Falls IPA (by Sockeye Brewing Boise, ID).

Steve never left us wanting & always kept our water glasses topped off. All in all, this was a solid dining experience & is on my list of places to revisit when back in the Boise area. Nicely done FORK, you've made a loyal customer out of me! 4.5 Stars!

Eat well & drink responsibly...this has been another deez® review because you need it & want it. Enjoy the day.', "I'm going to be honest, while the ambience was fun because it was packed, this wasn't a love fest for me.  We stopped and had 2 drinks and deep fried asparagus, which was delicious.  Our drinks however, were smaller shots so we weren't impress.  We decided to cut our losses and head out to try a different restaurant. The price were great and we can check it off the list for awhile."]

name: Western Passport Center
categories_raw: Passport & Visa Services, Travel Services, Hotels & Travel, Public Services & Government
categories: ['passport & visa services', 'travel services', 'hotels & travel', 'public services & government']
top_reviews:
["I don't think I've rated a government office on Yelp yet, but this was such a great experience, I'm giving them 5 stars.  The building is a one-block walk from my office, which was a really great surprise.  When I got there, everyone from the security guards to the passport clerks were friendly, courteous, and professional.  Total time was about 20-25 minutes over three visits.  Even though it cost $95 extra to expedite, I walked back and had a new passport two days later.  Highly recommended!", "My wife and I booked a trip to Greece to see family. The night before the trip she got online to check-in and realized that her passport had expired a few weeks prior. We were not able to fly out, of course. That night we called the automated line and made an appointment for the next day at 10:30am. Got there at 10:15, was let through, waited in line for a while but once we spoke to the appointment lady all went extremely fast and smooth. My wife showed them her itinerary (from our flight that we didn't get on), paid $170, showed them her Drivers license and expired passport, and within an hour they had a new passport ready for us! We were really impressed with them. The only thing I'd recommend for others that have this issue, is to get there as early as possible so the passport can be issued the same day. As they issue passports at noon, and 2pm, so you need to get there at least 2 or 3 hours before in case something happens and there are others there. If you plan it that way, you really shouldn't have a problem obtaining it here as they are very accommodating, nice, and intelligent here. Definitely NOT your average government workers. If every department operated this way, we would be doing pretty great! Thank you again to the Western office for helping us. 

Lesson learned: check passport prior to booking flight.", "Oh NO! 
My passport has expired and we're leaving in two weeks. Even our vacation in Mexico now requires a passport for the boarder crossings and I don't have the small blue book that unlocks the door to the other side.
If I knew then, what I know now, I would not have panicked. What I would have liked to know then was that the Tucson passport office is populated by the most accommodating and polite employees I could possibly have hoped for. From the guards to the workers behind the counters everyone made me feel welcome with no disdain or recriminating questions concerning my need for an urgent passport renewal. 
The face of government bureaucracy displayed at our passport office is perfect in my opinion and I highly praise the employees of this location.
With an expedite fee the passport was renewed in time for our vacation."]

name: Mian Sichuan
categories_raw: Japanese, Chinese, Ramen, Noodles, Restaurants, Asian Fusion
top_reviews:
["A small, no-frills dine-in kind of place with a small selection of Asian noodle soup  - across the board different regions of China (ie. Zhajiang Mian, Chongqin noodles, etc.) and Japan (ie. Chicken with wasabi sauce, Shoyu Ramen). Also some Asian street eats, like fishballs on a stick, wasabi chicken, lobster balls, etc., etc.

On a quiet weekday mid-afternoon the restaurant had several people coming in to get take out orders, including myself. I ordered a Zhajiang Mian (after asking the lady owner if it was *authentic* - duh - like, what was she going to say, NO?), the much-hyped Volcano Noodles, a side of fish balls and the wasabi chicken.

While each noodle dish was around or over $10, with the current Groupon deal, or an Uber Eats discount for your first order, the prices were very reasonable. 

Since we didn't eat our food for over an hour after buying it, I'm sure the noodle consistency was affected. However, the noodle dishes tasted fine - basic Zhajiangmian sauce - not overly sweet like some places. The Volcano noodles were also OK, not overly spicy, and the portion is generous. Fish balls tasted pretty authentic (ie. Fishy, as they should be, with the right amount of springy texture, in my opinion), but the wasabi chicken seemed refried, though the flavors were fine.

Like others said, perhaps this new place is trying to find itself in the ocean of recently-opened noodle shops. Nothing outstanding nor the second coming of General Tsao, but a good alternative for a fast and tasty meal on a cold day.", "On the inside, Mian Sichuan is no frills, minimalistic, and clean. Don't let that fool you because their noodle bowls are the polar opposite. Mian Sichuan reminded why I have a love/hate relationship with carbs. 

They offer 5 noodle bowls: 3 soup-based and 2 noodle-based. All are meat based but can be made vegetarian with tofu. Good thing it wasn't busy because it took me 5 minutes to pick one. I had the vegetarian Dan Dan Noodle which is wheat noodles in a mild spicy sauce with sesame, ya cai, chili oil, green onion, and Sichuan pepper. I have a moderate tolerance for spice and thought it was more mild+ than mild. The sauce was more than just spiciness; it was multidimensional and packed a lot of flavor. You could taste all the individual ingredients yet they formed a cohesive sauce.

Definitely come here on an empty stomach because they serve a large portion of noodles. It's almost a fault because it would be nice to have a more balanced noodle to sauce ratio. 

Mian Sichuan broke the stereotype for oriental restaurants of having poor service and being dirty. The staff was very attentive, kind, and helpful to explain the different bowls. 

Elite tip: get the Groupon!", "I was very hesitant to try this place because I've become such a huge fan of Noodleholics, but I'm so glad I finally did. The inside of the restaurant is very clean, modern and comfortable. The employees are also very nice. I ordered the Chongquing noodles and was so excited that they had a vegetarian option of this as well as others. With this noodle being vegetarian, I expected small amounts of spinach or some other vegetable to substitute the meat, like so many restaurants do. To my surprise they added a good amount tofu, spinach and cucumber. It was delicious! 
The filling vegetarian options provided is why I gave this place five stars. It feels good to know us, vegetarians are given more than one option like Noodleholics sadly does. This might be my favorite noodle place thus far."]

name: HeeMee Coffee + Bakery
categories_raw: Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea
top_reviews: ["I'm 100% about supporting your local POC businesses, so I was beyond ecstatic to see an Asian-operated bakery open up literally two blocks from my house. Being Asian-American in Tucson, I would have to drive up to Phoenix to satisfy my Asian baked goods sweet tooth. Now I can cut that 2 hour drive out and substitute it in with a ten minute walk! \n\nWe went during their soft opening, and my friends and I each got a cold brew and three different pastries. I cannot remember what they were called, but I can tell you they were delicious. They're dense and light at the same time, probably from the gluttonous rice flour (I'm assuming, don't quote me ever lol). They aren't too sweet, and are unique enough that you can't find anything here anywhere else in Tucson. They also have patbingsu, which is going to be your life raft during the summertime. Think finely shaved ice with asian flavors. My review doesn't do the bakery justice, so go for yourself when you get a chance!", 'After serving in the military and being in Seoul, I am a huge fan of HeeMee Coffee & Bakery. The coffee drinks are very good. My son and I had the Dalgona Latte (hot although you may also order it iced) which has Korean toffee/honeycomb-topped latte. My wife likes her coffee drinks sweeter and ordered the Cookie Butter Latte: Latte w/ hazelnut syrup, cookie butter, and fresh cream which she really enjoyed. For breakfast my son and I had the breakfast sandwiches and my wife ordered the avocado toast. Everything tasted very well. HeeMee is very clean and the staff is reserved but friendly. We will be back in two weeks to order more drinks and buy more drinks and dessert to bring home.', "I'm gushing over HeeMee! Great coffee (Verve and Yellowbrick) and baked goods that take center stage! This family run operation is beyond charming. It's not a huge space (max capacity 45 people) but in a year or so the patio will be completed. For now, focus on the delicious treats! I've tried the carrot muffins, rice doughnut, chocolate stuffed bears, lemon cloud cake, and two flavors of the Bingsoo (Strawberry and Matcha).They also have mango and oreo. I love anything flavored in Matcha with red bean paste. So good! Bingsoo is EVERYTHING! This is Korean style dessert is served with super finely shaved ice. In fact, they  brought in a special machine called a Snow Van to shave the ice. It grinds to a super fine consistency, and by mixing it with a  touch of milk to it imparts a creamier consistency. I love this style of eating shaved ice! I'm already dreaming about my next pastry!"]

name: Clue Carré
categories_raw: Active Life, Arts & Entertainment, Challenge Courses
top_reviews:
["I am a dork who hangs out with a group of lovable dorks. One thing that binds this group of dorks together is our love of games. We have game nights on the regular, everything ranging from cards to puzzles to RPGs (yep, we're those dorks). One of our valued members wanted to try out the Clue Carre experience for his birthday this year. 'So we'll all be locked in a room together while we solve puzzles to escape?! Perfect!' the dork crowd rejoiced in delight. So we tried our hand at the Voodoo Room. Disclaimer: Some of this review may seem like sour grapes because we did not solve the last bit and did not escape the room in an hour. 
Would I recommend doing this? Absolutely. Overall, it was a fun activity to enjoy while doing something totally different for the night. 
What were my cons? Just a couple. This experience is for anyone and everyone. Do not be intimidated by your lack of problem-solving, puzzle crushing, number manipulating, or overall intelligence. You'll do fine. There are no complex things going on here. This kind of disappointed me. I was looking for puzzles and I got more randomness than I had anticipated. There are some 'puzzle elements' but nothing you need to rack your brain over. This was a con for my group. We overthink everything. The only other con I had was that I had anticipated more of a theatrical element to it: an explanation or clue given by an actor, an introduction with a back story of why I'm here...just something to satisfy my theater geek. 
That being said, this is a wonderful group exercise for friends, co-workers, dates, whoever. You will enjoy your time here and it is well worth it for the different experience.
