['This is a cool looking Nawlins bistro that has sidewalk dining and it's located diagonally across from our hotel of choice "Lafayette".

The were busy when we arrived just after 8pm on a Tuesday. The maitre de greeted us with one word "reservations". Okay, my response was a one word "nope" and there we stood looking eyes. You know what they say "the one that speaks first loses" LOL. She spoke after a long moment, not checking a screen or paper but simply with a "this way" .... lol I win.  To be fair I was hot, tired and hungry so after driving for 3.5 hours, navigating the nightmare construction traffic in New Orleans, checking into the hotel and trying to adjust to the 800% humidity that is all typical of Nawlins, I wasn't in my normally chipper and fun loving mood :-) 

The interior and the server were just fine but there was this guy who kinda stood around peering around the room was a little odd. First of all he was dressed in a formal black suit and looked like he combed his hair with buttered toast and struck me as a guy badly imitating an Italian used car salesman waiting for a bus. I mean he wasn't talking to the servers, chefs, customers or even fetching napkins, just adjusting his hair and clothes while looking at everyone and no one, like I said odd. 

We were hungry but we were going to turn in early for a 4am wakep to catch a train so we didn't want anything to big or spicy before returning to our room for the night. 

We both got waters and ordered right away. My sweetheart ordered the spring lettuces and fir me I ordered the beef short rib. The spring lettuces was small but okay but OMG the single teeny tiny cube of meat I received was not only comical but was burnt, flavorless and too tough to chew, seriously rediculous. I don't know why my phone failed to record the picture I snapped of that beef dig treat but maybe my phone doesn't have a sense of humor. 

We waited a little too long to get this meager "meal" and is was over $30 and as stated I was too tired to put up a fuss and just wanted to get out of there and that's what we did. What a disappointment because I always look forward to a culinary experience when I blow into Nawlins but this was a cruel culinary joke. 

Bottom line: They staff kinda act like they're a bit overwhelmed, the chef(s) are definetly out of their depth, the food is just plain bad, the portions are small and the prices are high. 
Fail', 'After checking into the Lafayette Hotel we ventured next door to this restaurant. They seem to be proud of their "French" cuisine, we shall see moň ami;-) ...... Okay, not impressed with the food. Service is very good but food is foo foo blah. My beef short rib was tough as leather, the horestadish cream was bland & palette was too. My honey had some very greasy "baked" asiago and while the lettuces salads were okay tye werr just play. Tje bread was pretty good though.
Nope, not a good place to eat.
The two stars are for the potential.', 'LOVE! 

Love love love love this place. It's modern, it's stylish, it's fresh, it's French fabulous. 

I love that they have a "small plates" section on the menu. The drink menu was cool. The champagne cocktails were the bomb & the wine list was fantastic! We LOVED all three bottles of wine we choose.
It was all fabulous! 

Hubby & I with two colleagues tried all the small plates. We ordered everything on the menu! The grouper was super fresh & cooked perfectly. It was a little bland for my taste but the greens that accompanied it were amazballs!  I did not get pics of the tuna sashimi dish bc it disappeared so fast! Lol 
It was fabulous :)' 

The house speciality dish, the spaghetti with the poached fried egg was as interesting to look at as it was to eat. Everyone's favorite. 
It was fabulous :)' 

The rabbit pasta was divine. The flavor of this dish was Incredible. I'm salivating just thinking about it. In fact I can't stop thinking about it!
It was FABULOUS! :)...

The service, the food & the atmosphere was superb. 

GO NOW! 
It's freakin Fabulous! :p']

name: New Orleans City Park
categories_raw: Arts & Entertainment, Active Life, Parks, Venues & Event Spaces, Stadiums & Arenas, Party Equipment Rentals, Event Planning & Services
categories: ['arts & entertainment', 'active life', 'parks', 'venues & event spaces', 'stadiums & arenas', 'party equipment rentals', 'event planning & services']
top_reviews:
["HUGE park with free entry; great for walkers!  Cute swan paddleboats available to rent, vendors selling food, and a lovely sculpture art garden.  My daughter and I were here on a hot August 2021 day but the greenery along the paths kept us cool and shaded.  There were a countless variety of ducks and birds to feed along the water.  The Dueling and Singing Trees were two of my favorite spots.  NOLA's city park is definitely worth the trip.", "City Park is one of THE oldest & largest urban parks at 1300 acres in the country andd you'll need an entire day to visit all that it has to offer ~ it's absolutely beautiful!!

Inside the Park you'll find: the Sculpture Garden,  the Botanical Garden, Couturie Forest and Arboretum, the New Orleans Museum of Art (NOMA), the Louisiana Children's Museum, City Putt Miniature Golf, Disc Golf or 18-holes of Golf, Storyland, Carousel Garden Amusement Park,  NOLA City Bark, Pepsi Tennis Center, Café Du Monde, Fishing,  Boat && Bike rentals plus endless amount of trails, bike and running paths, green space and many other hidden gems worth exploring.\xa0

We thoroughly enjoyed City Park, exploring the beauty within the city andd the peaceful moments we spent inside enjoying the Sculpture Garden, Café Du Monde, City Putt Putt Miniature Golf, riding bikes, the Singing Tree, this magical, unique oasis that was lined with hundreds of year old Oak trees and plenty to keep the day's adventure delightful and fun.  This is a MUST...so go explore andd enjoy!!", "This is the very best park in the entire world. OK, at least in the United States, from what I have seen of parks that are within city limits. It is huge. There is an equestrian area with stables of horses to ride. Mini golf and a huge regular golf course. Story land, the amusement park, botanical gardens. A sculpture garden, a children's playground, the museum of art, and a place to get Beignets at. For a list of things to do in City Park, here is my list of what I have reviewed so far: https://www.yelp.com/list/city-park-new-orleans-la-new-orleans-2 for just an idea of everything that can be done.

There was a traveling China Lights show that came to the botanical gardens last spring, the tulips that come up annually, and several festivals that the highlight being is that it is here. The fields for kids to play team sports is in one area. Tennis courts in another area. Celebration in the Oaks during the December holiday season with light displays throughout the park, and the highlight of walking through the botanical gardens and Storyland (for a fee) and ride the rides in the amusement park, ride the train through the park to see the lights. This is truly a magical place for everyone.

Oak trees that are hundreds of years old with the moss hanging from them. Picnic spots galore. Walking areas everywhere. You can take a guided tour on a kayak here. Wild flower area. There is just so much to enjoy here. It is possible to get away from the hubbub of life and spend a few days here exploring all that there is to enjoy about the park. If you are visiting New Orleans with or without children, this is a perfect place to go to get away from the Quarter or the other major tourist areas in town.

Parking can be tight during festivals, and often you have to park quite far away and depend on shuttles that are run ferrying people back and forth from the festivals. The only gender neutral restrooms are the port-a-johns set out by the park. I love everything about the park."]

name: Garden District Neighborhood
categories_raw: Social Clubs, Local Flavor, Arts & Entertainment
top_reviews:
['The Garden District was my favorite neighborhood in NOLA, and I should have stayed here instead of where I did.  They have great architecture and just so many shops and restaurants that are not as touristy as in the French Quarter.  The streetcar runs through there, too, so you can reach many other neighborhoods very easily.', "Heard in the news that they were pulling down statues of Confederate leaders, including Jefferson Davis.  Reminded me of the time I walked by the home where Jefferson Davis died, here in Garden District.  Hope they didn't do the same thing to Jefferson Davis's deathbed house  what they did to his statue.  

Made a reservation to eat lunch at the world famous Commander Palace restaurant in New Orleans.  Took the St. Charles streetcar from Canal street to the Garden District, walking to the restaurant.

After we finished lunch, got a pamphlet from the restaurant outlining the self walking tour of the Garden District.   

No, you don't have to pay for an expensive meal and meet the restaurant dress code to get the walking pamphlet, which are free inside the lobby of the Commander Palace.

One of the most prominent features of the Garden District, is the Lafayette Cemetery, opened in 1833, and filled for the next twenty years with yellow fever victims.   Hope they left room for the 513 who died and hundreds others still dying from the coronavirus pandemic in Orleans Parish.    

Homes of Southern belles and gents enjoying a host of lively social events in the 19th century, to Edgar Degas, Mark Twain and others.   19th century guests who visited such elegant home stayed for weeks.  Life centered around balls, theatre and opera.  

The Nolan family house is the nursing home where the Benjamin Buttons movie took place. 

Lots of homes with elaborate iron work trim, Corinthian columns, lavishly decorated inside, Victorian style interiors, Italianate and Greek revival exteriors, lush surroundings, or designed in free Renaissance style.  

Seven sisters row of shotgun homes, and servant's voodoo relics of skull and crossbones under the floor boards of another house.

Home of novelist Anne Rice in the New Orleans interpretation of the Greek revival architectural style of the time.  

Renovated carriage house well suited for New Orleans tropical weather.  

Governor of Louisiana lived here 1920-1924, where he entertained his hunting partner, Theodore Roosevelt. 

Cornstalk fence built around the Italian villa style house.  

Areas of the Garden District partially flooded by Hurricane Katrina. 

Famous residents  include Sandra Bullock, Nicolas Cage, John Goodman, Gloria Henry, Archie Manning, and Eli Manning.  Eli may be the New York Giant ex quarterback, but he lives here in New Orleans Garden District.  Given a choice, I too today may prefer living in New Orleans to New York City, epicenter of the pandemic.", "I probably will stick on touring with the audio version on this one. Definitely fell in love with the houses.. pardon me. The mansions. They are very driven in the olden days and my friend was excited that they filmed at the Benjamin Button house here. I don't know any of the celebrities names personally, but I do find that to be very intriguing that Nicholas Cage resided here. Anne Rice is another favorite public figure of mine and I thought it was refreshing to see where up close must she have grown up in. The most important thing is to really just look for a cheaper way to complete the tour. Otherwise, you won't have 100% to learn for yourself and create that personal experience like we did."]

name: Jason's Deli
categories_raw: Restaurants, Event Planning & Services, Delis, Sandwiches, Salad, Caterers
top_reviews:
["I havent been to Jason's Deli in while. I was coming from work when I craved a huge baked potato. I was not surprised by the friendly atmosphere as this location used to be my spot back in the days. I made a call ahead order and the sweet young lady who took my order, complimented me as soon as I walked in. The staff is always pretty sweet and friendly. My food took a few minutes to be ready, but with such great customer service who cares. My potato was piping hot and so was my alfredo. I love the fresh food and flavors they have to offer. There is so many options. I think they still do the free ice cream cones. I'll be sure to ask once I return next weekend.", 'The salad bar is tremendous. 

For $7.99, I did takeout and they gave me a "big ass box" to put as much as I wanted in the container.

By the way, those were the exact words of the cashier when I asked if I could do the salad bar to go. He was extremely accurate.

Found no lack of freshness in the items and was extremely impressed with the selection.

Apparently they tried to pull hard boiled eggs recently, but those are back out there after objection from some nearby USF employees. I really liked the whole green olives, that Asian slaw (Anna M. would insert a joke there) and their unique spin on potato salad.

I would endorse the wonderful Yelp Elite Diane G's suggestion of adding a little meat to the mix as well, as some sliced chicken or ham would be sensational.

As usual, timing is everything as some of these places. I was smart enough to attack the salad bar just after 5pm on a Tuesday when they were not as busy as they always get in the lunchtime window. 

Employees were not only helpful, but had a good sense of humor too. So, just watch out for the guy behind the main counter who looks like Shaggy from "Scooby Doo."  

This plaza just needs a second exit onto Fowler Avenue. There's no good reason why a plaza this large cannot have a second way out. Whomever designed that traffic pattern NEEDS to go back to USF for additional schooling.', "Jason's Deli is out of my favorite deli's. Their food is usually fresh and I've never had any complaints. 

This location is extremely busy, but I had to wait for 28 minutes for a soup and 1/2 sandwich. They really need more staff. But they did the best they could with the short staff, long lines , and phone orders. I was really patient too. 

The employees are really friendly, and helpful. The store is clean as well. This is also a really great location. 

If we're in the area, I may visit again."]

name: Luv Child
categories_raw: Cafes, Coffee & Tea, Food, Latin American, Mexican, Burgers, Nightlife, Bars, Cuban, Cocktail Bars, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["I'm happy the Ciccio Restaurant group rebranded the former Lodge spot as The Luv Child with 70's flair and Cuban cuisine! Luv Child is located on South Howard SoHo strip next to Wine & Wood, Casa de Monte Cristo, Macdintons SoHo, SoHo Saloon, Yard of Ale SoHo, Cheap, World of Beer, Dubliner, Bar Hwrd, Taco Dirty, Cask Social Kitchen, Shomi sushi, Koto Japanese Steakhouse, Bulla Gastro Lounge, & New York New York Pizza. I was initially sad to see the Lodge close. I really enjoyed the Lodge's sushi roll special on Wednesdays and their late night party atmosphere with red led lighting. The Luv Child brings an old 1970's vintage vibe with amber or yellow lighting, circular drop down lights similar to On Swann and M Bird, comfy vintage booth seating on the right side of the restaurant, vintage 70s disco music, and a gold disco ball. I'm really not a huge fan of the yellow lighting but it is something different and at least not crazy bright. On the Luv Child's patio, there is purple lighting which I much prefer over the yellow lighting. 

Luv Child serves combo plates, tacos, tortillas, sandwiches, and salads with your choice of shredded ahi verde chicken, Lima polla frita, herb marinated chicken thigh, orange mojo shredded pork, roasted pork ropa vieja, chimichurri toasted pork, grilled carne asada steak, grilled sustainable salmon, chickpea Rojas, toasted nacho mushrooms, and impossible burger beef. 

I got the chimichurri roasted pork, roasted pork ropa vieja, orange mojo shredded pork, and grilled carne asada steak tacos served with onions, cilantro, jalapeño, and home-made guac on a soft flour tortillas. All the tacos were pretty tasty! I really liked the unique and tasty meat marinades Luv Child chose!

My friend got the kale & shaved Brussels salad with grilled salmon, grape tomatoes, plantain croutons, Parmesan & lime Caesar and was pretty please as well. 

To drink we got the frozen traditional margarita, frozen strawberry margarita, the Aguila cerveza pale ale from Barranquilla, Columbia, and Paul Chenau's Lady of Spain Cava Spanish Sparkling Wine. The frozen margaritas were very tasty and quite potent! Drinks are a little on the pricey side but the food is pretty reasonably priced so it balances out. I was impressed that Luv Child had quite a large imported wine selection from Spain, Chile, Portugal, & Argentina and quite a large imported brew selection from Cuba, Columbia, Belgium, Italy, Mexico, and the Netherlands. 

Starting the week of Nov 19th, Happy Hour will be 3pm - 630pm on weekdays. On Tuesdays, Luv Child will serve  $2 cubano tacos on Tuesdays. On Wednesday's, ladies get $3 strawberry mojitos, dragonfruit margaritas, white rose sangria, and glasses of rose wines. On weekends during brunch, Luv Child will serve $3 Palomas and Mimosas. On Sundays, hospitality gets 50 percent off food, and 25 percent off mixed drinks. 

Our server was pretty friendly and knowledgeable in recommending items on the menu. It did take awhile to get seated because the place is new and very busy. It took about 10 minutes to order and another 10 minutes to get food which isn't bad. The kitchen brings out all the tacos individually instead of all together which is a little different but I didn't mind. I look forward to coming back soon and trying more of the meat options for taco Tuesday, more of the imported brews, and more of the frozen drink options soon!", "Came for happy hour which is 3-6:30 everyday. They have a $5 small bites menu and $8 drinks. They offer fresh or frozen mojitos and margaritas. I prefer the fresh. Had the fresh strawberry mojito and it was so good I ordered a pitcher after the first glass which was worth the money. 

Good size portions. Even the smaller sizes for happy hour were filling. The entrees (which I was too full and didn't order) were huge. I tried my friends chicken and rice burrito with some kind of avocado cream on it that was heavenly. The yucca fries were cooked well and came with two dipping sauces, one green one that was kind of spicy and a grayish one that was my fav, it tasted like kalamata olives. So good! 

The decor inside is so cute and it's a fun vibe and fun music. They also have covered outside seating. Parking is $5 valet. I would come here again.", "Super fun vibe here. I love love love the bright colors. I mean hello, we r in Florida!!! The fun upbeat music also makes me happy. Our lunch experience was awesome, and even better with the frozen watermelon margarita I ordered. That packed a punch for me big time!!

Sunday's and Saturday's are brunch days and there's a good mix of breakfast and lunch items.

We picked out two entrees - the Lima and the famorro. You're able to pick your proteins so we picked a chicken and pork. After 3pm, you pick two proteins. There's a whole bunch of options besides what we chose such as chick peas, mushrooms, and plant based chorizo. 

They have regular tacos and paratha tacos too, and you choose your proteins as well. I say go for the paratha tacos if either of those cross your mind.

This is a Cuban fusion restaurant with lots of fun and pizzazz. They also have happy hour with bites and drink specials in the afternoon after 3 til like 6 ish.  The nachos and, fried yuca, and wings were super popular.

Definitely check Luv Child out!! It's a blast!!!  If you do not want to dine in, you can also order online and save 10% on your first order and do take out!

Lastly, they have shaded outside seating and even better bonus points: dog friendly!"]

name: London Town Barber Shop
categories_raw: Barbers, Beauty & Spas, Hair Salons
top_reviews:
['My husband came home today looking super hot after his visit.  Best haircut ever. What else is there to say?', 'Found the place on Yelp, otherwise I had no idea it existed.

This place was pretty busy, but I walked in and got a cut from Nick. It was just as I expected, and more. Would definitely recommend. 

Cash only, like most barbers.', "Andy was my barber.  He's definitely 5 stars.  Everyone else looked cool and we'll experienced.  This is a great shop. I got my head shaved and beard trimmed.  Great Job Andy.  Thanks for the great service"]

name: Catty Car Corner
categories_raw: Soul Food, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['If you like cafeteria style restaurants that serve hot daily lunch specials, then Catty Car Corner might be a place you should try.  Located on Poydras Street in the ground floor of the Amoco Building, this restaurant caters to the west side of the CBD; especially to those in walking distance, as free on-street parking is nearly non-existent in the immediate area.  So if you are driving, try and find a meter, or simply go to a pay lot or garage. 

Although they also serve breakfast, I have never had the opportunity to try it.  However, I have dined here for lunch on multiple occasions and have never been disappointed.  The actual footprint of the restaurant is fairly small and the tables are very close in proximity to one another to maximize seating.  Furthermore, it's pretty loud in here.  But don't let that detract you from what brought you here in the first place; and that's the food.

Catty Car Corner serves 5-6 different hot specials every day.  These are comfort food at their best.  I can personally vouch for the baked chicken, the rosemary chicken, and the fried catfish. And the meatloaf is good enough that you may want to slap ya' momma when you taste it.  Furthermore, they have a damn good "combination " gumbo with chicken, sausage & okra.  These meals aren't for the faint of heart, especially once you add your 2 side dishes.  If you are looking for a little less food, try one of their salads (especially the Cobb) or perhaps a sandwich.

There is no table service here, only counter service.  Although usually crowded, the line moves quickly and the prices are pretty reasonable.', "Everytime I make a visit to City Hall or anything on Poydras I have to make my way over to Catty Car Corner.  If you in need of a hearty and soul warming meal at lunch this is the place for you. From catfish to macroni, to beans to salad there is just so many yummy things for you to get on your lunch break. You get enough portion that you could possibly let such a meal carry over into dinner.

Everytime I visit this location the food is tasty, well seasoned and just overall well done. You really  can't get any better.  The staff is friendly and they get you in and out so you can have a ample amount of time for lunch.", "This is a Mon-Fri breakfast and lunch establishment in the CBD.  They have a quick moving line with plenty of selection and good food.  The people behind the counter can be a little intimidating because you have to know what you want and place your order quickly.  Don't forget to grab a tray, and then after you pay, turn around and grab your utensils.  The baked rosemary chicken (a special) was really good.  I think their gumbo is Ok.  They have everything here from sandwiches to fried shrimp."]

name: Tampa Bay History Center
categories_raw: Arts & Entertainment, Museums
top_reviews:
["The Tampa Bay History Center is a beautiful  museum on Riverwalk with lovely views of the Hillsborough River. There are three floors of permanent and temporary exhibition galleries highlighting 12,000 years of Florida's history. The highlights for me were the following. 

1. The Touchton Map Library. It is the only cartographic center in the southeastern United States and has over 8,000 original maps, charts and other documents dating back to the discovery of the New World. Very interesting! 

2. The presentation of the Seminole Wars
from 1817-1858 and the Seminole warrior Coacoochee\xa0 was great with really cool special effects. The exhibit explores how African slaves worked with the Seminoles to protect the land. Really enlightening! 

3. I most enjoyed Treasure Seekers! You learn about pirates and privateers including thier unique form of democracy. This included the interactive
Pirates Fate\xa0 which is an 8-minute action-packed\xa0 inmersion\xa0 on the high seas with Pirates Jack Rackham and Anne Bonny. This is based on two real-life Buccaneers who sailed the Caribbean in search of plunder in the early 18th century. You vote on which direction to sail and you have an opportunity to fire a\xa0cannon at the enemy. I manned the canon and picked which direction to sail.\xa0Let me tell you, when the need arose,\xa0 I did not hesitate to fire that cannon and steal the booty!! Very fun! 

Terry Zitek was our guide and he did an incredible job!  We had a great time. You can really spend all day here!", 'The Tampa Bay History Center has quickly become my favorite museum on this side of the Bay, and it is a great place to spend the afternoon. The History Museum is located in a 3-story building right alongside the waterfront, and behind the Amilie Arena (AKA Tampa Bay Times Forum). The easiest way to get to the museum is to drive across Old Water Street, directly in front of the big Marriott and the Arena, and then follow the signs back around to the museum. There is a parking lot immediately adjacent to the museum, and the cost of parking is included with your admission fee.

For those who want to get out and take a stroll, you can easily reach the museum by parking your car in Channelside, or near the Convention Center, and then following the Riverwalk. The Tampa Bay History Center faces Harbour Island, and you can sit on their outside terrace at one of the umbrella-shaded tables and enjoy something to eat or drink in the fresh air.

I started my afternoon at the History Center with a stop at the indoor location of the Columbia Café for a 1905 salad and a cup of their very delicious Spanish Bean soup. My high-top table overlooked the Riverwalk, as well as gave me a view of their spectacular hand-carved wooden bar. WOW!

After lunch it was time to start exploring. The second level of the building is the first story of the museum, so after paying your admission it's through the doors and time to step back into history. Your self-guided tour begins with a look at Florida's first people -- the indigenous tribes of native Americans who had settled in our State. There's a very good movie which portrays the Spanish landing in the New World, and their interactions with the Indians.

Walking along past the exhibits, you'll be transported back to the days of the Seminole and Miccosukee Indians, and learn about their daily lives -- hunting, fishing, simple agricultural tasks, making baskets, and weaving blankets -- quite an idyllic life. As you walk through time you'll see more about the European explorers and learn about their less-than-stellar interactions with the natives. The need to conquer land for the Queen and search for gold seemed to far outweigh our ancestors' common sense. There's a lot of information about the various Indian Wars, and the story of the famous chief Coacoochee.

Next up is the story of tobacco, the Cuban immigration to Florida, and the development of the cigar industry in Ybor City -- leading to Tampa's nickname of "Cigar City". Very interesting displays about the cigar factories and the life of a cigar roller.

Up the stairs and the timeline brings us to the time of the Florida cow herders and crackers. (The term "cracker" refers to cracking the tip of leather whip in mid-air as they made the cattle mosey along.) You'll learn about life on the cattle ranches in the center part of our state. From there you'll spot the exhibit about Florida's citrus industry, and hear the story of growing, picking, packing, and shipping oranges, grapefruit, and more.

Tampa's history moves along quickly with stories about Italian immigrants and organized crime invading Ybor City, and living alongside the Cubans. You'll learn about the importance of the military in our region and hear stories of soldiers from the various wars. There's a great exhibit about the history of the Gasparilla Pirate Invasion, the impact of professional sports on the Bay area, and the development of the Tampa Port to enhance commercial trade. All sorts of little tidbits of history which kept me entertained for hours.

The tour finished up in the map gallery where you can visually see the development of various cities and towns in Central Florida through the changes in their city maps.

I was very impressed by the quality and the diversity of information shown in this museum, and will definitely be back. If you're a history buff then you might want to consider an annual membership which includes free admission, regular newsletters, and access to lectures and special events.', "We've been to the Tampa Bay History Center several times, for different exhibits and functions. We've always been impressed. It has a beautiful location, on the Riverwalk, between the Aquarium and Amalie Arena. You can walk to it from either location, or take the Tampa Electric Trolley from Downtown or Ybor City or parts in between.

The static exhibits are the discovery of Florida, with an engaging film when you first enter. As you move through each floor, you can explore the history of Tampa, and the individual influences contributing to its present: the Seminole Indians, cigar making, sports, the wars, and more. The visiting exhibit for now concerns fossils and artifacts. 

We enjoyed the interactive film about pirates, as well as the exhibit surrounding it. The pirate ship is HUGE! We also enjoyed visiting the replica of the cigar shop, and the room where workers made cigars. We did not ride on the saddles provided to watch the cattle ranching film, but we were tempted.  A family before us seemed to enjoy it! We did not eat at the Columbia restaurant, outside the museum, but we did shop at the gift shop which has lots of Florida themed gifts. 

Note: During CoVid, masks are required inside."]

name: New Orleans Botanical Garden
categories_raw: Arts & Entertainment, Botanical Gardens, Active Life, Parks
top_reviews:
["Came here by trolley from Canal Street next to the French Quarter.    Canal street trolley route still severed by the wreckage of the Hard Rock Hotel, so you need to catch the trolley north of the wreckage, about a mile from the center of the French Quarter.  

Leave your stilettos for the nighttime, and wear comfortable shoes, as we walked at least a half mile walk from the trolley stop to get here.

$8 admission to the gardens, located behind the Art Museum.  And right at the entrance is the obligatory gift shop.  If you don't want to pay the $8, you can see the outside Sculpture museum area free, and then wander through the 1300 acres of New Orleans Park, checking out the stadiums, ponds, canals.  But even a cheap skate like me can afford the $8. 

Some magnificent vistas, walkways, arches, architecture, and water fountains.  Came here in January 2020, so no roses in bloom.  Wife thrilled by numerous butterflies in the butterfly garden area, the Japanese garden, and the greenhouse full of cactus, making it worthwhile for one of us.   

Highlight of the day for me was seeing the New Orleans historical train garden, with a circular track running maybe 150 feet through miniature sections of New Orleans, complete with houses, buildings, water towers, railway stations, restaurants, and vehicles stopped at the railroad gates.  At least they have the track laid out.  The only train cars we saw were a stationary few, 1/22 scale,  permanently mounted on the side tracks.  We didn't see any trains on the main tracks, let alone trains running today.  

Was told that the train runs on weekends, before the pandemic hit.   The city has apparently cut back on garden maintenance, due to the pandemic, so some of the lawns and nurseries are starting to look a little ragged with weeds, just like my back yard!

$8 admission fee waived on Wednesdays, but for locals only!", "One of the many great sights in City Park, so you might as well visit while you're spending the day there. My favorite part of this beautiful garden was The Flute Player by Enrique Alférez, the Mexican-born Louisiana artist. They have many of his other works throughout the garden, so take some time and find your own favorites. The garden also has a pretty impressive miniature train exhibit and succulent hall. Pretty cool!", "The botanical gardens are such a peaceful and calming experience if you go towards closing time and not first thing in the morning. I personally think you only need about 1.5 hours to take your time and explore the grounds. I am wanting to bring a book or laptop work so I can enjoy the scenery one day.

From venue spaces, to botany, to a open wood fired kitchen pizza, there is so much here! Entry was about $8 per adult and they sell alcohol. Gotta love New Orleans right??

I love the sloth like fish that's indoors. Quite a bit of nooks and crannys here to explore.

I recommend being aware of your shoes in case you go the day of or after it rains.

Plenty of photo opportunities and you'll see folks getting their pictures taken."]

name: Cappy's Breakfast Cafe
categories_raw: Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
top_reviews:
["In my never ending quest of trying new breakfast spots in town, I came across Cappy's. I am pretty sure they recently opened cause I have not seen this place until today. The vibe is a small hometown breakfast diner, which is my favorite. We came in and were told to seat ourselves and quickly had drinks in front of us. Me and my two guests order pretty much the same thing with just different variations, Cappy's Breakfast Plate. Basically you get homefries(or in my case hasbrowns) onions and green bell peppers, with your choice of meat mixed together, with your eggs and toast on the side. The food came out very quickly and it was delicious. I want to come back yo see how their chorizo and eggs is. This is a nice new addition to the diner market here in town, give it a try!", "I was hungry and this place has amazing reviews!!!

+++ mom and pops. I love these little places because it is littered with regulars, and that alone tells me this place is bangin'.

+++ service. I always appreciate the waiters and waitresses in a place like this. It is always fast, friendly, and they make great recommendations. 

+++ Cappy's huge country steak.  Idk who Cappy is...but damn, his meat is huge!!! (See pic.)  The meat takes up about 83.572% of the plate and the quantity of the gravy they put on it is massive. Did I finish it? That's none of your business.  

+++ the toast. They have rye bread!!!! Idk about you...but when a place butters my bread, I'm all about it. They put a lot of butter on it...get extra napkins though. 

When I come to Tucson, I'm coming back.", 'Breakfast can be a bit tough on a Sunday morning; the first place we went had a huge line, the second place said they had a 25-30 minute wait. We called here and were pleasantly surprised when they said they had no wait. The service was pretty spot on, they kept the coffee cup full  We all ordered something different, unfortunately everyone was so hungry, I could only get a photo of mine. Would definitely go here again if in the area.']

name: Louisiana State Museum - The Cabildo
categories_raw: Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Public Services & Government, Arts & Entertainment, Museums
top_reviews:
['I was lucky enough to find a couple minutes to stop by the Louisiana State Museum and take in some New Orleans history. I visited both museums and really enjoyed learning about the history and background to this beautiful city. Situated right in the middle of Jackson Square, I explored the museum while I heard a street band performing jazz just outside the window. It made for a very authentic experience! The museum entrance fee is only about six dollars and worth the ticket price if you are a fan of history. You can get a discount if you buy a ticket to both museums at the same time.', 'This Cabildo was built under Spanish rule between 1795 and 1799, after the previous structure burnt to the ground. It was designed by Gilberto Guillamard, who also designed St. Louis Cathedral and the Presbytére, both literally next door and all part of Jackson Square. The Cabildo was the site of the Louisiana Purchase in 1803, which doubled the size of the United States. Fr 1803 to 1853, it was the site of the Louisiana government. After that it became the location of the Louisiana Supreme Court, where the Plessy v. Ferguson case was decided. 

In 1988, the building suffered fire, but was then restored using 600 year old timber techniques.', 'If an atrium busting with old white guy lawyers doesn't tickle your fancy, the Louisiana State Museum can help. We held our kick-off reception here for a conference, and The Cabildo kept the entertainment lively when the lawyers couldn't. 

We sipped on wines and bourbon, snacked on hors d'oeuvres consisting of pancake-sized silver dollars with jam and steak; tuna; and salad cups, and had the run of the place while lawyers babbled in the background. 

The Cabildo has a fantastic spread of Louisiana history that is easy to read and often tangible. Dining room sets from our founding fathers, paintings of the Purchase, letters to and from good ol' Napoleon, and... DEATH MASKS. In the immortal words of Kanye West, "That sh!t kray." 

I can guarantee no matter how bored your kids are when you drag them here, or how little your boyfriend or husband cares about history, they will find the death masks cool as hell. BTW, Old Nappy had a ginormous head for being a midge. Me thinks the plaque adjacent to the bust explaining a bamboozle involving the mask actually being formed from the head of Napoleon's doctor may just be the final answer. 

History is cool, Southerner history is way cooler and the Louisiana State Museum does it right.']

name: Discount Tire Town
categories_raw: Automotive, Tires
top_reviews:
['Why 5 stars? Because this process could not possibly have been easier.

   ---   ---   ---

Okay, I guess it *could* have been easier. The guys who work here could have come to my house and paid me for the right to fix my tire. But that's the only way.

My tire light had been coming on every week or two, which would result in me feeling up each tire with air until the light went back off. I wasn't even sure which tire it was. So after it came on again, I took it to a tire shop near my house and the guy identified the problem tire and said the tread was too low to patch it, so it would cost me about $100 for a new one. He also said that it would be about 2.5 hours before they could have it ready. That just felt a bit off to me, so I went to get a 2nd opinion at Discount Tire Town since they had such amazing reviews.

Here's how that played out:

I pulled up, gave them the story and they started checking the pressure of each tire. They quickly identified which one was the problem tire and the owner (I presume) asked if I just wanted air in it or if I wanted to fix it. I said - fix it, if you can. He nodded and put it up on the jack.

I went over and sat down on one of the chairs and pulled up an article on my phone to read while I waited. I literally got through two short paragraphs, when the owner walked back over to me and said, "It's gonna be 8 dollars, will that be cash or charge?"

$8 instead of $100. 3 minutes instead of 2.5 hours. Hilarious. Almost too good to be true, but I am a first-hand witness to this sorcery.', "The absolute best experience I could have asked for! I about damn near cried when I found a HUGE screw wedged in my tire tread. From past experiences, dealerships and repair shops have put me in a place where I could only buy a new tire (if the others were new-ish) or replace all 4 with having a screw/nail of this size. I read the reviews on Discount Tire Town and decided to give it a go since it's in my neighborhood. I figured in the worst case they could sell me a used tire that would hold me over until I get a new car. I pulled up around noon on a weekday and the gentlemen working were so quick to help me. They plugged my tire in about 5 minutes flat, right in front of me. No line, no wait. Upon asking how much I owed them....$5!!!!! I had to double that for the kindness they bestowed upon me. Excellent place to go if you find yourself needing some help with your tires. At no point did these great guys try to sell me anything. They are a legit business, operating in people's best interest. I will 100% give them my business next time I need tires or have an issue with mine. I wish I could give them extra stars!", "Honest and affordable! Referred to them fr a friend. Thought I needed a new tire, only needed 1 used 1 since I had a flat fr a bad patch work job, called they had my size. Came in, Monty looked at it, fixed the patch for $8 and said I didn't need a used tire for $40. I liked his honesty I am coming bk."]

name: Slice & Ice
categories_raw: Fast Food, Sandwiches, Shaved Ice, Food, Restaurants, Pizza
top_reviews:
["What more could one ask for pizza delicious french fries and ranch to die for yes this place has it all it's quick simple delicious!!
After reading the reviews about who is the original owners are I knew I had to come and try them out and I was not disappointed and neither will you be.
The portion sizes are plenty definitely enough for today share I have to snack special which was a mere six dollars for half a pizza and a box of fries.
And if you're thirsty they have flavorful ice similar to Italian ice although you can drink it through the straw it's a little bit thinner. 
Great place for you, family and friends y'all will for sure  enjoy it. They offer sandwiches pizza and french fries what more could one ask for, looking forward to coming back they've gained a loyal customer for sure!!", "Their pizza is crisp, fresh and delicious! If you prefer a thinner-crust pizza like I do theirs is great -- and they're open for take out during lockdown. We've gotten take out twice now and each time I've been left happy and full. Their pepperoni pizzas come with one big pepperoni on each slice. It doesn't look the prettiest, but the flavor is there and it's the perfect ratio of toppings to pizza, even if it doesn't look it. 

Today we got two pepperoni pizzas and ranch fries for about $18. Last time, we got a pepperoni and a Hawaiian. Both are great. We always order a large pizza for each of us and it's the perfect amount of food. 

Their large isn't as large as other places, so plan for that if you're hungry. If you're hungry sharing a large probably won't be enough. Their ranch fries were pretty good as well. They use some sort of bacon bits type of topping it seems as opposed to real bacon but I like it.", "Nice and airy inside with lots of windows, a nice simple menu with pictures makes it very inviting!  We went the 2nd weekend they were open, and surprisingly, it wasn't super busy.  I ordered a tuna salad for myself, the snack box cheese pizza for my grandson, and my husband had the pepperoni pizza and fries.  We also tried the eegees lemon/lime and strawberry/lemonaide drinks - I wasn't as fond of the drinks as I am of the regular eegees drinks, they were less sugary, and I do love my sugar!  The sandwiches looked great in the pictures, I didn't see that anyone ordered one.  Everyone seemed to be having pizza.  The fries were exact eegees fries and the ranch, best fries in town!  The pizzas were thin crust and had a good crisp to it, the pepperoni was big and thin, just the way I like it!  My tuna salad was the perfect size, and tasted great with the Italian dressing, there were pickles in the tuna, pepperinis, tomato and lettuce - perfect!  I love the big pictures of pizza on the tables!  This place is dangerously close to my house, it will for sure be a regular stop!"]

name: Mai Thai
categories_raw: Thai, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['264th reviewer of Mai Thai, Downtown Boise, Idaho. 
This is my 378th review on Yelp! I love Yelp! It's helped me find amazing places like this and amazing people like you! 

Happy Hour 5/5
Healthy Choices 4/5 (based on happy hour menu only) 
Bar 5/5 EASY!
Seating 3/5
location 5/5
Price 4/5
Overall diversity and comfort level 5/5

Wow! What a good time! I've been wanting to try this place for some time and tonight I finally did! Yay! I'm a SUPER fan and will visit again soon, tomorrow perhaps?!?

Walking in, I was nervous because I didn't have reservations and I looked at other reviews on Yelp using the keyword "Happy hour" and it was very clear that I needed reservations. I walked in about 5 pm and I was the only person there, which allowed me to look around and take some photos. Beautiful-- period. Shortly thereafter the people rolled in, and rolled in, which was an ah ha moment! Get there early! The crowd was all over the place, which as a sociologist I loved. People are beautiful and amaze me! This is a smaller establishment and they do their best with space. Look up at the fans--- never seen that before (look at my video). 

Being a single dad of 4 I've recently learned that Happy Hour is a way to get what you want, and pay half the price and Mai Thai didn't disappoint. 
The waiter was very nice, knowledgeable, and receptive. 

Happy Hour is 1/2 price apps and BOGO drinks! You must sit in the bar area for Happy Hour, but there are over 10 tables, one booth and ample seating at the actual bar. You just can't sit in the dining room. 

This is what we ordered:

Portobello Tempura Mushrooms ($6 happy hour $12 regular) A++ 
Huge chunks of Mushroom tempura covered and fried. Served with Sweet Soy sauce. Epic!

California Roll--  ($5 HH $10 reg) These rolls were wrapped very tightly and big chunks with quality ingredients-- another A+ Ordered two of them! Classic Kani and avocado roll with sesame and cucumber. 

Thai Chicken Satay's with a peanut sauce ($6 HH $12 reg.) 3/5-- not my favorite, but good nevertheless. 
_________________________________________________________
********* DRINKS************
Full bar-- bartenders are true mixologists! Their menu has lots of signature drinks and lots of different expirimental drinks. 
Again, BOGO. I ordered:

First was Spiced & Iced-- Markers Mark, Averna, Amarula, Thai Chili Honey, Mint, Thai Iced Coffee and vanilla whip. This was really good, but has a little spice to it, which is good-- just beware. 

Should I get another? Of course, I should because it's free! BOGO ... 
I couldn't decide between the house Mai Thai or the or the smoke show. I asked the waiter and he was 100% invested in the smoke show, which is: Bulleit, rye, Benedictine, Peychaud, burnt pineapple, with baked pinecone smoke. When it was brought over you could smell the smokiness... mmmm it was good n strong. 

Well, thanks for reading. I hope you get to enjoy Mai Thai and have the most amazing day ever! Thanks for reading!', '2nd visit in one week-- downgraded to 4 stars. 
I made a reservation for 10 pm and in the special instructions, I requested seating at the bar so that we can enjoy the late night happy hour. I got a call at 8:45 pm and was told that reservations can't be held for the bar or happy hour. I get it, but at least allow us to sit in the dining room... 

I went there anyway and sat at the bar with 4 friends. It was hard to talk to them. The dining room, 5 feet away, was nearly empty. 

Additionally, I took a sip of my partner's drink and the bartender told me they would have to charge us separately next time as there is no sharing, the BOGO drinks are per person-- I get that, too, but it was a drink-- I didn't take a whole glass...  

Lastly, you can't use the 10% check-in offer on happy hour. Again, another thing that I understand, but they really should list that. 

So, 2nd time wasn't as good as the first. However, I understand all of the "rules" they aren't necessarily "customer" focused. 

I wanted to bring attention to their Buffet. This is taken from their website: It includes a rotating menu of fresh-cooked items but always includes stir fries, noodles dishes, rice dishes, curries, vegetarian entrées, sushi, soup, appetizers, and salad. All of this for $11.99!', 'This is a great spot for bigger groups! Vegan, vegetarians, and omnivores all have great options here! We had a reservation for 6 and they sat our party in their back room, very private with a cool vibe! I would book again for any other type of big work, family, or friend dinner! 
While at Mai Thai's, we had to get the Mai Tai! Very delicious and in a really cute tiki cup. Sooo good, I think almost everyone at our table (including me) had two of them. 
The vegan in our group ordered the Verisoy Thai Basil Pad Kra Pao. Our server noted "I know it looks like chicken but I swear it's not!" when they brought it over. This dish is also Gluten Free! In Boise, a GF Vegan option is hard to come by so if you've got hard dietary restrictions this is your best bet. 
We also ordered the Drunken Noodles- Phat Khi Mao. This dish is GF and you can add any sort of protein, and we ordered it with chicken. All good stuff! 
I ordered the papaya salad, which came with a side of their sticky rice! It was fresh and very yummy. My only issue was that there were large chunks of garlic and whole green thai chilies. The thing with the thai chilies is that there were also little green beans in this dish, and I bit into a thai chili thinking it was a green bean. I had to spit it out in front of some work colleagues, I felt very rude doing so but everyone was obviously understanding. 
I would honestly order the papaya salad again, regardless of this chili and whole garlic incident because other than that it was really good!']

name: One Day Nail and Spa
categories_raw: Beauty & Spas, Nail Salons, Day Spas
top_reviews:
["WOW!  This place is absolutely amazing!!  I hesitated to write this review because it seems like they are getting a lot of attention and I want them to succeed but I also still want to be able to get my nails done.  Anyway if they continue running their business the way I saw them when I went there is no need to worry.  
After not being able to get in to my regular nail place -  at the last minute on a Saturday - I started looking around for what I thought would be a temporary one time visit somewhere else.  I just got back into town and desperately needed a mani/pedi otherwise I wouldn't have even bothered.  I found a few places on here and for some reason this one caught my eye even though it was the furthest one from me.  I called them up and asked for an appointment later in the day and the woman, might've been the owner, immediately said yes but then asked if I wanted to come in right then instead. Yes!  I showed up to the salon and took one of the few seats open, questioning why the woman would have asked me to come in then when they were clearly busy.  Eventually  the same lady came over and when I told her what I needed she asked if I had called and then quickly got me a pedicure chair ready.  She essentially is like a hostess at her shop and keeps everyone moving in a pretty smooth motion.  She greets everyone warmly, guides them to choose colors and chairs and circles around to see who she can move next, takes payments and again gives a friendly goodbye and starts all over.  She checked in a couple of times to see how my pedicure was going and then to comment on my mani color.  Very impressive!  
As if that wasn't enough, I would easily pay double their very reasonable prices for that pedicure alone!!  Even in that bustling atmosphere it was so relaxing and just mesmerizing.  There's a soak, scrubs, hot towels, massage - the works!  I opted for the basic gel mani/pedi combo but now I can't wait to go back and see what the deluxe version offers.  The employees all worked at a steady pace and although there were people coming and going constantly you never feel rushed, the scrubs and massages are thorough and the color is flawless.  I am not one to jump around from salon to salon, I like to find a place I enjoy and stick with it and while I have frequented my favorite place for a few years now they have unfortunately gotten more popular without the staff to support them so it is harder and harder to get an appointment and walk-ins are no longer an option.  This salon has plenty of staff plus did I mention the pedicure??!  I think I found a new spot.", "First time coming here visiting in town and I'm impressed! Booked with Pam (owner) for a full set because of all her reviews. I wanted a reverse french ombré, and I'm pretty sure she questioned why I wanted white at the bottom instead of pink but I wanted to try it out. I was very pleased with how it came out! She constantly asked me if I liked each step she was doing, always saying that if I'm happy, she's happy. 

The salon was very busy but Pam never failed to make sure everyone had a good experience and no wait time.", "I really enjoy this place. The staff is so friendly and they're reasonably priced. They do a hot stone pedicure for $25 and every time I have gone its been great. Their gel manicures are also $25. Also, every time I have scheduled an appointment they've gotten me in right away. They prefer cash just a heads up, but you can still pay with card"]

name: Sprinkles Tampa ATM
categories_raw: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Bakeries, Cupcakes, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food
top_reviews:
["A little pricey, but the frosting is where it's at.

I am a huge sugarholic and I love frosting. Cake has to be really really good to tickle my fancy, so the fact that these cupcakes are about half frosting really appeals to me. I have to be honest, I don't buy dessert that often. I have surprisingly strong willpower when I have to purchase something sweet. At home, where I have a ton of sugar, I have no willpower (I've already taken a break from writing this review to eat two types of Ben and Jerry's Ice cream and Ghirardelli chocolate). Now that I've tried these cupcakes, I'm pretty screwed, because they were a solid hit for me and I see myself returning every time I'm in the area.

I love that they have mini cupcakes and they are probably better for my waistline, but when I get dessert I go big so the normal sized cupcakes are for me. I did try the mini version of the red velvet and it was great. However, my love is reserved for the salted caramel cupcake. Holy mackerel was it amazing. Warning, it will give you diabetes, immediately. 

I love the combination of salt and sweet. If you don't love (like really love) sweet things, do not get the salted caramel. It is extremely sweet, but the salted part makes sure it doesn't get cloyingly sweet. If you like things a little less sugary, the dark chocolate has the slight bitter flavor of dark chocolate. For dark chocolate fans, like myself, it is a welcome relief. I've also tried a cookie cupcake and it was also exceptional - very sweet like the salted caramel. 

So, although I've enjoyed every cupcake I've gotten, I'm going to have to go back time and time again to the salted caramel. These cupcakes are about half frosting and half cupcake. This is the perfect ratio to me. I'm a huge frosting fan. 

The cupcakes are on the pricier side, but the way I can tell they are worth it to me is I would definitely buy it again. I will be back for my salted caramel cupcake.", "Have loved sprinkles since I first experienced tasting a cupcake from them in DC (Georgetown location).

They are insanely good to the point where I won't go anywhere else. First of all, can we talk about the moistness?! I hate places that make it out like their cupcakes are superior, when it turns out it's just a piece of dry ass cake and pounds of buttercream icing on top.

Sprinkles is none of that. Their cake is always moist, the cupcakes don't taste like a sugar overload, and the icing is infused with actual flavor and not just cloyingly sweet buttercream. 

I'm so excited the Tampa location is open! 
I stalked the website, found out when they had the flavors I wanted, and picked out four cupcakes. I got strawberry, banana, and salted caramel. The strawberry was divine, and I haven't gotten to the banana yet, but what I will say is that I underestimated the salted caramel. I'm usually not too fond of it anymore because that flavor is so over featured now, it's become pretty basic To me. But wow, was I wrong. I'm confident that is by far is the best cupcake they have! So moist, salty and sweet the icing and the sea salt flecks tied everything together in harmony...I'll  even admit that as a strawberry lover!

Please do yourself a favor and go to sprinkles!! Great location for a place like that!", "I'm happy to report that my fur baby Mocha Coconut loved his pupcake. He couldn't stop eating it after his initial lick. It was going going gone. check out the video of him.

I had my lemon blueberry cupcake and it was okay. Yes just okay. It honestly was just quite dry like desert dry not dessert dry. Not that great. The flavor of the lemon was only bc of the frosting. I think it should also be in the cake.  I was excited to try it and may give it another chance bc my pup loved his, but we will just have to see.  I honestly don't think I favored the flavor selection all too much either so ehh. Yep just ok."]

name: Psomi
categories_raw: Mediterranean, Breakfast & Brunch, Bagels, Restaurants, Food, Bakeries, Greek
top_reviews:
['I'm so glad to welcome Psomi Greek American Bakery & Eatery to the North Howard NoHo South Tampa neighborhood! I've been eyeing the construction of Psomi for quite some time in eager anticipation of its opening as I pass by the area often on my way from Soho to the interstate. It's a shame Psomi is only open until 3pm because they're closed most of the time I pass by in the evening and it's been a tough place to catch open. Psomi elevates the entire North Howard Avenue area with its brand new beautiful building and helps make North Howard no longer just an area you pass by on the way to the interstate. Psomi is located next to another new California style building, Clinical Research of West Florida, and is across the street from a recently renovated Bryan Glazer Family JCC Fitness Center.

Our server told us Psomi literally translates from Greek to "bread" but its essence refers to the best bite, the "choice" piece, the crumb that everyone at the table fights over. The Decor of the Psomi restaurant is very modern, open, and elegant with large slide out glass panels that extend the open air feel through the back patio and Greek wall art everywhere. However, unlike Acropolis Greek Taverna, off Kennedy, Psomi does not feature any live music, napkin throwing, or belly dancers. 

We came to Psomi for brunch on a Sunday and it was packed with an hour wait for good reason! Psomi is the new hot spot! Psomi's parking lot was full and 2 blocks of cars lined both sides of Cass street. Luckily, there was patio seating available for us to wait and we could order coffee or to-go items from Psomi's bar. Due to the ability to purchase to-go, our wait for a table ended up being much less than an hour, and only about 25 minutes. I definitely recommend making reservations in advance here! 

Our multiple servers that stopped by our table were friendly and knowledgeable but did not seem to communicate between each other as we had to tell 3 people the same thing of what we ordered and that someone already took our order. Once we ordered, food came out in under 10 minutes which was nice. We found it a bit odd that Psomi did not have the most famous best Greek appetizer on its menu, Baha Ganoush, but it turns out they just call it melitzanosalata and it also has eggplant in it. Unfortunately, one of our many servers brought the entree out before the appetizer so we just canceled the appetizer because it missed the whole point of being before the entree.

The Pork Gyro came with hand stacked pork, tzatziki, tomato, red onions, on a pita with some amazingly spiced fries that were some of the best I've had in a long time! The meal was filling and the pork was lean and not greasy. Aside from all the fries in a container, there were additional fries inside the Gyro too which I'm not sure is sloppy or meant to be a cool new thing. I'll give them the benefit of the doubt,and chock it up to being a cool new thing. The fries were so good, I don't mind getting more of them. 10/10 

The Chicken Souvlaki also came with tzatziki, tomato, red onions, on a pita with some amazingly spiced fries! The marinade on the chicken was very unique and good! 10/10 

For dessert, we split the baklava coffee cake. It was a pretty big serving enough to adequately split between 3 people, was surprisingly not dry, and not too sweet so I liked it. However, if I do order dressert, I prefer something with chocolate in it. But when in Greece, you gotta try theocal specialities! 7/10 

Although service was a bit off and the place is a bit pricier than average, all our food was really good and I really like that this place elevates the entire North Howard area! On my next brunch visit, I look forward to trying the Psomi bagel special with salmon, avocado, cucber, tomato, & cream cheese!', "I love this place! It's a gem located in an unassuming part of North Howard Ave. I'd say NoHo instead of SoHo but that just doesn't sound right. It's in a neighborhood that is part of North Hyde Park. Who knew? I'd never been to that part of Howard before and it looks like they are constructing new complexes in the area. It's actually starting to look trendy.

Anyway, I'd seen reviews from other Yelp friends and it just looked fantastic. I met up with a friend for my first visit. For your first time, I'd suggest going for breakfast on a week day. It's just not as crowded during that time and it makes it even more comfortable. It's counter service at breakfast. Just place your order and find a seat inside or outside. They bring everything to you once you're seated. The service has been outstanding each time I've been there. I tried the mama's baklava and the fresh fruit filled bougatsa pastry. I loved how the baklava had a clove honey taste. It had a great flavor and it was moist and not dry. The pastry was so light and heavenly. The fruit was perfect and not a single blemish. I was also loving the baklava latte with oat milk. We sat indoors for this visit since it was a very hot day. It was a very delightful visit.

My second visit was at lunch and the parking lot was full, as well as every seat in the house was occupied. More of a casual business lunch setting at the time. I ended up leaving and going somewhere else. But that didn't keep me from going back for another breakfast this past Thursday. I just had to try the BYO focaccia boat. I'm so glad I did. It's so unique and I loved the feta and mozzarella cheese mixture baked inside the boat. I decided to add an egg and their house cured smoked salmon. It was all delicious. The host noticed right away when bringing it out to me that it didn't have the salmon. He didn't give me a chance to discover that for myself which is great. He apologized and went back to get the smoked salmon. I'm kind of glad that it ended up being served on the side. I got to taste it separately and liked it better that way. The egg was good and you can order it cooked the way you want it. I honestly didn't need the egg. It was so filling that I just couldn't eat it all. It was a large bread boat. I also loved the arugula salad with a touch of dressing and sea salt added. I'd get this again. The double espresso was also a very nice treat. 

I didn't leave without getting some baked goods for the road. This time I got the plain bougatsa that is loaded with this amazing and light custard filling. The giant chocolate chip cookie was good but I didn't really taste the chocolate pieces. I could see lots of chips but not a whole lot of chocolate flavor. I'll get a different cookie flavor next time. Other than that, it was a fantastic experience each time. Especially sitting in the front patio in this cool fall weather. It's so pretty out there being surrounded by the beautiful potted bougainvillea. It was a very relaxing morning. Just try it for yourself one day.", 'Psomi is a GORGEOUS new bakery/cafe ("rooted in a Greek foundation") that just opened in North Hyde Park Tampa today, Nov. 4th. The concept melds Greek and American aspects while including influences from other cultural cuisines as well. "Psomi" literally means "bread" in the Greek language and this bakery/cafe offers much more than that. Being Greek American myself I appreciate the concept and design of the space.  

The space was literally stunning! The owner did a complete and extensive rehab/remodel and the old building was completely overhauled. The new space looked like something you might see in Greece quite literally. It is very beautiful and aesthetically pleasing! I cannot wait to dine here but for my first visit today I took some items to go after ordering at the cafe counter. There are baked goods for purchase as well as locally roasted Bandit Coffee (St. Pete). There is also full service available as a dining in option where you can sit in the indoor lit outdoor dining areas. 

The staff I encountered today were incredibly amiable and welcoming. I enjoyed seeing their menu items although today I only had time for drop in service. I have not tried some items I bought but I must tell you the "spanakopita" was excellent, fresh and flavorful. I liked how the spinach, cheese, and onion filling was nestled in a croissant vessel of sorts which was lightly sprinkled with sesame seeds. The delicate pastry really complimented the delicious filling. I cannot wait to dig into my tyropita which is a more traditional example of tiropita you would find commonly...a cut square of a mixture of cheeses housed between layers of phyllo dough. 

To some the price point may seem somewhat high however you are paying for great quality ingredients. I am all for paying more when this is the case. Psomi proudly uses local sourced and organic foods "to their fullest abilities" and the meats are antibiotic and hormone free. In addition, the breads and baked goods are made fresh daily! Check out the menu and give it a try yourself!

Parking is found on the side and in the rear of the building as well as parking on the street.

Enjoy!']

name: Leo's
categories_raw: Restaurants, Mexican
top_reviews:
["I had the chicken fajitas here. They were mediocre at bet. In a city filled with delicious Mexican food places this would not be among my top choices. It may look like an appealing hole in the wall, but you'll be disappointed. At least the service was friendly and speedy!", "This is one place I have definitely overlooked in the last few years. 

I'd been here years ago but it fell off my radar for the longest time... I may have even just assumed they had closed. 

Then a co-worker, who used to work close to Leo's, suggested we should get food from here.

Now here's where I'm going to be completely honest. With a lot of good Mexican food in Tucson, Leo's is far from the best. Don't get me wrong... the food is fresh, authentic,  unpretentious and still tasty. 

HOWEVER my appreciation for this place is in the people... namely Leo himself. Last time I picked up food he, himself, was working the front. We chatted a bit and I found out some about the history of his restaurant. 

He's been in business for 38 years so he is definitely doing something right.  I will always go out of my way to support a hard-working, local restaurateur like Leo, so you can be sure I'll be back.", 'I came here with some friends and agree that it is a bit of a hidden gem. The salsa is on point--perfect level of spicy. I ordered the cheese enchiladas and they hit the spot w/the traditional sauce. Their frozen margarita portions are very generous (maybe the biggest frozen margarita I have seen!) and their service is very friendly. Glad I was able to stop by!']

name: O Sushi Restaurant
categories_raw: Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Japanese
top_reviews:
['We (party of 2) went here on a Friday night around 7:45. Waited about 8 minutes for a table. Service was very good- we were brought complimentary edamame and miso, which was really nice. Ordered spicy tuna, salmon, Vegas roll, and spicy California. I also opted for gyoza since I really like to have something cooked along w my sushi. Super speedy and attentive service and the sushi was VERY good. Rolls were a sizable portion and well made. Boyfriend really enjoyed his salmon roll since they are usually quite small, but this roll was large and super tasty. I liked the ambiance; the restaurant was clean and upscale. Prices were extremely fair- we paid $44 for alcohol, 4 plates, and gyoza! Really want to return for HH. They seem to have daily specials as well. 

TLDR; Good prices, high quality, good service.', "Disclaimer. This is a great 5 star sushi restaurant for Tucson Arizona. 
I've had my fair share of great sushi. Living in LA and Hawaii, I know my stuff. This is definitely some good American sushi. Not too rice heavy and the service was great! 
Came here on a Saturday night and there was no wait but definitely people were flowing in. The tempura was a little heavy for my taste but it was fresh and the edamame was nice. I definitely appreciate the free taste of sushi that came with our meal, but it was a super American fried salmon roll. 
Nigiri was really nice. The tamago and the tofu skin was flavorful and fresh. The rice was seasoned perfectly. The rolls we got were also very good and not to rice heavy which I really appreciated. 
All in all, best sushi place I've found in Tucson.", "Its been a long time since I've found a good sushi place in Tucson. Lots of my favorite sushi restruants have changed their menus/prices/chefs/quality/etc. But I think I have found one of my new regular spots now! 

I ate here for lunch and got their lunch bento special with sushi and sashimi and an extra roll. I was super impressed! The fish was fresh, thick cut. The rolls were a good size and the rice layer was thin! 

The restaurant is small, but has plenty of tables (maybe not for large parties). When I went it was not very busy so I don't think it will be a big problem. It was clean and quiet. The servers were very nice. However for being one of the only tables in there, I wish the servers were a little bit more attentive. We were trying to flag down and find a server to help us. But once we found them, they were very nice and friendly. 

Environment:5/5
Food: 5/5
Price: 5/5
Service: 4/5"]

name: Tullia Salon and Spa
categories_raw: Skin Care, Beauty & Spas, Nail Salons, Nail Technicians, Hair Salons
top_reviews:
["A problem I face every 3 months is that my ends start to look like the bristles on a overly neglected closet broom... and every single time this happens I end up paying more than $60 pre tip for a trim.   Thankfully, I have finally found a solution to both problems. $30 gets you an(intern) level haircut pre tip which is PERFECT for me. It's so hard for me to justify paying more than double that at other salons especially when I am just going in for a trim each time. Jessica did a wonderful job, and I definitely will be a repeat customer moving forward. Place was clean, and service was top notch. 

FYI: I believe they used to be called Style 7, back when they operated behind Sullivan's. They have now moved a few spaces over in-between Sullivan's and Starbucks.", "I found my new favorite salon!
After a series of events, I had to leave the salon in town I have been going to. I was apprehensive to try a new salon, but my roots needed some care. Being a platinum blonde faker is a tall order, Especially if you've had the same colorist for a long time.
Nicki Attolia has completely perfected my blonde! She is absolutely adorable, really funny and amusing and best of all she is a damn talented colorist. I cannot wait to go back to her to get conditioning treatments, hair cuts and even more services from her and the other staff members. The salon had all walks of life from younger girls, older women and a fair amount of men as well. The staff was also friendly and smiley no wonder so many people came here. If you are looking for a new salon, Tullia is perfect and you must give them a try!", 'When I first walked in, the place seemed great and the girl at the front desk was really friendly. However, I sat down to wait and heard the word "cunt" loudly said from across the room. I was startled and expected to see a crazy customer saying the word. When I looked up, I heard some more expletives, though none as bad as that first one, and saw it was one of the people working there! I later found out that this lady was the owner (I asked the girl doing my hair a little about her). I was shocked that a place with such good reviews on here would allow the owner to openly use such unprofessional language, but hey, I'm a grown woman and I can take it.

What really bothered me was later on I heard this same lady yelling at one of the young girls who washes hair there. She was saying really degrading and mean things and didn't seem to care that her customers could hear it too. I saw the girl she was yelling at walk through the salon with puffy eyes from crying and she seemed totally broken and dejected. I gleaned from the girl who did my hair that this sort of thing isn't uncommon at this place and the owner often treats her younger workers with degrading and mean behavior and that gossiping behind other workers' backs there is common practice. 

This is a small thing, but I also smelled cigarette smoke really strongly when several of the employees walked by. It was gross and it certainly made me glad that they weren't the ones doing my hair.

Now, my hair looked great and I was happy to leave a nice tip for the wonderful girl who did my hair, but I will not be returning to this place if the owner thrives off of creating a hostile environment and degrading her employees. I think I'll try gadabout next time']

name: Kodawari Studios
categories_raw: Massage Therapy, Beauty & Spas, Massage, Health & Medical, Active Life, Chiropractors, Fitness & Instruction, Yoga
top_reviews:
["I have always been into physical fitness, yet have never been as interested in the practice of yoga. At the encouragement of my doctor, I finally decided to give it a chance. 

A friend turned me onto this place. Feeling a bit intimidated at first, as I have little flexibility, the staff put me at ease.  From the moment I walked in I felt comfortable and welcome.  I leave after each class so relaxed. I feel like I have had a massage after many classes. My mind is cleared and I am ready to focus on the day in a new energized way. This has been a worth while addition to my fitness routine. I now can't imagine not incorporating a class into my schedule.  The classes challenge my body in a different way than a run, spin class or weight class. The yoga classes broaden my mind  and  physically strengthen my body while increasing my flexibility.   

Annette has a great studio that offers a variety of classes through out the day.  You are sure to find one that suits you. In addition, the studio offers different workshops, events, massage and float therapy.  The studio also has a small cafe that I have heard great things about. I have tried the bulletproof coffee which is a combination of coffee, coconut oil and grass-fed butter. It packs a punch. They also have a nice retail area.", 'I've practiced yoga for a many years and have actually  been to this studio a few times, but unfortunately this review needed to be posted. 

Although many members are happy with this studio, I actually had to leave the class before it was over. Having explored the practice of yoga, breathe, meditation, and all the healing attributes that have drawn me to yoga, I experienced nothing of the sort in the class I attended. To say that the owner/instructor used the word FU$& more than 30+ times in her class, is not an understatement. She literally dumped all her bad energy and anger into her practice. Yoga is transforming, peaceful, healing, and a true spiritual practice. I'm not sure where the lines got blurred to a point that this is even allowed in a class, let alone by the owner. 

I even tried to "work through" what I was feeling, thinking it was a lesson I could learn from today's practice. However, every time I calmed myself and got back into flow, the word A$$, FU$&, and other negative words were yelled out by the instructor. 

This energy is the exact OPPOSITE of everything that yoga is meant to teach someone. I offer healing to the owner, because it's obvious she has much more to work through in her own practice and heart, but as a member, this is not the energy that should be dumped on ANYONE, specifically someone going to a yoga class. 

There is a HUGE disconnect to what is being taught in this class as to what a person should experience during their practice. 

I never write reviews but this was beyond what should be considered "yoga." The instructor could have gotten her message across beautifully in a way through light and love, rather than so much suppressed anger and pain. 

Please work through this before you continue to pass this energy to another member. 

We go to class to heal our bodies. We go to class to clam our minds. We go to class to clear out the noise, not to have the instructor consistently cussing. This is the number one indication of anger and suppressed pain. We are not there  to take an emotional beat down from someone who obviously hasn't fully dealt with some major internal scars, and who chooses the bottom of the barrel of communication to get through to her students. 

I coach women on wellness and self love, so please take this into consideration, as to how bad this experience was that I had to leave class, write a review, and also spend an hour in nature to release all the negative energy that was just spewed out by the owner. I literally felt suffocated when I left. NOT how I ever feel when I leave 4 of the classes I practice each week at other studios. 

This is NOT how yoga is supposed to be practiced.', 'I've been practicing yoga for about 4 years and a few months ago was making a move - within Tampa. I had loved my previous yoga studio (should write them a review, too! I never did!) and was a bit anxious, if I'd find another soulful place.  A yoga instructor from the previous studio mentioned Kodawari.. and from the first time I came here, I FELL in LOVE with it!!!! 

I never went anywhere else to "check it out" and compare. This was IT!!!! 

For me yoga is an all-encompassing practice - for body, mind and soul.  I love the community aspect of yoga studios (hence I am not a person doing yoga in the gym).  Annette, the owner, is awesome, welcoming...   Most of the instructors are. Marley and Annette are my favorite however. 

There are TONS of classes on the schedule and it's easy to find a class you'd like at any time of the day!  (which actually is even better in my previous studio)!  I highly recommend it. I thought I'd be driving back to my studio because I LOVED it so much... but energy, space, people and spirit are amazing at Kodawari.  

HIGHLY HIGHLY recommended!  I love most of the warm classes - flow, fusion etc.']

name: El Sur Restaurant
categories_raw: Restaurants, Mexican, Comfort Food, New Mexican Cuisine, Food, Tacos
top_reviews:
