As for the beers, they only have a core list of 6 beers right now. The best in my opinion is the Ramble On Raspberry Ale. All beers are low ABV and the IPA needs some work in my opinion. The beertenders were super cool and they offered me a mix of the raspberry and stout which was tasty. Beers are $5/$6. I'm excited to see what they offer in the future since i was told that they will have guest taps down the road. 

There was a food truck outside and i imagine they will have a rotating food truck gathering after their official opening. I also expect a larger selection of beers once they get going. I totally support this brewery, because it is the first in the immediate area and they have a large space to expand. Good luck 81Bay!!!!!", "I recently visited this new brewery. 
It's off Gandy. Its 81Bay. 
I sampled a few of their beers
But they were all just okay. 

The space they have is massive. 
Though, to me, it felt rather empty. 
But they've got these cool glass beer taps
Where the colorful beers did tempt me. 

Two of the beers that I tried
Were the Raspberry ale and their stout. 
While they both had decent flavor,
They were nothing to write home about. 

There was this really creepy mural. 
They project movies up on another wall
While I was there, they played Major League 
They followed that with Spaceballs. 

I appreciate what they have to offer 
To the Tampa Bay craft beer scene. 
But I have many others I need to try
Before I come back, if you know what I mean."]

name: La Indita
categories_raw: Mexican, Restaurants, Vegetarian
top_reviews:
['That was weird. Really. Weird. 

I haven't been to La Indita in a while, and I think it's going to be a while before I try them out again. 

1. It took a while for a server to come over. 
2. My two tacos were dripping with grease, so much so that if they weren't crispy I would have wrung them out to make them more enjoyable to eat. 
3. Nobody came to check on me until the very end of my meal so it didn't matter if my tacos were juicy for all the wrong reasons.
4. I had to wait ten minutes to settle up because my server was helping hang a new "Open" sign in the window. Ironic, because I'm closing the door on you La Indita. 

Strangest interaction:

ME: Can I have whole beans instead of re-fried?
WAITRESS: We don't have whole beans, our beans are sort of mashed up.
ME: Like re-fried?
WAITRESS: No, not re-fried, but that style. We start with whole beans and the chef mashes them a bit so some stay whole, some are more mashed than others.
ME: So can I just have beans that haven't been mashed?
WAITRESS: Let me see what I can do.
(times passes, food arrives)
WAITRESS: Great news, the chef found whole beans!', 'Yay! My belly is happy. My spirit is full. An economical date night with the honey featuring chicken enchiladas in green sauce. Yum. Complex flavors, not just heat, good refried beans and Spanish rice. Fresh and warm chips with salsa. Yes.

This place is the BOMB! I've gone there a number of times, once with my classmates towards the end of the semester and had a blast (food great also) and twice with the honey. 

Three words: chicken with mole. Five more words: Chicken Enchiladas with Green Sauce. Now sear them into your brain. Repeat several times so you remember to say them once you get there.

I have no idea what they put in their green sauce, but it is flavorful, not (hot) spicy but oh-so-indescribable. Crazy good.

The chicken with mole should come with a warning label:

"Cannot be held liable for the aphrodisiac properties of this dish."

I've only had chicken with mole in a few places which hold a dear spot in my heart: in DF, the Mission district, and here. Doesn't that tell you something?

Although I won't downgrade to a 4-star review, the service ranges from impeccable to bored. Also, the fly situation is off-putting, but it is monsoon season, and those pests come out of nowhere in the Sonoran desert. 

Otherwise, I highly recommend.', "I ate there with some friends from out of town, Why, Why, Why!!!!!!!  I told them this was a bad idea, but they used to live here and loved it (that was a long time ago).  
This place is tired and the food is gross, the beans were burnt and I think left outside for days, the carne asada was a grisly mess, like it was left over from the 1970's version of The Texas Chain Saw Massacre,  and they charge a lot extra for guacamole, if they had it.  If you care about your stomach, your life and your health, go somewhere else!"]

name: Das Alpenhaus Delikatessen
categories_raw: Restaurants, German, Grocery, International Grocery, Food, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Beer Bar, Ethnic Grocery, Bars, Nightlife, Delis
top_reviews:
['"I put my heart into this", said the owner to my husband and me at the end of our first visit to Das Alpenhaus when we went in to eat at the deli and shop the little market.  We could already tell that was so from the sparkling interior and delicious food made from top quality ingredients.  This won't be an often visited destination for us given the limited amount of seating and the distance from our home but it is definitely on our 'eager to return list' each time.  Planning ahead for your visit might help given only one hot dish is prepared daily and when it is gone it is gone.  No worries on that score though, because the soups, deli sandwiches and salads are delicious too.  So, here is what you might want to know before you go.

THE LAYOUT:  Sparkling and welcoming from the moment you walk in the door.   Seating for maybe six each at two picnic style tables.  There are well organized and stocked shelves of German and other Euro specialty items.  We were last in in November, and there were all kinds of traditional German holiday treats on the shelves.  Plus a great selection of luscious D'Arbo preserves - great for gifts or yourself are these luscious products from 5th generation family owned Austrian business!   Also a small section of beer and wine in an alcove - we bought a nice bottle of Alsatian Pinot Blanc.

THE DRILL:  When I was a little kid my favorite book (Mr. Angelo's Kitchen) was about a chef who cooked only one thing a day and then sold it until it sold out.  I was first intrigued to go into Das Alpenhaus by reading a review that said this chef did that very same thing.  

There is one hot deli dish made each day and served 'til sold out.  The menu for the week is posted on Das Alpenhaus' Facebook page if you want to plan ahead for your visit.  The weekly menu for those specials also appears on a menu board above the counter.  Given the number of local folks with German or Eastern European heritage who have already discovered this for authentic German cooking, the specialty hot dish is often gone before the end of the lunch hour.  And, no, you cannot call in advance orders for take out.  I asked.

THE FOOD:  Ingredients are top notch and so is preparation, based on our experience.  The owner brings in real German style sausage made by company in Seattle.  Also real German Style breads, like great German rye, from a German bakery in Salt Lake.  The ham and Swiss we had on rye bread with warm sauerkraut added and grainy mustard was among the best of all deli sandwiches we've had in Boise.  Soups are delicious too,  We highly recommend the red potato salad in the deli case.  Everything is made in house.

If I could wave a magic wand I'd have them sell hot German potato salad daily and also the braised red cabbage.  But those are only available as part of the hot dish specials on days when they are part of that offering. 

As heads up, this is a wonderful place for omnivores but vegetarians may find options more limited.

THIS N THAT:

1) PARKING:  Small private lot.

2) ACCESSIBILITY:  Minimal accessible parking but there is at least one spot.  Entry is ramped from the parking lot be level in at door and all one one level.  Ample aisle space.  Seating at picnic table ends may work for wheelchair users; I didn't check that.  Bathroom accessible.  Looks as if these accessibility elements were newly added as tenant improvements by the owners.  

3) NICE TOUCH:  German language / music station playing at just the right level not to compete with conversation but to know it is there adds to the sense of authenticity.  It made us homesick, in the best way, for the home of our German friends who hosted us at so many wonderful meals and spoke German at their table.', "Das Alpenhaus isn't just a German deli. It's a whole experience that everyone should experience. You've gotta love the adorable grocery store that has tons of European goodies and novelties. It's hard not to grab something while waiting for your food.

I'll keep this short and sweet because I could go on and on. My absolute favorite item on the menu is the Schnitzel Sandwich (thinly pressed pork cutlet, egg washed, breaded and then fried served on a pretzel bun with mustard, mayonnaise, and fresh cucumbers, onions, tomato and lettuce. $11.99). Holy schmoley this sandwich is huge but you'll want it all to yourself. The schnitzel is about twice as big as the pretzel bun. I was already feeling full even before digging into the pretzel bun. Every bite is heavenly!!! Perfectly breaded and fried. 

My other faves are the Reuben Sandwich and Bratwurst on a Brötchen, but I'm convinced you can't go wrong with whatever you get at Das Alpenhaus. Highly recommend!", "I had meant to check out Das Alpenhaus after hearing good comments about them after they opened last fall, but I just don't get out Vista way very often around lunchtime. Today, I thought of them and stopped in.

I knew from reading about them they prepare one hot dish daily along with their selection of sandwiches and soups. I went to their Facebook page to look up their choice for the week and saw they were offering Hackbraten and Salzkartoffeln, a beef and pork meatloaf with fried potatoes and a mushroom gravy.

The waitress standing behind the deli counter was friendly and asked if I had been there before. She explained their lunch offerings and I told her I had come for the hot dish. She prepared me a plate from the dishes held in a hot case, which meant I was seated and ready to begin eating in just a couple of minutes.

The hot dish of the day has a limited number of servings, so once it's gone it's gone. You have to come back another day if you show up too late. But their sandwiches and soups are always available. 

The meatloaf was tender and flavorful. The gravy, complete with sliced mushrooms was very good and there was enough to douse the potatoes in it, as well.

The shop also includes a grocery filled with German and other European foods and a wide variety of beers. A freezer contains a selection of sausages.

I read some early reviews that mentioned that seating was limited, with two wooden tables that could hold six diners each. Since then, they pulled the wooden tables away from the front windows and added several two-seat tables. There are additional tables outside.

The hardest part about dining at Das Alpenhaus is finding the right shop. Their road sign is easy to spot driving from either direction on Vista Avenue. But there's no sign on the building itself. 

The parking lot of the small strip mall the restaurant is located in is split by a curblike concrete divider. Das Alpenhaus is located on the north side of the curb and the closest to that curb. Look for the cold case inside.

I was very pleased with my meal and the service. Everyone was friendly. It's nice to have a choice of eating at another family-owned ethnic restaurant in Boise."]

name: Cielos
categories_raw: Restaurants, American (New), Breakfast & Brunch, Cocktail Bars, Nightlife, Bars
top_reviews:
["Our November 20, 2021 stay at the Lodge on the Desert brought my daughters and me to Cielo's the following morning. 

If I lived in Tucson, this place would definitely be in my Yelp bookmarks for its hacienda-style charm and interesting menu including the cocktails.

Our overnight stay at the Lodge provided us complimentary breakfast vouchers.

For our 7:00 AM meal (the earliest they opened), we all chose what our waitress described as a hot Mexican lasagna which came with a side of beans and seasoned potatoes. Before that we received a small bowl of fresh fruit and a muffin. 

The coffee was served hot and fresh. Replenished often. 

You'll enjoy your choice of indoor dining where the place is adorned with Southwestern art, large painted potted plants, and solid wood beams in the ceiling... or the pleasant outdoor patio with heated lamps and a fireplace in the chilly morning (and presumably evening) air.

I regret not ordering a poolside margarita and an appetizer from here the night before. Hope to be back soon someday.", 'I really like the food and the ambience at Cielos. True, they maybe a tad pricey but taking into account the whole "experience" makes this restaurant worth it. Went here to have a celebratory dinner with the fam and had a great time. However, Cielos is probably better as a fine dining/date night/romantic dinner spot. The lights strewn across the outdoor seating really ties the place together. We ordered the grilled lamb chops and octopus as starters, then scallops and short rib for entrees. The flavors were great but the portions seem small for the prices. But then I guess that's kinda how it goes for a lot of "fine dining" restaurants. Definitely a great local place though.', "Fantastic! I was so pleasantly surprised. My husband decided to give this place a chance and we enjoyed everything we had. I ordered the lamb chops and they were amazing! I couldn't believe they were only $17!! My husband had the pork chops. Absolutely delicious! I would return in a heartbeat!"]

name: Homewood Suites by Hilton Boise
categories_raw: Hotels & Travel, Hotels, Event Planning & Services, Venues & Event Spaces
top_reviews:
['This property will be our new "go to" when visiting Boise.  Friendly staff, clean and comfortable rooms and convenient location.

There were a few "hiccups" too and enough to mention them here to help set expectations. Somehow surprises don't seem as unhappy if you're prepared to think they could happen.   (The problems seem to be in process and procedure not in customer service training.  Process problems are easier to correct.)   In the meantime, by far the best mid range lodging experience of our visits to Boise.

The PROS:

1) STAFF:  Friendly and efficient at check in and check out.  Our reservations were all in order and we got the room type and location we requested.  Every staff member we met during our stay was engaged and courteous.  Very nice.

2) PUBLIC SPACES & EATS:  Large breakfast / evening room where breakfast is served 7 days a week and an evening "light meal" Mon - Thurs.  We never eat evening meals at a Homewood, but the breakfast comes in handy as they always have something that even we  who eat low on the food chain and eschew processed foods can enjoy.  If you're into the standard American hot breakfast as offered at hotel chains, you'll probably find this is one of the best offered. And the staff keeping all in order are so friendly and efficient.  

3) ROOMS:  Two room types here.  The "all in one room" and the "separate bedroom suite".  We prefer the latter.  Well laid out with spacious closet  near bathroom sink, spacious WC and shower room, living room includes desk and comfy desk chair, kitchen with full fridge, etc. Works well for an extended stay or a short one.

4) CLEAN:  Everything sparkled everywhere.  From public spaces to halls to rooms.

5) ELECTRONICS:  Free, fast, reliable WIFI.  Large screen, good quality TV in living and bedroom. 

6) EXERCISE: Finishing touches were just being made to the updated exercise room during our stay.  Three treadmills, weights, gliders, bicycles, etc. All in good working order and the room was bright with windows on both sides and with good AC.

7) LOCATION:  Easy on and off the freeway to get to either downtown Boise or Eagle.  

The CONS:

1) MAINTENANCE REQUEST RESPONSE: We had a couple of maintenance issues we noted on arrival in our room, minor but needing attention like burned out light in the kitchen.  It took two calls across two days to get it fixed.  On the second day no one answered the service phone after multiple attempts so we had to go to the lobby to re-report the issue. 

2) HOUSEKEEPING:  We recognize the tough job housekeepers have and try to be very tidy guests in return.  We also appreciate how clean were the rooms. But each day there was some "surprise".  As in fresh towels left but old ones not taken. As in finding all lights in every room and the ceiling fan in the bedroom on when we returned one night.  As in finding a cleaning bucket with supplies smack dab in the middle of the hallway when returning another night.  Likely could be solved by a supervisor walk through for reinforcing details for the young guys (at least on our floor) doing the cleaning.   They're working hard and I'm sure they'd apply the reinforcement of the basics.  

3) LOCK OUT SNAFU: On our third day we were locked out of the entry door on the wing of our building. In the rain.  And had to go to the lobby to have our keys reactivated.  On the fourth day the keys were difficult to get to work in the exterior door.  We talked to other guests with the same problem.  In the context of the world's suffering, think people living in Ukraine, we know this is less than small thing.  But hopefully it is a think they will fix. 

THIS N THAT:

1) ACCESSIBILITY:  All public spaces seem nicely accessible.  

2) ROOM TIPS:  The back of the building, the south side, is quietest and rooms there look out onto an open parcel.  Parking is also most convenient there.  As in all hotels, I'd say avoid the first floor rooms if you can.  A heads up that  the hotel is in the flight pattern for Boise's Airport and that seems most noticeable on the south side of the building.  

3) NEIGHBORS:  A few restaurants are nearby (like a BBQ place and a chain Italian) if that's your thing.  Costco is a couple of blocks away and a movie theater too.', "Absolutely the best place for a family to stay. Very clean, modern, and my children love the breakfasts and dinners. We love the separate bedroom, which means mom and dad don't have to go to bed with the tired toddler. 

Our go-to home away from home. The Homewood chain gets our highest seal of approval, and this particular location is fantastic.", "The facility is amazing. The  rooms are clean and the water pressure is strong and refreshing , showerhead are incredible. I slept like a baby. 

The Front desk staff upon check was great. She was helpful, gave directions to the room. 

Unfortunately, pot smokers set up next door  and not much could be done.

My biggest frustration is the manager at the desk. I went to your front desk to update my key and texted the staff I would be a late checkout and they answered no problem.

I arrived. A note at the desk said I am away and in the kitchen. My key was not working and I needed to get to a plane. I searched for the front desk person per the notes and looked in the kitchen and no luck.

When I cam back to the desk a manager and fd clerk were coming out of a back office. I asked to update my key and explained my difficulty with their note and my efforts to find them.

He decided to train a girl at the desk who was clearly having trouble, I waited and waited. l said can you please make a key I have to catch a plane. He ignored me. I waited and she was still having issues as he trained. I again hinted about my time and the plane. I waited as he observed and did not answer me. I said CAN YOU PLEASE train later I need a key why are you ignoring me? he didn't budge kept his head down. I  said can we trainer later?  He , kept his  head down , continues training and she was going very slow. I said please  make me a key now and train her later I need to  go!!!?

Finally he asked her to step aside and I, at last, got my key. I dont blame her but, at last, its  COVID1 time maybe 30 people in hotel and you have a guest in front if you in a hurry. It now angered me to be ignored. He apologized only after I  said I am going to write a review,  you earned it buddy.

Honestly, if a gueat tells you three times they are in a hurry, why not stop training and get a key made?

Could you not train and  practice without a guest waiting? How do you think she felt under pressure? What a poor decison to do with a Diamond frequent stay guest!!!

I would have rated five stars if it was not for that  idiot manager. Common sense knucklehead!

Add insult to injury they did not check out and I had to remind to send me a bill."]

name: Thai Cuisine
categories_raw: Restaurants, Thai
top_reviews:
["I've driven by this spot many times and somehow never stopped in. I'm so glad I rectified that on my last visit to Boise.

My mom and I were enjoying a day out together and decided to end the day with some Thai food. Enter Thai Cuisine.

It was the perfect spot to cap off our day. Their dining room is lovely! I ordered their pad thai with fried tofu and my mom had a noodle dish with a ginger basil sauce that she raved about. We also shared an order of their avocado rolls (fresh, crisp lettuce and deliciously fresh avocado with a sweet peanut sauce to dip in! So good!). My mom ordered and enjoyed a glass of their chardonnay. Everything we ordered was freshly made, perfectly seasoned, and piping hot. 

The service was a bit slow, but we chalked that up to what appeared to be an influx of takeout orders.

Aside from that, an exquisite experience from beginning to end. 

Get to it!", 'What happened here, I wondered, for a decline in food quality and other benchmarks that had once put this comfortably in 4 star rating.  I was told there was an ownership change several months back.  That would explain it, I think.  Once I would have had Thai Cuisine near the top of my recommended list for Thai food in Boise, which is frankly and sadly, pretty Americanized with the exception of two places.  Now I pass this by.', 'Like a great gift wrapped in a brown paper bag the building doesn't look like much on the outside but holds treasures within of Thai decor, friendly and efficient service and really good Thai food offered from an extensive menu.  For consistency in food and service this is at the top of our favorites list for Boise Thai restaurants.  

VIBE:  Serene space with Thai decor and music.   Tables and chairs down the middle of the room and booths lining the walls.  Tables can seem a bit tight when packed with people, as it has sometimes been during our visits,, but still it feels like an "all people are welcome" comfortable space even then given the standard height seating throughout.   

SERVICE:  Warm greeting and good service by friendly folks who can answer questions about menu items.   Even when packed with people the wait time from seating to order and from order to service is efficient.  

MENU & FOOD:  Extensive menu of Thai dishes including house specials.  They offer lunch menu from 11a to 3p with combination plates that run from about $8 - $8.50 and so prime time lunch hours seem particularly busy.

We always order off the main menu - combination plate diners R not US - which offers a host of choices from appetizers through soups, noodles, fried rices, curries and entree dishes. You can't miss with any of the Thai curries here, like red, green Panang, or Mussamman.   If you're a ginger fan try the Caramelized Ginger entree.   If I could wave a magic wand, I'd have them add Khao Soi to the menu. 

We order 'medium' on their heat scale and it works for my hubby and me if we're sharing dishes, although he'd go up a notch if left on his own.  The kitchen is very consistent in heat level so once you find the one you like it's a "go" each time.

Portions are generous if ordering from the main menu.  Plan on leftovers to take away. 

I so appreciate that they've picked a lane and drive in it.  It is hard enough to do one Asian cuisine well and so many Thai food places in the Boise area add in sushi or Chinese or Vietnamese dishes to their menus with not great outcomes for anything.  The focus is on Thai food and the outcome is delicious-ness!

PRICES:  Very reasonable for quality and portion size.  For example, $9'ish for fresh rolls and $12'ish for noodles and curries. 

PARKING:  Private lot.

ACCESSIBILITY:  Short ramped up space from parking lot to door.  All on one floor inside.  Ample floor space.  Standard height table seating and level in booths.  Loo is accessible too.']

name: Nico's Mexican Food
categories_raw: Restaurants, Mexican
top_reviews:
["Cheap, quick, and tasty Mexican food! The food is always tasty and fresh (except the breakfast burritos, bleh). This location has a drive thru which makes it very convenient.

My favorite items are the shredded beef tacos with the rice and beans! Everything always tastes so authentic and the service has always been very friendly and quick. I once got sick after eating a machaca and egg burrito, though, so I'd stay away from those! Otherwise, everything is always up to speed and the prices are very reasonable.", "I walked by Nico's Mexican Food when I was out for a stroll while staying nearby. When I did I was interested and filed it in the back of my mind to possibly stop in. I'm certainly glad I did. The inside is very unassuming but it works well. You'll find a very extensive menu board posted overhead and a clean dining area. I quickly found what I wanted and ordered to go.

I ordered two bean burritos without cheese. I'll put my disclaimer here if anyone is mostly plant based like I am, I don't know if the re fried beans contain lard. I didn't ask. Some places use lard in their re fried beans and if I would have thought of it at the time I would have asked. Anyway, my to go order came out very fast (less then 5 minutes) in the mean time I visited the salsa bar and got a few tasty looking salsas. I wish they were labeled but it's not a big deal. The burritos were huge! Truly large portions are served here. 

When I got back to my hotel I ate the burritos and they were very, very good. I was surprised at the flavors of such a simple dish but the tortilla was outstanding and the beans were on point. I added salsas to them and it just made the flavors more intense. I really enjoyed my meal and it was very reasonably priced. 

The service was very warm and kind. I will most definitely be back if I am in the area again.", "If you're not a stranger to Tucson, you're no stranger to Nicos, LosBetos, Viva, etc.  This is yet another place to get great mexican food that doesn't cost much, and puts portion size higher on the priority list than interior decorations- and that's just fine with me!  This locations facilitates dining in a little better than some others solely due to the interior room available, the seating is still bare like a McDonald's.  But the food is delicious and more than makes up for perceived short-comings inside.  More than just a burrito stand, you can order combination plates, enchiladas, tacos, rolled tacos, quesadillas, tostadas...  Good stuff, and one of our favorite places to makes runs to when buying burritos for the workcenter on base because they're huge!"]

name: Java Coffee & Café
categories_raw: Cafes, Coffee & Tea, Food, Breakfast & Brunch, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['I feel a little nervous posting a 3 star for Java, because the Treasure Valley loves this place so much. But after many, many visits, I've come to grips with saying that Java is just A-Ok. 

Firstly, Java is a nice addition to the charming Hyde Park area. It is truly a neighborhood coffee shop as many people can walk or ride their bikes there. Unfortunately, there are lots of other people (like me) who don't live in the North End and drive there. This makes Java crowded, noisy and hard to find parking. They have two single bathrooms tucked very close to tables in the back, and it can be difficult to navigate the maze to get back there (especially with a preschooler doing the potty dance). Though there is a ramp in back, I doubt this place is easy for folks with walkers, wheel chairs or strollers to navigate. The tables are very close together and the doors are not very wide. 

I do not like their coffee. It often tastes bitter and burnt to me, especially the iced coffee. They do have a nice "additions" bar where you can add all sorts of things like liquid cane sugar, soy milk, cinnamon, etc. 

For me, the pastries are hit or miss. The muffins are amazing, the scones are super dry and small. I had a maple bacon donut once and it was ok. My husband does like their breakfast burritos. 

They do have quite a lot of patio seating so it's not quite as crowded in the summer. I totally understand why lots of people love Java. But it's not my ideal coffee spot.', 'Nestled in the heart of Hyde Park, this coffee house is an absolute gem!  Located in a darling little (what seems to me, 1920's maybe?) house, Java not only serves a fabulous cup of joe but offers a charming atmosphere (including in AND outside seating).  Frequented by many in the historic North End neighborhood--this place is bustling with energy, as on any given weekday morning you will find North Enders casually gathered for a little neighborhood gossip over coffee (while I was there, the people sitting next to me were discussing some construction being done in the neighborhood and before I knew it, three other tables and a guy in line were all in on the discussion).  

Ok...ok...let's get down to business...because, though the décor may be darling, the service fast and friendly, the patrons amusing, and the location incredible--that doesn't mean a lick to this caffeine junkie if the coffee isn't stellar!  Which, thankfully it is!  Their coffee is certified organic and absolutely marvelous.  I generally order their skinny caramel mocha, which never fails to delight.  They offer an array of baked goodies, all made from scratch with organic ingredients whenever possible.  They also have a limited menu of café style breakfast and lunch items.  I didn't indulge in the baked goodies the morning I went, but I did have an egg croissant, which was decent (their eggs are "steamed", which I'm not sure of...they have a bit of a strange texture to me).  The person I was with, however, ordered their eggs Benedict and was wowed.

Other notes:  Their prices are a bit higher than other places in town (I paid over $4 for my mocha), but it was far better than many other places in town.  Their breakfast items WERE a bit overpriced in my opinion.   Oh, and a quick note with regards to their mochas:  They use a Mexican chocolate for their mochas, which I absolutely enjoy but tastes very different than your standard American, or even any of your European chocolates.  You CAN opt for a more traditional chocolate, you just have to ask.', "Gotta go with 5 stars on this one.... their food is bomb, their coffee is bomb, their location is bomb, their friendly staff are, you guessed it, bomb!  Java - Hyde Park simply does things right, from their Bowl of Soul mocha to their Tuna melt sandwich.  Add to that their amazing Hyde Park location, their seating options (indoor, deck, patio), and the equally friendly staff and patrons... and you have a recipe for a stellar coffee house.  

If you haven't yet been, try them out."]

name: Tap & Bottle
categories_raw: Shopping, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Food, Nightlife, Pubs, Beer Bar, Bars, Wine Bars
top_reviews:
["Upon recommendation of my fiancé's brother & his wife (who have been to multiple breweries in Tucson), we all headed over to Tap & Bottle to get some brews. All orders were placed at the bar and the beers were poured & served to us immediately. I was really surprised to see that they had 20+ beer choices on tap AND also a few wine choices on tap.

I'm actually not much of a beer drinker, so I thought I would try out some of the fruitier beers. I went with a flight of the Death by Coconut, Belgian Peach, Passionfruit Pinner, and Imperial Raspberry Stout. As expected, I liked the Belgian Peach and Passionfruit Pinner the best since the Death by Coconut and Imperial Raspberry Stout were both dark beers. While the coconut, peach, and passionfruit flavor came through in the beers, the raspberry one was the only one that did not have as much of the flavor as expected. I actually liked the Passionfruit Pinner so much, I went back up to get a 16oz glass of it (which is unusual for me).

My fiancé ended up going with a flight as well with the Campfire Stout, Tank 7, Victory @ Sea, and Black Butte XXVIII. Three of the beers were really dark (Tank 7 was not), but the favorite of this flight was definitely the Campfire Stout. You could literally taste a marshmallow flavor in the beer, like a s'more. His brother ended up going back to get that a full glass of that one and commented that he liked it much more than the Death by Coconut which he had gotten first. Fiancé's brother's wife got two different kinds of red wine and commented that the AZ wine (did not catch the name) was the better of the two.

Pricing was fair (I believe). The four 5oz pours for the flight were $9, and the 16oz was $5.50. I'm not sure how this compares to other breweries, however I will say that the beers were very strong! We went early afternoon on a Saturday so it wasn't too busy. We were able to grab a parking spot right out front and an empty table inside as well. I didn't get a chance to look through their bottle beer selection but did notice they had quite a few options. I would definitely make a trip back here while in Tucson!", "I'm a huge beer girl and a snobby elitist one at that.... with that.....

Love this place! Finally a craft beer place without obnoxiously loud music [or they haven't caved into it yet... ugh.. If I wanted that, I'd go to a whack club... I go to these places for great beer, and great conversation.]

I was waiting for a friend and chatted it up with the 2 bartenders in the meantime. They were super friendly however I felt they could get to know a bit more about beer and the beer that they're serving especially. I felt I knew more about them.... I was ready to take his spot and apply for a job so that someone there knew their stuff... 

One of my favorite craft beer places ever is Haymerchant in Houston and I can say that this is probably the closest to it that Tucson has to offer and that's GREAT that there even are parallels I can draw!

 In comparison to other beer places, I'd say Please oh please get more taps! [the selection is great, but 1702 and some other places are killing it with their selection and # of tap handles... even yucky Junxion has 7 IPA handles alone.. and Whole Foods has more handles....]

Not sure how service is so I just went to the bar and grabbed a seat there. Some small grabs of food would be nice. Maybe they're cool with you bringing your own? Not sure....  

Loved this place and I could easily spend a few more hours inside just like last time.", 'Hipster beer and wine bar in downtown Tucson!

AMBIENCE:  4 stars--cool old building, exposed brick, intimate space with ample seating and a retail section.

SERVICE:  4 stars.  Very helpful and knowledgeable staff--they really know their stuff and luckily they are quite patient with those of us who are not as educated as they are.  

ALCOHOL:  5 stars.  Yes, this is the place for beer and wine, with a rotating roster of top talent in the brew and fermented grape department! 

OVERALL:  4 stars.  This place is a great spot to meet friends and have drinks after work or before heading into the awesomeness of downtown Tucson or 4th Ave!']

name: Ceres
categories_raw: Food, Cafes, Bakeries, Pasta Shops, Specialty Food, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['With my true love with all things Italian- Ceres has a special spot in my heart. The special are lovely, the pastries Are perfection.  And now I need to indulge their gelato. Order for takeout, or buy in bulk to cook at home. Lovely ladies working so hard to feed delicious thoughtful food!', "Ceres is an adorable little hole-in-the-wall across the street from La Cocina that serves beverages, bread, pastries, and fresh pasta.  An important thing to note is that there is only one seat (a barstool) inside the cafe.  Ceres is essentially a take-out only place.  However, you can sit in the little picnic area by the stained glass outside of La Cocina to enjoy your pasta lunch.  

Fresh pasta is only served 11am until sold out.  You can order the type of fresh pasta you want to eat with one of their sauces, or you can take the uncooked fresh pasta to go to cook yourself at home.  Bucatini (like spaghetti with a hole in the middle of the noodle) is the vegan option, while the tagliatelle (wide and flat) and tagliolini (thin and flat) are egg noodles.  

We arrived around 11:30, and the cafe filled up quickly.  Mr. Picky Toddler Who Doesn't Like Sauce On Anything chose plain (no EVOO or butter or anything) bucatini, while my foodie bestie and I decided to split the special (tagliatelle with beet, arugula, cheese, and some other ingredients - lemon, maybe?) and tagliolini with the cacio e pepe sauce.  We also decided to try the mocha drink (made with Monsoon Chocolate) and the matcha latte.  

All of the pastas were cooked perfectly al dente and were delicious, including the plain bucatini.  Even the toddler tried and repeatedly requested more of both the special and cacio e pepe pasta (eating pasta with sauce instead of plain for the first time ever!)  Everyone's favorite pasta was the tagliolini with cacio e pepe - simple, but with great flavor.  The mocha drink was subtly sweetened by the dark Monsoon chocolate, and it was a joy to drink.  The matcha latte had no added sweetener, but it had good matcha flavor and was smooth and creamy.  We polished off all of the pasta and drinks happily while enjoying the beautiful fall weather at the picnic tables.  Given how tasty everything was, we made a pledge to come back and try all of the different pasta sauces over the next few weeks.  

TL;DR: Delicious fresh pasta (only for lunch 11a until sold out) and cafe drinks; little hole in the wall across street from La Cocina; no indoor seating (basically take out only; some outdoor picnic tables by La Cocina).  Recommend: cacio e pepe on any pasta, mocha, matcha latte", "I went yesterday with a couple of co-workers for lunch.  We agreed that it was one of the best places we've been in a while.  It was the last chance to go eat anywhere before restaurants were shut down due to the corona virus, so we were lucky enough to enjoy the outdoor eating area located near La Cocina.  I got the tagliatelle with cacio + pepe for lunch, it was creamy and divine with a cheesy, peppery goodness, and came with a small piece of focaccia bread, I loved the little to-go container that it came in.  I got some bucatini and bolognese to take home for dinner as well.  Fresh daily made pasta, sauce, there is also coffee, and pastries!  They practiced social responsibility by only allowing 4 people in the store at a time, and bringing your food outside to you.  I took the extra time for lunch to get over here, and it was totally worth it!"]

name: Ten55 Brewing Company
categories_raw: Breweries, Restaurants, Salad, Breakfast & Brunch, Beer Bar, Bars, Brewpubs, Nightlife, Food
top_reviews:
["Is it wrong to have fallen in love with a grilled cheese sandwich? I think not! This restaurant is amazingly unique with great food concepts. All comfort food and very good at environment, is very welcoming, despite the crowd. They rotate a different grilled cheese each week. I was fortunate, nay, blessed to have been able up enjoy their grilled cheese with smoked Gouda and apple bacon jam. The sandwich also came with Belgium cut fries and a pesto mayo dip, which was insane! Love in one bite. 

My sister and I split the sandwich, bad decision to split that amazing sandwich though... But we thought sharing would allow us to sample other options, good in theory not great in execution... Moving on... we ordered a bowl of their mac & cheese. Which came recommended and was a complete disappoinment. Although, the mac & cheese has an amazing pasta, one which I never have seen before, Campanelle, which was the only positive to the dish. Their cheese sauce was bland and the pasta was over cooked. Just made me regret not ordering one of there amazing sausages. 

I still give them a 5 star rating because, Mac & cheese aside, this is an amazing restaurant with a great atmosphere and amazing food. Can't wait to go back.", "SO excited to have this spot in Tucson. As a Milwaukee transplant, this is the kind of spot that makes me feel at home. A German-inspired beer & sausage house! I visited with some colleagues for happy hour and was blown away by the interior - open, modern, welcoming, with lots of space to meet with friends. You hop up to the bar to order drinks and food and grab a number for delivery to your table. Our group split the off-menu PARTY FRITES, which was a HUGE serving of their Belgian frites with a serving of each dipping sauce. Since a gal cannot survive on fries alone, I ordered a bratwurst with kraut, as well. It was fabulous. Toasted and pillowy bun, flavorful sausage, homemade tangy kraut. The beer mustard on the table was the perfect complement. The chef came by to say hello - shoutout to the Midwest - and every staff member we encountered was friendly and attentive. (Off course, can't forget the beer - lots of their own brews, with a good selection of German/Belgians, as well!) I look forward to returning to explore more of the brews, and more of the delicious food!", "Ten55 has always delivered on brewing delicious beer so it's no surprise that they also deliver on delicious food with the same friendly and welcome service. Ten55 epitomizes what it means to work with local vendors to source ingredients. From their Sausage being sourced from local Forbes Meat Company to collaborating with Barrio Bread, we love the Tucson representation! 

The Food: Their menu features traditional sausages like bratwurst and polish style (which I thoroughly enjoyed!) in addition specialty sausage, such as duck and bison. Sausages are served on a fluffy, delicious bun with your choice of toppings and sauces. Huge kudos for offering two vegan options on their menu, no one is left out!

I enjoyed the polish sausage with Belgian fries and a side of the Pesto Mayo sauce. I'd order this again for sure. 

We had a group get together to celebrate Bourdain Day and the Bourdain Special was probably one of the best soups I've tried. Portuguese sausage and kale soup with Barrio Bread. The presentation was beautiful too. Bourdain would have been proud. Hopefully we'll see this dish on the special rotation again! They also have other options like mac n cheese, salads, grilled cheese, etc. 

Speaking of specials, Ten55 has specials every week that worth checking. 

The beer: Ten55 offers options for all from their Pale Ale to IPA, Hefeweizen, coffee stout, imperial stout and many more.

The space is awesome with a view to Congress. They have a small patio out front and bar seating inside and outside. They also have a lofted seating area that is perfect for groups. They have a couch and two TVs up there as well, so if you're ever in need of a private space, this one is great. Great vibes here, super friendly staff!

Know before you go:
This is not a full service place. You order at the bar and get a number. They have stations set-up for you to grab water, napkins, utensils, etc.

Many mention price as an issue but i gotta say- the quality is good here. You're paying for good ingredients and supporting various local artisans and purveyors."]

name: Revolutionary Grounds Books and Coffee
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Restaurants, Cafes, Bookstores, Books, Mags, Music & Video, Sandwiches, Shopping, Soup, Food
top_reviews:
['In the grand expanse of the political spectrum, there's this thing called left-of-center political thought. You know, still leaning moderate, except for the random "we're all in this together" flourishes here and there. But then there's this place. Marx, Mao, Lenin, and good ol' Ernesto aka "Che". All iconized and made very much at home here in one way or another.

For this is Revolutionary Grounds, a small, quirky cafe nestled on 4th Avenue. Upon entrance you'll immediately notice enough stuff to make Joe McCarthy's head spin off, for there's socialist schwag for sale all over the place: bumper stickers, books, pins, art, t-shirts, you name it. Similarly themed posters adorn the walls, including one of a cat, leading the marching proletariat as distinguished Chairman Meow. 

You think Marxist study groups don't exist in this day and age? Wrong. They meet here weekly. Shiny golden bags of coffee beans grown by Zapatistas from Chiapas are also for sale and are being ground and brewed in store. 

Also in effect: language tables. Know a random language, like Hindi or Japanese? They have weekly/monthly meeting times when speakers, natives and learners alike, can get together and converse here. How does one say "mass collectivization" in Tagalog? I do not know.

But what I do know is this: the soy latte I've had brewed here was good. But even better? Nay, WAY better? The basil lemonade. If you're from the Phoenix metro, imagine Sweet Republic's basil lime sorbet has elegantly melted into a tall, cold glass with ice. That's what this would be. Coupled with the fact that the outside temperature from which you've been wandering around for the past hour is around 108, nothing other than this glass could be more perfect. Some limited outdoor seating is available in the backyard, but why do that to yourself in August?

The staff is really friendly so don't be afraid to enter. It's not as if the place is a cement, drab gray room with Stalin hiding just around the corner. It's inviting and a great little addition to Tucson's independent coffee scene. Just come on in, if only to be a socialist for 20 minutes before you go back to checking the latest stock quotes from your capitalist smart phone.

4 stars.', 'Looking for a little left wing ideology with your latte?  Find it here.  A new coffeehouse & bookstore in the college neighborhood on 4th Ave in Tucson, Revolutionary Grounds brews up leftist coffee from Chiapas and offers a variety of leftist political publications.

The space is small and cozy and there are options for outdoor seating:  a small courtyard off the street and a more secluded gravel patio area in back.  Indoor seating is available but limited and surrounded with books and other offerings from the left.

Service and conversation are friendly with the staff/owners.  

Cash only.  

A great addition to any area.', 'I love this little social-justice oriented coffee shop. It's a cozy, cute little place with great front and back patios. Theirs is the best coffee in town, and it's fair-trade to boot. I've gotten sacks of books here, but sometimes I just borrow a book to read during my visit. [Not Burnt Out, Just Unscrewed's "First Friday Funnies" interactive improv is the highlight of the month;  you should definitely check it out. Edit: No longer happening as they now have their own space.]

Unlike most coffee shops, you'll often see people interacting or reading, Small groups tend to get together here. It's not uncommon to strike up a conversation with a stranger, which I rarely have the opportunity to do in other coffee shops. They do have free wi-fi, though, and it's a cozy spot to do your internet browsing. 

I previously commented on the quality of the food and the unprofessionalism of the baristas. It looks like the owners have made better hiring choices over the past year or so. I can typically count on good food from most of the staff. The owner, Joy, makes terrific food and the best cookies in town. She always has vegan stuff available, and almost always has gluten-free and soy-free options. 

Bonus: The bathroom is gender-neutral. :)']

name: Francisco's De Noche
categories_raw: Restaurants, Mexican
top_reviews:
["UPDATE: The general manager contacted me immediately and promised that this would be rectified, all staff would be retrained, and procedures would be put into place to not have this happen again. That's good, because I've always thought Francisco's was a fantastic value with very tasty food. And I think it is pretty great that the general manager acted so quickly to fix this problem. 


You know, I've always been a fan of this place. It was pretty much a weekly spot while I was doing doctoral work.

But what I saw there tonight makes me not only never want to go back but warn everyone of the danger. I ordered my usual, the two pork chop plate. But, for the first time ever, I sat at the bar, which has a full view of the grill. And I watch this woman who was doing the cooking. She kept on picking up raw chicken with her glove covered hand, and then with the same hand, grabbed the spatulas, the oil that is above the grill, and the sauce container. That in itself was disgusting and dangerous.

But what she did next took the threat to public health to new heights. With pretty much everything in the kitchen now being contaminated with whatever was on that raw chicken (and everyone should know what's on raw chicken). she then stuck that same hand in the raw lettuce and tomatoes and dressed a plate with them (the Mexican side salad). Then she grabbed four other plates with the same gloved hand, a glove stained with blood and raw chicken juice, and dressed all of those plates as well.

By this point, I was debating on whether to purge my food that I had already eaten. I flagged over the manager, and I told him what was going on, even told him that I used to work for the health department and that stuff like that is either going to 1. get him shut down, or 2. kill someone with salmonella. He said that he would talk to her. He did. She changed gloves and then proceeded to do the same thing again. 

HOWEVER, the manager let the plates full of contaminated salad go out to the customer without being cleaned. I hope no one gets salmonella poisoning. I hope I don't get salmonella poisoning, although it's been 6 hours later and my stomach doesn't feel so hot.

Let's hope it's psychosomatic and not salmonella.

If this is how Franciscos de Noche runs its shop in the areas you can see, I don't even want to know what goes on in the back in the areas you can't see!

I'll never ever go back here again, and I would warn you not to do so either. It's cheap, but the hospital isn't!", "Only 9 reviews???
Seriously?


When visiting my sister in Tucson... this is a MUST stop for me.
She got my hooked (Julia C.)

The Good:
* Prices... $1.50-$3.25 for a taco, quesadilla, carne asada!? come on... CAN'T GO WRONG!
* Sauces = yummy, authentic... all you can eat!
* Private parking lot
* Free beans, but you have to find the pot of beans yourself!
* Great service, always smiling, always helpful

The Bad:
* Sticky tables
* Sticky chairs

The Weird:
* Interesting to see the different people that come into this joint. Real mexicans, white-washed mexicans, asians (me), and full caucasian. See what amazing food can do!! It can all bring us together!", 'This place is unpretentious and delicious!  For other transplants to the Sonoran desert who, like me, are still wrapping their head around the fact that chimichangas, flour tortillas and lots of carne asada are actually what is authentic Mexican food here in Tucson, you will be pleased to try to this Michoacan-style restaurant which is a little more like what I'd expect in a down-home Mexican place in CA.  But don't worry, they do still cater to Sonoran tastes with grilled chiles and onions plus Sonoran hot dogs on the menu, etc.   

Highlights included:
-Housemade corn tortillas
-Enchiladas estilo Michoacan, which means they dip the whole corn tortilla in bright red chili sauce then throw it on the griddle and fill it with white queso fresco
-Help-yourself salsa bar and pot of beans!  All salsas were fantastic plus they had homemade pickled carrots and jalapenos and some crazy sauce I'd never seen before:  it was very dark brown/red and oil-based, seemed to be made with finely ground, deeply toasted chiles and seeds...had a great nutty, spicy flavor.

I love all the old photos and funny signs on the wall plus the vintage lunch counter.  If this place was in my neighborhood I'd be here all the time.  BYOB encouraged and definitely no "corkage" fee.  Oh god, I almost forgot we got free refills on horchata and jamaica!  Unheard of!']

name: Peking Palace
categories_raw: Restaurants, Chinese
top_reviews:
['After a trip to the zoo, Amy and I were in the mood to eat animals.  We settled on Peking duck as the solution to our cravings, and I set about finding a location that might actually serve it.  Enter Peking Palace, the only place that Yelp yielded as a source for the dish.

We decided to share half a Peking duck, a "lunch special" order of Northern-style vegetables (to keep things healthy, you see -- the egg roll and fried rice were merely tolerated and not actively sought out or gobbled voraciously), and a pot of Oolong tea.  While we waited, we were treated to crispy noodles with a very mild sweet and sour sauce.  The staff was extremely attentive about keeping our water glasses full, and both of the ladies who helped us were very friendly.

The lunch special was quite good as far as standard Chinese restaurant lunch specials go -- the helping was generous, the vegetables were properly-cooked, and the dish tasted about how I would have hoped given what it was.  The Peking duck was served de-boned; the skin had also been removed and apparently fried to achieve the desired crispy texture.  As expected, the duck was accompanied by a few pieces of green onion that had been flowered out at both ends, some hoisin sauce, and some thin pancakes.  The end result was quite tasty, as duck, fried duck skin, green onion, and hoisin sauce in a pancake almost cannot help but being delicious.  

For those who have had more faithful recreations of Peking duck, it may be difficult to get beyond the clearly non-traditional preparation methods used here.  A real Peking duck is prepared using a time consuming process of hanging the duck in a seasoned marinade for a number of hours, and then achieving the desired crispiness of the skin when the duck is roasted.  This Peking duck was clearly not the result of such a process.  For $12 for half a bird, I can't say I blame them, but if you're hoping to have an authentic Peking duck experience you should probably not expect to get that at Peking Palace.

If you show up expecting a solid Chinese food restaurant in the standard vein, then our experience suggests that you won't be disappointed.  We found good service, tasty food, and decent prices here.  Just don't show up expecting anything more than a cheap imitation of any iconic imperial Chinese dishes you may happen to order.', 'I have a love-hate relationship with Chinese food.  When I am in China (though the last time I was there was two years ago), I crave Panda Express.  When I am eating Panda Express in the U.S, I crave something more authentic.  Is there a compromise - really good Americanized food, perhaps?

See, when I have had "traditional, authentic" Chinese food, it has been mostly the preferred dark meat (a specialty!), mostly the other half of the animal I don't eat (tendons, knuckles, wings, etc), covered in oil, and mostly squishy textures.

But Peking Palace really brought me back to China, something I can't say for most Chinese places.  And what better day to go than the beginning of the Lunar New Year!

When I first walked in and sat in a red-fabric booth surrounded by Chinese paintings, I noticed that there were tables of Mandarin-speaking elderly eating.  When I want to hear Spanish, I go to Little Cafe Poca Cosa.  When I want to hear Mandarin now, I will definitely come to Peking Palace.

They do have a lunch buffet, but it is not that impressive, and it's mostly like a hybrid of Americanized and traditional.  For example, there were sauteed bean sprouts, some fried whole chopped up chicken, some lo mein, and some egg drop soup that I saw.  Most people eating there today actually ordered off the menu.

I asked my Chinese friends if they had heard of Peking Palace, and appropriate to the name, they said that it was one of the few places that serves 'Peking' Duck.

I was immediately impressed by the hot tea served.  You don't have to ask for it and wonder if it's free or not.  The tea is black and delicious - no strong hints of jasmine or chrysanthemum.  I never eat those won ton chips that come with the meals, but these were pretty good - light and crispy.

I ordered the dumplings that they called "ravioli."  You can get them either steamed or fried.  I ordered them fried, and my friend actually started drinking the dipping sauce!  It was good.  It was like a high-quality soy sauce with chili oil on the rim and green onions in it.  The dumplings were as authentic as the street food in China; slightly doughy, larger than the ones you usually get at restaurants, and yummy!  Six were $6.50 I think.

I can read Chinese, and the servers could speak Mandarin and Cantonese.  I read somewhere in the restaurant that the owners are from Taiwan and the food is specialized in Sichuan/Szechuan and Northern cuisine.  

There is a Chinese menu which is a piece of paper with simplified Mandarin Chinese characters but no translation or prices.  Things like steamed sea bass, salt and pepper chicken, sauteed beef, and the like.  I can tell you more if you want.

I ordered Szechuan Beef and Spicy Tofu.  The Szechuan Beef was picture perfect, but the only bad thing was that it was 80% celery which totally overpowered the dish.  My friend was surprised that it was neither sweet or salty or garlicky, so it was surprising to her.  I was very surprised because I asked for extra spicy, and it was extra mild.

The Spicy Tofu was not spicy either.  Honestly, the whole dish appeared to be canned but was much better when I ate it!  I asked for it extra spicy and it was mild.  It was great how it had tiny slivers of cooked dried pork instead of just ground meat.  It was a different interpretation because it was silken tofu!  Extra slimy instead of the firm tofu I was expecting.  I liked it, but it was so different of a congealed texture.

I was drooling over the food on the next table over.  They ordered chow mein and it had tons of veggies on it.  It looked so delicious.  They also ordered soup, and the soups looked amazing.  At this point,  felt like I was in China or at least the best Chinatowns and was so in that mood, so I was surprised when other non-Chinese started walking into the restaurant.  Yeah, I was displaced for a second.

All that food was $20 which I thought was pretty good considering I had jiaozi pot stickers, two large platters of food for two people and more for leftovers, and tea.  Although I was not in a hurry, it took 25 minutes for our food to come out which is a little bit longer than most places I believe.

Overall, great experience, just different food for me.  I want to go back and get some of their noodles and soups!  Their rating will probably either go up or down, if you know how repeat visits usually affect ratings...  I better get spicy next time!', "Best Chinese food in a town that isn't known for it's wonderful Chinese food. Szechuan  chicken, extra hot, is a personal favorite. The owners are sweethearts and care about their customers."]

name: Merritt's Family Restaurant
categories_raw: Breakfast & Brunch, Diners, Bakeries, Restaurants, American (Traditional), Food
top_reviews:
['JESUS CHRIST THATS A WHOLE LOT OF REALLY GOOD DRUNK FOOD. WHOOOOAAAAAA.

5 stars only if you are looking for a filthy roadhouse with incredible scones, hash browns, and other things that you can put gravy on. And the jukebox....oh, the jukebox.

Being one of the few places in Boise that stays open 24 hours, Merritt's gets business and cred by default. However, the food, the atmosphere, the uber-gnarly late night crowd all come together to make this one of the top 10 "drunk food" spots in the country, IMO.

You want casino-style hashbrowns? Hell Yes. Biscuits and Gravy the size of your head? Word. Coffee with a peculiar viscosity? Well...it IS Idaho.

They advertise "World Famous Scones". You will not be disappointed. I actually skipped the Scones for the first few times I was here, because scones, to me, were those dry blob looking pastries that you got at coffeehouses. At Merritts, a scone is essentially a warm, soft, sheet of fried dough the size of a plate. Throw some butter and honey on that sucker, and you've successfully defeated a hangover.

Oh, and the whole thing will run you like 5 bucks.

Like I said, the place is a ramshackle roadhouse a few miles out of town, the restrooms are fantastically filthy, the place is full of drunks, young and old. The walls are covered in greasy pictures of racehorses, and the impossibly old jukebox plays Cash, Haggard, Jones, and Jennings. I cant remember, but I think it might actually play 45's.

If Merritt's were a person, you would be all 'Merritt's is good people'.', "Two words ........... Be afraid !!!!! ..............This place sucks. When my wife and I went in it was by far the epitome of a dive or hole in the wall. (not in a good way) It was busy so we overlooked the shabbiness of the place because we figured if that many people went there the food must be good. BIG mistake on our part. We were sat right in the path of everybodys way. Customers going to the  restroom, servers delivering food, customers coming into the place. Just in the way. It also took forever to get our drinks. Even longer to have a server get our order. Only one cook. Looks like she just got out of prison and so skinny it was obvious she didn't even eat there. We finally moved to a booth which was much better.

A family of 5 came in, mom, dad, and 3 girls at the table we were first sat down at. Only 4 chairs, and the servers didn't even try to get a 5th chair. They finally left because of the lack of attention they got. Finally we got our order placed and the server recommended the chicken fried steak. It took 30 minutes to get our order. Remember..... only one cook. My wife ordered an omelet. Got our food finally. Chicken fried steak so greasy it made my stomach upset withing 15 minutes of trying to eat it. Gravy sucked, eggs over done, toast cold. My wife's meal was not much better. 

So since this placed brags about their scones, we ordered one...... Waited another 20 minutes and never got it. Refills on drinks was a joke. I had to ask every time to get refills. Long story over with ..... We were there for a little over an hour and ended up not paying for my meal, but paid for my wife's and the drinks after I complained about everything. During our visit I had also seen and heard a few other customers complain about some of the same things that bugged us.

As I said before ............... Be afraid !", 'The sign outside says SCONE, the servers all wear tshirts that say things like, "Get Sconed", or "I Just Got Sconed" - but mark my words - these are not scones but delicious Indian fry bread covered with powdered sugar/cinnamon sugar/plain that's larger than the size of a baby's head.  And I'm talking a baby that was born by C-section, because it weighed 35lbs, as its mother ate these scones from Merritt's everyday, three meals a day for 9 months.

The place isn't much to look at.  Dark wood paneling that's sagging and peeling in places.  Your (nearly blind) grandmother's light fixtures.  And booths with tables jammed up so close to your body that they'll have to physically remove the table after you're done eating so that you can have more room to stretch out for the sugar coma that's about to follow.

We sat in the back booth facing the door, ready for the gunfight that we were pretty sure would happen during our Sunday morning brunch.  Our Prius was the only non-4 wheel drive in the parking lot (along with a Harley).  A guy stood outside the front door with one of his hands suspiciously hidden in his checkered shirt, looking at everyone who went by.  

Ordered the Two Eggs with Bacon and Scone and a Denver Omelet with Scone.  About $8.75/ea.  "The scones won't be too big, if they're a side with the breakfast," we reassured ourselves.  When the scones finally arrived - spilling over on a plate larger than half my ass - we  realized that our asses would be bigger than the scone by the time the meal was over.  The scones were delicious, having just been deep fried and sprinkled with cinnamon sugar.  Each one came with a generous dollop of honey butter.  Despite our promise to eat only HALF of the scone, by the time the rest of our breakfast arrived, we'd pretty much finished the entire thing.  

The omelet was a decent homemade omelet full of ingredients - what you'd expect in a family restaurant - not a fancy omelet of the "New American" variety.  My hash browns were a little on the soggy and bland side but the bacon was great.  The restaurant had all the condiments on the table and a specialty ketchup we've never seen before - infused with lemon and spices.  The condiments were clean, not spilling over and encrusted with flies, and the service was friendly and efficient.  Besides breakfasts the place also serves lunch and dinner and even late night, though at $7.75 for a Sirloin, as advertised on their white board, I'm not sure how good the steak would be.  (It was $8.75 for the breakfast.)  And I'm not sure what the crowd would be like later in the day.  Happily, however, the place doesn't serve alcohol.']

name: Zemam's Too
categories_raw: Restaurants, Food, African, Imported Food, Coffee & Tea, Specialty Food, Ethnic Food
top_reviews:
['Amazing, the mango drink was awesome, next the  food is served on sourdough flatbread and you pick it up with the bread , the dish has everything under the Sun, there was chicken, beef, fish, vegetables, curry, lentils and salads. Everything was tasty, they give you extra bread.This place is a must visit in Tucson. Parking is on the side of the street.', 'Great food, reasonable prices and good service.
You can also bring your own beverages', 'Wow! I've never had Ethiopian food before so I didn't know what to expect. The food is served on top of a sourdough flatbread and you pick it up with the bread - no forks! Most dishes are a kind of curry/stew called wat that is loaded with spices. We each got samplers, which come with 3 dishes of your choice, and I'd definitely recommend doing that. The sampler comes with a lot of food; we each got one but probably could split one next time depending on how hungry we are. 

Between the two of us, we got the following, which were all good:

Shiro ("A unique dish of pureed Chickpeas blended with traditional spices"): I thought this was pretty good. My wife thought it was OK but the worst of the six. The texture was a pureed consistency. 

Yetakelt Wat ("A delicately seasoned medley of fresh Vegetables and Potatoes"): This one was great. The texture of the potatos really gave it character and the flavor was spot on. 

Gomen Wat ("Traditional Collard Greens with garlic, coriander and cayenne"): Another hit. The chopped collard greens were infused with big flavor! She's still talking about them. 

Yemisir Kay Wat ("Red Lentils, sautéed with onions in a spicy berbere sauce"): I thought this were only pretty good, but my wife really liked them. Spicy! 

Spinach ("Spinach stewed in a mild blend of traditional spices"): This one was good but we both agreed that the collard greens were better! 

Spicy Boneless Chicken ("Traditional Chicken dish slowly cooked in a rich, spicy berbere sauce"): My wife is a vegetarian so I got this one to myself! The chicken had a nice, deep spice to it. Really nice. 

The restaurant itself looks like a converted house, with some nice African art/decor. We really liked this place, and now that I've tasted Ethiopian food I can't wait to have some more!']

name: Black Crown Coffee Co.
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Food
top_reviews:
["Quaint little mid town coffee shop. Lots of old wood throughout. It's a great place to people watch on the patio which faces Speedway Blvd.  They have really good pastries as well. And for you real coffee aficionados this place is open until midnight!  The drinks are great and the baristas are talkative and funny! Definitely worth checking out if you feel the need for caffeine!", 'What was once a dingy hole-in-the-wall known to many in the Tucson community as SafeHouse, has been reborn and transformed into a welcoming, clean, and homey coffee locale that retains its distinct Tucson flavor. Literally rising out of the (mostly cigarette) ashes, Black Crown emerges.  

Those who were uninitiated to the joint may remember Safehouse for one thing: a coffee shop where smoking was allowed inside. To much anticipated clamor, smoking is no longer permitted inside the building. However, there is ample seating outside for those who wish to indulge.

I am no coffee connoisseur, but I can tell you what I had today was delicious. For those who like the slightly sweetened iced coffee thing, I recommend the "Tar Heel" (sp?). While I was there, a version of this drink was made with pumpkin flavoring which was fantastic, and I hope they include it on their menu (at least seasonally).

Free wifi and ample power outlets make this place an easy go-to for those people who like to mix business and pleasure. Separate seating areas including a cozy living room setup upstairs make the place manageable for larger groups too.

This transformation was no small feat, and has resulted in a comfortable environment to enjoy fantastic in-house roasted beans from around the world. Many many props to the new acquirer of this business, Scott, for keeping this Tucson staple alive. Further, congrats to him on producing a product (both in terms of coffee and ambiance) that far exceeds in quality its predecessor. I highly recommend that people come in and meet the friendly staff and become a regular here. It is no coincidence that many who frequent this coffeehouse regard the other patrons as family.', "I'm not-so-secretly in love with Black Crown. In fact, I'm a little obsessed.

First: the shop. It's a house that has been converted into a coffee shop (or at least has that appearance). There are several separate seating areas, as opposed to the wide open modern concept of most coffee shops, including outdoor space and upstairs space. This makes it the perfect spot to go to when you need to get some work done on the laptop. 

Next: the staff. Always super wonderful and friendly. That being said, there are sometimes super pretentious friends of employees hanging around the register, shooting the occasional judgmental look as my one year old (quietly!!) climbs on the staircase or glares down at my Wednesday afternoon (post yoga class!!) flip flops. That I could certainly do without. Peace, love, etc., guys. Calm it down. 

Finally: that coffee. It's good! You'll love it! They also have some interesting concoctions to try for the flavored latte-loving crowd. 

Don't let the somewhat grungy (in a good way!) exterior keep you from trying this place. It's a winner."]

name: El Sinaloense Hot Dog Cart
categories_raw: Food Stands, Restaurants, Hot Dogs, Mexican
top_reviews:
["Not soon hidden gem, a MUST GO TO. Growing up on the east coast I had never experienced the wonder that is the Sonoran hotdog until later in life, so I've been attempting to make up for lost time and crush as many as I can from all across town. 

El Sinaloense does them right! All the toppings, super fast, friendly, and some great drink options as well- classic sodas as well as horchata and lemonade from cooler. Highly recommend and will definitely return. Beware pepper served with your dog is hot hot hot.  

***note only cash is accepted", 'If you've ever been to Sonora, Mexico and eaten a hot dog from a stand on the side of the road there, and wanted to repeat such experience, go to this hot dog stand on Alvernon. Here you will find the most authentic Sonoran dogs in Tucson, and I can say that with certainty. My Honey and I have made a quest of trying to find the best hot dogs in town, and for months we wouldn't try the same tent twice until we found this place and, call it love at first bite, we knew right away it was the best.
 
Although I order my hot dog sans hot dog, or "sin carne" I promise it's just as good without the meat. Honey might disagree. My mom says no onions. Whatever. Whichever way you prefer to eat it, just eat it.
 
The Bun (made in Tucson by a small local "factory" - Alejandro's) is thrown on the grill with a slathering of butter. They will grill the bun top and bottom.  Front and back. Side to side. No soggy bun here. It's all crispy, buttery, goodness baby. The dog (which I have never actually tasted, since the bun + beans+ condiments = enlightenment, as it is) is wrapped in bacon and covered in homemade Mexican - style black beans, jalapeno salsa, fresh tomatoes and fresh onions, sweet grilled onions, mustard, and mayo. Nearby, a magical, white k-mart cooler contains; mushrooms, spicy green salsa (wow! spicy), shredded cheese, and avocado sauce. The cook will ask you, "Chili?" Your answer must be, "Si." He will put a grilled yellow- hot chili on the side for your nom-ing pleasure. The pepper makes a big difference... Trust me. They're grilled to perfection with lime juice and a little sprinkling of grainy salt.

Also, the horchata. Whether you are a horchata drinker or not, you will like it. It's like dessert in a glass... a creamy cinnamon drink, sweet and milky to cut the fiery salsa on your hot dog.
 
The owner, Beto, is usually the one cookin' up the dogs outside in the summer heat, but sometimes his brothers help him out too. He'll remember you the second time you go - and try to let you know he appreciates your business in his thick accent and broken English.', 'Not all Sonoran hot dogs are equal. There are very popular eateries around Tucson that offer the Sonoran dog but those who know, know that if it isn't from El Sinaloense or Los Chipilones hot dog carts then you ain't eating the best. They each have a few carts around town. Let me help you step your game up.

First off, the bread they use is another level good and they take the time to toast the outside of the bun to create a nice crunch. It seems like a small thing but so satisfying texture to have that crunch on a soft bun. The bacon wrapped hot dog is cooked when ordered, placed in the toasted bun and covered in pinto beans, chopped tomatoes and onions, mayo, mustard and green chile sauce that spices it up a bit. Add to that it one of the best cheap eats you can get. Two dogs and large drink is easy $8 (cash only spot BTW). Show up with an Alexander Hamilton ($10 bill for you Burr fans) and you can eat like a king!

I know. You're thinking, "Yo J, that's how every Sonoran dog is made. This ain't special." And my answer to that is first, how dare you? Second, maybe so, but the chile sauces and bread quality and toastiness sets it apart. Maybe it's powerful hot dog cart magic that has been proven to exist that makes hot dogs taste better when served from a cart. Maybe it's that I'm starving when I leave church and this is literally the first food I drive by. Whatever it may be, El Sinaloense serves up some of the best dogs in town. Stop by and tell them Johnny sent you (they have no idea who I am and will probably look at you very confused, but I'd get a shout out). 4.5/5*']

name: ABC Vaccination Clinic
categories_raw: Pets, Veterinarians
top_reviews:
["We went in for first set of puppy shots because we bought a golden retriever puppy that was way underweight, unvaccinated and only about 4 weeks (we found out at a new vet). We expressed our concerns to the vet and she told us our dog is a chihuahua and suppose to be that small , gave him the shot and walked away. We scheduled an appointment for more shots with a new vet. Here's Cooper: 4 weeks old to 11 months and close to 75 lbs :) I've never seen a chihuahua look like this! But glad he got the proper care from a better veterinarian facility!", "This place is a low cost option for those who want their cat and dog to see a vet. However, before I explain anything else please note that they give quotes that are much lower than the final bill. I witnessed another visitor lose her cool with the staff for this reason. I knew they were going to do this so I saved extra money in anticipation for a hefty (but more affordable than your average vet) bill. They quoted $130 but my bill was $239. 

Therefore, if you are quoted an amount over the phone DON'T expect it as the final amount. Also, when I came back to pick up my animal the staff did not give me any over all info about how to care for my pet after surgery. They gave us the medicine our pet needed and told us the basic instructions and that's all. If I have to ask twenty questions and your staff won't hand us a sheet of paper with care instructions then you might want to think about telling the front desk to do so.

They really are the most affordable, in my opinion, than anyone else in town. They have a small facility and they are located in the center of town. They were able to to schedule a same week appointment for my cat to get a few tooth extractions. They are open from 7am-4pm.  I only found out about this place from the ABC clinic on Craycroft and 22nd. This clinic is different from the others since they offer more services.

Their services include:
- Physical Exams
-Spay/Neuter
-Surgery
-Dentistry
-X-Rays
-Prescription Drugs
-Vaccinations
-Nutrition
-Microchips", "This was my second visit to this particular ABC.  This time i had two young cats that needed rabies (3 year) and FVRCPC shots.  This clinic is always busy, no appointment needed but that can mean a little wait sometimes.  Today we were greeted immediately, both cats were taken to the 'back' so they would not be stressed by all the dogs, I was ushered into a beautifully cool room to complete my paperwork.  We were seen promptly by a very pleasant, knowledgeable and helpful vet and her tech.  Both cats were weighed, examined and given their shots all for a quarter of the price I would have paid at my local vets office.  I am delighted with the service and the care at this clinic, thoroughly recommend it.  
The Craycroft and 22nd street clinic is also very good.  I had one of my cats spayed there and the care she received was fabulous.  Everything you would hope for and expect from a veterinary office at a fraction of the cost.  I took one of my geriatric cats in last week, he had an exam, a full blood work up and urinalysis, the news was not fabulous but was delivered efficiently and again at a fraction of the cost my local vet would have charged.
This is great for 'pet parents' in Tucson, no excuse to not spay or neuter, plus all the necessary shots for their good health are affordable.  
Thank you ABC."]

name: Ikkyu
categories_raw: Restaurants, Ramen, Japanese
top_reviews:
["With all these new trendy poke pop-ups opening throughout the West, some times it's nice to just order a simple spicy tuna don without all the fixin's. 

From bentos, curry to ramen, it was a hard choice but I picked the Spicy Tuna Don ($8.50).
