The bowl had an appropriate amount of sushi rice with a heaping amount of fresh tuna topped with nori (seaweed), negi (green onions) and sesame seeds. The tuna quality was fresh and didn't have any fishy aftertaste. The rice was nicely seasonly without being overly sweet or vinegary. The bowl is served with a cup of miso soup. 

During the lunch time, this place was packed with diners either eating the Spicy Tuna Don, Ramen or Curry Rice. Others had take out orders as well. My food was quickly made and I enjoyed eating in their small self serve dining space.

This mom and pop establishment comes directly from Japan and Hawaii roots and I appreciated their goal of providing a tasty meal rather than following the fads. Because of their selection, you'll be able to find a meal to fulfill a variety of your Japanese cravings. 

They are closed on Sundays and share the parking lot with the LeeLee grocery store. 

It was just me and my tuna and rice. Happy tummy = happy gal. Sometimes less is more.", 'OK, finally, a Japanese restaurant that does things right.

My usual disclaimer for Asian restaurants: I'm third generation Japanese/Korean, grew up with great Asian cooking by parents born in Hawaii, can cook Japanese food better than most Tucson Japanese restaurants, and lived in Japan for two years.

Finally got a weekend opportunity to check out Ikkyu's ramen so I took my wife and my daughter and ordered each of us a tonkotsu ramen and an order of yakiniku in a bowl. Excellent ramen! Good broth, fresh ingredients, and a generous portion. Both my wife and daughter could not finish theirs, which was a bonus for me as clean up in the batting order.

The noodles are cooked just right and have the right consistency. The pork is fresh and lean and sliced consistently thin. The bamboo shoots are not the woody, canned variety, but was fresh. The broth is not overly spicy, but just enough to give a little kick and it was nice and creamy like a good tonkotsu broth should be.

The yakiniku was delicious. It had the right amount of grilled flavor in it and was not overly marinated which can produce a salty flavor.

The staff was very friendly. Most of my dealings were with the co-owner, Lori, but I did have interactions with two other of the staff and they were helpful and friendly. Upon leaving, going through the door I shouted out the traditional "Go-chisoh-sama deshita" and both Lori and Hiro turned and waved from the kitchen. I don't know if they really know the phrase as she is fourth generation but I think he is second or third generation.

The place is very informal. You order and pick up at the counter. You get your own napkins and o-hashi (chopsticks) and water. Seating inside is small and there is some seating in an outdoor patio. All in all, a very typical Japanese restaurant.

One of the two Japanese restaurants that I would recommend so far. (Samurai being the other.)', "I can't believe I haven't reviewed Ikkyu before, as I am a frequent customer, and have been for years. Ikkyu is a small Japanese restaurant on the end of the shopping plaza where Lee Lees Oriental Supermarket is located. They have maybe 10 tables inside, and an outdoor patio that is covered for the short time of the year when eating outside isn't oppressively hot with another 4-5 tables. The menu includes bento boxes, rice bowls, a limited number of sushi rolls and salads. After the gym I love to go here and either get their spicy tuna don (which I order Volcano style-with eel sauce, tempura flakes, spicy mayo and dried seaweed flakes) or their ramen which is only offered Thursday-Sunday. So when you walk in looking for Ramen and don't see it on the menu, that is because it isn't on the menu. There will be a sign posted for Ramen on the counter with pictures and then you know you are in luck. Boy is this great ramen! I like the Tonkatsu Ramen best;  i've had all three and all are delicious. A special detail I especially like about Ikkyu ( which is silly I know) is they have a self served soda machine with 7-up, RC cola, ginger ale and lemonade( possibly root beer too). I love love love these choices so much. I usually drink water or green tea when I eat a dinner unless I get a cocktail. This to me is all my favorites from when I was a kid. 
Bathroom's are single stall rooms for men and ladies, which are at the end of a hall way past the order counter. The place is small and a bit cramped for space. So many times when I am sitting customers ordering or inches from me. Also if you need to use the restroom, you often are waiting for another customer to vacate the restroom.That being said, I love the food here. For Japanese food in Tucson this it is my comfort food and reasonably priced. The staff are always very nice and if it's not too noisy you'll notice they always seem to be playing pandora radio 80's hits which brings a smile to my face."]

name: Proof Artisanal Pizza & Pasta
categories_raw: Restaurants, Pizza, Italian, Nightlife, Gluten-Free, Bars, Cocktail Bars
top_reviews:
["Came here because I wanted to try burrata. I had the burrata fruta, chicken piccata, and affogato for dessert. The food was very good! That fig onion jam was insane, me and my friend still talk about it to this day. The piccata was also delicious, they even kindly split it into two servings for us. Finishing with the affogato, we almost didn't get it but the espresso was deep and smooth and such an amazing complement to the ice cream. Service was great, our waiter was so nice and fun to talk to. There weren't many people inside but we did come at an odd hour. I can't wait to come here again.", "With crazy good pizza places like Reilly & Anello, why settle for terrible pizza?
The what:
Cauliflower crust may as well be cardboard (texture- and flavor-wise). With all the gluten-free goodness out there today herbs and parmesan and just natural cauli flavor could make this crust sooooo good, but instead it's just so boring.
Toppings (especially cheese and sauce) are so scant are they even really there? Except on the Margherita pizza where the tomato pieces are so big and drippy they ruin the whole pie. The margherita pizza also has basil oil on it, and it is so overpowered by the drippy tomatoes its just pointless. (I tried some off the pan, and even just by itself it's so subtle.)
The regular pizza crust on this pizza has NO flavor either, not salty, not fatty, just kinda hard and too chewy dough. 
The rapini side dish was a complete joke: the tough woody ends were left on and the rapini was DROWNING in oil with really no added spices or flavor. Just limp almost broccoli.
UGH so sad we spent money here today.", 'Stopped in after work with some coworkers and enjoyed Proof for the first time. I will echo another reviewer and say they definitely appeared short staffed. Hostess seating was almost nonexistent and our server was assigned to 9 tables. It was enough to notice, but our group had plenty to talk about during the wait. The mule was a nice start to the evening and on happy hour from 3-6 pm for $5. I ordered 3 different items, also from the happy hour menu: bruschetta, meatballs and pizza. Reasonable serving sizes for the price. My favorites were the pizza and artichoke bruschetta. All items tasted fresh and were full of flavor with the right amount of ingredients. I would definitely order my favorites again. We ate inside but the outdoor patio is decorated with string lights and a band was playing as we were leaving. I look forward to coming back to get a different experience outside!']

name: Guido's Original New York Style Pizza Downtown
categories_raw: Italian, Salad, Pizza, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Still really fabulous NY style pie.  Still great prices.  Still solid service (a bit gruff on occasion, perhaps).  And, still:  wine.

And, now?  They accept visa!  Finally!  

Get to it!', "Now that I have been graduated from college, have a big girl job, and rarely let myself drink to the point of craving a whole pizza from Pie Hole... I got to thinking that I should definitely replace my cheap/drunk pizza place that encourages pizza binging at 3 am with a place that I don't mind walking into at noon. That place is Guido's.

They put something in their dang crust that makes it irresistable. They always have cheap prices. They are super nice. And best of all, they switch up their offerings while staying true to traditional pizza toppings. I just love Guido's!", 'My favorite pizza place in Boise. NY style thin crust, perfect amount of toppings, not too much like other places, not greasy. Simple cheese and few toppings on good sauce. Quick in-and-out lunch place or snack while walking around downtown Boise. Price is great, about $2.50 a slice. My boys favorite place too.']

name: Ren Coffeehouse
categories_raw: Cafes, Food, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Restaurants, Coffee & Tea, Bakeries
top_reviews: ["Love this place! But, let's be real, I'm biased here. The owner is from WI, and she brought along some Milwaukee-based coffee called Colectivo with her. Being a fellow Sconnie transplant, I was SO excited to see her bring these products to the desert! (Another WI product she carries is Rishi tea - it's top-notch.) All that aside, the service is friendly, they have a solid food menu to keep you satisfied, and the space offers plenty of indoor and outdoor seating. Last time I stopped in on a Saturday morning, they even had a little bit of live music going. This is a great spot for the plaza, and a perfect place to grab your caffeine before walking around the weekend market. Pro tip: It's right near the loop path, so if biking or walking is your thang, it's super convenient!", "Ren Coffeehouse has a little bit of everything- the coffee, bites from pastries and smoothies to sandwiches and salads. Ample seating and tables as well as cozy couches. In need for a change of scenery of working from home, I popped in for a couple of hours. It's a great spot to  get some work done or have a meet up with friends. I chatted with the owner a bit about the menu and the kombucha and she is super lovely! They carry good quality and seem to be dedicated to supporting other local makers, which is awesome! I also ordered the avocado toast which was very flavorful. A little too heavy on the garlic for me, but I'm sensitive to garlic. But it was fresh and very much had the homemade touch. Ren is not in my neighborhood per se, but I'll definitely be back for another to try more menu items.", 'Great place to have a cup of coffee. Their menu is something for everyone. They have matcha, latte, espresso, a turmeric drink and plenty to choose from. They know their stuff and even make great designs on the drinks themselves. They close at 4 on weekends.\n\nDropped a star due to the atmosphere. Little gloomy.']

name: Chef Wang
categories_raw: Noodles, Chinese, Szechuan, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['This is not your standard Americanized Chinese restaurant. Definitely not a orange chicken and beef broccoli kind of place. This is more like the kind of authentic Chinese food I grew up eating!

I finally decided to try Chef Wang on a night that I was craving green onion pancakes and Taiwanese beef noodle soup. I live on the west side and Chef Wang's came up on Yelp when I searched "green onion pancakes" so after checking out the reviews my husband and I decided to give it a chance. We were not disappointed! 

I was immediately excited by the fact that they had Xiaolongbao! Soup dumplings are hard to come by in Tucson! I think on their menu they called it "small steamed bun - 10 pc."  We got an order of those, the green onion pancakes I'd been craving, the spicy beef noodle soup, and the salt and pepper ribs, all family style. We also got a pitcher of beer. 

Just re-capping everything we ordered is making my mouth water all over again! Both the green onion pancakes and the spicy beef noodle were *exactly* what I was craving. So flavorful! When my husband and I bit into the ribs, all we could say for a good minute was, "Wow!" The ribs were perfectly salted. My husband couldn't stop raving about them! 

My only "complaints" are that I wish they had given me a dipping sauce with my green onion pancakes, and that I wish there had been more bok choy in the spicy beef noodle. The latter is more of a personal problem though as I just love a lot of bok choy and typically need to order "extra" veggies anyways.

Service is standard for any good, non-American restaurant. It's similar to how some people say the hole-in-the-wall restaurants typically have the best food. In my experience the trade off is usually giving up an attentive server for the most amazing, authentic food. I'm 100% down for that trade-off and typically if I sit down and I realize service is that way, I have my strategy locked and loaded. I keep a mental list of everything I might need in the future and ask for it all at once. Napkins, sauces, extra drinks before we need them, and if there's something I think I'm forgetting a polite "I think that was it but can you please come check back in 10 minutes?" usually suffices! 

I think during our visit we were checked on a total of 4 ish times from start to finish, but I was too enamored by our delicious food to need anything but space anyways. Trust me when I say we will be back.', "First time diner on 12/1/2021.  Place is new, uber clean, friendly service.  Located in a somewhat sketchy part of town - it is worth the stop and like finding a 'diamond in the rough'.

In a city where street tacos and Mexican food reigns supreme - I truly appreciate having wonderfully fresh and clean tasting Chinese food just a stone throw away.  I will definitely be back and I would also pat myself on the back for squeezing 3 cheesy clichés into this review. 
General Tsao chicken and Mongolian Beef = 5 stars each!  Thank you.", 'One of my favorite authentic Chinese restaurants in Tucson. They offer some Chinese/American dishes, but their expansive menu has items to please diners looking for "the real deal". I've been here many times solo & also w/a group. Up front is a mother/daughter team & they're both warm, friendly & very helpful & always remember their regular customers. Unique in my experience is a 'deli' case filled w/cold appetizers & any combo of 3 is only $8.95. Today I selected sliced pig ears, pork stomach & delightful seaweed salad. My entrée was a lamb & fish hot pot served w/medium heat upon my request. All of the portions are very large & is great for food to take home. If you don't think that Tucson has high quality Chinese restaurants that offer items other, than egg rolls, won ton soup, chop suey & egg foo young, you're in for a taste treat. Ask for chopstix, please!']

name: Fiesta Chicken
categories_raw: Mexican, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["This is a very unique little joint. It has most of the traditional Mexican foods that you would expect to see in Idaho. But it also has fried chicken, homemade macaroni and cheese and the best broccoli salad. It's kind of a mix with Southern cuisine, I guess? Either way, it works! And it means that more people can enjoy the cuisine together. 

I've never actually been inside, because drive throughs. With little human beasts, drive throughs just get me. I have been extremely impressed with the service in the drive through! Fast, courteous and always with a smile. They also maintain their picture worthy presentation in the drive through. My burrito to go still had the same giant beauty of one served in house. 

We've had the chipotle chicken tacos, carne asada street tacos, green chicken burrito, beef burrito, all the sides, and the fried chicken. I have nothing negative to say about any of them. I love the chicken that they use inside the burrito. It must be pulled from the fried chicken, because it is on the drier side, which I love! It is packed with flavor. I will say, everything we have ordered has a kick of spice, so if your tongue is on the wimpier side of the Scoville scale, you might want to check with staff first.", "Like a large number of recent transplants from California to Boise, I loved El Pollo Loco back home.  Well guess what?  Fiesta Chicken is the answer to that fix that you're craving!  

The BRC is GIGANTIC and cheap and sooo damn delicious.  

Very unassuming location next to a gas station, but it hits you right in the yumms for sure.  

I will definetly be back to actually try the chicken next time.", "OPEN SUNDAY!!! Great, quick and easy post-church stop before heading out for a hike!

If you like El Pollo Loco, you will like Fiesta Chicken. There was a time I thoroughly enjoyed EPL.

Food is simple and fresh. Salsas are authentic and flavorful, but there are only 3 choices - pico de gallo, green tomatillo, or spicy red. I'm confused by the guacamole though. It is too perfect. I know that is a weird complaint. Something is up with the guac - it is perfectly smooth and has a perfect amount lime flavor which makes me suspicious. Sides are rice, beans, veggies, mac&cheese, potato salad etc. I just ordered the chicken with a side of guac. Can't go wrong.

You can see the chickens cooking on the grill when you order so you know it's fresh. They also can make chicken enchiladas or chicken tacos - or you can just do like me and order a leg and a drumstick ren-faire style. Huzzah!

Couple of downsides: ambiance is lacking. This place has all the charm of a converted truck stop donut shop. The complimentary forks and knives are cheap and not so great for carving up chicken, so if you do order meat on the bone, your best course of action is probably teeth.





(SECRET REVIEW EASTER EGG!!) Doesn't this logo have a strong Los Pollos Hermanos vibe? Makes me wanna call Saul..."]

name: Panda House Stir-Fry
categories_raw: Chinese, Restaurants, Vietnamese
top_reviews:
["Probably one of my favorite restaurants in Tucson. Let's just be clear on this whole buffet part. I'll tell you right now, you're not coming for the fried rice, lo mein or soups if you're doing the buffet. It's all about the stir fry and the right mix of sauces. Personally, I keep it very simple. Noodles, broccoli, steak and house sauce. Yes the fried rice and soup with crunchy noodles are a nice touch but they aren't all that great. The stir fry however is addicting. My boyfriend and I have been coming to this place for months now. We're seriously there about once a week. Staff is super friendly and attentive and we usually get seated right away. We've never even ordered off the regular menu because we always choose the buffet option. This is a place we will continue to dine at regularly. Food is just too good to resist.", "Panda House Stir-Fry, let me count the ways that I love thee. I last ate here in the 1990s. Apparently the owners have not changed, and this place is sparkling clean. It looks brand new. It was a good sign when my friend, Mark, and I arrived; I felt right at ease, we settled into a seat, and dove for the all you can eat stir fry. 

And then it just got BETTER. The experience was legendary. 

The selection is fantastic. Healthy bok chop, broccoli, carrots, pork beef and chicken, sprouts, sauces, various noodles. You mix it all into a bowl exactly what you whatever quantity. You want nothing but egg noodles? Go for it. Just a big bowl of beef? Sure! Genghis Grill eat your heart out, they have nothing on Panda House. Hand your bowl to the chef and they'll wok it up for you in a few minutes, served to your table steaming hot and ready to go. In the mean time, we grab a plate and can eat some white/fried rice, noodles and egg flower or hot and sour soup. Mmmm! 

We both went through two bowls of the all you can eat. I swear I thought they would change the all you can eat rules after I was done (she was smart and made a smaller portion bowl, but my mouth was bigger than my stomach!) There was endless delicious cold ice tea to wash down all the sodium. 

It's about 10-11 bucks to eat so it's not cheap on the surface but if you consider how much food you get and exactly what you want, in a very clean nice environment, then Panda House should be on your radar. Skip Genghis and get the real thing, a Tucson based treasure. Panda House, I will be seeing you again.", 'I have come here many times over the years, and in my personal experience this place has gone down hill. Our reason for coming has always been fresh ingredients as you go down the line. But over the past few years the offerings have never changed and they are always out of have numerous items. 

What is more, is both my partner and I have noticed it has become dirtier and dirtier. Variety is the spice of life, and I certainly wish this place will get a little more spice. We keep coming back wishing for more as it is one of the few grills on our side of town. Just a real letdown for both of us.']

name: Bisbee Breakfast Club
categories_raw: Restaurants, American (Traditional), Breakfast & Brunch
top_reviews:
["Bisbee Breakfast Club is the perfect example of what a Yelp Five Star rating should be.

Awesome menu, great prices, delicious food, clean establishment, and oh yes... terrific service.

We walked in and were greeted by a friendly smile.  We had the amazing server Shelby. She didn't hand my friend a menu as she remembered what he always gets. I was amazed by the numerous breakfast selections. They have everything from omelette's to pancakes and even delicious scrambled eggs topped with any type of protein or cheese you can think of.

The restaurant was crowded; however, our food came in less than 10 minutes.  Both our breakfasts were served hot & freshly made, even the bacon was cooked to order.  Shelby came by several times and filled the coffee & water. 

All the waitstaff are very attentive however I highly recommend asking for Shelby as she is awesome.

FIVE STARS for great service, delicious & abundant food, and great prices as I highly recommend this place!", "Sunday Brunch with my fellow hungry girls. We've been to the location on Sunrise drive. Was good experience for breakfast so we thought we would try out the Wilmot location. Even on Father's Day we were able to get a table in 15mins. Robert was our awesome waiter/server. We ordered Cold Brew, Coffee, Water to drink. Crazy Burro, Cornbeef Hash, Blue Granola Pancakes, & D's Potato Cakes. We didn't make a dent in the pancakes but got it boxed to go. Everything else was cleaned off the plates. Great tasting food. Space was nice & open Tables are large. I'm tall so it's nice to be able to stretch out a bit while I eat & visit. Robert did not rush us at all. Very pleased with our filling tasty brunch out. We will definitely be back with more hungry friends.", 'It was our traditional breakfast on the day before the first day of school.  We decided to go to BBC on Wilmot because they let you call ahead if you are on your way.  Having re-acquainted myself with the joy that is biscuits and gravy, I decided to get the chuck biscuits (2 biscuits, gravy, chopped bacon , ham and sausage, and cheese)- I had forgotten that the last time I came here I got a single biscuit because this thing was HUGE!  and so very tasty!  My dining companions got a half portion of french toast (still huge), a short stack of pancakes that fill the plate (and the stomach) and an omelette.  Beautiful hot cocoas for the adolescents, coffee for me and OJ for the spouse.  It was a delicious meal and we took home three doggy bags!']

name: Arizona Pest Control Company
categories_raw: Home Services, Home Inspectors, Pest Control, Professional Services, Local Services
top_reviews:
["I am an East Coast transplant who is still terrified of her desert surroundings. Today, one of my cats was going nuts at the glass door, so I went to investigate. At eye-level on the wall outside was THE MOST ENORMOUS SPIDER I HAVE EVER SEEN. I didn't know what to do. It had a 3 in + legspan. I wasn't about to try to get it in a jar or bowl because I am a pansy. So with some google-fu, I found AZ Pest Control. When I called, I got their answering service. I felt pretty silly reporting a Spider Emergency, but I was connected to a very nice man who said they would send someone out as soon as they could. I sat waiting, watching Spiderbro meander around my Arizona room until Stephen showed up. Professional, friendly and helpful, Stephen caught my spider and promised it a good life as a star of the Home Show and school visits. I'm glad the spider will get to live a pampered spidey life and I don't have to have a heart attack when I go out to do my laundry.

THEN, as I was signing up for regular pest treatments, Stephen explained how the company has honey bee hives with the bees they humanely remove from residences. HOW AWESOME IS THAT?! He gave me a jar of desert honey! From the bees they rescue! I'm all about pest control because I am a pansy, but I would really rather not kill everything. The fact that this company strikes a balance between NUKE EM ALL and rescuing is really appealing. 

This was a wonderful experience and Spidergate 2014 ended humanely and, deliciously?", "I was unable to eliminate the ant issue occurring in my kitchen by myself, so I called AZ Pest Control.  The 3 stars is based on the price factor.  $150?? What??!  Come on...give me a deal as a new customer.  It makes a big difference!  I like deals. The deal they offer is lame (if I had purchased a package deal, I would've saved $25 today).  If my review was based only on customer service, it would be a 5.  Cindy, who scheduled my appointment was great.  I called on a Thursday and my original appt was scheduled for Saturday morning.  Cindy called me a shortly after i scheduled and said she could have someone come the next day instead.  That was ideal.  The sooner someone could come and assist my ant situation, the better!  Gabriel was on time, which was a bonus. I like that they don't give you an estimated time (someone will come between 8-12 business).  My appt was scheduled for 8:30 and he arrived at 8:25. Gabriel found the entry areas of the ants invading my home and got out all of his tricks, so I am hopeful that they will leave my condo and find another place to visit.  He also told me that vinegar, not bleach should be my go to solution when ants occur.  I would like to say I would use AZ Pest Control again, but I will do some price shopping first.", 'AZ pest control serviced two of my properties and I was completely happy with the sales process, scheduling, and treatment. They were prompt, polite, and thorough. So why have I downgraded my review from 5 stars (which they nag you for, btw) to 2 stars? 

Because as soon as the 1-year anniversary came around where I had the opportunity to extend the first warranty, they began badgering me with fake invoices 100% disguised to look like I was obligated to renew (I'm not), nagging phone calls, emails, and automated phone calls, EVEN after I called and politely (the first time) explained I did not plan to purchase an extension.

Nothing says "We are a shady company" like mock invoices, and this company's inability to accept my simple "thanks, no thanks"  turned them into worse pests than the ones I hired them to get rid of.

Next time I'll look elsewhere.']

name: Berry Divine Acai Bowls
categories_raw: Food, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Acai Bowls
top_reviews: ["A simple review for a simple dish. Berry Divine delivers on what they're meant to do. I've had both smoothie and bowl; I prefer the bowls. The staff is always so kind and helpful whenever I have a question. Never once been disappointed!", "During these especially challenging times with the pandemic- online ordering is queen! Berry Divine makes it easy to order and pay online, which I appreciate immensely. I ordered the regular size traditional cleanse açaí bowl. There's nothing small about it! The portions are very generous and my container/bowl was so full I made a mess opening it up! I chose the cleanse bowl since it seemed to have less sugar than other options. It was the perfect afternoon pick me up and super refreshing. It was ready within 10 minutes.", "Such a great spot in downtown Tucson! The staff is friendly and the food is delicious! It takes a while for the bowls to be made, but the wait is worth it. All The ingredients are fresh and the bowls are filled to the top. \n\nI ordered the Brazilian Bowl and can't wait to try the others. I will for sure come back!"]

name: Discount Tire
categories_raw: Tires, Wheel & Rim Repair, Automotive, Auto Repair, Auto Parts & Supplies
top_reviews:
['Great customer service! Brought in a flat tire (I was riding around on my old tire, which I use as a spare b/c it is still in decent condition). CHAD said he would be happy to try to patch my tire. It was a huge hole...I had run over an Alan wrench that someone had thrown in the intersection! Grrrrrrr. =P

It only took about half an hour, even tho I was a walk-in! On top of that, he found that my tire was still under warranty, so it was a free service! Will definitely continue coming here....customer service is friendly and personal here vs. other places. Even if they charged me more than other places, it would be with it. :)', 'I got a nail in my tire right at the borderline patch point. I first took my car to Walmart and the technicians refused to even look at it. Told me the only thing I can buy is for $180.00 . I can't afford that today so I called these guys to see if I can have a new less expensive tire put on. I was in luck, they did and they could ... the turning point in this story that took my experience from "great, $115.00 that I really needed to allocate to something else" to "tears of joy" was when Esteban looked at the tire and said "you know what, I bet we can repair this and save you money". The fact that he looked at it and said he would try was good enough for me!  Took about 45 minutes all together at about 2:30 in the afternoon to get done and when Esteban came back around to check on the customers in the lobby he gave me good news. It was repairable! He saved this mother of 3 money! I really enjoyed the friendly customer service. Thank you so much!', "I got the tire repaired by the place where I bought it in San Diego... for free.

So not only was it overpriced and over two and a half hours to put on... it wasn't even needed. Flat out lies."]

name: Dillinger Brewing Company
categories_raw: Breweries, Food
top_reviews:
["This place is so cool! Everything from the name, location, and the little details in the brewery make this a really fun place to go. 
Opening weekend the beer choices were Serano Seduction, Desert Wheat, and Lock Down Brown. My favorite was Serano Seduction - definite taste of Green Chili and s a little spicy.
The employees and owners were super friendly and you can definitely tell they are very dedicated to beer and the brewing culture. 
The whole brewery is very OCD clean and organized, which I love. 
I am really excited to have Dillinger's here in the area and I will be back!", 'Great little brewery, nice folks, good beer. A little hard to find at the end of the complex. Loved the one with green chillies.', "I love Dillinger Brewing Company! I remember I first tried the Serrano Seduction at another brewery in town and was instantly hooked, as I had never had such a unique and delicious beer. It's a wheat beer brewed with Serrano peppers and hatch green chiles. That's my go to whenever I get the chance to go to Dillinger. So amazing! 

I took my family here last night for the first time, as I had a living social coupon for 4 pints and two flights. A great deal! They had never been to Dillinger but enjoyed the beer and the relaxed atmosphere.

The place can be a little hard to find and the location is kind of weird, but overall it seems to work. It's not a pretentious place; just a chill little brewery with some of the best beer in Tucson."]

name: Casa Blanca Cuban Grill
categories_raw: Cuban, Food, Latin American, Restaurants, Spanish, Caribbean, Food Trucks
top_reviews:
['Once upon a time I thought Cuban food was the second most delicious thing to have roots in that beautiful and beleaguered country.  The most delicous thing?  Andy Garcia.

While I still so appreciate how yummy is Mr. Garcia, time passes and at my age priorities realign to put him in second place.  Now my vote for the most delicious thing with Cuban heritage is the food.

How lucky are we in the Boise area to have remarkable Cuban food in this independently owned restaurant where pride of ownership shines in every detail.  From the ambiance, to the service, to the food it is all fantabulous.

Gems like this are rare.  They can be fleeting given so much depends on the people who own it and cook the food wanting to continue to do that.  Enjoy it now.

VIBE
"Welcome to Cuba" says the little sign near the cash register as you enter.  But even if you didn't see that sign, you might know where you were.  The Cuban music playing at just the right level on the sound system, the aroma of garlic and braising pork, rice, toasting bread and simmering beans, the warm colors, the tile floors and wood tables, the photos and posters of Cuba on the walls; on each visit you'll likely notice some new detail.  Like the lyrical hum of some of the diners and staff speaking Spanish, a beautiful language that in this restaurant sounds especially so.  It sparkles in every sense of the word, from the greeting at the door, to the pristinely clean surroundings, to the stellar service to the flavors in the food.

SEATING
Comfortable chairs at standard height (hooray) tables throughout.  Some tucked into alcoves, some in the center of the room, some in a separate room (a great spot for a private party).   My husband and I particularly appreciate that even if full house the seating is arranged in a way that one feels they have 'elbow room'. 

SERVICE
Welcoming, friendly, gracious, efficient, delightful.  This has been a perfect experience for us on each visit from the beautiful young woman who was covering the entire restaurant.  Top notch.

MENU / FOOD / VALUE
The multi page menu is the same from opening at 11a through dinner service that ends at 9p.  You'll find appetizers, entrees, sandwiches and sides all of traditional Cuban food.

Don't miss the soup list on the back page.  In addition to the delicious black bean soup served daily there is a special soup for each day of the week.  If you go on Thursdays, do not miss the garbanzo bean soup that has a wonderful full flavored broth with pork and potatoes.  Remember that tip.  And note if you order a sandwich you can substitute a cup of soup for the fries that come as normal side for only a $1.99 extra.  Leave the fries.  Order the soup.  You'll thank me.

You can't miss with anything on the menu.  The tostones con mojo (fried plantains with garlicky mojo sauce for dipping) are wonderful. ($3.99)  So are the black beans.  And the sweet plantains.  My husband loved the bacalau, a cod dish simmered with tomato and bell pepper sauce with potatoes.  ($11.99)   Braised pork shoulder asado with onions is served with a side of black beans mixed with rice and also yucca with garlic that is scrumptious.  (And a bargain at $9.99.)  You'll find shrimp dishes and classic chicken dishes, like arroz con pollo, and sandwiches including the ever popular Cubano.  Sandwiches (around $8) are large easily shared by two, and stand out not just for the perfectly crafted fillings but for the Cuban styled bread on which they are served.

Portions are generous and we always eat very well here with leftovers to take away for just about $30 for two people and that includes a couple of beverages and always (always!) a dessert to share.  Look at the dessert card on the table (beverages on the flip side) and save room.  I recommend the Flan de Coco, a dense coconut flan drizzled with real caramel or the Cuban chocolate pudding. (Each about $4.00)

LIBATIONS
Soft drinks, bottled beers domestic and imported, a few wines by the glass and housemade Sangria ($4.50).  The Sangria is delicious.  So is the Cuban Espresso ($2.50) made with coffee brought in from Miami; the perfect counterpoint to any dessert.

THIS N THAT:

1) PARKING: Private lot.

2) ACCESSIBILITY: No marked accessible parking in the lot. There is a curb ramp accessing the sidewalk at the front door. Level iin and throughout. Single stall in loo likely too narrow for people who cannot stand and step in.

3) 7 DAYS A WEEK:  It must be exhausting and daunting to be open every day of the week in a small restaurant ilke this.  Hats off to them!

4) FOOD TRUCK TOO?:  Note a spiffy looking food trudk sometimes parked behind the restaurant.   Seems as if it is a mobile until for the Casa Blanca sandwhiches.', "Due to my extensive travel history, I have built a very strong and picky tongue for authenticity. That being said, I can tell you Casablanca is the real damn deal. I'm about to tell you why. 

The entire menu at Casablanca is filled with what you'd find at a typical restaurant in Havana. I recognized many dishes that I've dined on and they were all delicious, so it was hard for me to make a decision. During my first visit I bellied up to the world-famous Sandwich Cubano (roasted pork, ham, pickles, Swiss cheese and mustard on a Cuban style bread). Man, I tell you, it was SPOT ON. Reminded me of my trip years ago when I had my first one. The meat was roasted to perfection, delivered a dynamite of flavor and was too damn good to stop eating! If you try one thing here, this is it!

On another occasion I was served the Ropa Vieja (shredded beef in Cuban Creole sauce with onions and peppers. Served with white rice, black beans and sweet ripe plantains (maduros)). This also happens to be Cuba's national dish! Again, each bite took me back to Havana. Sweet, delicate and tender beef paired with fresh cooked rice and beans. The taste was outstanding. Boise lacks so many authentic cuisine but Casablanca reminds me that true food is there if you seek it. 

On another note, I absolutely loved our waiter both times. He was very kindhearted and humorous, took time to inform us of what each dish consisted of, which was super helpful for my very Americanized husband (nothing wrong with that - he just doesn't have the palate for authentic food like I do!). 

In a heartbeat, I recommend this to anyone who is tired of over-sweetened, sodium packed eateries that boast but fail to deliver genuine cuisine. Also, if you've never had Cuban food you are missing out on so much!!! And it's here, in little Boise so HEAD OVER AND SUPPORT THIS LOCAL BUSINESS that I love so dearly!", 'I had been wanting to try this place out for quite a while, and for some reason never made the time. Located on overland, between orchard and Curtis, this place was delightful. I was looking forward to having tostones (fried plantains) again. Haven't had them since I was a kid living in Puerto Rico. They weren't as good as I remember them being as a child. I'll have to pick up some plantains the next time I see them at the grocery store and make my own. 

We started with the tostones and Casablanca's chorizo croquetas. Described as "six savory flour based rolls lightly breaded and fried to a golden brown. Available in three flavors: Ham, Cod fish, and Chorizo". I love croquetas. The amazing ones from Bar Gernika/Manfreds come to mind. These were also delicious! Different, in a good way.

I was going to order the Arroz con pollo (rice with chicken), but that's what my wife wanted to order, so I went with the ropa vieja. "Affectionately called old clothes in Spanish. Shredded beef in Cuban creole sauce with onions and peppers. Served with white rice, black beans, and sweet ripe plantains." This was very good. The sauce made this exceptionally tasty. The beans were some of the best I have had in a while. The only downfall, again, was the plantains. Everything else was quite good. My wife's dish was delicious, and I got to try my father in law's cubano sandwich. Really quite delicious. I highly recommend this place if you want to try something a little different.']

name: Prost! Boise
categories_raw: German, Nightlife, Pubs, Beer Bar, Bars, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Gutes essen und gutes bier. 

Prost was something of a lucky find. Not only do they serve amazing food and beer, but the name itself has a special place in mine and my best friend's heart. Prost means Cheers in German, which happens to be the name of the show we just religiously watched, and loved. 

The inside of the restaurant is small, but they also house a lot of seats outside as well.

 I ordered the Bratwurst sandwich, which came with gherkin, and a side of German potato salad. The sandwich was out of this world. The sausage was huge, the homemade mustard and ketchup tasted unbelievable, and the mound of sauerkraut was the cherry on top. Everything tasted simply incredible. The sandwich came with a small side salad, with a dressing that tasted like tzatziki sauce. The German potato salad was not overly mushy, and it actually tasted like potatoes. 

I ordered the Warsteiner Oktoberfest bier, which had beautiful color, and tasted great; however, it did have a big head on it. It went perfectly with my sandwich. What I also love about the bier is that they serve them in glasses with the bier names on them.

The service was friendly, but not very attentive. Our waitress came by once when we weren't ready to order, and when we were ready she was nowhere to be seen for over five minutes. In a place this small, I would expect that time to be way less.

I would highly recommend checking this place out if you're in the area, and you're in the mood for something tasty and unique.", "If you love German food, then this place is the place to be! It's really amazing and the beers are fantastic! 

Seriously, the only reason I'm giving it four star is because I WISH the menu was bigger! I love their food, and if you've seen my tips, then you'll know that Ithink they have the best Potato Salad ever! German style of course....but still.

Beers are all cold and amazing..and I want to talk like Klaus from American Dad when I'm there. It's great! Please go! If you've been, go again! And AGAIN! AND AGAIN!", "If you want to indulge in fun, full bodied, robust beers, Prost! is the place for you.  In addition to their regular list of biers, they also have some pretty tasty specials.  I ordered the Andechs Doppelbock (dark roasted malt, notes of cocoa with a dried fruit aroma).  I don't know about the aroma, but it was surprising light and easy on the palate for a dark beer.  I enjoyed it very much but one was plenty for me.  

The menu leans toward more traditional, heavy pub food, so I ordered the Ruben Salat (marinated beet salad) and I forgot to order the dressing on the side, but it was dressed perfectly anyway.  My friends and I also ordered the cabbage rolls special.  We were expecting something more like a stuffed cabbage roll, but these came as ground beef and cabbage encased in bread rolls.  It's a good thing we split the order, but even so, I ended up breaking it open and eating the center.  It was just had too much bread and I thought it overwhelmed the taste of the filling.

The atmosphere is open, loud, and boisterous so not a place for a quite conversation.  Our service was great and I will definitely be back again."]

name: Diggs Pizza
categories_raw: Pizza, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Reviewer # 44

When I walked in with 4 kids, my partner, and my mother and noticed how small the area is, I was concerned. We wanted to go out to a pizza place and eat, play games, and enjoy our time. I looked up pizza with the highest ratings in our area and Diggs looked delicious and it didn't disappoint. The person working the counter ended up moving two tables together and we all could fit comfortably. 

I ordered one extra large pizza (pics attached) and although I didn't taste the pizza due to dietary restrictions, my family loved it. My kids and nephew were telling me how they want to come here all the time, which made me feel happy because I like to make my mom and kids happy. The pizza was extremely cheesy and the toppings were fierce. I got a salad and it was very large that I shared with my whole crew. 

They have 2 liters for you to purchase and dine in customer get free bottles of water. Their ranch dressing was very good. 

They have other food, too. I took my son home finger steaks and he enjoyed them. There aren't any games, and is extremely small space, but the people working there took good attentive care of us and made the best of the space. 

We will surly visit again. It's on the other side of town, so it won't be often, but we will go over there again for this place. 

Thank you Digg's Pizza staff!", "I've been seeing Diggs pop up on Yelp's delivery suggestions. I wondered where the heck this said pizza place was, and who knew it was only 5 minutes from my house! Possible the greatest discovery of the month, for more reasons that it's convenient location. 

I prefer to keep things simple when testing out new pizza joints. Call it an entrance exam. If a pizza joint can't produce a decent pepperoni pizza is it even really a pizza joint? So after examining Digg's very extensive and intriguing menu all I ordered was a large pepperoni ($16.44). Their prices are kind of random but very reasonable for the quality and size. Holy smokes it was delicious! They definitely don't go light on the pepperoni! My pizza was nearly completely covered. Also, there was so. much. CHEESE! I had to use two hands to eat because if I only used one everything would fall off and all I'd get was a slice of bread covered in marinara sauce. Such good pizza I can't believe I didn't know this gem of a place was only 3 miles from me!

Now that Digg's has passed my entrance exam, I look forward to trying one of their more exotic pizza flavors.", "As a restaurant owner, I love the opportunity to leave positive reviews on other restaurants that stand out above the rest.  Today we tried Diggs Pizza for the first time.  We are always looking for new venues and we are so extremely pleased we found Diggs online.

First off, we were happy they deliver out in far South Boise.  When we called the gentleman that took our order was polite and informative.  The delivery took around 45 minutes which is totally acceptable due to where we live.  The gal that delivered the goods was very happy.  The first thing I noticed when the delivery was handed to me was how heavy a small pizza, medium pizza and a salad was.  The first bites were nothing short of incredible.  The pizzas were loaded with probably double the toppings of any other pizza we have every had.  Everything was so fresh and amazingly good.  Let's just say that after two slices I was stuffed.  My wife and son also couldn't believe what we were indulging.  Let's just say that we never made it to the awesome looking salad, but we will tomorrow.  That is a meal in itself.

Bottom line, this is a 10 star restaurant."]

name: Big City Coffee
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Breakfast & Brunch, Restaurants, Food, Bakeries
top_reviews:
["Tried to go this morning and found it absolutely packed. Which it always has been, but times have changed, man. I don't understand why they're not limiting the number of patrons in the building. I don't understand why they're not having customers wait outside. I don't understand why they're not enforcing social distancing AT ALL. 

I mean, I do. They make their political leanings very clear. Thin blue line right on the door.

Shame too, I used to like this place. Fuck that. Black Lives Matter. Masks and distancing save lives. There are plenty of other brunch places in Boise.", "The first time I visited in 2/2016, I wasn't impressed. Today I visited and I was super impressed; therefore, I am updating my review from a 2 to a 5 (would do 4.5 if I could) and here is why. 

I walked in with one of my besties, Yesi, and the place was packed. Even the front tables were full and it was only 50 degrees outside. The line took about 10 minutes. Someone came out and took our order as we stood. The service was great, the atmosphere was on point, the food was amazing! We were able to sit at the big table in the middle with strangers, which to me, was super fun and enjoyable. Felt like I was back in High School sitting with the popular people-- only I didn't get shunned away this time--- kidding! ... well, kinda :) 

I got the refinery scramble with turkey ($8.99). It was huge! The eggs were super fluffy and had good chunks of real carved turkey (not lunch meat) and came with fresh fruit (see photos). My dining companion got a 1/2 order of biscuits and gravy with bacon on top and it was a very large portion and she said it tasted very good. 

Their pastries look amazing. I bought my kids a cinnamon roll and it was very big. They said it was very good and not dry. This is a great place to bring out of towners or friends that have never been. Sharing a plate is my suggestion, though. The portions are very, very big and the prices are affordable.", "We were visiting the city and really enjoyed the vibes here. Cozy and busy. The moment when we walked in we could feel this is a community and local favorite. 

We waited in line for about 10 mins and read the big menu trying to decide what to get. I ordered the bacon and spinach quiche with fruits, and hubby ordered the Deluxe bagel sandwich. We waited at our table for another 20 mins before getting our food. The quiche was absolutely delicious and worth the wait. Fresh and hot out of oven - it's savory and rich. The fruits on side were refreshing. 

Hubby thought his meaty bagel sandwich was good but could be warmer - maybe the kitchen finished making the bagel sandwich first and waited for the quiche to cook in the oven. I think if you are ordering something along with a quiche,  you should know that the quiche could take a longer time to cook and your other food orders could turn cold a bit because of that."]

name: Idaho Botanical Garden
categories_raw: Museums, Event Planning & Services, Venues & Event Spaces, Arts & Entertainment, Botanical Gardens
categories: ['museums', 'event planning & services', 'venues & event spaces', 'arts & entertainment', 'botanical gardens']
top_reviews:
['I was a little underwhelmed by the Idaho Botanical Garden, but I appreciate the effort of showing off the beauty of nature in the area. The garden is directly next door to the Old Penitentiary east of downtown Boise. Parking is free and abundant. 

The gardens have clearly evolved over the years with the older exhibits lacking the detail and labeling of the newer ones. The classic English and meditation gardens are lush and attractive, but lack much description. The newer sections have much more information and structure. 

The garden is a bit awkward to navigate especially with morning field trips and classes. It can get hot here during the summer so be prepared. This would be a nice combination trip with the penitentiary in cool weather. With so much natural beauty in and around Boise, there is just too much competition outside the garden!', 'An old guard tower from the abandoned State Penitentiary caught my eye as I admired a sculpture in the Idaho Botanical Garden.  It took me back for a moment, to think of people once incarcerated at this spot where I was enjoying the freedom to roam a beautiful place created among stark surrounds.  My husband and I went in for what we thought might be an hour visit and ended up enjoying more than two hours with so much to see.  With a modest entry fee, multiple garden themes and good accessibility this is recommended for Boise visitors of all ages for however much or little time you choose to spend.  A tip if you're there in warm months, as we were, take sun protection and water!

ENTRY
You enter the garden site from the grounds of the old penitentiary.  (Also open for visiting.)  We were confused about how to get into the garden itself, so offer this heads up: turn right at the small garden administration building and you'll see a kiosk to pay your admission ($5 for adult) fee to the garden then continue driving up until you get to the gravel lot just outside the garden's entry.

LAYOUT
The garden is on 33 acres leased from State with about 15 acres developed into roughly 15 different themed areas that rise in elevation from lower to middle and upper gardens demonstrating four habitats.  As examples: on the lower (entry level) you'll find English and Rose gardens, then rising up through areas like Herb and Meditation and Children's gardens and on up to Lewis and Clark Native gardens.  The latter, installed in 2006 I learned, was my favorite with the chirping sounds of  big covey of quail running through the plantings, a round house structure with a plant roof and at the highest point a great view out over the old Penitentiary and towards the city.   

SCULPTURES & ART
Recycled material sculptures, bronze sculptures and other art installations are throughout the garden created an outdoor gallery of sorts among the plantings. 

PATHWAYS
Slopes can be steep in some places given the natural elevation of the site but the folks who designed the garden have done a good job of leveling out the cross slopes of the pathways so people pushing strollers or using wheelchairs should find them navigable.  Surfacing of most, but not all, of the garden is firm and stable and installed it seems with the idea of being appropriate to the theme of that particular garden area.  As examples: cobblestone pavers in the English Garden, brick pavers in the Rose Garden outlook, hard pack dirt surfaces on some other trails and so on.  The most accessible surfacing is at the higher elevation gardens with broom swept cement.  The flaws for accessible connectivity include the grassy meditation garden, some rough patches of gravel covered pathways between areas and that the parking lot is loose gravel to be navigated before getting to the firm surfacing at the entry.  (Anyone who has pushed a stroller across deep grass or loose gravel knows why that doesnt' work for a wheelchair or crutches either.)

UNIQUE TREEHOUSE
"Woohoo worthy" is a treehouse that seems to have been recently installed at the Children's Garden.  That treehouse is set up in universal access design that allows children using wheelchairs  to have level in access from a pathway and participate along with all others.  Very nice.  Having seen children with disabilities being left on the sidelines again and again, this was a delightful element.  Of course, this works too for children beng pushed in strollers.  And PS - for parents using wheelchairs, as in my acquaintance whose legs were severed in Iraq, it is equally cool for him to be able to join his toddler son there as all other dads might do.  Everyone wins.
 
SEASONAL EVENTS

SUMMER: Hosts occasional public concerts about which we heard a lot of kudos from locals. Also other monthly events (like cooking and food showcase) that are public.   

WINTER:  Lit for the season with thousands of lights in "Garden Glow" which starts on Thanksgiving Day and runs through January 5.  Santa themed elements are included for kids and kids at heart.  Glow event is evenings only, roughly 6p - 9p.  (Higher entry fee may apply?  Check with the garden.)  Open Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and Day, New Years' Eve and Day. 

THIS N THAT:

1) SWEAT & FUNDING:  Land is leased by a private non profit from the State of Idaho and is funded by donations and entry fees; receives no government funding.  The gardens, all designed and cultivated since 1981, are lovingly maintained by staff and volunteers.  

2) HOURS VARY WITH SEASON:  March - November: 7 days a week roughly 9a to 9p (or dusk whichever is sooner).  Check garden site for winter hours.  

3) FREE ENTRY MORNING STROLL:  During some months there are no entry fees from 7:30a - 9:00a.   Can't think of a more beautiful time of day to visit this peaceful place. 

4) PETS:  None allowed.', "The Idaho Botanical Garden offers a 15 acre lush, blooming paradise just a few short minutes from downtown Boise. 

A few of my favorite things about the garden:

+ I love the area that shows the different sorts of lawn, how it grows, and what it looks like in Idaho's climate. A surprisingly handy thing when you're purchasing lawn seed.
+I love that they display indigenous plants that flourish here without watering (aside from natural rain/snow)
+Outlaw Field! Great concerts in a beautiful setting!
+The fact that you can bring in a picnic! We did this last Mother's Day and it was a lovely treat. There are tables here and there at picturesque spots throughout the gardens, so we were able to dine amidst colorful abundance 
+October Fall Harvest Festival, The Scarecrow Stroll, and Winter Garden Aglow!  

A relaxing, gorgeous, and reasonably priced (general admission is $7) way to spend an afternoon. 

Get to it!"]

name: Egg Mann and Earl
categories_raw: Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch
top_reviews:
['This is an awesome place for breakfast.

Our server was smoking hot, funny, and joy to be around. 

Food was awesome well cooked to perfection. Great presentation and big portions.

The decor is strange but who cares when you get great food and service.', "Incredible Brunch Experience

 Eggman and Early made me feel like I was living in a 1990s Video Game while having an Incredible Brunch Experience...

Right when you walk in you cant help but notice the super wacky decorations that make you smile ear to ear and they are literally EVERYWHERE. Being it is Covid times and the tables need to be spread apart they went the extra mile(s) and had cool characters at each table. This made the place feel full and warm even at limited seating capacity.

The waitress was hustling and in great spirits. Encouraging me to take more pictures and making sure my glass was always full.

The food was excellent. The complimentary scone was light, warm, just the right amount of sweet and a perfect start. I ordered the French Toast and the Seasoned Red Potatoes and WoWZers I was really blown away. Super seasoned, cooked to perfection. It was like a Fiesta on my tongue and I just wanted to keep dancing.

I'm loving this place and will have to return with my wife so she can get the experience as well. Thank you Eggman and Earl and to all the staff who make this magical place happen. I will Definitely be back SOON!!!", "The Northern Lights was a South East Boise institution.  I ate there more times that I can count. The food was always top notch and the staff treated me and the people who frequented like family. Needless to say, I was saddened to see them close their doors in 2017.

However, we didn't have to be down for too long, a new breakfast place has come to carry on the wonderful legacy of the Northern Lights: Egg Man and Earl.

Run by the same woman who owns ZeroSix Coffee on Parkcenter, Eggman offers wonderful eating experience. The staff is equally welcoming, the food is just as good, and the overall positive energy of the Northern Lights has been maintained (and by many ways evolved).

The prices are very fair, the eggs are amazing, and the coffee is second to none."]

name: Fujiyama
categories_raw: Japanese, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Think about it: 

- you are in Boise, Idaho, a place called the "City of Trees" only because everywhere outside this valley are foothills covered with prairie tumbleweed and prairie dog poo, with nary a tree in sight.
- you are farther east and farther inland than Las Vegas, Nevada
- you are in a place better known for potatoes than rice
- the Asian population is miniscule

So why are you looking for Sushi here? 

Turns out, Fujiyama, which means Mount Fuji and is named after the famous, perfectly coned shaped tallest mountain in Japan so ingrained in its heritage, art and lore, is the name of this restaurant. They have bright pictures of Fujiyama behind the sushi bar, and truth be told, the sushi is not bad, all the above considered! 

Although it is definitely decorated in a motif decidely Japanese restaurant, the place is Chinese owned (for the past 9 years), operated and staffed. The owners are a youngish couple from Fujian, China, and speak Mandarin to their little toddler child. The sushi chefs are pretty decent, and are also Chinese. And the waitresses are also CHinese, but speak English. So save your Japanese or Korean, and practice your hsieh hsieh in poh tung wua.  

Unlike so many Korean and Chinese owned sushi-ya in other cities (i.e. most of California) that scrimp on the rice balls, and cut the sushi too thin so it appears like you are getting more than you deserve, these guys conform their sushi rice balls pretty close to what you find in Japan,and their slices of fish are close, too. They don't put a dab of wasabi under the fish like you would find on 95% of sushi in Japan, but most places here don't do this, and rather in the American tradition, let you put the wasabi in your soy sauce dish to taste. (In Japan, usually the wasabi is in the sushi, and you dip it only in soy sauce.) But most people would be confused by this here. 

They have a large menu, and they offer a lot more than sushi, with a good selection of other hot dishes from the kitchen, and the typical appetizers and casual dishes.

The service is quick and polite, and the presentation is good. I had my standard Nigiri selections and my associate had sashimi and was satisfied. We had edamame, 2 bowls of miso soup, and a double scoop of green tea ice cream dessert, gren tea, a diet coke, all for under $60 for two. 

This is perhaps the best sushi place in Boise, Idaho. It's average for the sushi haven cities on the west coast, but above average for Boise and above average for a Chinese owned sushi restaurant. I would come back.

So why are you looking for Sushi in Boise? 

Wo bo ju dou! 
(Wakaranai)
(I don't know)', "Fujiyama has been a Boise staple for years. And for good reason. Their West Boise location is cozy, with private, screened rooms for intimacy and a bar where you can sidle up and watch all that tasty sushi being made. 

I've been a customer for a long while. I tend to go during lunch. They have excellent bento box prices and I always leave full. My favorites are the salmon bento and spicy salmon roll. I've never been disappointed on taste or quality. Sometimes my stomach objects to certain sushi restaurants, but never Fujiyama. 

If you dine in the evening, you may be treated to a free bowl of edamame or another simple but tasty appetizer. The waitstaff are all veterans and service is typically attentive and fast. The specials are listed on a white board near the sushi counter. While I'm not an adventurous eater when it comes to sushi, my friends are always pleased with their more exotic sushi creations. 

Get to Fujiyama for a consistent, tasty fish fix!", "Stopped in for lunch, had a great meal. In a strip mall near the Towne Square shopping center, they had private rooms as well as the normal eating area. We found a lunch special that was amazing - soup, salad, a combination of sushi and sashimi, as well as something OTHER than a traditional california roll (eel avocado roll).

Our nephew from Florida had a similar special, but his roll was a dynamite roll with spicy salmon.

They also had no problems substituting whitefish for ebi given my wife has a shrimp allergy.

Although we didn't have any dinner items, the lunch impressed us enough to ask for a take out menu which we are looking at to decide what to get when we go back!"]

name: Sakana Sushi Bar and Grill
categories_raw: Sushi Bars, Soup, Restaurants, Japanese
top_reviews:
["Beautiful and delicious sushi! We've been driving by this place for quite awhile, but stopped in today on a whim. Don't let the exterior fool you. It's clean, tastefully decorated, and well-priced. They also come around with dollar sampler plates, which make it a fun, cheap way to try different kinds of sushi. Stop in for a great meal on the bench!", "I dig this place. Sure, it's not a fancy building in a fancy location, but that's why their prices are reasonable; they're not paying exorbitant downtown Boise rent. I'll happily go to this place vs. a more expensive downtown location, especially since their rolls and food are really tasty and reasonably priced. The service is always friendly and the atmosphere is nice too. I will continue to eat sushi here", "I had the shrimp tempura bento box for lunch and for $8 or so it is a very good deal. You get a small salad, miso soup, a ginormous portion of rice, cantaloupe, some pieces of California roll, a few nice sized tempura shrimp and a nice small assortment of tempura veggies. The tempura was hot, fresh and not greasy. Pretty tasty grub for a land locked state like Idaho.

The service was second to none, attentive, fast, not intrusive, caring with a touch of a sense of humor.

They could use a bit of decor up date, the vibe in this place is kinda cross between Asia and a Denny's!

Yeah, I will come back when I need a good, hot inexpensive Bento for lunch."]

name: Flatbread Neapolitan Pizzeria
categories_raw: Food, Restaurants, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Sandwiches, Pizza, Italian
top_reviews:
["Yesterday I came to this Flatbread location for the first time, and it is hands down my favorite of all their locations! (Side tangent: The Bown Crossing neighborhood is so charming, and sort of flies under the radar. If you've never been, imagine the Hyde Park neighborhood but with newer buildings and located on the east side of town...and you have Bown Crossing!)

On to Flatbread - 
Due to it's location, you can come here on a weekend night and not have to worry about the hassle of parking or fighting a crowd like you would at a downtown restaurant. We came in around 8:30-ish and were seated right away. Our server came up to our table within a minute after being seated and gave us water and asked if we had any questions about the drink menu. Our server was so warm, friendly, and pleasant to talk to!

I ordered a cabernet to drink thinking it was $8 a glass. To my surprise when I got the bill I was only charged $4 - I suppose we unintentionally went during happy hour, score! For food I ordered a Gluten Free Farmhouse flatbread. It had a red onion jam, goat cheese, pancetta, asparagus and arugula on it. SO yummy. I highly recommend trying this. I also really enjoyed their gluten free crust, it was a little crispy on the outside and sort of chewy and soft towards the center. All together, my meal cost right around $15. For a good dinner out AND a nice drink? I'd say that's a steal. 

Other things-
- They don't have vegan cheese, but all of their flatbreads have so many other things on them that if you have to bypass the cheese you're not missing out, you'll still really enjoy it (IMO).
- They have a little patio (looking forward to checking this out in warmer months)!
- And as I noted with my glass of wine, they have an awesome happy hour (Mon-Fri 4pm-6pm and Fri-Sat 9-close // 50% off wine and drafts)!", 'UPDATE: I sent my review below to the company this afternoon and the general manager of the Bown Way responded to me a few minutes ago. I never expected anyone to respond on a Sunday and within just a few hours of contacting them.

She apologized and said she had already followed up with some of the employees at the restaurant and invited me to come back again.

That's the kind of customer service I appreciate and the reason I'm bumping them up to five stars, the same rating I gave their downtown Boise restaurant.

I really like the company, so it was disappointing when they didn't measure up to my expectations. I have complete confidence that I'll have a different experience when I return. Thanks, Flatbread, for listening and getting back to me.

-----------------------------------------------------

Earlier, I gave them a three-star rating:
If I hadn't had such great experiences at the downtown Boise and Bend locations, I doubt I would make a return trip.

I ordered a "Pick Two" lunch with a sopressata and capicolo pizza and a deconstructed Italian pizza.

The pizza was undercooked, which is hard to do in a high-temperature, wood-burning oven. The top of the crust was still doughy and the bottom was likewise underdone. The ingredients, though, were fantastic, as always. The salad was delicious.

When I walked in through the doors leading to the outdoor seating, I walked around front and didn't realize a woman standing next to the bar was a hostess. At the other locations, I've never been confused about that. Unlike the servers who have attire identifying the restaurant, the hostess was wearing civilian clothes and didn't immediately greet me. I looked at her for a moment, she looked back and then asked if she could help me.

I love the open kitchens of Flatbread Neapolitan Pizzeria. I enjoy watching the flames inside the oven and watching the cooks stretch dough and make pizzas in full view. The downside for the restaurant is when the cook is between pizzas and he spends his time texting. And texting some more. And then has a server come and look at his phone and either text or play a game. And then another server comes over and they're laughing at whatever is on the phone. I guess there wasn't anything more important to do. I wish I got paid at work to text.

I gathered that the hostess isn't the manager because she walked past Mr. Texter and didn't say a word. Nor did he hide what he was doing.

The Bown Way shop is beautiful and I really like the outdoor seating and the fire pit for when it cools off. I just wish they paid as much attention to their service and their pizza quality.', 'I love this place! Hubs introduced me here! Its close to his work so we usually eat lunch together here. I love the location & how fancy looking it is surrounding this neighboring establishment. Their food is great, I love their soups & the flatbreads are yummy! Enough waiting time!']

name: The Peregrine Fund's World Center for Birds of Prey
categories_raw: Museums, Arts & Entertainment, Active Life, Zoos
top_reviews:
["Review #16 for 2021.

I've been to this place twice when visiting Boise, and it's pretty fun! Lots of cool predator birds to see, and there are really great displays to learn more about conservation. I also appreciate the presentation where the staff bring out some birds to teach visitors about them. Grateful that a friend has an annual pass, so visiting is free for me! Fun for kids and families, but also fun for adults who care about animals and the environment. I'd definitely visit again!", 'THIS PLACE IS SOOO COOL. i mean, if there is any reason whatsoever that you are ever near boise, you should check this place out. all of these birds could kill you and me easily. even those weird stuffed pygmy ones.

they have demos at particular times of the day (call in advanced to see when they happen!) where they show off one of their "for educational purposes only" birdies (they would die if they were released to the wild apparently) and make them eat frozen mice bits and fly around a showroom above your head. my boyfriend was freaking out...for good reason. that's okay old man, you're still punk to me.

adult admission = $7. although if you sneak into the falconry center (which, by the way is sponsored by the son of the founder of the united arab emirates...mad monies) and find a little flyer for the place, the flyer has a $1 off coupon on it.

the gift shop is craze.

overall...what's not to like? birds of prey, man! just smoke a bowl and check it out.', "Looking for an activity to do while visiting the grandparents, my grandma and I decided to go to Birds of Prey for some educational entertainment. Set in the foothills of the Owyhee Mountains which surround the Treasure Valley, it's a nice sanctuary for endangered birds who some call their home either permanent or temporary.

Upon arriving we checked in and paid a reasonable fare of $7 ($6 for seniors or $5 for youth). Inside the staging area there is a gift shop and a friendly volunteer storekeeper who enthusiastically tipped us off to a live bird presentation that was about to begin. He radio'd to the presenter letting him know we were on our way which was nice.

We walked out of the store into a courtyard leading to the main building while other paths led to ancillary buildings and exhibits. Headed straight to the Tom Cade Theater for an interesting presentation on one of the birds who's name escaped me. It was so interesting being so close to a bird whom is constantly on alert and if let loose could do some damage probably to my eyeballs (think Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds). Nonetheless it was fascinating!

Once we were done there we toured through the main building and were allowed into their archives building which the public is only allowed guided entry twice a day...we were VIPs YO! The archive had some great artifacts from dignitaries who enjoyed falconry as well as artifacts detailing the sport of falconry. All very interesting and many things I didn't know.

At the end of our visit we were urged to come back for live flight demonstrations of some of the birds in October. Just so happens I'll be back in the area in October, they must've known since I'd like to think I'm a VIP now!"]

name: Coffee Studio
categories_raw: American (New), Food, Coffee & Tea, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Coffee Studio in 5: Really really ridiculously good scones.

~Some guy on yelp posted a picture of a lemon blueberry scone and...~
Blueberry anything is just Dani bait. Yesterday I walked in for the first time hoping for a lemon blueberry scone and ironically they were all out. The only other option of scone was white chocolate raspberry. The lovely person at the counter, Emily, offered to warm it up and it was one of the best scones I've ever had. 

~The baked goods stole the show~
The majority of their baked goods (including the scones) are made in house. The difference is astounding, most scones I encounter are a bit dense and saw dusty. Not these. These are delightful. The coffee is great, not my absolute favorite but it does the job. I didn't get anything fancy, just a plain almond milk latte and I'd get it again. 

~I honestly thought it was just a drive thru~ 
This place is adorable. I think it's the smallest coffeeshop I've ever been to. Since most seats strategically face, or are next to, the windows, it doesn't seem small at all. I've been in shops twice the size that feel half the size. 

~I like it, I like it a lot.~ 
I enjoyed hanging out at the Coffee Studio. The barista was genuinely kind, I loved the playlist, and that scone was spectacular. The service, coffee, fresh baked goods and cozy atmosphere are all reasons I'll be back. Especially to try the lemon blueberry scone.

All the stars.", 'Mini review is only fitting for this mini gem. Small and cozy place, very clean inside with LOTS of natural light. I thought the floor layout (especially considering the small size of the place) was spot on. There weren't many customers inside on a Saturday evening, and once everyone left, it almost felt like you were sitting at your own personal coffee shop. 

Parking is limited, but I feel like it is proportional to how many people can physically fit inside the place. There is an outdoor patio area in the front, but I really enjoyed the cozy vibe inside that I would recommend you sit in there (at least until it gets nice out). I'm sure it gets loud inside when that thing is packed with customers, but when there's no one there except you, it's very peaceful, ESPECIALLY after being at the Boise mall and dealing with people, parking, and the general chaos there.

Coffee tasted good, but to be honest, I'm not experienced enough in the coffee game to tell the difference between any of these local coffee places. They also have premade burritos, pastries, and donuts up front by the counter. Prices were a little high IMO, but if you're dining inside I feel like it's well worth it. Staff was super friendly, no complaints at all.

One small recommendation I'd give is to have prices next to the food in the little counter, makes you feel less like a peasant for asking how much everything is in there lol.

Overall, this is 5 stars EASY. My favorite coffee place so far has been Flying M in Nampa, which does get very busy / loud at times that can be a turn off for some (even though they have awesome latte art there). Come here at the right time (which appears to be 4 PM on a Saturday), and you're served coffee in your own little personal "coffee studio" (Yes that was corny... I'll show myself the door).', 'Stayed across the hotel at the Hyatt last week and stopped into Coffee Studio early Tuesday morning for some caffeine before going into the office. Thankful there is a drive through for all the lazy people like me who do not want to get out of the car. Hallelujah!

24 oz iced vanilla latte (~$4.50): 4 shots of espresso in this puppy is sure to send me bouncing off the walls. The vanilla syrup was not overpowering or overly sweet in the drink. Both ladies working were quick and efficient to provide the drink.']

name: Ruth's Chris Steak House
categories_raw: Steakhouses, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Can't complain about the food here, but I will complain about the dress code. I like a restaurant that asks gentlemen to remove their caps before dining. I'm old school and when I take my wife out for an anniversary celebration and spend $200, I expect the right sort of atmosphere. When Ruth's confirmed my reservation via email, they included this message: "For the dining pleasure of all guests, our dress code is Business Casual. We ask you to kindly remove your hat when entering the restaurant." 

We've seen caps before at Ruth's but haven't said anything. This time, a guy sat directly in my line of view with his hat on the entire evening, and I did say something. I complained to my waiter who punted by saying, "Our General Manager would certainly take care of the matter, but he's gone home for the night." There were three well-dressed folks at the front desk who must have been too afraid to say anything to the offending party. With only four tables occupied on a Saturday evening, I sincerely believe that this location will put profit ahead of principle.

I filled out a survey from Ruth's three days ago and asked that someone get back to me about this issue. So far, no one has.', 'I came here tonight to celebrate getting engaged to my amazing girlfriend.  I made reservations early in the week and they asked me if I was celebrating anything special.  I told them it depended on whether or not my girlfriend said yes, :) and she did.  They called me earlier today and confirmed the reservation and all went well.

We were both seated promptly.  Although our reservation was at 9:30pm, I thought more people would be there.  In the section we sat in, there were only 4 tables/booths being used out of maybe 20 tables? 

I ordered for my girlfriend and the waiter was kind enough to encourage us to try the herb roasted mushrooms verses the ordinary sautéed mushrooms.  Good call.  I felt the mushrooms were the best thing there.  I ordered the Ribeye and I ordered my girlfriend the New York steak.  We also ordered the Wedge Salad which was awesome, if you like bleu cheese, bacon and walnuts.  We split that and for sides we ordered the mac and cheese and mushrooms as stated above.

I have been to Ruth Chris many times in San Diego before and I didn't get the same experience in Boise as I remember in San Diego.
