This may only be my point of view but one of the ways I consider some restaurants to be worthy of $150 dollar meals is the professional level of balanced service.  Good waiters know how to take care of you and not over impose.  They know when to talk and when to just come by and fill drinks and realize you are in a conversation.  I have to say I was disappointed that my ice tea and water were empty 80% throughout my dinner.  My waiter at one point did ask if I wanted another ice tea and I did say no but that should mean you better make sure the water stays full.  Their glasses were maybe 10 ounce glasses and they were literally one drink glasses.  I do admit I do drink more then most people but that is how I view great service.  The funny thing was waiters were standing around looking at the 4 tables and I didn't feel it was appropriate to raise my hand like I was in 3rd grade.  My waiter was taking care of my table and another table out of the 4 tables.  The other waiters were focused on their one table and would walk by my empty glass of water and it just seemed like "I am taking care of my table" and thats all that matters.  I literally left my dinner thirsty.  Not good.

Steaks:
I thought my Ribeye was flavorful and I know most Ribeyes have a little more gristle but I would say 30% of my 16 oz steak was fat.  My girlfriend had the New York and she said it was just average.

Mushrooms:
Amazing.

Mac & Cheese
I wouldn't order it.  It wasn't that good.  Wish I would have gotten some type of potato.

Temperature:
So hot in there.  I went there on a day where we were in the 80's and the restaurant was hot.  I was sweating and I could have drank a gallon of water.  It was perfect for my lady so I didn't complain but even the waiter was complaining of the heat.

Once my fiancé (first time saying that) and I were done, we wanted to leave.  As our glasses were both empty, my waiter continued talking to a table for at least 10 minutes (which feels like an hour when you are full, thirsty, hot and tired) and I so wanted him to come over to pack up the food and give me my check.  He filled my water one more time (3/4's full) as I quickly chugged it.

Overall, I have been torn whether to give 2 or 3 stars.  If I am paying a good amount for dinner, I have to be a little more critical.  All in all, food was ok and service was not that great.  Also if you are asking me if I am celebrating a special event, why ask if you aren't going to do anything?

Maybe my experience was isolated and hopefully there are many good servers that work there.  My waiter was really nice but wished he would have come around more.', 'This review is not about the food, which is part of the problem.  I am a professional in her 50's and enjoy a fine restaurant such as Barbacoa and Chandlers to name a few.  I also enjoy meeting a friend or two for a cocktail before leaving city center for home at the end of the day. When I heard Ruth's Chris was opening in downtown Boise I was delighted and eager to add Ruth's to my list of favorite dining places.  To "get my toes wet" I decided to meet a friend there for happy hour and sample their atmosphere and food.  I arrived at 5p.m. and found that there was a reason for the empty lounge I had glimpsed from the sidewalk.  They have a policy that is giving a very bad impression of them.  
I found that the only place you can get appetizers with your drinks is at the bar top which is only about 25 chairs long. There are four lounge couches back to back by the window that you can order a drink at, but no appetizers can be served there.  The REST of the lounge area, which consist of approximately 7 booths and 5 tables, are fully set for dinner with crystal and white linen with little reserved signs on every one! Since the bar and the lounge couches were full a waitstaff told me we could sit at a table but they could only serve us a drink.  So, confused and wanting to stay we sat at the closest table.  We sat and sat for a full 10 minutes while seeing waitstaff pass by and pass by.  We finally came to the conclusion that they were instructed to NOT serve someone sitting at the tables unless they had come for a full dinner.  It was an uncomfortable experience that I was not use to, especially in such a highly rated place. Finally, we left without being waited on and went down the block to the new place "The Mode" which turned out to be a wonderful little place for drinks and appetizers!
Unwilling to let one experience sour things, we decided to meet again at Ruth's Chris last night, (Wed. night) to give it one more try.  I didn't want to have the same experience so left work early and got there at 4:40pm.  I was amazed, the bar top was full already!  10 minutes into happy hour and the bar top was full.  The lounge couches all had people sitting on them, but only four people, one person per lounge couch.  Since there was room for at least three people per couch, one kindly elderly gentleman offered for me to sit down.  I texted my fiance that it was full but I was sitting on a couch and would wait for him before figuring out what to do. Again, all the tables and booths in the lounge area, NOT the restaurant area, were UNOCCUPIED and fully set for dinner with crystal and white linen with a reserved sign on each one.  
I found out that the elderly gentleman was meeting his daughter and son in law for appetizers and cocktails before moving on to Chandlers and then ending up at Angell's.  He was nonplus about what to do because he had just found out that appetizers were served at the bar top only.  I told him this was the second time this had happened to me and told him about The Mode and its delightful appetizers and cocktail.  He took my suggestion and headed there with his party. The man sitting across from me in the couch area  told me he had arrived there at 4:26 and had found the door to the lounge locked so he went down the block to look at North Face for a couple of minutes before coming back.  He said he got back to Ruth's Chris at 4:36 and the bar top was full!  He made the crack they must of been hiding around the corner because ten minutes earlier there was no one around.
As I sat there on the lounge cushion waiting for my fiance, I saw MULTIPLE parties and people come in and were told that appetizers were only served at the bar top.  They all left because the people sitting on the couches were waiting for an opening at the bar top already.
It was NOT an inviting atmosphere at all.  I do not experience that kind of awkward situation very often and they need to change their policy about lounge serving ASAP or lose customers by the dozens.  To have a lounge not being used as a lounge and so many people turning and leaving will only create a bad image for them.  It could have a snowball effect.  I would suggest not to hae happy hour at all if they are going to limit it to 25 customers because the 125 people that leave an empty lounge because of no service will feel slighted.  It was the first time I have felt that their attitude was not happy to have us, but we were lucky to be there.  Bad publicity if you ask me.
Thank goodness they are in an area of good restaurants because we walked down the street and had a good time with good food at Matador's.']

name: The Kilted Kod
categories_raw: Seafood, Street Vendors, Restaurants, Food Trucks, Food
top_reviews:
['It's a rating for the Kilted Kod but also a microcosm of the lackluster state of fish and chips in the area. No one here pulls it off to my liking. And barring a pub opening up that's run by and caters to a predominant and demanding British/Irish crowd (yeah, right), I'm saving my money for other meals.

I visited twice early in their existence and criticized them on a different foodie site. Recently errands led me to the Maclife strip mall it usually takes residence in out in the parking lot, and it happened to be there. I figured "Why not?" and hoped that the three years that had passed had led to some improvements.

Nope. Strike three. This place has the exact same problem as Parrilla Grill. Sounds good. Looks good (I hate it when there's an excessive amount of batter on the fish, but the layer here is kept pretty thin). But bland as all hell. Neither the fish nor the batter did anything for me. Without the ketchup and tartar sauce provided, my taste buds may as well have been hopped up on novocaine when eating here. It takes a certain kind of fish/batter combo to completely neutralize malt vinegar, but the Kilted Kod's managed to make it possible for me. Each time there I've poured excessive amounts of vinegar to elicit taste in the fish but to little avail. I can't fathom trying to survive on the one packet of vinegar provided for takeout. 

I guess wanting some hand-cut fries out of a trailer might be asking too much, but in the local hierarchy of frozen fries they're in the average category. I expected higher quality out of a place that only offers three kinds of food.

They appear to have a good chunk of regulars, and maybe this is considered good quality for Boise by the lifelong locals. But for me this doesn't pass muster. I hate pulling the "I lived in (insert city here) so I know what good (insert cuisine here) is" card, but in cases like this it's unavoidable. Living most of my life in a large port city, I was used to a steady diet of either having Alaskan or Icelandic cod at legitimate British/Irish pubs or having whatever was market fresh at a fish market that served fish and chips. So to go from that to my experiences at the Kilted Kod (who is playing off the angle that they're like fish and chips you'd get in Britain) is too much of a dropoff in quality for me. The head guy told me that they use Alaskan cod, but I'll be damned if that's not the most tasteless Alaskan cod I'll ever come across. Admittedly the value of the meal ($7) gave me pause about his statement considering I can pay upwards of over twice that for the same thing in Los Angeles, but I'll take his word for it.

I feel a little bad about this one because they seem like genuinely nice people. But there's been talk here and elsewhere about a lack of good fish and chips in town, and I wanted to throw in my $.02 as I think this holds true, especially if you're a transplant from a larger city and/or a port city. They claim to be the real deal, and that's what intrigued me about them more than any other place that offered fish and chips around here. But it turned out to be fools gold.', "I was mad craving something greasy this past Friday and remembered Kilted Kod typically hangs out at the Journey Church parking lot on this day. My last experience here last year was fantastic. I was really hoping for the same outcome but it fell just a tad short off. 

I ordered the same 2 piece Alaskan cod n chips ($10.00) as before, this time adding a side of homemade coleslaw ($1.50) and my husband (not a fish fan, weird dude) got the 2 piece chicken n chips ($12.00). The portions seem generous, but for the price it's okay. 

My cod pieces were definitely greasier than before. My first bite literally felt like eating fried grease. It also tasted rather old. Same with the fries. I didn't feel very good afterwards. The chicken strips were huge! I had a couple bites and they were awesome. I thought the coleslaw was rather watered down and tasteless. It definitely could have used more sugar or salt to enhance flavor. 

All in all it satisfied by yearn for an oily dinner but it was a little too much this time. I hate to have to drop my rating from 5 to 3 stars when my expectations were so high based on a wonderful previous experience. I'm a little weary to promise a return - at least next time I'll have an idea of what to expect.", 'I was out on a "Pokewalk" on my lunch hour downtown.  I had been hanging out at Capitol Park, but needed to head back to the office.  Out to grab more Pokestops on my route back, I walked up 6th and waited to cross State.  I saw it.. the red food truck.. I wondered.. could it be?  No, said that negative Nelly in back of my brain.. it's probably someone else.. but.
The light changed and I crossed the street.. I heard someone say 'fish & chips'.. and yes.. oh yes.. THE KILTED KOD was within my grasp! I have been trying to make it to an event to try their eats for some time, but it just hadn't worked.. now.. here they were. 
I looked at my watch.. it was going to be a tight squeeze to get food and get back to the office.. but I had to, I tell you.. I  HAD TO.   Quickening my step I popped into line just before a woman and four kids.. scanning the menu I made my choice.  Surf & Turf.  2 pieces of fish, 2 chicken strips and fries.  I said YES to malt vinegar and tartar sauce, and faced with the choice of BBQ sauce or Ranch.. went with Ranch for my chicken.  
While I waited I chased down a couple of close Pokestops.  I then received the styrofoam box of (what I hoped were) NOMS and hit the pavement as quick as I could headed the six blocks to work.  As I walked I feared my lunch was suffering from being enclosed .. I had visions of sog brought on by condensation..  Thankfully my fears were nullified. When I opened the box.. 
I put up a photo.. it bears proof to how well the food stood up to a six block jaunt.. the all items remained crispy and hot.   To be honest, I hadn't planned on lunch, I'd had a good snack mid morning- but when opportunity knocks sometimes you just have to go for it. 
The fish.. oh my.. the glorious cod, firm, flaky, juicy.. cooked to perfection.. in a batter nicely spiced, but leaving room for augmentation with tartar sauce (by the by, whoever their vendor is.. or is it handmade.. the tartar sauce is great!).  The chicken strips, also battered and cooked to perfection, with a slightly different seasoning profile.  The only let down for me was the Ranch dressing.. but that is all about perspective.. I just didn't care for it.. HOWEVER the chicken didn't need sauce.  I only sampled a few of the (battered) fries, since I wasn't very hungry.. but what I had.. they were a delight!
I grew up on the Oregon coast.. I KNOW fish.. being in Idaho has been a challenge for me in terms of seafood (hello.. FRESH fish in a landlocked town? Only if you just got it off the plane).. but yes yes.. this was the COD (Kod?) I needed.. wanted.. I'm going to track them down again.  No offense to the chicken.. but it will be full on Kod from here on out!']

name: Chick-fil-A
categories_raw: Food, Caterers, Fast Food, Restaurants, Event Planning & Services, Chicken Shop
top_reviews:
["OK, so it goes without saying that Chick-fil-A has the best chicken sandwich ever. But I never realize how good the drive-through service was and the curbside assistance is fantastic this makes getting the sandwich and fighting the crowds so convenient that I will have to return over and over again. People stand curbside to take your order, and take your payment. You pull up to the red umbrella and they hand you a receipt. By the time you get to the drive up window they're calling you by your first name in handy order there's almost no stopping at all once you place your order it's fantastic and fast", "I've got love for Chick-fil-a. This is probably the only fast food place I feel comfortable eating inside the establishment. The tables are always cleared and cleaned, the employees are pleasant and helpful when needed. This chick-fil-a pays close attention to details that would make a dine-in experience stand out from the rest. For example, their bathroom doors handles are situated where you can use your forearm to open it instead of the hands you just washed, they provide bleach wipes if you would like to wipe the table yourself, they deliver the food to your table and ask if you would like anything else, they have employees roaming the dining area refilling drinks etc. Love their little extra touches they provide and it does not go unnoticed! 

The food is fresh, sauces (of which you can have as many as you would like!) are good, and if you get a salad, ALWAYS get that avocado chili ranch!! Don't bother with boring soda, get their lemonade, its the best around!", "These guys were fast and efficient even during the lunch hour! Food was hot when it arrived and delicious!

I don't think you can get a better chicken sandwich anywhere else. Plus, the waffle fries are da bomb!

Bathrooms were clean, as was the diner! All the employees were very friendly and eager to help us."]

name: Jumpin Janet's
categories_raw: Nightlife, Sandwiches, Pubs, Mexican, Sports Bars, Restaurants, Bars, Tacos
top_reviews:
['My friends and I decided to pop in here for happy hour yesterday.  I was very happy to see the "no smoking" sign on the door when I entered.  I was also pleased to find happy hour is a double for $3- M-F 4-7.  

This particular evening table service was provided.  The server was friendly and quick.  After a couple of drinks, we thought it would be smart to order some food and were surprised by the menu options available- sandwiches, salads, and burgers.  One friend ordered the spicy chicken sandwich ($6.75), while i shared a prime rib dip ($7.75)with the other friend. Both sandwiches came with a side salad.   

This being somewhat of a dive bar, we really didn't have high hopes for the food but were hungry.  Well we were VERY surprised at what we got.  The salad had romaine lettuce with tomatoes and grated cheese (no iceberg in sight!).  The chicken sandwich wasn't a fried chicken patty but a chicken breast with a tasty sauce.  The dip was an amazing amount of sliced prime rib, not deli meat in the least, served up on a tasty roll with a very nice au jus.  

I came here for the happy hour; I will return for the food!', 'Well this is one of our go to neighborhood dive bars. We typically come in on Sundays for their build your own omelets and bloodys! Staff is very friendly and the owner, Janet is usually in the back cooking. She comes out to say hi to the patrons as well. Gives you that local vibe which is always a great touch. The have pool tables here, so while the wait for food on Sundays can sometimes be long, you can keep busy with some pool. Highly recommend if you are in the bench area. Great little spot!', 'I've always loved Janet's...until tonight. We went in for last call trivia (our first time doing trivia at Janet's). When we arrived, we ordered beers and asked for glasses of water. The waitress told us that because of the high volume of people they expected for trivia, they only sold bottles of water on Wednesday nights. Her excuse was, their ice machine couldn't keep up with the amount of mixed drinks the bar makes, plus ice water for the customers. We were fine with that (my friends and I all work in the restaurant industry, and we know sometimes certain appliances - like ice machines - can't always handle the rushes). So we asked for plain old tap water, with no ice. 

The waitress told us that wasn't allowed and the only way we could get water was to buy bottles of water. Umm, what? Are you kidding me? I'm not familiar with Idaho water laws in relation to restaurants, but...I have never, EVER, in all my time working in restaurants heard of a business refusing to give a table TAP WATER. 

Not to mention, a few minutes later, we saw her taking out big glasses of what was unmistakably ice water to other tables. And, it wasn't all that busy tonight. I've seen it way more packed at Janet's than it was this evening, and I've been able to get a glass of water - with ice! - during busy nights. 

So we were pretty irritated, but willing to get over it, because the trivia was fun and the beers were great. 

At the end of our night, we asked to close our tabs, and only then did the waitress tell us, "We have to add a dollar charge onto your cards, since you're using cards instead of cash tonight, just so you know."

I've been going to Janet's for years. They have a $10 minimum on cards, which I feel is pretty standard and fair. I have never once been charged an extra dollar to use a card during my times there. When we asked the waitress about it, she said the company policy has been in effect for two years, and that the employees get in a lot of trouble if they don't add the amount onto credit/debut card tabs (which apparently goes to cover the cost of running cards in the first place).

First of all - if Janet's wanted to be a cash only bar, whether just for trivia nights or for any transaction, that needed to be said at the very beginning of the night - NOT as we were trying to leave and didn't have cash on us. It was only $1, but the fact that no one told us about it...and didn't give us the chance at the beginning of the night to, say, go get cash for our tabs...that's not right. 

Second, the fact that it's been "company policy" and yet, none of us has ever been charged this? And we've been going for years? I call bullshit. If you're trying to make some extra money off the people who come in for trivia nights, Janet, that's a pretty poor way to say thank you to the customers who come in and keep your bar busy for a few hours. 

Third, I've worked for all different kinds of restaurants - corporate and locally/family-owned. Even in the locally owned restaurants, we never, EVER charged people for choosing to use a credit/debit card over cash. 

When we asked the waitress why we were being charged extra when we've been coming to Janet's for years and have never had that happen, she said "Oh, they probably just assumed you knew about the charge, so they just added it without telling you."

Even if that were remotely true, what an awful business practice!!! "Hmm, these people come in and spend their hard earned money buying drinks and food at our bar - let's sneak an extra dollar here and there without saying a damn word, and see if we get caught!"

The waitress was very pleasant, and I realize none of this is her fault - she doesn't make the rules - however, the fact that she kept adding charge after charge, for no reason she could adequately explain, was completely and utterly ridiculous. And taking tap water out to your other tables, after telling someone you'd only bring them bottled water you'd have to charge them for? Not okay. 

Like I said, I'm in the restaurant industry and I know how it is. I'm usually pretty lenient on servers when I go out to eat and drink, because you never know if they're getting their asses kicked or are struggling in some way. But what we experienced tonight was terrible. 

Needless to say, I'm extremely disappointed in Janet's - a place I've always enjoyed going to in the past. We won't be coming back, and you can be damn sure we'll be letting others know about the terrible service we received tonight.']

name: Chip Cookies
categories_raw: Food, Bakeries
top_reviews:
['**Warning** **Warning** **Warning** **Warning**
Yelp's pretend attorney general warns: 
The following business products are highly addictive, feels your belly with YUMMY goodness and leaves you wanting more and more and more! Consumers of this product become highly addicted quickly, on first consumption, and with the easy online ordering, order tracking, and late night delivery-- it's certainly a recipe for an instant high and overall addiction on both the belly and the pocketbook! In the words of Britney Spears "Gimme, gimme more gimme more gimme, gimme more!" I need it, I want it, I can't not have it! 

8th reviewer of Chip Cookie, Boise! This is my 408th review on Yelp. 

Ok, all that may be a little dramatic(a little), but it's kinda true! Last night, the kids and I wanted a snack, yet Dad didn't want to go to the store or go bake something, so I remembered seeing Amie's (our Yelp embassador) review and I thought I should try it. 

The app is amazingly easy to use. Right now we in Boise only have one flavor, chocolate chip. A box of 4 is $10 and you have a small delivery fee $2.99 and I tipped so about $15 for 4 cookies. The order was simplistic. You then get an email or text alerts (you chose) then you sit and anxiously wait. What did I just do?!? Did I really order cookies this late in the evening? Oh, yes-I-did! 

The text messages kept me updated and I walked out to the car where I was handed these steamy, melt-in-your-mouth, addictive, heavy, large, warm cookies! Within 30 minutes of ordering, I had my cookies. 

Getting them in the house, I thought the box was awfully heavy. They were perfectly cooked, melted wonderfully, and amazing tasting. Seriously. I couldn't finish one and saved it for the next day. I warmed the cookie up and it was still just as good.  All 5 of us mmmmm'd as we ate them. It was the quietest I've seen my kids in, well, forever! 

As Amie says in her March 2018 review, it's over the top... and lifes never the same, I agree and that's what's awesome about it! Give them a try. They deliver until 2am!', "2.5 Stars now. I've been ordering cookies from Chip for about 1.5 years now, ever since my friend first brought back a box of their delicious Biscoff chip cookies from a work trip to Idaho. The cookies were so good that I was excited to discover they ship nationwide. 

I've tried several of their flavor of the month cookies, and while I haven't loved all of them, I couldn't deny the quality of their cookies and service. I always received my cookies expediently and without issue. Until recently that is.

A few weeks ago I ordered their current cookie of the month flavor- the Snickershoedle chip, described as a snickerdoodle cookie stuffed with Biscoff cookie butter. I ordered 2 boxes and received the first box after a short delay, which wasn't actually Chip's fault but due to postal service being delayed in general due to protests. However, when my box did arrive it was damaged. Again, this isn't necessarily Chip's fault as they did have a fragile sticker on the box. But once I opened the box I realized two of the cookies were broken into pieces, and the other two, which were lopsided in shape, started crumbling into pieces as soon as I opened the wrapper. One of the cookies also didn't have much cookie butter filling in it, as advertised. 

Just as concerning was the shoddy wrapping that was done this time around. The cookies were wrapped but instead of being sealed like they used to be, the wrapping was taped together. To paint you a picture, the cookie and the packaging basically looked like how cookies your friend who doesn't bake often would make and send to you, and not how you would expect a store bought package of cookies or bakery cookies to look. 

The last problem I had, which I don't entirely blame Chip Cookies for this specific issue, but wanted to bring up to highlight how unfortunate this entire recent experience was, is how I never recieved my second box of cookies. Usually when I order more than one package of cookies, they tape the boxes together and I receive my entire order together. That didn't happen this time around, and when I got the email notification that my order had been delivered and completed without mention of the other missing half of my order, I became concerned. I emailed right away, and I will say they did respond and work on figuring out the issue. A couple days later, after I emailed again, I was told their delivery specialist forgot to send the second box of cookies I ordered, so they offered to send me a new package or refund. And since I wasnt happy with the cookies I did receive, I decided on a refund.

I'll end this review by saying I would like to order from Chip Cookies again some day, especially when they start selling their delicious Biscoff chip flavor cookies again, but I know I will be hesitant to do so given this past experience.", "My friend went to Idaho for a business trip and he brought a box of these cookies back to the office to share. My friend said he was looking for local dessert places when this place popped up on his feed, so he decided to drop by. He said the store was setup in a way where he could see them baking the cookies in front of him. After seeing them make the cookies, he asked what kinds of cookies they had left and they told him they only make two types of cookies a day. He ended up buying a box with both types- chocolate chip and biscoff cookies. 

The box came with 4 giant cookies, each the size of about three regular-sized cookies. And I absolutely loved the biscoff cookie, which had white chocolate & cookie butter chunks! It was so good that when my friend said they do orders online and ship nationwide I knew I had to order some for myself. And because one box is $10 while shipping was $15, I of course ordered two boxes to make it more worth it in my head. And I'm glad I did because I just got an email saying they would stop making the biscoff flavor soon and move onto a different flavor cookie. 

Anyways, here's what you need to know: Amazing giant gourmet cookies that are absolutely worth the price of shipping & handling!"]

name: Boise Fry Company
categories_raw: Restaurants, Burgers, Fast Food, American (New), Gluten-Free
top_reviews:
['When you are in Idaho it is a pretty good idea to eat potatoes.  The Boise Fry Company offers several types of fresh cut fries and burgers in fun environment.  The staff was pretty laid back, but made some very good food.  The place was pretty minimalist aside from a few TVs.  It was very clean and there was plenty of indoor and outdoor seating.

Starting with the fries - my russet curly fries were good.  They give you hot, plain fries and you take your order over to the seasoning bar.  They have a dozen different salts and other seasonings to dress up your fries.  There is also 8 or so dipping sauces to try out.  The end result is a very good fry, but nothing out of this world. Perhaps some of the other varieties are a little more interesting. The burger here was quite good - way better than the fries.  It was a fresh griddled burger on a potato bun.  The meat has a pretty interesting taste to it - kind of spicy.  I really liked the fry sauce that went great on the burger. The burger with fries was almost too much for lunch!  It was around $10 for a combo meal so a very fair price for a nice, fresh meal.

This is a fun place to try if you are visiting - they have a ton of info and pretty good food.', 'We'd been craving burgers ... but more than that we were craving fries this evening --those perfectly cut, crispy fried golden carbo sticks that are very bad for the body & manna for the foodie soul... where should we go for such fare? Why BFC of course, right? They serve fries with burgers on the side! Made to order for our purposes tonight it seemed. Unfortunately not. The fries we were served were soggy, greasy, limp, and  tasteless ... a few were even undercooked. Dollops of sauce can only do so much to save a meal. The bison burgers were dripping with grease to the extent that i had to wipe mine off including the _top_ of the bun. The plates on which the food rested were wet. Clearly, our food was plated without an ounce of care or QC. 
Adding insult to injury, three oblivious patrons each accompanied by a dog - with one of them boldly, unapologetically off-leash - arrived at the door while we were mid-meal on the patio. The off-leash dog proceeded to saunter right onto the patio (while the owner was nowhere in sight), looking for scraps under the seated customers tables. For some, a dog taking food bits into its mouth then bringing it out for inspection and then licking it back off the ground might make for a perfectly acceptable dinner experience but it makes my stomach turn. And I realize that this might put me in the minority at least in the  Bown crossing area but being in the minority doesn't imply that my feelings/ expectations are wrong or to be ignored, does it? As a paying customer & a human being with a set of reasonable preferences, I have the right to a non-vomit-inducing dining experience on a restaurant patio. "Dog friendly" policy is one thing. "We will have customers let their dogs run wild under your table as you eat" is another. It is important to remember that the reason why civil society needed to devise so many rules is because, left upto their own devices, people don't always make considerate or even rational choices. Anyway, in sum, a very unpleasant experience. Will not be returning to the Bown location.', "One of the guys at the counter had to see my id because he thought I was a cop...
Not a cop super offended ,Won't ever be back."]

name: Madhuban Indian Cuisine
categories_raw: Indian, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Ok, First off, what Madhuban calls the biryani, does not entitle to be called so. I would call it 'Synthetically Colored rice'. I am guessing the color is some edible coloring thing they toss in along with the veggies and rice and oil. Well, how about some flavour, aye?  Here's a humble tip from someone who grew up eating briyani home made style, and has had authentic biryani in India: Please add some Ginger-garlic paste, and Green chillies, and may be , just may be, some garam masala.  The people of Boise who believe Biryani is what they serve, sure deserve more than mere red colored rice. No that is not Biryani! You are insulting the word Biryani! You are insulting the whole culture of Biryani making!  No. I am not going to die without attempting to tell you how grossly far away it is from anything like Biryani!  

The other dishes are alright actually. What they call Palak Paneer actually seems to have saag and palak in it, but tastes good anyways. What they call Dal tadka is simply dal makhani minus the cream. No that's not what it is supposed to be!   Stop giving wrong names to wrong dishes please. If you call it something it better be , well, just that.  

Their Samosas are awesome though.  They nailed it there. The buffets are good value for money. However, the wait list is usually long. But that shouldn't hurt their review. It, in fact, shows how much the people of Boise love what they serve here with names according to their own whims and fancies. Doesn't really matter as long as it tastes good I know! But when you know what it should be and you get a bowl of something else, is not so pleasantly surprising.  It is kind of annoying. Don't you think ?

And the last time we visited them for a la carte dinner, the service was so bad. we waited a whole of 45 minutes for our rest of the meal to arrive after the appetizers. The appetizers 'appetized' us and left us gulping down water. When the dishes finally arrived, we simply got them boxed. Because we all were full- of water- tummy and bladders. We couldn't eat  and we all wanted to pee and did not want to use the wash room there.  

Yay to a so called good restaurant.  I dont think Im going there again unless for the 10 dollar buffet on a lazy weekend day when it is easier to drive than to cook  . But the 'red colored rice '  is not  entering my system ever.Never.", "So much flavor in one tiny place! And when I say tiny I mean packed like pickles. I came for lunch which is BUFFET ONLY - I usually like to order off the menu due to food sensitivities but I decided to take a chance- glad that I did!

Buffets aren't always great - I usually avoid other types at all times - but the great thing about an Indian buffet is being able to sample all of the flavorful sauces and curries. This was the most comprehensive indian buffet I have ever experienced. 

There was papadum, masala dosa, naan, plain rice, chicken biryani rice, tandoori chicken, chicken curry, lamb curry, goat something, chicken mahkani, matar paneer, vegetable something with every vegetable including okra, cauliflower dish, chana masala, lentil something I think.

And chutneys! So many chutneys! Chutneys I've never seen or tried before - a cornucopia of chutneys! Mint chutney, tamarind chutney, mango chutney, hot chutney, coconut chutney! I judge an Indian restaurant by the quality of it's mint chutney and this one is bang-on! Spicy, salty, fresh and just thick enough to sit on top of my chicken without getting too watery everywhere.

There was a little spot for salad with a plain lettuce mix and separate toppings: red onion, cucumber, tomato, lemon wedges. Raita. Or you can do like me and just put mint chutney on everything!

Desserts were mango something, rice pudding, gulab jamun. Classics.

I'm telling you guys - this place had it all. I was blown away by the variety of foods (and  amount of people) they were able to squeeze into such a small space. And they never ran out of anything - all dishes were stocked.

What to expect: for the lunch buffet when you walk in a waiter will direct you to an available seat. They will bring you silverware, a napkin, plus you OWN PITCHER of water (hallelujah!) which they leave at your table and two glasses which they fill. Now put your coat down and grab you plate and get in line and fill it up. When you're finished just leave the plate at the edge of the table and they will collect it. Go back for seconds or if you've had enough you can get up and pay for your meal at the back counter.

I will be back. For dinner, for lunch, for everything. Was great!", "Hands down, some of the best food I've ever eaten.. I've eaten Indian in L.A., Seattle, Portland, etc and Madhuban is the best I've had. Shrimp curry, chicken tikka masala, palaak paneer, even the naan is first rate. The buffet is a great value, always very crowded but the food makes up for it. Service is very friendly, with warm atmosphere inside and the smell of the food cooking in the back is divine. My favorite place for grabbing lunch or date night. If you haven't, you must try Madhuban."]

name: Mongolian BBQ
categories_raw: Restaurants, Barbeque, Mongolian
top_reviews:
["This has to be one of my favorite lunch stops in Boise.  In fact it is not uncommon for me to come here up to 2 times in a one week stay while here.  
The staff are friendly, the food is good (hell if it isn't it's mostly your fault since you are putting it all together yourself), and its quick.  For $8-12 (incl tax and tip) you have plenty of food and they even serve you a bowl of rice in addition to what you have prepared in your own bowl.  I personally got 2 meals out of my small bowl.  
It's nothing fancy, but maybe that is why I like it.  
Plus I have a nice meal and I am not in a rush and still get in and out in an hour.", "If it's not good it's your own fault! ;-)

All the fixins, three sizes of bowel, good selection of sauces and Dr Pepper to wash it  down. $10 for lunch--and some serious eats!", "Oh man!  Everytime I eat Mongolian BBQ I get overstuffed and have to save the rest for a late dinner.  I am so in love with these places it's almost pitiful!

I went here today with a friend and had the best time ever.  We say down and we watched part of the New England Patriots vs Denver Broncos game.  It was a great setup for someone who is now handicappable.  They made room for me and made me feel welcome.

After the food was done, I was easily able to wheel into the bathroom and made it easily to the toilet.

Thank you guys and gals for being so helpful!"]

name: Anniversary Inn Boise
categories_raw: Event Planning & Services, Bed & Breakfast, Hotels, Hotels & Travel
top_reviews:
['All that we see or seem is but a dream within a dream. -- Edgar Allan Poe

39th person to review Anniversary Inn near Ann Morrison Park in Downtownish Boise. This is my 431st review. 

Anniversary Inn is in both Boise and Salt Lake City, Utah.

This place, to me, is a dream within a dream-- a step back in time, to bask in the ambiance of love, to relax, to share romance, to have sexual independence and role play all while in a themed room which matches your personality and overall desires. 

Have you ever wanted to walk down a spiral staircase calling out your Romeo? To have your knight in shining armor break the castle door to win your love? Wanted to sleep in a tree house, or two take a jet bath with fish tanks? Or spend the night playing pool and darts while you have a Harley to "play" around with/on. Have you ever wanted to be on stage? To feel Presidential? To have marble floors, or sleep in a jungle with Elephants, or perhaps submerge yourself into the mysteries of Egypt all while King Tut watches you from afar? Maybe you wanted to sleep in a boat, or a canopy, in the artic or on a King sized bed in Paris? There are all sorts of fairy tales or fantasies to be discovered. 

Well, my friends, you can do all of these at the Anniversary Inn and their many themed rooms. The rooms come with cheesecake, champagne, and bathrobes for the two of you.  A few good to know's: Two people only. If there are three in your relationship you'll have to get two rooms or be creative. No children, this is a place for romance. Many of the showers have creative flowing showerheads, big bathtubs for two with jets, and you can take a free tour 1-3 every day. Go pick out your room! 

I'd like to see a patio in the back, maybe a pond or fire pit.', 'Very cool little spot!  What a fun hotel with a lot of character and charm.  Safari Room did not disappoint.  The bed was really comfy, parking was free, friendly staff, and affordable.  I went alone because I was on business and could not find a hotel, but this is a place for couples.  The tub in the room was a special treat.  The 2 complimentary  slices of cheese cake were also a special treat. 
Just wish there was a full length mirror in the room, and wish there was a fitness center.  
Boise is for lovers.', "Absolutely amazing!  Finally a hotel that treats you like a real guest. My hubby and I stay at a lot of hotels and we are always wondering what execty we are getting for paying $100-$200 a night. A bed that may or may not be comfortable and a shower. If you want anything extra you have to pay ridiculous amounts. Hotels that include bathrobes call themselves 5-star. Anniversary inn goes above and beyond. I feel like my money was very well spent.  They had sparkling apple cider chilling, mood lighting, and romantic music playing as we walked in the room. The room was cozy and inviting with funny little secrets to be reveiled if you explore enough. A very comfy bed. The ambience was about as romantic as it gets. In the morning we woke up to a beautiful breakfast at our door.  Now I can't wait until the next time we get to come back.  Thank you so much Anniversary Inn for making our night and really knowing how to treat your guests."]

name: Graeber & Company Salon and Spa
categories_raw: Men's Hair Salons, Waxing, Blow Dry/Out Services, Skin Care, Hair Salons, Hair Removal, Beauty & Spas, Hair Stylists, Nail Salons, Barbers, Day Spas, Hair Extensions, Massage
categories: ["men's hair salons", 'waxing', 'blow dry/out services', 'skin care', 'hair salons', 'hair removal', 'beauty & spas', 'hair stylists', 'nail salons', 'barbers', 'day spas', 'hair extensions', 'massage']
top_reviews:
["Worst haircut I ever had. I went back the next day to have someone besides the stylist, Tanya, check it out. It was so uneven that the stylist had to chop my hair off to my ears. Erin, the manager came up to me as I was throwing a fit and stated Your husband will love it.. Fuck you lady. This was not a fantastic sans. They compensated me with some samples of Aveda products., I walked out crying looking like little lord Fauntleroy.. I hate that place and the way they conducted this disaster of a cut.. In order to post this I have to give it a star, it doesn't deserve", "BEWARE!!!

I went to Brandon for a simple haircut and a little color to take out some of the gray. I told Brandon I was looking for more of a George Clooney salt and pepper color and would like a small trim, keeping some length. OMG!

Not only did he completely botch the color, but he also went wild with the scissors and ended up giving me a look that is part Navy Seal and part Flock of Seagulls.  While the owner refunded my money and offered store credit to fix the job, she wasn't interested in seeing just how bad Brandon left me.  Too bad because she actually said Brandon was one of her better stylists! Really? Huh? 

The good news is Breanne at Tonic is used to cleaning up Graebers' messes and really helped me out. She was awesome.

I've been to Graebers over the years and have had decent cuts and service. This one takes the cake. So long, Graebers!", "Went to carrie at one point and she did a great job, so I booked her again. She did not do what I asked, and refused to do it over, once I got home and realized my hair was STRIPED and still had roots. She straight up REFUSED to do it over.Goodbye over 100$ and a fat tip.Snotty bitch doesn't cover it."]

name: White Dog Brewing
categories_raw: Brewpubs, Food, Breweries
top_reviews:
['= Boise Beer Tour (self-guided) - Stop 3 =

After taking a break at my hotel and then walking some more along the river, I checked Yelp and decided to angle towards White Dog to grab some dinner and another brewski (or two). The place was quiet for a Friday, and I had no trouble finding a seat at the bar. The staff was relaxed, uber-friendly and answered all my questions. I finally opted for a 4-beer sampler and a Beer & Bacon Burger, the latter being prepared by a food truck in the adjacent alleyway.

The beers in my sampler were all delicious and well-crafted: I was the least excited with the hazy IPA (it's a beer fad I'm quickly getting burned-out on), but I loved the Scotch Ale, the 5-hop IPA and the English IPA.  When I discovered they had some of the English IPA on nitrogen, I decided to get a pint of that and stay a little longer. It was by far my best beer of the night. (I stopped by the following night to have another, but they were out of it...dang).

As for the food, my burger was absolutely phenomenal, cooked perfectly and with some kind of oniony bacon-jam. It came with excellent, thick-cut fries as well. A 5-star meal.

Cool feature: White Dog has a 5-inch wide, metal rail embedded in the bar that is held at icy temps so you can sit your beer on it, keeping it from getting too warm. I've never seen this before, but it worked well (and it also made a fun, mini snowscape).

In short, I loved White Dog. It was a another, great Boise brewery "find," and so I was surprised (and a little sad) the place was not busier. I understand they are still "newish," and so hopefully they will gain a larger following over time.', "Who doesn't love adorable pictures of dogs and wolves surrounding you while drinking delicious beer with great service?

I came here one afternoon to enjoy a few pints while getting some work done. It was about 3:00 pm so I had the place to myself. It's a great space. Very open, ample seating, with HUGE skylights that let in so much beautiful sunshine. The bar top has this super cool ice run that you can put your beer on to keep frosty chilled. My old man is obsessed with ice cold beer, so I'm stoked to show him. 

I enjoyed the Blood Orange Hefeweizen and the Blackberry Sour. Both were delicious and hit the spot. I sat at a large booth and spread out all my things. The sun began to stream in through the skylights and I felt warm, content and happy. They happily gave me the public wifi password and I was checked on frequently. 

I did not sample their food, but the kitchen was hard at work and it smelled amazing. I will definitely be back to try it. 

They do allow dogs, although pooches must remain outside on the patio. It was a very cool space and I look forward to sampling more!", "Cute brewery with a large selection of hazy beers. The Octoberfest is delicious! They have a good selection of snacks as well. There is indoor and outdoor seating available.
This is the only brewery I've ever see that has a frozen ice area to set your beers on to keep them cold! Make sure you try the fries with gravy and fry sauce. Amazing!!"]

name: Wiseguy Pizza Pie
categories_raw: Vegetarian, Sandwiches, Nightlife, Pizza, Restaurants, Bars
top_reviews:
['Oh boy, where to begin with this one? How about: I just threw up Wiseguy in the toilet. It's not really Wiseguy's fault. Well kind of. Who knows?! I guess you'll just have to read on to find out.

This week, Tom and I are joined by our friend Austin: mac n' cheese connoisseur and pizza aficionado.

Don't really know much about Wiseguy and couldn't find anything online. It's a NY style pizzeria. They have two sections; the front does pizza by the slice and the back is more of a sit down pizzeria with bar and sports. I really appreciate that you can have both experiences. Nice atmosphere. Very hipstery, parts of it look like a pirate ship and other parts look like a wine cellar or some kind of medieval hallway.

Tom and I each ordered a drink, a pepperoni slice, and a specialty slice. I got Hawaiian, he got veggie. Austin ordered a single slice of their signature Wise Guy which is essentially a meat-lover's. Two big slices and a drink came out to $7-something which is a very reasonable price.

As we waited for our slices to heat up, we watched Metallica proceeded to play the national anthem at a hockey game.

Metallica on Ice: 1 shred out of 5

At some point we noticed our slices had not yet arrived which was a little strange. I jokingly said "he probably forgot about our slices and the whole pizzeria will catch on fire." As I say this, Tom sees the guy who put our slices in the oven walk nonchalantly into the room. Then he spots us, a look of alarm overtakes his face, and he runs back in the other direction. A few minutes later the guy walks back in and says, "Hey so your slices... they're a little crispy. I'm going to make another set but I forgot what you guys had." We say it's no problem and tell him we had 2 peps, 1 veggie, 1 hawaiian, and a Wise Guy. A few minutes later he is back again with 2 veggies, 1 hawaiian, and a Wise Guy. We tell him that's not what we ordered and he's just devastated. The guy is so nice that we can't really be mad at him. We finally get the correct order and dig in.

-Pepperoni-
Austin says the dough tastes like marshmallows. Tom and I look at him confused. Don't believe Austin, the dough tastes like regular pizza dough. The pepperoni and meat-lovers in particular are very crunchy. I like crunchy but I know most folks would say this is too crunchy. You couldn't fold it without it cracking and falling apart. Sauce is good. It's very Italian but there's very little of it. That cheese though. The cheese is just awful. It didn't seem to bother the others as much but to me it was just goop. It's like when you have leftover pizza and heat it in the microwave for not enough time so it's kind of melted but not enough and it's really oily. The peps are 'flat on it' style, not crunchy style. I'm more of crunchy kind of guy but peps will be peps.

-Veggie-
This is my favorite of the bunch and probably Austin's favorite as well. Tom doesn't like it much. The flavors are everything you expect from a veggie, strong taste of mushrooms, peppers, olives, and onions. That cheese though. AUGH.

-Hawaiian-
Some jalapenos for an extra kick, but really the jalapenos don't have any kick. Pineapple doesn't really have taste either. Canadian is very nicely cooked and tastes great. I would have preferred just the Canadian bacon.

-Wise Guy-
This had some good meaty flavors. Mushroom and sausage go well together. Good steady flavor but no thrills. After the first bite, you kind of know what you're eating and you're just eating more of it. And that cheese. Oh that cheese. Cheese Louise amirite?

-Verdict-
So when we left Tom and Austin were adamant that this place was really bad. I was more on the mediocre portion of the spectrum. Their argument was that it's downtown, there are at least a couple places that are better and just a few blocks away. My argument was that it was cheap and it wasn't that bad. I was ready to give this place 3 slices.

Then the vomit.

It was hot, I had a headache, and pizza is not the best food to eat in these conditions. That being said, the pizza really didn't help. It was greasy and oily. I might have been more motivated to keep it in, had the pizza tasted better. I guess that doesn't make sense because if it tasted really good, then throwing up would kind of let me taste it a second time? So maybe if it tastes really good, then throwing up is actually a compliment?

Nah, it was bad. This actually brings up an important point about food that we didn't consider in the other reviews. You should feel good after eating it. This is the place you go to when Guido's and Pie Hole are closed for the day.

1 slice out of 5

[EDIT: Originally 2/5]', "Can I get a slice of pepperoni and 2 health code violations for dine in?  Over an hour after I ate I was able to say good bye to some of the pizza's that greeted me when I came in. (they should have been thrown out after an hour per code ...Gross) 

  This is a hard order to fill in a lot of other places but here at Wise Guy's they gladly deliver.  In my quest to find the best NY pizza my travels took me to Guido's and next here, in my previous post NY Giant came out on top but how did Wise Guy's do?  Let's just say the atmosphere is way better than NY giant and Guido's combined, (sports bar meets brick bistro) 

First off BEST Coca Cola In the valley (carbon, water, syrup ratio is on point. Not that it matters) 

- Price Again same problem as Guido's the price is like we are in Manhattan not In Boise. 

Size- Again it fits on the plate (paper plate) 1/2 the size of authentic NY pizza.  

Flavor-  I needed help so I consulted the 2 wise guys on painted on the wall, When I asked them how is my pizza bottom burnt yet the top looks barely cooked  they were just as lost for wisdom as I was. (Oh well) 
To make matters worse the pizza was bland and the cheese was a hard congealed mess, it was not stretchy as melted cheese should be.  The sauce has some potential as I tasted it apart from everything else... so yay something good. 

Overall- 
 My experience sitting in the big back room was that this place is run by a bunch of college guys, I watched one drink from his open container in the sight of all the customers. (against health code) 
  I spent over an hour dining here on purpose and making various phone calls.  Now many reviews state the pizza tasted old and flavorless, I was curious if I would witness old pizza being sold and I did.  Another cooking 101 pizza is 80 percent cooked, it then cooks the other 20% when you order.  80% cooked pizza sitting for more than an hour is breeding ground for bacteria and also strips cheese of the moisture giving it a non gooey texture.  

NY Giant Still reigns as the best NY pizza in Boise 
Guido's tops wise guy by a landslide, but hey a digiorno beats this pizza. (Disclaimer) *All tasting was performed under a sober palette*", "This was our first time in as a family. My husband works downtown, and has been there before alone. I wanted a quick Guidos meal as it was late and the kids were starving. We had just been to a long yet fun city choir function at BSU. My husband suggested Wiseguy's, said I would like it. It was fast. Customer service was spot on. We sat in the back area, the kids got a table of their own. We loved the pizza, the garlic knots, and even the simple garden salad was fresh. The ranch dressing was cold, like it should be! I hate a warm dressing.. And ewe.. always scared to eat it anyway. 

The downside.. Well, the NBA game was on and given there were only 3 other people there, one was LOUD. Now.. I'm no pansy to sports bar loudness. I get it! I love a good game. The couple at the bar were normal. Laugh a little, root a little. It's all good. But.. Apparently the LOUD girl was a girlfriend of someone working there. No food, maybe a drink by her, but good lord, I felt like I was sitting next to her. She cussed a few times, LOUDLY. Her ultra volume wasn't even about the game! Everything from her view about other girls to how she was the cutest baby in the world. I would guess she was pretty sober as well.. I'd HATE to see her inebriated.  Enter manager..or who appeared to be the manger. He was awesome. Told her to pipe down and then pointed to the kids in the room. I really appreciated that!

Will I return? Yes. Do I hope girlfriend isn't there, just hanging out, legs stretched over a bar stool like a lounge chair in mega amp yelling mode? YES."]

name: Elmer's Restaurant
categories_raw: American (Traditional), Diners, Breakfast & Brunch, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Have you ever walked into an establishment and feel you just entered an episode of the ol' 60's Twilight Zone? 

It happened here at Elmers.

With the hustle & bustle, the noise & congestion of Capitol Blvd's partial street closures, drivers with long faces honking away, officers with whistles directed traffic on the main thoroughfare. Walking in through the doors all changed in an instant. A nice calming noise suppression from the outside world happened when the doors closed behind us. Once inside, it was a down-home country cottage feel. The smile of the hostess was genuine & happy to see us. Background white noise was that of silverware klinking against stoneware & diners humming as they noshed. She showed us to the one open booth by the windows & introduced us to our server, Katie, who was already setting glasses of ice water down on our table. 

Katie smiled, and though her station looked busy, she made friendly small talk & gave us a moment to decide. When both our menus where on the table, she was there in an instant ready take our order. Unusual as I witnessed that she was hustling in her section. I'm already impressed with her attentiveness. We ordered & she committed everything to memory.

For the wife: Bacon burger w/Tillamook Ched sat on a grilled Kaiser bun & came with bottomless fries! She likes her burgers "medium" & she had the "Cheshire cat" grin that signaled that it was cooked to perfection. We shared her fries as we knew we'd get s'more! They're good...but then I'm reminded, "...we ARE in IDAHO!"

It bein' Saturday mid-morning & nursing the effects from a night out on the town, I went with the Saturday Market Skillet. A hefty meal of Hickory smoked ham, smoked bacon, German sausage, hash browns, red & green peppers, onions topped off with fluffy Tillamook Ched-scrambled eggs; served on a small cast-iron skillet. There on the side sat a fresh-baked buttermilk biscuit to die for. I love that my dish isn't overly seasoned as I like to add the salt n' pep myself and the bacon/ham added just enough saltiness that didn't warrant any. But I like pepper. A pinch here, a pinch there, over the perfectly cooked eggs & the crispy outer bits of the hash, this dish was solid & guaranteed to knock last night's cobwebs outcha head!

My wife's fries were dwindling & somehow I locked eyes with Katie from a distance & she seemed to know what I was thinking as she mouthed the words "...more fries?" I couldn't help but grin & nod. Only in the Twilight Zone...

Kuddo's to the staff @ Elmer's for the awesome hospitality we'd received while in BoDo.

Stepping back into the outside world, it was a return to the hustle, bustle & long faces. Night & day I tell'ya.

It was 3.5-Star food, but a 5-Star experience throughout. The FREE Wi-Fi & Katie, being on point and easy on the eyes put it over the top.

Plenty of parking on their private lot & a short walk from our hotel the Residence Inn Boise Downtown.', 'Definitely NOT the best first impression of Boise's dining scene. AT. ALL. 

Elmer's was the first eatery I tried when I finally survived the 15 hour journey from Los Angeles, CA to the university.  The first "real" food since leaving SoCal at 3am.  And, the first time encountering a 9PM sunset.  The restaurant is located at the entrance of a hotel cul-de-sac, like Residence Inn and Townplace Marriott.  It's like any other American diner serving breakfast fare all day, sandwiches and burgers, and hot food plates with a mild touch of fancehh.  

There's an older woman running the show, she's very friendly, but she didn't talk much and a group of young'uns serving the folks.  The servers are interesting, one of them, Justin looks like he could be a GQ model or something, not an apron wearing type guy.  Heck, he's not very good serving, he forgot straws three times (there were only 2 tables, us included).  Though, servers are friendly and very glad they kept a smile on their faces till the end.  

The place is rundown and old, it's outdated, dusty, sticky, and ughh.  The booths are the worst, your thigh skin/calf skin will stick to the seat and don't touch the window sill or anything by the booths, they don't wipe it down or remove the dead flies.  The carpet is like late 70s flower pattern and it's nasty, nasty enough I don't even want it to touch my shoes, heh.  The wall decorations are nice, they add that cozy factor along with their dustmiteous wall drapes. Other than whatever is going on in there, it's a pleasant restaurant with semi-decent edible food. 

My group ordered: 

Pot Roast w/ Broccolini and Mash Potatoes - SALTY. VERY SALTY. Mashed potatoes were wonderful, but the Pot Roast ruined it with so much salt. I felt like a cow licking a salt block. The broccolini was served as the "seasonal vegetables," and I find this to be somewhat fancehh for a place like this, but nonetheless, it was fresh and tender.  

Hazelnut-Crusted Alaskan Cod w/ Pilaf and Broccolini - Probably the smallest portion of fish and pilaf I've ever seen on a big empty plate. It was tasty enough though, and Granny somewhat enjoyed it so it's A-Okay.

Farmer's Omelet w/ Hash Browns and Biscuit - Thee best value out of all. The omelet wasn't cooked very well, it's like they ran out of eggs so the omelet itself was mostly a flat egg tortilla, but it was loaded! The country gravy isn't my thing, so I just took it off.  Overall, this was a good choice and it lasted for 2 meals!! Oh, and ask for hash browns well done, it will taste better.

Chicken Fried Steak & Eggs - My brother is obsessed with Chicken Fried Steak and will order it just about anywhere. He said this was just ok, he said IHOP had better... I don't know what that says about Elmer's but, I think it's weird he compares it to IHOP LOL.  Anyway, funny story. The older woman came around to check on us and refill drinks, she tried to do the "pour over someone's meal" serving technique and it FAILED miserably.  The water pooled all over my bro's meal and on the table and his shorts. Yup. She came and got him a new, dry plate, but not a new meal... 

Saturday Market Skillet - My bf's dad ordered this and was slightly disappointed because it didn't come in a skillet.  The picture showed a cast iron skillet that would perhaps keep his food warm for awhile, it didn't happen. 

Breakfast Sandwich - typical sandwich. Bf enjoyed it, he took out the bacon because he thought there was too many slices (only 2 slices) LOL. Oh well, more for me! 

Short Stack - PANCAKES! JUST COME HERE FOR PANCAKES!! Pretty much the best edible thing here. Hot, fluffy, buttery pancakes with warm maple syrup. Made me happy for sure. GOOD JOB ON PANCAKES!! 

So, our server Justin gives us the bill, we split the check, give him money, and only to find out that the bill didn't include the pancakes and he awkwardly hands us the new bill with the correct total. Really?! 

Overall, for semi-decent, semi-warm food, a solid 3.2 stars. Menu pictures look way better than in real life. Menu pictures also taste a bit better than in real life too, haha jk.  Not that wonderful but for the convenience (it's across from Boise U and by Residence Inn) it's ok.  No one got potty problems, so that was wonderful. Happy eating Boise!', "Elmer's Restaurant is a long standing tradition in the northwest. They have been around for over fifty years and continue to feed both the residents of the northwest and hungry travelers much like myself. I guess that the restaurant started out in Portland, Oregon by Walt and Dorothy Elmer and was initially known for Walt's buttermilk pancakes and started franchising in 1966. Since I prefer a savory breakfast over a sweet breakfast, I opted for a Denver omelet with Tillamook cheddar cheese. As I have said, I am not too into sweet breakfasts, but my client had a German pancake and it looked pretty impressive. I had never even heard of a German pancake,much less seen one. It looked good.

My Denver omelet was good and a great way to start the day.  

Elmer's uses a lot of products from the northwest, so you do get a true taste of the northwest.

I would definitely recommend this establishment for a breakfast spot. I give it an overall four () stars and suggest you check it out."]

name: Mad Swede Brewing
categories_raw: Pubs, Food, Beer Bar, Bars, Nightlife, Arts & Entertainment, Breweries, Wineries, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Wine Tasting Room
top_reviews:
["Visited Mad Swede Brewing this weekend and echo what several other initial reviews convey--a solid start for this new local brewery!

Came on a Saturday afternoon with friends and was happy to see they had a food truck on the premises. Picked up a burger and fries from the food truck and then headed inside to try the brews. We ordered their 8 beer sampler. 

We found all the beers to be resoundingly a-ok with a couple of stand-outs for me. I tend to favor porters and stouts and so my favorite beer was their Varangian Nectar Stout, which was smooth without sacrificing complexity. I also really enjoyed another stout (don't remember the name!) that had a marvelous smoky flavor (not for everyone, but I rather enjoyed it). Their nut brown was quite good and rivals any brown ale out there. Their Freya's Pale From Exertion is  an incredibly smooth and easy drinking beer, for those who fancy pales without a ton of hoppiness. 

The service was above and beyond wonderful. They have bar billiards, which we had never played before and a guy working in the tap room (brewer? owner? bartender? not sure) came over and gave us a run down of how to play (even though the rules are posted), which I thought was terribly kind. They also have a couple brewery dogs (kept mostly out of the tap room), which I always love to see. And, because they don't serve food, dogs are allowed inside! Love dog friendly breweries!

The best part? They're located across the street from Costco. So, once you've done a little Costco shopping craziness, you can reward yourself with a beer. 

Go ahead. 

You deserve to drink like a Viking after that insanity.

Get to it!", "We got an amazing delivery from Mad Swede at the beginning of the COVID19 quarantine life. We received two half growlers and a 6 pack for $30 plus free delivery. Such a Great deal! The delivery driver was wearing gloves. It wasn't contact-less as he handed the cardboard box to my hubs, but otherwise it was a very easy transaction. 

We got the Lollylager Lager, the Peregrine Pilsner and their Golden ale. The lager was definitely my favorite. Very crisp and light but full of flavor. No watered down nonsense of domestics. 

Can't wait to visit their taproom!", 'Nice setup at this brewery. Prices for a beer run around $5 or so which makes it easy to have a couple drinks and not break the bank. There are games like shuffleboard and darts available to play along with trivia cards on the table.  Plus a couple TVs in there allow for watching a game or something to have in the background with the beer.

They have a wide variety of beers from a session IPA to heavy IBU beers to stouts and everything else you could imagine. The beers are smooth and you can even make your own little taster sampler to try a little bit of everything.

Worth a stop along a Boise brewery tour.']

name: Reel Foods Fish Market & Oyster Bar
categories_raw: Food, Seafood Markets, Specialty Food, Restaurants, Seafood
top_reviews:
['Marcus Bonilla is OPEN for business at the Vista location as of 12/09/18!  Although it is true the estimated time to move from the old downtown location on Capitol Boulevard and re-open on the Bench was off by almost nine months (original ETA mid March 2018).  It takes time to birth a remodel of former Blimpie store in an old strip mall space and in particular when one of the contractors flakes out with $20K of paid for work left undone. 

Star rating "I'm a fan" 4 is based on experience as his customer at the old location and first visit to this one.  Selection is not as robust as it was at the old site but Marcus is working hard to get it there as customers discover he is here.

The name remains the same for Reel Foods as before although the "& Oyster Bar" piece is not so much evident.  And there is no hot food or prepared take out being done here as was so at the other location, simply because there is no kitchen at which to do it on this site.

But Marcus is not only enthusiastic and skilled buyer of all things seafood, he is also a Chef and he is hoping once he settles in at this location and gets his processes and fish inventory where he wants them to be that he'll be able to find an additional location offering hot food.  During our brief time in the new store, at least three other shoppers came in asking about hot dishes that were served at the other store.  Marcus says that is a common request so he hopes to find a space to provide what customers want. 

As has always been so for the fish Marcus sells, he can tell you where it came from and when it came in.  He "walks the talk" of transparency in sourcing.  He is still getting processes and stocks into the mode of new normal for this location, but on the day of our Monday holiday - when he was open visit - he had things like fresh halibut, Dungeness crab, sashimi grade tuna, Ecuadorian wild shrimp harvested that were large - 12 ct/lb size, rockfish, Atlantic salmon, steelhead and petrale.

Open six days a week (closed Sunday) with fresh deliveries daily, Marcus shared that his busiest days are Friday and Saturday and that is when he has the most fresh fish delivered.

He is keeping a low profile for marketing for now until he gets completely rooted in here.  But we're glad he's back and pass along the news to others.  I've requested Yelp change the "closed" header.

PARKING:  Private lot.

ACCESSIBILITY:  Level in the and all on one floor with ample floor space.  Marked accessible parking at the far end of the mall lot has no curb ramp associated but there is a ramp still further down. (Those aren't Reel Foods' failures but the Vista Village strip mall owner's problem of non ADA compliance even 29 years into the law.)  

GOOD NEIGHBORS:  Long time family owned Lee's Candies is near the other end of this same strip mall.  A good place to pick up some sweet treats.', 'It does not get better than this for the very freshest seafood with a broad variety of options.  That the owner, Marcus Bonilla, is such a nice guy and that the folks that work there are delightful too makes it all the better for shopping experience.  See my earlier review for details, but it is just great to see shoppers who care about knowing what their seafood is and where it comes from have found Reel Foods now that Marcus has settled in to the new location.  (See my earlier review for the details.)  Marcus and his team can answer any question about sourcing and arrival date and even preparation. 

I also appreciate that Marcus follows safe shopping protocols during this covid19 time and it seems all we who like to shop there do too.  Everyone in mask, lined up with 6 feet (or more) between us, only 3 shoppers at a time inside the store.  And on one occasion earlier on in the "stay home" period I ordered in advance and one of Marcus' team happily delivered my order to the cooler inside the open SUV hatch when I called from the parking lot.  (Side note re cooler:  We always arrive prepared with cooler and ice packs inside for transporting fish home.  But just in case you don't the folks at Reel always ask if you'd like a pack of ice to use to travel home with your 'catch' and provide it for customers who want it.)

I think Reel now does some scheduled delivery too.  Maybe free within XX (10?) miles and then what seems to me to be a really nominal fee for mileage beyond that.  I live about 30 minutes drive away (in normal traffic times) and may try delivery some time.

In the meantime, I follow Marcus' posting of what fish is available (see his FB page or link to same on his web site http://reelfoodsfish.com/ ) and make the trek every other week to buy a couple of day's worth of the freshest seafood to savor at home.  We have enjoyed great Dungeness crab (they'll clean it for you), halibut, rockfish, cod, swordfish, dry (day boat) scallops and Marcus' in house made lobster salad on rolls baked for him by local bakery Gaston's.  And while we don't choose sushi as an option, if you're a sushi eater I'll point out he has a wealth of sushi grade fish of all kinds in the case which always seem to be big sellers for other customers when we shop in store.', "Good news worth sharing for customers and fans of Reel Foods, like me, who wonder where it is going now that a 'closed and moving' sign has been up for several weeks at the Capital Boulevard location.  Per article in The Statesman this morning:

*Owner Marcus Bonilla hopes for mid-March 'ish' opening of the shop at the relocation address 1118 Vista Avenue (Vista Village Shopping Center in the Bench Depot area).

*They are remodeling the space that was once a Blimpie's sandwich shop.  Smaller space by far than the old digs.

*The focus will be entirely on being the neighborhood fishmonger. 

*There will no longer be the restaurant food that was available at the old location in the small dining space at the back.  Farewell to the fantabulous Oyster Po'Boys and the sushi rolls to say nothing of that luscious-lobstah salad for rolls when they had it.  Although they may add in chowder and seafood stew for take away once the new market is up and running.

*Hours likely to be Mon-Fri 10-6 and Sat 9 - 6 / Closed Sun.

I am disappointed in losing the convenient parking at the Capitol Boulevard location with the lot adjacent and easy and quick in and out to Reel Foods but pleased to learn they are going to refocus their original charter of being fishmonger (as they were when Ocean Foods owned it into 2015) and not restaurant.  The casual dining eats were good for sure, but the last couple of times I was in the shop I wondered if the owner needed to revisit mission.  It seemed the restaurant piece of Reel might be sapping the focus of the fishmonger primary function.  I walked out empty handed on both of last two visits given such limited options in the fresh case and the staff at counter told me it was several days old when I asked when one of the few fin fish choices was delivered. 

I'm looking forward to having the great fishmonger piece of Reel Foods back!  Even if I will have to drive to the Bench to sh"]

name: Even Stevens Sandwiches
categories_raw: Salad, Sandwiches, Breakfast & Brunch, Gluten-Free, American (New), Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Solid downtown Boise sandwich spot...can here with no expectations and left with very satisfied. I also liked that they weren't being over done on safety protocols but they were reminding customers of the rules when they weren't following them like walking through the restaurant without a mask or please wear it upon entering.  Plus they did a great job of social distancing the tables as well. So for applause for following what we should be doing...

The sandwich and soup was outstanding and yet not a lot of ingredients....I had the Do Gouda sandwich and consisted of roast beef, gouda, onion marmalade on sourdough bread with some fresh greens. Also accompanied was a cup of their tomato soup.  First bite of the sandwich I was like Oh Yeah! The crispness of the sourdough and then the blend of cheese, meat and onion marmalade was in every bite. Then onto the soup and well balanced here with very forward tomato which in my opinion is the best because some folks think they need to reinvent this classic and they don't.  So after a few bits of my sandwich and sips of soup something dawned on me and that was just because this wasn't grilled cheese (which they have by the way) this sandwich would taste amazing dipped in this soup. Well here I went and wow a whole new flavor profile immersed. So while I wasn't planning on dipping this sandwich into my soup that's exactly how I finished. 


Something else that threw this into 5 star for me is how friendly and nice the staff was about everything. I mentioned above on the safety protocols they were so nice about it but from the front counter to leaving everything was exceptional!", 'Evens Stevens is the total package. 

Great food? Check!

They have a variety of sandwiches with familiar names, but their interpretation never fails to improve upon a good thing. Their Sloppy Joe? Includes slow simmered chorizo. I also love that their French Dip-like sandwich (theirs is a "Pot Roast Dip") is made with turkey pot roast! I love French Dip, but much prefer turkey to beef--so this sandwich is a great (and delicious) option for me. 

Great service? Check!

I've never failed to receive attentive service here. From my first visit to my most recent--I have always been met with supreme friendliness.

Great atmosphere? Check!

With quirky, fun, and creative decor in a prime downtown locale--what's not to love?

And, finally, the pièce de résistance? 

For every sandwich you purchase, the funds for one is donated to local nonprofits to feed the hungry. 

Their charitable business model alone would make me a fan.

Thankfully, for local taste buds, they've got a whole lot more going for them than that.

Oh! And, hey...did somebody say Sunday brunch? Heck yes! 

Get to it!', 'Went to this place with a friend for lunch. The food and atmosphere was very chill but what really impressed me was when my friend found out she was allergic to a ingredient in her order they immediately changed it and she had a new order in less than five minutes. The manager was incredibly nice and you can tell he truly cares about the Even Stevens cause. I will be going back.']

name: Island Sushi & Ramen
categories_raw: Restaurants, Desserts, Japanese, Ramen, Food, Sushi Bars
top_reviews:
["Finally!!!!! Some unagi that was good!! I have been so dissapointed in Boise sushi selection, especially the unagi. But this place gave me hope. It was delicious, so we're the valcano roll and squid salad. Husband had hibachi and he even had left overs. Food was delicious, portions we're large and price was right. Definitely going back soon to try other dishes", 'I came here for ramen.  I'm not going to sit here and say that because I used to live in San Diego or that I'm this-or-that makes me an expert on what ramen should be.  To me, it's like any other food. If it tastes good and you like it, that's what it should be. With that being said, I enjoyed the ramen here so much I've been back several more times. Does this place have "authentic" ramen?  Who cares. It was good. 

Now that I'm off my soapbox, I will say my favorite has been the Kimchi ramen with spicy broth. The tonkotsu ramen is good, too, but I think there's more flavor in the spicy broth.  Again, it's subjective. I've had the chashu ramen, as well, but I'm not a fan of fatty pork unless the broth is blazing hot making the pork almost creamy. Requisite veggies as well as the standard boiled egg in the ramen. 

As their name implies, there is a sushi bar in the back. I'm not a huge sushi fan, but my mom ordered some and said it was good.  I think I've seen more plates of sushi on the tables than bowls of ramen when I've been in. I assume that's a good sign for the sushi. Potstickers were pretty good, too.
