This place gets busy. They've only got a couple options for parties with 5 or more and we've had to wait for one of the larger tables to free up. Otherwise the service has always been good and friendly and the prices are reasonable.  Give it a shot.', 'Oh man, I REALLY hate to do reviews of ramen places because I've been to a few of the top-rated ramen places in North America. This ruins you for all the other ramen out there because you now know EXACTLY what perfect ramen is like, so please beat that in mind as you read. I'll also preface this by saying we ordered for pickup, so the dine-in experience may differ significantly.

We ordered ramen, they have a really weird way of classifying their ramen, unlike anything I've ever seen. It made me ask if they were even serious about ramen until I poked around a little more. You start by choosing your protien...or veggie only option, then you choose the broth. Tonkatsu, miso, or...darn, now I don't recall the third option, maybe kimchi (not a fan)? There is no option for extra this or that like I've seen so many other places. We both had tonkatsu with pork.

Sushi is a little more straightforward and I ordered an appetizer with 5 pieces of sushi. I'm a sashimi guy myself, but first time I thought it prudent to go the safe route. Not bad, not exceptional, but nothing to complain about either, so fine. It came with everything you'd expect, a generous lump of wasabi :), pickled ginger and the obligatory little cup of soy sauce. No complaints on flavor or texture, it all seemed fresh.

The ramen...I liked the egg, well done with a nice softish center and good flavor, the pork was also good. The noodles, they were a little stiff at the beginning and needed to soak and a little prodding from the chopsticks in the broth for several minutes before they gave up on their plan to remain one giant lump. My wife even asked, "What's wrong with the noodles?" On the plus side, it did seem like a larger serving of ramen that I've seen elsewhere.

Special note for the monosodium glutamate sensitive like me, I've had ramen that gave me an upset stomach within an hour of enjoying it, the ramen here DID NOT upset my stomach.

I just moved to Boise from Phoenix so hey, all things are relative and maybe, just maybe, this is the best ramen in Boise. I learned to enjoy what I had in AZ, even if it did bother my stomach 100% of the time. What I do know is that I enjoyed this ramen much more than the stuff I had downtown last year. Maybe, just maybe the ramen is "knock your socks off" awesomeness when you enjoy it at the restaurant...which I didn't do.

Final verdict, the quality of both sushi and ramen was good enough that I will try it again...in the restaurant, they deserve that much. I would order sushi/sashimi to go without hesitation. Getting a look at the shrimp tempura while I sat inside waiting really made me curious about the rest of the menu too!']

name: North End Pizza
categories_raw: Nightlife, Restaurants, Bars, Beer Bar, Pizza
top_reviews:
["Reviewer no. 43

The outside appeal to this establishment is the reason that we went. We parked on 13th street and walked up and down the two sides looking at all of the places to eat before making our decision. We didn't intend to eat here, we just knew that we wanted something downtown but not the hustle and bustle of the city center, so we decided on Boise's north end. In the Northend, you'll find old-style residential homes and a block of fun places to eat and drink, a nostalgic candy shop, a toy store and much more. 

The restaurant has a modern look, which drew us to it. We crossed the street and into the Pizza place we go. This place is much more than pizza! They had many televisions playing football and pleanty of seating. There is a large bar in the middle. Seat yourself and the menus are already on the table so you don't have to wait. Our server brought us water, with no ice, and asked us if we wanted anything else to drink. We did get ice when we got a refill. 

We ordered-- the menu has appetizers (photo attached), sandwiches, pizza, and a few more items, but not a whole lot more. Looking at other tables the pizza appears to be a hit. 
I ordered the turkey meatball appetizer.Three very large meatballs in a well-balanced marinara sauce topped with a (small) piece of mozzarella cheese. The meatballs were very flavorful and spiced with herbs and had a good flavor. I only ate one and took the other home where they were just as good the next day. My only complaint is that I would have liked more cheese. 

My dining companion got the meatball sub with chips. He was a fan of the sub but not the chips. They tasted hard to him and they made his teeth feel as if they were going to break because they were hard. I didn't try them, so I will take his word on it. The meatballs, also turkey, were just as good as the large meatball appetizer only smaller in size. 

The prices were fair as the meal for two was under $20. Friendly people.", 'The pizza here is clutch. When friends and family are in town and they are craving pizza, I have brought them here. This is definitely on the higher price point for pizza but you get what you pay for and the ingredients are of quality, especially that goat cheese. 

The Certified, Hyde House, Hyde and Seek, Goodies, and Sun Ray have been some of the best pizza I have had in years. Ask for some hot sauce or ranch and you will be golden! (Get a salad if you want to be healthier. The Cobb and the House were delicious but pizza is always better.)

They are large tables for many or the bar for the solos (often me.) Service is not bad but at times we have had to wait longer than normal with empty water glasses, the check, or to-go boxes. With that said, I notice that usually one person is running the floor so I am more patient knowing that pour soul working the floor is busy as a bee.

Plan to wait to eat here if you pick the meal hours. Coming here outside of the normal dinner hour (a bit earlier than 6/7 or a bit after 8, your wait will be much shorter if any.

They also have my favorite beer on tap, a hef.', "Just opened, so we decided to try it out. 
Prices are pretty high, very slow service. Over 45 min wait for pizza and a sandwich, place wasn't busy. That's much too long for lunch service.

Pizza was good. 

Salad was undressed, but then they charged for more dressing. They also charged a the wrong price for a topping."]

name: Zero Six Coffee Fix
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Food
top_reviews:
['Someone give me another five stars for this review! Impeccable customer service, like beyond worldy! These two baristas were incredible. They were comedic, knowledgable, very approachable, and just the perfect examples of fabulous customer service. The male recommended me to try to pillow talk iced and I was not disappointed. They made it not sweet for me, and it exceeded my taste buds expectations. This coffee shop is fun, vibrant, lively and cute. I cannot say enough great things about Zero Six Coffee Fix.', "Butter beer coffee was amazing! 
Burrito was...meh. I'll try something else next time. 
Interesting place. Loads of character. Love it. 
Will definitely be back", "Update: This place is extremely unique and an anomaly. Although I only see these people once a week, we go on like we are best friends. They make an effort to know my coffee choice, joke with me, and call me by name. 

After becoming a regular, in my mind, I now know I stumbled upon something great! No.... upon something, grrrrrreat! I tell everyone!

Initially this was suppose to be just a meeting place for work down the street but now I think I want to drive across town just to study, eat, and drink coffee. This fun, eclectic little coffee shoppe will take your breath away with fun, daintiness, weirdness, qwerkiness, with great coffee and grub. 

When you order you feel like you are talking to a life long friend. The coffee-istas ;) greet you with a smile and friendliness. They have a virtual reward card so don't forget to sign up with your phone number. Buy 9 get one free! I'll race you to the free coffee because I plan on getting my first one in 9 days because I want to be here everyday.

In the center of the fun and coffee filled room, there is a warm retro-ish fireplace that cozies up the room a bit. There are a few cushy seats that makes you think you are in a living room but you are quickly snapped back to reality with the bustling sound of happy, coffee drinking friends that are surrounding you. 

Along with coffee/drinks and food get a gift! There are funny little gifts all over that are sure to give someone a chuckle that is hard to buy for.

No more bragging about how dang cool this place is. You just need to roll out of bed, get dressed, brush your hair and get here. That way you can experience the fun atmosphere with weird puffy storm clouds with lightening and strange, beautiful art on the walls.

Chandeliers! They have fun chandeliers!"]

name: Crumbl Cookies - Boise
categories_raw: Bakeries, Desserts, Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt
top_reviews:
["OMG. OMG. Their chocolate chip cookie is my all-time favorite out of any cookie ever. Yes, that's a huge statement--I get it. Lol but it's true. Served warm and tasted like heaven. I'm depressed they aren't local to me. That being said, I will put this on my stop each visit to Boise!! Love you Crumbl!!!", "They really do crumble! I surely do love me a big soft cookie and that is exactly what I got when I ordered from here. My journey with this cookie started when I seen one if my friends post these cookies on their Instagram and I instantly did some Instagram investigation to figure out where she got them from. Once I found out it was Crumbl, I then looked on their Instagram page and seen all the goodness they were offering. The pictures looked so good that I wanted to eat my phone (luckily I didn't). 

So, I proceeded to go to their website, which is a very clean website and order a bunch of cookies. They also have an app that is very easy to order from. Once you go to order off the website they have a bunch of preset cookie boxes that you can order. for instance, you can order up to 1 to 6 cookies at a time with the main flavors being chocolate chip, a specialty flavor and snicker doodle. I opted to go with the option of ordering a preset box of three chocolate chip and three of their specialty cookies. They have different specialty cookies every week and this week was the butterfinger cookie. I ordered on Thursday and the cookies got to me on Tuesday. They were still very fresh and once I warmed them up a bit they tasted sooooo good. They are actually big enough to where you can cut it in fours and share it with people. This is what I did so my family and I could taste the different flavors. My son really enjoyed the chocolate chip. The price point is good. Paid $27 for six huge cookies and shipping. 

My only gripe with this place is that when placing my order I noticed my order shipped from Boise and not a closer store which would be in North Carolina. I feel like if my order would have came from here I would have gotten my cookies a lot faster and they would have maybe been fresher to. Overall a great cookie and I can not wait to go in a store to taste in person.", 'YES! YES! AND MORRREE YESSSSS!!!! 
I try to watch what I eat. Lately, ugh lol. Then I was given my first Crumbl cookie by a good friend...AT. MY. GYM. hahaha! She gave me the Oreo cookie one.
In my old NY lady voice "TA. DIE. FOR!!!" 
I was legit sad when it was gone.
Sooooooo....after it was gone, I went to the Boise location. 
I bought the chocolate chip one and the animal cracker one. Again, when they are gone, you literally feel like part of you has died haha! Maybe because you just ate 2 gigantic cookies and they aren't healthy for you ORRRRR you just loved them so much and were genuinely sad when they were gone. As I type this out, I'm listening to Garth Brooks, "The Dance" 
So yes, I may or may not have a tear coming down my eye.....or eyes.

Ok! Sniff, sniff! Gathering myself here! While The Dance still plays..."holding you, I held everything" a line from the song....which easily would tie into holding a Crumbl cookie hahahaha!

OK! so when I entered the store, I was legit EXACTLY like a fat kid in the best candy store! I think the staff was a little weirded out by me because I was too happy or something haha!
Know how I talk and talk and talk on here? That's basically what I did from the second I walked in... as I snapped pics. She looks at me and I said "taking pics for Yelp!" Haha! 
She was very shy individual, but incredibly sweet. 
Her coworker, I'm assuming was a manager type, was very helpful to me when I asked about shipping some of the cookies back home to my sista. 
So if you've been to Chip in downtown Boise u know it's $3 bucks a cookie or 4 for $10. Is it worth it there? Absolutely.
Is it worth it at Crumbl......hell yeah it is!
I said to the manager girl, "I think yall may be better than Chip. Not sure what it is.....your butter or something" hahahaha! Random af, right?? Lol
It's true tho. I DOOOOOO BELIEEEEEVE they may be better than Chip. They have more of a variety to choose from as where Chip only seems to have 2 choices...Chocolate chip and whatever their special one is. 
Anyway, if yall been here, you know exactly what I'm talking about. The cookies are massive too! So you're definitely getting your money's worth! I have NAAAAN shame in buying these cookies! 
I'm a whore for a great cookie and when it comes to Crumbl.....I'm the fn madame hahahaha! (Hope that doesn't get my review deleted. That'll make me sad lol).
Staff is great, cookies are PHENOMENAL, store is super clean...reminds me of Chip tbh. All around a great experience. 
I wanted to go back as soon as my last 2 were gone (I ate them over a like a 3 day period lol) BUUUUUT.....they are gigantic cookies with tons of butter, sugar, etc and well....yeah, I need a few days break before I go back hahahaha! (Try a few weeks.....sad face lol)

That's it, Yelpersssss!!!

Go to Crumbl!


Cheers!


Edit! Just checked this weeks cookies and they have SNICKERDOODLES!!!!!!!! Ima be back there with a quickness!! SNICKERDOODLES?!? YESSS!']

name: Bardenay Restaurant & Distillery - Boise
categories_raw: Pubs, Bars, Distilleries, Gluten-Free, American (Traditional), Nightlife, Burgers, American (New), Food, Restaurants, Wine Bars, Cocktail Bars
top_reviews:
['What happened to you, Bardenay? 
What happened to my favorite restaurant in Boise? 
Oh how you disappointed me. Us. My wife & I. 
On my birthday no less. 
Unspectacular. Unbelievable. Unequivocally the epic fail of our stay in Boise.

.

Although we were seated quickly (it wasn't very busy - maybe less than half the dining capacity), it took over 10 minutes before I had to...nay, before I NEEDED to wave a waitress over. If I have to wave a staff member over to the table you've already put your review in jeopardy. That type of wait time is uncalled for. With attitude, she asked what she could get for us. "uh...how about a couple glasses of water, some bread & maybe take our drink order, bitch?!" ...but I asked nicely just in case the night & her attitude gets better. I'm a believer of "benefit of the doubt" mantra & will give anyone a chance & she was no different. 

My wife excuses herself from the table saying she needs to visit the ladies' room. (I found out later that she stopped to talk to the manager mentioning that it was my birthday and if they could bring a lil something over for dessert.)

With lead feet our waitress sludges from the bar with our drink orders, and before she leaves again, we ask if she'd take our dinner order. Oh, she had a 'tude alright...

It's been 20 minutes since we placed the order, our glasses are empty & she's nowhere in sight..WTF? It's been 45 minutes since we've sat down! For the next 5 minutes I'm scanning the dining room & just as I was about to get up out of my chair, I see her...with plates in hand...coming to our table! Yay. Finally. With anticipation, my succulent bacon-wrapped tenderloin is about to remind me of how much I love Bardenay's. 

Whoa nelly! My medium ordered steak was a little more on the "well" side. Overcooked & dry...I wasn't going to complain, so I took it in stride & tried to stomach a couple more bites. The garlic mashed seemed less fluffy & stiffer than I remembered (like the whole plate sat under warming lamps longer than it needed to). I'm a little pissed, but I didn't wanna get overly excited as my wife wanted a lovely evening with her husband on his birthday. She seemed to enjoy her meal just fine, but she's good w/McD's fries & a few packets of ketchup...I'm seeing red & can't even remember what she ordered, nor do I remember what kind of veggies accompanied my steak.

Plates are cleared; a bit of after dinner convo & our waitress comes over with a piece of cake on a saucer & says "uh...is this for you?" to my wife. Wifey says, "no..." and does that eye thing to say "...it's for him. It's HIS birthday cake" look. So, after hearing my wife say "no", and taking no hint from the eye gesture, she retreats back to wherever she crawled from with cake in hand. My wife and I just kinda look at each other, dumbfounded. I say, "don't worry about it, let's just pay the bill, get out of here & meet up with your friends at 10th Street Station. We'll have a great time!"

My wife is looking at the bill & her expression goes from a smile that says she's enjoying my company to pure annoyance. She storms out of her chair & makes a b-line for the waitress. I dunno what's going on, but I'm intrigued. I can't hear what's going on but the expressions of my wife towards that waitress was fun to watch.

My wife returned to the table w/out the bill. She proceeded to tell me that "ugh, that waitress! OH, HELL NO! She added that piece of cake to the bill!" I had to laugh. Not because it was funny, but because I had nothing to say in response to how bad this waitress was. The waitress placed the check on the table, without a word. No "my apologies", no nuthin'. The wifey scanned over the check to make sure all is right in the world, paid with cash & we left. When we reached the sidewalk, wifey says, "Bitch is lucky she got a 10% tip!"

Bardenay's...you've left us with a bad taste in our mouths. Please hire experienced servers OR give your wait staff the proper training your establishment deserves. Hiring gum-smacking bleach-blonde high school dropouts with condescending attitudes does not represent well. Maybe sometime in the future, you'll earn back my respect and the 2 stars I took away from my last review.

Maybe we should've stayed @ 10Barrel & threw some candles on one of their delicious looking pizza pies.

2 S T A R S, and I'm being gracious!', 'Wow...
Bardenay accomodated our party of 10 adults 5 children. Without hesitation they got their crew to put several tables together & within minutes our drink orders were taken.
Our server didn't even flinch when I asked if I could sample two of their IPAs (without charge I might add). Before taking our food order he offered to split the check however we wanted! What server would even consider to "offer" that? This guy did...he already had me at the IPA samplers.
While waiting for the food to arrive, I always imagined that if I ever owned a bar/grill, I'd definitely like to model "my" bar after Bardenay's. In no way is it original as it borrows its style from many shot-gun bars I've seen in my bar hopping travels. It is certainly done with class.
They have a great selection of draught beers & next to that resides a refrigerated glass window wine bottle dispensary with several great selections. Above center a large mirror is cantered so that you can "see" pretty much everything from wherever you are seated. I also noted the showcase of which sat the distiller. It's magnificent! Like a piece of art on display. Barneday has a daily/weekly liquor special in which they personally have distilled. This day it was gin. I'd have liked to have tried it, but tonight, I'm into the IPAs. I like the use of the used brick which covers most of the interior walls & the high beam ceilings. Not that the high beam ceilings are original either...just that it looked so clean up there & not packed with an inch of dust as I've seen many other joints, pubs & restaurants with this common problem...
Three wait staff, including our server arrived serving up our party's dishes. One by one you can smell the wonderful aroma mixing in the air. The service was outstanding; our whole party had their plates in front of them in about 2 minutes. Timing was impeccable.
My dish! 
the Beef Fillet @ $19.00. Bacon wrapped with a demi-glace, seasonal veggies & garlic mash.
one word: PHENOMENAL
This meat was "medium" ordered & cooked to perfection...my only complaint is that the bacon was burned to a crisp & parts of it inedible. The perfection in the tenderloin made up for it & the mashed spuds tasty!
To my left, my wife was twisting her fork around her Fettuccine with tomato sauce & shrimp & offered me a sample. OH SO GOOD!
To my right, mom-in-law was ever so silent for the longest time only to find that she was silently humming while diggin' into her Salmon Fillet...which she also offered a bite. DELISH!
As I looked across the table, the family looked as if it was Thanksgiving dinner & hadn't eaten in weeks. Even the distant "non stop yapping" cousin was silent while she devoured whichever dish she'd ordered.
Our utmost fave spot during our visit to Boise. 
AWESOME place...wish we had something similar to this in the Los Angeles area. Thanks so much for an excellent eating/drinking experience. Did I mention that the men's room is spot clean?

Another deez® review. Thanks for readin', I'm out.', "Bardenay has been recommended to my wife and I so many times that if was actually getting to be sorta annoying. So when the opportunity presented itself we jumped! This location is downtown in the Basque quarter, so you just know it's gonna be tons of fun and totally delicious! 
The food is crazy good. We were with a good size group of people and we all got something different and passed our dishes around. We started with the Smoked Trout appetizer, it was so good that it actually reminded me of my grandma's smoked salmon spread... it's as good as grandmas!!
We all decided to order the Mediterranean dish which included some delicious hummus, baba ganoush and some warm pita triangles. I'm a total sucker for these flavors and this fresh, simple appetizer is executed at the highest level. 
I had a Cider Brined Pork Chop and it was really good... I've had better (I prefer double chops to keep it more juicy) but it was a solid dish. 
My wife ordered the Fish and Chips and they were incredible! So crispy on the outside and perfectly cooked inside. My son ordered the cheese burger and he didn't give me a bite.. he said it was almost as good as what I make. 

The decor is pretty simple but being close to Halloween they did have some great decorations up. 

This place is good size and they have a ton of seating but they filled up pretty quickly. I'm not sure if they take reservations but you might call ahead. 

All in all we loved this meal and are looking forward to going back!!"]

name: Boise Co-op North End
categories_raw: Delis, Food, Cosmetics & Beauty Supply, Shopping, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Restaurants, Specialty Food, Health Markets, Skin Care, Beauty & Spas, Organic Stores, Grocery
categories: ['delis', 'food', 'cosmetics & beauty supply', 'shopping', 'beer', 'wine & spirits', 'restaurants', 'specialty food', 'health markets', 'skin care', 'beauty & spas', 'organic stores', 'grocery']
top_reviews:
['"Big enough to meet your needs.  Small enough to meet your neighbors."  That sign was painted on the Co Op window when I started shopping there six months ago.  Recently removed as part of a front spruce up, it is worth memorializing the phrasing here since since it seemed just right..

While we're on phrasing, to riff on the old Amex slogan...

...MEMBERSHIP HAS ITS' BENEFITS:

You don't need to be a Co Op member to shop here but, really, if you Co Op shop just once a month why wouldn't you?  It costs only $65 to join, a one time fee with no annual dues.  But if you join on the first Friday of any month you get a $15 discount and membership is only $50.  Why one would join other than a first Friday, I know not.

Members are entitled to periodic specials.  Better yet, once a month on any day of your choice you can receive a 10% discount on your entire order.  You will very quickly recover that $50 membership fee!

On that same day of the month you also will receive a 10% discount from any purchases at the Co Op Wine Shop or the Co Op Pet Shop just  across the parking lot.  The 10% off the Wine Shop discount one day a month sure comes in handy for my hubby and me.

Even if those other two shops don't beckon to you, there are...

...SO MANY THINGS TO LIKE HERE:

PEOPLE:  Friendly staff, including the young woman checker who went out of her way when it was evident I was a stranger in a new land on my first few visits to talk to me each time, make you feel welcome.

PREPARED FOODS & DELI:  They list local purveyors used in their dishes, all of which are made in house.  (Try that at Whole Foods...you won't find it.)  This is the only market where I trust the take away and enjoy it.  PS to my omnivore, vegan, vegetarian and paleo friends, there are an equal number of great options for all.

CHEESE:  A very good selection of domestic and imported and a super helpful woman, who also once lived in my former home city, works there who always has a wonderful tip or two. .

PRODUCE:  Leans almost all organic, has local vendors (like Purple Sage and Peaceful Belly) and carries things no one else does, like the fresh Emmett grown strawberries that went into October this year.  Their seasonal offerings can't be beat.  This week they had two kinds of fresh kumquats, most groceries carry none at all, and beautiful escarole.  

BAKERY:  Local breads, like Gaston's wonderful Pouichette and Acme's teriffic breads of all kinds are sold here.  Their in house bakery has the most mmmmmarvelous ginger cookies and lots of other good things.   They have Wildflower Bakery  treats, like baked apple cider donuts or blueberry pound cake on a display.  They also have Boise's  own Guru donuts.

PACKAGED FOODS:  In addition to staples, like canned tomatoes, in brands we use, the Co Op always seems to have what I'm looking for that is hard to  find elsewhere.  Pomegranate molasses, for example..  They also have a great selection of top end, Italian made, speciality shape pastas.  My husband is a very happy guy that they have Willamette Valley Fruit Growers frozen berries in the freezer section in 2 pound bags.  

DAIRY: The dairy section is a bit small, but they have yogurt and buttermilk which does it for me.

MEATS $ FISH: The meat section is also a bit small, but what they do have is organic and humanely raised and the butchers there know their stufff.  The fish selection is even smaller and we normally find ourselves at Reel to buy ours.

TUNES:  Music on the sound system is so great it makes me want to sing and dance as I shop.

INSIDE SEAT TO EAT: There is a nice area inside where you can sit to nosh.   Seating is both at high counters and  standard tables so accessible to everyone.  

THIS N THAT:

1) PARKING:  Can be bumper cars even though the lot is good sized.  Proceed with caution.

2) ACCESSIBILITY:  From accessible parking in the door and throughout ample aisles, all is good.

3) NEIGHBORS:  The Co Op Wine Shop is unarguably the finest in Boise.  It may even be the best wine seller we've ever had the fun of shopping at and it is just across the parking lot.  See those reviews too.  Richard's Cafe Vincino two doors down from the Wine Shop is a wonderful place for lunch or dinner.  

4) MERIDIAN ON THE HORIZON:  Co Op is opening a second location in Meridian.  Will be closer to home for me.  Wohoo!  Their goal is summer 2015.', 'The Boise CoOp provides the most disgraceful customer service I have ever seen at any food market anywhere. 

After searching the dairy area for cottage cheese I was unable to locate it. I asked an employee standing 10 feet away. Rather than step down from his ladder and walk me to the product--as is done in every grocery store in the country--I was directed to the deli area. When I couldn't find it there the deli employees directed me back to the dairy area. I then approached the original employee who did in fact step down and walk me to the item in the dairy area. 

On five separate occasions I have  requested information about a roasted turkey product sold behind the deli counter. I've asked three deli employees and two customer service counter folks where it comes from, is it organic, and why they don't slice it for sandwiches. Answers have varied from, "The turkey arrives roasted and chopped," to "We are only allowed to slice Boar's Head products on our slicer," to "You have to ask the deli manager." Oh really, who is that? None of these employees was interested in attaining the information for themselves so that they might better assist the next customer. Letters to management go unanswered. 

Looking for local organic products? Better go to the Saturday Capital Market rather than the CoOp. Although the packaging may be pretty very few items come from local farms. Expect to find produce from around the world. Looking for healthy packaged food? Products on these shelves may contain GMOs, BHT, BPE, and BGH. Read labels carefully. 

The local Winco has identical products for roughly 60% of the price, and employees who actually know the store and are willing to help. 

Boise CoOp, shape up! Although the latest Whole Foods plan was denied by city council, they will be here soon. Their employees are well trained and their products are guaranteed to be free of many of the carcinogens you sell in fancy packaging.

**12/28/10 edit**
I bought medicinal herbs here the other day. Without getting into specifics let me warn you that the herbs were mislabeled. When I got home I realized the mistake and threw away the mislabeled herb. This could have been a very dangerous situation. Medicinal herbs--used improperly--can cause a multitude of problems on their own, or in combination with other medicines.

I brought the problem to the attention of employees, who corrected it but did not seem concerned.', 'Boise Co-Op fill in the blank review...

Please select the most relevant response which completes the following sentence:

The Boise Co-Op ________ than Whole Foods.

1) is more EXPENSIVE  
2) offers less VARIETY
3) is less FRESH  
4)  is DiIRTIER
5) ALL the ABOVE']

name: Flying M Coffeehouse
categories_raw: Shopping, Food, Flowers & Gifts, Bakeries, Coffee Roasteries, Restaurants, Gift Shops, Coffee & Tea
top_reviews:
["Fly M Coffeehouse Downtown Boise in 5 words: Students, hipsters, gifts, chaos, lattes. 

Mayhem
There is clutter, there are teenagers, and more frighteningly, there are hipsters. Just kidding, the tweens take the cake in the frightening department. There is a small nook just for little kids and I've never seen a coffeeshop with one before. I like the concept. I would usually avoid this much chaos but they're one of the only coffee places open late that serve an excellent latte.

Almond milk latte on a green couch
My favorite seat in the house to sip a latte is the green couch, it's got personality. The lattes are consistently fantastic despite the cluster muck that is this place. The baristas are very nice and the baked goods are a mixed bag. They aren't terrible, I just have high standards for baked goods and more often than not, theirs are too dry.

I just want a pretty fern
My only actual complaint is the latte art. I get hearts. Every. Single. Time. Come on guys. What do I have to do to get a fern around here? 

Could I interest you in some sarcasm? 
Their gift shop is the best. Snarky coffee mugs, kitchen towels that swear, unicorn faux taxidermy. Whatever you're in the market for, that isn't mainstream, they'll probably have it. 

If you're into great coffee, fun gifts, have a high tolerance for teenagers, and hipsters, you're probably going to love Flying M in downtown Boise.", 'An unpretentious and funky, all people are welcome vibe coffee house with a truly neighborhood sensibility that I wish was closer to my neighborhood because I'd go in often.  

DRINKS & EATS
I have not strayed from black coffee or Americano, although they make all kinds of coffee / espresso beverages.  The coffee is good.  The Americano is really good.  

Baked goods are created in house.  I am a fan of their biscotti in particular.

Can you say "share" boys and girls?  Of course you can.  And you should plan to do that if you choose a cinnamon roll as your goody because they are big.  The guy sitting next to my hubby and me this morning paused on his way out to say, "I admire the way the two of you are working as a team to attack that roll."  I laughed and told him "Pull up a fork, there is plenty for three."   And here's a tip; the cinnamon rolls often sell out by 10:30 a.m.

There is a sour cream chocolate sheet cake that seems to be a signature / staple and I hear it calling my name every time I'm here.  Maybe next time I'll succumb to the Siren's song.  Calories be damned.

Prices are reasonable.  

THE DRILL & SERVICE
Stand in line, place your order, wait while they make the beverage and plate up your eats.  Then carry it to your table.  Bus your own when done.

People behind the counter are friendly and pretty darned efficient too.. 

SEATING & VIBE
Seating is at tables and chairs, all standard height on the main level and also up one step to a raised seating area.  There is counter seating that is also standard height with chairs, another high counter height table with stools and a sofa near the front door. 

In the mode of all people being welcome here, let me say I wish I had my phone to take a shot of the cars in the parking lot the day before yesterday.  Left to right in the first three spaces :  a) car with Trump bumper sticker...next to that b) car with Obama 2012 bumper sticker...and one car over from that c) a car with Bernie 2016 window sticker.  

To be truthful, I imagine it might be a tad uncomfortable for anyone transferring that Trump sticker from car bumper to themselves and walking in here.  This feels more 4th Street Berkeley than Main Street Coeur d'Alene for audience.

Still, there seems a sense of grace filled detente here and people from all stages in and walks of life. 

GIFTS & THINGS
There is an area for buying cards and giftee-s too.  You know, like if you wanted to sit in a coffee house and write an actual long hand note in a card to mail to someone.  Ahhh...love it.  I used to be a prodigious sender of cards and handwritten notes.  I have lost that that practice.  

Free wifi too.

THIS N THAT:

PARKING: is on street and also in a very small lot in the back.  One space of accessible parking, although to my wheelchair using friends I point out it is only van accessible if you back in. 

ACCESSIBILITY:  Level in at the front door and in the back /side door.  Mostly on one floor although a few tables are up one step.

LOO:  Down the hall.  It is accessible.', '143rd reviewer of Flying M Coffeehouse Downtown Boise, Idaho. For those of you 90's kids, 143 was our pager code for "I love you". 

This is my 383rd review on Yelp. 

Flying M Coffeehouse! Amazing place-- very modern, cultured, accepting, pushing the red state boundaries, and great coffee and pastries! 

Flying M is known as a "gay" establishment. The people that run the show are oftentimes gay, transgendered, straight, bisexual and all around genuinely good people. 

The coffeehouse is a place to sit, talk, work on homework or work, and enjoy coffee and pastries. 

There is a store inside that has lots of fun, humorous stuff. See my photos and make sure to like em! 

This is the first of two locations-- the other one being in Nampa and is super awesome!']

name: The Hyde House
categories_raw: Restaurants, American (New), Food, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Nightlife, Wine Bars, Bars, Breakfast & Brunch
top_reviews:
['Instant star for being extra dog friendly; we asked for a cup of water for our fur baby and they brought a huge pail.  It seems like the surrounding area is pro dog.

Started with a very satisfying Mad Swede Nut Brown Ale, so good.

The Fettuccini Special lived up to its billing, very eye appealing.  The Ahi Poke was ample for the price., good overall.  The Brussel Sprout Salad was heaping, but sounded better than it tasted.  It was good mind you, just not great.

Great ambiance, awesome patio dining on a cool Summer evening.', "Oh man, I am so excited to have finally tried this place out! Charming outdoor dining space, great service, tucked away in the North End, and the yummiest food!

ATMOSPHERE: Okay, I am totally a sucker for atmosphere, so the dining space alone had me sold on this place. I actually didn't set foot on the inside part of their restaurant. I sat outside at a cute little table on the patio and enjoyed the sunshine, stringed lights, covered patio, misters, simple landscaping (mostly succulents), and a perfect view of all that's happening on 13th street--just dreamy.

FOOD: 

We tried the ahi wontons for our appetizer. Now before I start explaining how phenomenal these were, I must put out a disclaimer: I don't like raw fish. Now that we've got that out of the way, I will say that this dish had me strongly reconsidering that statement. These wontons were SO good, I would have ordered just a plate of those for dinner had I known how much I'd enjoy them. Seared ahi sitting on top of a crisp wonton with a wasabi cream, and cucumber. The perfect combination of textures--the ahi was easy to sink my teeth into, cucumber crisp, and wonton at the bottom tied it all together with a nice crunch. The wasabi sauce gave it the right amount of kick. SO yummy. 

For dinner, I had their veggie special of the night, which was a burrata cheese salad with fried potato wedges on the side. I loved this also, but man oh man, can I have some more of those wontons?! Those were my favorite part. 

To finish off our meal, my friend and I split their ice cream sandwich. It was simple and sweet, just like it should be--two homemade cookies divided by a generous dollop of vanilla ice cream.  

And of course, the drinks! We split a 22 oz bottle of Meriwether Cider's Ginger Cider. This was refreshing and paired perfectly with enjoying a meal outside on a hot summer day!

SERVICE: Our server was friendly, knowledgeable about the menu, and attentive. Every question we had about the menu, he had an answer to, our waters were full the whole time, and he was accommodating to our requests.

I cannot wait to come back...and when I do, you better believe it'll be Amie-Eats-Ahi-Wontons 2.0.", "We came here for dinner on Friday night. Cute little place with a lot of charm. We ordered the Niçoise salad and the BBQ Pork. The food was good and surprising filling. They seem to focus on community by trying to use organic and local ingredients. It tasted good and it's all made in house. The staff is really friendly and they make you feel at home. The owner Jill is especially nice and asked for our input on possible additions to the menu. The Hyde House is a good place to eat with your family or catch up with your friends. I'll be coming back for more!"]

name: Twisted Timber Tavern
categories_raw: Pizza, Restaurants, Pubs, Nightlife, Mexican, Bars
top_reviews:
['I can't believe I've been living 2 miles from this place for the last 2 and a half years and this was my first time visiting! Twisted Timber checked all my boxes for an A+ evening. If I could more than 5 stars, I would. 

For drinks my husband tried a Lush IPA (7% ABU, 80 IBU, Fremont Brewing) and I downed 2 glasses of Bourbon Barrel Peach Cider (6.9% ABV, Tieton Cider Works). It was the perfect balance of tart from the apples and sweetness from peaches. Super crisp and refreshing. I could have drank more if I wasn't DD. 

For food, we split a Buffalo Pizza with Cauliflower Crust (10", Buffalo sauce, chicken, olive, spinach, and avocado,  $16.00) and baked sweet potato fries ($5.95). Okay, if I'm being completely honest here I have to say I have my suspicions about the cauliflower crust because it was just too damn good! I've had cauliflower crust that was absolutely horrendous but you know what you're getting yourself into. The avocados were a nice touch and these were fresh! No browning or bruises on any pieces. It honestly was a really pretty piece of food. The sweet potato paired excellently. They were cooked to crispy perfection and served with delicious fry sauce. I'll come back just for some cider and fries!

We both walked out more than satisfied and agreed this is somewhere we may very well began to frequent on the regular. I definitely recommend Twister Timber to everyone!', "There are some places I've been visiting for so long that I just forget to Yelp about them. When I saw another Yelper's post about the Timber, as we lovingly refer to it, I checked to reread mine only to find out it doesn't exist, so here goes:

The Timber rocks. It's like a neighborhood spot. When we lived near Maple Grove and Lake Hazel, it was just a hop, skip and a jump away, so we were the regulars and got to know some of the servers by name. To this day, it still tickles me when we come in (after months of absence) and are recognized by their friendly wait staff. Great, great people work here and share their love, knowledge and passion for beer with their guests. I should mention, or maybe I shouldn't, that they never turn me down when I ask for excessive tastes. I'm sorry, but I love variety and I love trying new beers. So I always know that I will wind up with something I like, instead of being forced into picking a beer that I'm uncertain about.

Their tap selection is seriously killer. I love Bier:Thirty and a couple of other tap-houses in the area, but find most of them to be kind of stout / porter / black IPA heavy (even in the summer, when you couldn't pay me to drink something dark). Maybe one of the reasons I love the Timber so much is because they cater to my tastes a little more, which means more pale ales, IPAs, blondes and lagers / pilseners. However, they certainly have maltier, darker things available (just not in the abundance that other places might; sorry, Ophelia!), such as Mack and Jack's African Amber (it's almost always there) and a rotating stout / porter. Whoever selects their beer has amazing taste, usually featuring something out-of-this world (think Rogue's Dead Guy [even Double Dead Guy, on one occasion], Stone's Arrogant Bastard, Odell's Myrcenary, etc.). They also have amazing tap takovers by my favorite brewers in the world, such as Lagunitas, Deschutes and Hop Valley (my latest obsession).

I think if one area could improve, it could be the food; however, I haven't tried enough to really comment on this. Their baked, seasoned fries are incredible and we almost always order them. Their Timber sandwich (corned beef, turkey, bacon, the fixin's) is great, but their spicy ham sandwich and Rueben are a little lacking. Their house salad, as well as the mixed greens that come as a side with sandwiches, are really great and better than you would expect for a place like this. I think their pizza is just okay. I've heard great things about their nachos from multiple parties, but have never tried them myself. You could seriously do worse in the food department, it just doesn't satisfy as well as some other places. However, the tap selection is enough to bring my back every time (and make the drive now that we live further North).

The ambiance is, as another Yelper described, somewhere between a cozy sports bar (there are a few screens; free shuffle board; darts and pool) and a neighborhood restaurant. It's definitely a locals spot, but I never feel like an outsider (which I actually do at some breweries). Their patio is expansive, well-shaded when you need it and a great place to drink in the summertime.

This review has gone on long enough, so I'll try to quit spouting praise for this establishment, but suffice it to say that it's one of our favorite watering holes and we'll continue to make the drive as long as this place is around. Three cheers for the Timber!", "This is a great clean neighborhood sports bar. They have a great on tap selection that changes regularly.  Both times I have been here they have had everything from a porter to a IPA. The first time I went I told the server I wanted to give the Souless Ginger a try. To my suprise she brought me a sample.  She apperantly  knew my taste better than I did, I went with the porter. My friend suggested we share some Queso fries, I ordered them the next time I came back. I'm not sure how to describe  them other than an amazing pile of hot deep fried seasoned fries smothered in some sort of queso style nacho sauce.  I was so ashamed of myself as I wiped the last of the cheese sauce from my mouth. I can't wait for the next Broncos game... TV'S abound they are on every wall in the place. Not all of the seats have a great view of the TV but the arrangement works well enough. I didn't go around the corner  but I heard they have a pool table and a shuffle board in the back. This is a great clean sports bar crossed with a nice family friendly  neighborhood resturant."]

name: Andrade's Restaurante Mexicano
categories_raw: Restaurants, Steakhouses, Mexican, Seafood
top_reviews:
['Some Yelp reviews have expiration dates because restaurants are fluid - things change over years.   With that in mind, time to back up a bit for opinion about Andrade's.  Once our favorite Mexican food eatery in the Treasure Valley where we have enjoyed a dozen-ish meals over the past three years and recommended it to scores of other diners. this last time in it was such a poor experience for food that we left not only disappointed but embarrassed. Because along with us was a friend who was in for her first Andrade's visit based on our unwavering recommendation.

Alas, all three meals were so dry and lacking flavor that they were little edible.  So little so for my plate that our friendly server took half the cost of the dish off the bill.  Nice of her to do as none of us complained but we were honest when she asked, given none asked for take away box in spite of ample remainders on plates, "Didn't you like the food?" 

Every place can have a bad day.  This I know. And as update note 2/18/19, I share that I heard from the owner who was good to be concerned.  See my UPDATE comments embedded to try to fairly address his comments. 

But for three poor to nearly inedible dishes served at the shank-end of lunch hour (they make the turn from lunch to dinner menu at 3p, although dinner can be ordered during lunch hours too and dinner plates were ordered by two of us), was disquieting.

Also worth noting the salsa and bean dip that accompanies chips arrived in 'tasting sized' little cups nearly impossible to use.  Our friend asked if we could get larger serving vessels as are normally used here.  The friendly server subsequently obliged with apologies that the dishware was dirty when we arrived and she had some washed for us.  This at a time when I recall fewer than eight people in the eatery with the lunch crowd long gone.  A little thing but nonetheless another thing suggesting things are not as fine tuned as before.

The menu has much expanded in the last months.   Is that why the food was not now as good?  Could the kitchen be over stretched? I don't know.  But we all ordered standard offerings like enchiladas and tamales.  The dinner plate portions were huuuuge but less of better quality is more in my view. 

Also in the several months between our last visit and this one there has been a full bar added inside the main dining room.  Has the focus on food been lost in the transition?  I don't know.  But worth noting this addition for those interested.

All of this may not have been enough for me to give up on Andrade's without a follow up visit before deciding to take it off my 'favorites list' but for two other items in a perfect storm.

The first of these was, as we exited, raw big sink in the kitchen piled high with what looked to me like raw chicken.  It was an 'ugh' moment making me wonder if I wanted to eat here again.  (UPDATE:  The owner let me know this was a tray of thawed, raw breast meat which they use and on a tray over the sink getting ready for being washed / cleaned for safe use.)  Uncertainty reinforced the following week with the restaurant inspection news in the Boise paper (I read the report weekly) called out a handful of violations at Andrade's, a couple of which I considered significant on their own but in context of the several more disquieting still.  (UPDATE:  I assumed in my original comments that readers know how the process works.  For those who may not know here goes;  periodic health code inspections are unannounced and eateries are given X days - typically 10 days -  to correct the violations itemized by inspector and then there is reinspection.  So these were corrected.)

On the plus side, the people who work at Andrade's are have always been, most friendly and it remains a welcoming interior.  And more plus, although I didn't check it out, there is now a sign up at the entry with "Family Bathroom" which has unisex symbols and also a wheelchair icon and arrow pointing direction through an adjacent space. 

But 'thinkin' bout my Yelputation' - to borrow and butcher the lyric from The Who's tune - I have to say I'm lukewarm about returning to Andrade's after this visit.  

What to you mean you don't know the tune?  Sure you do.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qN5zw04WxCc', 'Neither the swankiest building nor in the best of locations but look closer and you see pride of place in keeping the front tidy and with lights strung as welcome and seasonal plantings in sidewalk pots.  That pride of ownership is carried through inside too in everything, starting with delicious food.  On each visit we've also enjoyed warm "all people are welcome" vibe and friendly service.  Andrade's is easily our favorite of all Mexican restaurants in the Treasure Valley.   The single thing that keeps me shy of 5 stars is a big-ish hitch in the giddeyup because of the old infrastructure.  (See THIS N THAT.)

VIBE:  This is an old building so if you're looking for flash and dazzle, you're going to need to hit up one of the chain joints.   (Good luck with that bad idea.)  But the interior is charming neighborhood style restaurant with evidence of the owner's pride in heritage.  As example, the great diorama that sits high on the wall above the dining room is a replica of his grandmother's house in Mexico.

On each visit we've noted diners are all ages and walks of life; an "all are welcome" that appeals to us.  On one visit three young men dressed in USAF uniforms sat at one table, next to them a young family that spoke Spanish, across from them four senior citizens (who were clearly regulars) and at the booth next to us two guys in suits discussing marketing strategies.  Nice.

FOOD:  I am grateful to the Yeep who sent me a message after seeing my review of a woeful experience at one of the flashy big chain outposts to suggest I try Andrade's for the best Mexican food in Boise.  She was right.  In fact, this is some of the best Mexican food we've enjoyed anywhere.  I'd put Andrade's mole in the same class as Nuestra Cocina's in Portland.  That is high praise.

I won't recite menu options because you'll be able to find that information in other reviews.  But worth noting the salsa served at table with chips is  just one of several available at the salsa bar where you can help yourself.  A couple of those choices are tastebud incinerating level of spiciness that my husband thought perfect.

Also worth noting that in addition to animal protein options for filling enchiladas and tacos, Andrade's  has a really good vegetable combination that can be used for that too.  So if you're like me and love mole sauce but never quite 'get' the chicken that typically comes with it, you can do veggie mole and be as happy as...well...a pig in mud!  This is authentic, dark, Mexican chocolate and spicy chile rich mole with not a hint of the peanut butter added to the "mole 101 for beginners" at chains .  Proceed accordingly.   I wanted to lick my plate.

The menu is extensive and every time each dish has been wonderful.  Including some specials my hubby ordered that seemed unique to Andrade's.

SAVE ROOM FOR DESSERT:  The flan is remarkable.  Thanks to the server on our first visit who volunteered that she could pack it to go when we were too full to eat it after the meal   She said it was unlike any other and encouraged us to order it to go.  She was right.  Worth every calorie.

SERVICE:  On our first visit when we were obviously new to the place our server was nice to take the time to answer our questions.  When I ordered mole she was also nice to ask if I'd like a taste first.   She laughed when I asked if I looked like a gringa who didn't know what I was getting into.  When she replied "Yes" when I asked if it was the owner's grandmother's recipe I said no taste needed, I knew I would love it.  And I did, but she was both nice and professional to check back in soon after we started eating to be sure.   On subsequent visits the service has been as friendly, no matter how busy they may be.  Each time at the end of the meal the servers took the time to say "I hope you'll come back."

LIBATIONS:  You walk in past a bar but I don't know if they have hard liquor.  I noted wine and beer but we treat ourselves to Jarritos with the meals.

THIS N THAT:

1) PARKING:  Small lot.

2) ACCESSIBILITY:  One 'sort of' ADA spot.  Level in the door.  All on one level.  Standard height seating.  The loo is not accessible.

3) LOO:  Bathrooms are small.   Not only impossible for people with mobility issues if they needed to get in with walker or wheelchair (increasingly possible for me as I have MS) but also might be impossible for zaftig sized people.  I can't imagine the remarkable Brittany Howard being able to squeeze in the door for example. The hitch that, absence of a bathroom all people can use,  keeps me from five stars.  May not seem important to you unless you can't get in to use it.

4) WHAT DO YOU MEAN YOU DON'T KNOW BRITTANY HOWARD?:  Sure you do.  By voice at least.  See and hear her here.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wwP_ydXgkWM', 'I hate to write less-than-stellar reviews.. I really do. I LOVE to give great places the praise they've worked so hard to deserve. Its NOT easy to run a restaurant, or any type of establishment... especially in this shitty economy. 

So last weekend, when I had a hankering for some delicious chips and salsa and a chile relleno, among other Mexican goodies... I, of course, checked in with my fellow yelpers to lead me in the right direction. This isn't like Southern California where you can throw a rock and hit 5 delicious Mexican joints. Hence why its taken me almost 2 months to even ATTEMPT to find a good Mexican restaurant.

When I saw the decent reviews for Andrades, I was pretty excited, especially since I happened to be in the general vicinity at the moment. One reviewer even went as far to say that it was the best Mexican cuisine outside of Mexico. Well, I'm assuming that he hasn't been to California recently. Because i was less than thrilled with Andrades.

First of all, we arrived late Saturday afternoon. Like, 2:00 or so... Not really what I would call the "rush" hour of the restaurant world. Manfriend and I waited at the host area for a good ten minutes. Finally, after we still were not acknowledged... Manfriend found a kitchen worker and asked if we were to just seat ourselves, or.....   FINALLY, the one and only server working came to inform us that he was just cleaning off a booth and we would be sat as soon as he was finished. Swell.

I do have to say, their menu is quite extensive, with all kinds of salads, combinations, tacos, burritos, seafood options, and carne. There are almost TOO many options, especially for my incredibly indecisive ass. One gripe that I do have, is that they seem to have a problem making any substitutions on the combos or anything else for that matter. Which I find incredibly odd.... at almost EVERY mexican restaurant Ive ever been to (which is ALOT), I've had NO problem substituting things... especially when I am willing to pay for said substitution. 

Finally after about 2 baskets of chips and several cups of salsa... oh, and a pitcher of water (the server just left it on the table. good call), I was ready to order. I decided upon the 1 item combo, which was a pork tamale (they only have pork tamales... womp wompppp), and my sides were the chicken tortilla soup and a salad. Also, I ordered a chile relleno on the side, since I couldn't seem to get it as part of my actual combo... whatev.

The tamale was good... I guess.. no Long Beach Cinco De Mayo shit, but okay.. and the chile relleno was exceptional at best.. I just had a hard time NOT comparing each thing I had with my fave joints in CA. Made me rather homesick. Not a feeling you want to have when going out to eat in the city you decided to move to..

I am still on the hunt for a GREAT Mexican place in Boise-area... let me know if you know of any... til then, my Yelpers. =(']

name: The Tortilla Factory Mexican Grill
categories_raw: Restaurants, Mexican
top_reviews:
['14th reviewer of The Tortilla Factory
This is my 360th review. 

I feel that this place in a work in progress and they're going the correct direction. The people that work here, primarily the owners, work long, hard, and seem to really care about their customers, food and your overall experience. The owner has been in there every time (manager perhaps?) and is always providing excellent customer service, asking me questions and telling me how important that it is for consistency, which I agree with. 

The food is of good quality, tasteful, warm and filling. They have a different albeit Americanized balance to their food-- there is a salsa bar to help yourself to. Coke products. I've tried a lot of things on the menu-- I prefer the shrimp tacos as they're super good. 

The Tortilla Factory is located on a small strip of businesses near Walmart and Lowes near the Edwards Spectrum. It's "fast food" so don't be expecting a 5-star restaurant. It's in the Los Betos level of mexican fast-food, just higher quality and made with care.', 'Wanted to give Tortilla Factory another go, this time i brought my better half.  Decided to implement a new rule for 2018, the 2-visit rule prior to feedback because this visit was much better.

We both got the Barbacoa Burrito and they were delicious.  Was hopeful the tortilla maker had come in but they are still waiting for it.  I look forward to that Barbacoa Burrito wrapped in a home made tortilla.

We also orderwd chips and salsa, chips were very good and the salsa bar has a couple of options that are very good.

The staff is incredibly friendly, even got to see a pic of the awaited Tortilla Maker... this thing is no joke... they are going to be able to pump out some hot, fresh flour tortillas!

Welcome to the neighborhood TTF, I am sure we will become more aquianted', 'Love, love, love this place!!!  Great service, authentic food.  Get it as spicy as you want it.  My problem with great Hispanic restaurants in this country is that the food is so mild and cilantro is so divisive (either you love it or you hate it). I love it. And I love my rice very flavorful!  Bland rIce and no cilantro will not get 5 stars for me.']

name: Boise Airport
categories_raw: Transportation, Limos, Hotels & Travel, Airports, Public Transportation, Airport Terminals
top_reviews:
['Cute and cozy. No, I mean it. Are those odd descriptors for an airport? Probably. How many hassles have I experienced in two decades of travelling through this airport on a semi annual basis? None. Zip. Zero. One terminal, two floors, small, logical design (I know right?), and friendly airport service individuals. If you've seen the delightful film The Terminal, sometimes I think about those characters when I walk through this airport. The vibe is a good one, that's what I mean.

Boise Airport is the busiest airport in the state of Idaho, second only to the dinky Idaho Falls airport in eastern Idaho that I nearly blinked and missed. Fun fact: this is also a military hub for the National Guard. "Busiest" is relative. I'm here right now, coming back home from visiting my Auntie and cousins, and save for my gate and a flight currently deplaning, it is dead. I was the only person to go through security. When you choose the last flight out before NYE I guess that's how it goes. :-) Honestly I can't remember it ever being super crowded at this airport on arrival or departure. 

The last thing I'll mention before pulling out the book I brought (hoping to finish it before the new year and reach my reading quota for the year) is that the rental car kiosks are all inside the airport right before the baggage claim area, on the left side as you ride the escalator down to the first floor upon arrival. So practical, so convenient! The cars are literally right outside and ready to go once you're squared away at the rental desk. 

My favorite airport if I HAD to pick an airport. Come visit Idaho! It is an absolutely beautiful state, and perfect for you if you enjoy hiking, skiing, hot springs, and also if you enjoy wine the sunny slope region is calling your name. :-)', "Easy peasy Boise! This little airport has all the noms and none of the petty ish that often plagues smaller city airports. 

Security? Friendly, fast and efficient. TSA pre check really feels like it here. They've got it down and dialed in. Huzzah. 

Foods? They've got new options for a smaller joint. The stores onsite have Boise items and some fresh eats too. It's nice to see things with some nutritional value offered. 

The only qualm I had was that there was no Delta lounge onsite, but not really a surprise. 

The parking and rental car areas are easy and walkable. There is a little reconstruction of a floor mural in the lobby going on so some of the direction signs could confuse you slightly - it's small though, so even being a little lost will probably get you to your gate. 

Good job Boise! You could teach Fresno a thing or two. Rawr!", "Boise Airport is the airport in Boise. It also happens to be a pretty decent regional airport with a mix of jets and smaller planes serving the area. Only a handful of flights visit the relatively small metro area so the airport shares with a military base. The airport is south of downtown with easy access to Interstate 94. 

I arrived on Southwest and departed on Alaska. The Southwest flight arrived in the main terminal while the Alaska flight used the lower gates with the outdoor walkway. Obviously the interior gates are more comfortable, but you don't have a choice with the smaller planes used by Alaska. 

The airport is modern and large, although there are few flights. They have a nice food court with several good options. Souvenir shopping is surprisingly bland, but they do sell Idaho wine in the gift shops. WiFi was free and fast, but spotty with drop off. 

Check in was a breeze. Baggage claim was fast. The rental car area didn't even have a gate. Everyone was nice and friendly. Some areas are a little bland and outdated, but most people will enjoy their hopefully brief airport visit."]

name: Eddie's Restaurant
categories_raw: Breakfast & Brunch, Restaurants, American (Traditional), Diners, Burgers
top_reviews:
["Dearest Diner close to my house,

I was very skeptical of your food and never thought twice about consuming anything from your menu; however, this all changed tonight. I have lived in the area for 20 years and walk past this establishment at least three times a week. I finally went in with my dearest friend for a quick bite. As i walked in i instantly noticed the old school diner ambiance and the classic tunes from my parents era (which i love!). 

The service was very prompt and we chose the bouncing booth to receive our entrees. I looked over the menu and found a very enticing item. French Dip. Mmmmmm. I had flash backs of my aunts french dip and was wondering if Eddie's had the comfort food/sandwich chops to pull it off. My good friend ordered a simple chef salad.

About ten minutes later both of our Entrees arrived. Dang Gina!! The presentation was very simple, but the taste and texture was perfect. The bun was toasted with care and the cheddar cheese was melted perfectly. The meat was soft and flavorful. Then comes the Au Jus to save the day! All four components sing together and the chefs where trained correctly in the fine comfort food arena. 

Fabulous Job Eddie's! I will be back to devour your breakfast menu items that looked quite tantalizing as well.

Till next time....", "A 50's diner, with great service!  For emphasis, this is a 50's diner, with great service!  So, with that being said, I will explain. The seating is crazy.  Booths on the sides, and long tables in the middle.  You are very close to your neighbor if your at the tables in the middle.  I heard their conversation, and could hear him eating.  (Yuk!)  That is too close for me.  I ordered the vegetable skillet.  One piece of broccoli and some random broccoli stems, over a bed of potatoes.  It was like they forgot the vegetables!  Being a 50's diner, it was very loud and very busy.  (Totally expected that)  Coffee was average.  Service was great.  Sometimes I think restaurants get good at what they do, and then they forget why they do it.  The business of serving mass people can make the kitchen forget that people come there for the food.  They come back because the food and service.  When one or the other lacks, you look for options.  I think if they were to slow the pace down a little, adjust the seating and remind the kitchen to make sure the plate is full of what made them famous, people would be lined up around the block!  Eating out is more then getting the customer in and out the door.  Great food and service makes for repeat customers!  Not that I won't go back, I would just probably leave it as an option.", "So this is an updated review. The first time I came in, I was less than impressed. The service was apathetic, the food was mediocre, and the music was too loud. I was asked back to give them another try and I did.  The second experience was much better. 

When you walk in, the hostess is still not very good.  She didn't greet us but she did get us seated quickly enough.  She also didn't tell us who our server was or how long we should expect to wait for her. I was not impressed with her customer service. 

It took about fifteen minutes before our server showed up to take our drink order, but that wasn't a problem for me because I like a little extra time to read over the menu and I could see that they were busier than the last time I came in. If you're the type of person who likes fast service, I might suggest going in the afternoon when they aren't quite so busy. Our waitress was much nicer this time around and brought my toddler's food out early for her because she was getting very fussy waiting.  The food took a long time but the waitress checked in frequently and was very sweet to us. 

So on to the food.  I ordered the steak and eggs breakfast. Please keep in mind that this is a diner style restaurant with very low prices. If you're looking for five star organic food, I might suggest a higher end restaurant. That being said, the steak and eggs was decent (marginally better than the skillet I had ordered previously). I ordered medium rare and it came out medium well, but it was seasoned nicely.  Was it the nicest cut of steak? Eh, probably not.  But for a $9 meal, it sure beats what you'd get at a fast food place for the same price! As usual the portion sizes were large.  My husband ordered a burger and he enjoyed it. My daughter ordered pancakes again this time and they came out nicely (last time they were overcooked), so that was better. 

As for the environment, the music was much lower this time, so that was better (last time they had it blasted so loud that I couldn't hear). The whole restaurant has an old-fashioned diner theme, which I feel like might be more appealing to Idaho natives (I'm from Portland). The biggest appeal of this place is the fact that they give you large portions for being so inexpensive.  

So I'm not really sure where to rate this restaurant. I wish I could do a 3.75 because that's about where I feel they are. Almost four stars but not quite. Hmm.  Last time I gave them two stars, but since the service and food improved, I'll would say it's four stars (averaging out my visits). Overall, a big improvement"]

name: La Vie Nail Spa
categories_raw: Nail Technicians, Beauty & Spas, Hair Removal, Nail Salons, Waxing
top_reviews:
['I am so happy I found this place!  There are so many reasons for my 5 star review!

Decor and Ambience- Tasteful , clean and fresh. Yes! Its nice to go get your nails in a place you actually find aesthetically pleasing. You can tell the owners took the time to make the spa appealing

Customer Service- Everyone was so interested in making sure I got great customer service from the moment I walked in. 

Mani Pedi- Wow. They did a fantastic job. My nails look amazing. I believe Yen did my nails. He took his time and put a double top coat so that my nails would last through my upcoming trip. He really cared about how my nails turned and was not just going through the motions. And I was so enjoying the hot stone massage that comes standard with the pedicure! And my favorite part is that they line the bowls with a disposable plastic cover for that extra level of cleanliness. Only one other place I have been to does this.

After moving to Boise from Los Angeles 4 years ago, I struggled to find a place to get my nails done. The struggle is over!

Finally a place I can look forward to going to without the worry of walking out disappointed.', "I tried this nail salon a week after moving here to Boise from California. Needless to say my nails and feet took a beating from all the moving and packing! 
My sister and I decided to spend some girl time together getting a pedicure. Being new to the area we didn't know where to go. I pulled up nails salos on YELP and this one came up first. It is very close to my house & had great reviews for the most part.  Upon walking into the salon they showed us nothing short of outstanding customer service!  
I am a cosmetologist. I have been doing hair for 19 years but have also dabbled in nails from time to time. Also being in the beauty industry and using my hands I have always wanted to keep up on my nails. 
The owner, Dave and staff were so very nice, quick to get us seated and great pedicure! Before we started the pedicure I had mentioned that my finger nails were a mess from unpacking and that I probably should get a manicure as well. After talking for a bit we decided to try a thin layer of acrylic with a tip since I had no length! Great job!! It has been 18 days and as I am in need for a fill...they are still holding up great!! I have never had my nails last this long!! I am so happy with them and look forward to getting the time to get in to have them filled!", "Found my new nail salon! Just moved back from Los Angeles and I couldn't be happier. My sister and I dropped in and they were super accommodating and very friendly! My sister got a gel manicure and I received a full set acrylic that I absolutely love. I highly recommend Lavonne (spelling?) she was super sweet and funny. I will be back every 2-3 weeks for my fill and acrylic sets. Highly recommend! :-)"]

name: A Tavola
categories_raw: Cafes, Delis, Restaurants, Desserts, Food, Breakfast & Brunch
top_reviews:
['My husband and I had a good experience all around at A Tavola during our stop on a trip through Boise.  For location, vibe, food, service, gourmet and home gift options, we enjoyed it all.  Thanks to the friendly staff who made us feel welcome.  

VIBE
Building seems re-purposed from a garage with big doors rolled up in nice weather.  Open interior with lots of seating at communal and individual standard height (hooray) tables and chairs throughout. More seats on the patio in the front.  

Part café, part deli, part gourmet market, part bakery and espresso bar, part cookbook library, part home and kitchen gifts and accessories in a high ceiling open concept space divided up with seating and displays. 

I've read criticism focused, no kidding, on the fact that most of the clientele are female and of a certain age.  That may be true but on the day of our visit, I'd say the people enjoying the patio and inside were about evenly split between men and women and across age groups.  Not that the gender or age of people there should be a thing at all. But since it has been a thing for critics, thought I'd offer my observation.

SERVICE
From the moment we walked in the door and were greeted by the young woman at the bakery / coffee bar counter through our ordering of breakfast and coffee to our ordering of take out to take home, service was friendly and efficient.  It was also very nice of them to provide us with a zip loc bag of ice to use in our cooler so we could order deli take out items to go with us for the several hour drive home.

THE DRILL
 Order at the deli counter, including your coffee order, take a number and they'll deliver to your table.  They also clear for you after you're done so no need to bus your own. 
 
FOOD
So many choices on the menu at the counter and in the deli case.  For breakfast we shared (it is big enough for sure) a chile relleno baked dish ($6.95) .  Also small side of the broccoli, red grapes and almond salad to go with my breakfast.  (Seriously.)  Both tasty enough.  

The bold roast coffee was great, served piping hot in 12 oz mugs ($1.95).

We bought several take out items to have for an easy meal when we got home later that day after a long drive.  The picante tuna salad was good.  Some of the other selections weren't as flavorful as I hoped. More what I'd describe as "caterer buffet quality".  Deli items rotate frequently so it seems there might always be something new to try.

The bakery case is too tempting to pass by.  We thought the baked goods better than the deli items.  Next visit to Boise would find us here for coffee and bakery only.

PRICES
Noting some have referenced this as break the bank pricing, I'll offer counterpoint that for my husband and me the deli food prices seemed reasonable for a gourmet / specialty store .  Could be visitors who live elsewhere have a different frame of reference for pricing than locals.  But comparing this to Oakville Grocery or Dean and Deluca, as analogs, in some of our old stomping grounds of SF area or NYC area or even food to go from food trucks in our current home in Bend, the prices here seemed reasonable to us for food items.  The gifts and housewares seemed spendy.

GO SLOW HOME / GIFT SHOPPING
All kinds of pretty and handsome items for personal care, like soaps and lotions, or home, kitchen and gift items like candles, trivets, books, cookware, linens...the list goes on and on.  A friend of mine calls this kind of store a "go slow shop" since you can see a new treasure tucked everywhere. Spendy, for sure, still I purchased gifts here that I didn't find elsewhere.

ACCESSIBILITY
Universally accessible design from level in and throughout and standard table height seating.  Loo accessible too.  Parking lot needs work for ADA compliance.  

HOURS
Mon - Fri 7 - 6  Sat 7 - 5

LOCATION / PARKING
Just outside the downtown core at 15th and Grove.  Has its' own parking lot.', 'Holy Cougarville, Northenders!  I went here for lunch this past Wednesday, and it was packed with what I would describe as an influx of overly-groomed Highland dwellers coming down into the valley to graze--lots of girlfriend lunch dates (dressed as if fresh off a jog or yoga stretch), mid-life crisis Joes, and well-off retirees.  There is an ample section of prepared foods and sandwich options at the deli counter to suit just about anyone. Breads  were fresh. Meats of decent quality.  Sides tasty (would highly recommend the Moroccan eggplant salad).  Careful of the question, "chip or salad with the sandwich?" The latter is a $4 up-charge.  I also tried the chicken and pepper enchilada (more like a casserole) and found it quite tasty, and filling.

The coffee and sweets side of the space did not stack up as well.  Dawson Taylor is decent coffee, and they're local, but they are really a little "blah" in the trend toward really delicious coffee.  The new Crux coffeehouse has keyed into this with their choice of Stumptown (Portland) beans, as has Salt N Tears with Doma (Post Falls, ID).  If they wanted to stay local, I think they should have hooked up with Flying M's Purple Bean.  What can I say, I'm a coffee snob.  I didn't much like my selected bake good, either, which was some sort of walnut, caramel bar.  The "flaky" portion was much too floury and came off as chalky, and the caramel part was more akin to overly sweet noughat (which I love when done well in the Italian fashion). Just the right amount of toasted nut, though.

Overall a good addition to food choices in downtown.  Especially for the single, mid-lifer on the make.', 'A friend and I had our entire day planned out - we were going to spend several hours working on project and wanted the perfect place, which we thought was A'Tavola.  We planned to start the morning with breakfast and end our time there with lunch. The only problem is that this place is not work friendly. . . or, friendly at all. There are no plug-ins and when we asked about plug-ins we were rudely told, "I am a small business owner and don't want to end up like Big City Coffee."  I'm not sure why she even had to share that and could not have nicely said that she did not have plug ins.  Or, maybe tried to figure out a way to accommodate us - a plug in in the back or in the bathroom if you need a quick charge.  One or two plug-ins is not going to create loitering.  This is the 21st century for goodness sake!  This is just one in a line of several times the staff has been rude.  We promptly headed over to Whole Foods where the staff was so welcoming, there are lots of plug ins, the view was amazing and the food was ever bit as good as A Tavola - and, cheaper!!!  And, I can't say enough about the great service.  I like to support local businesses, but I'm not going to support rude and arrogant.  If you want great gourmet deli-style food, head over to Whole Foods or the Boise Co-op.  

My point was driven home because when we went into A Tavola at 10:30 am - there was only one other person in the entire place.  Whole Foods was packed with people eating, drinking, working and socializing.  It was great!']

name: Chick-fil-A
categories_raw: Restaurants, Event Planning & Services, Caterers, Chicken Shop, Fast Food
top_reviews:
["Visited Boise recently on a business trip and for some reason we kept criss crossing town and this Chick-fil-A seemed to be right smack in the middle of things every time.
