It became so prominent in our paths that with each new appointment the question wasn't about traffic times or parking but rather: how far or what is the next appointment's proximity to the Chick-fil-A! lol! 

Really, they are just very centrally located near downtown Boise, Albertsons Stadium and both BSU and ISU university campuses. So we couldn't help but drive by or stop in a few times. Cold drinks, snacks, cookies, maybe a chicken sandwich or two kept beckoning us in. 

Convenient location, lots of free parking, almost no line at the register, clean restrooms, and friendly staff- made this an ideal place to stop off to refresh. Plus they have big tables and didn't mind us sprawling our stuff out for a bit. In classic Chick-fil-A style they came by and offered refills periodically - which was very much appreciated!", "You better look both ways and then look again fast food fried chicken fans!  A pedestrian entering this Chic-fil-A from the parking lot is bound to get plowed by a car due to the drive-thru lane passing directly in front of the main entrance to the restaurant.

Even though Chic-fil-A has placed signage for both vehicular and pedestrian traffic informing each about the potential for a collision, that is a piss poor solution to this obvious design flaw in my opinion. When walking, a pedestrian must be constantly on their guard and that is not the kind of welcome one expects. What was the person who signed-off on this design thinking? Ridiculous.

As for the food and other aspects to the restaurant, I have no idea why this place is so wildly popular - it is fast food fried chicken and waffle fries after all. Maybe people are used to eating bad fried chicken or something and this is a cut above other fast food places that when one consumes mediocre it actually seems to taste good?

My experience didn't convince me to become a regular, but this Chic-fil-A does deserve some praise for its execution in the QSR category.  The restaurant was squeaky clean, the fried chicken was hot as were the waffle fries, and the counter people were friendly and efficient.  This seems like it should be the standard across all restaurants of this type, however it is too bad that this standard is seldom met, this Chic-fil-A does.", '"Five stars for Chick-fil-A...really?"

CHYEAH! You better believe it.

This Chick-fil-A has been my trusty friend on those long days where cooking isn't an option and waffle fries are calling my name. Their service is quick and friendly! And if they mess up your order, they make it right...and then some. 

My roomie and I picked up dinner here (via the drive-thru) a few weeks ago. When we got home (we live less than a mile away) we realized that they left out one of our orders of fries. We drove back through and told them that they left out a medium fry. They apologized and when we got to the window they gave us a large fry and a coupon for a free entree during our next visit!

Now on to the food - it's always served hot and fresh! Each visit I've had here has been consistently excellent. As far as what to order, well, everyone has their preference at Chick-fil-A. But if you ask me, get a Chick-Fil-A chicken sandwich, fries, Chick-fil-A sauce, ranch, and if you've thrown calorie counting out the window, an Oreo milkshake...and feel no regrets. But if you are counting calories and are looking for something semi-guilt-free (is that even a real thing??), I love their chicken cool-wraps with balsamic vinaigrette and a small fry on the side (because how could I not?), so yummy!']

name: Boise River Greenbelt
categories_raw: Parks, Active Life, Hiking
top_reviews:
["Review #26 for 2020.

Boise River Greenbelt provides an awesome way to get some exercise, breathe in the beauty of nature, and check out various parts of the city without needing to drive. There are joggers, bikers, dog walkers, and families with kids. Small and big parks can be found along the trail, and there are lots of small businesses along the way as well. In certain parts of the river you can see ducks, and in other parts there are spaces for water sports. One Saturday morning I happened upon a farmers market and then visited every Saturday until it got too cold. I love the various views from the trail, and the sounds of flowing water, birds, and other animals makes you forget that you're in a city.", "The Boise River Greenbelt is an absolute local gem.

For 25 miles, along the Boise River as it meanders through Boise (including downtown), we have the Greenbelt.  A beautiful, paved path wide enough to have two lanes of foot/cycle traffic (stay to the right, yo!).  On the weekend, during pleasant weather, the Greenbelt will be packed with cyclists, walkers, roller bladers, and skate boarders--heck I've even seen unicyclists.  And, many of those walkers, cyclists, & etc will have their canine companions on leash along with them.  

But, even if the weather isn't particularly fine--you'd be hard pressed to ever find the Greenbelt deserted during daylight hours.  There will be cycle commuters rushing to and fro and hard core runners and walkers out in all kinds of weather.  

Other than the gorgeousness of the area surrounding the river to enjoy, one fascination that I can never seem to resist stopping for is the Boise River Park where wave shapers create waves in the river for kayakers and surfers to enjoy.  They are amazing to watch and there is a nice stone/paved area where people can lounge and watch the water sport fun.

Overall, a lovely feature to our lovely city.  The Boise River Greenbelt is truly a highlight of a city full of highlights and just one of the many things that makes life in Boise just so damn grand.

Get to it!", "Coming from a city where there only thing worse than the traffic is the inclination to BIKE RIDE in said bad traffic, the Boise River Greenbelt is like that sacred light emanating from God's head over the endless horizon of dopey motorists and orange traffic cones.

The path is over 20 miles long, almost 30, taking into account the side routes and runs through many Boise neighborhoods and suburbs.  You can run, walk, skip, bike, do the hokey pokey and if you get tired, there are plenty of spots for you to relax and enjoy the scenery, most of which follows the river.  

Have biked several times on this trail, starting west at the parking lot of a wastewater treatment plant and ending up all the way at the dam (east) at one point.  Have also gone further west.  The road is mainly unbroken, except for certain spots - paved and flat, and free of people most weekdays.  However, there is construction at certain points of the path, so check latest conditions before hauling out your loved ones for a (potentially) short excursion.

Biking along the greenbelt is a great way to get a sense of what Boise's all about - green and lush in the summer, uber-friendly people (you'll think you've died and gone to Walton heaven, where pretty much everyone you pass says HI or smiles at you...but not idiotically, like I'm inclined to do), well-maintained public spaces, families with their and dogs kids out, people out or in the water, with a backdrop of the trees and the water.  It's like a Thomas Kinkade painting on steroids.

The city government also spends $$ taking care of its spaces.  After a thunderstorm, crews were out cutting down wayward tree branches and clearing the road of brush.  (They also smiled and waved HI at us.)  While most people like myself are from cities where trying not to get swallowed by a large pothole is considered the favorite local pastime, the greenbelt is a great addition to Boise."]

name: Taqueria La Flama
categories_raw: Restaurants, Mexican, Event Planning & Services, Caterers
top_reviews:
["74th Reviewer of Taqueria La Flama in Boise, Idaho. This is my 386th Yelp Review. 

I like this place. I've visited here a few times. It seems to be an upgraded Los Betos. The food seems to be presented much better, cleaner, and more professional. The prices are higher than Beto's but you get what you pay for.", "Good, simple Mexican fare offered at reasonable prices, ordered at the counter and delivered by friendly people to your table in a cavernous but sparkling clean dining area.  Not destination dining for us, but if in the neighborhood again, we would return here.  If you read no further than this, here's a tip:  don't miss the salsa bar as it may be second only to Andrade's for good, incendiary salsa offerings.

THE SERVICE & THE DRILL:  Friendly people work at the counter where one orders from a limited menu of traditional offerings like tacos and enchiladas and burritos displayed on menu board over head.  Find a seat in the dining area and some of the same friendly folks will deliver a basket of chips and bowls of salsa and queso to your table and, in what seems like a flash, also the food you ordered which is served on real plate not disposables.  Hooray!   No need to bus your own; they will also stop by to pick up your plates when you're finished. 

THE FOOD:  We shared adobada tacos ($1.35 each) and a plate of two enchiladas verde that came with refried beans, rice, shredded lettuce and tomatoes ($9) which  along with the chips and salsa left the two of us comfortably full for under twelve bucks.  

The salsa bar has about half a dozen choices that range from mild, the one served at the table too, to hot as Hades with most of them in the mid-incendiary range.  Nice!  Also some cabbage crudo, sliced radishes, pickled carrots and wedges of lime that can be used to customize your dishes as you choose.

We were a bit disappointed to find the food offerings didn't include items  with complex Mexican sauces like mole. (Andrade's is the place for those dishes and is the destination Mexican restaurant in Boise for us.)  For my sodium content watching friends I also offer that we found our dishes very much salted, maybe too much, but that could just be a personal preference issue.

THE VIBE:  Dining and open kitchen were once home to a couple of fast food places and so both are really large.   Walk in past the black laminate topped tables and booths with blueberry-purple vinyl seats to the order counter at the back.  

We loved that all the seating was standard height and no high counter stool seating to be found  Hooray!  We also loved the Mexican music on the sound system.

We appreciated that the entire place was sparkling clean.

Two TVs, one on each side of the room, were turned to different stations, one news and the one near the booth we sat on to an obnoxious animated program with adult content of things like masturbation jokes turned loud enough to hear it. For what it's worth, I'd leave the TVs off unless tuned to Mexican station programming to add to the vibe.

ACCESSIBILITY:  Level in the door, all on one level, clear path of travel to the order counter, standard height seating, accessible loo.  The salsa bar is out of reach range, so people who can't stand to access it would need assistance.

PARKING: Big private lot in the strip mall location for what was a fast food place.  Inexplicably, the strip mall owner is in violation of Federal Law (ADA) and Idaho Building Code Access Chapter for failing to provide a single designated accessible (aka ADA) parking spot, let alone the several the code and law have both required since 1990 for a lot with this many spaces. 

HOURS: Open as early as 7:30a.m. and stay open until 10p.m. seven days a week.  If so, think about all the hard work needed by so many people to keep it so!", "The Boise Valley has a large number of Mexican restaurants but very few stand out. 

Most serve up the same lineup of bland, Americanized Mexican food. Taqueria La Flama is breaking the mold.

Salsas can make the difference between an OK Mexican restaurant and one that shines. Here, they have a salsa bar with several varieties, radish slices, lime wedges and a type of cabbage curtido.

The best is a guacamole with a chile kick. It's the best salsa I've tasted in Boise.

So far, I've tasted their tacos and a mulita, meat and melted cheese sandwiched between two corn tortillas. 

They are excellent. 

Although more of a fast food eatery, they deliver your dishes to your table and bring you a basket of chips, a tomato salsa and queso. [Edited] As of Nov. 1, they no longer provide free chips. They now charge $3 for chips and queso.

Arctic Circle and Speedy Burger didn't last very long in this same spot on busy Fairview Avenue. Let's hope the third time is the charm."]

name: Yoi Tomo Sushi & Grill
categories_raw: Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Japanese
top_reviews:
['We quickly discovered the worst sushi imaginable after arriving in Boise. Reading the reviews was most amusing..."best west of the Mississippi"? LOL!! We thought we might try it because it had four "stars", but the whole meal was a laugh. My Japanese friend wanted to try the Pearl Harbor Roll just because she was so offended by the name. It bombed too, and I was thoroughly embarrassed and was FAR beyond offended. 

The fish was cut too thin. There was no vinegar in the rice, which made it extremely bland. Normally, each fish has a distinct flavor, but none of it had any flavor and if I closed my eyes, I couldn't tell the difference from one to the other, and I have a VERY experienced palette when it comes to Japanese food. I could very easily deduce that no one working at that restaurant has probably studied proper sushi making in Japan. Maybe they changed planes there when coming to the US, but that's all. When I was going to order one particular roll (on a dare from my Japanese friend), the waitress was kind enough to tell us "I wouldn't recommend that." I'm grateful for her honesty. 

It's such a shame that people will go to this restaurant and think they are eating sushi. There is a vague resemblance (not the rolls, just the nigiri), but that's were all similarities end. Flavorless fish cut incorrectly, served on rice that was not prepared properly, and then drowned in sauces that should never cross the threshold of a "Japanese" restaurant. We were both so disappointed the well meaning customers would walk away with the wrong impression what a beautiful food sushi can actually be. 

To make matters worse, we were told that because we were ordering off of the "all you can eat" menu (first mistake), we would be charged if we didn't eat anything. I felt like I was taken hostage. We could only eat a couple of pieces of the last two rolls, not because we ordered too much and we were full, but because the taste was so disgusting and we didn't want to risk getting sick. So we had no choice but to leave the extra $10 on the bill for the left-over food, which I thought was robbery to begin with. $70 for an awful experience!! 

An hour after the meal I'm sitting in my hotel writing this review and have begin getting a headache. I hope it stops at that and I don't end up with dysentery. The owners of this restaurant should be ashamed of themselves for trying to pass this off to unknowing customers as being Japanese. They should go to Japan once and spend a few months learning how to make it correctly. Not that the management could read it, but even the signs on the wall written in Japanese were incorrect and irrelevant to what was being served!!

Our waitressed sensed our displeasure, and didn't even come back to the table after she dropped off the bill. I wasn't mad at her, just the owners and the chefs.', "Yoi Tomo is the spot for AYCE (All You Can Eat) Sushi in downtown Boise! I love coming here for date nights and here's what I usually order for the two of us: 
Apps: 2 miso soups, jalapeño bomb, and mixed veggie tempura 
Nigiri- ahi (3x), hamachi (x4), seared salmon (x4), salmon (x4), unagi (x2) 
Rolls: Red dragon and Match point. 

The appetizers usually come out really quick which gives the sushi chefs plenty of time to prepare our huge sushi order. 
The hamachi and salmon are my two favorites! The quality and cut are just great. 

Yoi tomo has indoor and outdoor seating, take out and delivery! One of best features that this restaurant offers is an online waiting list through Yelp!! So you can add your party onto the Live waiting list on this same app that you're reading this review, how awesome?!! 

Ok, so here's my issue: 
The names of the rolls have little to no relation to the ingredients in the sushi! I think that because it's located across the street from the movie theaters that a lot of the rolls are movie references. The confusing names just make it hard to skim the menu and remember what you may have ordered in the past. 
Another personal preference that affects my rating is that I'm not a fan of cream cheese in sushi and a lot of  Yoi Tomo's rolls have cream cheese in it. Which is why I like to order mostly nigiri!", 'Best sushi in Boise.  By a mile.  Super fresh (I don't how how they do it when other sushi places in Boise are so consistently erratic with that), beautifully crafted and presented, and actually startlingly fast, at least on my three visits there in the last few weeks.


No, that's only a tiny part of what I'm really wanting to say about this place...


How 'bout this:


Every once in while (but fairly rarely actually, no matter where in the world you live), you do run into a restaurant that simply and undeniably does *everything* right.


I could write a long, detailed explanation of each aspect of Yoitomo; citing every food item I've eaten there (which are many), every instance of careful and personally appreciative service, every inflection of mood and atmosphere and how the business is structured and how well it all works (not to mention how completely authentic it is, for those of us who care about such things)...


But what you really want to know is whether you should go there.


You should go there.


Whether you're a lifetime sushi-lover all-you-can-eater (me), or a neophyte looking for an introduction to Japanese cuisine (and wanting to meet it in the most accessible and positive possible way)...


Whomever you are, and whatever your reason for wanting to find a Japanese restaurant that more than pleases, Yoitomo WILL more than satisfy and please you.  You will go back again and again.  You will tell people you know to go there, even if they haven't been "into" Japanese food before.  You will be happy.  This is one rare bird in the world of Boise restaurants (or anyplace's, really).  Excellence to the rafters, but humble and unpretentious enough that no one will feel over-matched or in over their head.


Simply...  Fabulous.


You should go there.


.']

name: Shogun Sushi
categories_raw: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Korean, Japanese
top_reviews:
['My first time at Shogun Sushi was utterly embarrassing.

I picked the All-You-Can-Eat (AYCE) option and ordered way too much sushi. To make things worse, the restaurant had a Leftover Rule which required me to pay an additional $40 ($5 per four pieces of leftover sushi) on top of the $26 AYCE fee. I was getting punished for my gluttony. And deservedly so!

However, the server talked to her manager about my situation, and they both decided that I was only a hungry soul who had just come from playing three hours of volleyball, and that I had no bad intentions. Instead of paying $40 for my leftover, I was asked to pay only $20. I got to take my sizable leftover home, of course. Needless to say, I had to give the server a generous tip.

Lesson learned: Don't be a glutton when it comes to AYCE! Lol.

Shogun Sushi is located in Southeast Boise. I've been there a few more times after my humiliating experience and have been smarter with my choices. Most recently, I skipped AYCE and ordered pork teriyaki. It was a little bland, in my opinion. But props to them for being generous with the veggies. I am a huge fan of their baked salmon. It's my go-to sushi.\xa0

I'm giving this place four stars because while food is decent, the sushi is rice-heavy. Not a lot of seafood or meat. It's mostly rice. Staff was pretty friendly on all occasions. Restaurant is tiny. Only 10 or so tables. Bathroom was decently clean.

Just a final note about Shogun Sushi's Leftover Rule. It states, "More than 3 pieces left per table will be subject to additional charge." The additional charge is $5 per four pieces of leftover sushi.

Pace yourself if you're doing AYCE. Don't be like me. :)', 'Came here recently to try it and out and all three of us really enjoyed our meal.  We went for an early dinner to avoid the crowds and paid dinner price for the all you can eat sushi.  It was around $25 and well worth it. 

As for the restaurant in itself, it was a bit "cozy" but very clean.  We were helped by a very nice waitress who attended to our every need.  She was very attentive and provide excellent service.  In one of the reviews, they mention the seared tuna salad and how they could eat that daily.  I would have to agree.  Only on the dinner all you can eat option can you have the seared ahi salad.  It was excellent.  It had a great salad dressing and the tuna was very fresh.  The sushi was very well done as well including fresh fish and creative combos.  Their all you can eat also included appetizers which were really good.

All in all, I would definitely come back.  I do have to mention that the seared ahi salad makes this review lean towards excellence.  Since it is not included in the all you can eat lunch, I probably would only come back to pay their dinner prices so that I could indulge on their salad.  We are planning on going back next week to see if our experience is consistent with our first visit.', 'Went twice to make sure it wasn't a fluke! This is THE place to get sushi in Boise.  I'm half Japanese and would like to say I have a somewhat good idea of what good sashimi is. Obviously we are not in Tsukiji fish market Tokyo but man this is good. The fish was cold, firm, and had a great texture. No bad odors or funny tastes. The only one that was off was the seared tuna (little tough). Rice was warm, fresh, and cooked to perfection (rice is just as much a part of sushi as the fish... not just a vehicle to inhale more fish). Compare that to grocery store sushi where the rice is cold and borderline crunchy. The actual venue is quaint with several tables and and a bar section. Here is my gripe with (almost) every sushi joint in America; why all the cream cheese? Half of asia is lactose intolerant; cheese is not a big thing! The idea of cream cheese in sushi equates to putting soy sauce on top of ice cream instead of chocolate sauce?????? But we are in #merica; land of the supersized fry and diet coke, and have to put our #merica twist on things. Whats next? Gravy covered sushi rolls? Ok off the soapbox. It was great for Boise. What would I have liked to see? It would be so neat to see a new sushi joint simplify their menu, get rid of cheesy things like "the micron roll" or "the bogus roll", deviate from the cream cheese kick, and focus on high quality simple nigiri. Did I mention the cream cheese thing? Bottom line though, this place is legit. Check it aight!!!!']

name: 208 Moving Company
categories_raw: Local Services, Home Services, Movers, Couriers & Delivery Services
top_reviews:
['Just a quick review to say that these guys knocked it out of the park.  I liked that they asked detailed questions over the phone to get the best estimate for how long it would take to move our stuff.  On the day of the move, the crew showed up on time and were extremely professional.  They took a quick look around to see what they had to work with and then got right down to business.  The last time we moved, we got help from another company through a U-Haul referral and they really dragged their feet.  But this crew from 208 busted their butts and got the job done.

When we got to our new place, they asked us where we wanted everything set up and were very accommodating in terms of getting things as close to their "final" positions as possible.  Of course, who ever knows "exactly' where they want everything right after a move, but these guys worked with us all the way.  They even took an extra couple minutes to hook up the washer and dryer.  When it was all said and done, they wrapped up nearly 20 minutes ahead of their estimated time.

Bottom line, if you need to move in the Treasure Valley, spare your back and call 208.  Best money I ever spent.', 'I used 208 Moving Company to move a refrigerator from my sister's house to the garage at my home.  This company is amazing.  I called on a Tuesday to get an estimate.  There was only an answering machine responding to my call, so I left a detailed message.  Daniel Warns returned my call promptly, gave me a very reasonable quote, and offered to move this refrigerator that very same day.  It worked out better for me to move it the next day, so we set up the move for early the following morning.  The day of the move they called me with a courtesy call to let me know they were on the way.  Daniel Warns and Matt Shelar arrived promptly and immediately began planning for the move.  They covered the doors and doorjambs with protective quilted material to protect them.  When they got the fridge to the door, they realized it was not going to fit through.  So they carefully removed the front door to the house and part of the storm door.  They also removed the refrigerator doors and all the drawers and shelves inside to make sure nothing was damaged in the move.  This was a lot of work, but they went about this task with positive "can do" attitudes.  Both young men were very courteous and professional.  This all took more time than any of us had planned, but that did not matter.  They wanted to do the job right.  To finish up the move, they put everything back together exactly as it had come apart.  There was absolutely no damage to anything.  The price was fair and I will be using this company again.', "Excellent local moving company. Great communication from the initial contact until the day of the move. Moving services can be expensive but I felt like 208's rates were very reasonable. My movers, Austin and Rich were friendly, efficient and took great care of my belongings. I would highly recommend 208 Moving Company!"]

name: The Electric Chair
categories_raw: Beauty & Spas, Hair Salons, Waxing, Eyebrow Services, Hair Removal
top_reviews:
["BEFORE: I had been growing out my bangs for a few months and they had that awkward chunky look. My hair is red/ naturally wavy/ moderately thick/ long (5-6 inches past my shoulder)/ full of split ends. I asked for a layered, full body look (Victoria's Secret - ish).

AFTER: The layers are fabulous! My hair looks much healthier, the grown-out bangs now frame my face nicely, and the wind-blown/ tousled curls styling was exactly what I asked for. Great haircut for $45 (not including tip)!

OVERALL EXPERIENCE: Nathan cut my hair and his assistant helped with the styling. They were both friendly and obviously talented. The salon has an edgy, down-to-earth vibe. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a youthful, fresh hairstyle :) 

PS They are very accessible by bus, so support public transit and take a $2 roundtrip busride into downtown Boise :)

PPS They have this totally awesome painting of Edward Scissorhands back where they wash your hair :)", "Do I actually fly to Boise sometimes to get my hair done here?  Yes.  I do.  

The downtown location is not always super convenient (I usually pay to park) but the salon itself is welcoming, low-key, friendly and enjoyable.  

Owned by two stylish brothers, the salon is a much-needed addition to the hair world (or lack thereof) in Boise.  Their prices are reasonable and I'm always pleased with the results.   

Bethany does my hair and I'm quite fond of it...and her.  Seeing her is like getting a 2fer special because she's talented and quite entertaining.  Similar to dinner and a show.  Ren works on my sister's locks and she always looks fabulous.", "this salon has improved my view of boise, which is not an easy feat. i was in dire need of a haircut on my last visit to boise and figured i'd give it a try since it had the best reviews in town, compared to all the other salons i found on yelp. 

i had one of the owners do my trim. my previous haircut was not so great, so i requested that he try to fix it as much as he could. he did a great job taking off as little as possible (as i am trying to let my hair grow out), but still creating a better shape of my coif. not gonna lie though, the stylists are not what you expect to see in boise. they are definitely more portland worthy ;)"]

name: Spacebar Arcade
categories_raw: Bars, Arts & Entertainment, Nightlife, Arcades
top_reviews:
['If you go to Yelp's home page on desktop/laptop and click on "bars," you'll find that (as of the date of this review, anyway) Spacebar Arcade is one of the top rated bars in Boise.  So, upon noticing this one Saturday afternoon, I decided to investigate.

You might find yourself wondering, what is an "arcade" bar?  Can an arcade really be for adults?

Well, let me ask you this:

Are you the sort of adult who likes beer? (Postmodern Brewers Berliner Weiss on tap, yo!)

Are you the sort of adult who enjoys vintage arcade games (preferably while drinking the aforementioned beer)?  I'm talkin' Pac-man, Donkey Kong, Tron, Mario Bros, Frogger (yes!  freakin' frogger!)?

Are you the sort of adult who might like to play old school Star Wars pin-ball? Or Terminator?  Or Spiderman?  

How about lounging on a sofa and playing a little classic NES (the original Nintendo Entertainment System for those not in the know)?

Or hanging at a bar with big boxy TV's playing Pretty in Pink AND The Breakfast Club while the speakers rock what one patron (me) lovingly described as 80's roller rink jams?

If any of the above remotely refers to you--come and geek the heck out!  With me!  Now!  Let's go!

Seriously, so vintage in every way, you'll feel just the tiniest bit rebellious swigging beer.  Make the beer Pabst (which is also on tap) coupled with the fact that the Spacebar is located basement level and you may begin to feel all Nirvana Come as You Are and Smells Like Teen Spirit.  What?  Nevermind.  

Totally vintage and yet fresher than the Prince of Bel Air.

Grab yourself $10 dollars in quarters, a beer, and a game.  A cheap night of fun will ensue.

High fives all around!

(no fist bumps...they weren't invented yet)

Get to it!', "I love this quaint and nerdy local bar. Where else can you play old school Mario Brothers or Guantlet for hours while sipping back on a cider or a beer? Here! That's where! The games are a quarter and the alcohol is decently priced. The staff was welcoming on my first time in. I won't lie, I was a bit intimidated since I ventured here by myself one night. But I was put at ease and grabbed a drink and a game. I ended up spending only under 10.00 and kept myself occupied for 2 hours. Spacebar FTW!", 'This is such a fun spot! They have several pinball machines, arcade games, game consoles/games, and board games to choose from. A dj was playing great music, and trivia was going on when we arrived. The place was packed, but not too overwhelming.

The drink menu consists of beer and cider, wine, and a couple cocktails. 

This an excellent spot for groups, friends, and couples.']

name: Alchemist Coffee Roasting
categories_raw: Bars, Coffee & Tea, Food, Beer Bar, Restaurants, Nightlife, Sandwiches, Breakfast & Brunch
top_reviews:
['Indigo had my leg in a death grip, which was going to require the jaws of life, as I was getting ready to leave the house. I sighed, as I had no jaws of life,  and said "Get your Meow Meow and you can come with me!" She released my leg, grabbed her Meow Meow, and away we went. 

After a quick errand, we went to Awakenings Coffee House after consulting yelper (and friend) Greg first who said nice things. 

I remember frequently this coffee shop when it was a Moxie Java, it was a quirky place with sagging yellow crushed velvet sofas, antique plush winged back chairs and friendly staff. 

Gone are the creaky yellow and antique furniture but the staff are just as friendly as before. The place has a definite neighborhood hangout vibe and this is a place where you can linger all day. 

I ordered the lavender chai with almond milk, and an almond milk lukewarm chocolate for Indigo. We also shared a cream cheese danish because life is short! 

The nice people who work here are fantastic with toddlers, the drinks were great (not too sweet), and so was the danish. They also have a changing table! That added an extra star and if you think that's unearned then you've never changed a toddler on concrete! :)

There are gluten free options but please ask for details as I am not sure if they are made in a gluten free kitchen. 

Indigo gives this place 50 stars for danishes, and charming people who smile a lot!', "I visited Alchemist amidst their transition from Awakenings Coffeehouse, when I visited the signage on the storefront still read the latter. Now, taking a  look at the menu I snapped a pic of, I notice the new logo. I must say, I love the new name. It's unique, sleek and change is good! 

Before this experience I had only been here one other time, years ago. It was Wednesday afternoon, needed a quick pick-me-up after a day of errands. I ordered a small 12 oz iced vanilla latte (low on the ice) and a Club Panini (salami, pepperoni, turkey, cheddar cheese and onions, $6.00). I enjoyed my coffee, it did the job and tasted great. However I was mildly disappointed with the panini! The bread was very tough, like someone had microwaved it once, forgot about it and microwaved it again. I'm almost 90% sure this happened, because it also took for freaking ever to get this one lil sando. It was also very dry. I don't believe there was any cheese at all, and there were no onions. Unfortunately I ordered this to-go, so I wasn't able to request a remake. 

Overall, Alchemist has potential. The coffee is already great. My recommendation would be to work on improving the food, paninis specifically, or scratch them off the menu because this was not it.", "Reviewer # 25. 

I am a big fan of brunch. I was looking for something that I wouldn't have to wait in line for. I noticed this place on Yelp by using the maps icon near where I was shopping. When I walked in  I was pleasantly surprised by all of the awesome things that they had on the wall and the culture that was presented. 

The vibe is modern and relaxing, kind of like Flying M, but with a lot more space. There is a spot for you to help yourself to ice cold water, games for you to play, a section of items sold by local people, and yummy food and drinks-- even beer. 

They have real food, too. We got an omelet, which came with a side of bread (we chose the croissant) and my dining companion got the turkey sandwich melt and it came with lays chips. He also got a butter-finger frape and he said it was delicious. Oh, we both got avocado with our meals. 

I really enjoyed myself at this place. The only reason why I didn't give 5 stars was because it took 20 minutes to get the food and 22 minutes to get the drink. This isn't the usual I'm sure. IN addition, I didn't get the avocado inside my omelet as requested, but they brought me avocado once I made them aware. 

I'm a fan and will start working from there when I want to get out of the office."]

name: Tin Roof Tacos
categories_raw: Tex-Mex, Breakfast & Brunch, Mexican, American (Traditional), Restaurants, Tacos
top_reviews:
['I've been to TRT several times now. A great place to stop in and get some street tacos. The tacos are made right in front of you and there are lots of creations for you to chose from. Dieting? No problem, just get them without the tortilla and you have a carb free meal! 

356th person to review Tin Roof Tacos in Boise Idaho near St Lukes hospital on Broadway. This is my 458th review. 

They have a patio that you can chillax in and some large sized tables on the inside. There isn't much room at all and can get busy, but its all in the experience, right and as long as you have tacos, good tacos, then everything's gonna be alright my friends. 

As Tim D said in his review... "Now, stop reading this review and order you some tacos"! Here here, Tim D.!', 'The tacos were even better than the buzz!  The tastiest street-TexMexAmerican-style tacos we've had in all of Treasure Valley.   Arguably anywhere north of Austin.  If you need more than that recommendation, here are things  to know before you go...

BACK STORY:  The friendly guy behind the counter told us this was started by a couple of sisters who relocated from Texas to Boise and noticed the absence of street-style taco places here.  Filling the niche, they opened Tin Roof.  Aren't all of our taste buds tickled for their entrepreneurship!   (I'd love to know how the nifty name came to be.  If I have a chance to meet the owners, I'll ask.)  

FORWARD TIP:  I hear another Tin Roof is planned for Meridian.  El hurra!  Times two for that cheer since it will NOT be in the Village mall.  (Who wants to go to a big shopping mall and fight the parking to eat?  Not you?   Me neither.)

VIBE: Located at a little strip mall not far from downtown and with neighbors that include a dry cleaner and yogurt shop, this is a sparkling clean and 'all are welcome' kind of place.  For seating there are several long communal tables with chairs inside and also some high counters and chairs on one wall and at kitchen.  There are more tables and chairs outside on a covered patio with a funky-fun-firepit.  They have allowed ample room at the order counter and in the aisle way to get from food pick up counter to the tables. Seating at tables may be a tight squeeze in busy times.  One TV in the corner (with sound off when we were there - thank goodness.)

SERVICE:  Do friendly folks make terrific tacos taste even better?  Maybe.  The people at the service counter and in the open kitchen space sure are delightful.  And the time from placing order to calling our name for order being up was "flash fast".

DRILL:  Menu is posted on big, clear to read signs on  the wall to the left of the order counter.  It lists six breakfast tacos (available all day) and fourteen others including two pork, two chicken, three veggie (yahoo! says me), two seafood and five beef options. Order at the counter and when your meal is ready they'll call your name to pick it up to carry to your seat at a table...or to go with you.  

EATS:   We shared four tacos between two of us; one of the pork and all of the veggies tacos.  Each was delicious with fresh ingredients and flavors on very good corn tortillas.  (The tortillas came to them formed and par baked and they finish them off on the in house tortilla 'grill'.)  The tacos were very tasty just as served.  Next time we'll also try some of the sauces in squeeze bottles at the counter...tomatillo (mild), red chile (spicy), and orange (habanero hot).  The tacos are served inside cardboard containers and all placed on a nice round Tin Roof tray to make it easy to carry and eat them.

VALUE:  Breakfast tacos are only $2 each, seafood options are $2.50 and the others $2.25.  A bargain for this great product!

ACCESSIBILITY: I have MS so pay particular attention to equal access. (I bet the Governor of Texas, a man who uses a wheelchair due to an accident, does too.)  Level in the door and all on one level.  Tables are standard height with chairs that can be moved if necessary for wheelchair access.  Patio is fully accessible with some tables there as well.  Good for them. 

PARKING:  Parking is at a premium in Boise so a big advantage for this location is the small strip mall parking lot.  ADA parking spaces included.  

TIMING IS EVERYTHING:  Want to avoid the long line which can sometimes form here (for good reason) or to be able to have a group find seats together?  If you're going at lunch be in by 11:20 and you'll be good to go.', "Act 1, Scene 1: Get me outta here!

Black and white scene depicting Jack and Ophelia sitting in a living room with the sound of rain sprinkling outside.

Ophelia: (sighs, and walks to the fridge) What should we have for dinner?
Jack: I don't know...whatever...
Ophelia: Pizza? (rifles in freezer) Taco casserole?
Jack: Really. Whatever. (stares listlessly out the window)
Ophelia: Okay?
Jack: (unintelligible muttering while staring out rain drizzled window)
Ophelia: (slams fridge) No! Enough! We have got to get out of this house! Let's go out.
Jack: (looks up from sofa) Where?
Ophelia: Somewhere we've never been. Some place new to us! (consults Yelp app)
Jack: (gets up off sofa and looks slightly more energetic)
Ophelia: I've got it! Tin Roof Tacos! 

Act 1, Scene 2: Queso. Cuz I say so.

Tin Roof Taco cashier: Hey! What can I get for you?
Ophelia: I'll have the roasted corn taco and the grilled fish taco.
Cashier: Ok, and you? (gestures to Jack)
Ophelia: Wait! And, queso! You have queso?!?! Oh my god...queso! This is exciting.
Cashier: Yes! Got it. (looks again to Jack for order)
Ophelia: Oh and guacamole! Can I get an order of chips and guac?
Cashier: (smiling) Sure.
Ophelia: Wait. You have beer? Yes! (turns to high five Jack)
Jack: (begins to laugh) Can I order at this point?
Ophelia: Right. Sure. Of course. Are you getting beer? Because, (looks at the cashier), I'd like the black lager.
Jack: Are you done?
Ophelia: I'm just very excited. I think maybe I've been in the house too long.
Jack: Agreed. (to the cashier) I'll have a shrimp taco and a grilled fish taco.

Act 2, Scene 1: Technicolor

Server places food order before Jack and Ophelia on the table. 

Jack and Ophelia in unison: Thanks!
Ophelia: (bites into roasted corn taco and groans) Oh my god...
Jack: (takes a warm chip and dips it in the queso) Holy queso...
The scene continues with very little speaking and much groaning as the scene slowly transitions from black and white to color.

===============

Seriously, my friends, those were the best dang tacos I've had since my toes were buried in Mexican sand. Flavorful, fantastic, with a decidedly Tex-Mex flare. So much flavor! 

The prices are amazing, the food is bomb, and the service is friendly. 

Plus, they have beer.

And, queso. Did I mention the queso?

Tin Roof Tacos, you may have just saved my winter weary life.

Get to it!"]

name: Eureka!
categories_raw: Restaurants, American (Traditional), American (New), Nightlife, Bars, Burgers
top_reviews:
['There are a number of good places to eat on downtown Boise's 'Restaurant Row' of 8th Street.\xa0 Eureka! is not one of them.  The Boise location is the 21st installment of\xa0a California chain started in 2009.  (Kudos to the two guys who had the chutzpah to start a food chain during that recession).  From my perch Eureka! is to the 2000's into 2020's decades as Red Robin was to the 1970's to 1990's.  This is formula-place, the same menu and schtick at each chain location.  One visit was enough for us to know we won't go back on our own steam.\xa0 If someone suggested Eureka!, we would try to talk them out of it and in to one of the other places on 8th like Wild Root, Bittercreek or Red Feather.  (Examples didn't  include 8th Street located Matador - a chain Mexican food place.)  

VIBE:   Part of Eureka's success for 21 locations expansion is interior design that fits the local 'hipstah' community for each city there are in.  So the interior design here, although dark in the bar and interior seating spaces on the other side of the bar, is just enough "Boise funky" to grab attention in a good way.  There is also a biig outdoor patio at front and roll up garage door for warmer weather months.  Seating in the bar is all awkward high perch.\xa0 Seating in other parts of the restaurant includes tight-spaced standard height tables.  It is LOUD.

SERVICE:  People who work here were welcoming but the "team service" Eureka! touts in their business profile (see corporate web page) was like a Keystone Cops routine.  It is a different thing  to have a service team with a lead backed up by his or her peers when they are tied up. That works.\xa0 But Eureka!'s  is a "relay" approach and the problem is as the service-relay baton gets handed off it is dropped repeatedly.  This meant for us:

* Once seated a server came tableside to greet us and answer menu questions.
* Still another took the beverage order.
* Still another came by to ask if we wanted  to place beverage order at which point we said already done. "Oh. OK."
* Still another delivered 1/2 of beverage order and was surprised when we said "there was more to this".\xa0  "Oh.  I'll check."
* Still another delivered drink order part 2.
*First server took food order and said "No problem" when we asked for apps first and veggie burger afterwards.
* Looong wait before still another server delivered lukewarm apps and hot veggie burger all at once.  (Seems apps were waiting in the kitchen since no one was aware of need to deliver them first.) "Oh. Sorry."
* At end of meal one of the servers asked if we'd like dessert.\xa0 We said "Coffee first, please, but yes we're considering dessert.",  and then...
*Still another server set the bill on our table without coffee presented or dessert order taken.\xa0 Perhaps because the not so good lukewarm apps were left uneaten this server assumed, not having talked to the previous server, that we neither ordered coffee nor wanted dessert.

At which time we gave up and left.  

In exploring further we found the chain actually thinks this "passing the baton" relay service is a good thing and touts it on their website.  Problem is dropped batons.\xa0 Nice people.\xa0 Process is the problem.

FOOD: This is formula food - each Eureka! is same menu.  (You know.  Like Red Robin.  Or Applebee's.)  There are burgers aplenty.  We appreciated the veggie burger (BEET based) could be ordered with any of the beef burger toppings. The pork riblet app and Brussels sprouts were not good.\xa0 It wasn't only that they were served lukewarm, but the Brussels were oily and the pork tough.\xa0 Not like us to leave leftovers, we reuse them at home, but they weren't worth the transport.

Portions are moderate in size.  We think this is a good thing in the 'more is better' era in chain food service.

PRICES:Spendy for the quality and portion size.

LIBATIONS:\xa0 First a 'non-octane' tip.\xa0 They make their own ginger-lime soft beverage here and it is a winner.\xa0 Their schtick is as 'brown\xa0bar' for local whiskeys and beers.\xa0 (A big circle is drawn to define local.)\xa0 I'm a whiskey lovin' person so that might appeal to me were the whiskey served elsewhere.  The lofty prices of some pours here gives me shivers.

THIS N THAT:

1) PARKING:\xa0 On 8th is almost always non existant.\xa0 Park and hike from other streets or garages.

2) ACCESSIBILITY:\xa0 Given Eureka!'s CA HQ, the chain does a pretty good job.\xa0 That said there is no standard height seating in the bar (should be) and it seemed it might be\xa0a tight gauntlet between seating for a wheelchair user to get to the loo when highchairs were at booth ends.\xa0 (ADA requires 36" clear in aisles and between seats.)\xa0 Loo is accessible.\xa0

3) LOO:\xa0 In a hallway outside the restaurant but inside the building.\xa0 You'll need a security code for the door to get into the loo.\xa0 Write it on your wrist to remember it if you've had too much at the 'brown bar'. ;-)', "Alright, I did the responsible thing and came here twice before writing a review.

So far: PRETTY EFFING GOOD!

The happy hour deal, for a new, fancy, semi-expensive place, blows away most other happy hours in the area. It features some amazing appetizers (one of the best bruschettas plates I've ever tasted; osso bucco riblets; fried chicken sliders; fried brussels sprouts with a sticky glaze) for pretty decent prices, not to mention discounts on their (extensive, thoughtful, eclectic) tap list, wine list, and select liquors (Buffalo Trace bourbon and a vodka that I forgot... don't tread on me vodka... something). It's worth mentioning that their house wine is a wonderful cab from Paso Robles, a region that produces amazing cabs and zins.

I've also tried the marrow burger, which is just insanely decadent and rich... very, very tasty, but a once-in-a-lifetime pick for me. I need a little more balance in flavor. We also tried the lobster tacos, which were great but could use some improvement (if management wants to talk, I truly think we have minor changes that would very positively affect the experience). The truffle fries rock... it's just hard to pick a bad item here.

I always neglect peripheral qualities, but the atmosphere and interior are so damn relaxing, the servers are super polite and attentive, and I really can't think of one thing to complain about.

Oh, well, the restroom is a communal one, meaning you walk down a shared hallway and use a code to get in. If that's the worst thing that happens to you, you're doing a lot better than most of us.

Cannot say enough good things. Try this place now!", "We were lucky enough to be invited to their soft opening for lunch today. All the employees were super helpful and def on their best behavior. We shared an appetizer, their smoked chicken nachos. It was a nice size for 3 people to share, but if there are more in your group I would suggest ordered another app. For my entree, I ordered their blue burger. It had blue cheese, caramelized onions, and herbed mushrooms. The flavors melded great, the burger was super moist and flavorful, and the cheese didn't overpower the dish. If I had one suggestion, I would ask they reformulate the fixings so that they would stay inside the burger when I life it to my mouth. That said, the burger was a bit messy and hard to keep together. For dessert, we had their apple cobbler. They topped it with vanilla bryers ice cream and candied pecans. Very good!!!  

About the restaurant: Perfect for a date night spot. They have at least 20 beers on tap at all times. Service is on-point. Prices on entrees range from $12-24. Happy hour goes from 2-6 and again 9-close. HH appetizers seem to be about $2 off full price. On Tuesdays the special is 50% off glasses of wine."]

name: Amore Nail Studio
categories_raw: Permanent Makeup, Waxing, Beauty & Spas, Nail Salons, Hair Removal, Eyelash Service, Estheticians, Skin Care
categories: ['permanent makeup', 'waxing', 'beauty & spas', 'nail salons', 'hair removal', 'eyelash service', 'estheticians', 'skin care']
top_reviews:
['I'm torn between a 3-star and a 4-star review.  So, I'm giving 4-stars based on the person who provided my pedicure.  I booked my visit through the link on Yelp, so that was a great start.  I live an hour from town, so planning is necessary and I understand scheduling very well.

I finished breakfast at a nearby restaurant and thought, maybe I can stop by the Studio and get in early.  I had no expectations, but figured, it can't hurt to try.  From the moment I walked in the door, it seemed like I was interrupting a private social club.  The person from at the front desk was curt and unfriendly when I asked if it was possible to start early.  She kept saying, no appointment available until 4:30.  I said, at least 4 times, that I had an appointment already, and finally, I was told that I couldn't start early.  Based on this experience, I would have given a 1-star rating and would never return.

Then, at the planned start time, we made it to the chair.  However, a customer entered and had a catastrophic wedding day problem.  That problem was related to some nails that my tech had done.  The front desk person didn't want anything to do with the problem person.  And, my tech seemed stymied by the issue.  But, she balance the fixing of the nail problem with my pedicure very well.

Finally, the issues were gone, and the pedicure began.  This part would earn a 5-star rating.  The attention to detail and focus on me as a customer was awesome.  My feet were in need of help and they got exactly what they needed.

I'll consider going back, but I'll look for recommendations from friends before "settling" on this location.', "Everyone here was so nice, but I am speechless at the lack of training my nail technician had. 

I had a Mani pedi and noticed during the pedicure that she didn't seem to be doing much with my cuticles. I figured they must not have been as bad as I thought. The polish looked fine so we moved on to the manicure.

First, my cuticles weren't left to soak very long...then--and I just couldn't believe this--she pushed back my cuticles with *an Emery board*. I wanted to say something but it was clear that she didn't know enough about what she was doing to fix it. By the time the polish was going on my nails they looked rough and and the dust from buffing them was everywhere. 

She didn't give me a chance to wash my hands and didn't take the time to clean off the dust. The polish was applied clumpy and uneven in relation to my nail bed. Literally the worst manicure I've ever had --though from one of the nicest people ever. I hope this improves because they have a lot going for them as an establishment.", 'I would skip this place ( as it probably won't stay in business long due to COVID or the lack of solid customer service. ) Upon entering you're bombarded by country western music and a man at the front desk telling you that you're lucky to get a walk in appointment as they are " so busy all the time " even though there were only 3 customers but about 8 employees... oddly , I knew straight away that  I'd most likely never ever be back because It isn't In my hood and I just wanted a quick , yet overdue pedicure . The good things are that there is a nice big room to get your nails done and they offer you a cold bottle water of water upon seating you . It is quite spacious and appears to be clean . 
The bad things are that There are MULTIPLE ppl working here but hardly customers and There are no protocols when it comes to social distancing upon paying out when you're done . 
Not okay . You have staff ppl sitting there shouting to their boss when you walk up that they don't know how to take payment from the customers and it takes about two hours for the entire situation to take place from start to finish. 
The vibe is amateurish . The ppl working are straight out of beauty school which it obvious by their technique since they don't pumice feet . They remind you that it's normally busy and that walk ins are unheard of which was something that kept striking me as odd . I kept wondering Why would it would even matter ... Totally odd . The vibes are off in this place . Seems the owners take FULL advantage of the employees here since they have them work 10 hour shifts here during COVID . Yikes . There are many nail places in town that are more efficient and effective in COVID protocols that if I were you , I would deeply consider Running, not walking away from this place . You're welcome.']

name: Caffeina Roasting Company
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Bakeries, Cafes, Breakfast & Brunch, Coffee Roasteries, Restaurants, Food
top_reviews:
['This was destination coffee stop based on reviews.  Liked it fine to have tried it once but it wouldn't be destination again for me.  The brewed coffee was good enough, it just wasn't what I prefer - on the day of my visit they had only two medium roast options available.  There were no "just-a-little-something" food options available to go with the brew but a couple of donuts and what looked like a few shrink wrapped scones.  Also, the majority of table seating is high perch and those bar height seats don't work for me.  Also because, Oy Vey, the booming music selections really didn't work for me...Kurt Cobain, anyone?  How about Anthony Kiedis?  (Sure, you do too remember the Red Hot Chili Peppers.)  In addition, I've always found the strip mall in which this is located sort of, well, seedy and so poorly laid out as in the developer just threw it up and got away with it.  

But it is funky-industrial pleasing design inside with cool light fixtures and a sofa and chairs and also has an outdoor patio too.  Sparkling clean.  Those are all good things.  I can see why it works for some folks even if not for me.  Different strokes.  There were people camped out with laptops and documents spread across the tables - it does seem coffee places are study halls and portable offices in the main these days, doesn't it?  

PARKING:  There is a laundromat at the opposite end of this same building and on the day of our visit although about 40% full of people in Caffeina the lot was full and it appeared largely laundromat customers.

ACCESSIBILITY:   Is a problem at this relatively newly renovated 'strip mall' site.  But there is one ADA spot near the laundromat.  It is level in the door and all on one level at Caffeina with ample aisle spaces.  Maybe two standard height tables.  Didn't check the loo.', "Good latte.  Nice environment.  Cool baristas.  I recommend you check it out if you haven't.", 'I'm not a big yelp reviewer but I feel like my experience this morning is worth noting, for the safety of other potential customers. 
I am traveling from out of town and and am a bit nervous of being a potential carrier of covid 19 from my home town into areas that are less effected. At the same time, I don't want to pick this virus up from anyone along the way, because I would carry from one town to another. 
In my travels, I have been pleasantly surprised by the overwhelming number of business that are doing their part to fight off this virus by wearing masks. 

I really really really don't want to wear a mask. But I do. Every time I go out in public and absolutely each time I walk into an enclosed space where there are other people. Again, I don't want to get you sick and, I don't want you to get me sick. It's an easy courtesy.

When I walked into Caffeina this morning, I immediately noticed that 90% of the customers were not wearing masks. I thought, that's fine. Maybe the people of this town are similar to many other places iv been and they are more concerned with their "freedoms" than they are with stemming this disease which is killing WAY more people than it needs to. 
But then I approached the counter to order my coffee and I found that not one of the baristas was wearing a mask. With our masks on, we ordered our drinks and then patiently waited. 
The woman who came in after us was wearing a mask and after she ordered, she politely asked the barista "excuse me, why aren't you guys wearing masks?"
The barista responded "because we are not required to."

I was shocked. Traveling around the country, I have found that every business I go into; employees are always wearing masks. Sometimes they look like they don't want to but they do it. Either because it's the right thing to do, to help save lives or, because they have to.

In disbelief, I pulled out my phone and looked it up. Unless I misread my source, I seem to have read that it is in fact a requirement for any business in the city of Boise; for anyone in public, to wear masks. I disagree with the notion that we all must wear masks any time we are outside. But inside, in a place of business, it is an understandable essential. 

It is the law in Boise and these baristas were breaking the law. But even if it was not required, it is dangerously absurd to take "I am not required to wear a mask" as an excuse to allow themselves to be exposed to me, who might cough in their faces, and by extension, they would be exposing themselves to others who come into their store.

The coffee at this pace was actually really good. And I got a bran muffin which was also good. 

But the baristas who must have served 100 people before me and would probably go on to serve another 200 people after me, are thumbing their noses at safety precautions in the face of a global freaking pandemic. All because...... they don't want to wear masks.

Seriously. Wear your freaking mask when you are at work dealing with food and cash exchanges!! You morons!!! And unless this safety issue is addressed, I would urge customers to get their coffee from a company which showed a little more respect to their customers and community. Caffeina left a bad taste in my mouth for The whole city. Why have they not been fined???']

name: Bombay Grill
categories_raw: Indian, Buffets, Pakistani, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['Bombay Grill offers up delicious Indian eats in a lovely setting. 

When I first walked into Bombay Grill, I didn't expect the large dining room I encountered! I would say Bombay Grill is probably one of the better options for Indian dining in Boise with a large group (where you'll still have plenty of elbow room). 

I typically order their Chicken Tikka Masala, which always comes out flavorful and delicious. They are generous with the heat, though. So, if you don't like things too spicy, I would ask for it  very mild. I made the mistake of asking for it "mild to medium-ish" (a little indecisive, I realize) and it came out tasting like an edible version of the sun on the 4th of July (ie: blazing hot). A testimony to their deliciousness? Even with mouth on fire, neck splotching, and forehead beginning to perspire (I'm a baby), I couldn't stop from finishing it. 

Beyond their chicken tikka, I would say they nail all the staples. Their naan? Exactly perfect (ie: not too crispy, not too soft). Their basmati? Light and lovely perfection.

Their service is always spot on and their prices are reasonable considering their downtown locale. 

All in all...I'm a fan!

Get to it!', "We are very fortunate to have three great Indian restaurants in Boise and Bombay sets the bar very high. The food quality is always exceptional and the owners make the experience perfect. If you want to try a good selection of food to get a sense of what their quality is like or if you aren't sure what you like, try the lunch buffet first. 

Bombay is located in the old Idanha hotel and the space is well past needing to be remodeled but it doesn't take away from the experience. This is good quality food in a casual atmosphere served by people who truly care about their customers. My daughter, girlfriend and I have been going since they opened and have virtually never had anything we didn't enjoy here.

Their butter chicken and mango chicken are two of the best Indian dishes in Boise and they also make a Dopiaza that is divine. I'm not a fan of the deserts but that is true of most traditional Indian desserts generally for me.

Once you discover Bombay you'll become a regular, the food and the service combined will bring you back again and again.", "Why am I just now finding out about their lunch buffet?!? It is glorious. When my friends invited me out for Indian food, I was anticipating we would sit down, wait a few minutes, order, wait a few minutes, and then eat. What we experienced was far from that - we walked in, dropped our coats at our table, walked over to the buffet, filled our plates to our heart's content, sat down, ate, and then repeated the last four steps for good measure. ;)

The whole set up is genius - the restaurant is downtown (making it an ideal lunch spot), wait-time for food is pretty much non-existent, it's affordable considering what you get (around $12), and it is delicious!

I tried a little bit of everything - the tikka masala, butter chicken, a vegetable curry, fried rice, chai tea, and these fried vegetable things. Oh. My. Gaaaaah. Let me tell you about the fried vegetables (I wish I could recall the actual name of the dish) - they were somethin' else, in a good way. Everything was good - but those were my favorite thing I tried.

I cannot say too much regarding service seeing as it was a buffet. Our server did stop by several times and refill our waters/take away old plates - so I assume that if it were a normal dining experience service would be prompt! I also cannot say much about coming here for dinner as all I've experienced was their lunch buffet  - and well, after the last few paragraphs you already know how I feel about that! *Heart eyes*"]

name: San Francisco Style Sourdough Eatery - Boise
categories_raw: Delis, Salad, Soup, Restaurants, Sandwiches
top_reviews:
["Reviewer # 33
We stopped in here by accident. We were originally meeting at Cafe Zupas (LOVE THEM) but they were packed with a line out the door. Being that we were both on our lunch hour we decided that wasn't the best place. I did notice San Francisco Sourdough Eatery and suggested that. We both love the city by the bay, we decided to check it out. Besides, it was bookmarked on my Yelp for quite a while. 

When we walked in, I noticed it was a cute and quiet area. I got a salad any my dining companion got a sandwich. We both were pleased with the food and the overall price wasn't bad at all. We will check it out again for sure.", "Upon approaching San Francisco Sourdough, nestled in a strip mall on Emerald, one could easily mistake it for another run-of-the-mill sandwich shop in a community full of them. 

One would indeed be mistaken.  

I walked through their front doors when I smelled it..

*sigh*

...home.

Ok..ok...Boise, at this point, IS home.  But, I was raised in the Bay Area and lived there until I struck out and moved to good ol' B-town over a dozen years ago.  And, my people, there is nothing that transports me home like the smell of fresh baked sourdough.  I smell it, close my eyes, and there I am, sitting over a sourdough bread bowl filled with soup while listening to the sound of rain on pavement.

And, my people, this is a smell one doesn't tend to stumble across here in Boise.  I've tried sourdough all over this valley and none of it comes close to what you get in San Francisco.  

Until now.

How is this possible?  I don't exactly know.  Maybe it has something to do with the fact that their sourdough starter was cultivated IN the Bay Area.  From which, the dough is formed, frozen, and then delivered to San Francisco Sourdough Eatery here in Boise.  So, when you order your sandwich, your bread will be baked fresh and served as warm as you, wrapped in a blanket, in front of a wood stove, on a cold winter's eve.  Which, is to say, really quite comfortably warm, indeed.

I had sampled several of their sandwiches previously and so I knew what I wanted:  The Pastrami with Coleslaw.  That is to say, the coleslaw is ON the sandwich.  Had I not tried it previously, I would never have thought to order it, but, it is amazing.  Amazing!  The coleslaw is just the right amount of creamy coolness, paired with the warm bread, warm pastrami, and melted Swiss.  This sandwich is a game changer.  

I got the combo (they have 3 combo types:  sandwich with salad & drink, sandwich with soup & drink, sandwich with chips and drink) and splurged on a sugar cookie for dessert.  I didn't expect much from the cookie...but surprisingly delicious and worth the splurge!

The pastrami with coleslaw only comes in their large size, which was nice because, after having what felt like a hearty dinner, I still have half the sandwich that I shall be enjoying for lunch tomorrow!

Ahhh...comfort food.

Is my affection for this place based on some sort of whimsical, sensory, culinary walk down memory lane?

Perhaps.

Perhaps you too, would enjoy a little culinary journey to the Bay without ever leaving Boise.

I know I did.  And, will do so again.

Often.

Get to it!", 'Delicious. I'm talkin' everything you want a sandwich to be. Fresh bread topped with high quality meats, cheeses, veggies and toppings.

We had a team lunch at work and decided to get food from here. I had only a few moments to browse their menu on mobile and decide, so I didn't get to reading all of the descriptions. I scanned the menu and saw the words "Bacon and Avocado" in the title of one sandwich, and it was settled. 

All of my coworkers ordered half-size sandwiches, and I did as well...or so I thought. Apparently the Turkey Bacon Avocado is one of their specialties, and they only do full size sandwiches for their specialties. I wasn't mad about it. My plan at first was to save the second half for later...but who am I kidding? I ate every last bite of that sammie! It was delicious. The bread alone makes a trip here worth it. They also are generous with the amount of meat, cheese, bacon and avocado they topped this sammie with. The only thing I did not absolutely love was the mustard it came with. It was a bit too acidic for my liking. I think next time I'd just skip on this sauce. Aside from that, this sandwich was a total hit in my opinion!

**I've only tried their food via takeout (which someone else picked up), so I have no remarks on the interior of the building or the service.**']

name: Barbiere DeVino
categories_raw: Beauty & Spas, Hair Salons, Men's Hair Salons, Barbers
top_reviews:
["The EXPERIENCE and ambiance of this Gentleman's Barbershop is unparalleled or unrivaled in Boise. To find someone and/or a space to provide a proper cut is hard enough to find but add in that the barber uses a straight razor to attend to even the smallest of details and you have a fantastic cut, shave, and trim. The space is decorated like an authentic barbershop used to be and reminds me of a 1915-1920's look with fantastic eclectic artwork adorning the space with easy listing music and good conversation from the lead barber Chris. 

The prices are affordable, and I walked out of there paying $10-$15 for my haircut with the tip included. Its really amazing because its about 25% and cheaper cost wise than most barbershops around. I've met some fantastic people that were waiting for a haircut while I was there and it gets even better when you can pass the time with great conversation with any of the barbers there. At Barbiere DeVino its more than a haircut its an experience and with the barbers that work there and its more like getting a haircut by a good friend than one of your more run of the mill barber locations. It truly is something from the past where quality service, professionalism, and atmosphere make that place so special.

 This will be my new barber hands down and I look forward to getting my haircut at this fine establishment. I support small business and it doesn't get any better than a barber who is a small business owner that can send it right back back into the local economy. I support Boise, Small Business Owners, and Great quality of service should be rewarded. I will support Barbiere DeVino because I have yet to find anything similar outside of NYC itself; and the experience warrants me to make this part of my new routine and as my new barbershop.

Chris you do wonderful work, and I'll see you in 2 weeks! Your bringing back how a barbershop should be and reminds me of the good ol' days and I'm glad to see an authentic barbershop in Old Boise where it properly belongs.", "Okay. I read the reviews. And I was sold. I was likely going to get a half-decent cut. Being from out of town I was relying on the reviews for a good cut. And I could have sworn it would have been great. But when I showed Up without an appointment I was passed off on a girl who had recently started cutting hair and all the red flags were going up in my mind. Then she took 30 minutes to try to buzz one small section of my hair. It was a painful long haircut of over an hour as I watched the other barbers masterfully cut men's hair while mine was butchered. Definitely not coming back here next time I'm in Boise", "I am visiting Boise for a short time and needed a haircut. I get a pretty traditional barbershop high fade and searched around for places that had a traditional barbershop vibe on yelp and this place came up. I was a bit hesitant since it did not have as many reviews as some of the other local places, but gave this place a chance. You have the option of walking in or making an appointment. I made an appointment and am glad I did because availability of the barbers is random and I wanted to get in and get out. The shop is located below ground and when you walk in you're greeted by alternative/punk/ska tunes on the sound system and a legitimate barbershop decor. Place is clean and I was immediately greeted by the staff and by Chris, my barber.

Chris was a super down-to-earth guy who kept me engage throughout the entire cut. I talked to him about what I was looking for and showed him a couple of pictures to make sure we were on the same page and went from there. Chris took his time and was very attentive to detail as he cut my hair. He was receptive when I asked him to fix a couple of things and he was very helpful in offering suggestions to how best to style my new cut.

This place is a no-nonsense type of barbershop with the occasional cursing, scantily clad women on calendars (which I did not care for, and may not be appropriate for younger customers) and uncensored music. This place definitely caters toward a younger crowd, but does not exclude other age groups. Haircuts are $20, with a neck shave thrown in. Unfortunately, there is only street parking available outside and it can be limited at times. If you come on the weekends, parking is free.

This place is dope. You should get your hair cut here."]

name: Chandlers
categories_raw: Nightlife, Restaurants, Seafood, Cocktail Bars, Jazz & Blues, Food, Steakhouses, Arts & Entertainment, Bars, Lounges, Adult Entertainment, Wine Bars
top_reviews:
['Chandler's will be CLOSED FROM 11/5 UNTIL 11/13 due to covid19 issues.  "Taking a breather..." as the owners / management said in public announcement.  This from their announcement via social media and email today:  "We have had our first positive cases of COVID19 in the Chandler's family.  Therefore we are suspending service immediately.  Thanks for your patience and understanding.  We look forward to welcoming you back on November 13."', "This is a great place to take your father-in-law for a special occasion. You know the guy, he likes the NFL, driving his black Cadillac, and reminiscing about his days as a top salesman for the industrial supplier. Back then he used to take his prospects and clients to places like this and close deals over martinis to the sounds of jazz before it became fake. Bring him here and he will be in wanna-be-Sopranos heaven.

The Top Sirloin Kobe is amazing. Get the mushroom side. Also try the grilled artichoke. Spinach salad with bacon and goat cheese was perfect. I'd pass on the Hef-tini, it was a little too mediciny. And I like negronis. The Clayhouse Sirah was delicious.", 'Chandler's is definitely deserving of "As good as it gets".  

I found myself here on a special occasion (I'm pretty sure a 20 year wedding anniversary falls in that category) and our wait staff, Lucas, made sure our meal was special.  We both started out with a cocktail and a shared appetizer (Crab Cakes), followed by a salad and then a main course selection (Scallops for her, Mahi Mahi for me). Each course was brought in a timely manner by staff who seemed to enjoy their jobs and truly worked together as a team.  We then were treated to a complimentary chocolate souffle, because my beautiful wife mentioned we were there for a special occasion. 
     This was one of the better dining experiences I have had in Boise.  Thank you to Lucas and the rest of the crew at Chandler's for making this a memorable dinner.  

Chandler's is a beautiful restaurant that serves up some pretty amazing eats and drinks!']

name: Mount Everest Momo Cafe
categories_raw: Food, Restaurants, Himalayan/Nepalese
top_reviews:
['SUPER disappointing on many levels. After eating at Momo's in Meridian, I was really excited to try another places take on it. My mom got an Amazon Local deal for two lunch entrees at half the price (only $14, normally $28). Let me just say - the deal is not worth it at all. For the original price, I was expecting we'd have a feast and be stuffed before getting halfway through it all. Instead what we each got were: 4 momo's (I got the vegetarian ones, and they were HALF the size of my mom's chicken ones...), a small portion of plain white rice, the chau chau, and a little dollop of chutney and a tomato sauce. We also got some nan on the side with the deal (it was about the size of one medium pita). For reference, we had asked what the lunch special was that day and for $10, we could have ordered the exact same thing, except we would have gotten a little salad and a flavored rice instead of plain. In my opinion, since the normal price of our option was $8 more, it should have been just as good as the lunch special, if not better. I might have been ok with the price/portions IF the food was amazing, but it was far from that.

My mom prefaced the meal with: "I've had one dish from here before and it was pretty good, but it needed salt". This set me on edge because well, my mom NEVER adds salt to anything. Ever. Not even my wounds! So I knew the food would be a little bland. However, I had no idea just how bad it was going to be. The momo's had zero flavor. If I blind-taste tested them, I would think I was eating food from the future that had no flavor and was chalk full of the nutrients you needed to live, nothing more! Adding salt to them made them taste like salt. It didn't help to enhance any 'locked away' flavors. The sauces to dip the momo's in had very little flavor to redeem them. I'm no chutney expert, but I know what tastes good, and this didn't. I would not have even considered it a mint chutney because there was no trace of mint. The tomato sauce was better than the chutney, but it had some kind of bitter taste to it that just didn't sit right. The chau chau was the only somewhat decent dish, but I had to mix the white rice with it because the flavor was so strong (and no, I don't think that was the intention for including the rice). We even added salt to the nan. I've never in my life added salt to bread that was already prepared. It seemed like there was no balance...everything was bland or had too much flavor.

The owner came across as a little pushy in trying to get us to order more than the food we got with our deal. I told him we might order more, depending on how our lunch was. After that experience, I would not eat there again, even for half price. Being completely honest...I wouldn't even eat the food from there if someone treated me to lunch, and I'm all about free! Hate to be a naysayer, especially since I like to support local businesses, but I think food should be enjoyed and there was nothing appealing about this place.', 'Boise is blessed ten times over to have this absolute gem. Mount Everest Momo Cafe is the one of the only places is the city you can eat Nepalese/Himalayan food. The food is authentic, the service is outstanding and honestly, the interior is a little small and dark, but I love it. It mirrors how restaurants in Nepal typically look like. 

I went to Nepal as a student in college and grew to love their cuisine. I had major withdrawals when returning to Boise. My boyfriend-now-husby located Mount Everest for me and I had low expectations. I thought, "Authentic Nepalese, in Boise?! No freaking way." More like, holy cow I was blown away after eating. Now, I probably order take out 6-7 times a year. 

On a recent visit, I began my meal with Yak Momo (steamed dumplings filled with ground yak, served with mild or spicy tomato sauce, $11.99). For those who've never tried yak, I recommend it! If even to just say you've tried it. It's much leaner than regular beef, and IMO, is more moist, sweet and tender. The Momo was steamed perfectly, I swear the entire thing nearly melted in my mouth. They were so juicy and delectable. This is a must order, for sure!
