For my main course I ordered Lamb Masala (marinated lamb roasted in their special clay oven and cooked in curry sauce, $17.95). Do not let the price deter you. The owners use fresh lamb meat, and lamb tends to me a little more expensive. Also, it takes a little longer to cook so to be prepared to wait the extra 10 or so minutes it takes for the dish to be done. But I kid you not, it is absolutely 100% worth the wait. The lamb falls apart in your mouth with each bite and mixes in with the masala , bursting with flavor of the spices of the Himalayan cuisine. You want to eat this dish when it's fresh though because the lamb toughens up quick if you reheat it in the microwave (I learned the hard, sad way.). Also, you gotta get few pieces of Naan (tandoori baked soft and puffy bread, $3.00/piece). It's amazing either plain or dipped in masala/curry/vindaloo. 

Other highlights include fantastic service. On one visit we got the cutest little waitress who was super informative and attentive. The owner of the restaurant even came out to introduce himself and apologize for the long wait time. Above and beyond outstanding customer care. 

Mount Everest Momo Cafe is no doubt one of my top 10 eateries in the Treasure Valley. I look forward to many more visits and take out orders in the coming years.', 'Owner won't accept Groupons and actually lies about it to your face. Not once but twice. If a proprietor of an establishment, especially a restaurant where you have mutual trust that your food won't contain anything harmful, won't even honor a $14 Groupon, refuses business and doesn't understand the very simple concept "the customer is always right" then good luck. I give the business 6 months max. Unfortunate because Boise needs more culturally diverse food. Note to owner Raj: don't try to reap the benefits of free publicity through Groupon and then turn away customers. It is probably the best recipe in your cookbook for disaster.']

name: Barbacoa Grill
categories_raw: Nightlife, Latin American, Steakhouses, Seafood, Restaurants, Brazilian, Cocktail Bars, Bars
top_reviews:
["Barbacoa in 5: Decorated by squirrels on drugs.

Allow me to elaborate
This place has everything. Pictures that move, bedazzled high heels in the bathroom, loud (yes, I'm using it as a noun), guacamole made at your table, sparkles, a rooftop patio, a suit of armor, fire, artwork painted on the ceiling, and Santa. 

It's already decorated so...
It was my birthday (100 years ago) around Christmas time and I was having a small party. I knew this was the sort of place you had to try once (just to say you'd been) and it seemed like a good choice for a get together. 

The food & drinks & service
Service and drinks were fine. No complaints at all. 
The food was like a B movie but with a lot of special FX and make up, so at first glance it appeared to be a blockbuster. The food wasn't terrible, there was just a lot of flash and sizzle involved so it seemed fancier than it was. Which is kind of the point of Barbacoa. It's all just an illusion. 

Santa 
I pulled an Elf when I saw him walk in: SANTAAAA! IT'S SANTA!!!!!!!! He had a couple of elves with him and they sat at a table in the lounge area near our table. I got the waiter to find out what Santa liked to drink. Jager was the answer. Santa must have had a rough day at the mall I thought. So, on a snowy night around Christmas 100 years ago, me and Santa did shots on my birthday at Barbacoa. It was fantastic. 

3 stars 
As much as I think this place is painfully overhyped, expensive, and has decor that looks like Las Vegas threw up, I have to give them props for my birthday party 100 years ago. It was the only time I've been to Barbacoa and it was brilliant. 

-1 star for average food with fancy food prices
-1 star for an aesthetically stressful enviornment", 'Not as bad as we feared it could be.  Not as good as we hoped it might be.  Still, not even very friendly server and guacamole maker could balance out the deficits.  And this we say to Happy Hour goers; beware of their "two for one" policy for libations.  

It is partly that policy, which we laughed about at first "surprise" but then thought not so funny, partly garish decor and partly dated menu at high prices that leaves us feeling lukewarm.  We wouldn't refuse to come back here if someone suggested it.  Neither would we suggest this as destination.

VIBE
"We would have thought this cool when we lived in the East Bay in the 1980's.", my husband said as we settled in at one of the step up booth tables in the dimly lit bar.  "Yes",  I said.  "But that Medusa meets Lochness Monster sculpture evokes the bar from the first Star Wars movie."

Not that that is a bad thing.  But it is this thing.  If this was 30 years ago, we would have "dug it".  Different strokes in different times.  It seems laughably garish today.

HAPPY HOUR UNHAPPY SURPRISE
We arrived about ten minutes to six.  Our plan was to have a cocktail, peruse the dinner menu and decide if we wanted to stay for dinner.  Yeeps whose opinions  I respect had given this just 2 or 3 star ratings so we figured we'd approach with caution.

Our friendly server told us there was a Happy Hour deal that ended at six o'clock.  Two cocktails or glasses of wine for the price of one, she said.  Any wine or cocktail priced $15 or less qualified and both beverages had to be the same kind, she said.  

Sounded like a pretty good deal to us.

The server handed us an IPad to review  specialty cocktail menu and wine lists.  She said she would come back to take our order as the IPad was not for ordering just for reading the menu.  Seemed redundant to us since cocktail menus and wine list were on the table.   

This is indicative of the "flash without function" that seems hallmark for the space.  "Oooh, Myrtle, look at this!  An Ipad." 

More goofiness masquerading as coolness that makes this place laughable. 

We settled on top shelf Margaritas.  The drinks arrived in a tall glass with lots of ice and mixer and a straw.  Not the worst we've ever had.  Not the best.  Still, at $10 each on the menu and in the "two for one" Happy Hour mode, we were feeling good about the bargain price of $5 a drink.  

But to our unhappy surprise, after nearly an hour had passed and we were nearing the bottom of our libations and getting ready to depart  our server arrived with two more drinks.  

Speechless for a moment (not often a state for me) I asked "Umm?  We didn't order these".  

Our nice server said THIS was the "two for one" at Happy Hour.  You order one and you get a second one free after you drink the first one. 

Our first response was to laugh at being "had".  But being long past wanting to or being able to have two cocktails and navigate, this was lost on me as "value".  It seems a pretty sophomoric policy of the bar to over serve two drinks to folks who only want one.  Just sayin'.  

Our server said we weren't the first customers to feel "had" by the policy.  Seems to me ownership is shady to promote like this.  But it fit things being kind of "off" here all around.

EATS
Looking over the big, two sided, laminated dinner menu we decided we'd pass (hot rock cooked steak, bbq chicken pasta...dated), order the table-side guacamole in the bar with our drink and move on.

The schtick of table-side guac seems a relic of 2000's.  Like flaming cherries jubilee table-side was for  the 1970's.  But Barbacoa sells a lot of guacamole this way.  As many as three guys with guac carts work on busy nights making up to 40 orders each we learned.  Shtick sells. (PS - There is a tip jar on the cart to tip the maker.)  Whether made table-side or in the kitchen doesn't matter as long as the guacamole is good.  And this, made and served in a molecajete, was good.  

THIS N THAT:

1) PARKING:  Private lot and it was pretty full.  Goes to show, I guess, we are in the minority opinion about Barbacoa's mediocrity.

2) ACCESSIBILITY:  Troublesome.  My Yelp friends who use wheelchairs will understand how dangerous it is to have wheelchair users have to travel behind parked cars against traffic in a parking lot  because the building owners violate the 24 year old Federal Civil Rights law and Idaho Code to put curb cuts at ADA parking locations  Also only one table at standard height in bar.  All other seating requires step up.  Dining room is step down on one side but ramp in on another.

3) NEIGHBORS:  Boise Park owned lake and walking path right behind Barbacoa.  Fast food restaurant to front.', 'This restaurant will assault all of your senses and not in a good way. Barbacoa is the type of place that may promise appealing, but rather it is just appalling. What I've deduced is that this is where the trashy, brassy, over 35, new money crowd in Boise hangs out. If that sounds appealing then go for it.

The overwrought design is a blend of, well EVERYTHING!  It's as if Salvador Dali threw up every cliché he had ever tried in one three dimensional space. There is the tunnel of wine bottles that you walk through to get to the lounge or dining area, the glass antler chandelier and the downright creepy Medusa like sculpture. All of the décor detracts from the perfectly lovely lake and mountain views from the window wall which runs along the eastern perimeter of the restaurant.
 
The scene is further diminished by the uncomfortably loud noise level throughout the space. One would think that the lounge would be where one would expect to find liveliness and laughter but this aural assault is continued throughout the entire space. The reason why it is so loud is because of the type of person or people who patronize Barbacoa. Typical profile of the clientele: must drive an entry level German luxury car on a lease, over coiffed and perfumed, first divorce just settled, shirt open to three buttons (men and women), excessive amounts of gold jewelry, and drunk to the point of sloppy obnoxiousness. Definitely a caricature, but oh so frighteningly real at the same time.  

The food at Barbacoa is also a bit of a mish mash and the menu is slightly schizophrenic. There is an excellent guacamole which is prepared table side. Then there is a tuna tartare 'tower' which is served with a bizarre twist, mango sorbet. I didn't understand the point of the sorbet at all; I even followed the instructions of the food runner and let the sorbet melt into the tuna. It tasted like melted mango sorbet over tuna - neither ingredient worked to enhance the whole. Total gimmick IMO.

Someone at your table will certainly want to try the "Hot Rock" Filet ($34) which is a huge 10 oz.  cut that is served on an 'Argentina [sic] ironwood platter' and with a small copper Turkish coffee pot of cognac sauce. You get to pick your side. When the entrée arrives at the table a member of the service team will pour a bit of the sauce over your steak which will then cause...you guessed it a flame. Oohh, ahhh!  Theatre of the absurd for adults - I guess this is what passes for fine dining at Barbacoa. The entrée presentation is problematic because of the hot rock since the meat continues cooking throughout the meal due to the residual heat of the rock and by the time you get to the middle of eating your steak it will be well done instead of the medium rare that you requested. This is too bad because the steak is decent.

There are other options besides a full roster of steaks including BBQ Cedar Plank Salmon, Idaho Trout, Chicken Pot Pie, Paella, and all kinds of pasta concoctions.  This menu is too broad and the choices seem convoluted - it needs focus in my opinion. How the hell is there chicken pot pie at a self-described Latin restaurant? Some editing in the number of choices would be helpful to both the kitchen and the diners.  

Barbacoa's entrees and appetizers also suffer from too much of a good thing. The entrée "When Pigs Fly" ($27), aside from being just a dumb name, is a weird mish mash of a thick pork chop with chanterelle mushrooms and apples also comes with a small wood smoked quail and fig jam. Please I beg you, less is really more! 

If all the above were all that were wrong with Barbacoa that would be enough to not recommend this place; however what makes this restaurant memorable is the regrettable service. The front desk staff is horribly rude and not at all welcoming!  The three women reminded me of the Gorgon women - with their overly sprayed coifs protruding from their heads like snakes and their forked tongues sticking out between their bleached fangs. These were not exemplars of a welcoming committee but rather a trio of college BFFs who felt put upon when asked a question about the menu, the restaurant, and yes even for a table. Unacceptable.

The service in the dining area is almost as aloof, but here it is the lack of experience rather than outright rudeness. The servers don't give an explanation of the menu and they read the specials without any enthusiasm. The front server, as opposed to the food runners, is what is lacking. The food arrives in a timely manner from the kitchen via the food runners; the wine, drinks, and check do not which is the responsibility of the primary server.

Boise, you have much better places to spend your food dollars than at Barbacoa. I hope you aren't sucked in by the design and flamboyance, because you will be disappointed. If you are not, then I congratulate you on your ability to bypass the obvious shortcomings of this restaurant, I cannot.']

name: Slow By Slow Coffee Bar
categories_raw: Coffee & Tea, Food, Coffee Roasteries
top_reviews:
["Oddly enough, the older I get the less I like cream in my coffee.  Sugar or anything sweet was nixed a long time ago.  However, just because I like black coffee doesn't mean all black coffee is created the same.  If you try a pour over from Slow By Slow, you will see what I mean.  I recommend the Uganda, it's amazing!", 'Great cortados in every way - right resulting temp, flavorful, strong and rich espresso & naturally sweet and smooth milk foam. Bonus: beautiful latte arts in small cups. 

We tried both the Columbia & Seasonal Blend and enjoyed them a lot. Chocolatey and nutty Columbia based cortado was like a warm hug to your mouth. Fruity, bright and lighter tasted Seasonal Blend based cortado was a refreshing, delightful, more unique cup of espresso based drink.

The two baristas were both cool and nice guys. We enjoyed interacting with them. The interior is classy, homey and warm toned, which is what we like.', "Indigo and I were on the town for a boutique day downtown. 

I've seen the reviews, the pictures, and I'd say they're all accurate. The place has an approachable chic, hipster vibe. The type of place that would instagram well. 

I ordered banana bread and was debating coffee. I realized that it would be foolish not to get coffee since I was already there and paid for street parking insanely close by (I'm hardly that lucky). 

I ordered a vanilla latte made with almond milk. The broista whipped up beautiful latte, but realized he made it with milk. I tried to convince him that it was fine but he insisted that I get what I originally asked for. So he made it again, and it was beautiful as well. I felt bad drinking it but it was delicious. 

I'm not a coffee snob, or coffee expert, however this was the best vanilla latte I've had. I'm not knocking my everyday latte mind you. They do the job just fine, like my favorite jeans. But this latte is more like my date night heels. 

Service was excellent and entertaining. Atmosphere was just lovely. If you're feeling fancy, this is the coffee place for you. 

Indigo gives this place 30 stars for fancy...

I don't always drink fancy coffee, but when I do, I go to Slow by Slow."]

name: The Matador
categories_raw: Bars, Nightlife, Mexican, Restaurants, Cocktail Bars, Tex-Mex
top_reviews:
["Life is too short, Greg. Drink your effing coffee-- Dani S

And that is exactly how I feel about the chocolate cake at The Matador! Eat the cake and have it first... life's too short not to :)~ It's amazing. In fact, I was once thought to be having a seizure when eating this cake, but it was just one of those foodgasms that Chanda speaks of in her review of Island Creek Oyster Bar in Boston... I completely understand that analogy! 

275th person to review The Matador in downtown Boise on 8th st. This is my 453rd review. I've visited this place multiple times and have always had top notice experiences. The food is super good, extra large portions (some items), super yummy drinks (great mixologists), a relaxing environment albeit a little too dark at times. 

As many times as I've been there, I never noticed the app they participate in. Once you spend $200 you get $20 free and just for downloading you get a free (immediately able to use) guacamole which comes fresh to the table (already prepared) with green sauce and a thick tomato salsa on opposite sides. They have a good Happy Hour, too, if you are in there at that time. 

I've ordered many things and have had a few desserts and I am always pleased. If you're interested in sitting on the patio they have a nice one-- there is a lot of foot traffic because it's right next to other places and it's right on 8th st (My FAV.) but good for people watching!", "The Matador is the sort of place I enjoy going for light snacks and drinks as opposed to a full fledged meal. 

For that? I am most definitely a fan. 

With wonderful ambiance inside as well as an awesome patio situation on bustling 8th Street, it's a great stop any time of the year. They offer a wide array of tequilas and so it's a great spot to explore the different types and nuance of flavors that tequila has to offer. They also (of course) have one of the best margarita menus in town. One of my favorites is their Founder's Margarita--Don Julio Reposado, Patron Citronage, lime, lemon, and agave. It's a citrus, salted wonder. 

As for snacks, their Grande Nachos with house chorizo and their Quesadilla (the addition of goat cheese really takes their quesadilla to the next level of deliciousness!) are a couple of my favorites.

A word of warning, though: Their nachos are ha-yuge! You could probably easily feed 4 adults (looking to snack) with one order. It's astounding to me how much they can pile on one little platter without disaster ensuing. And, a mere 10 bucks? A-mazing. 

Finally? They're open late every. single. night. 

Got the midnight munchies? You're own personal red caped Matador to the rescue. 

Get to it!", 'Stopped in for drinks.  I loved the atmosphere and the bartenders were great.  I wished I had tried out the food but definitely a great bar atmosphere.']

name: Idaho Mountain Touring
categories_raw: Outdoor Gear, Bike Rentals, Shopping, Active Life, Bikes, Sporting Goods
top_reviews:
["The wife & I decided on our last day in Boise, the best way to take full advantage of the greenbelt was to bike it.
We Yelped & found Idaho Mountain Touring.
It was a short walk from The Grove (where we were staying) & upon entering the premisis, we noted that it was nicely layed out & greeted with enthusiasm. The girl behind the main counter pointed us in the right direction for the bike counter & Dax came out to help us out with rentals.
Dax & his crew were very helpful in fitting us with a couple of rental bikes. 
All they had this day were a couple of road bikes which I didn't mind, but the wife was a bit hesitant as she's much more a cruiser or mtb rider.
While throwing on peds on the road bikes, a couple of automatic 3-speed cruisers made their way back to the shop.
Before my wife could open up her soup-cooler, a crew member asked if we'd be more comfortable with these bikes!
The wifey swiftly jumped on the opportunity. They adjusted the seats for us, adjusted the price & deposit, filled out some paperwork & we were out of there in about 15 minutes.

FYI: one of many greenbelt entrances to the bike path is just a few short blocks just south of Idaho Mountain Tours (straight down 13th)  and a 4 hour bike rental is more than enough time to see a good percentage of the greenbelt.

AWESOME service from this establishment!
Thanks to Dax, the rental crew & the rest of IMT for a smooth experience.

Renting bikes? When you see Dax, tell him the couple from Calabasas sent ya!

Solid 4.5 stars for solid peeps.

A deez® PSA. Approved! I'm out!", "Dex, one of the salesman lied to me and said there were Grizzly bears in the Sawtooth Wilderness. I knew that black bears roam the Sawtooth Wilderness, but was not inclined to buy bear mace to protect our group from black bears, whom have relatively calm demeanors. Thus, I bought a $50 can of bear mace by relying on Dex's aforementioned false information. I went back to get a refund and the person in charge was not understanding of the situation at all. Worst customer service ever.", "I won't go anywhere else for my bike needs. After visiting a rude, now closed, bike shop in the N. End and getting a dose of snobbery from the staff, a friend sent me to IMT. Their service was a welcome change from what I'd previously experienced. 

I'm an out-of-shape poser on a cute cruiser bike and they have always been helpful whenever I've been in there, despite my ineptness when it comes to anything outdoor-related.  

My husband also has an abnormally large head due to his dreadlocks and IMT went above and beyond finding him a helmet. 

Nice people, and a good place to go to get you bike in tip-top shape."]

name: Naked Fins
categories_raw: Food, Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Poke, Mexican, Tacos
top_reviews:
["I ordered a poke bowl and the fish did not taste fresh and the sauces were gross. I also found out the fish comes from fish farms, which I believe is very unethical. Compared to other poke places like paddles up poke, this place is a huge disappointment. Not to mention the price was over $13 for a poke bowl. I wouldn't go back.", "This is exactly what Boise was missing! A delicious, affordable place with great Asian fusion food. 

I saw this place during the construction and was so excited for it to open and it did not disappoint. They have a good variety from poke and sushi to tacos and stuffed avacados. 

I placed me order online and went in to pick it up. When I got there, my order was not ready but they made a point to rush and get  it out to me.

We got a poke bowl with all kinds of yummy fixings and the quality was great! We also got a salmon roll that had some spicy sauce, cilantro. It was a little skimpy on the fish but it was $6 so that's to be expected. 

We also got the seared ahi boa which was pretty good. We took it home so it was a bit cold but I bet it was delicious when it was warm. 

Needless to say, I am a big fan and will definitely be back soon!", 'A less than satisfactory meal.  Sorry about this. 

I had a Pork Bao taco and a Tree Hugger taco.

The Pork Bao was almost saved by the kimchi that they make in-house. (The kimchi was good) however the bao was dry and tough (not the steamy soft bite I was expecting. ) The last time I was here , I recall that bao was sticky and too soft.  I guess you can just call me Goldilocks.

The Tree Hugger had far too much sauce for my personal taste; something brown and something white too. The tofu was a grey color which they said happens because the tofu is marinated. With all the sauces they put on this taco , any flavor from marinating the tofu is lost. 

I think after two strikes , I just need to conclude this is not one of my favorite spots .']

name: Meraki-Greek Street Food
categories_raw: Restaurants, Salad, Food, Greek, Desserts
top_reviews:
['96th reviewer of Meraki-Greek Street Food in Downtown Boise. 
This is my 377th review on Yelp. 

I really liked this place. We were going to a comedy show at Liquid Laughs and had an hour to kill. We wanted to eat and with many yummy places to eat, we chose this place because it is more fast-food than a sit-down restaurant, which means we would make our show on time. 

The inside is moderately decorated, which works. The decorations they have tells the story of their business and the food. They have Idaho decor, too. One of the neatest things was their soda machine-- nothing mainstream. There is no Pepsi or Coke-- rather different flavors that are made with no high fructose corn syrup. 

The food was super good. I ordered a chicken skewer and they were out of chicken breasts. My options were then chicken thigh or pork-- I went with the pork, which was a good choice. 

My dining companion got the pita nachos, which was divine. Nacho toppings with pita chips as opposed to tortillas, which works wonderfully. Another dining companion got a gyro (pronounced guy-row) with greek fries (regular fries seasoned with a greek blend). 

Everyone was super friendly and helpful. I enjoyed my meal. We will be back!', 'Pretty good spot for a quick lunch, though I found the menu hard to navigate. I came for a standard gyro sandwich but was given the choice between multiple styles (brunch-style, philly, italian...among others) and multiple options for meat. (I highly doubt the street vendors of Greece offer all these choices). I chose the standard Greek style called "Athena," with lamb as the protein.

The staff was friendly, and after submitting my order and getting a number, I sat at a large, blue countertop that had an open-air view of the street (for that good people-watching on a busy Saturday).

My gyro was delicious and large. Good quality meat. Fries were great too. But for $10 for the sandwich ($13 for the combo with fries/drink) it seemed a little spendy - I can get the same thing in pricey CA for a few bucks less.  Still, I'd go here again to try more items.', 'Came here for the soft opening and yum yum!  First, notice the metal art work of the State of Idaho and Greece...talked with a family member for a moment and was heartwarming to hear "Idaho to Greece & Greece to Idaho" connection. We talked to the father who is helping his son with the restaurant-he was extremely friendly even though very busy. 

So tried the Traditional Pork Gyro (they were out of the lamb/beef combo) and husband tried the chicken...the first bite I thought...oh darn, kinda  dry...but the rest of the bites once got into the sauce-YUM- I truly could have drank a bowl of it! There was also crispy french fries on top & filled with savory meat, crisp onions, herbs & house made tzitki sauce (by the way, heard I've been saying "tzitki" all wrong & it definitely sounded cooler in his accent!) And the pita/bread was soft and delicious. 

We also tried the The Village Salad...bright and fresh. Honestly at first I thought how can I eat a bowl of bell peppers? But it too, was savory and delicious (and more than just bell peppers) and the dressing was zippy and fresh. 

A plate of flat bread was brought out with the Fava Bean Dip/spread (much like hummus) and to my surprise a whipped Feta w/a bit of jalepeno (forgot the name of it) with maybe a touch of lemon (something citrusy) that gave it a bit of sunshine. 

Next....baklava sticks or think little baklava egg rolls! It was getting pretty loud now so hard to hear but think he may have said they may not serve them this way so I made sure to voice that the "stick" made it much easier to eat than traditional baklava and goes right along with "street food" flair. It had a deep cinnamon flavor that was very good.

THEN...they had Boise made BuckSnort canned root & ginger beer sodas. They also had Stubborn Brand fountain sodas with no high fructose corn syrup or artificial sweeteners. The black cherry soda and the lemon-berry acai was very refreshing. They also had beers on tap. 

We are excited to come back when it officially opens in the next week or so and try some more goodness! Since it is downtown (next to PF Changs) it was fun to walk around afterwards.']

name: Advanced Lock & Key
categories_raw: Keys & Locksmiths, Home Services
top_reviews:
["One time bad experience?  I called at 11:30pm because I got locked out of my house and they quoted me 45 mins.  After an hour I called back and they said nobody got the memo and nobody was sent out to my residence.  So they at that point quoted me 10-15 mins and sure enough, a guy showed up.  He was dressed totally unprofessionally and didn't even greet us when we met, he just walked up to the house and started working.  It took him over 20 mins to unlock the house.  By the time everything was said and done, it took them two and a half hours to get to my house and unlock it.  

Very unprofessional and untimely, I will go out of my way to use another business next time.", "Its been awhile since I last locked my keys in my car. I tried calling my husband for our extra key but didn't get an answer with him being at work. I called Advanced lock & Key who had someone to me in less then 15 minutes.  Not sure what his name was but he was a very nice young man that had just recently graduated from Capital high school. Would call again with out hesitation.", 'UNPROFESSIONAL and RUDE- Im very confused by all the positive reviews. Maybe they didn't work with the same guy we had to deal with. 

We got a new car and the locksmith place we went to for our previous car was closed so we found Advanced lock & key online and it looked promising because of the good reviews. BOY WERE WE WRONG.

The key that the guy copied would not work- so he was using the palm of his hand to try to punch it in. WHEN OBVIOUSLY IT WASN'T FITTING. 

I was in the car being physically rattled by how hard he was punching my car.

I was taking a video of the car for my friends and it is CRAZY how loud the punching was in the background. We have been to several lock smiths before and NEVER had them try to punch the key in.

My dad is the most polite and soft spoken person and like any rational human being was worried about the force he was using on our new car when clearly the key wasn't right.
 and the lock smith had the AUDACITY to say to 
him 
" Bro you're getting on my nerves- I've been doing this for 30 years". 

Now, I have worked in the customer service industry and know when a customer is crossing the line. My dad was in NO WAY crossing the line or even raising his voice to match the lock smith's loud and aggressive tone.
and if you have been doing this for 30 years, why can't you figure out how to copy the key? 

He went back and forth 4 times to try to modify the key that wasn't working and each time he would come back and try to punch it in again. We kept trying to leave and he kept saying he's going to try again that he has experience and that he can get it. 

We we tired of his rude  and unprofessionalism behavior- we grabbed our key from him and left.']

name: Diablo & Sons Saloon
categories_raw: Bars, Whiskey Bars, Nightlife, American (Traditional), Mexican, Breakfast & Brunch, Tacos, Restaurants, Beer Bar, American (New), Cocktail Bars
top_reviews:
['Diablo & Sons Saloon in 5: Tacos, tequila, chance of mischief.

~Three girls, and later, a guy, walked into a bar~
It was girls night. A bartender friend of ours was having a rough week so we invited him to join us for a little Diablo & Sons. It was a great night out. We all shared cheeseburger tacos from the Late Night Reaclette menu. Cheeseburger tacos, why? A better question might be why the hail not? 

~Not for the entitled~
The motto on their website is: "Reservations are lame." Yes, they are. Your time is worth the same as everyone else's. Walk in, find a table and claim it. If none are available, grab a drink from the bar and wait for one, or just bring the charm and join an existing table. 

~It's not for everyone~ 
This place gets crowded. It gets loud. It gets rowdy. This isn't the place to have a quiet private conversation or business lunch. This is the place to chat up the table next to you, have a strong drink and bring out your bold side.

~Tacos are a must~
I've been here a couple of times and recommend the skirt steak, rams head (it's mushrooms) and cheeseburger tacos. I can honestly say that all three were phenomenal, and I don't easily get impressed by tacos. If parking wasn't such a nightmare, I'd probably eat here a few times a week.
 
~Most excellent~
The atmosphere, food, service, drinks, people and vibe are definitely my type. It's classy but still has a gritty feeling that keeps it from being painfully pretentious. Everyday people will dig this joint. Bring your friends, it's about to get fun. All the stars.', 'Only rating this place for the service and happy hour we partook in this past week...came here after doing some shopping downtown Boise this past week and looking at the Boise State where our youngest is going to school this fall. We came in at a funky time and had dinner plans so was just looking for a light snack and a few drinks. I thought this place hit the spot. We had some chips and salsa, fries and some glasses of wine. Hit the spot! I also thought the inside and outside vibe of this place was really cool! Also our waitress was very friendly and super cool! So nice job and great spot in downtown Boise.', 'My husband and I went here on a date night. When we arrived at 9 on a Saturday it was very packed and very loud. We were childless so we needed this type of enviroment to feel a bit alive anyways but if you don't like crowds or loud places don't go here on the weekends. They have a standing bar which is convenient because we only waited there for 5 minutes before finding a seat. The place began to slow down around 10 so that would be an ideal time to go or earlier when they open at 5:00. 

*^^THE FOOD****
We tried the lamb tacos, pork tacos, skirt steak tacos, and the oyester tacos. The skirt steak tacos, and lamb tacos really bring the heat! I love spicy food and these did not disappoint. If you aren't big on spice I sugguest the pork tacos with the apple raddish. All of the tacos were PACKED with flavor and definately filling. I wasn't a fan of the oyester tacos but it wasn't my choice anyway. My husband who loves seafood more than me really enjoyed them. 

***DRINKS****
The drink menu is small as far as cocktails. I tried their verison of a bloody mary which was made with tomatillos. The spice took away from any flavor of the drink. My second drink was the healthy brew which seriously was amazing. I'd say it was one of the best cocktails I've had EVER! I am still super impressed with the flavor packed in that drink and how quickly my bank account went down last night because of those drinks.


***VIBE****
I really like the decor of the resturant it can feel as classy or casual as you want it to be which is nice. We sat at the bar so the bartender brought us everything and for being packed he did a damn good job. 

You would feel comfortable either dressing up or going in more casually dressed. Either works. I noticed they said that the menu had a "coming soon" on a lot of the sections, imcluding the kid's meal section. Just a heads up if you're going to try this with your children. As a mom I didn't get a kid friendly vibe but it was downtown Boise on the weekend. They just opened so this could be something that in the future would be more plausible.']

name: Boise Pie Co
categories_raw: Cafes, Desserts, Food, Bakeries, Restaurants, Sandwiches, Soup
top_reviews:
['Ownership changed in latter part of 2019.\xa0 What was good under the original owners has been made better by the current ones.\xa0 I imagine building\xa0on the original owners' dream may have been a reason why the seller chose these buyers.  Extra star added for making it work in these difficult times for eateries in addition to good eats.

OBSERVATIONS OF 'WASSUP' NOW: 

*Sweet pies are plentiful and include even more options than before. A round of applause earned from this fruit pie fan-atic that the Boysenberry and Marionberry pies this summer were loaded with fruit and just sweet enough to let the berries be the stars and not overwhelmed by sugar.\xa0 Their Key Lime pie is luscious.

*Savory pies - including hand pies and whole pies - have been added.

*Cheesecake offerings have been expanded and I cannot remember a better cheesecake in all my years of eating them than the huckleberry one here this summer.

*They are currently working on savory pie appetizers to develop some for holiday use.\xa0\xa0

*They are doing daily take out hot meal options (they change daily and see their menu here https://www.boisepieco.net/ ).\xa0 It works best to order these a day ahead but if you have your order in by 11a on 'day of' pick up it will be ready to pick up between 3p and 4p.\xa0 Sized to serve four, the family take out meals are only $29.99.\xa0 They also offer some 'for two' dinner options and boxed lunches.

*They continue to offer\xa0sandwiches.\xa0

*They also make specialty coffee beverages and craft bottled hot sauces.

I SAY 'YOU GO' TO THIS FAMILY BUSINESS:  The owners use top quality ingredients in their products. Keeping that in mind, it is beyond fair for them to find they need to raise their prices a little bit in the next little bit.\xa0 This is from a recent email send to customers:\xa0 "PLEASE NOTE:\xa0In the coming weeks you might notice some price increases. Running a restaurant during this time has been very challenging and prices of ingredients have been very inconsistent due to supply & demand issues. We have held off as long as we could and tried to just absorb any losses but we can't sustain that much longer and continue to remain open to serve you. Thank you for your understanding and continued support. We truly appreciate it."

DRAWBACKS:\xa0 The location is an awkward one tucked out of the way next to furniture retailer.\xa0 They have inside seating but even in non-covid days we found we wanted to take away and you may find that true for you or not.\xa0 They have added a couple of outdoor tables on the walkway.\xa0\xa0

PARKING:\xa0 The location may be awkward but it has a distinct advantage of having an associated, ample sized parking lot.

ACCESSIBILITY:\xa0 Two spots of ADA compliant parking in the lot.\xa0 A ramp up is adjacent to the stairs for equal access for people with disability that makes stair climbing impossible (like me having had MS since college days).\xa0\xa0Standard height seating available.

COVID-19 ISSUES:  Staff wears masks and they are required for customers.  They provide masks (box near display case) for customers who don't have their own.  (Really people...you should have your own at this point.)  Seating is spaced. 

IF I WERE QUEEN:\xa0 I'd wave my scepter and bid them offer more savory pie options that do not include ground beef given it is a protein we never eat at our house and their savory pies sure look great in the case.\xa0 The owners tells\xa0me they are working on pork options among others.\xa0 Were\xa0I Queen I\xa0would say "We are pleased!" ;-)

FUN GIVEAWAY:  Sign up via website for chance to win one free pie each week from 9/21 until Thansgiving.', 'Paah, y'all!   The couple who own this delightful pie shop and eatery are relatively newly transplanted from Florida (Key West) to Boise and many of their yummy pies have a bit of "southern accent".  As in their wicked good Key Lime, butterscotch, Derby, pumpkin praline, peanut butter and banana cream pies.  Others, like blueberry crumble and apple and chocolate are perhaps less regional and every bit as delicious.

I'm a pie fanatic, my Yelp profile even lists home baked pie as one of the things I LOVE, so I was delighted to find Bridgette and Terrance McAbee's pie shop and eatery.  Eatery being the piece some folks may not know about. I didn't until I went in to find they also have savory food here too like quiche, homemade soups like butternut squash or green chile or lemon chicken orzo, creative sandwiches, shepherd's pies and chicken pot pies.

THE EATS & PRICES: If you think real pie comes from one of the grocery store bakeries or Costco, think again.  Boise Pie Company pies are the real deal using all fresh ingredients and scratch made.  I'm hard pressed to think of another retailer in the Boise area who specializes in home baked pies like these, both as whole pies and by the slice.  Prices vary based on the kind of pie, but I think they are roughly $4.00 - $4.50 / slice or about $18.00 / pie.  And a really great deal is any three slices of pie as sampler for only $11.00.

Scratch made savory eats are also so reasonably priced as in a bowl of homemade soup for only $5.00 or a special this week of cheddar chive biscuit 'sandwich' with pimiento cheese, jalapeño pineapple jam, smoked honey ham, and  arugula and served with a cup of soup for only $8.95.

THE WHOLE PIES:  feed six generously and are big enough to cut into eight pieces for more restrained eaters or to share with others sipping vino at a local winery.  (Apple pie is a good pairing with some wines.  I kid you not.  And strangers become friends eating pie and drinking wine together.)   But I'm thinking for my birthday this year, when calories don't apply, I might just eat an entire Key Lime pie all by myself.  You think I'm kidding.

THE SPACE:  is light and bright and sparkling clean with décor that is both crisp, seafoam green and vanilla white and licorice black combined walls and ceiling details, and rustic with a driftwood / barnwood look trim at the order counter.

THE DRILL: is order at the counter to wait to take out, or after ordering for eat in take a seat and they will deliver to your table.  Tthe shop has seating at both high tables and standard height tables.  

WERE I THE QUEEN:  I'd wave my scepter and bid them move to a location closer to my neighborhood in Eagle so I could pop in more often.  Then again, were that true, I'd need to start a Go Fund Me account for a larger size wardrobe.

THIS N THAT:

1) Location is a bit out of the way, next to CHF resale consignment store and LaZBoy furniture, but that has advantages too in that there is a parking lot with ample parking.

2) Accessibility is good with ADA parking in the lot and an access ramp alongside the stairs to this elevated location.  Standard height table seating available.  Ample floor space. 

3) I don't now if they have a loo, in neither visit was I in need of asking.

4) Closed Sunday and Monday.', 'I can be pretty fastidious when it comes to restaurants & desserts worth suggesting to friends. Combine that with the fact that you can count on one hand the number of good places to get a decent pie in the Boise valley area, (That isn't another boring production-line pumpkin pie from Costco) I was pleased to hear the Boise Pie Co. had just opened up (10/31) on Orchard street & they had a variety of pies to choose from just in time for Thanksgiving.

Now, as any good husband or boyfriend knows, when your wife or girlfriend is having one of those weeks..and has been dropping hints that's she's been craving a slice of her favorite type of pie, (in this case Apple)...a smart man will search high and low to find her favorite pie & surprise her with it - earning some points along the way.  Enter the Boise Pie Company!  

Staff & Store
When I called and spoke to Terrance on the phone about what they had, he was very polite and professional and was patient with me asking questions about their different deserts, and was able to tell me exactly what they had available, from Pumpkin Pies, to Pecan Pies, Chess Pie to Peanut Butter Pie, 3-Berry Pies, to Apple Pie and Key Lime Pie.

I arrived at the new store location which is on the left side of the La-Z-Boy Building on 1216 N. Orchard Street, and to the right of Idaho Camera. The store is clean & cozy and has a rustic, yet quaint southern style spin on soups, sandwiches and of course Pies! They display their pies inside a glass case of emotion because even though you can see them, trying to formulate complete sentences while deciding how many you want can cause internal trauma and confusion. The struggle is real.

I was happily greeted by Bridgette and Terrance who make the magic happen with each one of their hand-crafted pies, each of which have a unique pinch of Unicorn and fairy dust added to the recipe which makes them 10 times more addictive than crack. Bridgette was very friendly and personable, and you can tell has a passion for baking these pies and desserts. She effortlessly explained the different key ingredients in each of the pies, making each one more difficult to choose from the last.

There are a few tables if you want to stop in for lunch or need a dessert to get you through the day or simply need a table to lie down on after your pie-educed food coma sets-in. They sell their branded thermos, T-shirts, hats & items in the store too. I suggested they sell a fake moustache and sunglass kit for when you are walking out of there with 7 pies and see your neighbor Betty from the PTA committee & want to make sure she doesn't recognize and secretly judge you. The parking lot has plenty of room, which is great if you go and unexpectedly eat a full pie by yourself and need to sleep it off in your car in the lot. The store is also in a great location if you need to grab a pie and hop on the freeway on your way to meet and try to impress your new girlfriends mother as something you just whipped up and try to pass off as your own. (psst...It won't work)

The PIES!
I wasn't sure what to expect when I got to the store, but I was assured by Bridgette that I could take my time deciding, but they wouldn't allow camp-outs inside the store as I suggested.  After I carefully compared my notes between each pie, and after finally being told I was being cut-off for what I assumed was endless samples, I had to make my decision! Ok, they didn't really give out endless samples, I made that part up...and I already knew what my girlfriend wanted, which was one of their Apple pies, but my point is the decision was still difficult! So it was at that moment as she was boxing up this Apple Pie which looked like it was sent from Heaven, that I made the horrible mistake of telling her my favorite pie was actually Key Lime pie. No sooner had the words left my mouth that I realized the gravity of my mistake, as Bridgette smiled & said "Actually, I just took a Key Lime pie out of the oven in the back!"  All I could do was blankly stare for what felt like an eternity as my brain scrambled to find the "Maybe next time" phrase... I felt like that kid Ralphie from the movie "Christmas Story" when he yelled.. "Ohh Fuddggee".  And like him, there was no turning back for me. I was doomed. Before I knew it, and after hearing that Key Lime Pie was one of Bridgette's specialties, having the Lime Juice specially imported from miniature baby limes in Florida, I just blurted out the words "YEAH I'LL TAKE THAT ONE TOO!"  without hesitation.  It was like she KNEW it was my weakness, and I was powerless against the Key Lime Pie.

I'm out of room on this review, but in closing, I will tell you these pies were hands down some of the best I've ever had. And the Key Lime Pie you HAVE to taste to believe. Especially with their homemade whip crème. To quote my girl the next day at lunch via text "This pie is Freaking amazing!" Trust me when I say just go and get one. I'm already ordering more for Thanksgiving!']

name: Taste Asian Fusion Bistro
categories_raw: Asian Fusion, Cocktail Bars, Bars, Restaurants, Nightlife
top_reviews:
['When the babies are away, mama will play! Or at least, eat alone. In sweet, sweet silence. 

I had a night off so I used my trusty Yelp app to search "foodie" and "new" and I got turned on to Taste Asian Fusion. I read a couple reviews, looked at the stunning photos and off I went on a Wednesday!

Overall, my experience was nice. The staff was extremely quick and I was seated where I wanted and given menus. I don't normally order fancy pants drinks, but the pictures just looked so darn pretty. So I ordered a "Spring Rain" Saketini. I definitely could only drink one as it was a bit on the sweeter side. But it had a hint of sour and that refreshing pink color made it so fun. 

I started with the Gyoza. Delicious! The potsticker was pan seared and moderately crisp. The inside was moist and full of flavor. I like a really crisp potsticker, so I would make a few changes. They served it on top of some delicious sweet chili sauce, but it made the Gyoza a bit stoggy. I'd serve that on the side, or nestle the Gyoza on top of some garnish. They also included some very thinly shredded carrots. These tasted nice, but again, a bit soggy. Maybe they could have fried them and added on top? Or maybe some crushed peanuts would have been nice. I was just missing some crunch. 

I finished my meal with the pho. This was pretty disappointing. I'm used to pho that is absolutely bursting with flavor and has that DEEP bone broth goodness. I needed to add quite a bit of hot sauce and (I think) hoisin sauce to pump up the flavor. The beef slices were pretty tough and the meatballs were not my favorite. They had a really tight texture...almost like a boiled sausage. The noodles were alright but not amazing. I should have asked for a recommendation on my entree. I won't be getting that again. 

I don't know how much this is Asian "Fusion" as it is more just a varied menu with different Asian food options. There were Chinese, Thai, Vietnamese and Indian foods represented on the menu. But as far as I could tell, none of those foods were "fused" together. 

Overall, it was a welcomed dining experience. A few modifications and I think this place could be 5 star.', 'We went for dinner tonight, Sat night. This is the first restaurant I have been to in the Treasure Valley with Malaysian flavors. We chose to eat at the bar, which has a nice ambiance, though we suggested they add a TV for sports. We started with the Shu Mai appetizer and if you ever tried to have dim sum here, you know its frozen at other places. This is made from scratch. For dinner we shared their take on Mussaman Beef, which was a deconstructed version using a giant short rib over a bed of carrots, potato, onion and peanut curry sauce. We also had pork lovers dish and the pork belly was En Pointe, though i think next time I would get a dish that was only pork belly. The dessert was a warm butter cake with (mango ?) sauce ice cream.  They do not have a liquor license (yet), but they make mixed drinks using Sake and they have beer and wine. The drink I chose had sake, berry syrup, seltzer and was garnished with berries and rosemary, recommended by the bartender. It was light, sweet and refreshing. This is a new restaurant and since they are still developing their menu it is not posted online. While we were there, a couple came in, looked at the menu and walked out. This saddens me but also I realize that these are dishes that people here are unfamiliar with. So, I guess this review is mostly for the people commenting on Facebook foodie pages about not having "real" Asian food in treasure valley (as compared to California, etc) but also for people who want to experience something new. These dishes will not continue to be offered if no market exists for them here. So I implore you foodies to try it out! Ensure that the market for food like this exists here!  And who knows, someday we could have a Oaxacan restaurant or a Mexican restaurant that serves Enoconcado with slow cooked chicken and not chewy freezer burned disgustingness covered in sauce, but I digress....And, while I am at it, I would like to make some suggestions to the owner of Taste for some other dishes I have been missing. How about some Nasi Lemak with Sambal Prawns, Beef Rangoon or Roti Pratha with Curry sauce as an appetizer? I wish you the best of luck and I hope you will be able to continue to offer dishes unique to this valley.', "This place is great! I ordered the generals chicken.  It was tasty but I think I should have ordered something else.  The chicken was deep fried and the sauce was really strong! Once I mixed the sauce in good, it was delicious. But I'm sure I want to come back and try something else that isn't deep fried.  The place is really nice.  Classy and cute.  The staff was friendly.  Price was reasonable.  I'll be back for sure. :)"]

name: Modern Hotel
categories_raw: Local Flavor, Travel Services, Breakfast & Brunch, Wine Bars, Cocktail Bars, Event Planning & Services, Nightlife, Hotels & Travel, Restaurants, American (New), Hotels, Vacation Rentals, Bars
categories: ['local flavor', 'travel services', 'breakfast & brunch', 'wine bars', 'cocktail bars', 'event planning & services', 'nightlife', 'hotels & travel', 'restaurants', 'american (new)', 'hotels', 'vacation rentals', 'bars']
top_reviews:
['Re-imagined from a former TraveLodge and located in Boise's Linen District, the Modern property is both mid-century modern hotel and a gem of a bar and restaurant serving dinner nightly and weekend brunch.  The restaurant reviews were originally posted on the Modern Hotel Yelp page but in June 2019 looks like owners set up a separate Yelp page for the Modern Bar and Restaurant.  Among my hubby's and my top 3 favorites of all eateries in Boise and after umpteen visits over the last 6 years we easily opine 5 stars for it - see review posted at that Yelp page - https://www.yelp.com/biz/modern-bar-and-restaurant-boise-3.

But we stay-cationed at the Modern Hotel with a 'one time is enough' experience.  I imagine that had as much to do with our demographic as with the hotel because the Modern Hotel consistently wins "Best of Boise" ratings from a local alternative newspaper in a yearly contest and gets high mention in travel publications.  So this is likely one of those issues where "it's not you, it's me" for relationship fit.  We are in the "Boomer" demographic - but clearly adventurous enough to appreciate the Modern Bar and Restaurant as regular diners and imbibers there, - and the hotel may better suit a younger age group.

In fact, when we shared with neighbors of about our age who are more hip and well traveled than we that we were planning 'staycation' at the Modern they urged us to reconsider based on their disappointing experience. "We shoulda listened to you!", I messaged her early on the evening of our stay.

So I share here for setting expectations.  Different strokes for different folks.  There is much to commend the Modern Hotel but also things that might not work so well.  An out of state traveler-guest who struck up a conversation with me in the parking lot and who was about my age said he and his wife were surprised to find this hotel that was highly touted by a college age relative to be so not a fit for them.  But, he said, "It's a hell of a good restaurant here - what a find!"  Yes, indeed.  

LOCATION:  The Linen District is far enough from downtown to be out of the chaos but close enough to provide easy access to everything.   Fun Basque wine bar and eatery Txikiteo, same owners as this, is just a couple of blocks walk away.  But there is a goodly amount of noise in the rooms, either from the nighttime 'hot-rod cruising' or from the revelers on the bar patio in the courtyard some of the rooms face.  For some that is no worries.  For others, now you know.  The hotel provides ear plugs on request.

PROPERTY:  Two stores, no elevator.  Some first floor rooms can be accessed from hall and from outside door.  Many rooms accessed only via outside door.  Nice exterior patio with tables for hotel and restaurant guests.  There is a small parking lot in front which is a good thing.  

ROOMS:  Comfy beds but the low slung chair in the room is not the easiest to get in and out of for guests of a certain age.  If you're planning on staying more than overnight the closet space is uber-limited - a 'hang 'em horizantal' cabinet for clothes.  Large desk-top with TV above it.  Wi-fi was not working for sign in and we had to go to the front desk for a work around. (See Service)  Walls are thin, as the saying goes, and your neighbors can be heard. 

BATHS: Spacious step-in doorless shower with two heads and a small window thru which one can gaze into the room or vice versa.  I imagine all that is much fun for some but our issues with the bathroom were practical functional ones:  the tiny pedestal sink lacked any counter space, the door into the bathroom from the bedroom was only about 23" clear width (I'm size 2, my hubby is 32 waist - not big people but this 'skinny door' felt just odd) and had obscure glass through which one could see with the light on in the loo and the commode was placed directly along the inside of wall that paralleled the bed so...  We've been married nearly 40 years but for a couple newer in acquaintance this might not be such a 'romantic' set up.  

EXTRAS:  Free continental breakfast Mon - Fri for hotel guests.  Not on Sat & Sun given brunch is served 8 - 2.  (Highly recommend the unique brunch!)  We didn't know free breakfast wasn't served on Saturday until after check in on Friday night when a server in the restaurant at dinner told us.  Now you know too.

SERVICE:  The young woman who helped us book our staycation night was so helpful.  In the dozens of times we've been through the hotel lobby on our way to or from the restaurant, always friendly folks.   Alas, on the night of our visit when we couldn't connect to wi-fi and had to go the lobby where the guy on duty had to use an employee password on our phones to make wi-fi work, he was in constipated service mode showing his frustration on that issue and answering a question we asked about the hotel.  Everyone can have a bad day.

ACCESSIBILITY:  ADA parking in lot.  Level in at lobby.  Didn't check for ADA rooms.', "The Modern Bar & Restaurant - four stars.
The Modern Hotel - three stars.

Ok, the hotel:

You can put lipstick on a pig, but it's still a pig. This hotel (a former Motel 6) is still a concrete Motel 6 dressed up. The bed was comfy, as were the pillows, so price depending, this is a great deal. I believe they offer complimentary cruiser bikes and downtown Boise is literally a 5-7 minute walk, so location wise it's also on point.

But, I found the rooms sad. No art adorned walls, digital television with limited channels, not a lot of natural light and if I did decide to leave the curtains open, the entire street would see me. Walls were thin, I could hear pretty much any noise outside, including the maids vacuuming at 9am and the doors didn't close well, but the internet was strong.

The complimentary breakfast highlight was the coffee and fresh juice. Food wise it was also a little sad: Chobani yogurt and meh looking bagels with butter, a block of cream cheese or jam. Add some fresh fruit into the mix and then we'd be talking.
____________________

The restaurant was good, albeit a tad bit over priced. Those corn fritters, tho. They were almost like corn beignets. So good, that we had them two nights in a row. My dining companion enjoyed her gnocchi and the lamb kofta was good, but again the price didn't quite live up to the hype. Drinks were nice and strong and a fairly local and inexpensive beer list.

Overall, not a bad option in Boise especially when I'm not aware of the competition. I would stay here again if options were limited.", 'Reading "hipster hotspot" descriptions in media coverage for The Modern, even terms like "swanky", I wondered if my husband and I might not be welcome.  We are for sure not that demographic.  But we are food centric travelers, The Modern was his discovery in planning a Boise relocation tripe was insistent we give it a go based on food reviews which sounded like just the fit for us.  Good thing I said OK!   Because the best food enjoyed during a week in Boise came from The Modern's tiny kitchen built into one of the former guest rooms of the Hotel which is a re-imagined Travel Lodge.  (That alone suggests "non-swanky", don't you think?)  We found "all people are welcome" vibe, friendly service, inventive cocktails, delicious food and good value.  We loved it.

This is an equally friendly gathering place as happy hour for grown ups of all ages, including those of us whose 50's are in the rear view mirror as well as those who are just started on the road of their 20's. Maybe I'd have felt less intimated going in if I'd checked the Modern's website first for what the owners have to say.  I share their comments below in the event it helps others of the "not so hipster" set go in the door.  Noli timere, Boomers! 

"...we envisioned a grown up space with great cocktails...friendly but stylish sort of establishment with knowledgeable bartenders, new music and good wine...small and intimate...Our kitchen provides our guests with simple, elegant bar food...showcase produce and meats grown by local farmers and ranchers...When the weather is fine...guests socialize on our outdoor patio and listen to local music while enjoying the best food and drink Boise has to offer."

Here is what you'll have a chance to enjoy:

MENU / FOOD:  Given the former Travel Lodge origination, we surmise the Bar (adjacent to the Hotel's registration office) may have once been meeting room in a former life.  As our server went in and out the exterior door to return with food we learned the kitchen was built into one of the former ground floor guest rooms. 

The chef, a California Culinary Academy graduate, has designed a small and creative menu ranging from appetizers through entrees and dessert (in price range of roughly $5 - $15) using seasonal and  locally sourced ingredients.  Local sources are printed on the menu and that is something my hubby and I appreciate as farm-to-fork focused eaters. 

We started with chile spiced nuts ($5) to share with cocktails.  With our wine order, we moved to lamb meatballs in red wine demiglace from the appetizer menu ($10); three nice sized meatballs nestled in the most delicious sauce came with crostini to sop up every drop.  We also shared an entree of tender gnocchi with fresh chard, cherry tomatoes and garlic ($13).  There is finesse in the preparation of each dish. 

There are options here for vegetarians as well as omnivores.

SERVICE: Our server knew the menu to answer our questions, provided share plates with our orders and paced the plates perfectly to allow us to linger as we wanted to do but not to have to wait.   So nicely done. 

LIBATIONS:  Happy hour here, 4p tp 7p, is a great deal with a couple of the inventive house specialty cocktails only six bucks during that time and a buck off wine.  

I started with a Sanlucar cocktail ($6) which combined tequila, grapefruit juice and Aperol and also had added a bit of salt to balance.  Served up in a coupe glass it was just a bit bitter, as anticipated from the ingredients, and a fun choice.  My husband chose a Manhattan-like specialty called Boulevardier ($6) of rye, sweet vermouth and campari.   Served in a highball glass with a single large "rock" of ice to avoid watering down the cocktail.   

Cocktails were moderate in size, that is a good thing, to leave us capacity for vino.  The wine list by the glass was small but thoughtfully crafted and fairly priced.  With our food I had a prosecco ($6) and he chose an Italian red ($6.50).  Both pours were generous. 

VALUE:  Total @ $53 before tax, for a couple of hours of enjoying the space and friendly service along with cocktails, wine and food for two.  A great value. 

THIS N THAT:

1) PARKING:  Lot is small and I couldn't identify where overflow parking might go.

2) ACCESSIBILITY:  Level in and throughout, although tightly spaced tables on patio may make entry there near impossible for wheelchair users. (Like me on this visit.)  Accessible parking in the lot.  High perch seating only at bar with standard height tables and chairs adjacent. 

3) OUTSIDE SEATING:  Available on a patio one travels to get from the parking lot to the Bar entry,  Too much wind and too many (many many) flies on the September evening of our visit for us to choose this.  But we noticed others braving both those things to sit outdoors.']

name: Guido's Original New York Style Pizza
categories_raw: Pizza, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['The sign posted at the order counter is Boise polite. It goes something like this: 

"Help us help you.  Please refrain from talking on your cell phone while placing your order here."

In a New York (or New Jersey) pizzeria it might read something like this:

"YO! Are YOU talkin' to ME? Put down the @*#$% phone." 

Use your imagination to fill in the @*#$%. 

I'm with them on that. Pet peeve to have people carry on a phone conversation when placing an order like this. Those nice guys behind the counter deserve the respect of full attention.

I digress.

Aside from the polite sign, the rest here is all New Yawk pizzeria. My Italian-American-Brooklyn-Born-And-Raised hubby approved. A slice is foldable to eat it; his true test of authentic New York pizza. Good crust, which is truly the thing for pizza, and just enough but not too much sauce and cheese to cover it up. Not to mention a big shaker of pepperoncino on the counter. 

The ambiance is just right; red-white-green floors (quick, what are the colors of the Italian flag) and New York photos and sports memorabilia on the walls (although too much Mets and not enough Yankees in my hubby's not so humble baseball opinion), linoleum tables and basic chairs. Most important, the aroma is all pizza when you walk in the door.

Ordering is easy, by the slice ($2.50 or less) from several pies they have at the counter, or a whole pizza. The latter comes in two sizes (18" and 20") and in three "bases", Cheese (starting at $13), Cheese and Basil (starting at $13.50) and White (starting at $14). Toppings are a buck each and range from traditional (think peppers and onions) to those that make my husband cringe (think Canadian bacon and pineapple). 

For my two bits, the best is Cheese and Basil, which is pretty perfect by itself, or with fresh tomatoes added for a quasi Margherite. 

They also have salads, garlic bread and stromboli. But why would you when the pizza is so darned good?

To go orders happily filled.

No delivery.

THIS N THAT:

1) PARKING: Private lot.

2) ACCESSIBILITY: Accessible parking in lot. Level in through door. Mostly standard table height seating.

3) NEIGHBORS: An outpost of Blue Sky Bagels is in the same strip mall. If you're looking for bagels for breakfast (assuming you run out of pizza which is perfect breakfast food), that is a good place to pick them up. Springhill Suites is visible down the block. If you're staying there (as we have), Guido's is a very good option for a pie to go for the room.', "I realize everyone's style of pizza is different so take this review with a grain of salt.  I really like NY Pizza in which you need to fold it over to eat it.  I love the fact that you can order a slice of pizza or order a whole fresh pie.  I am really picky about having hot fresh pizza so if you are like me, I recommend ordering a new pizza from scratch or getting your reheated slice really well done.  It is as close as you can get to a fresh pizza by asking them to cook it longer in the oven for you.  They have garlic salt shakers and it actually makes the pizza taste great, just my opinion.  I've been to this one and their downtown location, both are really good.", 'Sadly, Guido's has a falling star...

...because there's New York style thin crust pizza (defined as: crisp on the bottom with about a 1/8th an inch thickness of dough plus a layer of cheese and sauce that's not caked on but at least identifiable as a layer) and then there's "I can practically see right through this!" Unfortunately, I experienced the latter on my latest visit to Guido's. And I kid you not! There were several slices that were literally (proper use of the word, "literally," by the way) translucent. 

Furthermore, I think that the cheese, sauce, and toppings on my pie were afraid that they might fall off, because they stayed at least 3 inches away from the edge, all around.

Look, I don't know if this is an attempt to skimp for the sake of saving money from a business owner's perspective or if the new kid just wasn't properly trained on how to make a pie.

Either way, if you're a regular at Guido's, and you're reading this, please let me know if you think this was just an off night or if you've been experiencing the same issues.']

name: Kyoto Japanese Steak House
categories_raw: Restaurants, Specialty Food, Ethnic Food, Japanese, Food, Steakhouses
top_reviews:
['Pretty good hibachi place on a busy street not far from downtown. We went with a very large group so we made reservation which was a good idea. They had a dining area that was on a platform that was able to accommodate our group. This is a hibachi place so the seats are wrapped around a grill where your food is cooked in front of you. 
Our cook was great and all of these hibachi places are similar to a bennihanas. So the good ones try to joke around a bit and kind of make it a show too. Ours was good and did that. 
The food was very good and it was a great place to spend an evening.', "I arranged a Sushi-Outing UYE here on a Tuesday night.  Kyoto was lovely to work with.  They happily took our reservations, even though, at first, I didn't have a fixed number for them.  I had initially made reservations for 6 but warned it could grow to 12.  I called back the day before to say it looked like we'd be closer to 12 than 6.  And, good thing I did because we ended up with 12 (possibly 13?) attendees.  Kyoto was friendly and helpful throughout the reservation process and not the least bit impatient with the changing numbers.  I arrived early to make sure everything was set.   Kyoto had a plan in place and were completely prepared for our arrival.  Having planned several group outings in the past, I can say restaurants are not always so on the ball.  Kyoto really deserves recognition for having been so thoughtfully prepared for our arrival.

Now, part of my motivation for planning the UYE (other than obviously the desire to meet all the fabulous yelpers!) was to get a little more sushi-proficient.  My main dining companion doesn't care for sushi and so it has just never really made it on my dining out rotation.  Boise yelpers to the rescue!  All that attended were very generous with their wealth of sushi knowledge.

So, having said that, I am certainly not a sushi expert.  I did try some of the Co-op's offerings leading up to our visit here, as well as Trader Joe's, and a couple bites at Mai Thai.  I will say this:  Of all the sushi I've tried, Kyoto's was the best.  We began with Miso soup, which was scrumptious.  Boise Yelper Kim R., then shared her octopus salad with us.  I have never tried octopus salad before and was completely surprised at it's deliciousness.  I guess I was expecting it to be kind of chewy--but it was not in the least.  Fellow yelper, Shelle M and I, each ordered a roll and then shared with each other so that we could both try more than one roll.  I ordered the Austin roll and she the Ernie (I think?).  Both were out of this world.  They were both ample and seriously delish.  I also tried a bite of hokkigai nigiri which was amazing (another one I was a little tentative about but needn't have been!).  And, some sort of egg that was the star of the show for me--sweet, light, and lovely.

The service was a little spotty as we did have a snafu with on one of the checks (WAY overcharged).  The server didn't budge on the amount while we were there.  But, I was happy to learn that management DID make it right and refund her the amount she was overcharged.  Some in our party ordered hot food and Ben, our chef, was entertaining on the grill.  He put on quite a show and was funny to boot.  

Overall, great sushi, and a great time with fellow yelpers!  I will definitely be back!  I may even get my main dining companion to give sushi another try at Kyoto!  They may just convert him to a sushi enthusiast!  Fingers crossed!

Get to it!", 'Ok, let's set something straight right now, a 5-star restaurant is something like The Top of the Mark in San Francisco or something like that. This is NOT a 5-star despite what "Ronnie" wants you to believe. Maybe "Ronnie" is an Idaho native and one thing's for sure, their standards are *very* low.
OK about the restaurant: This place is VERY popular with the local crowd, probably because of the hibachi show (Think Benihana). I believe the joint used to be a Shakey's as can be seen carved into the original concrete. The interior, if you look closely, is all worn and beat up with massive water stains in the ceiling tiles especially over the sushi bar. (a *tiny* sushi bar) The main tepanyaki (flat grill and show) prepared food is decent and well priced during lunch. (rice and meats) The side dishes fall well below the mark. Salad is western style w/croutons, small and not very tasty. They also serve a blah onion soup, probably catering to western tastes, but not very Japanese. Prices go up by around 50% at dinner so be prepared to get socked.
The sushi side of things was a huge disappointment. The owner was not there, instead his wife was doing the slicing and dicing. Here they give you low quality miso soup. Our sushi was the biggest let-down. We got very tiny, paper thin (or shoji-thin!) pieces, the kind you'd expect at the $1.00 sushi boat place. Except these cost $4.00! That could only be categorized as a rip-off in my book. The fish was OK, and they did have a tasty No. 9 Kyoto roll, (shrimp, avocado, tobiko) but that didn't make up for their stingy portions. Also, they didn't serve any tea, guess you gotta ask for it or pay for it. If you want the grill tepanyaki show, a better place to go might be Ichiban. The best sushi place in town still remains Shige's.']

name: Highlands Hollow Brewhouse
categories_raw: Brewpubs, Restaurants, Sandwiches, American (Traditional), American (New), Food, Breweries
top_reviews:
["If I could give this place 10 stars, I would.
This is my boyfriend & my FAVORITE place to eat and we recommend it to everyone. We are big suckers for their burgers and especially their philly cheese steaks, YUM. The last time we were there the owner stepped in when they were busy and personally took care of us and was serving and busing just like his employees, that's always nice to see. My boyfriend is a big beer drinker, he gets this beer that has hints of banana in it with the name of monkey-something. Sounds weird, but he can't get enough. I love the atmosphere, very cozy and home-y. My favorite part is the food tastes like home cooking, and that's hard to find around Boise. Also it's always a good sign that whenever we would go almost all the tables are full! That means they're doing something right! I'll return here time and time again. Definitely one of my favorite places in Boise.", "One of THEE best breweries im boise and its been around forever which makes it even better. They have a solid list of base line beers but also rotate in special beers. If you're in boise and are looking for something hidden and off the beaten path (seems like only skiiers know about this place) then check this place out.  The food is also awesome and the service is quick, the temp and atmosphere is just as great. Highly recommended!", "This was formerly Harrison Hollow. I've eaten here a few times before they changed their name. I haven't been here since then, but their menu still looks the same. 

They deserve five gleaming stars just for their Mess-O-Chops, which is thinly sliced marinated pork chops, charbroiled and served on a large bed of hand cut fries and streaked with molasses. This glorious, gluttonous pile of meat and potatoes is a perfect accompaniment to one of their freshly brewed ales. Great place to get your grub on!"]

name: Old Idaho Penitentiary
categories_raw: Historical Tours, Hotels & Travel, Tours, Arts & Entertainment, Landmarks & Historical Buildings, Public Services & Government, Museums
categories: ['historical tours', 'hotels & travel', 'tours', 'arts & entertainment', 'landmarks & historical buildings', 'public services & government', 'museums']
top_reviews:
["After reading the background on the former penitentiary, and being someone who enjoys history, I really wanted to visit this place for a tour of this facility which was in service for 101 years.  

The guide (I wish I could remembered his name, he was a local teacher) for our tour was excellent, extremely knowledgeable, well versed, and had the perfect personality to conduct a tour. 

The place gave me a slightly uneasy eerie feeling as our guide wove the story of this place, the inmates, guards and wardens who served here over the years. Detailed stories about a resident cat, executions, riots, fires, and a couple of unscrupulous wardens over the years added to the intrigue. 

When this prison closed in 1973 there were still  several cells without a toilet, many prisoners were still using a bucket as a bathroom when it closed. 

In summary I'm really glad we took this tour, as it did not disappoint. I found it extremely interesting, and well worth a stop. Additionally at certain times of the year they offer overnight tours which would add to the experience, I hope to try it some time in the future.", "A hundred years ago, it started off as a jail for males only, then had to make an adjustment as a final count of 222 debauched women eventually came into the picture. A complex of buildings made of architectually interesting carvings and grey sandstone walls are reminders of the stark difference in jail life of the 1800 and 1900's to today's quarters.  Not that I would know....thankfully.

You can take a guided tour, or simply walk the grounds at your own pace, reading the signs along the way.  The best place to start is with the short historical video that runs about every 20 minutes in the main building.  The main entry has a few rooms staged to see what prison life was like from both viewpoints (prisoner and enforcer), and a roomful of artifacts in large glass cases.

The air feels thick as you pass through many areas.  Imagine the associations to crime and violence and inhumane, the depressing punishments given (sometimes too harsh for the crime committed). There is still the evidence of the raging flames that licked the cafeteria and kitchen building as a result of the riot of 1973 that ultimately decided the fate of this spector of a facility.  That entire grey stone building is now nothing more than a roofless, hollow shell with a visible depressing underground network of tiny rooms below the main floor that were used for food prep, storage, and who knows what. 

One old, still intact building is devoted solely to the history of tattoos and their significance to prison life. Large photos of notable inmates and their stories are posted on the walls. Quite fascinating.

Another building is set aside for a vast gun collection, old military weaponry and displays to depict life in the trenches of WWI. 

The trap doors covering holes in the ground and narrow dark cells used as tortuous solitary confinement chambers can be seen as you wander the grounds.  Some buildings that were open for viewing include the creepy, multi-leveled cell blocks for the masses, with rusty doors and peeling institutional paint. I cannot imagine enduring the extreme weather conditions and lack of significant protection.

The pathways are frequently cracked, uneven, and difficult to maneuver for those with physical disabilities, yet in contrast, some of the grounds have been cheerfully landscaped with green grass and flowers, a juxtaposition of the underlying morose tone.

Playing with your imagination, it is haunted in my opinion.  It took a hundred years until it finally closed its doors to this chapter in Idaho history.  Interesting place to visit.
