But I sure wouldn't want to live there.", 'FUN! This place is so interesting and unique. Lots of history and individual stories about inmates. Its crazy to see how the prison system has changed in less than 100 years.

Note: be sure you go on a day they offer tours, you get so much more history and interesting facts not listed on the pamphlets.']

name: Tangos Empanadas
categories_raw: Desserts, Sandwiches, Fast Food, Argentine, Food, Empanadas, Food Trucks, Restaurants, Latin American
top_reviews:
['Five words: I will double in size. 

Do you empanada?~
A fellow Yelper recently posted a review about this place so I finally caved after living in Idaho for over 10 years. I put my biggest hoop earrings on and headed over with Indy for the first time. Tango's does not look like much. It's a small unimpressive building with various flags from Latin American countries draped like curtains at the windows. I love places like this, it doesn't need to be fancy and you know it's going to be good. 

Fact: You already love empanadas~
Empanadas are basically like samosas, sambusas, pierogis, piroshkis, hand pies, or hot pockets. I've eaten all of those, they all have the same concept, different fillings and variations of flaky crust. It's comfort food and almost every country/culture has something similar. There are many empanadas to choose from, vegetarian, meat, breakfast, dessert, cheesy, there is something for everyone.

When you empanada, you're family~
You order at the counter and they call your number when your food is ready. Every single person who walks in the door is treated as family. Not like family, as family. It's a cultural thing, and I felt that. One step through the door and I thought "I'm home. I'm finally home."

Can't go wrong~
Indy and I ordered the Chinese (basically like spring roll type filling), the Salteña (ground beef, potatoes, onions, eggs), and of course for dessert the Cocco (dulce de leche with coconut). They were all fantastic and all the ingredients were correctly proportioned. The prices are affordable, around 2.50-3.00 per empanada. 

You can find me in stretchy pants from now on~
Tango's is an instant favorite. I am canceling my gym membership,  donating my skinny jeans, and kissing my svelte figure goodbye. I've accepted my fate. Tango's is going to make me curvy and I'm not even mad about it. Life is short. 

Indigo & I give Tango's all the stars and extra points for noticing our matching leopard coats.', "I have to admit that the only empanadas I've ever tasted are the ones that my Filipina aunt would share during family parties, and the ones that I made a few years back courtesy of Blue Apron. Both were delicious.

But let me tell you, the empanadas from Tango's Subs and Empanadas are at a different level. Located on Morris Hill in Boise, this gem serves some of the heartiest empanadas that you will ever get to taste. I ordered gaucho (the original empanada made of ground beef, onions, bell peppers, eggs, and green olives) and gardel (shredded chicken in a light marinara sauce), with fries and soda. Gaucho was surprisingly sweet but I loved it. Gardel was tasty too. And each was only $2.50!

The empanadas look big but they're airy. However, I think the meat-to-dough ratio is just perfect. Tango's Subs and Empanadas is a solid four stars. Nothing extraordinary with service on my first visit, so I'll keep it at four stars for now.

Will I come back? Absolutely! Very curious about trying the other flavors!", 'Tango's is a little hole in the wall on Orchard.  I wouldn't have looked twice if it wasn't for the yelp reviews (yay yelpers) and some word of mouth by friends.  And, thank God I did.  This place is not only so totally delicious that you'll find yourself gazing at your empanada whispering, where have you been all my life...but hands down the best service I've received in all of Boise.  We were greeted upon entrance by one of the owners (Monica?  I think) and when we told her that our seven-year-old had never had an empanada--she immediately showed him what one looked like (she actually had a clay/plaster empanada for this very situation) and told him the most popular fillings for children.  This was awesome and completely demystified what had a moment before been "weird food" to my son.  I can't say enough about the service--she was so very sweet to us.  

I ordered their Fugazza empanada, which was filled sautéed onions, mozzarella, and spices.  It was heady with herbs and flavor.  My dining companion ordered the Moleh, which was chicken in sweet sauce (chocolate, peanuts, and various chilies) and was pleased, though said the flavor was a bit unusual and wouldn't be for everyone (I didn't dig it).  My seven-year-old got the Hawaiian, which was the usual pineapple, ham, and mozzarella.  He was delighted.  The prices were incredible.  $2.25 per empanada.  We each had one, which was enough for me, but my dining companion could have eaten two plus dessert. 

We didn't partake in the dessert empanadas as we had already promised the little guy fro-yo.  However, we have every intention of doing so!  And, once we do, I will definitely update.']

name: Goodwood Barbecue Restaurant
categories_raw: Nightlife, Salad, Cocktail Bars, Bars, American (Traditional), Barbeque, Restaurants, Burgers
top_reviews:
['A few months ago Goodwood advertised on Boise's Craig's List for service staff.  Applicants must, they said, be "rock stars" for customer service with at least a year in a high volume restaurant.  Must have been one of the "rock star" hires who served us during our first visit to Goodwood because she did a stellar job from the moment she introduced herself as trainee and the staff member who accompaned her for supervision.

Which is the long way of saying that among many good things at Goodwood we enjoyed on our first try here, at the top of the list was simply splendid service.  Along with the wood smoke aroma enticing us through the sparkling clean lobby to the friendly host to the seating in the "all people are welcome here" space to the good food at fair prices, our expectations were exceeded. 

BACKSTORY: Started as a single restaurant in about 1999 by a couple of friends, Goodwood now is small chain with Boise, Meridian and Utah locations. 

VIBE: Sparkling clean everywhere you look.  Even the barbecue sauce bottles on each table glisten.  

You will find a roll of paper towels on each table, just in case you need more than the hefty black cloth napkin at each place setting.  

Walls are sort of cumin red on some walls and oregano green on others.  Booth seating was very comfy.  An inviting space with lots of windows and  high ceilings with open duct work that is painted black.

We saw people of all ages, from toddlers to octogenarians and all walks of life and physical abilities.  All people are welcome here.

As much as I am not a Country Western music fan, it fit in perfectly here and was at the just right level to support conversation and conviviality and not compete with it.

MENU / FOOD : Starting with the important piece of information that this is an all scratch kitchen.  Everything is made here and made fresh, as our server told us.  Including the ranch dressing which I consider an abomination in commercial production.  Here, homemade as it should be, it was a delicious go with for our onion rings.

But I'm getting ahead of myself.  Because the second most important thing is save room for a house made dessert or take one with you!  

The menu is broad from appetizers (if trying  onion rings but stick to a half order...trust me) to salads to non bbq options like salmon and steak to the expected bbq and sides.  Prices run from $2.19 (sides) to $17.99 (prime rib). They have a lengthy list of sides and entrees and we  noted options that would make a vegetarian happy as well as some for gluten free dining.

We shared a half order of onion rings that came with yummy (seriously) fresh ranch dressing ($6.49), pulled pork plate that came with two sides ($10.49) and ordered two more sides ($2.19 each) for a total of macaroni and cheese, coleslaw, baked beans and potato salad.  Here I admit that when I go to a BBQ place I am really there for the sides.  I would order the beans and coleslaw again.

We finished with Key Lime pie to go.

LIBATIONS: When I go back I'm going to try one of their specialty cocktails, like the spiked lemonade, from the full bar.

VALUE: Total bill for all that food, no libations, for two with leftovers was only $26.35 before tax.  A great value.

SERVICE: Stellar.  This is a team service approach with friendly, efficient server 'in the lead' but teammates also run food, help clear table and so on.  We didn't feel hovered over but "poof" there was a server to do this or that, like remove used plates or fill water, before we needed them.  Hot food was served nice and hot, cold food was served perfectly cold reflecting great coordination between front of house and kitchen. 

THIS N THAT:

1) PARKING:  In large lot seems ample and for overflow there is an even larger lot just across the access road to the Homewood Suites.

2) ACCESSIBILITY:  Accessible (aka ADA) parking right outside the front door (maybe 4 spaces).  Level in and throughout.  Several standard height tables and chairs.  Also booths.  Loo is accessible too.

3) THE LOO:  Worth "a word".  It is as clean as all else.  And they have conveniently provided both wrapped mints and a pump bottle of mouthwash along with disposable cups at the sinks. I guess if you were on a hot date or going to an important business meeting, these could come in handy!

4) ROOM SERVICE ANYONE?:  When we visit Boise we typically stay at Homewood Suites.  We just learned about two weeks ago that Goodwood provides room service for the Homewood.  Another reason to choose the hotel!', "This will be a different review but I was extremely impress with the attention to detail.  
First the food was so darn good.  I loved it way too much.
Secondly, the staff was great and well trained.  The waitress we had was very friendly, helpful oh and super cute. haha.

The thing that impressed me the most was the attention to detail.  Our waitress was very mindful of the condition of our table.  3 males eating and making a big mess with napkins and bones etc.  She would come back periodically and remove our soiled napkins and say that we need to tidy it up so she doesn't get into trouble with her manager.  I also watched as another waitress clean and set up the table in front of us.  I have never seen anyone do this before, she used a flash light to clean above the table, under the table and the area around.  Really?  isn't the reason to keep a restaurant dark is so that the customers don't see the mess hidden on the carpets and under the tables.

I was sure to seek out the manager and let him know how much I appreciated the tight ship they ran.  Wow.  I will be sure to pay this place a visit next time I am in Boise.", "As soon as I walked towards this place from the parking lot, you are over taken by the wonderful smell of BBQ wafting out from thier kitchen. As you walk in the place it has a warm and inviting feel and we were greeted and seated right away. 

I had the St Louis style ribs and they did not disappoint​, they were as good as the intoxicating smells we noticed in the parking lot. The baked patato was excellent, as good as any I've ever had. Additionally I sampled the beef brisket, it too was amazing. I would have been very satisfied had I picked that for my meal. 

Our server was great, I wish I remembered her name. We received our food reasonably quick for this type of restaurant, and she was there everytime we needed anything. 

They also have a small bar in the corner, offering a nice selection of drinks. The bartender while I was here made the drinks nice and strong, making me an even bigger fan of Goodwood Barbecue.

I would definitely eat here again, and I wish they had a location closer to home."]

name: The Front Door
categories_raw: Bars, Pizza, Italian, Nightlife, Beer Bar, Restaurants, Cocktail Bars, Sandwiches
top_reviews:
["Loved.  Period.  The most memorable thing wasn't the pizza--which was delicious, but the service.  They were so nice! They were packed with lots of families--every table full.  Yummy Moscow Mules, yummy beer (great selection) and just flat out a lovely, experience.  Well done and cheers to our friends at The Front Door. See you again on our next trip!", 'This place has got major hype. Friends and co-workers everywhere were like "you gotta review the Front Door!" But then those same friends were like "you gotta review Flying Pie!" and Flying Pie was really mediocre. We didn't know what to expect going in. Honestly, we were more focused on making middle school jokes about eating at the Back Door.

This place has a 'rustic' feel. There's a big focus on the bar. Tom asked for a Roy Rogers and specified he wanted grenadine and not cherry syrup. The bartender responded with, "aren't grenadine and cherry syrup the same thing?" Tom got T R I G G E R E D. Nah just kidding, he was fine, but he's told me a few times how much he dislikes when bartenders think they're the same thing and they serve him a cherry coke.

Bartender was very nice by the way. He looked like a much sexier Thom Yorke.

We got a medium 16″ pizza. Half Boss and half Wise Guy. Boss was like a fancy pepperoni. Wise Guy, not to be confused with terrible pizza place of the same name, was a mix of arugula, red onion, sausage, and salami. Pizza took 15-20 minutes and cost $17.

-The Boss-
Very high quality ingredients. Pair that with a reasonable price and large pizza, and you get nice value. The dough is excellent. Like a mix of flatbread and New York. Tom and I were both reminded of Allegrezza's. Peps are meh. They do the fancy, thick pepperoni thing that Tom and I aren't a fan of. Most important is the cheese. After doing some more research, I found out one of their signature things is using Grana Padano. This really adds an extra something that makes it stand out.

-Wise Guy-
All the ingredients were solid and mixed well. Sausage and salami were tasty. Again, the thing that stood out most was the bread and the cheese. Can probably drop the red onions. It doesn't feel like the red onions add much but can potentially bother picky eaters.

-Verdict-
I guess the hype was real. This place knows how to make a solid pizza. I don't think it's the best pizza we have ever had but it's up there. I recommend this place to anyone who is downtown on a second date and wants to impress that significant someone with a real good piz.

5 slices out of 5', "This place has one of the best tap selections in Boise! It may not be large but its always eclectic and interesting. The pizza there is also really good. The place looks kind of like a standard hole in the wall pizza place but it is anything but. The pizza is creative and extremely tasty. I highly recommend the Enforcer if its your first time. Its also a great place to snag a good beer if you heading to the Reef for a live band or just for other food. They don't mind if you bring your beer upstairs (I think its the same owners)."]

name: NY Giant Pizza
categories_raw: Restaurants, American (Traditional), Pizza, Italian
top_reviews:
["First of all... Very friendly!  I mean very friendly!!  These are the type of guys you want to succeed in a small business.   They are proud of their product and it shows.  This is a great place to stop before or after a movie and get a slice or a whole pizza. The restaurant is a little small but is great for take out or delivery.  Now about the pizza. It's pretty darn good. And the guys will help do what ever you want not like a chain pizzeria.  For example we got a giant 28 inch pizza quarter pepperoni quarter cheese and half supreme.   And everyone loved it!  And yes I know I'm known for typos but the 28 inch was not one of them.  So I definitely will try them for delivery.", 'Review for Pizza Delivery

Free delivery (min $11) but tip your delivery guy!

NYGP Boise only has a Facebook page but Yelp doesn't allow that to be added.  
https://www.facebook.com/pages/NY-Giant-Pizza-_-Boise-Idaho/576582322404749

Hours are 11am-10pm, 7 days a week 

Menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ny-giant-pizza-boise-4?select=GDeNyBS6Kvw6gn4q3FpGgA#GDeNyBS6Kvw6gn4q3FpGgA



Square is used for credit card transactions; receipt texted for delivery.

I ordered a 14" Supreme ($12.99) - Pepperoni, sausage, canadian bacon, bell peppers, mushrooms, onions and black olives, to be delivered across the complex at the Spectrum Hampton Inn.

Delicious pizza with a thin crust with a good crunch.  Toppings were evenly distributed and there is very little edge so if you're the type that throws away crust, there is little to waste!  Also, slices were cut through nicely - it's annoying if it's cut halfway and you have to rip your slices and rip wrong into the neighboring slice.  

Expect around 40 mins+ for delivery even if you're nearby.  It's an operational hurdle that very few small local pizza joints can work around, unless everything's pre-made or if they can afford many spare drivers.

Boise was hit with some crazy freezing weather early this year (negative 9 degrees on Saturday?!) and I wasn't equipped to walk 0.4 miles, according to Google Maps, across the snow for food.   Instead of national chains for pizza delivery, I opted for local joints and found that the new NY Giant Pizza has locations in San Diego and seemed to be well-liked.

Called at 11am and the friendly guy repeated every number on my credit card aloud.  He said it would be a "couple of minutes" which I knew was impossible, but whatever.   At 11:12am, he called back to get my zipcode to complete the credit card transaction.  At 11:40am, the delivery guy called to say that he's outside my door.  He didn't know that payment had already been made and looked at the $3 tip money weird so I had to ask some awkward questions.

Overall, I enjoyed the hot delicious pizza and will order again.', 'This is the second time I've been here. I used Yelp's eat 24 to order both time. Both times the process was super simple. The service is great and the pizza is very good. It's a thin New York style, so if you're not used to that you may think it's gross, but it's not!  I posted a few pics of the 28" meat lovers (under $30.00!). I called to order one from Garbonzo's Pizza, but it was $60 for the same pizza! 
The location is directly across from the Edwards 22 and next to the Creperie Cafe (check in and get a free scoop of ice cream)! There is generally a 30 minute parking stop or two that you can get in and about pretty quickly. If you're going to get the big pizza make sure your trunk is empty! The pizza wasn't messy nor was it greasy. My daughter was able to use the lid of the pizza box with her barbies for a romantic New York dinner (see pic)! 
Thank you NY Giant pizza! Two times perfection-- makes a third time definite.']

name: Bent Nail Inspections
categories_raw: Home Services, Home Inspectors
top_reviews:
["Extremely thorough, professional, and reliable! They really set the bar high! I have now used Bent Nail Inspections for two of my homes, thanks to the recommendation of my wonderful realtor. The first time was back in 2018 when I bought my very first home, my pride, soon to become my very cherished rental property. Bent Nails went all out to make sure the sellers weren't hiding anything that was wrong. The home was newer so there wasn't much wrong, made it easy to flip through the pages of the report. 

I was even more impressed when we had them once more inspect another house we bought in 2020. First off, the inspect report was fat! So much information. It was an older home, there was a lot to point out and our inspector made sure to notate every last detail. He went as far as to notate every single crack in the Sheetrock, even chips on the toilet! I say that is quality service worth your buck. I would definitely use their services again when I buy my third property, heehee! I wish you could find great house inspectors like this in every city!", "We have used Bent Nail for several inspections already.
If you want to be absolutely sure about your home purchase, Kevin Reynolds is your guy. I would not hesitate to use Kevin again if I was looking to purchase another property. He was so thorough that our Realtor actually became irritated at his attention to detail! (which isn't saying much for the Realtor) At the end of the day though, he is working for you, and not the Agent, and he knows that. The best money we spent was with Bent Nail and prevented us from having to spend thousands more. In fact, the picture of the drainpipe going through a cut floor joist on their site was a deal we walked away from thanks to Kevin. The whole experience from scheduling, to the inspection, to the report and the follow up was first class. Keep up the good work guys!", "This is our second inspection with Bent Nail.  They did a fantastic job and we loved the video which allowed us see the findings and still go to work during the day.    Bent Nail does a very close inspection and we trust their findings.   Don't buy a home either old or brand new construction without an inspection and use Bent Nail to get the job done."]

name: Saint Lawrence Gridiron
categories_raw: Restaurants, American (New), Street Vendors, Nightlife, Cocktail Bars, Barbeque, Bars, Food Trucks, Southern, Food
top_reviews:
["You might ask what vegetarian has business writing a review for a primarily meat-focused food truck? Well, I have two reasons: 1 - Fried Mac and Cheese and 2 - Wilted Kale Salad. Actually make that three. 3 - Hand cut french fries with cheddar beer sauce (or poutine minus the meat). 

Why do these items stand out? Because they are not the standard salad, flavorless mac and cheese, or salty carb. These items are made with ingredients from scratch and recipes with care. The kale salad has complex flavors of mustard and balsamic vinegar, accented by mushrooms and parmesan. The generous servings of fries are thick cut and fried perfectly. And the mac and cheese, I will be honest, can be hit and miss, but never is it inedible. Where SLG really stands out is their sauces. The ketchup is not like any other ketchup, the dressing is not like something you can find in your standard restaurant, and this is why I am a SLG's most devout vegetarian customer. 

Your food might come out a little slow, and the big red headed guy might be kind of an asshole, but he's always willing to bullshit with the customers. SLG is operated by humans, not pre-processed, not pre-packaged, or off the shelf recipes, but hot, fresh, home made food - from a truck.", "I went there for the first time last Wednesday. It. Was. So. Delicious! The pulled pork blew my mind. And the presentation with my side salad was delightful and high end. For those familiar with the Boise food scene, this is a welcome addition and enhancement, filling a void I. That Fork-Bitter Creek- 10 Barrel love triangle. 

Can't wait to go back again.", "Saint Lawrence Gridiron pairs classically creative craft cocktails and comfort food with an adroitness that commands respect.

Came here with friends to celebrate their anniversary and so, of course, the first order of the evening was for celebratory cocktails. I ordered their Boulevardier, which is the fetching and always enticing cousin to the illustrious negroni. Substitute negroni's gin for bourbon and the jazz age darling of a cocktail is swirling in your glass.  A cocktail that if done well is divine, and if done poorly leaves a flavor too Campari precocious and bourbon deficient.  Fortunately, Saint Lawrence Gridiron does the Boulevardier and does it well. This spirit forward cocktail will leave your head humming and your toes tingling in the loveliest of ways.  

Next, came appetizers. Our dining companions ordered the wings while my main dining companion and I opted for the poutine.  Poutine is Idaho meets Canada in one delicious dish.  I have had ho-hum poutine and I have had exemplary. Saint Lawrence Gridiron's interpretation of the dish is by far my favorite. Fries smothered in gravy with the sharp zing of bleu cheese (instead of the more traditional cheese curds), this is not a dish to be trifled with. It was gorgeous and beyond flavorful.  A word of warning, though--it is topped with beef--so not a vegetarians delight.

For my second cocktail, I had their traditional Old Fashioned. My dining companions found SL Gridiron's Old Fashioned a little too citrus forward. For my part, I found it to be spot on perfect.  But, then again, I like a little orange zestiness in my Old Fashioned.  It was rich, lovely, and smooth as Mulberry silk.

For my main dish, I ordered their macaroni and cheese. Delicious!  It's not the most creative interpretation, but it was exactly what mac and cheese should be.  It's pasta swimming in cheesy loveliness baked in its own cast iron casserole.  What's not to like?

For dessert, my dining companion and I shared their beignets and bread pudding and weren't wowed by either.  The beignets seemed to lack substance and the bread pudding wasn't terribly memorable.  Neither were bad, mind you, but they weren't fabulous either.

The service was friendly but often lagging a bit.  We sat on the patio, which may account for that.  The patio is protected by buildings on three sides, which is nice.  And, on occasion, they show movies out there.  Get yourself a cocktail, some poutine, and enjoy the show!

Overall, a place I will definitely visit again. 

And, often.

Get to it!"]

name: Amaru Confections
categories_raw: Specialty Food, Bakeries, Chocolatiers & Shops, Gluten-Free, Food, Coffee & Tea, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Cupcakes, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Not only did they deliver another bride's cake to my friend up in McCall, but they then made one of the guests come pick up her actual cake and refused to deliver the correct one. 

Somewhere there is a wedding today where no cake will be delivered (because they aren't picking this one up either), and somehow this isn't the bakery's fault? Ridiculous. Way to add unnecessary stress to two events, and to try and act blameless.", 'Wow, talk about a lifesaver! We are throwing a bday party for my son and his closest 30 friends. Lol. My wife (god bless her) is making a huge cake and a ton of cupcakes. A few of the kids have come out as gluten free, dairy free and soy free or some combination thereof. So what do I do? I mean I can't let the kids go without some chocolaty goodness right? So I call my buddy who just married a gluten free Vegan and he said that these guys made their wedding cake and it was "F***ing delicious!"! So I called them up this morning to see if they had any gluten free, vegan chocolate cupcakes laying around and they did! They actually have a fridge stocked full of beautiful wonderful delicious cupcakes of all walks of life. 
So are these miniature cakes in cup form "f***ing delicious" I don't know and probably won't get to sample one as I only bought enough for the kiddies BUT 5 big stars for being open and so accommodating with the allergies and intolerances. 
Amber and (didn't catch her name) are beyond friendly and helpful. 
So if you find yourself in a similar situation or if like my buddy you're looking for a allergy friendly wedding cake...this is your shop!!', "To be honest, I had high hopes for Amaru. I heard wonderful things and my fiancé and I were excited to taste their wedding cakes. I set up a cake tasting appointment mid-last week, indicating that my wedding was still a little over a year out. Since my fiancé and I are paying for the entire wedding entirely ourselves, we started planning early because we didn't want all the wedding costs to pile up all at once. 

The morning of our appointment with Amaru, I received an email from the owner asking us to move our appointment to next year since cake prices will differ. Completely understandable, but my fiancé and I wanted to get a better understanding of the process, the (average) costs, and what we like/dislike. His email was friendly but it gave us the impression they were trying to dismiss us because of how far in advance we were trying to plan. I replied, indicating that we would still like to meet since we had plenty of questions.

When we arrived, the owner sat us and left to go back to his office right around the corner. He wasn't rude but he made us feel our like our appointment was unappreciated and he made us feel unwelcome. During the actual cake tasting, the decorator left but never came back. We both felt like we were not taken seriously and we kept receiving odd looks and reactions from the cake decorator. My fiancé said (and I agree), that it was as if they were dismissing us because they knew they weren't going to make any money off us that day. I completely understand business needs but what ever happened to having the customer's satisfaction and happiness in mind? I would have been happy to pay for the tasting if they would have treated us more seriously. Had today gone well, I would have considered using them for my wedding cake. However, the service was definitely disappointing and the cakes we sampled were mediocre. I'll take my money to someone who doesn't mind working with early planners. It was a disappointing experience for something that should have been a happy and exciting event. The only reason I gave them two stars instead of one is because their signature buttercream frosting was delicious. 

When we went to talk to Sugar Rush the same day, they happily said they would do a tasting and book us for a year out. We've already picked our cake out with Sugar Rush and our $500 will be going to them. I will gladly pay more for good service."]

name: Willowcreek Grill & Raw Sushi Restaurant
categories_raw: American (New), Food, Restaurants, Nightlife, Sushi Bars, American (Traditional), Sports Bars, Coffee & Tea, Bars
top_reviews:
["This is where I go when I don't want to cook, but I also want something semi healthy. This place has a good assortment of salads, sandwiches, and of course the not so healthy burgers and dinner dishes. I appreciate that they have a well thought-out salad offering, something that Boise is severely lacking in. I have had several of their salads and liked every one of them. The Southwestern salad is very filling with it's chicken and I like the dressing. Last time I was here, it was blazing hot outside and I believe their air conditioning wasn't working because it was sweltering inside. That was a bummer. I hope they got it fixed and assuming they did, this place is a solid 4 stars.", "We had some friends visiting from out of town and were looking for a nice restaurant that served a variety of dishes. Willowcreek Grill filled the bill on that count. The menu is fairly extensive so there is something for every taste.
We all ordered either sandwiches or salads. Everything arrived quickly and I could tell that the ingredients were fresh. Service was friendly.
I had the chicken broccoli feta Greek salad. Although crisp and light, the salad was rather bland. It was basically a big bed of raw broccoli, with a grilled chicken breast that had little seasoning. The feta and olives gave it an assist in the flavor department, but It relied completely on the dressing to bring all the elements together. There was also a side of garlic toast that was ice cold and had bits of raw garlic atop. 
All in all, it was a good place to meet but the meal didn't leave me with the wow factor that would otherwise keep me coming back.", 'I will return to this restaurant time and time again. 
Summer time outside dining is delightful and the beers are cold. Winter soups are warming as is the indoor fireplace. 
Friday night is clam chowder night, all food is made in house, sushi is next door if you need a change. 
I make an effort to try something new each time I go in.']

name: Barbarian Brewing Downtown Taproom
categories_raw: Nightlife, Beer Bar, Breweries, Bars, Pubs, Food
top_reviews:
["= Boise Beer Tour (self-guided) - Stop 5 (last stop) =

OK, so maybe I actually cheated a bit and visited Barbarian on my first night in Boise (stop 2.5 or so), but it was a little late, I was a little lit, and the beer I sampled was so potent that I couldn't finish it.  I decided to do a do-over on my second night while in a better...uhm, frame of mind.

First and foremost - Barbarian was fantastic! One of the best beer spots I sampled in Boise. They had a HUGE selection of interesting beers, a friendly staff (who even remembered my name from the night before), and a great local vibe. They also had a bunch of cool swag (though they were out of my t-shirt size in everything I liked). 

I opted for a 6-beer taster from light to heavy, sour to malty.  Standouts were a pale ale made w/peaches (sounded awful but was actually delicious); and their Persephone Porter.

Yet another checkmark on the list of why I should consider moving to Boise.", "There's a freaking lone wolf on their label.... I'm In merch heaven! As for the beer? The nano wolf ipa was great! 100+ IBU got me. I'll admit I was lured into the unicorn farts because it's everything I thought I would want in a beer.  Purple,  Glitter,  IPA... did you see I said glitter?!? As if glitter could be in more places in my life.  I was truly excited... but honestly it wasn't my jam.  I'm sure there are TONS of girls out there (and probably some guys) who will like the taste, but this girl loves hops.  It was more of a sour than an ipa, but I'm sure calling it an ipa gives it street cred.  It also had this weird buttery mouth feel that you get from a chardonnay.  Could it be the glitter? Either way,  not mad that I had it.  Now my insides are as sparkily as my outside.", 'Super cool place! Love the beer names and Greek mythology aspect! They have an amazing selection of beers. We did a flight and our favorite was the Persephone porter. The Little Wolf IPA was amazing as well. Very friendly staff and great swag with indoor and outdoor seating!']

name: Tony's Pizzeria Teatro
categories_raw: Restaurants, Pizza, Italian
top_reviews:
['Tony makes not only the best pizza in all of the Treasure Valley, he makes the best pizza anywhere.  Full stop.  Period.  If you search far and wide you may find pizza as good as Tony's.  Maybe.  But you won't find any better.  Ever.  I am a person not given to absolutes or hyperbole, so trust me when I tell you with certainty that Tony's pizza is penultimate!

Pizzeria Teatro was our destination dining stop as our first dinner meal on our first "should we move to Boise" tire kicking trip almost six years ago.  My husband, who is Sicilian heritage and grew up in an Italian neighborhood in Brooklyn in a household where his grandmother spoke only Italian, said "I'm home" when we walked in the door then.  We feel the same way now.  (And this is a coincidence, my hubby and Tony went to competing high schools in Brooklyn.  Although decades apart for my old'un hubby, he still considers both of them to be guys from the same neighborhood.  As New Yorkers are inclined to do, I guess.) 

No matter what pizza you choose, it will be excellent.  The same can be said for the salads.  Not to mention a wine list that is 'perfetto' for Italian fit.   And it is also the friendly service, lovely art on the walls, and great jazz classics music on the sound system that season the experience.

See my first review from 2013 if you find details helpful.  But I figured it was worth a review update as it surprises me to find how many people we talk with about superior places to eat in Boise have never heard of Tony's, including people who have lived here far longer than we (of our now five year residency.)  Tony's continues to be on our recommendation list for others for destination dining.  

Also as praise for Tony and his pizza, I share that a few weeks ago while dining at another eatery where pizza is on the menu, the owner sat down with us to ask what we thought of the pizza coming out of his kitchen.  This man, who also shares Italian heritage, said he too thought Tony's pizza was extraordinary and if Tony ever retired he was going to ask him for his pizza recipe.  "Ah", we said, "But if Tony retires the pizza would never be the same, recipe or not, because there is the hand of the pizza artist in the making of Tony's pies that makes them so deliciously special."

The only thing I would change here if I had a magic wand is the location.  Parking in this part of downtown is a bear  for anyone and in particular for me as I have MS and rely on accessible - aka complies with ADA - parking to be able to park and get out of my car and there isn't much of it in this part of downtown.  Plus, I live out in the west side wilds of Eagle.  So, if Tony ever wanted to move his pizzeria out to my side of town somewhere with a parking lot, I would be on auto-pilot for weekly dining.', 'Dinner at Tony's Pizzeria Teatro (theater in Italian) was a great choice on the night we arrived in Boise for a week's visit.  This meal was the best of the week for food excellence from start to finish. Add in vibe that made my Italian heritage, Brooklyn born and Italian neighborhood raised husband say right out loud "I'm home!" the moment we walked in the door for the ambiance and aroma.  Fantastico!  

MENU:  Includes about five salads (@ $7 - $10).  Also bout 16 Neapolitan styled pizzas (@ $13 - $15) in classic combinations as well as house specials and option to create your own from toppings listed.  Also five calzones. One dessert is offered, tiramisu ($5).

FOOD:  We shared an Arristiti salad (@$10), generous enough to serve one as a meal or to be shared as a starter.   Fresh and delicious, it included fresh mozzarella, crispy romaine and oak leaf lettuce, tomatoes, roasted marinated bell peppers, capers and Gaeta olives.  Outstanding.  

Our server brought chilled share plates to table knowing we planned to split the salad. Many restaurants miss the importance of this chilled detail for salad service. Just another element of attention to quality here.

Salads come with a generous serving of flatbread, with a kiss of garlic, rosemary, salt.

Pizzas are one size, about 15", and amply serve two. The crust is the thing in pizza and this crust is an excellent thing; thin, fired in pizza oven to brown on the bottom and chewy overall. Toppings were just right so as not to overwhelm the crust. Sauce is excellent.  Our choice of one of the house pizza specials of San Marzano tomatoes, housemade sausage, roasted garlic and spinach served piping hot from oven to table was delectable.

The tiramisu as made by Tony was just right for sweetness, using real mascarpone and easily fed two.  Save room!

VINO:  Wine list leans to Italian (as it should) with a few domestic options and has maybe three whites by glass and half a dozen reds @$6 - $7. By bottle options, about $25 - $35, also tilted to reds but also a few whites including Prosecco. Our two glasses of good red wine clocked in at only $12.50 total.  A bargain.

VIBE / SEATING:  Located downtown, right across from City Hall, yet the ambiance is neighborhood.  Brick and neutral colored walls were adorned with local art work.  Nice classic jazz and acoustic Italian music mix on the sound system set at a level to support and not compete with conversation. Narrow interior with tables, seating for maybe 15 total, positioned along the sides in a way that allowed passage through the restaurant. But it is a small space, so not a linger to chat place when other customers are waiting.  As tempting as that may be to do since Tony makes his guests feel so comfortably "at home" welcome.  Also outdoor seating for maybe 10 at tables on the sidewalk.   

SERVICE:  Efficient and friendly server who knew both the menu and wine list well enough to make recommendations.   She made us feel most welcome.

VALUE:  Salad, pizza, tiramisu, wine for two plus one espresso clocked in at only $43 before tax.

BACKSTORY:  Originally from Naples, Tony grew up in Brooklyn.  Then back to Naples then to Florida and finally landed in Boise.  Lucky is Boise that Tony has put down roots there to make his pizza!  (FYI, Gino's Ristorante in Meridian is owned by Tony's brother.)

THIS N THAT:

1) PARKING: Is a bear.  On street downtown but none in front.  Public garage next door.

2) ACCESSIBILITY: Level in and throughout with path of travel to standard height seating and a couple of tables seem to have wheelchair clearance space. Getting a wheelchair into the narrow outdoor seating area may be impossible.  Accessible loo.', "I had dinner at Tony's for a romantic date night with my true love. He knows I have a disgusting passion for pizza. Well, he sure does know the way to my heart. Tony's has perfect pizza. It tastes like it straight from a Napoli oven. The crunch, char dough glazed with delicious roma-tomato sauce calibrated under an orchestra of fresh artichokes, olives, and prosciutto. The setting is romantic. The wine was divine. I can't wait to go back. If you have a girlfriend who loves pizza, take her to Tony's; she will fall in love with you."]

name: Guru Donuts
categories_raw: Food, Donuts, Cafes, Restaurants, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Desserts, Vegan, Coffee & Tea
top_reviews:
["Congratulations Guru Donuts!  You get my blue ribbon for your amazing vegan donuts.  I've tried a LOT of vegan donuts over the years, and you, amazing bakers, have my favorite, by far.  

Everyone else: 
Definitely stop here for a DELECTABLE and creative assortment of vegan donuts.  Only about a third of the donuts here are vegan, but holy moly are they rich, moist (cannot stress this enough), and DELICIOUS. 

Quick service, virtually no wait.  A little pricey, but trust me they are worth it.  We shared the Spring Breaker (coconut cream filled, pineapple glazed, and topped with toasted coconut), a Cinnamon Swirl, a Salted Chocolate Bar, and an Alice In Wonderland (think sprinkle birthday cake crumbs).  

Again, by far the most delicious vegan donuts I've tried.

Note:  They do not have soy milk, but they do have almond and coconut milk. Lots of street parking, close walking distance to a bunch of fun little shops.", "I no longer walk in ignorance. 

My dark donut days are over.

On the wings of a particularly luscious, freshly frosted maple bar--I have found donut zen. 

I have reached donut enlightenment.

And, my people?  

Maple bars aren't even my favorite sort of donut.

Guru Donuts pairs quality with culinary inventiveness.  The result is delicious goodness that will leave you donut delighted to a level that will give you the inexplicable desire to stand up, throw your arms in the air, and shout Amen. 

I mean...how about trying a little Chai Caramel donut? Or a sea salted chocolate bar? Or, my hipster darlings--how about a deep purple posh pretty known as the Hipsterberry?  Want to kick it old school? They have one of the best old fashioned glazed cake donuts my taste buds have ever been introduced to.

It'll spin you right round, baby, right round. 

All that deliciousness and no preservatives or artificial colors.  Even all those pretty little sprinkles are dyed with fruits and vegetables. 

Well done, Guru. Well done.  

And, hey--bring the kiddos!  They even have a story time series on Tuesday mornings at 10am (and again at 10:30am).  While the kids are fed and entertained, you can have a much needed cuppa and well deserved donut.

A feast for the eyes and gleeful felicity for the tastebuds--Guru is a supremely fine beginning to any day.

Get to it!", "Guru donuts has Tasty Tales on Tuesdays at 10:00 and 10:30 AM courtesy of  Rediscovered books. There are coffee and donut specials and the kids get to enjoy fun stories while the adults can have a mini break. It's a nice excuse to eat donuts, drink coffee and chat with other parents. Indigo loves story time and highly recommends it."]

name: Boise Juice Company
categories_raw: Food, Breakfast & Brunch, Nutritionists, Vegan, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Soup, Health & Medical, Acai Bowls, Vegetarian, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Absolutely awesome Acai bowls! The perfect lunch treat for when it's hot out or you want something filling that still feels and tastes healthy.

I opted for the bowl that also had spinach in the mix and the gal at the counter was exactly right about her recommendation - it didn't have the spinach flavor at all and was a great way to sneak in greens and extra vitamins. The medium sized bowl was more than enough for an entire meal. Any more than that and I would have had to take it home and turn it into two separate meals.

Based on her recommendations it sounds like another popular bowl is the peanut butter one. I'm tempted to try that if I get a chance to come back again soon!

The only odd thing about this place is that people seem to know they have a nice big bathroom. I was here for 30 mins or so to eat and people were coming in just to use the restroom. What's even more odd is that right in front of the door there's a two-top table for people to eat. Not the best spot but considering it's a popular place to grab a bite or a smoothie, maybe it's here because they need to maximize the space. Nonetheless - very lovely space, excellent service, and clean bathroom. I used it too, ha! Had to see what the fuss was about, I guess.", "Came here for an early lunch.

I ordered their peanut butter bowl which is featured on their acai bowl menu and was not disappointed.  I wasn't feeling famished so I got the small.  Am I ever glad I did!  These bowls are seriously filling!  I think I'll only ever order a small as it was completely satisfying (I DID opt to add protein and fiber).  They are smooth, light, refreshing, and filling all at once.  Not to mention flavorful and delicious.  I highly recommend one of their bowls for breakfast or a light and lovely lunch.  

They are fast (order at the counter and they'll call you for your bowl), reasonably priced, and offer friendly service.  My dining companion and I had never been here and they were happy to review the menu with us and offer recommendations.  

This is yet another great fast food alternative on State Street (The Gyro Shack being the other!).  

Get to it!

Oh...P.S.  On the off chance you were wondering, Acai is pronounced Ah-sigh-ee.  I'm notorious for slaughtering pronunciations and so I offer this to my fellow verbal bunglers.  I've got your back...we lexical fumblers gotta stick together.", 'Imagine "breakfast in a bowl." What comes to mind?

Do you think about scrambled eggs, sausage, grits, and cheese? Maybe just a bowl of oatmeal with butter, brown sugar, apples and/or raisins perhaps? Or possibly, a pancake stack layered with hot fruit compote and smothered in syrup?

Not so with Bowl of Heaven's concoctions.

Instead, this is what you should expect.

But first, put on your Trader Joe's/Boise Co-op/Whole Foods thinking caps... Are you there? Good.

Namaste.

Now, think. It's a fruit smoothie. But no, it's blended to the consistency of ice cream without the consistency of guilt. Then add toppings like organic granola and fresh fruit, and when it all comes together (in a bowl of course), magic happens! Or in this case, heaven happens... to actually be in your bowl. And you eat it.

So now you know. Heaven is meant to be eaten. And here's the way I recommend tackling the task. 

In order for your first and subsequent experiences to be ideal, the first thing you should do is call ahead to place your order over the phone. Obviously, to shorten or avoid any wait time. Because typically, there are about two (maybe three) "master blenders" whipping up bowls, and occasionally, they get a little bum rushed. So don't be surprised if you arrive and the vibe is a bit hectic.

You bum rusher, you!

During my first visit, not knowing that I could call ahead, I did have to wait for a few minutes before someone had a moment to take my order. However, for the most part, it's not overly busy.

Also, I did have the pleasure of speaking with Kim, the owner, who is very pleasant, polite and open to feedback from her customers.

By the way, I learned from our conversation that her store is independently owned and (other than sharing the same name and branding) is a completely separate entity from the Eagle Road location. This is especially useful information when it comes to Bowl of Heaven's loyalty cards, which I highly recommend getting. It's a buy 10, and get the 11th one for free type of deal. Only good at the State Street location.

(Also, read the tips on Bowl of Heaven Cafe's Yelp business page, and learn how to get your loyalty card double-stamped.)

After all, chances are that once you try a Bowl of Heaven, you'll be loyally back for more.

I know that I will.

P.S. Yes, the location (while economically sound from a business owner's point-of-view) on State Street is a little out of place. So I encourage you to show increasing support for this locally owned business, and hopefully, Kim will be able to relocate her store to a neighborhood more consistent her offerings.']

name: Growler's Pizza Grill
categories_raw: Restaurants, Sandwiches, Burgers, Pizza
top_reviews:
['Reviewer #14 

I noticed this place while driving down Overland looking at what business have just come into the new buildings. Growler's is next to a dance studio and Chiropractors office. There is ample parking. 

Once you walk into the restaurant you see how spacious it is; however, you quickly learn that the set up of the counter, as seen in other reviews, is confusing and cramped.  You have to pull a menu off the wall and look at it. Meanwhile, people are coming in behind you and you're holding up the line. If you go to the left, people can't get to the trash can and you have to move away. If I were the owner, I would think about moving the salad bar and the register.

The menu is full of pizza, burgers, and fries. They have a salad bar, which is hard to find on a weekend or non lunch hours. As you approach the register you see that the counter is full of wood-- which goes to the bear in the woods theme. The wall behind the counter is a chalk board with the drink menu. They have all sorts of beer, wine and non alcoholic beverages to chose from. Near the counter is the entrance to the kitchen and on both sides of the door is chalk boards that tell about happy hour and the Growler merchandise that you can buy (t-shirts and hats). While placing the order you're given a number which is two pieces of wood with a number on it, keeping up with the wood them, and very unique, I liked it. 

Walking away from the counter you are given the selection of many different sitting areas. There is a very large, beautiful, table (see photos), a bar in the back with a television (sport on), a back patio with ample seating, normal tables, and lifted tables with stools. 

The salad bar-- I, personally, found it to be very good. The plate they give you is super small, but it worked for me, but I don't each much. It was smaller than a normal saucer plate. The salad bar had lettuce, spinach, carrots, beans, sliced tomatoes, bell pepper, pineapple, onion, olives, beets, Pepperoncini, pepperoni, ham, pasta, garbanzo beans, egg, cottage cheese, and a few other items I forgot. There are many dressings, which are in large pour-able containers, which makes it much easier and cleaner than ladling. There are nuts, croutons, bacon bits  and more to top your salad off with. The salad bar, as of this writing, is AYCE $9.99, one time $6.99, and add to any pizza or burger for $3.99.

Next is the soda counter. Here you can find your silverware, napkins (good quality), straws, toothpicks, ketchup, mustard, peppers, Parmesan cheese, and hot sauce. The serve Coke products and iced tea. 

On each table is a wood lazy susan with pepper and salt on them. The seats are comfortable. The food is brought to you and they have excellent customer service. 

The food-- the salad I felt was delicious. It's just the normal items and dressings, nothing that they "made" per se, but the quality and freshness of the items made it a good salad, plus they have good ranch, which to me, is a make it or break it. My dining companion got the Philly cheese-steak sandwich. He kept moaning MMM while he ate-- which is surly a sign that he enjoyed it. He enjoyed his fries, too, although they didn't look appetizing to me as they were dark and looked overcooked, but he thought that wasn't the case at all. The steak wasn't the usually thing sliced steak, it was more hamburger than steak. It came with a side of mustard-fry sauce mixture (could be off on that, but its what it looked and tasted like). 

Welcome to the neighborhood Growlers! I hope you have a long and successful relationship with the community! Best of luck! You're off to a great start!!!', "Discovered this place from a friend's referral. We attended on their 1year anniversary. The place was busy, but the service was still great. They have indoor and outdoor seating. Outdoor seating is perfect this time of year. 

We have been back twice since (literally the following day after our first time). My husband fell in love with their calzones. They are custom built is one of the best calzones I've had in a very long while. 

They have a great beer selection as well as some wine. Their salad bar is also something to not pass up. One of these days we will venture off and try some of their other menu items.. but for now, it's an amazing calzone and salad bar fix for sure.", "When there's brand new zaza on Overland, you know your boys PizzaKen and PizzaTom will have it covered. This is the second Growler's to open. First is up in McCall. I guess they must be doing pretty well if they're able to open another place here in Boise. What's with bears and pizza? I feel like a lot of pizza places have a bear or wood cabin theme? How many pizzas do you think a mama bear could eat before going into hibernation?

The interior looks a lot like one of those edgy breweries, or an incubator for startups. It's clean but welcoming. We were surprised at how many families were dining on a weeknight. We got two 12-inchers: a pepperoni and a Big Growler. The pepperoni was $13 but the Growler was $20 (pricey for a 12″). Took 15-20 mins to arrive.

-Pepperoni-
A very traditional american-styled pie. Think Flying Pie or Red Baron's. There wasn't anything super exciting about it but it was good. The ingredients were pretty fresh but no x factor.

-The Growler-
It's a meat lovers with sausage, salami, pepperoni, and jalapeno bacon. Very good. Again, not super compelling. The jalapeno bacon just tasted like bacon.

-Verdict-
This place is good but nothing really stood out about it. We had a pleasant experience and it's nice to see more pizza places open up. You can never have too much pizza in this beautiful city. We recommend this place if you like bear mascots.

3 slices out of 5"]

name: AAD Inspection
categories_raw: Home Services, Home Inspectors
top_reviews:
["The best home inspector we've ever encountered, bar none.  The inspectors are engineers with degrees, which we appreciated, and they're extremely knowledgeable.  The owner spent about ten minutes just talking with us at the inspection site, and he told us if we ever had a question about something with our new home, or if something broke and we needed advice, we could call him, 24 hours a day, for free.  We thought that was great--and unusual--service.

We've used him for home inspections twice, and though we don't plan to purchase another property any time soon, if we do, we'll call Stan again.", 'I am positively impressed with my experience with AAD Inspection Corp.

Stan and Mike (experienced home inspectors) talked me through all the issues they found with a distressed property I was interested in. They provided estimated costs to fix issues along with alternative fixes, where appropriate. They also provided tips for maintaining my home (both verbally and in the inspection report).

Mike was very generous with his time and knowledge during the actual inspection; and Stan was extremely helpful on initial and follow-up calls. I now feel that I have a good understanding of the issues that need to be addressed at the property inspected. The property was somewhat of a "black box" to me before the inspection.

I made an offer that was accepted on the property. I feel confident about my offer now that I have a better understanding of the costs involved in fixing the property.

Shanna helped me obtain radon results, which required immediate placement of the test kits, retrieval of those test kits on a Saturday, and overnight shipping, so that we could get the results on a very short time frame. Her willingness to help me with this difficult request really stands out in my mind as exceptional service. Shanna and Stan have both been reachable and replied promptly and thoroughly to my queries.

I am thankful to have met such experienced, helpful, and professional people and highly recommend AAD Inspection Corp for your inspection needs.', "3.5 Stars.  Very thorough for the most part.  I found several boilerplate items left in their report that make it clear they did not look at the item on site and did sporadic inspection on certain items such as the foundation/stem walls.  One simple item: the dryer vent was noted in the report that it terminates above the roof, when in actuality it terminates just above grade through the foundation wall.  This makes me wary of whether they inspected the entire foundation or not because they would have clearly seen the ONLY vent penetration in the foundation (our crawlspace is ventilated and therefore has no other vents through the foundation wall).  Some small items like this worry me that they didn't do a thorough inspection on some aspects of the house, but they did catch some items that i would not have thought to look for on new construction such as missing vapor barrier in the crawl space.  I would have assumed since it was new construction that all vapor barriers would have been installed, but alas they were not.  Overall: good experience. They were prompt, cordial, and able to fit our inspection in with very little advanced notice."]

name: Noodles & Company
categories_raw: American (New), Restaurants, Noodles, Comfort Food, Asian Fusion, Italian, Salad, Food, Specialty Food, Pasta Shops
top_reviews:
['56th person to Review Noodles & Company near the Boise Mall on Milwaukee St. This is my 416th Yelp review. 

My first experience with Noodles & Company was at a Yelp event at the Harley Davidson center. They had a booth and let us sample a couple of their kinds of pasta. I really enjoyed it and wanted more, yet never made it that way. After well over a year of "meaning" to try it, I did it! I met two people for lunch and we chose to sit outside on their patio facing Milwaukee St. 

I was craving pasta, yet trying to avoid carbs and I was pleasantly surprised to see that they now make their pasts with veggies, too. You can get zucchini noodles in place of the noodle! Yes!! We got the chicken curry, mac n cheese, pot stickers (6 for $5), Asian meatballs (10 for $5), and steak stroganoff. All very good. I. Want. More!

After we ordered, we were given a number and to select a seat. We chose the patio. My friend, who ordered her food before me, waited 5 additional minutes for her food to arrive. Now its counter service so the people making the food wouldn't have known we were at the same table, but it still sucked. So not docking them for this. 

What I am docking them was the cleanliness of the soda/silverware station-- kinda gross. Generally, if  the mess looked fresh or is customer caused and they're slammed kind of a way I get that, but this looked simply unclean... standing water next to the lids and behind the to-go boxes, water stains, and some dried on food. Other than this area, it would have been a 5 star great experience for me. 

I plan to eat here again soon!', "This was my first visit to Noodles & Company. We got our order to go. It was fairly busy but they did a good job of social distancing and all staff were wearing masks.
I got the Penne Rosa but substituted the any noodle cauliflower rigatoni. The pasta was tasty and had good texture. Standard portions and the price was reasonable. The food was not exceptional, hence the 4 stars. Plus I'm not crazy about the location. Next time we'll call ahead for our order to go. 
Note:  you have to ask for napkins and forks.", "How is it that a chain can be relatively good at one location and totally suck at their other locations? My husband raved about the Milwaukee street location...we went, and I have to agree! Everything we had there was wonderful! We will return! Went to the location on Eagle Road - eh. Nothing to brag about. Will not go back. And just had lunch at the new location on Broadway. I'm sick. It was disgusting. The best part of the meal: the soda machine. The worst? Pasty parmesan crusted chicken. Dirty knives wrapped in napkins. Dirty tables waiting to be bussed. Pasty and icky noodles. Garbage tastes better. For 9 bucks, I deserved a far better lunch. Will not be going back to this location. And this location kind of put me off the Milwaukee location for awhile...got to let my tummy recuperate."]

name: Press & Pony
categories_raw: Nightlife, Bars, Cocktail Bars
top_reviews:
["I recently went to the Adelmann Building for a night out. First, to The Spacebar, second to Dharma Sushi & Thai, and I thought well I'll just make it a trifecta then. Press & Pony is only about 5 feet away from where I am.

5 feet later, I did what the chalkboard said (very Alice in Wonderland) and stepped through the Baroque velvet curtains into a dimly lit room. The lighting is excruciatingly frustrating if you want to take decent pictures but really excellent for looking sultry without trying. #Effortless 

I sat at the bar where there were two dapper bartenders wearing mustaches, suspenders, and overall looking very 1920s. This matched the music which I recognized as Parov Stelar (remixed swing music from  the 20's) that was being played at a reasonable volume. 

Service was fabulous and I was never forgotten about. I had a ginger beer which was great, not sweet enough to kill a unicorn, but just right. Light from the chandelier overhead, along with the candlelight flickering off of my drink, made for nice ambiance. 

This is a fantastic place for kicking off or ending a night out. In my case, it ended a night out and I walked about 3 yards to my car. Convenience at its finest.

Pro tip: Read all the reviews, especially if you fancy an Old Fashioned. 

Another tip: Acoustics are great here so please, say nice things.  

Last tip: There is a slight feeling of uneasiness (it's an old building) but it disappears after awhile and ordering alcohol would probably help with that.", 'Maiden visit to opens at 4pm, speakeasy-style, 24"ish" seat, craft cocktail bar Press & Pony makes me think I'll rescind the bad things I've said about burger joint Boise Fry Company right next door.  How is that connected?  Because I learned the BFC owner is the financial investor for  Press & Pony.  Good on him for that.

We likely will be one and done as Press & Pony customers but it was a fun visit, great service from the bar tender, top notch preparation of Pisco Sour (for me) and a Bloody Mary (for my hubby) that included a molasses and chili salt crusted rim, all enjoyed in a well designed nod to the past space.  A hour well spent even if I did have to hoist myself up on to high seating to do it.  (And there's the rub for less than 5 stars.)

SERVICE & VIBE:  The drinks were not only delicious to taste but also beautiful to see.  Sipping them in the romantically dimly lit 1920's interior designed space while enjoying the classic music tunes of years past (think Louis Armstrong's rendition of "You can't take that away from me" or a chanteuse singing "Someone to watch over me") made me need to bite my tongue not to sing along as I sipped.  And given we were older by at least double the average age of the people who filtered in while we were there (only about seven folks at 4:30 but by our 5:30 departure on a weeknight, the place was over half full and counting) I'll betcha I'm the only person in there who would know the lyrics.  Applause to the bar tender because as much as we may have seemed to him "escapees from the home" given how much senior we were to any other of his guests, he treated us with the same good welcome and care.

HAPPY HOUR:  Specials (4p - 6p on some nights) are in the Boise mode I do not like of buy-one-get-one but that means the same person needs to order two cocktails.  My ability to drink two cocktails without it 'hurting' the next day is in my rear view mirror and my husband never does as he's the designated driver.  So for people like us a discount on a single drink would make us much more happy.  Regardless, the space was so pleasant and we had come from a real estate and building developer meeting that had left me feeling the worse about things and that pretty first Pisco sour tasted so good going I did have another.  (The coupe glass in which it was served is small after all.)  Two expertly prepared cocktails for me for only $10 was a true bargain. 

PARKING:  On street.  A lot adjacent was largely empty but couldn't tell if it was open to public or reserved by monthly pay.

ACCESSIBILITY:   Wheelchair access symbol in the window and it is level in and throughout the small space.  So it was surprising to find only high seating available at bar and banguette as that is not wheelchair accessible.  I have had MS for 4 decades, am ambulatory with great difficulty and hoisting myself up into high seating - as I did this visit - is nearly impossible so I asked about standard height seating one might assume available (and required by Civil Rights law ADA so that people of my minority might be able to equally participate with all others) given the logo and given on my next visit a "hoist" might not be at all doable.  The nice bartender told us he had a 'flip down' top at the bar that he could flip down to seat two people if standard seating was needed.

BE NOT AFRAID BEER DRINKERS!:  They had about five on tap including Crux Pilsner and Anderson Valley Bourbon Barrel Stout.

WINE DRINKERS:  I am.  But here I wouldn't.  The list is not much.  But with such great cocktails, no worries!', 'Press & Pony is the tavern equivalent to that British synth pop sensation "Just Can't Get Enough" by 80's alt-band extraordinaire Depeche Mode.

Which, is to say--they're my jam.

Not that the atmosphere is remotely 80's vintage. No...it's far more vintage than that. In fact, it borders on the antique--with its low lit copper topped bar haloed by old fashioned lanterns. Even the bartenders with their suspendered, mustachioed charm harken to a simpler time.

Which, let's face it, is just plain cool.

But, hey--atmosphere and bartender style aside--how are the drinks?

My people.  

Masterfully crafted--inventive with classic underpinning--tongue tingling ambrosia

Which, is to say--exceptional.

I have had occasion to try a few of their cocktails.  Their Old Fashioned is an ample, distinctive, luxurious delight. The Denim Blazer is the pumpkin twist to that audacious flaming phantasmagorical wonder--the Blue Blazer. Their classic Manhattan is spot on perfect.

But, where they really rocked my liquid loving socks--was with their La Manzana.  Here's the thing--I dig tequila.  But, what I've found, is that many of the upscale lounges that specialize in inventive mixology--do very little with the spirit. Vodka? Check. Gin? Check. Whiskey, Bourbon, Scotch, Rye? Check, check, check, CHECK!  The best you can hope for with tequila is some obligatory, salt-rimmed, variation of a margarita. Hey...I'm not knockin' it.  Who doesn't love a good margarita?

But, I'm always left longing for a bit more.  A cocktail that will take tequila's pithy, pronounced pungency and weave it into an alchemists dream.

La Manzana does just that. Light, lovely, and lemony, with the lush elegance of elderflowers and autumnal apples--La Manzana is silky sublime indulgence

It's just. that. good.

Beyond the atmosphere and drinks--their bartenders are incredibly knowledgable about the spirits they mix, certainly, but also about the history and evolution of alcohol. Not often do I walk away from a repartee with a bartender with recommendations to add to my "to read" list. 

In short? 

Press and Pony is the total package.

Get to it!']

name: Guang Zhou
categories_raw: Restaurants, Chinese
top_reviews:
["If you think good Chinese food is one iteration after another of fried chicken drowned in gooey sauce - like Orange Chicken or Sesame Chicken or General's Chicken - and a plate piled high with bad food including combination specials with not just rice but 'free' inedible veggie chowmein - this is a place not to be missed.  Prices are low.  So is the quality of the food.  But you get a lot of it.  So if low price and high volume for awful eats is your litmus, this will pass the test.  Otherwise, you can pass it by.

It is not often I feel 'had' by Yelp, but this time I did.  I actually made this 
strip-mall-across-the-street-from-Edwards-Theater located eatery a destination given a few glowing reviews. Don't make that mistake.  My friend Carl Y tells me the word I was looking for when I shared with him my experience here might best be captured in a phrase people of Cantonese heritage like to use: \xa0哎呀.  Sounds like Āiyā.  Expressing shock or surprise.  I could open and close with only that and this review would be shorter yet on point.

THE DRILL & THE VIBE:  Order at the counter from a menu board overhead or use a  paper menu for reference.  The nice girls at the counter will try to answer questions but don't seem to know much about Chinese food.  If you plan to eat in, take seat at formica-esque tables and chairs in front, or walk to the back for a booth.  They'll deliver food to you on real plates with forks.  Chopsticks on request.  They bus for you.  You'll enjoy (yes, I'm being facetious in choosing that verb) a Justin Bieber-ish play mix at too high volume while you eat.

THE FOOD:  Lousy, in my non-expert opinion although I did eat a lot of great Chinese food in years of working near Chinatowns in SF and NYC.  That said, all was not lost here.  The pork mu shu had lots of good, crunchy cabbage in it.  And, thank goodness, although the menu said it was served with duck sauce...really...it came with hoisin as it should...although the pancakes were more like flour tortillas than Chinese pancakes.

Our choices also included what should have been spicy dry wok green beans that were not spicy and served with way too much sweet brown sauce.  And they served perhaps the very worst tofu dish we have had anywhere.  Mapo Tofu is a Chinese classic, spicy, and when served from a skilled kitchen it is a delightful dish.  We thought it a good omen to see on the menu here.  But this was bland on every level with the cubes of tofu seemingly just tossed onto the terrible sauce and all served barely lukewarm.  Add a pile of room temperature and gloppy veggie chowmein, steamed rice shaped like a block and, well, there was a lot of food to leave behind.

Food PS: egg rolls are described on menu as filled with ground beef. If hamburger filled egg rolls aren't a clue for American-esque focused kitchen, I don't know what is.

THE LOO:  They have no bathroom.  Not only in the restaurant, but in the building in which the restaurant sits.  So to use the loo you have to walk across the plaza, into a separate building and down a long hallway to find a bathroom across from the Boise Barber College.  It is my understanding that Idaho code requires a restaurant serving food with eat-in tables to have a bathroom in the building in which it sits while take-out only places (think Papa Johns) do not.  IF this code is violated here, it is failure shared by the strip mall developer and the restaurant owner.  Regardless, it is a know before you go issue that if you need to go you have to hike to a different building. 

ACCESSIBILITY:  Once in the door, all is on one floor.  Booths are not accessible.  Tables at front are.  The parking in this newish strip mall is not compliant for ADA minimums that have been Federal Civil Rights law and State Code for 27 years.  A person using a wheelchair find it impossible to find parking that didn't require them to travel against traffic in the car lane to get from the parking spot to the door.  That is both dangerous and illegal.  That is the developer's failure, not the restaurant owners.  

OPTIONS:  You can do better than this at Yen Ching in Boise or Wok Fusion or Red Pavilion, both in Meridian.", "This place has one of the best hot and sour soup in Boise and so in spite of the sometimes hour to hour and a half delivery time, I will wait every time. Even though there is a wait, food is always hot when delivered... and we're in the north end. They are over by Edwards on Overland. It's a drive, but they have always got our order right and deliver when they say they will. 

We have ordered here a number of times, and each time we have been happy. That being said, some food is better than others. Quality food, fresh and tasty. I think that I would have given 3.5 stars if possible... but the soup is so good that it bumped it up a notch.", 'My husband and I were in the mood for Chinese food after a week of camping in the backcountry so we turned to Yelp to help us find a good restaurant. Boasting a 4-star rating, we decided to try Guang Zhou which is located near the Edwards cinema. 

We had an address and a sign was located on Overland directing us into the parking lot. We drove the whole lot with no luck and ended up having to call to get directions. We  finally arrived and saw the place was nearly empty (clue #1).    At Guang Zhou, you order and pay at the counter then sit for service (clue #2).  The  only encouragement we had was a small sign saying, "This is not fast food. We make everything fresh."  We ordered our food and found a table. 

My husband's won ton soup came out first. The broth was quite tasty but the won ton itself was a little underwhelming. Next came the entrees. The pecan chicken was decent at first but I just couldn't finish it as each bite I took, the taste worsened.  My husband's egg foo young failed the test too. The star of the show, the egg, took a backseat to the vegetables. The pork fried rice and the steamed rices were dry and lacking flavor. We were about to leave when out came our potsticker appetizers. Seriously, I had forgotten we had ordered them. Again, I was disappointed. The potsticker meat was bland. Even pouring extra sauce on them didn't help. 

The dinner wasn't a comeplete disaster though. The iced tea and Pepsi were very refreshing and the refills were timely. We also did not over eat--which is better for our waistlines. 

All in all, it was a wasted $30 and without a doubt, the worst Chinese food we've ever eaten in our lives. Panda Express and mall food court Chinese is better than Guang Zhou.

So, if you think Panda Express is stellar, you'll like Quang Zhou. For the  rest of you who know what good Chinese food is supposed to taste like,  don't waste your time or money.  

Sorry Quang Zhou. I don't like writing bad reviews but your food just did not do it for us.']

name: Whole Foods Market
categories_raw: Specialty Food, Grocery, Food, Organic Stores, Health Markets
top_reviews:
['Fabulous "Chubby Hubby" cookies at this location. Definitely suggest trying them. You won't be disappointed :) They also offer a wide variety of Agua Fresca flavors to choose from and I believe they are made fresh, in house...I recommend trying one of those too! :)

I had some of the Indian food options from the hot bar, they were not the best I've ever had but they were not bad either. They just needed a bit more spice and flavor as they were just a bit bland. The pizza was great with a decent crust and a good amount of toppings. We ordered a whole pizza with three toppings. Also, tried the jam/preserve filled tea cookies... They were yum too! The staff seemed nice and attentive and the location is clean. 

They seem to have more bulk options available than other Whole Foods locations and I saw quite a few local options in the bakery area. They also have indoor and outdoor seating. I was pleasantly surprised by this Whole Foods and its offerings.', 'We had no idea Boise had a Whole Foods until we drove by this big one, nearly a city block square in size it seemed to us and just on the cusp of downtown.  Of course we had to go in and explore.  Our first impression was that this newly opened (November 2012) Whole Foods was a good one.  The store is well stocked, well laid out and stafed by friendly people.  In particular we were taken with the artisan bread and wine selections and the multitude of choices in the oive bar.  (Some bread, olives and wine and we are good to go for a meal on some nights.)

The Whole Foods in our town, which we like a lot and shop at regularly, is a "mini me" version of most Whole Foods stores.  But it is also staffed with super friendly people and we weren't surprised to learn, after the fact of our Boise visit, that a couple of the Team Leaders at this Boise store once worked at the store in our home town. 

New discoveries for us in  Boise to take away were Noosa (a Colorado company) strawberry rhubarb yogurt and fresh Nampa ID raspberries. Our regret after getting home is we didn't have more room in our cooler for more of that yummy yogurt since our store doesn't carry it. 

If we lived in Boise we'd shop here.  Next time we visit Boise we'll be back here.

THIS N THAT:

1) PARKING:  Ample amount in private lot.  Note on your first trip in you may find the parking lot confusing as the main entry and bulk of parking is around the side from where you intuitively think it would be.

2) ACCESSIBILITY:  Great as in most Whole Food stores from parking lot through the door and throughout.  Elevator to second floor where River Room is located.', 'Nicest Whole Foods on earth. And I live by many nice locations. But this one is superb. 
Great, clean design.

Most importantly, the customers are atypical Whole Foods shoppers. Usually one finds corporate zombies after work dragging their black bagged eyes around the yogurt aisle ready to cut you off at will. Not so much here. I saw COWBOYS in here eating the hot foods in the dining area! Yes, real down to earth folks!

And the customer service was extra friendly.

Parking was easy. Nobody tried to cut me off, or swore at me on the way in.

A+ Whole Foods']

name: Blue Sky Bagels
categories_raw: Bagels, Food, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['I have to start this review off by saying that I am originally from New Jersey and can be quite the bagel snob. New Jersey and the New York City area of New York (there's a huge difference between the New York City area and the rest of New York) has some of the best bagels (not to mention pizza, delis, hot dogs and Italian food) so my standards are kind of high. So with my review of Blue Sky Bagels, I will try to take into account that to paraphrase Dorothy in "The Wizard of Oz," we aren't in New Jersey (as opposed to Dorothy not being in Kansas).

I will say that the exterior is attractive and inviting. Walking in, I found it similarly inviting and a pleasant place to grab a bagel and cream cheese. Service was relatively friendly and the pricing was fair.
