I opted for the everything bagel with the jalapeno cream cheese. I found the bagel to be ok, nothing spectacular, but nothing despicable and terrible. Again, I understand it is not New York and/or New Jersey, but I was hoping for more. Also, they were rather light on the cream cheese. In New Jersey and New York, a bagel with a schmear of cream cheese usually equals the bagel with an inch or more of the cream cheese, here they put way too little on.

Again, I understand I am not in New Jersey or New York, but I just expected a bit more. Food has crossed state lines and you should get at least a decent version if what was once a regional thing. I have found great sushi in Vegas, great Italian in Florida. I was even shocked finding good barbecue up in Jersey. I remember twenty years ago when I lived up there, we had a place that we thought was good, then I moved to the south and found out it was terrible. On my last trip home to Jersey, I found some wonderful places. Sadly, this place just did not rise above mediocrity. It wasn't bad, it just wasn't anything special.

I give it three stars (), not terrible, just not exceptionally good. If you are dying for a bagel and are by here, well, it will probably satiate that craving, but will leave you feeling a bit sad afterwards, missing the greatness that a bagel and cream cheese can be.', "I have had a few bagels in my day but these are the best! I remember many people around Boise telling me that Blue Sky had the best bagels and I would roll my eyes into my head. I thought, they are just bagels how good can they be? Well, well, well, let me tell you I am now addicted to the asiago bagel. No really, I am!

When I order a bagel to go, I dig through the day old bagels in hopes of finding a bag of asiagos to take home ($2.00). When I don't, my day feels sad. I did go out on a limb and bought parmesan day old and yup, they are good too! Someday I will try a sandwich but for now, asiago, toasted with a smear of cream cheese please!", 'Overall, this place offers mediocre food and coffee for the price they charge. My husband went to pick up breakfast for the two of us, he asked for bacon on both bagel sandwiches, and the server not only did not put bacon on either one of them, but also messed up the cream cheese flavors. Now my husband is getting heartburn from the spicy chipotle cream cheese. I called them to for speak to a manager about this and was told "one moment". They put me on hold for 3 minutes then hung up on me.  I don't think this place is ever gonna get our business back.']

name: Discovery Center of Idaho
categories_raw: Active Life, Museums, Event Planning & Services, Arts & Entertainment, Kids Activities, Venues & Event Spaces
categories: ['active life', 'museums', 'event planning & services', 'arts & entertainment', 'kids activities', 'venues & event spaces']
top_reviews:
['Exquisite creatures is a phenomenal display of the natural world. The artist has brought these marvelous creatures into balance with the people who come here. It is a remarkable collection of life on Earth displayed in a sensitive way.

Totally recommend this to all idahoans especially those with children who are curious and active.', 'Raise your hand if you've always wanted to be an Egyptologist! My fascination with King Tutankhamun (or King Tut as he is more commonly known today) started in high school when I wrote a paper about Ancient Egypt. Learning about the discovery of his tomb and gaining insights into life in Ancient Egypt and the governance of the "boy king" were all very fascinating to me. How lucky are we that we get to experience the King Tut Exhibition here in the Treasure Valley?!

King Tut was just nine years old when he became King, hence he is often referred to as a "boy king." He ruled for less than a decade; he died at age nineteen. His final resting place is small and unassuming, compared to many other burial tombs. However, it remained untouched for more than 3,000 years. In 1922, his tomb was discovered by Howard Carter and fellow archaeologist Lord Carnarvon (yes, the 5th Earl of Carnarvon who was Lord of Highclere Castle, the Castle in which the hit British period drama Downton Abbey was filmed!!!).

A critical information that needs to be pointed out is that *not* all of the objects from the exhibition are actually from King Tut's tomb. The exhibition is full of both reproductions and real Ancient Egyptian artifacts. It took ten years to develop with the help of artisans from the Pharaonic Village in Egypt and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Is there value to seeing reproductions of real artifacts? I think so. The real thing would provide a whole new experience, but reproductions of real artifacts are perhaps the next best thing especially during COVID-19.

Traveling exhibitions such as King Tut cost more to bring to the Discovery Center of Idaho (DCI), and so DCI had to raise admission prices accordingly (see their website for updated prices). Because of COVID-19, DCI implemented a couple of changes to make the experience safer for everyone, such as limiting the number of people that can get in, requiring masks for the entire visit, not accepting cash. These all made for a comfortable, enjoyable visit, though. It was not crowded, so social distancing was fairly easy to observe. Also, all of the hands-on exhibits were closed. Aside from the King Tut Exhibition, they still have the Tinker the T-Rex skeleton and genuine fossils on display as well. 

I feel like anyone could have easily breezed through the King Tut Exhibition in 15 minutes, but not me. I'm the person that reads every single word on a museum label/caption. Yep, I'm THAT friend. Haha.\xa0

Overall thoughts? If Ancient Egypt is not your thing, then visiting the Discovery Center of Idaho is probably not a good idea right now. But if you're an Ancient Egypt geek like myself, then you would enjoy the exhibit\xa0so please go and support DCI! And please wear a mask. :-)', "If you want to broaden your places to go with kids at, definitely have this as #1 on your list. Science & Engineering, this is what this place is all about & they're hands on! They change exhibits twice a year I think which is good but i would love for them to do it quarterly. My daughter started coming here when she was less than 2 & loved it! They used to have a play grocery store which was one of her fav & actually my sons too but they're gone for good which was sad!  However, there still lots of things for them to enjoy! Definitely go for a family pass though because it's worth it!"]

name: The Shed
categories_raw: Restaurants, American (Traditional), Nightlife, Bars, Wraps, Burgers, Comfort Food
top_reviews:
['"Life is uncertain. Eat dessert first." -Ernestine Ulmer

80th person to review The Shed, downtown Boise, near Ann Morrison Park and Boise State Dorms. This is my 428th review on Yelp. 

As Ulmer suggests above-- eat dessert first and here is a must! My friend and fellow Yelper, Dani S, treated us to deep-fried Oreo's at the end of our meal, which is amazingly delicious! The cookie becomes soft and the cream filling explodes with flavor as opposed to just eating, or dunking, and oreo-- interesting concept. They have only two desserts, Crème Brulee, and deep-fried Oreos. On our visit, the Crème Brulee was not set yet, which worked well for us! 

This establishment is popular, especially the nightlife. Inside has multiple sports flags such as the Oakland A's, and the now Las Vegas Raiders. There are two outdoor areas-- both front and back porch, which accommodates about 7-8 tables. 

A full bar and an averagely sized menu. The food was very good! 

I ordered the shrimp avocado cocktail-- $9.50 
The shrimp was ample, juicy, and served with a bed of lettuce with perfectly flavored cocktail sauce. The avocado was sparing. 

Nachos- $11.50 + $2.00 to add chicken-- a super large portion size meant to be shared by many. The flavors were spectacular and blended well together. The jalapenos were fresh and large in size. Onion, tomato, refried beans, guacamole, sour cream and a blend of ranch dressings. 

I tried one of my dining companions fries and they were super tasty-- she ordered a side of blueberry ketchup, which was extremely tasteful. 

The drinks-- to me, they were a little pricey at $10 a drink, and nothing too special. They do have a menu with lots of good sounding drinks, but just meh for me. My dining companion Chanda ordered a drink with fresh mint which looked beautiful. I recommend the Shed Painkiller, especially if you like Pineapple, which I do! I also ordered the spiced Paloma, which I wasn't a fan of. 

My recommendation-- GO TO THE SHED! Order dessert first, consume some drinks and enjoy your life, your friends, and yourself! Happy dining, friends.', "Some yelp turned real life friends (Greg, Chanda, George) wanted to go to The Shed for lunch. I was curious about it. Especially after my Spirit Animal Miki wrote a hilariously entertaining review about her take on the place. I had to check it out for myself. 

I ordered the cucumber salad because I planned on getting the dessert and didn't want to spoil my appetite. The cucumbers were... lets face it, I didn't actually care about the salad. 

I was only interested in conversing with my new friends and dessert. Because life's too short. The dessert I selected was by default, because the creme brûlée hadn't set yet.The only available option was the Deep Fried Oreo Cookies. 

I'm not an Oreo cookie fan. I wouldn't turn one down, I wouldn't cross the street for one, and I don't recall ever buying them on purpose. Until Sunday. Sunday I found myself left with no choice but to order them, deep fried no less.

It was the best deep fried anything I've ever had, my friends enjoyed them as well. They're pure unfiltered deep fried magic. I dream about them, I see them when I close my eyes, I can smell them if I concentrate, and my friend Greg mentioned that he can still taste them... 
They weren't crunchy, they were pillow soft and melty in the middle and the dunking sauce was a nice, although not necessary, option.

I can confidently recommend the Deep Fried Oreos! I don't believe any other Boise area restaurants have them. Get 2 baskets because 5 cookies just isn't enough! Parking is a beach and if you don't want to risk getting towed, park at Ann Morrison Park and walk over.

This is guiltless consumption of calories at its finest because there's exercise involved. You're welcome. Enjoy!", 'You know when you see a smart kid who could really go on to do extraordinary things, like identify the cure for cancer or successfully implement commercial space flight, but instead they become a meth dealer and end up in prison? That's what this place is. 

Let me explain.

The location is awesome, located in a quaint BSU neighborhood. The parking is nonexistent (what architect or counselor needs 24/7 parking AND permits? Do small businesses support each other anymore?), but we found something on the street soon enough (luckily it was after 6 so we didn't risk getting towed, especially since it the entire ordeal lasted three hours). The place itself has a really cool atmosphere, and displayed the greatest thing I've ever seen - two taxidermy ducks doing the nasty. I hope I can find that on eBay because I really need it in my bathroom (which won't wreak of urine like The Shed's did). Maybe I'll buy it at auction when this place goes out of business for treating their customers like garbage. 

So, we get there. There's maybe 10 people in the dining area. I have 8 people with me. We sit down. We order drinks. We order food. Of the 8 dishes we ordered, 5 people received them. After two hours. No, I'm not exaggerating. Of the 15 drinks we ordered, 11 were received. Of the 6 checks we requested, 4 of them were delivered and 2 of them were "comped" (that's after the waitress took my boyfriend's credit card to pay a bill and returned an empty checkbook. No receipt. No credit card. No kidding.) Well, we *were* told items were comped, until everyone left except our two friends who were finally eating the meal they ordered three hours prior. To further test their patience, they were eventually slapped a check with the formerly-declared "comped" items. Seriously?

To recap: It took 3 hours to get a portion of the food and drinks we ordered. We were told items would be comped for the terrible service. The comped items suddenly reappeared after all but two of our party left. Those two paid it because they have decency, unlike The Shed.

Most people would blame the waitress, but that's not the case here. She was brand new, didn't even know the menu, and it was the NCAA championship game (tonight). Who schedules a new waitress on what ended up being an 60+ person dining room on a huge game night where the closest divisional team to Boise was playing in a championship for the FIRST TIME EVER? 

I'm guessing it was the blonde woman with the green cardigan and sideways pony tell sitting in the corner, being completely unhelpful and drinking while she watched this one new waitress struggling to do her job. I hope she was the manager and not the owner, because her behavior towards her employees and her customers was disgusting and, at least as a manager, she can get fired. 

Good luck to this place, and to the brunette waitress tonight in the trucker hat - good on you. I'm sorry you've been cursed with such inconsiderate employers and I hope you can find a quality establishment to work at in the future that actually values you as an employee and human being.']

name: Goldy's Breakfast Bistro
categories_raw: American (Traditional), Breakfast & Brunch, Restaurants
top_reviews:
["Goldy's Breakfast Bistro is an amazing place that you truly must visit if you are in Boise.  This is located in a historic building adjacent to City Hall.  The street and sidewalk are both currently under construction, but that isn't keeping people from getting the awesome food here.  Also, be careful if you are taller - the ceilings are like 6' upstairs and you will need to duck. The staff is all super friendly and treat you like you're at home.  Everything is cooked to order in an open kitchen.  The 3 cooks on hand were all very efficient and made some killer breakfast!

I ordered a 2 egg combo.  The eggs were ok and the biscuit was just meh.  None of that matters because I ate the best corned beef hash I have ever had!  Maybe it was the fresh Idaho potatoes...but this was amazing!  The large portion of caramelized corned beef and potatoes was salty and satisfying. It was crispy and had an almost smoky taste.  My side of bacon was equally impressive, but the corned beef has stole the show.  I heard they are known for Egg Benedict - I suppose that may be good too.

If you are in town you realty should try this place!  I would wait even if it is crowded - it is that good!", "Goldy's Breakfast Bistro is everything you expect in a breakfast restaurant in downtown Boise. This popular place is crammed into a small facility often requiring a long wait. Limited street parking is available, but the local garages are an easier option. 

I was recommended to eat here by a friend, and a late Monday morning still saw a packed house. I grabbed a seat at the coffee bar and decided on biscuits and gravy. The two young women sitting next to me were eating eggs and planning stops heading to Yellowstone. The man on my left was working on his second mimosa. 

The food was excellent. My single biscuit was oversized, fluffy, and drowned in delicious sausage gravy. I opted for a side of bacon which was generous and perfectly cooked. The bottomless coffee was from a local roaster and was great. 

The decor was fun and eclectic with a partially open kitchen. Ventilation and natural light is limited due to the classic building. Like most of their fans in Boise, I really enjoyed my generous breakfast at Goldy's. They are a fun part of a growing downtown Boise and worth a stop.", "This is a terrific little, and I mean little, place.  I'm sad it's in Boise, and not next to my house in Santa Monica.  :( 

They definitely don't need any more glowing reviews, but any place that puts pots of fresh coffee on the sidewalk for the poor bastards sitting outside waiting for a table gets 5 stars in my book."]

name: Capri Restaurant
categories_raw: Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Food, Diners
top_reviews:
['What happens when your flight is delayed by 3+ hours and you don't want to go home?! You feed your cravings and treat yourself to breakfast! Capri is a ways from the Boise Airport but worth the time if you're in the mood for a greasy, old-fashioned diner meal. 

This is the original location. You can't miss the building. On top of the sign sits a big old rooster overlooking the cityscape. A large poster on the awning reads "Famous Biscuits and Gravy," so naturally that's what I ordered the moment I sat at the bar. And yes, you gotta get it Loaded (fresh baked buttermilk biscuits, country sausage gravy, topped with crispy bacon, fresh cut green onions and cheddar cheese, $8.95/half order). The food came out super quick - not that B&G ever takes long. The smell of bacon and hot gravy had my mouth watering the second it was placed in front of me. There was so much gravy. Personally, I think B&G should be more G&B. There was a generous amount of chopped bacon, which made up for the insane lack of sausage in the gravy. I wish there was a little more cheese, with how much was on my plate I wouldn't have noticed if it was there or not. The green onions were a delicious addition, albeit a bit strong, so be prepared and okay for onion breath the rest of the day. Generous portion sizes, too. I ended eating half my plate and taking the rest to my husband at home. 

The service was excellent. When I eat outside alone I like to keep to myself by reading articles on my phone and the waitstaff understood. Since I was sitting at the bar they were right there, but never once bothered me. I was in and out of Capri within 15 minutes. 10/10 would recommend and consider returning for a classic diner experience.', 'This place has been a Boise favorite for a long time. At one time, it was an outstanding value. A good breakfast for a great price.

Prices Were Raised in 2016
They raised the prices so now the average meal is $10.00 and the average tasting coffee is $2.50 per cup. Along with the new prices is slower service. The price makes the Capri like most breakfast houses around town.

I expect that I will be going to those places and not holding the Capri as a special value from now on. After all, I can get the same breakfast (or better) for the same price! The Capri is small and often you have to wait in line for a table.

Update 4/6/16
I have received two rude comments from a "Nick" in relation to this review.
FYI Nick West owns the Capri. I received other messages from patrons who critiqued the Capri. They received rude messages from Nick too.', "Update: the owner Nick pretending to be a customer has left a threatening comment on my post like many other posters below have mentioned, he apparently doesn't know you can see who owns each business at IDSOS. Im going to approve it so he can dig his own hole. 


I have eaten here for years and years, the reason why was it was a great value, the food has never been that great to be honest but it's cheap and it goes in my stomach.  Today I go in there to get food and notice they jacked their prices up at least $2 bucks a plate.  The chicken fried steak I always got was $11, this is a deep fried from freezer chicken fried steak, a small one at that $11 really, Black Bear Diner has one for $11 but it's got Capri's beat by about 4 ounces?  I'm a fair man I can understand a slight raise but someone didn't think this out, you are going to bleed out business, it's sad I'm sure the owner is kind of stuck as food prices keep climbing but that is business I guess.  

As well I understand they are trying to stay with the prices of other restaurants, but other restaurants are not connected to an old beat up hotel known for drug busts and Swat team visits.  Other restaurants have newer cleaned up décor and adequate seating space.  Other restaurants is where I will probably go from here."]

name: Record Exchange
categories_raw: Books, Mags, Music & Video, Shopping, Music & DVDs
top_reviews:
["Holy smokes this is a fantastic store! I have been to countless record stores across the county and I got to say, Boise you have a gem here! 
The Record Exchange was conveniently located 3 blocks away from the hotel I was staying and I had a few hours to kill so I walked over in the cold to check it out! I'm so happy I did!

First off the store is immaculate, for a store that has been around since the 70's the place is super clean and organized! They have everything from fun toys, to clothes (sock anyone), to books, to a cool little coffee shop, and to the good stuff the music! 

I know the store is legit cause I found a few things you don't see everywhere! Like a couple Nilsson records I did not own, a bunch of rad bootlegs, Record store day exclusives and I found Odetta sings Dylan for my pal's b-day! They also had the Christopher the Conquered album I produced so that was cool to see in the store!

The staff was great, I had fun talking to the guy working, and I told him I was from Iowa, so he wanted to show me the Idaho t-shirt that say Iowa on them, we had a laugh I spent 80 bucks and then I got a latte from the coffee shop side to end my visit! I could have spent hours in here! 
They even have a little stage for in-store performances! I must say, I can tell why this store has been here since the 70's! It was perfect! Worth a trip to Boise alone! BOOM!", "Warning: Prepare to lose yourself for at least an hour, minimum, in this treasure of a record shop. It's a deceptively big store inside. 

This place is overflowing with kitschy, humorous, and vintage gift and apparel finds.  Sock collectors, especially, will have to wipe away tears of joy as they find the trove of hilarious rare socks.  

I was happily surprised at both the quality and size of the selection of vintage vinyl.  Some great prices on some hard to rare vintage albums, and high prices on others, I found. Overall, good pricing on albums.

Service was definitely friendly, and there is a little coffee counter and a few tables for those of us that want to spend way too much time exploring here.  Employees seemed very happy to be there.  You will be too. Enjoy!", "There are two reasons why I love this place...the first, nostalgia. With all the streaming services and online music options we have nowadays, finding a spot like the Record Exchange is roughly impossible. I remember growing up going to local record shops and spending hours in them at a time, browsing through the aisles and saving up to get that new cd or guitar tab book. Now that those places are mostly extinct, it's so cool to walk into a place like this to go back in time. Though I have yet to buy an actual cd or record, I freakin LOVE all the gift shop related madness they have going on. I find myself browsing through all of THAT more than anything else. 

Now the SECOND reason I love this place? They are taking this pandemic seriously. They have a ton of things in place to keep everyone and their staff safe, from mandatory masks to hand sanitizer and ways to keep people socially distanced. I find it annoying that people have voted this place down because the RE is doing what they can to help fight the pandemic as THOSE PEOPLE are the ones who should stay home and do nothing as they are most likely to spread it...idiots. I wish ALL businesses took the pandemic this seriously so we can get out of this madness a little quicker. 

Anyway, GREAT shop with a ton of nostalgia! FUN!"]

name: Oxford Suites Boise
categories_raw: Event Planning & Services, Hotels & Travel, Hotels
top_reviews:
["I am not a stranger to Oxford Suites and have stayed at some of the locations in central California. What I love about Oxford Suites is that they are dog friendly (up to 2 pets per room, $29 per pet, per day), have a complementary evening reception with food and drinks (both alcoholic and non alcoholic) and a substantial complimentary breakfast offering. It is also nice that there is free WiFi and parking. Please note that this location has plenty of Tesla charging stations in the parking lot for those that may find this feature beneficial.

Being that I have had a great experience at previous locations, I knew I had wanted to stay at this location when visiting Boise. I made a reservation on hotels.com because they were able to offer a cheaper price per night than Oxford Suites' website. I stayed here a few nights with my husband and our little girl dog last month. Unfortunately, the evening reception still was not offered because of the pandemic so we only were able to enjoy the complementary breakfast each morning.

Our room had a microwave and small mini fridge. The bathroom was very spacious and also had both a shower and separate bath tub. This is the only hotel where I really love their body wash, shampoo and conditioner. Typically other places give you the bar soap that dries out your skin and the shampoo and conditioner also ruin your hair, which is why I always bring my own. But their products are much better quality and smell fantastic. I also like that the bathroom has liquid hand soap instead of the bar soap, which does not dry out my hands.

While staying here, we ended up using the coin operated washer and dryer, which cost $1 each. The washer and dryer can be found in the basement. There is also a little business conference room with computers available if you need to use it. If you need to print something, each guest gets the first 10 black and white prints out for free, in which you can pick up at the front desk (which was nice since I had to print out a page). With the pool and sauna, it is indoors. You can request towels at the front desk. There is also a fitness center but unfortunately was closed during this visit, because of the pandemic (as one employee had informed me when I was down in the basement looking for it).

For breakfast, at the other Oxford Suites, you are able to get an omelet made to order, in addition to getting other hot food items like sausage/ bacon, potatoes, etc (whatever is available for that day) and then other food items on your own (beverages, cereals, fruit, pastries eat). But because of the pandemic, at this location, I lined up and had to wait for an employee to ask me what items I wanted and place them on a tray going down the line.
 
During my visit, I had breakfast items that included breakfast burrito, breakfast sandwich (on a croissant), scrambled eggs, potato, bacon. The breakfast was filling and I enjoyed it (even ended up saving the breakfast burritos to consume later too since it was individually wrapped). Pancakes and waffles were also offered but I didn't choose to get any but figured I would mention these offerings for those that do like having them. Hotel guests had the option of eating their breakfast there or back in their room, which is what I ended up doing each morning.

Overall, I had a pretty good experience staying at this location and would stay here again.", "Yowza - this place is amazing!  Went here for a staycation and was beyond impressed.  The staff from start to finish of my stay were AMAZING!  Everything was very clean, updated, and spacious.  I was very impressed that they also have a steam and sauna room!  A nice perk was the evening reception, where each guest gets two free drinks (beer, wine, or soda) along with some appetizers.  

The room bathroom was one of the best I've ever been in with travertine floors, granite counter tops, and both a sizable shower AND a soaker style bathtub!  My only complaint is that the noise from surrounding rooms was louder than expected, so bring ear plugs if you are sensitive to sound while sleeping.

Overall, do yourself a favor and check this place out!  It's located next to the theater and tons of restaurants.", 'Good, but not great. I am usually a big fan of Oxford Suites. I like the large family style rooms. Lots of space for my large family to stretch out. We booked a Family king/two queen room. As you walk in the room, it is set-up as a normal double queen. A nice bathroom with separate tub, shower and toilet area. A small sink area with fridge, microwave and coffee maker. Two queen beds, couch, desk and TV. At the rear of the room, you walk through a separate door into the "master bedroom". This room had a king bed, TV and separate bathroom.

Pros - Clean, smell-free room. Lots of space. Newly built or remolded (not sue which) with fairly comfortable furniture and beds. The bathroom in the queen room side was really nice. Large counter, walk-in shower, separate toilet. It made it so more than one person could be in there at a time.

The complimentary breakfast was good with a made-to-order omelette bar.

$180.00 per night with taxes.

Cons - pillows were terrible. Small and flat. The master bathroom was small with a tub/shower combo with a shower curtain. The curtain kept sticking to me as I tried to shower, annoying! Small pedestal sink with no room for toiletries. No hooks anywhere to be found to hang towels.

The employee's were very matter-of-fact. Not overly helpful. The housekeepers walked down the hall and turned their heads away as to not make eye contact. It happened twice! There was no hotel amenity book in the room. We had no idea when or where breakfast was. No idea where the gym was. It was just odd.

The hotel seemed like it was only about 25% booked (based on the parking lot). Yet, we still got stuck on the freeway side. 

Bottom line, when i'm back in Boise, i'll try a different hotel.']

name: Bogus Basin Recreational Association Office
categories_raw: Ski Resorts, Local Services, Event Planning & Services, Nightlife, Hotels, Hotels & Travel, Community Service/Non-Profit, Child Care & Day Care, Bars
categories: ['ski resorts', 'local services', 'event planning & services', 'nightlife', 'hotels', 'hotels & travel', 'community service/non-profit', 'child care & day care', 'bars']
top_reviews:
["Our family has been coming here since the late 80's.  It's pretty much where I've spent the bulk of my skiing.

What I especially enjoy here is the unpretentious family feel and the reasonable prices for ski lift and rentals.  We always stay at the Pioneer Condos where you can literally ski in/out and viola, you're on the lift.  

The runs are great (when there's snow) and there are a variety of intermediate runs.  All this time and my brother and I just discovered the Good Enough run.  

We almost always never stay over a weekend, so during the week we have the place to ourselves and try and cram in as many runs before some lifts close at 4:15.

There's two lodges that you can chill at and enjoy a bite to eat or have a liquid lunch at the bar.

Love this place and can't wait to return.  Just hope it's not in another six years.", 'This review is based off of night skiing, I was very impressed.

I grew up skiing Jackson and Targhee since I was two. Both of the mountains are very different but my favorite out of both was Targhee. The feeling I get when skiing Bogus is the same feeling I got with Targhee. I enjoy "ma and pop" hills and although Bogus is far larger than a "ma and pop" hill it still feels small. I love it. There are some slow oldie but goody lifts while there are high speed quads. There are short runs and then there are longer runs. I am slow and I enjoy my turns so all my runs are long. :) I win!

Bogus has an older foundation. Meaning it isn't all glitzed out like that of other ski resorts. Their locker rooms and bathrooms are older, their snack bar and bar are not fancy but they are perfect and rustic.

We stopped at the upper lodge for a burger and beers and I was surprised that we could actually afford to eat. A burger was $6.50. Most resorts now are overpriced and it costs about the same amount to eat as it does for a lift ticket. Way to go Bogus, trying to keep it affordable.

Overall, I am excited to experience more of my town hill under the shiny sun. My first impression was off the charts positive. We are so lucky to have a place to take some turn. I went to Jackson's for three Aquafina waters and received $10.00 off each of our lift tickets. Great deal! Snow was great!

The lifts had music pumping and I thoroughly enjoyed the energy that was flowing through the loud speakers!', "The proximity of Bogus Basin to Boise is fantastic and the facilities are great. It's unfortunate that their business practices are, well frankly - bogus. I reserved the yurt to spend an evening watching a meteor shower with friends. I received a confirmation email that the transaction was approved and they charged my credit card $125 for the transaction. In the email - they said I would receive a separate email with a code that would allow me to open the door to the yurt. I replied and asked them to please send it as I was concerned about cell phone coverage. No reply. I never received any email from them at all. That day I went up - figuring someone at the lodge would know how to get in. There was no one at the lodge - just a phone that went to an answering machine. I left a message and was never called back. We started driving around and found a house that looked like it belonged to the caretaker - so I went up and rang the doorbell. I knew somebody was there as Ted Nugent was blaring on the stereo and I could heard loud voices inside. After 10 minutes of ringing, knocking, and shouting I finally got the attention of the caretaker. He was a nice enough dude who tried to help us out. But - he didn't even know they had a yurt and had no idea how to get in! We went up t the office and he started trying to call the Bogus Basin people to find out about the yurt while some other friends started driving around trying to find any maintenance people who knew about the yurt. They finally found one - long before the caretaker was able to do anything and were given a code. It didn't work. We then found out about the 'secret' hiding location of the key and after nearly 3 hours of trying were able to get into the yurt. Again - the yurt is nice and we had a great evening watching the stars. I sent Bogus an email about the incident and asked them to respond so that I knew they had received it. It's been a week - no reply. There are way to many recreation opportunities in Idaho to have this kind of disregard for your customers. My recommendation is to take advantage of any of them - except for this one."]

name: Woodland Empire Ale Craft
categories_raw: Breweries, Food, Nightlife, Bars
top_reviews:
["= Boise Beer Tour (self-guided) - Stop 1 =

Before I even arrived in Boise, I couldn't help notice there was a local brewery within a block of my hotel.  So on my first night in town I chose to walk over after dinner and see for myself.

The vibe was of a super-casual, local spot for those in the know; low-key and friendly. There were only a dozen or so patrons inside, and I sat at the bar to examine the posted beer list. There was a lot going on here: IPAs, stouts, porters, lagers, pilsners, saisons, and several sours; lots of interesting combos and experimental stuff. Talking to the tender, they sometimes made batches of only 5 gallons (talk about a microbrewery!) My kinda place.

I chatted with my my neighbor at the bar and it turned out he was a regular here but actually worked for another brewery in town. He just liked to come here for the innovative brews, pick up some ideas, and get away from the 'usual stuff'. The staff seemed to know him and were cool with it. My kinda place.

I got a flight of mini beers (served in old muffin tins - love that!). I wasn't wowed by the two IPAs I sampled, but I loved their Warhammer Porter-Stout and tried one experimental sour beer with cherry, cardommom & licorice, among other things. Weird and wonderful.

The place was so casual that when I was ready to go I had to remind them I hadn't payed yet, which they received with a shrug and a thanks.  Beers were cheap. My 6-beer flight plus one pint of the stout-porter was under $15. Definitely my kinda place and a must-revisit when in town again.", 'You looking for a locals brewery... this is the spot for you. The beer staff are extremely helpful and friendly. The vibe is eclectic funky brewery. Tons of seats for small groups and large.
Given it is a brewery, there are tons of tasty cold beers to enjoy.
As a plus, there is a restaurant next door that serves food to the brewey.
I would highly recommend a stop here for a beer or two for anybody.
Cheers Always!', "Some crazy innovative beers they have here! Sure they have their normal beers that will entice anyone's tastebuds....but I really appreciated the funky ingredients and favor mixtures they were trying in some of their experimental beers. I had a beer with habanero and pineapple, and another beer that tasted just like a salad (it was as weird as it sounds, but oddly good), other beers tasted like herbs and tomatoes fresh out of your garden...strange I know, but sooo fun to sample!!

The staff is amazing, they're constantly running fun events and the atmosphere is AWESOME!!! I love the look of this place. They work with a food truck too....so if you're hungry while swallowing your liquid lunch...no worries...they've have got you covered!!!"]

name: Extreme Pizza - Boise
categories_raw: Sandwiches, Restaurants, Salad, Pizza
top_reviews:
["Extreme Pizza did not disappoint. After arriving from Anchorage on an evening flight I was a tad disappointed that not more was open, not surprising for a Sunday. However Extreme Pizza was and they even delivered! I had a half and half pizza so that I could experience some variety. I enjoyed Pandora's Box & The Boar'der pizza along with a cookie to meet the delivery minimum. I was pleasantly surprised! The delivery driver was prompt and courtesy. I would recommend Extreme Pizza to anyone looking for a late night nom session.", 'Quickly becoming my favorite pizza in Boise - delivery is always prompt and friendly.  Ingredients are always fresh and pizzas are consistently good.  Is there better pizza out there?  Yes, but for a chain that delivers?  This place takes the cake.', 'This week on Pizza Ken and Pizza Tom review pizza:

EXTREME PIZZA

That's not just a declaration, that's the apparent name of the store. EXTREME!!!

How extreme was it?

I personally knew nothing about Extreme Pizza before going in on Monday to try them out. Having looked them up a bit before writing this review, I've since discovered that they're a coast-to-coast franchise that focuses on having novelty designs for their specialties.

Their atmosphere is extremely basic. An effectively forgettable half-hipster half-sporster kind of feel. I mean, a Ms. Pacman arcade sat tall underneath a small widescreen showing the latest game. To be honest, I was unsure what sort of crowd that's aiming to appeal to. But it makes me want to say a "stout-drinking" hipster would be more at home here than an "IPA-drinking" hipster. Don't take that last part to heart, though.

Our pizza had already been ordered by our friend Nathan who joined us for this week. Thanks Nate! To be honest I completely forget the name of the special, but I can remember that they had a lot of interesting and quirky names on their menu. So if you're someone who likes to make guesses at what toppings are included on pizzas named "WHAM, BAM, THANK YOU MAMMOTH" and such, you've come to the right place.

Sitting at the table, it seemed a little dingy. The table itself had that kind of plastic top that seems to create a thin coat of black goo over time. I am pretty sure the table was clean, but it was obviously pretty cheap. I didn't worry about it, but, it stuck out to me.

The pizza took about 15 - 20 minutes to arrive after Nate had ordered. Not bad. Definitely faster than some other places we've been in the last few weeks. The price on the pizz itself was $24, and I paid about $2 for my drink, so three drinks would have been $30.

Well, let's dig in:

The first thing I noticed about the pizza was that it was a Chicago-ish style. The cheese seemed to be spread on top of the toppings. Unlike other Chicago pizza, though, it didn't ring particularly thick or anything. It's unclear what sort of region this style is supposed to hail from, but it's hardly important.

-Pepperoni-
The easiest thing to notice was that there weren't many pepps. Perhaps it was because they were hidden in the cheese, but Nate actually tried to hunt through a slice and count them and he felt a bit disappointed. There wasn't much of a pepp flavor that stood out past the cheese. I don't mean to sound so negative, because actually the cheese and the sauce and the crust all came together very, very well. I could have used a few more pepps is all.

-Specialty-
This was a barbecue chicken special, recommended to Nate by the restaurant staff. BBQ sauce rather than classic red, chicken cubes were well cooked and flavorful, and onions and cilantro thrown on top. I am actually one of those people who can't stand cilantro, but, they kept it at a good ratio on the slices, and I was able to enjoy it.

The whole pizza in general had a well-baked crust, the cheeses were gooey and stretchy without overwhelming the rest of the toppings. On both, the sauce complimented and gave the slices a solid completeness.

-Verdict-
Originally, while in the store, I was inclined to give Extreme Pizza perhaps a 3 out of 5. Perhaps it was because I didn't feel the pizza lived up to the title of "extreme." The atmosphere of the place also left something to be desired, if you ask me. However, I will say that the pizza came together really well. And looking back at that long list of weird specialties, I know for a fact that I'd like to revisit and try out a few different slices.

It might not quite live up to its name, but I guess "Above Average Pizza" doesn't roll off the tongue quite as well as E X T R E M E!!!

4 extreme slices out of 5']

name: Maru Sushi
categories_raw: Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Sushi Bars, Japanese
top_reviews:
["146th person to Review Maru Sushi on Yelp. This is my 396th Yelp review. 


I think not. Sorry, I rarely give a one star, but I walked in on a Thursday. Three people in the restaurant, two eating. I sat down and within 5 minutes our order was taken. 50 minutes later, our lunch break was over, and no food. When we asked about it, we still had 4 orders before us-- it seems that they were more concerned with their to-go or delivery orders than the people sitting inside, which is unfortunate. All three of us had to go back to work with empty bellies. All afternoon, with each grumble of my GUT, reminded me that this place is SLOW. 

With that being said, there were only two people working (may have been more in the back)-- perhaps this is abnormal? One person on Sushi and the other was the waiter, order taker, cashier, hostess, and delivery bagger-- very friendly, bright smile, and humorous, however, there was no appology about the wait-- it was as if there was no problem and it was us. 

Please just note-- if you're on a time crunch don't come here.", 'In Boise, there are several great Sushi bars.... and then there is Maru Sushi!  

I could go on about their ho-hum strip-mall location, or their so-so decor..... but none of that matters!  What matters is the White Angel roll.  I will repeat this because it's that important.... White Angel roll.  Speaking of "repeat", we did just that with the White Angel roll.  Yep, "We'll take another one of those!  Please and Thank you!"  

Sorry, I got a little carried away there.  

I almost forgot about the other fantastically delicious rolls Maru Sushi made for us, including Red Samurai, Jimbo, Mike's, Miyako and Halibut rolls.  All were worthy of their own praise as well.

So, grab a friend (or three) and head over to Maru Sushi for a (subliminal message follows)
########WHITE##########################################################ANGEL################################ROLL#######################', "I was visiting a friend of mine in San Francisco when he gave me this option:  

There's two places we can go for dinner. One has dynamite food and so-so ambiance, the other serves up good food in a gorgeous setting.

Option dynamite. Every. Single. Time.

Maru Sushi is true strip mall magnificence. Is it the sexiest location in town? No. Will you ooohhh and ahhhh over mood lighting and chic stemware? No. (Though, I feel I should add, it is quite clean and overall pleasing inside)

But, my people. The food? Boom. Dynamite.

Our party of four tried a variety of rolls and every single one was amazing. There doesn't seem to be a bad order to be had at Maru Sushi. The shining star of the evening was the White Angel Roll. It's off menu, but definitely ask for it. It was the only roll our party couldn't resist ordering twice. It's light, lovely, and full of goodness (angelic?). 

The service was in a word: sublime. Our server was wonderfully attentive and kind. He gave us superb recommendations (which we absolutely asked for) and was prompt and perfect in every way. Maru Sushi may have sold me with their fresh and fabulous cuisine, but our courteous, charismatic server has ensured that I will look forward to more evenings spent in their dining room. No need to relegate yourself to takeout here. Maru Sushi is the total package.

Get to it!"]

name: Neighbor Tim's BBQ
categories_raw: Event Planning & Services, Personal Chefs, Southern, Caterers, Food Trucks, Food, Barbeque, Restaurants
top_reviews:
['There really is a nice guy named Tim (Goebel) who is owner and experienced pit master creating Texas style slow smoked meats (in custom wood burning smokers set up on site) and handcrafted sides available at drive up windows (two) at a former pizza take away kitchen kiosk turned into Neighbor Tim's (off Greenwood on Goddard across from Capitol High) where Tim illustrates being a good neighbor for the substantial sprucing up he has done to building and site along with providing picnic tables for eating near kiosk and on a well maintained lawn.  Pride of ownership and care for customers and community shine here.

WHY YOU SHOULD GO:  Great food in generous portions at good prices is a key reason to go to Neighbor Tim's.  But you might also go to support Tim because he is of the vanishing breed of "let's do what's right for employees, customers and community" business owners with a young family that include his charming wife and three adorable kids all under the age of six (I think) who took a chance on Boise by relocating his long time (since 2004) BBQ and catering biz from Santa Barbara to here to open in June 2021.  The over 100 reviews with 5 star average include happy customers in Santa Barbara days.  

MEET TIM:  Tim's delightful, downhome prose on webpage and FB page that first led us to the drive up window.

As this:  "We are a genuine Texas style BBQ team made up of a farm-boy husband and surfer-girl wife...bringing the best smoked meat product there is...to serve our guests with as much genuineness and respect as our neighbors deserve...Having been born and raised on a three generation cattle and wheat farm in South Dakota growing up, my mom and dad taught us kids to love your neighbor and to love your enemy even more. Hard work was just called work where I come from. Our food grew from the ground behind our house or we just chased it down and around the cattle pasture."

And this: "...we were raised to leave items we borrowed and places we visited in better shape than they arrived."

And this public 'thank you' to a friend who helped get the business in Boise started:  " She is a hardworking, trustworthy bulldog that gets the job done in a firm and direct order...She was the belt holding the pants of our operation up."

Is that last sentence "aaahhh..." some or what?  

Admiration for Tim first led us to the drive up window.  Appreciation for the food that keeps my hubby and me coming back.

THE FOOD:  If you read my Yelp friend Juli S.'s (6/26/21) you will have lots of good information about the eats.  I could not write it better than does she.  I will just offer brisket burnt ends are available on Wednesdays and Tim has just started offering smoked turkey breast, sliced on sandwiches and by pound, on Thursdays (go order so he'll keep this on the menu). The dee-licious German sausages (pork) on are made for him by a German specialty butcher in Nampa.  Sandwich buns come from local baker Gaston's.  Beef brisket is from a young "mom n pop" owned Idaho cattle ranch.  Pork is commodity sourced, as is so for almost all BBQ places as most consumers will not pay substantially higher price needed to source pastured pork.  Menu includes ribs, brisket, pulled pork, sausages and handcrafted (as example, no slaw out of a bag here, it starts with fresh veg) sides with prices starting at $3.50.  Menu here: https://www.neighbortimsbbq.com/menu-1

THE SERVICE:  The people at the take away windows on our visits have been young, this may be the first 'customer facing' job for some, and so friendly and efficient.  Good for them and for Tim for the training of them.  The food is expertly packed to go as well.  Order when you drive up or you can call ahead.  We did that once but not sure it matters for a small order as in for a couple or small family as you still wait in car line to pick it up. But if placing a large order be a good neighbor and call ahead.  It saves you and the people behind you in car line time and it helps Tim's crew out too.

TIPS:
*Ask for cold sides, like potato salad or slaw, to be bagged separately so they don't get hot tucked in with the hot box on the drive home.

*Special menu available to students at Capitol High across the street at lunch hour with low prices to fit into their lunch budgets.  A neighborly idea!  But heads up, you may want to avoid the peak of high school lunch hour and go for your order just before or after.

*Catering!  A number of 5 star reviews behind the Yelp filter sing the praises of Neighbor Tim's catering for events ranging from wedding receptions to birthday parties to business meetings to boat shows.

EQUAL ACCESS:  The seating set ups do not meet the requirements of ADA rules so a child in wheelchair or a parent using walker would not be able to have a seat at table to stay and eat.  Just as I can't (I have MS). Easy fixes. I hope Tim will make them.  

LOO: None.  Plan accordingly.

PARKING:  On site.', "Congrats Santa Barbara

You finally have somewhere to go, for what the rest of the world considers to be barbecue.  Nothing against Santa Maria style grilling, but comparing tri-tip to brisket is like comparing hamburger to filet minion.

I was lucky enough to try his Que on the second day of having a Santa Barbara legal trailer.  He offered up brisket, pulled pork, ribs along with beans and mac & cheese.  The smoke ring and aroma was evident on all the meats. Sauce on the side, nice and tangy.  Exactly as it should be. 

Can't wait to try him again when I'm back in town.  Hopefully the lines won't be too long!!!", 'Funny thing about food trucks or caterers is that you usually can't "Check In"   The business has an address and the address for Neighbor Tim is in the far reaches of Goleta...Unless his event is within 5 miles--no check ins.   If I could have I would have checked in three times now!

 I'm sure to his neighbors he is just Tim, the guy with the big-ass smoker parked in his driveway.   I hope he gives them free stuff if they have to smell him smoking 125 pounds of brisket at 3am.

I have enjoyed his Pulled Pork, Tri Tip, Brisket and his Chicken.  I hope sometime he is cooking ribs for an event, I bet they would be fall-off-the-bone delicious.   Every bite that I have ever enjoyed has been amazing.   As a regular visitor to Saint Louis I  know what good Barbeque tastes like and that is what Tim delivers.   Dang it Tim, would you please just open a restaurant.   Next to my house! 

In addition to the great meats his sides are wonderful.   Love the mac 'n cheese!   

But as good as Tim's food is it is only beaten by the great people he has serving it.  Always pleasant and enjoyable.']

name: Corona Village
categories_raw: Restaurants, Mexican
top_reviews:
["Great food. Plain and simple. The staff is the most personable and friendly staff I've ever experienced! They match any other mexican restaurant's coupons up to 8 dollars.", "My husband had been coming here for lunch for several years and he finally convinced me to try it out. 
I ordered 2 picadillo crunchy tacos a la carte. They were only $1.95 each! My husband got the 2 enchilada combo ( 1 cheese &1 picadillo). The combo included rice & beans. 
Our food came out promptly and the presentation was really nice.  Even my a la crate plate looked great.  The picadillo was absolutely delicious!! I was floored.  All of the toppings (meat, cheese, lettuce, taco shell) were super fresh. I tasted my husbands enchiladas and they were equally delicious.  The sauce was really good. 
The service was awesome! So many restaurants are short staffed right now and the service is lacking, but not here! The server was attentive and helpful without being intrusive.  
The have a great lunch special here that can't be beat! They also offer take out with a drive up window! It makes life so easy to be able to order authentic fresh Mexican food and have the ability to pick it up without ever getting out of the car. 
While Corona Village might not look like much from the outside, the food makes up for it!", 'I can't believe we have not tried this place yet, because it is really hard to find yummy mexican food around here. I like the combo plates with the cheese and the grease and the little bits of lettuce as garnish...that's just the kind of mexican food I CRAVE.

my parents had been here a couple weeks prior and said you have to go because you will love it! so we did!

the chips and salsa were tasty and fresh and hot. the salsa was a little spicy and very flavorful.

I ordered the 2 item combo plate with a cheese enchilada and a chile relleño. everything was so perfectly cooked and tasted authentic. I just was in heaven the entire time I was eating. I ate every single bite and then regretted it because I was so full LOL pregnancy makes you do crazy things!

my hubby got almost the same thing as me but his was a 3 item combo and he got a chimichanga as his 3rd item. it was stuffed full of "picadillo" which is just shredded pork and beef in a yummy red sauce. he really enjoyed it.

we left so full we were almost sick, but we couldn't help it...when you get good mexican food, you eat it!

we will 100% be coming back often. I have a feeling i'm going to crave it!']

name: The Wylder
categories_raw: Nightlife, Restaurants, Bars, Pizza, Cocktail Bars, Salad
top_reviews:
["The Wylder in 5: Sleek, upscale, unpretentious, justifiable hype. 

Eat here they said, it's amazing they said...
Usually when I read glowing review after glowing review about a restaurant, I don't get too excited because sometimes hype is just that. Hype. Sometimes, I am wrong. 

Fancy & Fun
Upscale joints can often lack whimsy which I completely understand. They are meant to be stylish, not for kids. However, this place surprised me. We had the choice of dining inside or on the patio, we chose the patio and we chose well. The waitress, Iris, was a delight and Indigo just loved her. Their interaction was just adorable. 

The Honey Badger (don't care, he don't give...) 
Aside from being a hilarious reference, the Honey Badger pizza had me at Italian sausage and caramelized onions. I am usually unimpressed with pizza but this one was kind of brilliant. It was unique but not in an outrageous way. The side salad was simple and fresh. We were served promptly (salad first) and everything was fantastic.

This is how Boise does classy
I am genuinely impressed with this place. The waitstaff are all professional, kind, and personable. Their pizza is high quality and worth the price. That patio is where it's at and the string lights make it fancy. The Wylder hit the trifecta of exceptional service, food, and ambiance.

It would be difficult for me to give this place less than 5 stars.

Indigos take: Can we come back tomorrow?", 'New-kid-on-the-block eatery and bar located street level at still under construction Fowler Building (5th & Broad) is new hipstah-hotspot.  Creative menu including good pizza, shareable small plates, house cocktails and SF Bay area prices.

They need to work out wobbles as kitchen seems already too busy, especially with awkward\xa0"family style" kitchen service model the owner hails as Wylder signature piece creating problems for diners.\xa0 (See below.)\xa0 Know that before you go and be prepared to be patient until processes are fine tuned and you'll be happier.\xa0 Go for good eats, crafty libations, chic décor and skilled wait staff and in spite of sardine can seating, ear splitting noise, non-existent parking, construction mess and...dare I say it?...not for everyone pizza crust. 

VIBE: Owner is CA transplant who was once director of Ops for a big restaurant group.  That background shows in thought and money invested in concept and design here. Industrial-meets-chic-bling (cool),  sardine can tight (alas) seating at standard height (hooray) tables and chairs in the dining space with high seats at bar and counter looking into open kitchen.\xa0 Unadorned tables sporting white cloth napkins and votives fit the space.\xa0 Windows on two sides keep it light.  Noise is deafening given too loud music, tight tables and high ceilings. 

MENU:  Laminated menu has food on one side and libations on the other.\xa0 (Wine list separately.)\xa0 Casual fare.\xa0 Divided into salads ($9-13), starters ($9-13), veggies ($7-8), pizzas ($14-18 @ 14") and 'plate of the day' ($17 - $30).\xa0 It works for individual meals (as most around us seemed to order) or for grazeable sharing (our preference).

EATS:  Pizzas are intended stars with about a dozen options in red or white and topped with best quality ingredients in both traditional and unique combos.\xa0 Cut into 8 pieces, they are easy to share even 4 ways.\xa0 Anyone who loves pizza knows the dough is "the thing" and it is a good thing here for chew although crust edges are too thick, puffy and white to be my thing.\xa0 Different strokes.

VALUE:  Meal for two - $60ish before tax and tip included 2 specialty  cocktails ($20) + 1 veg plate ($8) + 1 pizza ($18) + 1 dessert ($9) + 1 cup coffee specialty ($6.50).\xa0

LIBATONS:  House cocktails well priced (@$10) for quality ingredients and skilled mixology.\xa0 Wine list by bottle ranges @ $40-$125. By glass options @$9 - $13  (UPDATE 11/18:  House wine $5/glass 11:00 - 4:00.) Coffee from local company Form and Function (Update 11/18: now next door neighbor here).

SERVICE:  Alyx did a top notch job.\xa0 Clearly experienced in the craft of restaurant service, she knew the menu well to answer questions and recommend options, her demeanor was pitch perfect blend of friendly without being familiar and while clearly working her legs off all night with full house, we always felt well tended. \xa0That she enjoys working there shows. Good service can make all the difference for diners' patience and so it did here as Alyx set our expectations up-front for "family style" service model and associated food delays that evening.

"FAMILY STYLE" KITCHEN TO TABLE SERVICE IS  "NO-GO" IMHO:  "family style" here means the kitchen sends dishes out as they are completed not necessarily for serving all diners at table at same time. Examples: At table of 6 behind us, the veg dish ordered as main by one diner arrived 10 minutes before salads as main ordered by 2 others, then much longer delay before still another diner got his entrée and even more long delay before pizzas were delivered remaining 2 diners.  For couple next to us, her salad arrived nearly 20 minutes before his pizza; salad which sat to warm and wilt while waiting.\xa0 Not good for diners.  Ultimately, it won't work for the house either because tables held up by this kitchen output can't be turned to seat waiting others.

ACCESSIBILITY:  Level in from sidewalk both entrances.\xa0 All one floor.\xa0 Aisle-ways too tight for wheelchair users to get to many of the tables.  Loos are accessible.  

PARKING:  Very limited on street made worse by construction.  Gravel lot across is permit-only 'til 6p then $5.  (UPDATE 11/18:  ADA parking finally added to lot on corner and on street across from restaurant. Delay wasn't restaurant's issue but city's.)

LOCATION:  First floor of in-progress mixed-use (with apartments up) building  just a few blocks from hotels (Inn at 500 and Residence Inn) in old residential area being canniblized for commercial construction.

THIS N THAT: 
1) HAPPY HOUR:  Not now.
2) LA LOVELY LOO:  Spacious and gender neutral.  Expensive finishes like Duravit sinks, brushed brass fixtures and obscure glass front doors thru which you see shapes passing in the hall as you...ummm...perch.  Can they see you? :-)', "They deserve 4 1/2 stars... cocktails here are epic! If you want to not be disappointed, order the True Grit- it's literally the best drink I've ever had. Only downside is that they stay busy, and there's no happy hour. We ordered the Wylder Chopped salad, which is one of my new favs- salami, provolone, Crispy chickpeas and vinaigrette- easily shareable for 2 people. Summer squash noodles was good, but it's healthy, so be wanting healthy when you order. Then we had the honey badger pizza $18- it's amazing!!! Savory and sweet in one pizza. They know what they're doing. My one regret was not trying their pina colada drink.. sounds and looks amazing!"]

name: The STIL
categories_raw: Specialty Food, Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Beer, Wine & Spirits
top_reviews:
['As the ho-ho-holiday festivities surround us, indulge in the Fig-Bourbon Pecan while it is still on the seasonal menu.  Beats the "figgy pudding" of the Christmas song all to heck!  Or take the Vanilla Cream Cheese option home to pour some port (Telaya's new port release as example) over it.  All will be merry and bright!

But as good as this ice cream is (they use Idaho based Reed's dairy mix as their base so it starts from good foundation), I don't make the journey to the BoDo location given the parking is simply woeful.  And if you think regular parking in the area is lousy, try being a person with Multiple Sclerosis who relies on the city of Boise to have adequate (per now 27 year old ADA law) accessible parking (ha...ha...not) and you'll see an even bigger barrier to getting from car to the door.

Bottom line is this is good stuff ice cream and the product is so rich and flavor filled that even a small cup serving hits the spot.  I think they may have had Salt & Straw in Portland as a concept when starting this business, but having enjoyed Salt & Straw delights several times, I'd say the STIL options are perhaps even better, more approachable for all palates.  Think as in Eugene's Red Wagon.

And yes, that I know all these places products so well suggests I have an ice cream addiction.  Now if I could just park and get out of my car to get in here, STIL would join my list of those preferred providers who feed the addiction.', "Today, Indigo and I were on the town for the day. It was boutique day and we had already been to few fancy places when we remembered it was free micro scoop day for kids at the STIL. 

The STIL is what can only be described as fancy, boutique ice cream in a perfect spot for people watching. 

Indigo got a micro scoop of vanilla cream cheese ice cream, which reminded me of Haagen Dazs only creamier, which was fantastic! 

I got a micro scoop of the coconut matcha ice cream which has a coconut base. They also have another matcha flavor which has a milk base. I'm coconut and matcha crazy so this was the flavor for me! It was not too sweet, earthy from the matcha (which I believe is from Wanna Matcha) and toasty from the coconut. 

Service was friendly, they are always kind to Indigo which I appreciate, and fast. We ate our treats on the patio and enjoyed the sunny day. 

Next door, we saw the kind gentleman from Idaho Trust Bank (who earlier gave Indigo a blue piggy bank) and stopped to say goodbye on the way back to the car. She showed off her piggy (she's pig crazy) for a moment and off we went. 

It was a sweet way to end our boutique day downtown. 

If you're feeling fancy, give the STIL a try! 

Indigo gives the STIL 30 stars for decadent ice cream and a pig friendly patio.", 'So I've reviewed this place before, but I wanted to provide an update as these guys are really killing it.  I gave them 4 stars before, but completely deleted the old review (didn't simply "update review") because this place really deserves a full 5 stars, and my previous review no longer applied.

I came here on a Saturday night over Labor Day Weekend.  I'm usually impressed that this ice cream store seems to always have a line out the door, and of course a busy Saturday night was no different.  As an industrial engineer, I'm always curious to see how fast lines move and see how businesses try to efficiently move customers through the door.  So we decided to time our wait in line.  From the time we got in line (we joined the line just slightly outside of the gated patio area) to the time we paid, it took a bit over 17 minutes-- but don't let that detract you from visiting this fun place!  Some members of our group played corn hole on the patio while others held our spot in line.  It's a fun atmosphere & the wait doesn't really seem too daunting knowing you have such a tasty treat to look forward to.

Once you get up to the counter, I can see why the line takes a bit of time to get moving.  The employees are SUPER friendly & you don't feel rushed at all.  They let you sample anything you want & are extremely patient while you pick out the flavors, cups, cones, sizes, etc.  This is fabulous!  While it does make the line move more slowly, the customer service and genuine friendliness of the employees make you really feel like a valued customer.  The employees all seemed happy to be there and happy to help us pick out a flavor that we'd enjoy most. 

The ice cream itself is actually phenomenal.  I'm absolutely obsessed with "artisan" ice cream & have visited the shops of most of the big-name players in this space.  The STIL's ice cream is honestly right up there with the likes of Salt & Straw (Portland), Ample Hills (NYC), & Van Leeuwen (NYC).  The flavors are really unique to Boise and of course they have their booze-infused flavors.  (Side note: make sure you bring your ID if you want to order these!  I came a week prior without mine & wasn't allowed to order the booze flavors!)  I've been here a few times & my favorite flavors are the "Idaho Wilderness" (lavender & berries), "Ed & Carl take Reno" (honey bourbon), & "The Mad Hatter" (pistachio & mint).  The ice cream is extremely creamy and thick, almost like a custard, but doesn't leave a greasy film in your mouth like some other premium ice creams.  The flavors that have mix-ins are not overly heavy on the mix-ins-- which I love as I hate when there's more chunks than ice cream.  The ice cream sandwiches look particularly soft and delicious so I'm planning to order that next time I'm in!

As portions go, The STIL gives you a TON of ice cream for the price you pay.  I usually get the single scoop, but this time that I went I got a double, and I think I got over a pint of ice cream.  They really load up the cup & it was just a little over $5.  When the guy scooping it handed me my cup, I was amazed that the double came with so much.  Of course I ate it all though because I would never dare to throw away ice cream :)

Overall, a quality place to spend your evening with an ever higher quality ice cream to match it.  I know many places in Boise are overly hyped and whenever you see a line somewhere it's often because people are disillusioned by the atmosphere.  The STIL is different.  The ice cream actually lives up to the hype, and indeed is worth standing 17 minutes in line for.  Can't wait to go back soon!']

name: Taphouse
categories_raw: Bars, Restaurants, Pubs, Food, Gastropubs, Nightlife, Sports Bars, Beer, Wine & Spirits
top_reviews: ["Great service, minus stars for the beer. We took advantage of their flights and got Pineapple Habanero Cider, Contemporary Fashion Sour, Dominga Mimosa Sour, & Cuvée du Jongleur Sour. 2 of the 4 were disgusting where I didn't even want to shoot it like a shot; the other 2 of 4 were a little better than the nasty ones, but even those were hard to drink. Never have we ever had such a difficult time finishing a flight lol.", 'I already thought very highly of Taphouse, but they found a way to go up even higher in my book. I attribute it to a previously unknown category known as "Clutch Factor".  I was at the Egyptian attending an event and had already purchased the one theater beer I said I\'d get. It was fairly expensive and wasn\'t even a beer I was particularly fond of, but I just got it  to show my support for the venue and presenters. By the time intermission came, my theater:beer ratio was already tragically skewed. I decided to step outside and get some fresh air when I noticed Taphouse. I managed to stroll next door and get an 11.25% glass of deliciousness and a JD sidecar for a price much more favorable that the theater beer. In matter of minutes, I returned to the theater in much better spirits having restored order to my theater:beer ratio. Heck, the intermission was so long that I didn\'t even miss anything! Lucky me. Anyway, the Taphouse has great brews, wine, meals and snacks, and the prices are totally reasonable. The Taphouse has your back.', "Let me start off by saying that this was set to be a solid 4 star review. Went for a place to sit outdoors but when we got there the outdoor seating was full. Sat inside for a but and service was prompt. Soon a table opened and we moved outside. It was ridiculously noisy inside due to being a Friday night and games being on. Once outside though, the ambiance was nice and the same waitress stayed with us. There is a decent beer selection, a few strange cocktails and an okay selection of bar food.... burgers, wing, sandwiches.... and what??? Prime rib :) \n\nOur table ordered a variety, and everything was super tasty. The burgers are hearty and a good size, 12 boneless wings are huge, prime rib is a sizable cut but a little undercooked (the au ju is too peppery) and the turkey sandwich plate was stellar. At the end though a waiter came out and was down right mean, accusing us of being told not to smoke and continuing to do so. He was menacing and accusatory, then have a half hearted apology when we told him no one had said anything and that we had not all been smoking. The fact is, I was putting mine out and we were in a corner away from people. Before we moved, I'd told the waitress there were smokers. I didn't even know you can't smoke outside in Boise, my bad. I had something similar but not as bad at solid about smoking so perhaps its s city rule. However, beyond that the guy was MEAN he all but yelled at us. His voice was raised, other patrons looked our way, and he accused us as though we had intentionally broke the rules.  There was no need for the aggression and my night, after spending 60.00 was wasted. I don't have money for that! Its not often I can go out and he ruined my night. I tried to call later to speak to a manager and it was so loud that he couldn't hear me, or so he said. . . Then the phone disconnected ... how convenient!"]

name: Cloud 9 Brewery
categories_raw: American (Traditional), Burgers, Breweries, Gastropubs, Restaurants, Food
top_reviews:
['Nano brewery and brew pub with small menu of items made from mostly organic and sustainable ingredients with friendly people working there and an "all are welcome here" vibe has limited indoor seating and outdoor patio for drinking and dining in nice weather located in a strip mall in  the North End.  There were many things to like here,  Were I of the neighborhood I might make this a regular stop.  In fact on the day of my hubby's and my late lunch visit to Cloud 9 it seemed as if the fifteen or so folks who were present when we arrived and the dozen or so still present when we left who ranged in age from toddlers to septuagenarians seemed to be neighborhood folks.  We can see why this could be a convenient and welcoming gathering place for them.  But it would not necessarily be a destination place for us again.  

Here's why:

*Although the food was a good value (lunch for two plus two root beers was only about $21) and good enough in flavor it was not so good as to make us want to go back for food alone.  As example, some of the salad greens had seen fresher days but the salad dressing was delicious.  The sweet potato soup was good but not better than I can do at home. 

*We don't drink beer, so that wouldn't be our destination draw here and while their house brewed root beer was interesting enough, it was not so interesting that we'd  have it again.  It was also served too warm, nearly room temperature.

*While the servers, two on duty and one tended bar as well, were friendly the service ws so inefficient that even with arrival just before 2:00 and few orders coming out of the kitchen, it seemed folks there were mostly enjoying libations, it took well over an hour for lunch.  Much of  the time spent waiting to have our order taken and then waiting on the soup and salad and simple sandwich to come out of the kitchen.

So while we're unlikely to return ourselves as destination and not sure we'd recommend it to others as  destination, we would recommend this as convenience if you're in the neighborhood anyway.

THIS  N THAT

1) PARKING:  Ample amount in strip mall lot.

2) ACCESSIBILITY:  Level in and all on one floor.  Standard height tables line the wall.

3) MINORS:  Welcome to be seated at tables but not at bar seating.

4)  PATIO:  Seemed pretty nice to us but our server said they were improving it to add bench seating around the perimeter and replace the currently rented tables and chairs with something more hip.

5) TIMING IS EVERYTHING:  Noting some reviewers talk about packed house here, if you're looking for lots of open seating, mid afternoon, like 2:00-ish is a good time for few people.

6) GREAT NEIGHBOR:  Janjou Patisserie is right next door.  Now THAT is a destination stop!', "This lived up to the hype! We kept trying to get here and last night we stopped by. The patio was inviting and the seating was better than normal patio seating so we decided on that because of the beautiful weather. Our server was very knowledgeable of the different beers and food specials. I started out with the Salted Caramel Stout, and the wife had their malbec, which were both great. The Salted Caramel tasted like a Guinness with a fresh twist and wasn't quite as heavy. I had the classic burger and she had the Apple Pecan Salad. The food came out quick and was skillfully made. The meat and veggies were all very fresh and flavorful without having to drown it in ranch or mayo. The second beer I had was the Never Say Never IPA, which was the highlight of the evening. Very tasty for an IPA but not as hoppy as I expected. It was an beer I'd give to someone just starting out on IPAs. Went down smooth, light and refreshing. Perfect for a July evening. As an added bonus, they accidentally poured an extra one and gave it to us! So I was feeling it when I left. The wife finished with the chocolate mousse dessert which was tasty but unmemorable. The one knock I would give it would be the location, as it's right next to an Anytime Fitness and you can see people on the treadmills. 

I'm excited to go again, and since it's walking distance from my house I feel like I'll be there a lot!", "Cloud 9 is an awesome name.

And, if you order their Bleu Cheese Fries, it's not only an awesome name, it's apt.

Came here on a Thursday night for a UYE I organized where 8-10 people were expected.  They don't take reservations, so I got there a 1/2 hour early to try to get enough seating for us all.  The two servers who were working were so completely lovely and accommodating--as the place began to fill and I'm by myself hoarding a table for 8.  Seriously.  I realize in a place this small, my table saving wasn't terribly convenient and so I really appreciated their understanding.

So, having said that--I wouldn't necessarily recommend this place if you've a large group.  They've only just recently opened and word has spread quickly, as they are standing room only on most Thurs, Fri, and Sat nights.  But, my people, great energy abounds in this place.  It's a true neighborhood joint hidden in the back of the strip mall by the original Albertson's.  And, though I'm not a beer drinker, my main dining companion is a big fan of their salted caramel stout.    

Their food menu isn't expansive but what is there is quality and farm to table fresh.  Plus, not to look like a complete dork to all you beer drinkers--but their nano-brewed root beer is pretty dang fabulous.  Really!  Even for grown-ups.  

What else?

I did mention the fries drenched in creamy bleu cheese sauce and topped with bleu cheese and bacon crumbles?  And, it's ability to transport you directly to the metaphorical Cloud 9, while you sit in the literal Cloud 9?

Then, my people, I have nothing more to say.  

If bleu cheese and bacon crumbles don't sway you--nothing will!

Get to it!"]

name: Java Downtown Boise
categories_raw: American (Traditional), Restaurants, Food, Coffee & Tea
top_reviews:
["I live pretty close to this Java location, so I recently stopped in to do some studying and grab a cup of chai. It was somewhat late, and there was only one server. She was extremely friendly, and chatted with me about what I was studying. 

I ordered an soy vanilla iced chai, which was delicious. Perfectly sweet. They were out of pastries for the day, so that was a bit of a bummer. 

The atmosphere is great here, nice and cozy. There was only two or three other people there at the time, so it was nice and quiet as well. If I was a full-time student, you'd find me here a lot!", 'The bowl of soul is heaven. It's so good ("how good is it?!") that I try to avoid coming here too much so that I can enjoy the magic that is Java's Bowl of Soul. The atmosphere is so cozy and inviting, the baristas are friendly, and the drinks are top notch. I've been meaning to try a brunch meal as well, because their menu looks delicious. What a great downtown coffee spot!', "I love coming here and have been for the past 6 months.  Good coffee, good tea, great service.

And then today, the woman who took my money, counted out my change from the cash register -- she made my tea.  With her bare hands.  To be clear: she touched the filthy money and then WITHOUT PUTTING ON GLOVES OR WASHING HER HANDS, touched my tea bag.  When I told her that this was really gross at best, she told me that the hot water from my tea would kill all the germs.  I guess she is a scientist/barrista.

Anyhoo, I know this is Idaho, but there oughta be a law against touching the money and then touching the food.  Or at least a policy.  And maybe a little education for the employees, eh?

I will still come here, but I will never order tea again.  And I've soured a little on the place.  She knew it was wrong and she told me I was wrong.  Great policy."]
